headline: Public Survey Highlights Britons’ Global Ambitions
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Referendums', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Despite an election season that has seen little mention of defense and foreign policy issues, more than 60 percent of Britons surveyed believed the nation should remain a “great power.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British parliamentary elections are less than 100 days away, and they are a mess — at least five parties in a fragmented system designed for two, and absolute rule by the winner.

headline: As Ebola Ebbs in Africa, Focus Turns From Death to Life
abstract: New cases in Liberia, where streets were littered with the Ebola dead just a few months ago at the height of the epidemic, now number in the single digits, according to the World Health Organization.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Life is edging back to normal after the deadliest Ebola outbreak in history.

headline: Fire on Williamsburg Waterfront
abstract: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: The seven-alarm fire on North 11th Street began on Saturday morning.

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan Clash With Increasing Ferocity Over Disputed Land
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.
lead_paragraph: An armed conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh has escalated with deadly consequences in recent months.

headline: An Imposing Team Symbol Finds a Niche in the Hoopla
abstract: A local artist spent about $50,000 to create an enormous metal cardinal, intended as a statement about the N.F.L. and the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The N.F.L. has become a $10 billion behemoth partly through innovative marketing, but also through ruthless protection of its brand. The league, after all, has cracked down on businesses that have used the words Super Bowl in their advertising, one reason some critics called the N.F.L. the No Fun League.

headline: Sisi Blames Muslim Brotherhood for Bombings in Sinai
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Saturday declared that Egypt was “fighting the strongest secret organization of the last two centuries.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Saturday blamed the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood for bombings that killed at least 30 people in the North Sinai two days earlier, and declared that Egypt was “fighting the strongest secret organization” in the world.

headline: Tribal Loyalties Drive Jordan’s Effort to Free Pilot
abstract: A Jordanian pilot captured by the Islamic State is a member of a politically influential tribe, part of a crucial base of tribal support for the king.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — It is often said that in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan all politics is tribal.

headline: $3 Tip on a $4 Cup of Coffee? Gratuities Grow, Automatically
abstract: Increasing varieties of digital payment options are expanding when and how much people are encouraged to tip.
lead_paragraph: The flat white coffee drink was $4. A suggested tip was $3.

headline: Rose Marie McCoy, a Songwriter for Rock, Pop and Jazz Legends, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. McCoy composed or collaborated on some 850 songs, which were recorded by artists including Aretha Franklin, Bette Midler and Nat King Cole.
lead_paragraph: For a woman who composed or collaborated on some 850 songs over seven decades, Rose Marie McCoy, who died on Jan. 20 at 92, was largely unheralded, recognized only belatedly in a nationwide radio documentary.

headline: Sip the Light Fantastic
abstract: There is no shortage of teahouses in Connecticut offering an authentic English-style experience, but the some parlors excel at serving high-grade teas in combination with traditional foods.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything more civilized than afternoon tea? The relaxing tradition of sipping tea while nibbling on sandwiches and sweets began in Britain, but one need not fly to London to enjoy it. There is no shortage of teahouses in Connecticut offering an authentic English-style experience, but the three parlors listed here excel at serving high-grade teas in combination with traditional foods.

headline: Canadian Upsets Olympic Medalist in Winning 2 Races
abstract: Cam Levins was the star of the Armory Track Invitational in Manhattan, pulling off a stunning double win in the one-mile and two-mile races and beating the Olympic silver medalist Galen Rupp in completing the feat.
lead_paragraph: Like Samson, Cam Levins figures his hair is the source of his prowess.

headline: At Polich Tallix Fine Art Foundry, Master of Metals Is Artists’ Ally
abstract: Since he opened his first art foundry in the late 1960s, Dick Polich has helped produce sculptures for 500 artists, including Louise Bourgeois, Alexander Calder, Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, the sculptor Rona Pondick arrived at Dick Polich’s foundry with some challenging goals. She was working on her now-famous animal-human hybrids and was interested in new ways of incorporating color in stainless steel. She recently recalled explaining her project to Mr. Polich: “He told me, ‘You’re trying to push the envelope, and I’ll go there with you.’ And then he said, ‘And while I’m going there with you, can I show you a few things I’m playing around with?’ ”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 31, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: At This Party, You’d Better Keep It Down
abstract: Inmates at the Maricopa County Jail in Arizona will be allowed to watch the Super Bowl on television, but Sheriff Joe Arpaio still has strict rules.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When the Super Bowl begins Sunday, 70,000 fans will ease into their seats and suites at University of Phoenix Stadium, munch on hot dogs and pizza, and wash them down with soda and beer.

headline: At 32, Phoenix Open Leader Seems Ancient
abstract: After 54 holes, the top 16, led by Martin Laird, includes a cluster of young players who grew up idolizing Tiger Woods, 39, who missed the cut for the tournament.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Pity the old-timers on the PGA Tour, who have seen their workplace overrun by trophy kids. The millennials, a group that includes Jordan Spieth, Daniel Berger and Justin Thomas, do not hew to the stereotype of the entitled, high-maintenance employee. They deserve the praise lavished on them, they do not have padded résumés and they are respectful, addressing anyone over the age of 25 as “Mister.”

headline: Inspired by N.F.L., Art Imitating Sport
abstract: Michael Levine, a preservationist and artist based in Arizona, wanted to show the N.F.L. a new way to market its product, so he made an enormous metal cardinal as a tribute to Phoenix’s hometown team.
lead_paragraph: Michael Levine, a preservationist and artist based in Arizona, wanted to show the N.F.L. a new way to market its product, so he made an enormous metal cardinal as a tribute to Phoenix’s hometown team.

headline: Rory McIlroy Widens Lead in Dubai
abstract: McIlroy extended his lead to four shots with a 6-under 66 on Saturday in the third round of the Dubai Desert Classic in the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: Rory McIlroy extended his lead to four shots with a 6-under 66 on Saturday in the third round of the Dubai Desert Classic in the United Arab Emirates.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 1, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 1, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Fundamentally, this is about the extent to which societies change their behaviors, how they change them, and the speed at which they change them.”

headline: To Jets’ Geno Smith, 2015 Isn’t His Last Chance, but It’s Vital
abstract: Geno Smith, talking with reporters at a team event, said he looked forward to meeting Coach Todd Bowles and working under the new offensive coordinator, Chan Gailey.
lead_paragraph: Geno Smith, meeting with reporters Saturday for the first time since the Jets overhauled their front office and coaching staff, sounded like someone who realizes time may be growing short for him to prove himself as a starting quarterback.

headline: Hardhanded Judge Is Picked for American Reporter’s Trial in Iran, Rights Group Says
abstract: A judge in Iran with a reputation for imposing harsh sentences has been selected for the trial of Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post, human rights campaigners say.
lead_paragraph: A Revolutionary Court judge in Iran with a reputation for imposing harsh sentences has been selected to preside in the trial of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated for more than six months on unspecified charges, a human rights advocacy group said Saturday.

headline: Alexandra Corsi and Ian Lambert
abstract: The couple were wed at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Corsi and Ian Paul Lambert were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Bruce C. Page, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Hugh Eastwood and John Holmes III
abstract: The couple were married at their home in Ladue, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Athelstan Eastwood and John Arthur Holmes III were married Friday at their home in Ladue, Mo. Jean C. Hamilton, a senior United States District judge for the Eastern District of Missouri, officiated.

headline: Mimi Hoesley and Benjamin Slater IV
abstract: The couple were married at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Drews Hoesley and Benjamin Richard Slater IV were married Saturday at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Henry L. Hudson, the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: From the Idea of a Germ
abstract: When a future infectious disease doctor meets a self-professed germaphobe, he decides to try anyway.
lead_paragraph: Injy Artense Carpenter and Dr. Timothy Francis Nichols Sullivan were married Saturday evening at India House, a private club in Manhattan. The Rev. Lissa Gundlach, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Christopher Lesisko and Albert Pfeiffer
abstract: The couple were married at the First Unitarian Church of Orlando in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Alan Lesisko and Albert Pfeiffer were married Saturday at the First Unitarian Church of Orlando in Florida. The Rev. Marni Harmony, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Shifting Gears, Incrementally
abstract: Going from schoolmates to roommates to life mates.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Marcus and Thomas Clinton Greulich were married Saturday at the Stowe Mountain Lodge in Stowe, Vt. Annie Alexander-Kramer, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, led a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions and Episcopal vows.

headline: Top Sundance Prizes Go to ‘Me and Earl and the Dying Girl’
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Festivals', 'Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: The whimsical tearjerker that rode a crescendo of buzz after screening in Park City last week claimed top prizes at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival awards on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: The whimsical “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl,” a film that rode a crescendo of buzz after screening in Park City last month, claimed top prizes at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival awards on Saturday night. It was named the U.S. Dramatic Grand Jury Prize winner, and also won the U.S. dramatic audience award.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (NBC) SUPER BOWL XLIX The New England Patriots face off against the Seattle Seahawks at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz. Al Michaels provides play-by-play commentary; Cris Collinsworth is the analyst; and Michele Tafoya reports from the sidelines. Kickoff is at 6:30. Katy Perry, above, will take the stage at halftime, with Lenny Kravitz and Missy Elliott as special guests; Idina Menzel will perform the national anthem; and John Legend will sing “America the Beautiful.” Bob Costas will host the pregame show, starting at noon, featuring commentary and analysis; visits to the teams’ hotels; an interview with Ms. Perry by Josh Elliott; celebrity reports by the figure skaters Johnny Wier and Tara Lipinski; a stop at the official tailgate party; and an interview with President Obama by Savannah Guthrie.

headline: Corrections: February 1, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, February 1, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Amanda Mason and Richard Moseley
abstract: The couple was married at the Chestnut Hill Friends Meeting House in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Marie Mason and Richard Duraunde Moseley were married Saturday at the Chestnut Hill Friends Meeting House in Philadelphia. The Rev. Callie Swanlund, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: A Rout, and a Resurrection
abstract: Rounding up old cast members, a producer hopes to reverse the ill fortunes of the 1991 film “Shuttlecock” with added scenes and a new title, “Sins of a Father.”
lead_paragraph: Nearly 25 years ago, the producer Graham Leader made a film called “Shuttlecock.” Alan Bates had the starring role, as a British spy during World War II whose secrets inflict psychic damage on his son. The film opened the San Sebastián Film Festival in Spain in 1991 and was broadcast once on Channel 4 in Britain and on Canal Plus in France, where it had a brief theatrical release. It never found a distributor, however, and sank without a trace.

headline: Protesters Once Again Fill Streets in Hong Kong
abstract: The rally was much milder than the “Occupy” protests that ended in mid-December, and fell well short of the 50,000 participants that organizers had promised.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy protesters streamed through the heart of Hong Kong on Sunday in their first sizable show of strength since the police cleared occupations that blocked streets for 11 weeks late last year.

headline: 1940: Mabel Boll, “Queen of Diamonds,” Weds No. 3
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Manhattan socialite weds for the third time in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Fort Lauderdale, Fla. — Mabel Boll, one-time sales girl in a cigar store, who became known as ‘‘Queen of Diamonds,’’ has married again and husband No. 3 is Theodore Cella, thirty-nine-year-old harpist and assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. From her humble beginning in Rochester, N.Y., as a dispenser of stogies and Colorado Claros the blue-eyed blonde Mibsey Bach, the daughter of a bartender, as she was then known, suddenly found herself in luxury as the wife of a wealthy Colombian.

headline: Blues and Hip-Hop Meet at the Hands of a Power Guitarist
abstract: Q-Tip, from A Tribe Called Quest, shared the stage with Mr. White, who refuses to be a throwback.
lead_paragraph: Feedback erupted time and again as Jack White headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night. It was no accident; Mr. White’s music hangs on the edge of overload, and the feedback only proves it. The occasional electronic screeches were part of his joyful assault; so were the quivering whoop in his voice and the way his guitar solos rushed way up high and stayed there, to zoom around or wriggle and wail. And so was the flat-out bashing of the band’s drummer, Daru Jones, who often stood up to provide extra wallop.

headline: Learning the Language in Wales
abstract: Chateau Rhianfa in Wales is offering guests courses taught by a local language expert.
lead_paragraph: Chateau Rhianfa, on the Isle of Anglesey in Wales, is offering guests the chance to test their linguistic abilities by learning how to pronounce Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch — the longest place name in Europe — among other words and phrases.

headline: Novak Djokovic Leaves Andy Murray Crushed in Reprise at Australian Open
abstract: After a scintillating start to the men’s final, Djokovic cruised in the final two sets to defeat Murray and claim a fifth title in Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Huffing and stretching with full-throttle effort, ripping forehands from inside the baseline, Andy Murray for quite some time seemed to be a player on a mission to impose a new ending for himself at the Australian Open.

headline: Hostage’s Apparent Beheading by ISIS Stirs Outrage in Japan
abstract: After the Islamic State posted a video claiming to show the killing of the journalist Kenji Goto, the public has remained supportive of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s stand against Mr. Goto’s kidnappers.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan reacted with sorrow and outrage on Sunday to the posting by the Islamic State of a video purporting to show the grisly killing of the journalist Kenji Goto, bringing an end to a hostage standoff that has horrified this usually tranquil nation.

headline: Home Schooling, and Teaching, a Child with Down Syndrome
abstract: In school, nothing our son did was seen as typical. At home, I’m able to see him as more than a diagnosis, and he’s able to learn.
lead_paragraph: This past September we started home schooling. Before that our son, who has Down syndrome, attended public school in a regular classroom setting — often referred to as inclusion — at our request. After two years we realized school was hindering his education.

headline: An Overnight Stay at Hotel 22
abstract: A bus route in Silicon Valley has become a well-known overnight shelter for the homeless. The video journalist Elizabeth Lo rode Line 22, documenting its many patrons throughout the night.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley, one of the most expensive places to live in America, is also one of the toughest places for the homeless to survive. As the tech boom prompted property values to skyrocket, some of the city’s poorest residents have been displaced, with limited options for affordable housing. In this Op-Doc video, Elizabeth Lo documents scenes from a bus route that has become a well-known overnight shelter for the area’s homeless.

headline: A Month of Puzzle Love
abstract: Welcome to the February 2015 Times Insider crossword puzzle pack.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — Even in the coldest, darkest part of winter, we have cause to celebrate. The Super Bowl, President’s Day, Valentine’s Day, the Chinese New Year and many more holidays help us shake off the winter doldrums.

headline: Floor Waxes, Dessert Toppings, and Blogging
abstract: Blogging is dead, long live blogging.
lead_paragraph: I see from Ezra Klein that Andrew Sullivan says that he’s stopping blogging; Klein and others are offering various encomiums. You’ll pardon me if I don’t join in. You see, I remember Sullivan declaring that the “decadent left” was poised to become a fifth column in the war on terror — and of course I remember the campaign of character assassination he waged against yours truly for daring to criticize his then-beloved George W. Bush and his wars. If he ever apologized for any of that, I never heard about it.

headline: The Disappearance of Alan Simpson
abstract: Bowles what?
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago Alan Simpson bestrode Washington like a colossus — a rambling, cranky, potty-mouthed colossus. As Ezra Klein noted, reporters didn’t treat him as an ordinary public figure, but rather as the voice of obvious responsibility, on whose behalf the ordinary rules of press neutrality didn’t apply. And his pronouncements — like his early 2011 declaration that we faced fiscal crisis within two years — received breathless coverage.

headline: London Theater Journal: Laughing Wall to Wall
abstract: In just a few days Ben Brantley sampled a rainbow spectrum of comedies, “My Night With Reg,” “The Play That Goes Wrong,” “The Ruling Class” and “Golem.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Comedy comes in many shades, from jet black to shocking pink. In a rare moment of giddy confluence, the theaters here seem to have the whole rainbow on display.

headline: Fire at a Brooklyn Warehouse Puts Private Lives on Display
abstract: The blaze sent soaring flames and choking clouds of smoke into the air along the East River and disgorged as-yet-uncounted scraps of paper, including medical and court records, into the streets.
lead_paragraph: No lives were lost in the huge fire that gutted a storage building on the Brooklyn waterfront over the weekend. But the flames put plenty of lives on display as the crumpling warehouse belched up its contents: decades’ worth of charred medical records, court transcripts, lawyers’ letters, sonograms, bank checks and more.

headline: Egypt Deports Peter Greste, Journalist Jailed With 2 Al Jazeera Colleagues
abstract: Peter Greste was jailed for more than a year in a case that had been criticized by human rights groups. Two other journalists in the same case remain in prison.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian authorities have deported an Australian television journalist jailed for more than a year on politicized charges about the content of his work.

headline: 1965: Dr. King, 300 Negroes Arrested in Selma
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Dr. King is arrested during protest after receiving Nobel Peace prize in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — Civil-rights leader the Rev. Martin Luther King jr., was arrested today [Feb. 1] while attempting to lead a mass march of 300 Negroes on the Dallas county courthouse to protest voter-registration procedures. The Negroes, who were walking en masse from a church, were taken into custody on orders from Selma’s Public Safety Director Wilson Baker on charges of parading without a permit. Mr. Baker stopped the procession near the church, where the Negroes had assembled. He told them: ‘‘Each and every one of you is under arrest for parading without a permit.’’ After an hour of waiting in the jail, Dr. King was released without charges filed against him. But he was quickly rearrested when he did not obey an officer’s orders to leave the scene. This was the first time he has been arrested since he received the Nobel Peace prize last month. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 2, 1965

headline: Obama’s Plans for Deficit and Taxes Are Detailed on Eve of Budget Proposal
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: The central question posed by the 10-year budget is this: Should Washington worry about the rising gap between the rich and everyone else, or address a mountain of debt?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will propose a 10-year budget on Monday that stabilizes the federal deficit but does not seek balance, instead focusing on policies to address income inequality as he adds nearly $6 trillion to the debt.

headline: Ties Between India and the U.S. Deepen
abstract: Where does that leave China?
lead_paragraph: Where does that leave China?

headline: Do-It-Yourself Orthodonture: Don’t Try This at Home
abstract: Orthodontists warn that D.I.Y. teeth straightening or gap closing is not only foolish, it can lead to permanent loss of teeth.
lead_paragraph: Jamila Garza, 24, from Everett, Wash., has made no less than nine YouTube videos enthusiastically describing how she closed a gap between front teeth with $5 elastic bands. Ms. Garza is not a dental professional. Until recently, she was a fashion design student.

headline: Straighter Teeth by Mail
abstract: Some people who want to straighten their teeth for much less money are using a kit to make dental impressions and sending them back to companies that will provide their aligners. Critics say this process overlooks oral health issues.
lead_paragraph: When John Hofford, a 27-year-old digital media specialist, wanted to straighten his teeth, he wanted invisible plastic aligners that would correct his crowding, instead of conspicuous metal braces. But he couldn’t afford the clear aligners sold at his local orthodontist in Atlanta.

headline: A Job Filled With Forecasts That’s Unpredictable by Nature
abstract: Everybody likes to talk about the weather, but meteorologists are expected to do it with unassailable certainty. Recent events show that is not always possible.
lead_paragraph: The meteorologist Steven DiMartino signed off Twitter at 11 p.m. last Monday, warning his followers that “intense heavy snow is approaching.” After 20 hours of blizzard-tracking for clients who pay him to predict how the weather will affect their travel, families and businesses, he finally took a nap in his chair.

headline: Even on Super Bowl Weekend, ‘American Sniper’ Wins
abstract: “American Sniper” topped the domestic movie box office, with an estimated $31.9 million in sales during its sixth weekend in theaters and third weekend in wide release.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Even the Super Bowl couldn’t crowd out Clint Eastwood’s “American Sniper,” which again topped the domestic movie box office, with an estimated $31.9 million in sales during its sixth weekend in theaters and third weekend in wide release. The strong haul — a record for any film during Super Bowl weekend, if the estimates hold — pushed total domestic sales for the reality-based Iraq war story to about $249 million.

headline: The Reconstruction Wars Begin
abstract: Before the Civil War even ended, Northerners were at odds over what post-Emancipation America should look like.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 26, 1865, the Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society convened inside Boston’s Melodeon Theater, a mainstay of the city’s cultural, religious and civic life, for its annual meeting. A break from frigid temperatures and heavy snow led to high attendance. The Congregationalist minister Theodore Parker had often offered sermons at the Melodeon. In 1850, the antislavery Parker called for democracy “of all the people, by all the people, and for all the people.” After 30 years of labor, abolitionists now believed that they were in a position to push not only for the final destruction of slavery, but also for a new definition of who made up the “people.” With the bloody Civil War coming to a close, the future of the abolitionist cause, according to the Boston Brahmin Wendell Phillips, was inextricably linked to Reconstruction.

headline: In Liberated Kobani, Kurds Take Pride Despite the Devastation
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Among the Kurds of the Syrian border town, pride in victory outweighs grief over losses, even amid the destruction wrought by an Islamic State siege.
lead_paragraph: KOBANI, Syria — Lasheen Abdulla steered her white minivan through the streets of her hometown, past the charred husks of bombed cars, the shattered storefronts, the unexploded mortar shells. Across the gray of destruction were streaks of color: the purple sheets hung to hide the Kurdish snipers who, for months, defended this city from the extremists of the Islamic State.

headline: Scenes of Devastation in Kobani
abstract: The destruction in Kobani, Syria, wrought by an Islamic State siege and the American-led air campaign, is so thorough that it manages to feel unreal.
lead_paragraph: The destruction in Kobani, Syria, wrought by an Islamic State siege and the American-led air campaign, is so thorough that it manages to feel unreal.

headline: Cement Makers Holcim and Lafarge to Sell Assets to CRH of Ireland for $7.3 Billion
abstract: The deal is meant to help Lafarge and Holcim satisfy requirements by antitrust officials as they seek to close their own merger.
lead_paragraph: The European cement makers Lafarge and Holcim agreed on Sunday to sell assets to CRH plc, an Irish manufacturer of building materials, for about $7.3 billion to help pave the way for their own merger.

headline: Christie Returns to Good Old London; London Says, ‘Who?’
abstract: Interviews with soccer fans revealed that few were aware of Gov. Chris Christie’s attendance at the Arsenal vs. Aston Villa game, or even who he was.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Presidential politics can be a humbling business. Local renown is revealed, uneasily, to be just that: It translates poorly onto a bigger stage, allowing a man accustomed to instant, cellphone-picture-frenzied celebrity on the boardwalks of the New Jersey shore to stroll in awkward anonymity through a packed stadium in London.

headline: Fire at Library in Moscow Destroys Millions of Volumes
abstract: A major fire that threatened to consume one of Russia’s most important libraries was finally put out late Saturday, but scholars are only beginning to assess the damage from the flames, smoke and water.
lead_paragraph: A major fire that threatened to consume one of Russia’s most important libraries was finally put out late Saturday, but scholars are only beginning to assess the damage from the flames, smoke and water.

headline: A Question Over the Reach of Europe’s ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
abstract: A man’s victory in a Paris court could set a precedent that Europe’s “right to be forgotten” ruling should apply far more broadly than originally understood.
lead_paragraph: Dan Shefet doesn’t want you to Google his name.

headline: A Bach Interpretation Springs to Life
abstract: Jennifer Koh displayed an allusive breadth of sound and stirring intensity in the third part of her Bach and Beyond series for violin.
lead_paragraph: John Harbison’s new work for Jennifer Koh is “For Violin Alone.” It’s a simple title, but one that evokes the essential solitude that draws listeners and violinists to Bach’s solo works for violin. There’s a unique rawness to watching the sonatas and partitas played live, more so even than the cello suites. The hush is audible, the imagery statuesque.

headline: To Russia, With Capitalist Ambitions
abstract: In “Red Notice,” Bill Browder recounts his euphoric early success and undoing in the Russian markets as well as the murder of his Russian lawyer.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s Bill Browder invested $2,000 in a handful of Polish companies being privatized after the collapse of Communism. Eastern Europe was dipping a toe into the cold bath of free-market capitalism, and Mr. Browder, fresh out of Stanford University’s business school, wanted to jump in, too.

headline: From Early Triumph, to Toil, to Vindication
abstract: Katherine Heiny’s short-story collection “Single, Carefree, Mellow” is billed as a debut of sorts, but the road has been long: She was published in The New Yorker at age 25 and has written for young adults under a pseudonym.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — Katherine Heiny has led a somewhat clandestine life as a writer, which is perhaps fitting for the wife of a former spy.

headline: At a Benefit Event, Pressure Takes a Seat at the Table
abstract: It is important to pressure your opponents, whether it is in the bidding or the play.
lead_paragraph: It is important to pressure your opponents, whether it is in the bidding or the play. Make them come up with the best call or card. Especially when you have a fit with your partner and know that you are outgunned in high-card points, bounce the bidding as high as you can.

headline: Knicks Top Lakers in Meeting of Teams Not Fit for National TV
abstract: The game, which featured only one star player, Carmelo Anthony, was not shown on ESPN, which instead broadcast a charity bowling tournament that took place over three weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: Just over a week ago, the people in charge of programming at ESPN decided that Sunday afternoon’s contest between the Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers was no longer worthy of a national television audience.

headline: Gray and Stormy Palettes Mirroring Reality
abstract: Recent weather conditions united concerts by Juilliard 415, the Juilliard School’s period-instrument ensemble, and the Juilliard Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Atmospheric conditions united two Juilliard-related concerts last week. Baroque music inspired by extreme weather and natural phenomena was the focus of Saturday’s concert by Juilliard 415, the Juilliard School’s period-instrument ensemble, at Alice Tully Hall. And the previous night at the conclusion of the school’s Focus! festival dedicated to contemporary Japanese music and its influences, Debussy’s “Clouds” led a program by the Juilliard Orchestra at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

headline: Dreams of Flight, National Pride and Love à la Bollywood
abstract: “Hawaizaada” wraps itself in a love story, but its main focus is on a pair of aviation pioneers in India who are said to have designed an airplane in 1895, before the Wright brothers.
lead_paragraph: About flying and freedom (and, of course, love), the Bollywood movie “Hawaizaada,” directed by Vibhu Virender Puri, spins legend into more legend. The year is 1895, and the setting is Bombay. The story concerns a quest by two Indians to build an airplane and to show the British rulers of India — “A monkey can’t make a machine!” one says — what their subjects can do.

headline: Basking in Seahawks’ Success, Not the Spotlight
abstract: Though he has owned the Seahawks for 18 years, Paul G. Allen gives few interviews and fans rarely see him outside of the sidelines before a game or at an occasional pep rally.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Amid the frenzy of Super Bowl media day Tuesday, as thousands of reporters and cameras surrounded the New England Patriots coaches and players, the dapper owner of the team, Robert K. Kraft, held his own impromptu news conference.

headline: With Dramatic Drops, Exploiting Gravity’s Force
abstract: Travelogues, a new series at Abrons Arts Center, began over the weekend with the American premiere of “Solitudes Solo,” by Daniel Léveillé.
lead_paragraph: When we watch a dance performance, we rarely think about where it has been and where it’s going. The dancers you see in New York today could have been halfway around the world last week. With a new series at Abrons Arts Center, Travelogues, the independent producer Laurie Uprichard (formerly a curator at Danspace Project and Dublin Dance Festival) frames performance as something that exists before and after we see it. The series began over the weekend with the American premiere of “Solitudes Solo” by Daniel Léveillé, whose company is based in Montreal. (Ms. Uprichard had seen the work in Montreal and Paris before bringing it to the Lower East Side.) This is a dance that, wherever it goes, plants itself firmly in that place — or at least it did on Friday in the intimate Experimental Theater at Abrons.

headline: January Job Data, Big Earnings Reports and the Greek Bailout
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Company Reports', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The big corporate news of the week will be earnings reports from BP, Twitter and major carmakers. But the January jobs report, on Friday, and news from Greece will overshadow it all.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: When an Abstract Artist Falls in Love With Monet
abstract: Ellsworth Kelly chose and installed every work in the exhibit “Monet/Kelly” at Clark Art Institute. The abstractionist and the impressionist unexpectedly make a logical match.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — Love can be counterintuitive. If I were asked to pair up the artist Ellsworth Kelly with a historical soul mate, Claude Monet would not readily come to mind. The American painter of abstract pictures as clean as Shaker tables and the French Impressionist who piled on pigment as thick as mulch? I don’t think so. Yet here they are together in a small, crystalline show called “Monet/Kelly” at the Clark Art Institute, and they make an utterly logical, and mind-stretching, match.

headline: Melodist and Minimalist in Harmony
abstract: Stephen Sondheim and Steve Reich chatted and compared notes onstage at a Lincoln Center American Songbook concert that illustrated their mutual interests.
lead_paragraph: Oscillating tones, shimmering and percussive, echoed through the Appel Room on Saturday as an array of musicians from various musical worlds performed works by Stephen Sondheim and Steve Reich. This Lincoln Center American Songbook concert was a genial two-hour-plus seminar, moderated by John Schaefer, in which the composers chatted and compared notes in a program whose selections followed a through-line, each piece roughly continuing the style of the one before. An excellent trio (Tedd Firth on piano, John Beal on bass, Paul Pizzuti on drums) anchored Mr. Sondheim’s songs.

headline: A Meeting in the Desert
abstract: The weeks of preparation over, the Seattle Seahawks and the New England Patriots met in Super Bowl XLIX before avid fans in Glendale, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: The weeks of preparation over, the Seattle Seahawks and the New England Patriots met in Super Bowl XLIX before avid fans in Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Understated Detective Wraps It Up
abstract: The final three episodes of “Foyle’s War” go online at Acorn TV, bringing an end to that British series.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long war for the British detective Christopher Foyle. On screen, he’s served as a home-front police superintendent and MI5 operative for nearly seven years, from mid-1940 to early 1947. In the real world, it’s been even longer — “Foyle’s War” had its premiere in Britain 13 years ago, producing 28 feature-length episodes around long hiatuses and one premature cancellation.

headline: Bach, Filtered Through Balanchine and Robbins
abstract: New York City Ballet continued its season with performances of “Concerto Barocco” and “The Goldberg Variations.”
lead_paragraph: Does art get any better than this? There were many moments when it was easy to ask that question during the performance of George Balanchine’s “Concerto Barocco” (1941) on Thursday night at New York City Ballet.

headline: Jazz & Colors
abstract: Scenes from the music series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the music series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Exalting Tunes on a Big Canvas
abstract: Jazz & Colors, an event previously in Central Park, has bands playing the same set across a broad location. On Friday, it hit the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an image I won’t forget: the saxophonist Lakecia Benjamin and her band Soulsquad blasting out the romantic anguish of Ornette Coleman’s “Lonely Woman” in front of Emanuel Leutze’s painting “Washington Crossing the Delaware.” You know that painting — a dozen men in a rowboat breaking through the ice floes, the general facing left in the breaking light.

headline: A Politically Charged Piece Meditates on Civil Liberty
abstract: “Shesh Yak,” created by Laith Nakli, is set four years ago during the first heady days of protest during the uprising in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Though set only four years ago, Laith Nakli’s “Shesh Yak” at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater is already heartbreakingly out of date. “The Syrian people will prevail,” declares Haytham (Mr. Nakli), an activist in his 50s who has come to New York to lead a rally. “The world will stand by us and there will be reform. I am sure of it.”

headline: Cleaning Up Damage From a Blaze
abstract: A seven-alarm fire at a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, left documents and debris strewn along the East River shoreline.
lead_paragraph: A seven-alarm fire at a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, left documents and debris strewn along the East River shoreline.

headline: There’s No Branding a Symbol of Free Speech
keywords: ['Slogans and Mottoes', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Joachim Roncin, the art director of a free Paris weekly magazine, is trying to prevent people from capitalizing on his “Je Suis Charlie” sign.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after jihadists killed 12 in an attack on the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, the image went viral: “Je Suis Charlie” or “I Am Charlie,” white and light gray letters against a black background. The words are now a shorthand for support of freedom of expression. The sign is the creation of Joachim Roncin, 39, the art director of Stylist, a free Paris weekly magazine. Now, with the aid of pro bono lawyers and the good will of France’s patent office, he’s trying to prevent people from capitalizing on it. “I can’t trademark it. It’s not something that belongs to anyone,” Mr. Roncin said in a telephone interview. “If it’s a slogan, it cannot be a brand.” Mr. Roncin said that even arms manufacturers had filed requests with the French patent office, hoping to sell weapons with the phrase. He said that the patent office has said it will not trademark the slogan. Mr. Roncin has only granted Reporters Without Borders permission to use the image to help raise money for Charlie Hebdo. (In its first issue published after the attacks, the magazine ran a cartoon depicting people in Bangladesh hunched over sewing machines sewing “Je Suis Charlie” T-shirts.) Mr. Roncin posted his image on Twitter not long after the killings. With only around 400 Twitter followers, he expected only a few friends to share the image, but it swept across social media, and tens of thousands marched in Paris on Jan. 11 holding “Je Suis Charlie” signs. “It’s incredible,” Mr. Roncin said. “Now it’s crazy.”

headline: In a Rare Assignment, Fireboats Battle a Blaze in Brooklyn
abstract: The New York Fire Department’s Marine Battalion responds most frequently to medical emergencies and boats in distress.
lead_paragraph: Once a common sight at urban disaster scenes, the fireboat, with its cannons of cascading water, is rarely called upon to battle fires in a New York City of receding industrial zones and new riverfront condominiums.

headline: Is it Bigger Than a Breadbox?
abstract: Jeffrey Wechsler will meet you at the top of the Empire State Building.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s always nice to see a puzzle that celebrates my hometown, and Jeffrey Wechsler returns to do just that.

headline: Hard-Charging Uber Tries Olive Branch
abstract: The striking reversal in tone comes at a crucial time for Uber, which once somewhat prided itself on its antagonistic attitude.
lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick did not build Uber into a global force by playing nice.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Dies in Apartment Building Fire; Brother Is Injured
abstract: A 49-year-old woman died and her older brother was seriously injured after a blaze spread smoke through the three-story building where they lived together, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 49-year-old woman died early Sunday morning and her older brother was seriously injured after a fire spread noxious smoke through the three-story apartment building where they lived together in Brooklyn, officials said.

headline: Football Major, Basketball Minor?
abstract: To reform college sports, some educators propose acknowledging reality, and awarding academic credit for playing and a curriculum built around the sport.
lead_paragraph: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has long clung to the idea that college athletes are essentially engaged in extracurricular activities, but evidence to the contrary is mounting.

headline: U.S. Considers Supplying Arms to Ukraine Forces, Officials Say
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama has made no decisions on providing lethal aid in Ukraine’s fight against Russian-backed separatists, who have gained territory since a September cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Russian-backed separatists pressing their attacks in Ukraine, NATO’s military commander, Gen. Philip M. Breedlove, now supports providing defensive weapons and equipment to Kiev’s beleaguered forces, and an array of administration and military officials appear to be edging toward that position, American officials said Sunday.

headline: Disney to Crown Elena, an Animated Latina Princess
abstract: The 16-year-old title character in the coming animated series “Elena of Avalor” lives in a fairy-tale kingdom inspired by Latino cultures and folklore.
lead_paragraph: The realm of Disney princesses is expanding to include its first member of Latina royalty. The company announced in a blog post on Friday plans for the 2016 airing of “Elena of Avalor,” an animated series about a princess in a fairy-tale kingdom inspired by Latino cultures and folklore. The “bold, caring, funny and clever” 16-year-old Princess Elena, to be voiced by Aimee Carrero of the ABC Family series “Young & Hungry,” will be introduced next year in an episode of the Disney Junior series “Sofia the First.” The spinoff show, produced by Disney Television Animation and geared to ages 2-7, will include messages of “leadership, resilience, diversity, compassion and the importance of family and family tradition,” according to the announcement.

headline: For Greece, Bank Trouble Looms Again as New Government Takes Shape
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: As depositors yank their savings from Greek banks, the question is being asked if the E.C.B. would bail them out again.
lead_paragraph: In January 2013, as Cypriot banks faced collapse, Jens Weidmann, Germany’s powerful representative at the European Central Bank, made it clear how unhappy he was with the Cyprus bank bailout.

headline: More Snow Is in Forecast for New York, but Don’t Expect a Shutdown
abstract: After being criticized for closing down the city ahead of last week’s storm, Mayor Bill de Blasio said he expected schools to be open and public transportation to be running on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio warned New Yorkers on Sunday that more snow was expected in the city overnight, but he said officials were prepared to handle the storm and schools were expected to open on Monday morning.

headline: The N.F.L. Takes On Domestic Violence. Can Hollywood?
abstract: Should Hollywood hold stars accountable for their behavior?  If the N.F.L. is trying to take domestic abuse seriously, should Hollywood?

headline: Vaccines: An Unhealthy Skepticism
abstract: An outbreak of measles that started at Disneyland has turned a spotlight on those who choose not to vaccinate their children. How did we get to a point where personal beliefs can triumph over science?
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of measles that started at Disneyland has turned a spotlight on those who choose not to vaccinate their children. How did we get to a point where personal beliefs can triumph over science?

headline: A Discredited Vaccine Study’s Continuing Impact on Public Health
abstract: A doctor’s 1998 report of a relationship between the M.M.R. vaccine and the onset of autism has been widely rejected, but a link is still accepted by some.
lead_paragraph: In the churning over the refusal of some parents to immunize their children against certain diseases, a venerable Latin phrase may prove useful: Post hoc, ergo propter hoc. It means, “After this, therefore because of this.” In plainer language: Event B follows Event A, so B must be the direct result of A. It is a classic fallacy in logic.

headline: New Magazine Teaches Children Financial Lessons
abstract: The financial editor of NBC’s “Today” show and Time for Kids, a division of Time Inc., have introduced a magazine intended to teach financial literacy to fourth, fifth and sixth graders.
lead_paragraph: Jean Chatzky, the financial editor of NBC’s “Today” show, has made a career sharing personal finance tips with adults. Now, she is trying to reach a much younger audience.

headline: After Turmoil, The New Republic Re-emerges on Newsstands
abstract: After mass defections of staff members over changes at the magazine, even the choice of a cover article proved contentious.
lead_paragraph: The New Republic is a small magazine that set off a big commotion.

headline: Celtic Prevails Over Weak Rangers in First Old Firm Match in Nearly 3 Years
abstract: Celtic has been a cut above in Scottish soccer recently, but an Old Firm victory over Rangers may even top a league title.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Sunday’s match between Celtic and Rangers, the Glasgow giants collectively known as the Old Firm, was their first in nearly three years, but for all the hatred and bile, it seemed the two clubs had missed each other.

headline: At 37 and Coming Off Surgery, Bode Miller Readies for Season Debut
abstract: Miller, who has not raced this season because of a back injury, has confirmed that he will compete in the Alpine world championships, which are set to begin Tuesday in Beaver Creek, Colo.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — The six-time Olympic medalist Bode Miller, who has not raced this season because of a back injury, has confirmed that he will compete in the Alpine world championships, which are set to begin here Tuesday.

headline: For Devils’ Backup Goalies, Every Start Is an Audition
abstract: Devils goalie Cory Schneider leads the league in starts, which means long stretches on the bench or in the A.H.L. for the two players who back him up.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Before the Devils’ rookie goaltender, Keith Kinkaid, made his first career start on Dec. 9, he was too excited to sleep. He had been fortunate enough to learn of his starting assignment on the morning of the game against the Chicago Blackhawks, so he was not awake all night, but he was robbed of his traditional pregame nap.

headline: Sex Toy Shops Prepare for Tie-Ins to ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’
abstract: The sex toy industry is banking on the hope that “Fifty Shades of Grey” will generate soaring sales, much the way the blockbuster erotic novel created thousands of new customers from the readers who passed the book around.
lead_paragraph: When toys are made for movies, they are usually intended for children.

headline: Wisconsin’s Treasurer Wants to Cut Needless Workers, Starting With Himself

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Last Wednesday, in the grand Beaux-Arts Capitol here, throngs of lawmakers and tourists milled around upstairs. Matt Adamczyk, the newly elected state treasurer, however, was in his basement office — alone.

headline: France Offers Support, but No Debt Relief, to Greece
abstract: Michael Sapin, the French finance minister, said Paris was ready to help the new Greek government, but that debt reduction was out of the question.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French officials said Sunday they would support the new Greek government’s efforts to get the country back on its feet after five years of crushing austerity, but warned that there would be no write-down of Greece’s debt and pressed Athens to continue with reforms that are still needed to help mend the country’s economy.

headline: Rebels Set Sights on Small Eastern Ukraine Town

lead_paragraph: DEBALTSEVE, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers rattled along the snowy streets here in armored personnel carriers with the hatches battened down, their helmeted heads safely below plates of steel.

headline: Even Ordinary Pros Have Extraordinary Skills
abstract: The talent level between club players and professionals is like an ever-widening Grand Canyon.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — I am an awesome tennis player. Seriously. You should see my one-handed backhand. It usually goes over the net.

headline: Ebola Drug Trial Is Halted for Lack of Patients
abstract: Chimerix, a pharmaceutical company, had sent enough of its antiviral drug to Liberia for 140 patients, but fewer than 10 had shown up, underscoring the falloff of Ebola cases in Western Africa.
lead_paragraph: A clinical trial in Liberia of a drug to treat Ebola has been halted because of a sharp decline in the number of people infected with the virus, and studies in West Africa of other potential treatments are also facing problems finding patients.

lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Keegan Bradley, the Patriots’ No. 1 fan on the PGA Tour, woke up Sunday with an uneasy feeling. Not about New England’s coming game, but his own. A down comforter of fog blanketed the area, causing a ground stop at Sky Harbor Airport 21 miles away and reducing road visibility in many areas to a few hundred feet.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An explosion on Sunday ripped apart a bus carrying Lebanese pilgrims to Shiite shrines in Damascus, Syria, killing at least six people and wounding 27, official news channels reported.

headline: Media Titans Murdoch and Bloomberg at Play in Politics and News

abstract: Rupert Murdoch and Michael Bloomberg are extremely successful businessmen who spend many hours on noneconomic parts of their businesses because they can, and because it is fun.
lead_paragraph: When Mitt Romney announced on Friday that he would not seek the Republican presidential nomination for a third time, he cited the desire to “give other leaders in the party” a chance to win the White House. He did not mention the public mugging he had received from Rupert Murdoch, the media titan who had called him “a terrible candidate” and whose Wall Street Journal had suggested that his run in 2012 had been “a calamity.”

headline: Training Teachers to Take Aim Against Taliban

lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Gunfire rang out as Fatima Bibi squeezed off three shots, hitting her target every time. Then she lowered her Glock pistol, turned to her fellow academics and smiled.

headline: Settling Case, S.&P. Backs Off Claims of U.S. ‘Retaliation’
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As part of a $1.37 billion settlement, S.&P. is expected to say it never found evidence of retaliation for cutting the credit rating of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s, the giant credit rating agency accused of inflating the subprime mortgage bubble, had long been convinced that a Justice Department lawsuit lacked merit. So convinced, in fact, that it portrayed the lawsuit as an act of “retaliation” for its decision to cut the credit rating of the United States in the summer of 2011.

headline: One Yard From Crushing Loss, Patriots Grab Their 4th Title

lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The seconds ticked off late in the fourth quarter Sunday, and how familiar it must have all seemed to Bill Belichick, to Tom Brady, to the New England Patriots and their fans wondering why, oh why, was this happening again.

headline: Carroll Petrie, a New York Philanthropist, Dies at 90

lead_paragraph: Carroll Petrie, a prominent socialite and philanthropist who gave hundreds of millions of dollars to museums, hospitals and charities, continuing the largess of her husband, the retailing mogul Milton Petrie, after his death in 1994, died on Jan. 22 at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

keywords: ['Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: For the first time, government prosecutors on Friday disclosed that the arrest of Joseph Hunter, who is charged in a murder-for-hire plot, was aided by his boss, a seasoned South African criminal.
lead_paragraph: In May 2013, court papers say, Joseph Hunter, a soldier of fortune, got an email from his boss. The boss, a South African named Paul Le Roux, wanted Mr. Hunter’s assistance with “a priority job.”

headline: Primary Strength of Seahawks’ No. 1 Defense, Their Secondary, Falls Apart
abstract: The Patriots used quick and short throws to test Seattle’s vaunted secondary, and it paid off as New England erased a 10-point fourth-quarter deficit in the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — To try to win the Super Bowl, New England quarterback Tom Brady and the Patriots first fearlessly, then desperately tested the strength of the Seahawks’ strength — the secondary of the league’s No. 1 defense — the way few have.

headline: Hackers Use Old Lure on Web to Help Syrian Government
abstract: A rebel fighter chatting with what he thought was an alluring young woman on Skype inadvertently helped hackers steal a trove of data to aid the government of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To the young Syrian rebel fighter, the Skype message in early December 2013 appeared to come from a woman in Lebanon, named Iman Almasri, interested in his cause. Her picture, in a small icon alongside her name, showed a fair-skinned 20-something in a black head covering, wearing sunglasses.

headline: Not Exactly Brilliant, but at Least the Colors Are
abstract: On a massive stage, one that requires pop stars with wide cross-demographic appeal, Katy Perry held her own.
lead_paragraph: Given the agonizing over air pressure that has racked the N.F.L. in recent weeks, it was appropriate that the halftime entertainment at Super Bowl XLIX was Katy Perry, a queen of our deflated pop times.

headline: Cleaning Up Damage From a Blaze
abstract: A seven-alarm fire at a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, left documents and debris strewn along the East River shoreline.
lead_paragraph: A seven-alarm fire at a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, left documents and debris strewn along the East River shoreline.

headline: Tom Brady Refreshes His Legacy With a Fourth Super Bowl Title
abstract: After losses in his last two Super Bowls, Brady knew the effect the outcome of Sunday’s game would have on the narrative of his career.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — When quarterback Tom Brady first jogged onto the field before Sunday’s Super Bowl, thousands of New England Patriots fans rose from their seats, burst into applause and then sat down.

headline: Finding the Next Big Thing (and Fighting FOMO) at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival
abstract: This year’s highlights included the weepy teen dramedy “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl” and the David Foster Wallace biopic “The End of the Tour.”
lead_paragraph: A significant part of the fun of attending the Sundance Film Festival lies in trying to guess the dominating narratives beforehand. Will a star emerge from nowhere, à la Kevin Smith in “Clerks” or Quvenzhané Wallis in “Beasts of the Southern Wild”? Will we see anything as heartbreaking as “Blue Valentine” or as compelling as “Hoop Dreams”? What, if anything, will be this year’s “Boyhood”? There’s no real indicator for where the hits will come from at Sundance — and when they do, there’s a good chance you’ll still miss them, thanks to the festival’s breadth of programming.

headline: The ‘Pay What You Want’ Experiment at Synagogues
abstract: Congregations that have eliminated mandatory dues have reported growth in both members and revenues, even as many other synagogues are declining on both fronts.
lead_paragraph: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich. — For more than four decades, Temple Kol Ami financed its operations as most American synagogues do: it charged annual dues.

headline: Word of the Day | gloat
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: gloat •\ˈglot\• verb and noun

headline: Ann Mara, Matriarch of the Football Giants, Dies at 85
abstract: Mrs. Mara owned part of the Giants with her family and was regarded as the team’s matriarch.
lead_paragraph: After the N.F.C. championship game in 2012, as the broadcaster Terry Bradshaw tried to interview players from the victorious Giants, Ann Mara intervened.

headline: On a Dark Day for Seattle, a Receiver Is a Bright Spot
abstract: Chris Matthews, 25, played in the Canadian Football League before he was drafted by Seattle, which has made a habit of finding unheralded free agents.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Every so often, a player comes out of nowhere and has fans wondering, who is that guy? In this year’s Super Bowl, that player was Chris Matthews.

headline: Bold Addition to Paris Skyline Gets Art to Match
abstract: The new Louis Vuitton Foundation museum in Paris, designed by Frank Gehry, will feature an exhibition of modern masterpieces with loans from institutions around the world.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When it opened in October, the Louis Vuitton Foundation museum was such an audacious addition to the landscape here that all eyes were on the architecture and its creator, Frank Gehry. At the time, it seemed that the art on view — from the foundation’s collection — was little more than an afterthought, and few details were disclosed about future programs. But it turns out that Suzanne Pagé, the foundation’s artistic director, was secretly working on an exhibition of modern masterpieces to open in April with loans from institutions around the world including Edvard Munch’s “The Scream,” Matisse’s “Dance” and Léger’s “Three Women (Le Grand Déjeuner).”

headline: Hit in Head, Patriots' Julian Edelman Stays In, Leaving Questions
abstract: Edelman caught the game-winning touchdown, but questions lingered as to whether he should have been evaluated for a concussion earlier in the game.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — After a Super Bowl performance that had people raving about his toughness while questioning his team’s training staff, Julian Edelman of the New England Patriots is sure to be a hot topic in the coming weeks.

headline: Corrections: February 2, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, February 2, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Tale of Comebacks Is Tom Brady’s to Tell
abstract: In the end it was Brady, the New England Patriots quarterback, who claimed the role of Super Bowl champion, tossing one brilliant pass after another.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — That was merely insane.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 A.M. (AMC) GROUNDHOG DAY (1993) Once more, with feeling: A smug Pittsburgh weatherman (Bill Murray, above) is condemned to relive one day in Punxsutawney, Pa., until he gets it right. Andie MacDowell plays the woman of his dreams; Stephen Tobolowsky is the most annoying guy in town. Or is he? Writing in The New York Times, Caryn James called Mr. Murray “the screen’s most likable cynic.” The movie repeats at 12:30, 3 and 5:30 p.m.

headline: Late Seahawks Drive Ends With a Screeching Halt After a Risky Call
abstract: In an improbable series of plays in the final 75 seconds of the Super Bowl, the Seahawks landed on the threshold of their second straight N.F.L. title, but the Patriots snatched it away.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — On the same field where a receiver named David Tyree had improbably caught a desperation throw to propel the Giants to Super Bowl victory over the New England Patriots seven years earlier, the Seattle Seahawks had a potentially historic acrobatic catch of their own to remember and treasure.

headline: Barcelona Firmly in Title Chase
abstract: Barcelona came from behind twice in a 3-2 win over visiting Villarreal to stay 1 point behind the leader Real Madrid.
lead_paragraph: Lionel Messi and Neymar kept Barcelona in the hunt for the Spanish La Liga title.

headline: Seahawks’ Call Joins List of Big Gaffes in Sports
abstract: The decision by the Seattle Seahawks to throw the ball on second-and-goal from the 1-yard line joins an ignominious list of the worst coaching decisions in sports history.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Seattle Seahawks to throw the ball on second-and-goal from the 1-yard line, trailing the Patriots by 4 in the closing seconds of the Super Bowl on Sunday, will go down as an infamous blunder. A team with Marshawn Lynch, one of the best goal-line running backs in football, instead opted for a far riskier option, and Malcolm Butler made them pay, intercepting the ball at the goal line to effectively end the Seahawks’ hopes of winning a second consecutive Super Bowl.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Clippers at Cavaliers
abstract: After drawing criticism over a slow start, Cleveland has made several moves that have paved the way for a successful run. They face a Los Angeles team that has been playing much better defense than it has for much of the season.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Patriots Make a Stand
abstract: With a late interception, the Patriots won Super Bowl XLIX on Sunday at University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: With a late interception, the Patriots won Super Bowl XLIX on Sunday at University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz.

headline: One Killed and 4 Wounded Near City College as Gunman Flees
abstract: The shooting took place Sunday night in front of a deli on Broadway near the corner of 135th Street.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and four others were wounded in a shooting Sunday night near City College, the police said.

headline: #R.I.P.: Grieving My Dog Offline
abstract: Wasn’t it possible for me to truly process the loss of my childhood pet without sharing it on Instagram or Facebook?
lead_paragraph: “Aren’t you going to post something about Ginny on Facebook?” my father asked.

headline: How to Be a Stoic
abstract: Practicing the ancient philosophy of Seneca today is not much different from practicing Buddhism, or some forms of modern Christianity.
lead_paragraph: In every culture we know of, whether it be secular or religious, cosmopolitan or tribal, the question of how to live is central. How should we handle life’s challenges and vicissitudes? How should we conduct ourselves in the world and treat others? And the ultimate question: how do we best prepare to die?

headline: Reducing the Influence of Political Donations
abstract: Two readers, including the president of the Center for Political Accountability, offer views on political spending.

headline: Don’t Drill Along the East Coast
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Global Warming', 'Oil Spills', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Obama shouldn’t open the Atlantic’s waters to oil and gas exploration.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — THE Obama administration’s whiplash decision last week to allow oil and gas companies to drill along a wide area of the Atlantic Coast is a big mistake.

headline: The Long-Run Cop-Out
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: In today’s economic and political environment, dismissing the here and now is craven and irresponsible.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, President Obama will call for a significant increase in spending, reversing the harsh cuts of the past few years. He won’t get all he’s asking for, but it’s a move in the right direction. And it also marks a welcome shift in the discourse. Maybe Washington is starting to get over its narrow-minded, irresponsible obsession with long-run problems and will finally take on the hard issue of short-run gratification instead.

headline: A Future Segregated by Science?
keywords: ['Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Science and Technology', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Engineering and Engineers']
abstract: When you look at the number of women and minorities seeking STEM careers, the situation is bleak.
lead_paragraph: Let me say up front: I’m not a science guy.

headline: Sex, Fear and Loving: A Conversation
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “Searching for Sex.”

headline: Live, From the Nursing Home
abstract: Why would I want to grow old and die, all alone, in my own house?
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio — DONALD HALL, 86, a former poet laureate, probably captured the general mood when he wrote that nursing homes are “old-folks storage bins” and “for-profit-making expiration dormitories.” He wants to die in his farmhouse in New Hampshire.

headline: The Economy, Past and Future
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Modest growth has never been enough to overcome the Great Recession’s damage. Congress could do much more to help.
lead_paragraph: The data necessary to assess the economy’s performance last year and help project its path for this year is now coming in. One point stands out from all the rest: For all the talk about accelerating growth, the economy grew last year at a rate of 2.4 percent, basically in line with growth over the past several years.

headline: In the Bronx, New Life for an Old Prison
abstract: For locals, the former Fulton Correctional Facility’s transformation into a community re-entry center is a welcome step forward.
lead_paragraph: The seven-story, faded-brick building at 1511 Fulton Avenue — across from Crotona Park in the Claremont section of the Bronx — has no distinct personality, which may help explain why it has been reincarnated so many times over the past century.

headline: Mr. Putin Resumes His War in Ukraine
abstract: Certainly the United States and Europe should increase their aid to Ukraine, but lethal assistance could open a dangerous new chapter in the struggle.
lead_paragraph: The fighting in eastern Ukraine has flared up again, putting an end to any myth about the cease-fire that was supposed to be in force since September.

headline: Test Yourself | Katy Perry at the Super Bowl
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 29 article written before the Super Bowl, “At Halftime, Hear Her Roar.” Can you choose the best word or phrase for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a Jan. 29 article written before the Super Bowl, “At Halftime, Hear Her Roar.”

lead_paragraph: In “One Yard From Crushing Loss, Patriots Grab Their 4th Title,” Ben Shpigel writes about a close game with a climactic fourth quarter.

headline: Chip Wilson, Lululemon Guru, Is Moving On
abstract: Chip Wilson made billions selling the world’s most ubiquitous yoga pants. Then he insulted his customers and lost control of his company. Now he talks for the first time about his impending departure and his plans for his next venture.
lead_paragraph: The morning sun threw a halo of light on the billboard-size liability waiver standing at the trailhead of Grouse Grind, a steep, dangerous ascent just outside Vancouver, British Columbia. Hikers were warned of their assumption of risk, and the hazards detailed included property loss and death as well as “slippery, unstable and dangerous trail conditions; avalanches; rockfall; cliffs, gullies, ravines and waterfalls; rapidly changing weather conditions; overexertion, dehydration and exposure; encounters with domestic or wild animals” and, not least, “becoming lost.”

headline: Survival and Death in a Faraway War
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Veterans', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Vivid autochromes document how 170,000 West African soldiers took part in World War I’s most decisive conflicts, enduring the brutality of combat, the ravages of frostbite and the deaths of their comrades in arms.
lead_paragraph: “I was going to die. … And I was thinking about God and his Prophet… ,” Aliou Diakhate recalled in the historian Joe Lunn’s “Memoirs of the Maelstrom: A Senegalese Oral History of the First World War.” “And when you wish to pray you have to stand up – to stand and bend down on your knees, and put your forehead on the ground. But I could not do that [because I was wounded so badly]. So I took some earth in my hand and I put it to my forehead. And I prayed to God [to bless me] in that way.”

headline: How Should Schools Handle Unvaccinated Students?
abstract: Have you heard about the measles outbreak that began at Disneyland and has since spread to 14 states? How do you think schools should handle children who are unvaccinated?
lead_paragraph: Have you heard about the measles outbreak that began at Disneyland and has since spread to 14 states?

headline: Good Housekeeping Seal Keeps Going
abstract: At the Good Housekeeping Institute’s laboratories, researchers test everything from skin creams to convenience breakfasts, exercise clothes, cleaning products, blenders and baby strollers that can affect the well-being of consumers.
lead_paragraph: Consumers concerned about the healthfulness and safety of products can thank Harvey W. Wiley, an American chemist who championed the passage of the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, then did work as head of Good Housekeeping’s Bureau of Food, Sanitation, and Health from 1912 until just before his death in 1930.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

abstract: Monday: A treacherous commute, schools in the city will open, and it’s Groundhog Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this slushy Groundhog Day.

headline: Australian Leader Alters Course After Losing State Vote
abstract: In a speech, Prime Minister Tony Abbott, who has been in office less than two years, said he would refocus on the economy and consult more with his party colleagues.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott, struggling to keep unhappy political allies from toppling him, said on Monday that he would abandon some costly and unpopular policies and refocus his attention on the economy.

headline: China Executes Members of Sect for Beating a Woman to Death
abstract: Two followers of the Church of Almighty God, a banned religious order, were executed over the deadly attack of a woman who had declined to give them her phone number.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese court announced on Monday that two members of a banned religious sect had been executed for beating a woman to death at a McDonald’s restaurant in May, an episode that was caught by a cellphone camera and incited outrage across China.

headline: Daily Report: Uber, Known for Playing Hardball, Tries Softer Approach
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The striking reversal in tone comes at a crucial time for Uber, which once somewhat prided itself on its antagonistic attitude.
lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick did not build Uber into a global force by playing nice, Mike Isaac reports.

headline: Twitter Displays Its Value With Instant Timeline for New Users
abstract: The social network, which is under pressure to attract new users more quickly, has begun testing a feature that allows new users to dive into Twitter’s content without investing much time setting up an account.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has created a Twitter account knows how difficult it can be to get value from the service. When you  sign up, you have to “follow” dozens of people and organizations on the service and then hope they post items that actually interest you, since that is all you are going to see.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 2, 2015

lead_paragraph: Updated: Feb. 3, 2015

headline: More Women Than Ever on Capitol Hill, but Influence Also Cut
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Women for the first time in history hold more than 100 seats in Congress, but the Republican takeover of the Senate has also cost women powerful committee chairmanships.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, the new chairwoman of the energy committee, was at a reception in Hershey, Pa., last month when aides to Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the No. 2 Republican in the House, presented her with a party favor: a black windbreaker with the words “Chairman’s Table” on the back.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: When it came to rooting, potential presidential candidates kept their Super Bowl preferences quiet.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl? Presidential Hopefuls Refused to Take Sides

headline: How to Measure a Medical Treatment’s Potential for Harm
abstract: Aspirin, antibiotics and mammograms can hurt as well as help, and the N.N.H. is a statistic that helps us make sense of that balance.
lead_paragraph: As we wrote last week, many fewer people benefit from medical therapies than we tend to think. This fact is quantified in a therapy’s Number Needed to Treat, or N.N.T., which tells you the number of people who would need to receive a medical therapy in order for one person to benefit. N.N.T.s well above 10 or even 100 are common.  But knowing the potential for benefit is not enough. We must also consider potential harms.

headline: Strauss-Kahn, Former I.M.F. Chief, Goes on Trial in Sex Case
abstract: The former head of the International Monetary Fund faces accusations of “aggravated procurement in a group,” or pimping, in Northern France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, went on trial Monday on accusations that he participated in a prostitution ring that extended from the north of France to Brussels, Washington and New York.

headline: Morning Agenda: S.&P. Walks Back ‘Retaliation’ Claims
abstract: S.&P. is backing off claims of government ‘retaliation’ for its decision to cut the credit rating of the U.S. | The E.C.B. is again considering aiding Greek banks. | Two judges issue rulings to protect borrowers against financial giants. | The cement makers Lafarge and Holcim agree to sell assets.
lead_paragraph: S.&P. WALKS BACK ‘RETALIATION’ CLAIMS | The giant credit rating agency Standard & Poor’s, which was accused of inflating the subprime mortgage bubble, had portrayed a Justice Department lawsuit as an act of “retaliation” for its decision to cut the credit rating of the United States in the summer of 2011. Now, it is walking back that claim, Ben Protess writes in DealBook. As part of a $1.37 billion settlement deal expected this week, S.&P. has agreed to acknowledge that it never found evidence supporting its accusations of retaliation, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Pay-Walled Links
abstract: The science editor considers the problem of links that are a ‘dead end’
lead_paragraph: A reader, Rich Dempsey, writes that he is “sick of articles that reference professional journals that hide behind a pay wall.” For example, he notes, in a recent Op-Ed on ageism, a link leads to an article from the Journal of Social Sciences that cannot be accessed without paying a hefty fee.

headline: Christie Says Parents Should Have ‘Choice’ on Vaccinations
abstract: Amid an outbreak of measles that has spread across 14 states, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Monday said that parents “need to have some measure of choice” about vaccinating their children against the virus, breaking with President Obama and much of the medical profession.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — Amid an outbreak of measles that has spread across 14 states, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Monday said that parents “need to have some measure of choice” about vaccinating their children against the virus, breaking with President Obama and much of the medical profession.
