headline: Sysco Offers to Sell 11 Facilities to Win Merger Approval
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Seeking the blessing of the F.T.C. for its $3.5 billion acquisition of US Foods, Sysco will sell 11 facilities to Performance Food Group for an undisclosed sum.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than a year since Sysco, the big food distributor, agreed to buy its closest rival, US Foods, for $3.5 billion. Now, Sysco finally believes it has come up with a way to get the deal past antitrust regulators.

headline: Jeremy Scott, Moschino, Katy Perry: Who Scored at Super Bowl XLIX?
abstract: High fashion is a world away from football and yet Mr. Scott may have snagged the gold ring Sunday night, with his fast changes, cartoon colors and Barbie silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: We know that a few minutes of screen time during the Super Bowl are considered the most valuable commercial seconds on television, so just consider the potential value of exposure during the halftime show. Mega, right?

abstract: Designers are riding a wave of rope detailing and sailor stripes.
lead_paragraph: Designers are riding a wave of rope detailing and sailor stripes.

lead_paragraph: With the Seahawks 1 yard from a Super Bowl victory, quarterback Russell Wilson fired a pass to Ricardo Lockette — a play call that many have questioned.

headline: Blackstone’s Chief Has a Warning for Wall Street’s Entrepreneurs
abstract: “I have begged, literally begged” young financiers not to start their own firms “because they’re going to destroy their careers,” says Stephen A. Schwarzman.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire co-founder of the Blackstone Group, has a sobering message for any junior financiers hoping to emulate his success: Think twice.

headline: Snow and Rain Hit New York, Creating a Slushy Commute
abstract: Freezing rain caused an array of transit delays in the region, but New York City remained open for business.
lead_paragraph: There was snow. There was rain. There were prickly frozen bits shooting down from the sky. But New York City was open for business on Monday, and workers slogged their way through cold, messy streets, dodging lakes of blackened slush, as roads and subway trains tussled with the nasty weather.

headline: Russia Outlines Prescription to Bolster Its Ailing Economy, but Experts Scoff
abstract: Some insiders said they expected the Kremlin to react to the economic crisis the way it had in 2008 — with disaster management, but no fundamental changes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — With oil prices down more than 50 percent in the past year, the ruble having lost more than half its value, a recession looming and the country already dipping into its rainy-day funds, the Russian economy is in a race against time. But one would be hard pressed to grasp the depth of the troubles from the Kremlin’s prescriptions.

headline: In Net Neutrality Push, F.C.C. Is Expected to Propose Regulating Internet Service as a Utility
abstract: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is expected to propose reclassifying high-speed Internet as a telecommunications service.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission this week is widely expected to propose regulating Internet service like a public utility, a move certain to unleash another round of intense debate and lobbying about how to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet.

headline: Courts Write Decisions That Elude Long View
abstract: Despite criticism of the practice, federal appeals courts designate 88 percent of their decisions as “unpublished,” meaning they are good for one time only.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In April, a federal appeals court issued a 40-page decision on a serious subject, ruling that a trial judge had unlawfully increased a prison sentence out of vindictiveness.

headline: Derision Lands in Lap of Seahawks’ Offensive Coordinator
abstract: In the span of one play, Darrell Bevell became the goat when the ball was intercepted at New England’s 1-yard line, allowing the Patriots to escape with a Super Bowl victory.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Darrell Bevell was 20 miles from home, but he really just wanted to go one yard. That was how far the Seattle Seahawks were from the winning touchdown in the final seconds of Sunday’s Super Bowl. How they would get there was Bevell’s decision.

headline: The Secretive, Sleazy Process to Replace Sheldon Silver
abstract: Democratic Party leaders are trying to make Carl Heastie the speaker and are forcing possible challengers to step aside.
lead_paragraph: In the next few days Democrats in Albany could choose a new speaker to replace Sheldon Silver, who was arrested on corruption charges almost two weeks ago. After Mr. Silver’s 20 years of dominating the New York Assembly, it is a rare opportunity to create a better, fairer legislature.

headline: British Airways Parent Tries to Woo Irish Government in Its Aer Lingus Bid
abstract: The parent company of British Airways said it would commit to continue operating Aer Lingus’s routes in Ireland for five years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The parent of British Airways tried to sweeten the pot on Monday in hopes of winning over the Irish government in its $1.5 billion bid for Aer Lingus, the Irish carrier.

headline: Exxon Mobil Revenue and Profit Off 21% on Oil Decline
abstract: The company said its fourth-quarter results were bolstered somewhat by asset sales and improved profits in its chemical business.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil on Monday reported a sharp drop in fourth-quarter revenue and profit because of declining oil prices. But the company did better than many of its competitors, thanks to improved profit margins at its chemical business.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Days of Wine and Droning’

headline: Downtown’s Newest Gallerist
abstract: A former director at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, Bridget Donahue, opens her own space, with a focus on underrated artists.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Donahue, formerly a director at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, is opening a massive New York gallery with a refreshingly eclectic program. “I’m drawn to those who engage with the long game,” says the Iowa City native, who will champion artists of all kinds — older, under-the-radar, anti-establishment — who might otherwise get sidelined in Chinatown’s trend-heavy scene. Her debut exhibition will celebrate the work of Lynn Hershman Leeson, a 73-year-old artist whose prescient mixed-media creations began addressing the relationship between gender and technology as early as the 1960s. Following that, Donahue will host a show featuring the work of the artist and fashion designer Susan Cianciolo, whose homespun zines, pillows and clothing demonstrate artisanal flair and a subversive sensibility that fits the space.

headline: Obama’s Budget Seeks to Loosen Austerity Reins
abstract: The $4 trillion budget released Monday is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint, but buried in it are kernels of proposals that could take root even with a hostile Republican Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The $4 trillion budget that President Obama released Monday is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint for his final years in office, but buried in the document are kernels of proposals that could take root even with a hostile Republican Congress.

headline: Obama’s Defense Budget Aims Higher, and at Overseas Conflicts
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The base defense budget for 2016 exceeds by $35 billion the mandatory across-the-board reductions known as sequestration, and President Obama is asking for an additional $51 billion for operations in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is asking the new Republican Congress for a base defense budget of $534 billion in 2016, the Pentagon said on Monday in its annual budget release, exceeding by $35 billion the mandatory across-the-board reductions known as sequestration.

headline: 1890: Blood Shed for Honor
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A duel leaves one injured in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The much talked-of duel between the Marquis de Morès and M. Camille Dreyfus was fought at 10.25 yesterday [Feb. 2] morning in the outskirts of the little town of Comines, which lies in Belgium, just beyond the French frontier. At the word of command, M. Dreyfus fired instantly, and missed. The Marquis de Morès aimed more deliberately, and sent his ball into the arm of his opponent just above the elbow joint. The wound is painful, but not serious. Had it not been for the fact that M. Dreyfus dropped his arm immediately on firing, it is very probable that he would have been mortally wounded. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1890

headline: Through Decades of Unrest and Decay, Always Calling It Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: Generations of the Casuso family have endured urban blight and change as they continue to call Bushwick their home.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, when the Bronx was burning, Bushwick, Brooklyn, was burning, too.

headline: G.M. Victim Compensation Program Seems on Track
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: No payment offers have been rejected so far in the automaker’s effort to avoid the image-damaging litigation over defective ignition switches.

headline: Vaccination: How Personal Belief Came to Outweigh Public Health
abstract: The history of the fallacy that led to the current spread of vaccine resistance.
lead_paragraph: Retro Report, a series of video documentaries studying major news stories of the past and their consequences, offers this special report on the history, not of vaccination, but of the resistance to it that began with a now-discredited vaccination study and has since spread. Read more.

headline: New Rule for Mayor de Blasio and Staten Island Chuck: Hands Off
abstract: A year after Mayor Bill de Blasio famously fumbled Chuck, the Staten Island Zoo introduced a different approach to Groundhog Day.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps justice demanded a different coda, a sequel to redeem the suspect’s questionable dexterity or enshrine it for all time.

headline: An Icon Goes Minimal
abstract: The elegant Birkin bag gets a practical upgrade for the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to improve on perfection, but that’s precisely what Hermès has done with the new hyper-pared-down Birkin Sellier 40. According to Couli Jobert, the leather artistic director at Hermès, natural brown was deemed too obvious for the new Birkin, which is only available in matte black with silver palladium hardware. As the goal was to create an essential design without clutter, the structured cowhide bag is extra-wide, has no lining and the stitching is extremely subtle. It’s a radically modern update of the elegant classic, which has been the subject of girl envy — and the cause of waiting lists — since it was first crafted in 1984.

headline: 1965: Kozlov Ashes Put in Kremlin
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet politician Frol R. Kozlov is interred in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Slowly, their feet moving to the measured cadences of a funeral dirge, the leaders of the Soviet Union bore the ashes of Frol Romanovich Kozlov across the cobblestones of Red Square toward their final resting place in the Kremlin wall today [Feb. 2]. Leonid I. Brezhnev, first secretary of the Communist Party, and Premier Alexei N. Kosygin led the line of pallbearers that carried the urn at shoulder height, resting on a black pillow and covered by a canopy of white flowers. The funeral contained all the pomp the Soviet Communist Party, the government and the military could muster. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1965

headline: David Oyelowo Says Academy Rewards Black Actors in Subservient Roles
abstract: The actor reiterates the critique that Oscars rarely go to performers of color who are the protagonists.
lead_paragraph: David Oyelowo of “Selma” made news over the weekend by reiterating the idea that Hollywood was most comfortable with black actors in subservient roles.

headline: In Budget, Obama’s Unfettered Case for Spreading the Wealth
abstract: The 2016 budget indicates that President Obama feels newly free to outline an ambitious set of goals that will set the terms of a debate between the parties and shape the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama presented a budget on Monday that is more utopian vision than pragmatic blueprint. It proposes a politically improbable reshaping of the tax code and generous new social spending initiatives that would shift resources from the wealthy to the middle class.

headline: Jordan Sends Envoy Back to Israel as Tensions Ease
abstract: The envoy had been recalled three months ago because of strife at the site revered by Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and by Jews as the Temple Mount.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Jordan said on Monday that it was sending its ambassador back to Israel, three months after he was recalled in protest of what the Jordanians called Israeli violations at a contested holy site in East Jerusalem. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel welcomed the decision.

headline: Obama Proposes Tax for Upgrade of Infrastructure
abstract: A $478 billion construction spree would seek to upgrade roads, bridges and ports, using money from new taxes on overseas earnings by American companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s proposed budget envisions a nearly half-trillion-dollar transportation construction spree that would seek to upgrade the nation’s roads, bridges and ports by imposing new taxes on overseas earnings by American companies.

lead_paragraph: Choreographer Justin Peck observes New York City Ballet dancers during a rehearsal.

headline: Ukraine Rebels Upbeat After an Infusion of Aid
abstract: Rebels feel they are within reach of surrounding a contingent of hundreds of Ukrainian troops dug into Debaltseve, a crucial rail hub.
lead_paragraph: HORLIVKA, Ukraine — The rebel commander casually led the way down a muddy trench, shoulder high with shaved walls of moist earth, his boots slapping at wooden slabs sunk into the muck. Finally, he reached an earth-covered observation post.

headline: Two Bronze Sculptures Are Attributed to Michelangelo
abstract: Researchers believe that two works on display at the Fitzwilliam Museum at Cambridge University may be the only known surviving bronze sculptures by Michelangelo.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A group of experts, including art historians based at the University of Cambridge, researchers at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam and a professor of clinical anatomy from the University of Warwick, is claiming that two virile bronze figures mounted on panthers were sculpted by Michelangelo.

headline: An Exclusive Clip From a New Dance Documentary by a “Girls” Director
abstract: Jody Lee Lipes’s “Ballet 422″ follows the rising choreographer Justin Peck as he prepares his piece “Paz de La Jolla” for the New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: The uninitiated might see ballet as a sort of 19th-century relic, conjured to the stage by stern dance masters and ethereal waifs too beautiful to break a sweat. “Ballet 422,” a new documentary by the cinematographer-cum-filmmaker Jody Lee Lipes, which premieres tomorrow night at BAM, is an antidote to such illusions. Lipes, whose varied credits include “Martha Marcy May Marlene,” several episodes of “Girls,” a Jay Z video and the dance film “NY Export: Opus Jazz,” follows the rising choreographer Justin Peck as he creates an original work for the New York City Ballet (the company’s 422nd): “Paz de La Jolla,” a critically-lauded reverie set on the beaches of his native Southern California. Lipes captures the young dance-maker and his collaborators during every step of the two-month process, from the first choreographic sketches through costume and lighting design to the premiere. The result is a vivid, multifaceted depiction of the hard and necessary work of making art for the 21st century. In the exclusive clip above, Peck observes and corrects several of the company’s dazzlingly fast dancers during a rehearsal.

headline: Obama’s Priorities, in Budget Form
abstract: The president’s 2016 budget represents his policy aspirations as he begins negotiations with Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The president’s 2016 budget represents his policy aspirations as he begins negotiations with Republicans.

headline: Court Sets Up a Hurdle, Not a Barrier, for Insider Trading Cases
abstract: An appeals court ruling that narrows the grounds for insider trading cases may not be the cataclysm that the government contends it will be, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: It is interesting to see how a few words in a judicial opinion can mean so much. One sentence in the recent appeals court decision in United States v. Newman that overturned the convictions of two hedge fund traders has caused the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission to cry foul and ask for its removal, contending the statement will imperil the government’s efforts to crack down on insider trading.

headline: U.N. Weather Agency Confirms 2014 as Hottest Year
abstract: The World Meteorological Organization also said that 14 of the 15 warmest years on record had occurred in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: The World Meteorological Organization reported on Monday that 2014 was the hottest year in a historical record of global temperature dating from 1880. That finding confirms an announcement made last month by two American scientific agencies and one in Japan.

headline: Mayor Bill de Blasio Did Not Kill the Groundhog This Year
abstract: The useless ritual survives another year. So does Chuck.
lead_paragraph: The good news this morning: Mayor Bill de Blasio did not kill Chuck, the groundhog at the Staten Island Zoo whose otherwise cushy life requires a once-a-year photo op with the mayor on Groundhog Day. It’s an easy job but can be dangerous. Last year Mr. de Blasio, wearing bulky gloves, fumbled and dropped the groundhog; she hit the ground hard and died of internal injuries soon after. So this year the mayor kept his hands to himself.

headline: An Unexpected Bingo Call: You Can’t Play

lead_paragraph: All she wanted to do was play bingo.

lead_paragraph: Memoirs, graphic novels and stories in verse were the big winners of this year’s American Library Association’s awards for young adult and children’s literature. That question became even more relevant this week with the news that NATO’s military commander now supports providing defensive weapons to the Ukraine government.

What’s your call? Run or pass?

lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered a circuit in the brains of mice that controls thirst. Turn it on, and the mouse will drink regardless of how much water it has had. Turn it off, and the mouse avoids water.

headline: P.C. and the Political Left
keywords: ['Gender', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Responding to Jonathan Chait on the link between P.C. culture and national politics.
lead_paragraph: Not content with one long post on the argument over political correctness kicked off by Jonathan Chait, I wrote my Sunday column on some deeper impulses at work in the late-Obama left that I think are connected to the new P.C. — in particular, a sense of futility around economic policy, a renewed “post-post-racial” scrutiny of racial injustice, and a greater confidence, in the wake of the same-sex marriage debate, that a vanguard moral minority can become an ascendant majority in a swift cultural march.

headline: Don’t Be Afraid to Stand Apart From the Herd
abstract: Few decisions will feel riskier than making an investing choice that contradicts what everyone else is doing, but going against the crowd can be the right move.
lead_paragraph: What feels safe is often risky, and what feels risky is often safe. This statement contradicts just about every evolutionary instinct we possess. We tend to seek out safety and avoid risk whenever possible. A classic example has to be the instinct that (still) tells us we are safer staying with the group.

headline: A Comics Scholar Draws a New One of His Own
abstract: Scott McCloud, who has analyzed the methodology of the comic-book medium in works like “Understanding Comics,” has produced a new graphic novel, “The Sculptor.”
lead_paragraph: The cartoonist Scott McCloud has spent the last two decades examining, in a scholarly way, the medium of comic books. It began with “Understanding Comics” (1993), a primer, appreciation and history of the form, and stretched to “Making Comics” (2006), about technique, characters and creative choices.

headline: A Fresh Look at the Watery Side of Earth’s Climate Shows ‘Unabated Planetary Warming’
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Research']
abstract: New measurements show an unabated buildup of heat in the world’s oceans, mainly in the Southern Hemisphere.
lead_paragraph: A fresh analysis of thousands of temperature measurements from deep-diving Argo ocean probes shows (yet again) that Earth is experiencing “unabated planetary warming” when you factor in the vast amount of greenhouse-trapped heat that ends up in the sea. This is not even close to a new finding, but the new study shows more precisely where most of the heat has been going since 2006 (in the Southern Ocean outside the tropics; see the red splotches in the map below).

lead_paragraph: AFTER college, I joined the Peace Corps and eventually started working with refugee charitable organizations. When I started working with Catholic Relief Services, I had some travel under my belt, and now almost all of my work is focused on going to countries where people are in crisis, whether because of a natural disaster or war.

headline: For Mule Deer, an Incredible 150-Mile Migration
abstract: Capturing and collaring the animals looks a bit like a rodeo, but it’s all in the name of preservation.
lead_paragraph: THE RED DESERT, WYO. — As a small group of scientists and volunteers waits by the side of a gravel road here, a helicopter swoops down, carrying two blindfolded mule deer in slings. It hovers for a moment in a furious swirl of rotor-blown snow, detaching the deer slings. As it lifts and turns, the team runs into the stinging cloud.

headline: Tales of Dating, Whose Audience Is Also the Cast
abstract: “The Human Symphony,” Dylan Marron’s new play, is performed by six audience members taking instruction from MP3 tracks.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to participate in “The Human Symphony,” a playful, patchy and compassionate show conceived by Dylan Marron, a member of the New York Neo-Futurists. When you check in, you can pretend to be under 18, or you can invent a medical condition (“I will break out in hives,” I heard one woman threaten), or you can simply decline. But six willing spectators will be plucked from the audience and invited to the stage. There, Mr. Marron will hand each of them an MP3 player with a specialized track dictating a particular set of instructions.

headline: How Broadway Weathered Last Week’s Storm
abstract: Last week’s winter storm in the Northeast did only minimal damage to ticket sales for Broadway shows.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s winter storm in the Northeast did only minimal damage to ticket sales for Broadway shows, according to box-office data released on Monday. Broadway musicals and plays grossed $17.5 million for a total of 25 productions, compared to $16.7 million for 26 productions for the same week in January 2014. Attendance was 177,158 last week, compared to 183,092 a year ago. Shows benefited from the snow coming during a traditionally slow-selling week and on a night – Monday – when few performances are held anyway; and snowfall was below projections in New York City, leading most shows to resume performances on Tuesday.

headline: S.T.D. Care for Two
abstract: Some states let doctors give antibiotics to a patient and to a nonpatient sexual partner. But not all doctors are comfortable treating someone they haven’t seen.
lead_paragraph: Recently, while William, 21, was manning the chicken-wing fryer at a fast-food restaurant in suburban Seattle, he pulled aside his sort-of girlfriend, 18, a pizza deliverer there. He had bad news.

headline: Mayor Faces Groundhog in New Ceremony
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio took part in a new Groundhog Day ceremony meant to avoid a repeat of a falling rodent last year, with Staten Island Chuck emerging via elevator from his underground home.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio took part in a new Groundhog Day ceremony meant to avoid a repeat of a falling rodent last year, with Staten Island Chuck emerging via elevator from his underground home.

headline: Oil and Gas Prices Steady Despite a Refinery Strike
abstract: The United Steelworkers action comes as the nation is awash in fuel, though a lengthy strike could affect two-thirds of production.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices rose and gasoline prices remained low and stable on Monday, the opposite of what usually happens when labor strife threatens the operations of refineries.

headline: A Spirited Journey Backward, From Modernism to Classical
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet was at its most stylish in performances of the oldest work on its program, the Grand Pas from “Paquita,” at the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Mariinsky Ballet demonstrated on Saturday and Sunday that it is still one of the world’s supreme ballet companies. In the final week of its three-week visit to the United States, it produced its best dancing in the tour’s oldest ballet, the Grand Pas from “Paquita” (1881). In New York, the company’s way with classical style had seemed straitjacketed in its tempos and phrasing by its musical director, Valery Gergiev. He, however, stayed in New York to conduct the Metropolitan Opera and, at Carnegie Hall, the Mariinsky’s orchestra.

headline: Who’s Unreasonable Now?
abstract: Syriza is making sense.
lead_paragraph: OK, so as I understand the latest from the new Greek government, Yanis Varoufakis is saying that he and his colleagues don’t care what happens to the headline value of the debt — if you want to claim that there has been no write-off, OK. What they want instead is substantive but not outrageous relief from the burden of running primary surpluses (surpluses ex interest payments), reducing the amount of resources transferred to creditors from 4.5 to 1-1.5 percent of GDP; they also want flexibility to achieve these surpluses with a mix that includes more revenue and less spending austerity.

headline: Walkabout: Kayak Adds Cuba to Its Search Database
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: New Destinations Kayak, the travel search engine, will now include Cuba hotel and flight information in its search function. Information will now be listed for flights to Havana, Santiago de Cuba and other cities. (Newsweek)

headline: Apple to Open Giant Data Center in Arizona
abstract: The company plans to invest $2 billion in creating a data center in Mesa, Ariz., after it dropped plans to produce sapphire, a hardened and light material, at the facility.
lead_paragraph: When you’re as rich as Apple and life gives you lemons, you make data centers.

headline: The Young Lion Aesthetics Updated, but With an Earthy Intensity
abstract: Marquis Hill and his band, the Blacktet, performed in the Monk-in-Motion series at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: For much of the last decade, Marquis Hill fit the description of a prized local phenomenon. A dauntingly skilled trumpeter from the South Side of Chicago, he came up through that city’s jazz infrastructure, which extends to the classroom as well as the bandstand. He worked with a smart range of collaborators and made several albums, but the glowing reputation he’d earned was concentrated within a single metropolitan area.

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It’s always news in the opera world when an important singer takes on a touchstone role of the repertory for the first time. Preferably, an artist stepping up to such a challenge wants attention, but not too much.

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Serena Williams is now prepared to confess what led to her stumbling about the grass in a bizarre and brief doubles match at Wimbledon last year.

headline: Journal Eyes Corruption in India’s Medical Schools
abstract: Private Indian medical schools secretly charged admission fees of as much as $150,000 in addition to tuition, even though India’s Supreme Court banned such fees in 1992, according to two articles published in The BMJ.
lead_paragraph: A leading British medical journal has harshly attacked corruption in India’s medical schools.

headline: A Different Kind of Opening

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Outside China, he is best known as the man behind Mr. Chow — the high-end Chinese restaurants and longtime watering holes for artists and celebrities in London, New York, Beverly Hills, Miami Beach and Malibu.

lead_paragraph: A series of paintings by Leanne Shapton based on the book ‘Lucie Rie: a Survey of Her Life and Work.’

headline: A Planet With Rings That Dwarf Saturn’s
abstract: The planet, the first of its kind to be found outside our solar system, is surrounded by 30 rings, each tens of millions of kilometers in diameter.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have discovered a planet with a ring system that is 200 times larger than Saturn’s. The planet, the first of its kind to be found outside our solar system, is surrounded by 30 rings, each tens of millions of kilometers in diameter with large gaps that indicate the presence of small moons. The discovery, described in Astrophysical Journal, was made by scientists at the University of Rochester and Leiden Observatory in the Netherlands. They were investigating mysterious eclipses of the planet’s star, which turned out to be caused by the rings.

headline: A Path for Precision Medicine
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Medicine and Health', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Cancer', 'Diabetes', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Research', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The budget President Obama sent to Congress would establish a coordinated way for researchers to get genetic and clinical data on a million people.
lead_paragraph: For three years, Dr. Robert Green, a researcher at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School, has been painstakingly gathering genetic data on thousands of Alzheimer’s patients, trying to figure out whether genetic differences explain why the disease progresses over a quarter century in some people and kills others within five years. He has called in favors from colleagues and filled out the reams of paperwork required to share data across institutions, but still has only half of what he needs to do the analysis.

headline: A Struggle to Survive in Each Soulful Lyric
abstract: Bettye LaVette’s words rang with the conviction of someone who had emerged unbowed from a lifetime of setbacks as she performed her new album, “Worthy,” at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: I walked through a wall of fire

headline: A Grunge Aesthetic at the L.A. Art Book Fair
abstract: A diverse mix of Angelenos browsed 40,000 square feet of affordable zines, prints and editions over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, Los Angeles hosted three very different art fairs in three very different locales: Art Los Angeles Contemporary in Santa Monica, Paramount Ranch in Agoura Hills and Printed Matter’s L.A. Art Book Fair downtown. With 40,000 square feet worth of affordable zines, prints and editions on offer, the latter event was the most populist, and populous. For three days, the normally quiet streets of Little Tokyo teemed with pedestrians as art lovers, thrill-seeking teenagers and curious onlookers migrating from the Hello Kitty exhibition next door crowded the Geffen Contemporary at MOCA. Live bands and food trucks lent a music-festival feel; fittingly, the fashion on view tended toward the grungy, with black-on-black layers and mom jeans (on both men and women) among the more visible trends. The style outliers, many of whom were exhibitors, took things a step further. Highlights included statement shoes, sparkling face paint and multiples of “symbolic jewelry” from the artist Tauba Auerbach, whose Diagonal Press hosted a booth at the fair. The photographer Laure Joliet was on hand to capture the action for T.

headline: Releases From Bob Dylan and Diana Krall
abstract: Bob Dylan’s “Shadows in the Night,” an album of 10 songs that were all recorded by Frank Sinatra, is a tribute from one venerated American musician to another.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a put-on. Bob Dylan’s “Shadows in the Night,” an album of 10 songs that were all recorded by Frank Sinatra, is a tribute from one venerated American musician to another, a reconsideration of a school of songwriting, a feat of technical nostalgia and a reckoning with love and death.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Wants to Override State Laws Curbing Community Net Services

lead_paragraph: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, will propose an order to pre-empt state laws that limit the build-out of municipal broadband Internet services, senior F.C.C. officials said on Monday.

headline: Closing Education Gap Will Lift Economy, a Study Finds

headline: Viewing a Composer in a New Light
abstract: At an authoritative recital at Alice Tully Hall, Garrick Ohlsson set Alexander Scriabin in his Russian context, with Prokofiev and Rachmaninoff.
lead_paragraph: “It may be true that the Russian composer is too far advanced for the present generation and that his doctrine and music will be accepted in years to come,” the Musical Courier wrote of Alexander Scriabin in March 1915, a month before that composer’s early death. “But as the writer is not a reader of the future, the work is condemned for the present.”

headline: Maternal Depression Often Starts Before Giving Birth, Study Says
abstract: Unexpected links in the timing and severity of symptoms have been documented, which could help mothers and doctors better anticipate and treat the condition.
lead_paragraph: A large new study has documented unexpected links in the timing and severity of symptoms of maternal depression, which could help mothers and doctors better anticipate and treat the condition.

Chris Christie of New Jersey, a fellow Republican, and inserting himself into a hot debate that will likely resurface if the senator runs for president.

headline: Video Analysis Suggests Egyptian Officer Shot Protester, Rights Group Says
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

headline: Jeep Cherokees to Be Recalled to Upgrade Airbag Software
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Chrysler will recall more than 228,000 vehicles because their airbags could unexpectedly inflate without a crash.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler will recall more than 228,000 vehicles because their airbags could unexpectedly inflate without a crash. The company will upgrade software governing side-curtain and seat-mounted side airbags in Jeep Cherokees from the 2014-15 model years, including more than 168,000 vehicles in the United States. Chrysler engineers initiated an investigation after getting reports of “a small number of inadvertent deployments involving drivers who executed extreme maneuvers.” In these cases, the airbag systems, sensing potential rollovers, automatically activated. The action follows a much larger recall for inadvertent airbag deployments announced on Saturday by regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That recall covers about 2.1 million vehicles made by Chrysler, Toyota and Honda with airbags that might suddenly deploy.

headline: Catholics Fear Campaign of Church Attacks in India
abstract: At least five Roman Catholic churches in and around Delhi have reported various episodes, including suspected arson, burglary, vandalism and stone-throwing.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A series of episodes at churches over the last two months has prompted Roman Catholics here to worry about a deliberate campaign of violence, and to call on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to speak out against religious intimidation.

headline: Trial Begins in Hit and Run That Killed Expectant Brooklyn Couple
abstract: Julio Acevedo is charged with manslaughter and leaving the scene of an accident in the deaths of Raizy and Nathan Glauber in Williamsburg in 2013.
lead_paragraph: It was Saturday night in Orthodox Williamsburg, and Shabbos had ended not long before. Raizy Glauber, who was almost seven months pregnant, was leaving her parents’ house with her husband, Nathan. She affectionately tapped her older brother, Joseph Silberstein, on the shoulder as he entered the house and they left.

headline: France’s Ideals, Forged in Revolution, Face a Modern Test
abstract: A debate over what it means to be French — and whether that definition can make room for its growing Muslim population.
lead_paragraph: CLICHY-SOUS-BOIS, France — In the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo attacks, France has begun a defensive but potentially decisive debate over what it means to be French — and whether that definition can make room for its vibrant, growing Muslim population.

headline: Want More Vaccinated Kids? End Religious and Personal Exemptions.
abstract: There is no need to silence or punish parents who choose not to vaccinate their children. If we end exemptions to vaccine requirements for public school attendance, most parents will make a different choice.
lead_paragraph: There is a simple and effective way to decrease the number of parents who choose not to vaccinate their children against preventable diseases, and it doesn’t require suing those parents or criminally charging them. Instead, state legislatures need to end both religious and personal exemptions to the requirement that children be vaccinated in order to attend public schools. A strict vaccine requirement — without loopholes — is all it would take to reduce the numbers of unvaccinated children to levels that would allow us to maximize protection for everyone.

headline: U.S. Declines to Prosecute News Corporation Phone Hacking
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The Justice Department will not pursue charges against the News Corporation or 21st Century Fox for phone hacking and payments to public officials done in Britain.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department will not prosecute Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation or 21st Century Fox over voice mail interceptions and payments to public officials, actions done by their journalists in London, the companies said on Monday.

headline: A New Sandals in Barbados
abstract: Sandals Barbados, which recently opened, is a couples-only resort with 11 restaurants and three pools.
lead_paragraph: The new couples-only Sandals Barbados, which opened late last month, is poised to be one of the most upscale in the group of 15 all-inclusive resorts.

headline: Belgium: Man Accused of Threat Close to Parliament
abstract: A man with a gun and a chain saw in his car was detained Monday by the police near the European Parliament, prompting the temporary evacuation of several buildings.
lead_paragraph: A man with a gun and a chain saw in his car was detained Monday by the police near the European Parliament, prompting the temporary evacuation of several buildings. The man, a Slovakian citizen born in 1982 and identified only as W.R., was dressed in camouflage and sought a meeting with the Parliament’s president, according to a statement by the Brussels prosecutor’s office. He was arrested, accused of threatening an attack and possessing unauthorized weapons. Belgium has been on alert since recent raids in which the authorities killed two men suspected of planning a terrorist attack.

headline: North Korea: Investigator Rules Out Reforms by Kim
abstract: The special United Nations investigator of human rights abuses in North Korea suggested that the ruling Kim family must be replaced before the country’s extensive network of prison camps can be broken up.
lead_paragraph: The special United Nations investigator of human rights abuses in North Korea suggested in an interview published Monday that the ruling Kim family must be replaced before the country’s extensive network of prison camps can be broken up. The investigator, Marzuki Darusman, emphasized in the interview with The Associated Press that he was not advocating force to oust North Korea’s government. But in discussing how to end abuses, most notably in the North’s penal system, he was quoted as saying: “That can only happen if this cult leadership system is completely dismantled. And the only way to do that is if the Kim family is effectively displaced, is effectively removed from the scene, and a new leadership comes into place.” North Korea’s rights abuses were documented in a United Nations report published last year, which the government of Kim Jong-un has denounced as propaganda orchestrated by the United States.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Ratifies Musicians’ Contract
abstract: The new contract, which will run through November 2018, provides for a new base minimum salary in the first year of $2,892 a week — the third highest in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In a reminder that labor negotiations in the world of classical music are not always marked by disharmony, the San Francisco Symphony announced Monday that it had ratified a new contract that would keep its players among the best-paid in the world.

Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, has said repeatedly. Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, told lawmakers, “Apple has recommended to the Obama administration and several members of Congress — and suggests to the subcommittee today — to pass legislation that dramatically simplifies the U.S. corporate tax system.”

headline: Measles Outbreak Proves Delicate Issue to G.O.P. Field
keywords: ['Measles', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The national debate on measles and immunization poses a challenge for Republican presidential hopefuls, who must reconcile modern science with the skepticism of their core conservative voters.

headline: President Obama’s New Budget

headline: Pharmacies in Venezuela Are Accused of ‘Sabotage’
abstract: The Venezuelan authorities detained several executives of a pharmacy chain, which President Nicolás Maduro accused of orchestrating long lines to sow discontent.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The authorities detained several executives of the country’s top pharmacy chain over the weekend amid accusations that retailers were seeking to maintain long lines outside stores as part of what President Nicolás Maduro called a “guerrilla tactic” to sow discontent in the economically beleaguered nation.

headline: Bratton Says Terrorism and Protests Will Be Handled by Separate Police Units
abstract: The New York Police Department will soon have two new groupings of officers: a heavily armed unit to combat terrorism, and a mobile unit for more common events, like protests.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department will soon have two new groupings of officers: a heavily armed unit given the task of combating terrorism, and a mobile unit trained to handle more common events, like protests and neighborhood crime spikes.

headline: A Heated Path Toward S.&P.’s Legal Settlement With Prosecutors
abstract: An overflow crowd of government regulators spent a day last month ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement of an array of lawsuits against S.&P.
lead_paragraph: When lawyers for Standard & Poor’s traveled to the Justice Department in Washington last month, they hoped to settle an array of government lawsuits and extinguish two years of bad blood. But within minutes of arriving, their plan collided with the demands of government negotiators — all 25 who attended.

headline: True Hero for Patriots Put Rookie Butler in Spotlight
abstract: Cornerback Brandon Browner cleared the way for Malcolm Butler to make the interception that saved the Super Bowl for New England.
lead_paragraph: With less than a minute remaining in the Super Bowl on Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks lined up in a three-wide-receiver set at the 1-yard line. To the right of quarterback Russell Wilson, Ricardo Lockette stood nearly directly behind another wide receiver, Jermaine Kearse, a yard back and on Kearse’s outside shoulder — an alignment commonly used on pick plays.

headline: Lands’ End, Post Sears, Replaces Its Chief
abstract: Lands’ End announced that the president of Dolce & Gabbana would replace its chief executive, offering clues about the brand’s new direction.
lead_paragraph: Lands’ End announced on Monday that it would replace its chief executive with the president of the high-end Italian fashion label Dolce & Gabbana, offering clues about the classic American brand’s new direction months after it separated from the Sears Holding Corporation.

headline: Uber to Open Center for Research on Self-Driving Cars

headline: Nailed the Test

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Now here’s a Tuesday puzzle I can get behind. When you’ve been solving for a while and love the late-week challenges, you might start to feel like you are still doing the early-week puzzles out of a sort of loyalty. In my case, it’s to feel smart. Once in a while, however, you have to shake things up. Joe Krozel is back and, as usual, he’s stirring the pot.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday is set to declare housing as the focal point of his second year in office, unveiling a vision for an even denser yet more affordable New York City that will transform neighborhoods from East Harlem in Manhattan to Staten Island’s North Shore.

headline: Rangers Put a Damper on the Panthers’ Postseason Hopes
abstract: Dan Boyle’s deflected goal in the third period put the Rangers ahead to stay in a 6-3 victory over the Panthers, who are trying to earn a postseason berth for only the second time since the 1999-2000 season.
lead_paragraph: Flush with young talent, and with a smattering of accomplished veterans, the Florida Panthers are the leading team among the Eastern Conference’s also-rans, perhaps the only squad outside the top eight that still has a chance at a playoff spot.

lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Nearly two years after injuring her right knee in a horrific crash, Lindsey Vonn was primed to compete in Tuesday’s super-G, the opening race of the 2015 Alpine World Championships here.

headline: Drug Makers’ Data on Side Effects Is Called Lacking in a Report
abstract: A new report from the Institute for Safe Medication Practices found only about half of reports of serious side effects submitted by manufacturers met basic standards for completeness.
lead_paragraph: The main system for keeping track of the dangerous side effects of prescription drugs is deeply flawed, primarily because drug makers are submitting incomplete information about the problems to the Food and Drug Administration, according to a new study by a nonprofit group that tracks drug safety issues.

headline: Super Bowl Was a Stunner, and That’s Just the Size of the TV Audience
abstract: New England’s 28-24 victory Sunday attracted a record 114.4 million viewers, more than the average of 112.2 million who tuned in live to Seattle’s 43-8 rout of Denver last year.
lead_paragraph: The other day I suggested that even a lousy game can yield sensational Super Bowl viewership, which happened last year. But a game that is incredible, surprising, tightly played and has everything but an elf on the sideline deflating balls?

headline: Inside Mercado Roma, Mexico City’s Newest Foodie Destination
abstract: For those in town for this year’s Zona Maco International Contemporary Art Fair, a new food hall offers up a range of local flavors — and an internationally-sourced biergarten.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow, more than 120 galleries from 22 countries will descend upon Mexico City for the 12th edition of the Zona Maco International Contemporary Art Fair. And this year, the art set has a new culinary destination to hit up between booth visits: Mercado Roma. Situated in the hipster neighborhood of La Roma, the bustling food market, which opened last summer, takes its cues from sleek stateside food halls like Manhattan’s Chelsea Market. There are communal tables set against a vertical garden out back, where guests can enjoy prepared foods and artisanal treats from approximately 60 vendors, most of whom produce local, farm-to-table dishes and desserts.

lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general’s office accused four major retailers on Monday of selling fraudulent and potentially dangerous herbal supplements and demanded that they remove the products from their shelves.

headline: What’s in Those Supplements?
abstract: New York’s attorney general said that tests on popular store brands of herbal supplements at Walmart, Walgreens, Target and GNC found that roughly four out of five of the products contained none of the herbs listed on the labels.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general’s office accused four national retailers on Monday of selling dietary supplements that were fraudulent and in many cases contaminated with unlisted ingredients.

headline: President Tweaks the Rules on Data Collection
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Intelligence analysts will be required to delete private information they may incidentally collect about Americans that has no intelligence purpose.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year after President Obama ordered modest changes in how the nation’s intelligence agencies collect and hold data on Americans and foreigners, the administration will announce new rules requiring intelligence analysts to delete private information they may incidentally collect about Americans that has no intelligence purpose, and to delete similar information about foreigners within five years.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE KING’S SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, in the role that won him an Oscar for best actor, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps Bertie conquer a debilitating stutter. And Helena Bonham Carter is Elizabeth, Albert’s wife and staunch support system, who can’t quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the American divorcée who leads Bertie’s older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. “It isn’t exactly ‘Pygmalion,’ not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movie’s biggest draws,” Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 Oscar nominations and also won for best director, best picture and original screenplay. “Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type,” she added, “ ‘The King’s Speech’ wears history lightly no matter how heavy the crown.”

headline: Alibaba and Lending Club to Form Financing Partnership

lead_paragraph: The companies behind two of the hottest stock market debuts of 2014, Lending Club and the Alibaba Group, are teaming up — to help American companies buy parts from Chinese manufacturers.

headline: China Considers Whether to Allow Baijiu With Bling
abstract: China’s National Health and Family Planning Commission announced last month that it was soliciting professional opinion on whether to approve adding gold flakes to baijiu, a powerful Chinese liquor.
lead_paragraph: Among the casualties in China’s continuing crackdown on corruption have been the spirits makers who sell to the country’s monied elite. With ostentatious imbibing now highly frowned upon, the makers of liquor like baijiu have seen serious hits to sales growth over the past two years.

headline: Central Banks in India and Australia Take Steps to Lift Growth
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In India, the reserve requirement for banks was lowered, freeing up money to lend, and Australia cut short-term interest rates to a low.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Two more central banks have joined the growing international trend toward monetary stimulus as an antidote for weak global demand, as India on Tuesday reduced the reserves that commercial banks must hold while Australia cut its benchmark interest rate to a low.

headline: ‘Coming Out’ as Anxious
abstract: Would it be therapeutic to publicly reveal my psychiatric condition?
lead_paragraph: When I was 10, I was diagnosed with a collection of anxiety disorders. For the next three and a half decades, I hid my condition from those around me. I concocted elaborate explanations for the absences caused by my therapy appointments. I kept my medications out of sight. I generally did everything I could to project an aura of competence and confidence that was often at odds with the vulnerability, and sometimes the terror, that I felt.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Secret Decisions
abstract: Each year, it issues thousands of rulings with no transparency.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A CONVICTED murderer, Charles F. Warner, was executed in Oklahoma last month after the United States Supreme Court denied his request for a last-minute stay. Mr. Warner and other death-row inmates had challenged the state’s lethal injection procedures as unconstitutional. In a strange twist, the court agreed to hear his claims — a week after Mr. Warner had been executed.

headline: Government Handouts at Wireless Auctions

lead_paragraph: Large telecommunications companies have repeatedly taken advantage of rules meant to help small, rural, female- and minority-owned businesses buy licenses for airwaves for wireless phone and data transmission, including in a recent auction that raised nearly $45 billion for the government. Congress and the Federal Communications Commission should crack down on such abuse.

lead_paragraph: THE pattern is striking. Men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives. In many cases, the charges of domestic violence were not taken seriously or were dismissed.

headline: Building Better Secularists
keywords: ['Atheism', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Today’s secularism speaks convincingly to the rational mind, but it must speak to the whole human heart if it is to serve as a guide for life.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few years, there has been a sharp rise in the number of people who are atheist, agnostic or without religious affiliation. A fifth of all adults and a third of the youngest adults fit into this category.

headline: Measles and the Vaccine Opponents
abstract: Readers respond to an article about criticism of anti-vaccination parents as cases of measles spread.

headline: Reckless Rejection of the Measles Vaccine
abstract: Misguided parents are endangering their own children and others by eschewing a vaccine that federal health officials deem at least 95 percent effective.
lead_paragraph: It is bad enough that many misguided parents are endangering their own children by refusing to let them be vaccinated against measles and other contagious diseases. But it is shockingly irresponsible of them to put other children and adults at risk of catching measles from their unvaccinated children.

headline: Inside Syria’s Jails
abstract: The screams of the tortured were unbearable; I nearly lost my mind. I feel lucky just to be alive.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the spring of 2011, hundreds of thousands of Syrians rose up in protest to demand democracy and freedom and an end to the dictatorship of President Bashar al-Assad. The response of the regime was to escalate the methods of repression that had been tried and tested against political opponents since the 1970s: arbitrary detention, disappearance and torture.

lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, students in a youth orchestra program in Chile pursue their love of music to escape poverty.

lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, my home country of Chile has had a stable democracy, as well as a thriving economy. At the same time, Chile has one of the largest wealth disparities in the world, reinforced by high tuition rates for secondary and college education.

headline: The Tough Path Facing Chris Christie and Marco Rubio
abstract: Jeb Bush appears to have substantial support from the same Republican officials and donors whom Mr. Christie and Mr. Rubio would probably need.
lead_paragraph: The end of Mitt Romney’s candidacy has brought the so-called invisible primary — the behind-the-scenes competition for the resources and credibility needed to win the nomination — into a new phase, with new players. Marco Rubio and Chris Christie, in particular, seem as if they might benefit. The two are racing against Jeb Bush to earn the support of Mr. Romney’s former supporters, according to my colleague Nicholas Confessore.

lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission this week is widely expected to propose regulating Internet service like a public utility, a move certain to unleash another round of intense debate and lobbying about how to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet, Steve Lohr reports.

lead_paragraph: On a cold, dark street in Tijuana, Mexico, I asked Eddie Huang a question that many people were sure to ask him in the months to come. “What did you expect?”

headline: Art for Money’s Sake
abstract: As art becomes a popular investment vehicle, the market for storage is booming.
lead_paragraph: You could be forgiven for thinking the boxy structure that opened last November in Long Island City, Queens, with gray-and-white stripes flanking a blue frontispiece, was a bold new art museum. The modern-looking facility, built from the ground up at a cost of $70 million, is set to span 280,000 square feet when an adjacent building opens this spring. The complex will be packed with thousands of works of art, from old masters to contemporary rising stars. But unlike at a museum, few will ever see the works that live inside it.

headline: A Republican Joins Obama in Seeking Ties to Cuba
abstract: Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona has waged a long and lonely battle against fellow Republicans to push for easing restrictions on Cuba, and now the White House is counting on him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two days before President Obama  ended a half-century of diplomatic estrangement with Cuba, his national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, asked Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona to be the only Republican on a secret flight to Havana to bring home a jailed American, Alan P. Gross — and to tell no one.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Road to S.&P.’s Settlement
abstract: S.&.P.’s settlement ends a heated, two-year fight with regulators. | President Obama’s corporate tax reform irks the business world. | Slump in oil prices brings pressure. | Ally chief steps down.
lead_paragraph: THE ROAD TO S.&P.’S SETTLEMENT | An overflow crowd of government regulators, including attorneys general from states across the country, spent a day in January ticking off their demands before eventually negotiating a $1.37 billion settlement with the giant ratings agency Standard & Poor’s, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. The settlement, expected to be announced on Tuesday, was the culmination of a heated, two-year fight between S.&P. and the Justice Department, according to an account assembled through interviews.

headline: A Plan Is Slow to Take Shape
abstract: The beloved triangle of Phil Jackson, the Knicks’ president, has so far been seen as a failed experiment, but ultimate success would burnish his basketball legacy beyond wins and losses.
lead_paragraph: There were 60 million good reasons for Phil Jackson to accept the formidable challenge of rebuilding the Knicks along with one intangible benefit that could not be banked. Some might think the one he chose, however, borders on obsession: to resurrect his beloved triangle and prove to the world that it is an offense for the ages.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Harrowing Descent Into War
abstract: “Liberian Girl,” a debut play by Diana Nneka Atuona, forces its audience to confront a violent coming of age.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The boys with the rifles separated us according to sex, the men forced into one group and the women into the other. Most of us complied, a startled and sheeplike herd.

headline: Tough Fedding
abstract: Aiee! Seriously.
lead_paragraph: The monetary-policy gap between insiders and outsiders — between economists at the Fed and other policy institutions, who still seem eager to raise rates, and those of us on the outside, who think this is a really, really bad idea — continues to widen. This morning Tim Duy — one of the outsiders who, commenting from his perch at Mark Thoma’s invaluable blog, has seemed most sympathetic to the urge to hike rates — joins the what-are-they-thinking chorus. Core inflation is drifting downward, not upward, and is now well below the Fed’s target. So why hike?

headline: Comedy Material Woven From Real Life
abstract: “Schitt’s Creek,” a new series starring Catherine O’Hara and Eugene Levy on the cable channel Pop, is a family collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Having worked together on and off for more than 40 years, Catherine O’Hara and Eugene Levy can withstand almost anything one says about the other, unless it is complimentary.

headline: Cisco Makes Its Annual Predictions on Mobile Data Traffic
abstract: Cisco’s annual outlook for mobile traffic projects a tenfold increase in mobile traffic, at higher speeds, between 2014 and 2019. Even more traffic is expected to go over Wi-Fi networks.
lead_paragraph: If everybody has a smartphone, maybe we’ll soon just start calling them phones.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
abstract: Last week, we looked at near-miss word choices. This week, a round-up of homophone problems, many of them familiar by now. Put them on your list — and look them up every time if you need to.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we looked at near-miss word choices. This week, a roundup of homophone problems, many of them familiar by now. Put them on your list — and look them up every time if you need to.

headline: For Transgender Students, Business Schools Are a Transition
abstract: M.B.A. programs, long bastions of male dominance and conservatism, face a gender-identity challenge.
lead_paragraph: It was 2 a.m. when Danielle Piergallini composed an email to classmates at Vanderbilt University’s Owen Graduate School of Management announcing she was transgender. She had spent her first semester in the M.B.A. program presenting as male and worried what kind of response she would get after she clicked “send.”

headline: A University Recognizes a Third Gender: Neutral
abstract: Rocko Gieselman goes by the pronoun “they.” Acknowledging the next step in identity politics, the University of Vermont has agreed to use it.
lead_paragraph: Rocko Gieselman looked like any other undergraduate at the University of Vermont but perhaps a little prettier, with pale freckles dancing across porcelain skin and bright blue eyes amplifying a broad smile. Black bra straps poked out from a faded black tank top emblazoned with the logo of the indie band Rubblebucket; a silver necklace with an anchor dangled over ample décolletage.

headline: In Performance: Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske of ‘Everybody Gets Cake!’
abstract: An excerpt from a new show by the comedy troupe Parallel Exit.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the performers Ryan Kasprzak and Joel Jeske in an excerpt from “Everybody Gets Cake!,” a new show from the comedy troupe Parallel Exit. The scene takes place at an unusually taxing taping of a public service announcement about Novocain abuse. In his review, Neil Genzlinger called the skit “pretty hilarious.” The show, directed by Mark Lonergan, continues through Feb. 8 at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Viktor & Rolf Hop Off the Ready-to-Wear Treadmill
abstract: Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren have announced that after 14 years of ready-to-wear, the March show in Paris will be their last in the collection.
lead_paragraph: Well, this is a turn of the fashion wheel I did not see coming: A season after Jean Paul Gaultier announced he was closing his ready-to-wear line to concentrate on couture, the Dutch designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, otherwise known as Viktor & Rolf, have followed suit.

headline: Grid Sensors Could Ease Disruptions of Power
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Sensors']
abstract: Utilities are experimenting with new systems that can monitor the flow of electricity and pinpoint failures more quickly, perhaps even avoiding them.
lead_paragraph: For decades, utility companies have relied on customers telling them when their lights have gone off as a sign that there may be a broader power disruption. The utilities then send workers to drive along mile after mile of power lines, looking for tiny devices — little red circular tabs — that have popped up, signaling the source of the problem in the network.

headline: A Solo Traveler’s Guide to Meeting People

abstract: Some tips on how to connect with other single travelers or locals and ensure your safety amid all the fun.

headline: In London, an Olympic Park Anchors a Resurgence
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2012)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Swimming', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cycling, Track']
abstract: The centerpiece of Stratford’s regeneration is the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, the 560-acre tract where the 2012 Games took place.
lead_paragraph: Before London snagged the 2012 Olympic Games, Stratford — due east of Hackney, on the banks of the Lea River — was among the poorest areas of the capital, renowned mostly for its industrial pylons and its “fridge mountain,” an imposing fortress of discarded appliances, along its waterfront. More than nine years and £9 billion (about $13 billion) later, the industrial wetlands have been transformed into a gleaming sports and shopping hub.

headline: New York Times Co. Profit Falls Despite Strides in Digital Ads
abstract: Outlays for digital journalism and severance costs cut into profit for 2014, but digital ad revenue rose 19 percent in the quarter compared with last year.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company said on Tuesday that its annual operating profit declined in 2014 because of investments in digital journalism and severance costs from a round of job reductions. Revenue was flat as growth in digital advertising and circulation offset declines in its print business.

headline: CCTV Appoints Hosts for Lunar New Year Gala, With Some Surprises
abstract: The television station announced the eight presenters who will host this year’s Spring Festival Gala, and for the first time, an ethnic Uighur is among them.
lead_paragraph: Lunar New Year celebrations in China are typically marked by travel back home, dumplings with family members and, on New Year’s Eve, the Spring Festival Gala on China Central Television.

headline: Baccarat’s Crystal Palace
abstract: Unsurprisingly, the grand mansion, designed by Patrick Gilles and Dorothée Boissier, is a shiny affair.
lead_paragraph: Not surprisingly, the new Baccarat Hotel, a grand mansion opening next month in midtown Manhattan, is a shiny affair. The French designers Patrick Gilles and Dorothée Boissier have adorned lamps, walls, arches and even armchairs with the company’s gleaming crystal. Thousands of backlit Harcourt tumblers — Baccarat’s most iconic design — flank the entrance, and tiered chandeliers hung from slack hemp-covered chains intensify deep red walls in the bar. The sumptuous guest rooms, bathed in crisp whites and grays, mix elegance with informality — which, says Boissier, “is so not French.”

headline: Saudi Oil Is Seen as Lever to Pry Russian Support From Syria’s Assad
abstract: Talks have centered on persuading President Vladimir V. Putin to stop backing the Syrian president, officials said, in return for moves to raise the price of oil, which could bolster Russia’s economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia has been trying to pressure President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to abandon his support for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, using its dominance of the global oil markets at a time when the Russian government is reeling from the effects of plummeting oil prices.

headline: A Gender-Neutral Glossary
abstract: Students are developing an evolving vocabulary for gender and identity. Here’s a sampling.
lead_paragraph: SEX Classification as male or female or, rarely, intersex (not exclusively male or female). Sex is usually assigned based on external anatomy but is determined by characteristics like chromosomes, hormones and reproductive organs.

headline: Is Book Reviewing a Public Service or an Art?

lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Anna Holmes debate whether book reviewing should be considered a public service or an art.

headline: Richard Linklater and Ellar Coltrane on ‘Nerding Up’
abstract: The director and star of “Boyhood” agree that the main character was much less hip than the actor playing him.
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater’s crowning cinematic achievement, “Boyhood,” seems locked neck-and-neck with Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” in the race for best picture. Yet way back in the early aughts, when Mr. Linklater decided to move ahead with his idea of filming a fictional family over a dozen years, he wasn’t sure if such a movie could even work. The idea hinged on finding the right boy, which Mr. Linklater did in Ellar Coltrane, who was cast when he was 6.

headline: For the Prickliest Patients, a Desert Doctor Makes House Calls
abstract: Homeowners in Arizona often call Rilée Leblanc, known as the “cactus doctor,” who has turned a passion for the plants into a business.
lead_paragraph: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. — The aging patient, prickly and stiff, loomed over the doctor, showing a number of troubling signs. The doctor noted poor posture, callused skin, limbs pocked with deep scars. He feared survival would hinge on drastic action, maybe even an amputation.

headline: 1940: Rationing May Be Started
keywords: ['Food', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French officials consider wartime food rationing in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Paris newspapers yesterday [Feb. 3]  published articles intimating that ration  cards for at least a few food products  may be introduced in the capital, if not in  all of France. Thus far in the war, France  alone of the belligerents has not introduced the ration system. Several newspapers also announced the fact that the  Seine Department General Council on  December 30 passed a resolution asking  that ration cards for sugar, coffee, oil,  macaroni and spaghetti be issued within  the department. At the same time, it was  revealed that ration cards were printed  by the government in 1937 and distributed to town halls throughout the nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1940

headline: Harper Lee, Author of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird,’ Is to Publish a Second Novel
abstract: The new book, “Go Set a Watchman,” focuses on the character of Scout as an adult, and was written in the 1950s. It will be published in July.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, “To Kill a Mockingbird” has stood apart as a singular American literary masterpiece, a perennial best seller that has provoked countless classroom discussions about racial and social injustice. It brought instant and overwhelming fame to its enigmatic author, Harper Lee, who soon retreated from the spotlight to her native Monroeville, Ala. She never published another book, leaving her millions of fans yearning for more.

headline: Apparent Discount Mars $41 Billion Spectrum Sale
abstract: A 25 percent “small business” discount claimed by Dish Network is helping the pay-TV company add to its unused stockpile and outbid rival operators that badly need capacity, contends Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The United States government has made a windfall. Some $41 billion of bids in its latest radio spectrum sale added up to about twice as much as expected. But the small print is making the auction look flawed. By bidding through entities it doesn’t fully control, the $33 billion Dish Network seems to have secured a 25 percent price discount aimed at small businesses.

Moaz al-Kasasbeh, they tried to keep it from his mother, Issaf, and his wife, Anwar. They switched off the television and tried to wrest a smartphone out of his wife’s hand, but she had already seen a mobile news bulletin.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the final day of his trade mission to Britain, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey met with titans of London finance, visited a drug rehabilitation center, dined with the chancellor of the Exchequer and took in a rehearsal of “Henry V” at Shakespeare’s Globe.

headline: The Right Way to Pay Ransoms to Terrorists
abstract: Create incentives for kidnappers to break ranks with one another.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — IT all began in 2003, when a German official flew into the wilds of northern Mali with three suitcases full of cash to secure the release of 14 European hostages. That first big ransom breathed life into the militant group known as Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, and laid the groundwork for a kidnap economy that now finances Islamist extremist groups around the globe.

headline: Secondhand Smoke Exposure Drops, C.D.C. Reports
abstract: The share of American nonsmokers exposed to secondhand smoke fell to 25 percent in 2012 from 53 percent in 2000, according to an analysis of health data.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ exposure to secondhand smoke has declined by half since 2000, federal health authorities reported Tuesday, as states and municipalities banned smoking in bars, restaurants and offices, and fewer Americans smoked inside their homes.

headline: Macroeconomic Cronyism
abstract: Putin invents something new.
lead_paragraph: My old teacher Rudi Dornbusch — whose presence is sorely missed in this world gone mad — once wrote an influential analysis, with Sebastian Edwards, of what they called macroeconomic populism. This is the historical tendency of some (not all) populist governments to engage in wishful thinking, to believe that they can repeal the usual rules — that they can indefinitely contain inflation in an overheated economy with price controls, that they can ignore limits on capacity, etc..

headline: Fiat Chrysler Profit in U.S. Declined 56% in 2014 on Charges From Merger

headline: Thom Tillis on Burdensome Regulations, Like Hand-Washing at Restaurants
abstract: The Republican senator suggested restaurants could opt out of certain health rules as long as they posted a sign explaining their policy.
lead_paragraph: It is often hard to tell whether Republican legislators are joking, because so many of the things they say are unintentionally funny. So I don’t know whether Senator Thom Tillis, Republican of North Carolina, was trying to be a latter day Jonathan Swift or was perfectly serious when he said restaurants are over-regulated and should not be required to tell employees to wash their hands after using the toilet.
