abstract: Pilling, who spent the last nine years at the sports marketing firm IMG College, arrives as Columbia tries to overhaul its moribund football program.
lead_paragraph: Columbia has hired Peter Pilling, a vice president at IMG College, the sports marketing firm, to be its next athletic director, the university said Tuesday.

headline: A Cultish French Shoe Brand From an Alumna of Louboutin and Pierre Hardy
abstract: Solovière, which launched with men’s footwear last year, has recently expanded into women’s sizing, thanks to a request from Colette.
lead_paragraph: “The ideal men’s footwear symbolizes power, taste and singularity,” the French shoe designer Alexia Aubert says. “Those are the qualities I’m attuned to in a man.” Aubert, who started her career assisting Christian Louboutin, went on to run the studio at Pierre Hardy and to transform the footwear division at Oscar de la Renta from a collection of licensing agreements into a proper design collection. Since then, she’s been consulting for various brands (including Mulberry and Balmain) and, last year, launched her own line of footwear, initially intended for men. She deems Solovière — named after her maternal grandfather — “a laboratory for new classics.” And her latest experiment came at the request of the Parisian boutique Colette: to offer additional sizes, effectively making some of her designs unisex.

headline: New York Philharmonic to Celebrate 50 Years of Concerts in the Parks
abstract: The Philharmonic will perform across New York City this summer in June, marking the 50th anniversary of its free series of park concerts.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic will mark the 50th anniversary of its free parks concerts this June with Alan Gilbert leading the orchestra in a program of American music on Central Park’s Great Lawn featuring the violinist Joshua Bell performing a suite from “West Side Story.”

headline: Senate Democrats Block Republicans’ Homeland Security Bill
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Money for the Department of Homeland Security runs out on Feb. 27 unless the Congress acts, but the G.O.P. wants to withhold money to stop President Obama’s immigration policies..
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Tuesday blocked a Republican bill that would finance the Department of Homeland Security, objecting to a measure that would have gutted President Obama’s recent executive actions on immigration. The vote set up an urgent confrontation over the department, which will see its funding run out at the end of the month.

headline: 1965: Connoisseurs Steal Paintings
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: sophisticated thieves rob a château in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A sophisticated gang of thieves carted off four paintings and silverware worth $400,000 from a château east of Paris, it was learned today [Feb. 3]. The theft was the latest in a series of about 60 committed in châteaus, mainly in the Paris region in recent years. In most of the cases, the ‘‘gang des châteaux’’ carefully selected only a few of many valuable items readily available for the taking. The style of the operation has been so consistent that police investigating the latest theft reportedly are working on the theory that the burglars are ‘‘replying to the orders’’ of a private collector. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1965

headline: Leon Silverman, 93, Dies; Lawyer Led Inquiry of Labor Secretary
abstract: Mr. Silverman was appointed to investigate a Reagan labor secretary accused of ties to organized crime.
lead_paragraph: Leon Silverman, a tenacious litigator best known outside the legal profession as the federal investigator who found insufficient evidence to prosecute Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan in 1982 on charges that he had ties to organized crime, died on Thursday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Some See Risk in de Blasio’s Bid to Add Housing
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gentrification', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Many New York residents, especially in Brooklyn, say the influx of market-rate apartments called for in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plans could gut neighborhoods, not preserve them.
lead_paragraph: Every month, city planners come to East New York to explain how the city wants to help this corner of Brooklyn, scarred by decades of poverty and violent crime, grow. They will invite developers to build up local streets in exchange for more units of affordable housing. They will invest in new trees and sidewalks. Better services and shops will follow, they say.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Slips to Third but Sees a Silver Lining
abstract: Anna Fenninger snatched away the super-G gold medal at the world championships, but Vonn was not disheartened for long, recalling that she had injured her knee twice in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — As Lindsey Vonn crossed the finish line and took the lead in the super-G at the Alpine World Ski Championships here on Tuesday, her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, shouted and pumped his right fist repeatedly as he watched nearby.

headline: Saddle Bronc Part 2 Intro

lead_paragraph: Intro sequence for part 2.

headline: SXSW Film Festival Announces Lineup
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The festival feature lineup includes 145 features and 100 world premieres.
lead_paragraph: From lovers of sneakers to lovers of spies, this year’s South by Southwest film festival seems to have a little something for everyone. Organizers on Tuesday announced the bulk of their features lineup, which includes 100  world premieres.

headline: Palestinian Newspaper Accused of Running Muhammad Cartoon
abstract: The newspaper said the cartoon had been misunderstood, but the president of the Palestinian Authority has ordered an investigation.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Saying it was a “grave mistake” for an official Palestinian newspaper to publish a cartoon that some readers thought depicted the Prophet Muhammad, the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, has ordered an investigation, according to Wafa, the official Palestinian news agency.

headline: U.N. Concerned About Reports That Food Aid to Syria Is in ISIS Hands
abstract: The United Nations World Food Program was responding to reports that the Islamic State was distributing its aid bags but rebranded with the militants’ logo.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations food relief agency said it was “extremely concerned” about the possible manipulation of its aid to Syria after images posted on jihadist websites and social media appeared to show Islamic State supporters distributing the agency’s relief supplies rebranded with the militant group’s logo.

headline: Preventing Suicides Among Veterans Is at Center of Bill Passed by Senate
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The bill, named for a Marine who suffered post-traumatic stress disorder and committed suicide, focuses on the V.A.’s suicide prevention and mental health programs.
lead_paragraph: As a Marine serving in Iraq, Clay Hunt barely missed being killed by a sniper, yet he faced what proved to be more powerful foes after leaving the corps: depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. Mr. Hunt killed himself four years ago, even as he worked to help other struggling veterans.

headline: Holder on S.&P.’s Settlement
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the agency will pay $1.37 billion to settle an array of government lawsuits that accused S.&P. of inflating subprime mortgage investment ratings.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that the agency will pay $1.37 billion to settle an array of government lawsuits that accused S.&P. of inflating subprime mortgage investment ratings.

headline: Gender Bias Case Against Sterling Jewelers Can Proceed
abstract: The arbitrator, Kathleen Roberts, ruled that Sterling employees may pursue a claim challenging the jeweler’s promotion and pay practices.
lead_paragraph: An arbitrator overseeing a gender discrimination case against Sterling Jewelers, parent of 12 chains in the United States including Kay Jewelers, has certified a class of thousands of women to proceed to trial.

headline: What Travelers Need to Know About Measles
abstract: After an outbreak of measles at Disneyland in California, doctors emphasize the importance of immunization.

headline: In Black and White, Illustration Sparks Reader Concerns
abstract: An Op-Ed essay’s artwork was not intended to depict race, but many saw it that way
lead_paragraph: Liz Ananat was one of many readers who wrote to me about an illustration accompanying an Op-Ed essay published Tuesday on domestic violence. The piece was powerful, making the point that “men who are eventually arrested for violent acts often began with attacks against their girlfriends and wives.” But for some readers, dismay at the illustration overwhelmed their reaction to the article itself.

headline: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
abstract: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that country’s far-flung diaspora.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that country’s far-flung diaspora.

headline: E.P.A. Says Pipeline Could Spur Emissions
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The report said that when oil prices fall, the lower cost to move the oil through a pipeline would make it more attractive to buyers and increase production and the amount of greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Environmental Protection Agency review of the Keystone XL pipeline emphasized that the recent drop in global oil prices might mean that construction of the pipeline could spur increased development of the Canadian oil sands — and thus increase planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: De Blasio’s State of the City Address
abstract: The complete State of the City address of Bill de Blasio, the New York mayor.
lead_paragraph: The complete State of the City address of Bill de Blasio, the New York mayor.

keywords: ['Jams and Jellies', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Pet Foods']
abstract: The deal, Smucker’s biggest in its 118-year history, seeks to capitalize on a high-growth sector and is expected to revive sales.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Jerome Monroe Smucker first started selling apple butter in 1897, the company that bears his name has been best known for jams, peanut butter and other treats.

headline: Shares Fall at Chipotle Although Sales Rise
abstract: The made-to-order burrito chain said same-store sales grew by 16.1 percent, and overall revenue exceeded $1 billion in the quarter.
lead_paragraph: Chipotle Mexican Grill, the made-to-order burrito chain that is the darling of the millennial generation, continues its sizzling financial performance.

headline: Macy’s to Buy Bluemercury Spa and Beauty Chain
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Macy’s agreed to pay $210 million for the company, which operates 60 stores in 18 states and has a growing e-commerce business.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s is planning a bit of a makeover, announcing on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the beauty and spa chain Bluemercury for $210 million, a move that could help broaden the department store’s customer base.

headline: SAP Aggressively Moves Customers to Its Database
abstract: The German software giant, which powers much of the biggest manufacturing, retail, and supply functions in the world, says future versions of its big corporate software will require a fast-acting SAP database. It’s a big break from the company’s past.
lead_paragraph: You’ve got to hand it to SAP for competitive vision. Then take some back for how it’s explaining itself.

headline: Beheadings Frame a New Debate About Restraints on Japan’s Military
abstract: As the shock from the beheadings of two Japanese faded, a battle to gain political advantage from the deaths began.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As the shock from the beheadings of two Japanese hostages by the Islamic State faded Tuesday, a battle to gain political advantage from their deaths began.

headline: Green Dot’s Decision to Stop Selling MoneyPak Cards Will Take a Toll
keywords: ['Debit Cards', 'E-Commerce', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Law and Legislation', 'Phishing (Computer Fraud)']
abstract: The loss could cost the company up to $40 million in operating revenue this year.
lead_paragraph: The decision by Green Dot to stop selling MoneyPak, its popular prepaid card, will take a bite out of the company’s projected revenue and bottom line this year, and that has taken a toll on the company’s share price over the last several days.

headline: Cracking Codes Through the Centuries
abstract: The exhibition “Decoding the Renaissance: 500 Years of Codes and Ciphers” is brimming with documents and insights about cryptography.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Sigaba encryption machine squats in the Folger Shakespeare Library here like a thuggish interloper. Used by the American military in the 1940s and 1950s to send coded messages, it looks like an oversize, boxy typewriter with rotors rising above the lid like a mechanical brain. No object could seem less Elizabethan, yet appearances deceive.

headline: A Two-Bedroom House on a Hillside in St. Barts
abstract: The house, designed to maximize views, is on the market for $3.9 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, designed to maximize views, is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: Donating Embryos, Not ‘Giving Up Babies’
abstract: Infertility is sad and frustrating and a huge financial burden, writes an embryo donor. I love the idea that one of our frozen embryos could end that heartache for a family.
lead_paragraph: This past November, we ran an essay by Maya Grobel Moskin, When All Else Fails, Embryo Adoption Offers Hope. Katherine, a mother who thought her family was complete after a successful IVF procedure and the birth of her twins, described her and her husband’s decision to donate their three remaining frozen embryos in the comments. I wanted to know more. I wrote her, asking if she would be willing to share her story.

headline: An Orchestral Group Effort, With a Star Turn for Banjo
abstract: The Knights, joined by Béla Fleck on banjo, gave an expressive and exuberant performance of " ...The Ground Beneath Our Feet,” the title track of their new album.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom holds that a surplus of cooks spoils the broth. And surely the same is true for composition: Can you name a masterwork of classical music composed by committee?

headline: Elgar and Haydn, Found Warming in a Hidden Space
abstract: Despite the difficult weather, the Manhattan String Quartet performed at the Kosciuszko Foundation on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen hardy souls made it through snow and ice to the Kosciuszko Foundation on Monday night. Small numbers make for acute listening, though, and often for rewarding experiences in chamber music. That was true of this brief, absorbing concert from the Manhattan String Quartet, presented by a venerable club for musicians and the musically inclined, the Bohemians.

headline: A Day in the Life of Eddie Huang
abstract: Performer and chef, writer and provocateur, Eddie Huang tries to take his brand of Asian-American anarchism to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Performer and chef, writer and provocateur, Eddie Huang tries to take his brand of Asian-American anarchism to the mainstream.

headline: An Immigrant’s Tale, With All-American Tropes
abstract: ABC’s “Fresh Off the Boat,” based on the restaurateur Eddie Huang’s memoir, is the first network sitcom centered on an Asian-American family in two decades.
lead_paragraph: In the buildup to Wednesday’s premiere of “Fresh Off the Boat,” we’ve been hearing repeatedly that this ABC series will be different: a comedy centered on an Asian-American family, something network prime time hasn’t seen in years.

headline: Rand Paul Gets a Booster Vaccination
abstract: Senator Rand Paul invited a reporter with him to watch him get his booster vaccination for Hepatitis A.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul, facing a backlash over his comments that cast doubt on whether he believes vaccines can pose a health risk to children, asserted on Tuesday that he believes vaccinations are indeed safe and that all parents should have their children inoculated.

headline: Britain Set to Approve Technique to Create Babies From 3 People
abstract: The House of Commons voted to allow the in vitro creation of embryos using the DNA of three people, a procedure that could prevent the inheritance of genetic diseases.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite warnings that a new ethical threshold was being crossed, British lawmakers on Tuesday voted to allow the in vitro creation of babies using the DNA of three people, a procedure that could prevent the inheritance of genetic diseases.

lead_paragraph: A measles outbreak has spurred a political debate over vaccine mandates, turning a public health question into one of personal liberty and becoming a wedge issue for potential candidates for the White House in 2016.

lead_paragraph: When a Montana judge ordered Hyundai to pay $73 million in punitive damages last year to the families of two teenagers killed in a car crash, she found that the South Korean automaker had “recklessly” ignored scores of warnings over more than a decade about the steering defect blamed for the accident.

abstract: The maestro Riccardo Muti brought the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to Carnegie Hall for three concerts, a master class and a side trip to Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio came out fighting for affordable housing, envisioning a city able to retain the working- and middle-class families that call it home.
lead_paragraph: Give Mayor Bill de Blasio time and he can toss out a lot of numbers. It’s what he did in his State of the City Address on Tuesday: nearly half-a-million potholes filled in 2014, a plan to cut greenhouse gases by 80 percent by 2050, a 65 percent drop in marijuana arrests, 1.6 million calls answered by the New York Fire Department.

lead_paragraph: Gilead Sciences sold $10.3 billion of its new hepatitis C drug Sovaldi in 2014, a figure that brought it close to being the best-selling drug in the world in only its first year on the market.

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday picked an American judge serving on an inquiry into possible war crimes in Gaza to lead its work to completion a day after the inquiry’s chairman resigned after Israel accused him of a “blatant conflict of interest.”

headline: ISIS Video Presents Grim Choice for News Media
abstract: A video showing ISIS militants apparently burning alive First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, a Jordanian pilot, raised the question of which images news outlets should use.
lead_paragraph: The images spread rapidly online Tuesday, some more graphic than others: A caged Jordanian pilot, captured by the militants of the Islamic State late last year, was shown apparently being burned alive.

headline: Video Shows Obama’s 2008 Comments on Vaccines Were Misreported
abstract: Video posted online in 2008 shows that President Obama, then a senator, did not identify himself as a vaccine skeptic.
lead_paragraph: As reporters press potential 2016 presidential candidates on the question of whether parents should be compelled to vaccinate their children, new attention has been focused on how the issue was handled in the 2008 campaign, particularly by President Obama.

headline: Alternate-Side Parking Suspended Through Saturday
abstract: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City through Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Metro-North Train Hits S.U.V. in Railroad’s Deadliest Accident
abstract: A crowded train in Westchester County in New York slammed into a sport-utility vehicle at a crossing.
lead_paragraph: A crowded Metro-North Railroad train passing through Westchester County at the height of the evening rush on Tuesday slammed into a sport-utility vehicle on the tracks at a crossing, creating a fiery crash and explosion that killed seven people, injured a dozen and forced the evacuation of hundreds. It was the deadliest crash in the railroad’s history.

headline: Ex-Contractor Charged in Navy Bribery Case
abstract: Paul Simpkins, a former senior contracting officer for the Navy, was arrested Tuesday and charged with conspiracy to commit bribery in a scandal involving ship-supply contracts in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Paul Simpkins, a former senior contracting officer for the Navy, was arrested Tuesday and charged with conspiracy to commit bribery in a scandal involving ship-supply contracts in the Pacific. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, 60, accepted several hundred thousand dollars in cash, trips and the services of prostitutes from Leonard Francis, a Malaysian businessman who recently pleaded guilty to bribing Navy officials for help in overbilling the services by at least $35 million. Prosecutors said Mr. Simpkins, who pleaded not guilty, overruled a subordinate who wanted to drop a contract with Mr. Leonard in Thailand that included “many exceedingly high cost” items.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Moves to Expand Ferry Service in New York City
abstract: In one of the best-received proposals in his State of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans for a citywide ferry service with stops in, among other places, Astoria and the Rockaways.
lead_paragraph: It has become a modern political axiom in New York, as bipartisan as it is expensive, according to transportation advocates: Elected officials love ferries.

headline: A City and Sea Hotel Pairing in Thailand
abstract: Como hotels is offering a city and seaside combination in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Travelers to Thailand who want to experience bustling Bangkok as well as pristine beaches can get a dose of both with the new customizable “Island and City Break” offer from the Point Yamu by Como hotel in Phuket.

headline: Our Curse
abstract: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, a young couple struggles to overcome every new parent’s worst nightmare: a child born with a life-threatening illness.
lead_paragraph: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, a young couple struggles to overcome every new parent’s worst nightmare: a child born with a life-threatening illness.

headline: ‘Nasza klątwa’
abstract: W tym krótkim, nominowanym do Oscara filmie dokumentalnym młoda para zmaga się z koszmarem każdego nowego rodzica: dzieckiem urodzonym z zagrażającą życiu chorobą.
lead_paragraph: Cztery lata temu, u mojego nowonarodzonego syna Leo zdiagnozowano bardzo rzadką i nieuleczalną chorobę, tak zwaną Klątwę Ondyny. Znana jest również jako zespół wrodzonej ośrodkowej hipowentylacji.

headline: ‘Our Curse’
abstract: In this Oscar-nominated documentary, a young couple struggles to overcome every new parent’s worst nightmare: a child born with a life-threatening illness.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, my newborn son, Leo, was given a diagnosis of a very rare and incurable disorder known as Ondine’s Curse. Also called  Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome (C.C.H.S.), the disorder prevents the thousand or so people known to have been born with it from breathing while asleep, and sometimes also while awake. Though the disorder is manageable when treated, our son is likely to need a ventilator for the rest of his life.

headline: Low Energy Prices Offer Opening for Subsidy Cuts
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Middle Eastern and developing countries have long kept oil cheap for political reasons, but a new global energy picture presents an opportunity to stop.
lead_paragraph: In Saudi Arabia, drivers pay roughly 45 cents a gallon to fill up their cars, and in Venezuela even less. Energy is so inexpensive in Kuwait and Qatar that residents chill their enormous swimming pools in the summer and typically leave their air-conditioners on at full blast while they are away on vacation.

headline: U.S. Official Says Cuba’s Political Detentions Declined
abstract: Cuba temporarily detained 178 political prisoners in January, the State Department’s senior human rights official said Tuesday. There were 489 such detentions in December.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cuba temporarily detained 178 political prisoners in January, Tom Malinowski, the State Department’s senior human rights official, said Tuesday.

headline: On Tour, Greek Leaders Wear No Ties and Aim for Looser Belts
abstract: Alexis Tsipras, the newly elected prime minister of Greece, and his finance minister are making fashion statements as they visit European capitals to lobby for relief from the country’s bailout debt.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Less than two weeks after taking power in national elections, Greece’s leftist-led government is now taking Europe. Fashion critics in London are debating whether the Greek finance minister is an arbiter of cool chic or looks like a nightclub bouncer. Politicians in Brussels and Berlin are mulling whether the new Greek prime minister is a radical looking to bring down the eurozone or a canny operator looking for a deal.

headline: In a Sale Gone Awry, a Lesson for Other Deal Makers
abstract: The sale of the GFI Group, a process that seemed to be going right, has been exposed to be less than ideal, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor.
lead_paragraph: The prolonged takeover battle for the GFI Group, a New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse, has been littered with missteps by Michael Gooch, its founder and executive chairman, raising the question of why supposedly intelligent leaders time and again do dumb things when they sell their companies.

headline: House G.O.P. Again Votes to Repeal Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The latest House bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act was the first one in the new Congress, and gave new Republican members a chance to take a stand.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed a bill on Tuesday to repeal the Affordable Care Act for the first time in the new Congress, but Democrats appeared to show more zeal in defending the law than Republicans did in trying to get rid of it.

headline: N.H.L. Trailblazer Finds Forgiveness in the Tip of a Pen
abstract: By writing about the abuse he endured as the league’s first American-born black player, Val James has been able to put the past’s ugliness behind him.
lead_paragraph: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — A little more than a year ago, the former N.H.L. player Val James handed his wife, Ina, the first draft of his autobiography and asked her to read it.

headline: S.&P. Settlement Leaves Future Unclear for Ratings
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: In the wake of the financial crisis, when rating agencies were blamed for feeding a subprime mortgage frenzy, Congress used the Dodd-Frank Act to adopt a battery of changes for the rating industry.
lead_paragraph: It cost $1.37 billion, but Standard & Poor’s has finally appeared to close the darkest chapter in its 150-year history as a rating agency.

headline: Moussaoui Calls Saudi Princes Patrons of Al Qaeda
abstract: Zacarias Moussaoui, a former Qaeda operative, said that members of the royal family were donors in the 1990s, and that he discussed plans to shoot down Air Force One with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In highly unusual testimony inside the federal supermax prison, a former operative for Al Qaeda has described prominent members of Saudi Arabia’s royal family as major donors to the terrorist network in the late 1990s and claimed that he discussed a plan to shoot down Air Force One with a Stinger missile with a staff member at the Saudi Embassy in Washington.

headline: New Speaker in Albany: A Skilled Operator, Embracing Change
abstract: Carl E. Heastie says he hopes to reform the almost czarlike system in which the Assembly is ruled by its speaker, though his political career would seem to make him better suited to thrive in that environment.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — After his election on Tuesday as speaker of the New York State Assembly, Carl E. Heastie echoed calls to reform the opaque and almost czarlike system in which the legislative chamber is ruled by its speaker, one of the “three men in a room” who dominate state government.

headline: Lincoln’s Failed Peace Process
abstract: The president tried to reach a negotiated end to the Civil War in February 1865. Why didn’t it work?
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, 1865, a lovely false spring day, the president of the United States traveled south by train and steamboat to a spot near the front lines of the Civil War for a peaceful talk with the enemy. Such high-level negotiations in the middle of a shooting war had never happened before, and have never happened since. After nearly four years of battering, the Confederacy was all but broken – and Lincoln was eager to stop the killing and begin to heal the country with a peaceful reconciliation instead of a military conquest. That’s why, that afternoon, Abraham Lincoln welcomed three Confederate leaders to the presidential steamboat River Queen, the Air Force One of her day, and exposed himself to political attack for the mortal sin of compromise.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks to Legalize Doctor-Assisted Suicide for Terminally Ill Patients in New York
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Doctors', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Under New York State law, any doctor who helps a terminally ill patient die by providing a fatal dose of medication can be prosecuted under the manslaughter statute.
lead_paragraph: A group of doctors and terminally ill patients are asking New York courts to declare that doctor-assisted suicide is legal and not covered by the state’s prohibition on helping people take their own lives.

headline: A Crashing End to a Work of Ice a City Had Warmed Up To
abstract: A 66-foot ice tower built to set a world record and to draw visitors to Superior, Wis., collapsed on Tuesday, three months after a backyard sculptor began the $30,000 project.
lead_paragraph: SUPERIOR, Wis. — The ingredients needed to build the world’s tallest ice sculpture — bountiful water and extremely cold weather — exist in abundance in this small city hard on the state’s northwesternmost tip. A perfect place, in other words, for a self-taught engineer named Roger Hanson to surpass that record.

headline: Regulators Cite a New Danger in the Skies: Selfies
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that when a light plane fatally crashed eight months ago, it was probably because the pilot had been taking pictures of himself and his passenger, with a flash.
lead_paragraph: WATKINS, Colo. — In an age of digital distractions, the lethal risks of driving — or just crossing the street — while looking at a cellphone have been well-documented.

headline: With One’s Head in the Clouds
abstract: Julian Lim returns.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE —The idiom “Your mileage may vary” comes up a lot on this blog, particularly when it comes to how a puzzle might make you feel. That’s an unusual stance to begin with, because many people believe that a puzzle can’t really affect your feelings one way or another. I understand that, and I respectfully disagree. We can agree to disagree, right?

headline: A Crumbling Tower of Ice
abstract: Roger Hanson calls himself the iceman. The 66 foot-high ice sculpture he’s been working on in Superior, Wis., since November came tumbling down Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Roger Hanson calls himself the iceman. The 66 foot-high ice sculpture he’s been working on in Superior, Wis., since November came tumbling down Tuesday morning.

headline: What You Get for ... $750,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a log house in Kentucky, a contemporary in Arkansas and a houseboat in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a log house in Kentucky, a contemporary in Arkansas and a houseboat in Seattle.

headline: High-Tech Fashion Redefines Meaning of Revealing Clothing
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: “Cloud Couture,” a show at Pratt Institute’s Brooklyn Fashion and Design Accelerator in Williamsburg, opens up the power and risks of advanced technology and clothing.
lead_paragraph: New to the city last year, Billie Whitehouse was struck by the inevitability of small-scale disaster on the streets of New York. Everywhere, it seemed, people walked with noses pointed into their smartphones. Like herself, these pilgrims were seeking directions. But they were liable to step blindly off sidewalks, to walk up the backs of people ahead of them, or to not notice that shop doors swing open.

headline: Evasive on Stand, Prosecution Witness Is Declared Hostile at Patz Trial
abstract: Juan Santana, an employee at the Manhattan bodega where prosecutors say the boy was murdered in 1979, gave evasive answers to questions that he had clearly addressed over the years.
lead_paragraph: The trial of a man accused of killing 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979 took an unexpected twist on Tuesday, after a prosecution witness — an employee at the bodega where prosecutors say the boy was murdered — was declared a hostile witness because he became evasive on the stand.

headline: The 10 Most Painful Losses in Super Bowl History
abstract: The Seahawks’ defeat in Super Bowl XLIX, with the team trailing by 4 points at the 1-yard line in the final minute, was painful, but there are several other candidates for toughest loss to swallow.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks were a yard from history. Trailing by 4 points in the final minute of Sunday’s Super Bowl, Seattle had the ball, on second down, at the Patriots’ 1-yard line. According to the website Advanced Football Analytics, that gave the Seahawks an 88 percent chance of winning the Super Bowl.

headline: A Matchmaker and a Festival Keep an Irish Tradition Alive
abstract: Willie Daly is one of Ireland’s last traditional matchmakers, best known for presiding over an annual matchmaking festival in the western village of Lisdoonvarna.
lead_paragraph: LISDOONVARNA, Ireland — After 50-odd years in the business of romance, Willie Daly has a lot of stories to tell.

headline: United Arab Emirates, Key U.S. Ally in ISIS Effort, Disengaged in December
abstract: The United Arab Emirates ended airstrikes in December after a Jordanian pilot was captured.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United Arab Emirates, a crucial Arab ally in the American-led coalition against the Islamic State, suspended airstrikes against the Sunni extremist group in December, citing fears for its pilots’ safety after a Jordanian pilot was captured and who the extremists said had been burned to death, United States officials said Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Enrique Peña Nieto announced Tuesday that a new federal comptroller would lead an investigation into the purchase by the president and his wife of two houses from government contractors.

keywords: ['Black Markets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']

lead_paragraph: A prosecutor asked a Manhattan jury on Tuesday to convict a California man, Ross W. Ulbricht, of narcotics trafficking conspiracy and other charges in a trial involving Silk Road, the black-market website for drugs and other illicit goods.

headline: Knicks Fall to Celtics in a Matchup of Duds
abstract: A largely listless battle between rebuilding teams at Madison Square Garden extended the pain of the Knicks, who were unable to rally from an 86-82 deficit with eight minutes left.
lead_paragraph: The sad drumbeat continued on Tuesday for the Knicks, who lost to the Boston Celtics, 108-97, in a mostly listless affair at Madison Square Garden between two rebuilding franchises.

headline: Syria: Chemical Weapons Plant Razed
abstract: Seven months after Syria exported the last of its known stockpile of chemical weapons ingredients, the first of its 12 production facilities has been destroyed, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Seven months after Syria exported the last of its known stockpile of chemical weapons ingredients, the first of its 12 production facilities has been destroyed, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons reported Tuesday. Ahmet Uzumcu, director general of the organization, which polices the chemical weapons treaty that Syria signed in late 2013, said the destruction of the first facility had been completed Jan. 31 after a delay he attributed to “technical reasons.” He gave no timetable for the rest. Western countries have accused President Bashar al-Assad of Syria of procrastination in complying with the terms of the treaty, which he agreed to sign after a chemical weapons attack in a Damascus suburb for which government forces and insurgents blamed each other.

headline: Accuser in Strauss-Kahn Case Builds Restaurant and a Refuge
abstract: Nafissatou Diallo, the hotel housekeeper who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of attacking her in his suite, has opened a West African restaurant in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: As the news media again turns its attention to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former leader of the International Monetary Fund who is on  trial in France on accusations that he participated in a prostitution ring, the woman who accused him of sexual assault in New York City in 2011 has quietly resumed her life, this time behind the counter of a West African restaurant in the Bronx.

headline: Aksel Lund Svindal Set to Compete at Alpine Championships

lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — After three months away from the slopes because of injury, Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway, the three-time Olympic medalist and defending downhill world champion, confirmed that he would race in Wednesday’s super-G and Saturday’s downhill at the Alpine World Ski Championships here.

headline: Sherry Arden, Publisher With a Passion for Best Sellers, Dies at 91
abstract: Ms. Arden, whose exuberance as a publisher invigorated the book industry, promoted countless best sellers, including “Mommie Dearest” and “The Peter Principle.”
lead_paragraph: Sherry Arden, whose exuberance as a promoter and perspicacity as a publisher helped invigorate the book industry with a raft of celebrity tell-all memoirs like Christina Crawford’s “Mommie Dearest” and pop psychology primers like Gail Sheehy’s “Pathfinders,” died on Jan. 27 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Sandy Socolow, CBS Newsman During Heady Days, Dies at 86
abstract: A longtime executive for CBS, Mr. Socolow contributed to shaping stories that defined history in the 1960s and 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Socolow, a longtime executive at CBS News who worked closely with Walter Cronkite and helped shape television coverage of the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Monty Oum, Web-Series Animator, Dies at 33
abstract: Mr. Oum was the director of animation for Rooster Teeth Productions, a company best known for repurposing avatars from the Halo video games into angst-ridden slackers in the popular web series “Red vs. Blue.”
lead_paragraph: Monty Oum, the creator of the animated web series “RWBY” and director of animation for Rooster Teeth Productions, a company best known for repurposing the bloodthirsty avatars in the Halo video games into angst-ridden slackers in the popular web series “Red vs. Blue,” died on Sunday near his home in Austin, Tex. He was 33.

headline: Aldo Ciccolini Dies at 89; Pianist Interpreted Satie
abstract: Mr. Ciccolini said he had no delusions about whose legacy would be longer: Satie’s or his own.
lead_paragraph: Aldo Ciccolini, an Italian-born pianist who specialized in the music of French composers and was known in particular as a champion of Erik Satie, has died at his home outside Paris. He was 89.

headline: Meh Head
abstract: The hairstyle of choice this season seems like no hairstyle at all. Unremarkable in color and length, and replete with flyaway bits, the look is effortless, but of course, it isn’t.
lead_paragraph: The hairstyle of choice this season seems like no hairstyle at all. Unremarkable in color and length, and replete with flyaway bits, the look is effortless, but of course, it isn’t.

headline: The Softer Side of Spring Manicures
abstract: The season's demure nail polish offerings range from sweet shades to garden party varieties.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, at shows from Thakoon to DKNY, light and neutral nails marked the departure of dark manicures for spring 2015. And the season’s crop of nail polish offerings, an array of delicate colors that just hit the market this month, pair as seamlessly with snow gear now as they will with ready-to-wear when the weather warms up. Consider some of Dolce & Gabbana’s romantic new hues (aptly named Innocence, Bella and Rosebud) and Nails Inc.’s garden party varieties (soft shades and confetti-like top coats that mimic May flowers).

headline: The Rise of Japanese Chefs in Paris
abstract: Aspiring culinary stars from Japan have been leaving behind the Michelin-starred dining temples that trained them to headline their own restos.
lead_paragraph: For years, aspiring culinary stars from Japan have been decamping to Paris to learn new techniques, but recently they’ve been leaving behind the Michelin-starred dining temples that trained them — from Astrance to Taillevent — to headline their own spots. At Restaurant ES in the Seventh Arrondissement, the chef Takayuki Honjo improvises with simple, market-driven dishes, such as roast pigeon in cocoa sauce, which are as delicate in flavor as they are graphic in presentation. At Neige d’Été in the 15th, Hideki Nishi dabbles in modern French cuisine including salmon with a Gorgonzola millefeuille. Over in the 11th, at 6036 — a 14-seat izakaya named for the distance, in miles, between Paris and Tokyo — the chef Haruka Casters plays up seasonal small plates (sake-steamed clams with cabbage, teriyaki burgers). “Paris is a cosmopolitan city with many opportunities to improve one’s cooking,” says Casters. “But it’s also much easier to be seen here than in a megalopolis like Tokyo.”

headline: Taiwan: Plane Crashes in Taipei
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: A small passenger airplane crashed into a river in Taipei after clipping a bridge on Wednesday morning, Taiwan’s Central News Agency reported, citing a local government official.
lead_paragraph: A small passenger airplane crashed into a river in Taipei after clipping a bridge on Wednesday morning, Taiwan’s Central News Agency reported, citing a local government official. The TransAsia Airways twin turboprop crashed shortly after takeoff from Taipei Songshan Airport on a flight bound for the Kinmen islands, near the Chinese province of Fujian. About a dozen people were rescued from the plane, an ATR-72, while 10 were still trapped, the news agency reported, citing local television reports. Local television showed the plane’s fuselage resting in the Keelung River near the southeast side of Taipei, the Taiwanese capital. The crash is the second for the airline in just over six months, following an ATR-72 crash on July 23 that killed 48 people. The cause of that crash is still under investigation.

headline: Plane Clips Road and Crashes in Taiwan, Killing at Least 31
abstract: A passenger plane with 53 passengers and five crew members aboard crashed into a river in Taiwan’s capital, Taipei, shortly after takeoff on Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A passenger plane crashed into a river in Taiwan’s capital, Taipei, shortly after takeoff on Wednesday morning, killing at least 31 people, officials said. Rescue operations were underway to pull survivors from the water.

(WE) MATCH MADE IN HEAVEN Shawn Bullard, a real estate developer and former college football player, receives guidance from Ken Johnson, chaplain and spiritual adviser to the Indianapolis Colts, who is charged with discerning the authenticity and godliness of 24 women hoping to make a love connection with Mr. Bullard. But it may be Mr. Bullard’s opinionated mother, who, after moving into the house with the contestants, has the final say on her prospective daughter-in-law. And forget about roses: The women will each be given a white cellphone at the start of the show to which Mr. Bullard will text messages as to the outcome of their romantic encounters.

headline: Europe’s Expanding ‘Right to Be Forgotten’
abstract: The push to censor information on the Internet to citizens beyond the European Union is a troubling idea.
lead_paragraph: European officials are pushing an idea that will encourage autocrats everywhere to demand greater censorship on the Internet. They want companies like Google and Microsoft to abide by the European Union’s recently recognized legal principle of a “right to be forgotten” not just in the 28 countries of the union but everywhere.

headline: It Is Time to End Subminimum Wages
abstract: Extending the full state minimum wage to tipped workers in New York would help combat poverty.
lead_paragraph: In New York, restaurants are allowed to pay servers a minimum wage of $5 an hour, as long as that hourly wage plus tips equals at least $8.75, the state minimum for nontipped workers (rising to $9 by 2016). That subminimum “tipped” wage is a vestige of the early days of modern labor law, when minimum-wage mandates were riddled with industry-specific exemptions, long since ended. It survives for tipped workers because of the strength of the restaurant lobby.

headline: 150 Years of Working on the Railroad
keywords: ['High-Speed Rail Projects', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The 19th century had the transcontinental; we have the bullet train.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — IN 1864, my great-grandfather arrived here, a teenager from Ireland with few prospects. He’d left County Galway with a coat and shoes and crossed the Atlantic, caught a steamer to Panama, then another one to San Francisco. The journey took three months, an eternity for a young man hungry to work.

headline: Philosophy’s Lost Body and Soul
abstract: Philosophy’s denial of different racial experiences and identities has compromised its capacities for both knowledge and self-knowledge.
lead_paragraph: This is the sixth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Linda Martín Alcoff, a professor of philosophy at Hunter College and the CUNY Graduate Center. She was the president of the American Philosophical Association, Eastern Division, for 2012-13. She is the author of “Visible Identities: Race, Gender, and the Self.” — George Yancy

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After a rough few months, Sony got some relief on Wednesday as net profit almost doubled analysts’ expectations and the company reduced its loss projections for the year.

headline: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
abstract: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that country’s far-flung diaspora.
lead_paragraph: When Rick Rocamora left his career selling pharmaceuticals to become a photographer in 1990, he was guided by the advice and encouragement of everyone from Eli Reed and Ed Kashi to Gordon Parks. He has been paying it forward ever since, serving as a mentor to a new generation of Filipino photographers, both in Manila and among his native country’s far-flung diaspora.

headline: When to Take the SAT
abstract: Middle school students may be taking college admissions tests, but experts suggest that later is better.
lead_paragraph: During morning announcements, loudspeakers blare out SAT words and definitions at all elementary and middle schools in the Malverne, N.Y., school district. Kindergartners keep a “word of the week” journal — recently, “incentive” and “consequence” — in which they draw the word’s meaning or, if able, write a sentence using it. Students and teachers at all grade levels weave the new words into conversation; the district sends home definitions for parents.

headline: The Wardrobe Politics of Greece’s New Prime Minister
abstract: As a personal trait, not just a style signature, Alexis Tsipras goes tie-less and gains political leverage.
lead_paragraph: Last week, as the Twitterati and the talking heads tied themselves in knots over the nonstory of Michelle Obama doing like her peers Hillary Rodham Clinton and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and eschewing a head scarf on a visit to Saudi Arabia, an actual political sartorial revolution was, in fact, taking place elsewhere.

headline: Slow Runners Come Out Ahead
abstract: Joggers consistently tended to live longer than people who did not exercise, a new study found. And the slowest runners lived longest of all.
lead_paragraph: The ideal amount of running for someone who wants to live a long and healthy life is less than most of us might expect, according to a new study, which also suggests that people can overdo strenuous exercise and potentially shorten their lives.

headline: Is Your First Grader College Ready?
abstract: Mock applications at age 6, campus tours at 10. More and more elementary schools are introducing college awareness. Is it ever too early to plan for the future?
lead_paragraph: What is college? To Madison Comer, a confident 6-year-old, it is a very big place. “It’s tall,” she explained, outlining the head of Tuffy, the North Carolina State mascot, with a gray crayon. “It’s like high school but it’s higher.”

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Defense Nominee Says He Would Consider More U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Detainees', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: At a confirmation hearing, Ashton B. Carter said he would consider selling lethal arms to Ukraine as part of its effort to fight Russian-backed separatists in the east.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ashton B. Carter, President Obama’s nominee for secretary of defense, told senators on Wednesday that he would consider increased American military assistance to Ukraine, including the sale of lethal arms, as part of the country’s effort to fight Russian-backed separatists in the east.

headline: Toyota Profit Gets Lift From U.S. Market and Favorable Exchange Rates
abstract: The carmaker is closing in on its most profitable year ever, with earnings in the first nine months up 13 percent from the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Buoyed by a growing American car market and the most favorable exchange rates in decades, Toyota Motor is closing in on its most profitable year ever, the automaker’s latest earnings report suggested on Wednesday.

headline: China Moves to Free Up Money in Its Economy
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A half-percentage-point cut in the reserve requirement for banks has the country’s central bank joining those taking measures to support growth.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China signaled fresh concerns about its slowing economy as the country’s central bank moved on Wednesday to stimulate growth by freeing up more money for banks to lend.

headline: 1915: Novelist Dies at Richmond
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The novelist Miss Braddon dies in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON ­— Miss Braddon, the novelist, whose real name was Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Maxwell, died at her home, Lichfield House, Richmond-on-Thames, Surrey, this morning at the age of seventy-eight. Miss Braddon’s health only began to fail about a fortnight ago, just after she had completed her last novel. Miss Braddon was devoted to literary work from the age of twenty and published her first novel, ‘‘The Trail of the Serpent,’’ in serial form so long ago as 1860. She secured her first big success with ‘‘Lady Audley’s Secret,’’ a sensational novel which enjoyed a great vogue. From that time onward Miss Braddon was an indefatigable producer of novels. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 5, 1915

headline: The Shame of America’s Family Detention Camps
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The Obama administration’s draconian policy toward female refugees and their children has sown misery on the border — and pushed volunteer lawyers to the breaking point.
lead_paragraph: Christina Brown pulled into the refugee camp after an eight-hour drive across the desert. It was late July of last year, and Brown was a 30-year-old immigration lawyer. She had spent a few years after college working on political campaigns, but her law degree was barely a year old, and she had only two clients in her private practice in Denver. When other lawyers told her that the federal government was opening a massive detention center for immigrants in southeastern New Mexico, where hundreds of women and children would be housed in metal trailers surrounded by barbed wire, Brown decided to volunteer legal services to the detainees. She wasn’t sure exactly what rights they might have, but she wanted to make sure they got them. She packed enough clothes to last a week, stopped by Target to pick up coloring books and toys and started driving south.

headline: Tim O’Reilly Explains the Internet of Things
abstract: The publisher and web guru says the Internet is about to cause its greatest changes, augmenting people with sensors and ever-present computing to create entirely new economic systems, and new ways of thinking about politics.
lead_paragraph: Tim O’Reilly has been at the cutting edge of the Internet since it went commercial. In fact, he helped take it there: In August 1993 he released the Global Network Navigator, a web page containing information, catalogs and a marketplace, which may have been the first site with advertising.

headline: Morning Agenda: What S.&P.’s Settlement Means
abstract: S.&P.’s settlement leaves the future unclear for ratings. | A lesson for deal makers. | Smucker announces it will buy Big Heart Pet Brands. | Staples and Office Depot are in advanced talks to combine.
lead_paragraph: WHAT S.&P.’S SETTLEMENT MEANS | Standard & Poor’s $1.37 billion settlement with prosecutors, announced on Tuesday, will settle an array of government lawsuits against the giant rating agency. But it does not represent closure for the broader ratings business, DealBook’s Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report. An uncertain future still lies ahead for S.&P., as well as its main rivals, Moody’s and Fitch.

headline: Staples and Office Depot Say a Merger Will Keep Them Competitive
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Regulators shot down a combination of Staples and Office Depot about 18 years ago, but since then, the competitive landscape has changed, with both companies now facing rivals in Walmart, Target, Amazon and others.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:48 p.m. | In planning a $6.3 billion merger, Staples and Office Depot are betting that 18 years was long enough for government regulators to change their minds about how consumers buy office supplies.

headline: Investigation Underway in Metro-North Train Crash
abstract: Federal officials said the impact between the train and a vehicle on the tracks dislodged an electrified rail, which, mixed with gasoline, created an inferno.
lead_paragraph: When a crowded commuter train slammed into a car on the tracks on Tuesday night, it dislodged the electrified third rail, which, combined with gasoline from the vehicle, created a deadly inferno, federal investigators said at a news conference Wednesday evening.

headline: A Boost From the State Capitol Helped Penn State Escape N.C.A.A. Penalties
abstract: Legal maneuvering by State Senator Jake Corman led the N.C.A.A. to roll back its original penalties against Penn State in the Jerry Sandusky molestation case.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Like his father before him, State Senator Jake Corman represents the district that includes Penn State, his alma mater, in the Pennsylvania General Assembly. In his office as Senate majority leader, he keeps a box of Wheaties autographed by Joe Paterno, a model of Beaver Stadium and a small statue of the university’s Nittany Lions mascot.

lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II returned here to an unexpectedly warm welcome on Wednesday, as cheering crowds expressed support for the country’s swift executions of two terrorist prisoners in retaliation for the Islamic State’s grisly killing of a Jordanian pilot.

headline: A Man’s Death Strikes a Nerve in China
abstract: News of the death of an injured man who was ignored by passers-by has rekindled a debate over public apathy.
lead_paragraph: Once again, video footage of a citizen, lying helpless in the road as passers-by ignore him and a car runs over his body, has set off outcries online about apathy in Chinese society.

headline: ‘Gravity’ Dispute
abstract: A judge says a novelist did not provide enough support for her claim that she was owed credit for the film.
lead_paragraph: Even as the 2015 Oscar race heads into its final weeks, there’s still old business to settle from the 2014 race. Tess Gerritsen, the author of the 1999 novel “Gravity,” claimed that Warner Bros. owed her credit or 2.5 percent of the net profit for the film of the same title, which wound up winning seven Academy Awards. Last week a judge ruled that Ms. Gerritsen had not provided enough support for her claim, reports the Bagger’s colleague Michael Cieply, who adds that the writer’s lawyer has said that he would file an amended complaint.

headline: London Theater Journal: In the Shadow of the Nazis

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Nazis have crept into this city’s theaters during the past month, glowering with murderous hatred and occasionally singing a song or two. Their arrival was perhaps inevitable in a town where life on the stage tends to echo the word on the street.

headline: Morning After Fatal Crash, Metro-North Riders Adjust to a New Commute
abstract: At the North White Plains station Wednesday morning, some passengers worried about possible delays, but no one said the accident would make them give up their rail routines.
lead_paragraph: NORTH WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. — The morning after a horrific Metro-North train accident, commuters in Westchester filed in and out of the North White Plains train station while Metro-North workers directed traffic and called out directions.

headline: Two Versions of ‘Twelfth Night’ Coming From Bedlam Theater Troupe
abstract: The Bedlam theater company will offer two versions of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” using the same script but with different emphases and approaches.
lead_paragraph: “Twelfth Night, Or what you will” is the full name of the dark comedy by Shakespeare that is simply called “Twelfth Night” in most productions, like the hit revival on Broadway last season. And that four-word subtitle will be put to inventive use this spring by Bedlam, the critically acclaimed Off Broadway troupe that recently mounted innovative stagings of “Sense & Sensibility” and “The Seagull.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in 2009, when Rand Paul was pursuing his long-shot bid to win Kentucky’s Republican Senate primary, he spoke to a small physicians’ association that has publicized discredited medical theories, including possible links between vaccines and autism and between abortion and an increased risk of breast cancer.

abstract: How can federal tax policy differentiate between “rich” and the “middle class”? Should tax brackets be adjusted for regional cost of living?

lead_paragraph: Video from a driver’s dashboard camera captured the moment a Taiwanese TransAsia Airways plane with 58 people on board crashed into a Taipei river.

headline: ‘Mourning Lincoln’ and ‘Lincoln’s Body’
abstract: Two new books about the aftermath of the assassination of the 16th president.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln died on April 15, 1865, of a gunshot wound to the head. He was 56 years old and 6 feet 4 inches tall: a giant, felled. He was the 16th president of the United States and the first one killed in office. (A madman once tried to shoot Andrew Jackson, but both of his pistols misfired.) An assassination is treason by way of murder. Lincoln’s assassination was more — an act of war. Lee surrendered to Grant on April 9. Lincoln was the last of the Union dead. His death had another meaning, too. It founded a civic religion, dedicated to the memory of Lincoln’s sacrifice and to the proposition that emancipation is redemption.

headline: A Laugh for Every Season
abstract: In the four mischievous stories in “A Wonderful Year,” Nick Bruel adds madcap humor to a trip through the calendar.
lead_paragraph: There’s a very particular allure to a picture book that teeters on the verge of becoming a chapter book — that divides into three or more micro-stories featuring the same characters, with a title page for each vignette. James Marshall’s classic “George and Martha” books from the 1970s, with their hilariously bickering pair of hippos, are probably the gold standard, but there are many good examples from recent years, like Laura Vaccaro Seeger’s “Dog and Bear” books and Grace Lin’s “Ling and Ting” series.

headline: A Documentary Collaboration That Didn’t Start Out Promisingly
abstract: “The Salt of the Earth,” about the photographer Sebastião Salgado, was made by Wim Wenders and Mr. Salgado’s son. But it was almost as if they were making two separate films.
lead_paragraph: The German film director Wim Wenders is also a photographer with numerous exhibitions and books to his credit, and has collected the work of the Brazilian photographer Sebastião Salgado since the 1980s. But the two men met for the first time only about six years ago, and initially there was no talk of the collaboration that led to the making of “The Salt of the Earth,” one of five nominees for the Oscar for best feature documentary.

headline: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center to Spotlight String Quartet Works
abstract: The society will present six complete string quartet cycles next season — including Beethoven’s 16 quartets, along with cycles by Bartok, Zemlinsky, Carl Nielsen, Alberto Ginastera and Leon Kirchner.
lead_paragraph: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center announced Wednesday that it would present six complete string quartet cycles next season — including Beethoven’s 16 quartets, along with cycles of quartets by Bartok, Zemlinsky, Carl Nielsen, Alberto Ginastera and Leon Kirchner.

headline: ‘The Test,’ by Anya Kamenetz
abstract: An education journalist makes the case against high-stakes standardized testing.
lead_paragraph: Teachers and their unions have resisted standardized testing since the early 20th century. Their critics have claimed they do so because they fear being held accountable for how much children learn. But over the past few years, on both the right and the left, in scattered suburbs and in urban neighborhoods, a small yet growing group of parents have begun to join teachers in denouncing standardized testing. They complain about the narrowing of the school curriculum to the questions asked on high-stakes exams, the many hours and days — sometimes up to a quarter of the school year — spent testing and prepping for tests, and the stress that testing imposes on children. Some parents even have their children opt out of standardized testing altogether.

headline: ‘It’s What I Do,’ by Lynsey Addario
abstract: A photojournalist describes her dangerous experiences and analyzes her profession.
lead_paragraph: The modern battlefield can induce a peculiar strain of skewed logic among those sent to chronicle it. Upon a landscape where it is often mortally dangerous simply to stand in one place, how much worse can it be to venture a little farther, to get a bit closer? And having assumed the added risk of getting closer, how then to leave before you’ve taken the perfect image, conducted one last interview? What makes such calculations especially tricky is that most modern battlefields have no recognizable boundaries or rules of conduct; they bear less resemblance to any traditional war movie than, say, to “Mad Max.”

headline: Picasso’s Granddaughter Plans to Sell Art, Worrying the Market
abstract: A decision by a granddaughter of Picasso to sell many of his works privately has led to speculation that she could flood the market and depress prices.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLE, France — Since Marina Picasso was a child, living on the edge of poverty and lingering at the gates of a French villa with her father to plead for an allowance from her grandfather, Pablo Picasso, she has struggled with the burden of that artist’s towering legacy.

headline: The Corn Cakes of Red Hook
abstract: Learning to cook Salvadoran pupusas in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: At some point during the Age of Disco, an enterprising Guatemalan organized a summertime soccer league in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and ever since, New Yorkers from all over Latin America have brought their cleats, kids and cowbells. What grew up around them was a propane-fueled paradise: tacos, huaraches and elotes, tamales tonged out of pots wheeled around in shopping carts. People and flavors from Mexico, Guatemala, Ecuador, Honduras, Colombia, all just blocks away from where Americans fired cannonballs at a British frigate during the Revolutionary War, desperately trying to keep intruders out.

headline: Howard Lutnick’s BGC Extends Offer for Clearinghouse GFI
abstract: Shareholders of GFI, who rejected a lower offer from the CME Group last week, now have until Feb. 19 to tender their shares.
lead_paragraph: BGC Partners, the brokerage firm owned by Howard W. Lutnick, announced on Wednesday that it was extending the deadline on its offer for the GFI Group, the New York brokerage firm and clearinghouse that has been locked in a prolonged takeover battle.

headline: Charlie Sifford, Who Shattered a Barrier of Race in Golf, Dies at 92
abstract: By the time Mr. Sifford was allowed to compete against the world’s best golfers, he was almost 40. But he won the PGA Tour’s Greater Hartford Open in 1967 and its Los Angeles Open in 1969.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Sifford carried a dream when he returned home from World War II, an Army veteran of the Battle of Okinawa: He wanted to be a professional golfer.

headline: Zoetis Adds Ackman Deputy to Its Board, Avoiding a Fight
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']

headline: Mississippi, a Vaccination Leader, Stands by Its Strict Rules
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Measles', 'German Measles (Rubella)', 'Hepatitis', 'Chicken Pox']
abstract: A bill that would have created a new immunization exemption was heavily amended on Tuesday, leaving the state’s rigid requirements effectively intact.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — The Mississippi state epidemiologist, Dr. Thomas E. Dobbs III, stood in a crowded room at the State Capitol this week and waited for a legislative verdict on the law that fostered what he regards as a public health triumph in a place that has few of them: the country’s highest immunization rate among kindergarten students.

headline: Times Article Prompts Investigation Into Herbal Supplements
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Labeling and Labels']
abstract: The Times reporter Anahad O’Connor writes about the connection between his 2013 Science Times article about herbal supplements and an investigation by the New York attorney general’s office.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 3, Anahad O’Connor wrote an article about findings that major retailers may be selling herbal supplements that contain little more than cheap fillers like powdered rice, asparagus and houseplants, and in some cases substances that could be dangerous to those with allergies. As he tells Insiders, Mr. O’Connor had some familiarity with these accusations.

headline: Our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest:  Write About an Issue That Matters to You
abstract: Back by popular demand, our Student Editorial Contest runs until March 10. Here you can find an overview, the rules, some resources that might help and a few ideas from teachers who taught with it last year.

abstract: Getting around Mexico via rental car, hired car, bus, small van or budget airline.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is a big country — and there are plenty of ways to get around it. Which method is right for you depends on a few factors, including where you will be traveling, what sort of travel you are interested in, and, of course, cost. With that in mind, here is a look at those options.

headline: After a 14-Year Boycott, Serena Williams Plans to Play at Indian Wells
abstract: Williams and her sister Venus last played the tournament in 2001, when they were booed and taunted after Venus withdrew from their semifinal match.

headline: Living With a Star

lead_paragraph: It is a fact rarely appreciated by the general public that to professional astronomers, the Sun is a pretty boring star. Which in fact is great news for the rest of us.

headline: Out There | Raining Fire

lead_paragraph: Though it is sedate in comparison with other stars, our sun is a volatile neighbor, a thermonuclear furnace fueling spectacular storms that send high-energy particles and radiation far out into space.

headline: F.C.C. Plans Strong Hand to Regulate the Internet

lead_paragraph: For the last year, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been working on new rules to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet. Over that time, his hints and comments have shown a steady shift toward stronger regulation — and a more direct confrontation with the cable television and telecommunications companies that provide high-speed Internet service to most American homes.

headline: A Close Bush Adviser Is All Charm and Grit
abstract: Far from her chicken farm, Sally Bradshaw is a shrewd adviser and major force in the former Florida governor’s evolving presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA, Fla. — Some of the world’s most rare and expensive chickens are bred on a 50-acre farm off a canopied road outside Tallahassee, Fla. Pitch-black Ayam Cemanis from Indonesia peck hands reaching for their $100 eggs, free-range Bresse hens eat greens, and strutting Appenzeller Spitzhaubens flare their Dalmatian feather patterns.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘Unbroken’

lead_paragraph: Perhaps the 12th time will be the charm for Roger Deakins. The cinematographer has received a dozen Oscar nominations for his work, making him the most nominated living cinematographer. This year, his photography on Angelina Jolie’s “Unbroken” is being recognized.

headline: Petrobras Executives Quit Amid Scandal

headline: China to Crack Down on Tax Collection From Multinational Companies

The activities have included police raids on the headquarters of companies’ China operations and heavy fines under antimonopoly law.

headline: 36 Hours in Anguilla
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Boats and Boating', 'Beaches']
abstract: The Caribbean island has no cruise ships, casinos or high-rise hotels. Its style is a perfect paradox: unfussy chic, barefoot elegance.
lead_paragraph: Anguilla has no right to be fabulous. The Caribbean island, a British overseas territory about seven miles north of St. Maarten/St. Martin, is a blip on the radar — a mere 35 square miles with just six traffic lights. It’s dry and flat, and its tourism scene took off only some 20 years ago; until the 1960s, after all, much of the island lacked electricity and telephone service. Yet fabulous Anguilla is home to some of the region’s toniest resorts, epicurean eateries and breathtaking beaches. It has architecturally striking villas like those at Altamer, named for exotic gemstones. And it is a magnet for celebrities like Kevin Bacon and Jimmy Buffett, a kind of British St. Bart’s. Without the pretension, though — Anguillan style is a perfect paradox: unfussy chic, barefoot elegance. There are no cruise ships, casinos or high-rise hotels, but there is a thriving local music scene, headed by notable up-and-coming singer-songwriters like Omari Banks and Ruel Richardson, and showcased at Moonsplash, the island’s annual reggae festival. And the fabulous factor grows with every season: luxe hotel unveilings include Malliouhana, reopened late last year after a three-year overhaul, along with coming debuts of Zemi Beach Resort and Spa, an opulent 115-room resort, and the Reef by CuisinArt, a boutique hotel powered by a four-acre solar field.

headline: Classical Playlist: Chopin, Mendelssohn, Gilbert Kalish and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: CHOPIN: 24 Preludes (Op. 28); Selected Impromptus, Mazurkas and Other PreludesAndrew Tyson, pianist(Outhere Music, Zig-Zag Territories ZZT347)The young American pianist Andrew Tyson, who has been picking up competition prizes and winning many admirers, proves a poetic, elegant and aptly impetuous performer of Chopin on this splendid recording, issued by one of the many new smaller labels. Mr. Tyson’s feeling for rubato and over-expressive freedom is balanced by his attentiveness to structure, clarity and inner details. In the 24 Preludes (Op. 28), he brings individual character to each one. Yet Chopin’s collection of preludes in all the major and minor keys emerges in this reading as a compositional entity. A beautiful recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Among the Anti-Vaxxers
abstract: The three circles of anti-vaccine sentiment.
lead_paragraph: I’m hopeful that the briefly-popular idea that vaccination is about to become a partisan issue turns out to be a one-week wonder: It was floated thanks to Chris Christie and (especially) Rand Paul’s rhetorical malpractice, eagerly grasped at by liberals and narrative-seeking journalists, and then — God willing — given last rites by Paul’s booster shot yesterday. But the related and largely nonpartisan debate over how best to argue with/persuade/shame the kind of parents who decide not to vaccinate their kids (see this piece from Conor Friedersdorf, and this one from Slate’s Phil Plait, for interesting discussions) is likely to remain relevant for quite a while … at least as long as we keep having disease outbreaks that seem to cluster in areas with clear pockets of strong anti-vaccine sentiment.

headline: Pops Isn’t Budging. Hear Me, People?
abstract: “Between Riverside and Crazy,” a constantly surprising play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, returns to New York.
lead_paragraph: A highly desirable piece of Manhattan real estate is once again on the market. Its location — to use the name of the Stephen Adly Guirgis play opening at Second Stage on Feb. 11 — is “Between Riverside and Crazy,” and it is a place where distinctions of mental health and morality blur vividly. First seen in an Atlantic Theater Company production last summer, this constantly surprising work from Mr. Guirgis (author of the unprintably titled “The ______ With the Hat”) tells the story of a retired police officer (the wonderful Stephen McKinley Henderson) doing his best to hold onto to his dignity, his family and, most crucially, a rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side. Mr. Henderson’s character is called Pops, but this angry old man is far less cozy and more complicated than his folksy nickname suggests. The same is true of this play, directed by Austin Pendleton with a sharp ear for everyday urban ambivalence. (Through March 22, 305 West 43rd Street, Clinton, 2st.com.)

headline: Taylor Swift Is Back at No. 1
abstract: The pop star’s album “1989” climbed back to No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for a 10th week on top.
lead_paragraph: The pop star’s “1989” (Big Machine) climbed back to No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart, selling 71,000 copies of the full release and another 302,000 downloads of individual tracks, enough for a 10th week on top, according to Nielsen Music. Since its release in October, the album, which was not made available for streaming on Spotify, has sold more than 4.1 million copies — never dropping below No. 2 on the chart — and continues to thrive after finishing 2014 as the best-selling release of the year.

headline: Need Help Finding Your Sweet Spot at Home and Work? Apply Here.
