lead_paragraph: The famous preface to “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” reads like a goad: “Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot in it will be shot.”

headline: The Killing of Shaimaa el-Sabbagh: Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: David Kirkpatrick reflects on the killing of Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, the 31-year-old mother and poet who was shot by masked riot police officers while heading to Tahrir Square in Cairo to lay flowers.
lead_paragraph: David Kirkpatrick wrote a  front-page article on Wednesday about Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, the 31-year-old mother and poet who was shot by masked riot police officers on Jan. 24 while heading to Tahrir Square in Cairo to lay flowers there. Here are his reflections on the story and the killing.How do we write about routine killing?

headline: Investment Bank’s C.E.O. Turns Down a $2.2 Million Bonus
abstract: Richard B. Handler, the head of Jefferies, and Brian P. Friedman, the president, turned down the bonus after the bank suffered a difficult final quarter in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Richard B. Handler, the head of the investment bank Jefferies, turned down a $2.2 million bonus after the bank suffered a difficult final quarter in 2014.

headline: Fox News Website Offers Unedited ISIS Execution Video
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The network said its audience should have the option to see the video of a burning pilot, which was posted with a warning that it was extremely graphic.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, media organizations around the world wrestled with whether to show either the still images or the video of Islamic State militants burning a Jordanian pilot alive in a cage. Within hours, Fox News posted the entire video on its website.

headline: Croatia Forgiving Debt of Some of Its Poorest Citizens
abstract: The government is offering a debt write-off to Croats who have blocked bank accounts, owe less than the equivalent of about $5,000 and currently receive some sort of welfare benefits.
lead_paragraph: ZADAR, Croatia — While Greece and Germany tussle over what debt forgiveness might mean, Croatia, the European Union’s newest member, is adopting its own approach, offering what it calls a “new beginning” to 60,000 of its poorest citizens.

headline: Dream Weaver
abstract: Born into Argentina’s first family of rugmakers, Alexandra Kehayoglou creates topographical wonders that elevate ancient craft to modern art.
lead_paragraph: Born into Argentina’s first family of rugmakers, Alexandra Kehayoglou creates topographical wonders that elevate ancient craft to modern art.

headline: A Failed Trial in Africa Raises Questions About How to Test H.I.V. Drugs
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Scientists are arguing about the extent to which it is ethical to pay participants, and whether results of trials that do so can be trusted.
lead_paragraph: The surprising failure of a large clinical trial of H.I.V.-prevention methods in Africa — and the elaborate deceptions employed by the women in it — have opened an ethical debate about how to run such studies in poor countries and have already changed the design of some that are now underway.

headline: Wood Taps Give Works a Slick Beat
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presents an imaginative lineup of works for percussion at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: During a performance of Thierry de Mey’s “Musique de tables” for percussion trio (1987), Ian David Rosenbaum, Christopher Froh and Ayano Kataoka sat at a table on the stage of Alice Tully Hall like three somber-faced magicians, their athletically choreographed tap-dancing hands eliciting a remarkable array of tones and timbres from the pieces of wood laid flat in front of them.

headline: That Versatile Instrument, the Voice
abstract: NYFOS Next, sponsored by the New York Festival of Song, concentrates on vocal music.
lead_paragraph: “What is a human voice? What can it do?” Michael Barrett, the artistic director of the New York Festival of Song, asked this before the premiere of a work by the Navajo composer Juantio Becenti during the sterling opening concert of this year’s NYFOS Next series at Opera America’s National Opera Center on Tuesday.

headline: Ferguson Tries Something Different
abstract: The police department is trying a largely untested, supposedly non-lethal projectile fired from a handgun.
lead_paragraph: The police department of Ferguson, Mo., after suffering months of notoriety over the shooting death of Michael Brown, has embraced an alternative to deadly force: A largely untested, supposedly non-lethal projectile fired from a policeman’s handgun.

headline: Ebola Drug Aids Some in a Study in West Africa
abstract: Favipiravir has shown preliminary signs of effectiveness in a study, raising questions about its wider use and the testing of another therapy.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, a drug is showing promising signs of effectiveness in Ebola patients participating in a study. The medicine, which interferes with the virus’s ability to copy itself, seems to have halved mortality — to 15 percent, from 30 percent — in patients with low to moderate levels of Ebola in their blood, researchers have found. It had no effect in patients with more virus in their blood, who are more likely to die.

headline: Reality TV’s New Capital Rests Deep in Missouri
abstract: “A Very Barry Branson” follows the former “Brady Bunch” star Barry Williams in his quest to start a 1970s-themed stage show in the Missouri mecca of country music.
lead_paragraph: This is a Disturbing Nascent Trend Alert: Branson, Mo., appears to have discovered television.

headline: Patriots Celebrate Super Bowl Win
abstract: The New England Patriots celebrated their win over the Seattle Seahawks in the Super Bowl with a parade in Boston on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The New England Patriots celebrated their win over the Seattle Seahawks in the Super Bowl with a parade in Boston on Wednesday.

headline: Revenge of the ‘Impossible’ Play
abstract: The Toronto writer Sheila Heti’s stalled drama-in-a-novel comes to life on the stage.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — On a cold evening in late January, a dozen or so actors were standing in a circle in a cramped rehearsal room here, harmonizing their way through an earnest indie pop song that warned against becoming “the thing you hated.”

headline: Do We Really Want to Regulate Internet Providers?
abstract: The F.C.C. chairman wants to reclassify the Internet as a public utility to ensure net neutrality. Will that help or hurt innovation?

headline: An Animator’s Death Releases a Flood of Sadness
abstract: The animator Monty Oum dies at 33, and his many fans grieve.
lead_paragraph: For fans of a certain kind of animation, Monty Oum was the Wizard — and the King, the Knight and the Pawn, all rolled into one. Millions of people watched his web series “Red vs. Blue” and “RWBY.” At conventions, thousands of fans, sometimes dolled up in the outfits of fantasy characters he created, waited for hours just to meet him.

headline: Bobby Shmurda Will Stay in Jail After $2 Million Bail Package Is Withdrawn
abstract: A $2 million bail package application that was posted last week was withdrawn, the prosecutor’s office said.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Shmurda will remain in jail for the time being.

headline: Joy in Boston, and a Parade of Questions in Seattle
abstract: The Patriots of Bill Belichick and Tom Brady always seem able to dig themselves out, but it will take a lot of work for the Seahawks to overcome such a devastating loss.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of fans ignored freezing temperatures Wednesday in Boston and turned out to honor their beloved New England Patriots with a championship parade. Despite two recent storms, which have buried the city under three feet of snow, the Patriots’ faithful lined a route from the Prudential Center to City Hall Plaza and cheered as amphibious trucks carrying players and coaches passed by.

headline: At Championships in China, Deft Defense but a Lost Match
abstract: A deal from the last board of a Mixed Teams quarterfinal at last year’s world championships in Sanya, China.
lead_paragraph: “I won the battle but lost the war.” That might have been the comment by Bill Pollack of New York City after the diagramed deal.

headline: Led by Tinder, a Surge in Mobile Dating Apps
abstract: Many app makers are trying to capitalize on the Tinder method of simple, smartphone-based dating. Of course, they add a twist to the swipe.
lead_paragraph: BLESS or curse the smartphone, but you can’t doubt its impact. Even digital dating has become a hand-held activity.

headline: Androgynous Eccentrics, All Moving on Their Own
abstract: The Nederlands Dans Theater, in a six-day stay at the Joyce, ventures into the offbeat and narcissistic.
lead_paragraph: The dancers of Nederlands Dans Theater — or rather its junior company, NDT2 — look individual, frank, unorthodox. As the company’s quadruple bill at the Joyce Theater proceeds, everything looks increasingly offbeat.

headline: Making Overtures Across the Plaza
abstract: At Lincoln Center, institutions that once competed, sometimes bitterly, over audiences, resources and donors are increasingly teaming up in ways both large and small.
lead_paragraph: It was a day of rehearsals all around Lincoln Center, and plenty of well-known artists were hard at work — but not in their usual places.

headline: Galleries’ Records Are Subpoenaed
abstract: The inquiries are reminiscent of an investigation started in 2002, when the district attorney conducted a large-scale review of potential fraud in sales tax payments on art purchases.
lead_paragraph: Several art galleries and dealers have received subpoenas from the Manhattan district attorney’s office requesting sales and shipping records, according to lawyers for the businesses, suggesting that investigators may be revisiting the issue of whether galleries and collectors are properly paying sales tax for art sold in New York, the lawyers said.

headline: Grain by Wood Grain, a Movable Feast
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Art', 'Wood and Wood Products']
abstract: Gaylord Schanilec’s “Lac DesPleurs,” a book made with centuries-old woodblock printing methods, suggests how such artisanry is experiencing a golden era.
lead_paragraph: SAN MARCOS, TEX. — On the day before New Year’s Eve, after making the 19-hour drive to Texas from Wisconsin, the writer and artisan Gaylord Schanilec began checking the status of the precious cargo that had been sitting, uninsured, in the bed of his Chevy Silverado. In the home studio of Craig Jensen, a bookbinder here, Mr. Schanilec plucked more than half a million dollars out of Rubbermaid storage bins. The money was in the form of 100 bubble-wrapped copies of “Lac Des Pleurs,” Mr. Schanilec’s ode to Lake Pepin, near his home in Stockholm, Wis., population 69. The going rate for each copy is $5,000.

headline: Homeland Insecurities
abstract: “Allegiance,” on NBC, joins the FX drama “The Americans,” the Showtime series “Homeland” and NBC’s own “State of Affairs” in the prime-time espionage sweepstakes.
lead_paragraph: The heroine of “Allegiance” has a brilliant son who works at the C.I.A. and has no idea that his mother is a Russian spy.

headline: ‘Men Is Cheap’
abstract: The late Civil War saw a booming market in recruiting fraud.
lead_paragraph: In February 1865, The New York Times announced sensational news: 27 recruitment and bounty brokers had been arrested after a federal government investigation into allegations of huge military recruitment fraud. Spearheaded by Lafayette C. Baker, the government’s detective in chief, the investigation laid bare a nationwide network of malfeasance, implicating businessmen, local government officials, military officers and soldiers engaged in a concerted effort to fraudulently help communities achieve their draft quotas by forging enlistment documents, and then surreptitiously pocketing the commissions paid for reaching those numbers.

headline: On the Red Carpet, a Revolt Builds Over the Pageantry
keywords: ['Movies', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Some A-listers have joined a growing outcry against the objectification of women on the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s Screen Actors Guild Awards, Julianne Moore, Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston made headlines, of a sort, by taking the revolutionary step of refusing to stick their paws in E!’s Mani Cam.

headline: Photographing a Filipino View of the Streets
abstract: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that country’s far-flung diaspora.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit opening this week in the Philippines showcases the work of street photographers, many of whom live among that country’s far-flung diaspora.

headline: Why Google Glass Broke
abstract: How Google Glass went from the hottest thing in wearable tech to the Edsel of Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: This is a story that involves lots of public intrigue, a futuristic wearable technology, a secret laboratory, fashion models, sky divers and an interoffice love triangle that ended a billionaire’s marriage. This is the story of Google Glass.

headline: Under Armour Buys 2 Fitness Apps, Including MyFitnessPal
abstract: To expand its fitness empire, the company agreed to buy the makers of MyFitnessPal and Endomondo for a combined total of $560 million.
lead_paragraph: To expand its fitness empire, Under Armour has again looked online for growth opportunities.

headline: Attuned in Rhythm, Whether Together or Apart
abstract: In a collaborative evening, Raja Feather Kelly and Tzveta Kassabova presented four pieces they created on their own, together and with the choreographer Sara Pearson.
lead_paragraph: The split bill can feel like a tired format: One person shows work, then another does, and then we go home. But with “Super We,” the dancers Raja Feather Kelly and Tzveta Kassabova really made something of it. In this collaborative evening at St. Mark’s Church, part of Danspace Project’s Dance: Access series, Mr. Kelly and Ms. Kassabova presented four pieces they created on their own, together and with the more seasoned choreographer Sara Pearson. And they put refreshing thought into how the night would unfurl, from simple flourishes, like programs folded into paper airplanes, to hypnotic musical interludes by the composer Aleksei Stevens.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

abstract: The fallout from Representative Aaron Schock’s “Downton Abbey”- inspired office continues.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from Representative Aaron Schock’s “Downton Abbey”- inspired office continues.

headline: Wait, What, I’m a Millennial?
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Age, Chronological', 'Youth', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Neither digital-world natives nor victims of the Great Recession, the children of the early ’80s deserve a different label.
lead_paragraph: The news that millennials will soon overtake baby boomers as the United States’ largest living generation disturbed me. Not the prediction itself, but the realization that, according to the standard definition, I am a millennial. Anyone born between 1981 and 1997 has been thrust into that category, and I was born in 1983. The label doesn’t feel right. I don’t identify with the kids that Time magazine described as technology-addled narcissists, the Justin Bieber fans who “boomerang” back home instead of growing up.

lead_paragraph: Diana Ross performed at the reopening of the renovated Kings Theater in Brooklyn on Tuesday night.

headline: At Madewell, Mickey Drexler’s Third Act
abstract: Mr. Drexler, who defined affordable American style at the Gap and J. Crew, turns his talents to Madewell.
lead_paragraph: Millard Drexler took three steps into the Madewell store on the corner of 19th Street and Fifth Avenue and already he was annoyed. Eight soggy umbrellas were scattered on the hardwood floor, rain collecting in puddles.

headline: Pop Royalty, Rechristening a Regal Stage
abstract: Diana Ross performed at the reopening of the renovated Kings Theater in Brooklyn on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Early on Tuesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio delivered his State of the City address, staking out his vision of a more unified New York, promising to invest in neighborhoods that had been long overlooked in hopes of curbing economic inequality.

lead_paragraph: Syracuse announced a self-imposed one-year postseason ban for its men’s basketball team Wednesday because of a continuing N.C.A.A. investigation.

headline: The Fine-Wine Theory of Fashion Advertising
abstract: The new Barneys campaign employs 10 of modeling’s most seasoned beauties including Christie Brinkley and 28 younger men magnetized in their thrall.
lead_paragraph: What becomes a legend most? Boy toys.

headline: A Sweet Blur Hides All
abstract: The hidden beauty of an effective under-eye concealer.
lead_paragraph: BEE SHAPIRO — Somewhere amid attending law school, pulling corporate lawyer hours, switching careers and having a baby, I gave up on under-eye concealer. I had all the typical complaints — puffiness, dark circles and even the beginnings of something crepe-y — but concealer didn’t do much more than my foundation did. Besides, many under-eye concealers rely on radiance (a.k.a., shimmery stuff) to distract from imperfections. Instead I would pat-pat some liquid or powder base below my bloodshot peepers and call it a day. So you could say I was skeptical about the Giorgio Armani Maestro Eraser Dark Circle Concealer ($42).

headline: Infections Tied to Lower Rheumatoid Arthritis Risk
abstract: Stomach and urinary tract infections are associated with a reduced risk for rheumatoid arthritis.
lead_paragraph: Stomach and urinary tract infections may have a bright side: A new study reports that they are associated with a reduced risk for rheumatoid arthritis.

headline: Meet Olivier Polge, Chanel’s New Fragrance Creator
abstract: Chanel appointed Mr. Polge to succeed his father, Jacques Polge, the man behind hits like Coco Mademoiselle, Chance and Allure.
lead_paragraph: The world of fragrance can be Old World and clubby, so it didn’t appear much of a stretch when Chanel appointed Olivier Polge, right, to succeed his father, Jacques Polge, the house’s fragrance creator since 1978 and the man behind hits like Coco Mademoiselle, Chance and Allure. The younger Mr. Polge, 40, brings his own bragging rights to the plum spot: He created best sellers like Viktor & Rolf’s Flowerbomb and Balenciaga’s Florabotanica. But will he fare as well in today’s changing landscape? Beauty counters are littered with niche brands, and according to the research firm Canadean, the fragrance market in the United States is projected to grow far slower (4.8 percent from 2013 to 2018) than in, say, India (23.4 percent) or Russia (8.9 percent).

headline: Desktop Diversions
abstract: In an era of digital devices, why are simple desktop toys still so appealing?
lead_paragraph: In an era of digital devices, why are simple desktop toys still so appealing?

headline: A Walk-In Bar for Hair Extensions
abstract: RPZL offers hair extensions on the spot.
lead_paragraph: Blow-dry bars have made no-appointment blowouts as easy as popping in off the street, but for more-complex hair care, planning is still required. But those days may be numbered. When RPZL opens Thursday in the Flatiron district, hair extensions will get the same kind of treatment. Women will be able to walk in and get extensions on the spot.

headline: Lasting Love, by the Letters
abstract: When Lauren Fleishman discovered her grandparents’ love letters, she decided to find couples who have stayed married for a half-century or more.
lead_paragraph: When Lauren Fleishman discovered her grandparents’ love letters, she decided to find couples who have stayed married for a half-century or more.

headline: Lisa Perry Evening Wear, Valentine’s Day Clutches and More Shopping News
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Dresses', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Fur', "Valentine's Day", 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: A designer known for her Pop Art collaborations pulls from Schumacher’s celebrated prints; accessories for the romantic and more.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, after reading an article on Dara Caponigro, the creative director of the 125-year-old fabric company Schumacher, Lisa Perry, known for her ’60s-style shifts and Pop Art collaborations, knew immediately that she wanted to collaborate with the company on an evening-wear collection. Ms. Perry’s family owned a home-textile business, and she had long been aware of Schumacher’s celebrated prints. The 13-piece capsule collection combines Schumacher patterns with Ms. Perry’s favorite shapes. The silk gown shown here uses the Art Deco Les Gazelles au Bois print released in 1927 ($1,995). The chenille minidress is Serengeti in Tigre Blanc ($1,495). The collection will be at Lisa Perry, 988 Madison Avenue, and lisaperrystyle.com on Feb. 23.

headline: A Selfie With Lady Gaga at MoMA PS1
abstract: At MoMA PS1 in Queens, a look at the Crusades from an Arab perspective gains a follower in Lady Gaga.
lead_paragraph: Where does the globe-trotting art world go in the winter lull between Art Basel Miami Beach and the spring art fairs and biennales?

abstract: Friends and co-workers share memories of some of those who died in the accident, including the driver of the S.U.V. stuck on the tracks and three passengers on the train.
lead_paragraph: The five men rode up front, whether out of preference or habit or for no good reason. They were going home from a day’s work. Finance work. Art work. Things like that.

headline: Palmieri, White House Communications Director, to Join Clinton Team
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has added the White House communications director, Jennifer Palmieri, to her fledgling 2016 presidential campaign staff.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has added Jennifer Palmieri, the White House’s communications director, to her fledgling 2016 presidential campaign staff.

headline: In Hudson, N.Y., Painting by Numbers
abstract: Fourteen artists were invited to burrow, excavate and embellish a couple’s Hudson, N.Y., home for a show open to the public called “Interventions II.”
lead_paragraph: Hudson, N.Y. — Last month, Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay invited a few friends over to help renovate the 164-year-old, brick two-family house they bought in November. But if you’re imagining an episode of “This Old House,” think again.

headline: Asking More of the Landscape
abstract: Planting with the birds, the bees and the butterflies in mind.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t believe I’ve been running this event for 19 years, but you seem to keep coming back,” Bob Hyland told the cheering crowd at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden’s auditorium last week. “A few growers from the North Fork are still digging out of 30 inches of snow. But they’re with us in spirit.”

headline: Designing Distraction: Executive Toys
abstract: In an era of digital devices, why are simple desktop toys still so appealing?
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art is a temple of useful design. It has sponsored chair-making competitions, turned a vacant lot into a showcase of prefabricated housing and exhibited paper clips as if they were Rothkos. Its retail arm, the MoMA Store, is filled with beautiful but sensible objects.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: A collection of Valentine’s Day shopping suggestions and sales.
lead_paragraph: Love — or is it lust? — is definitely in the air. On Friday, from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m., the emerging designer showroom the Shiny Squirrel will host a “lovecentric” event with 25 percent off jewelry, like ridge brass cuffs by Laurel Hill Jewelry ($96, originally $128), and tarot card readings ($10). At Species by the Thousands, 171 South Fourth Street, Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: Fourteen artists were invited to burrow, excavate and embellish a couple’s home in Hudson, N.Y.

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The farmhouse in Columbia County was a new kind of habitat for a pair that had spent a quarter-century on beaches of Fire Island.
lead_paragraph: After 25 years of owning a beach house, Dr. Sam Grubman and Paul Morris decided to trade it in for a house in the woods. And not for the happiest of reasons, initially at least: Dr. Grubman, an allergist who is now 55, had developed melanoma.

headline: Mix Masters: Cocktail Shakers
abstract: Cocktail shakers don’t have to look this good to work, but why not add a splash of delight?
lead_paragraph: As the owners of Coffinier Ku Design in Manhattan, Etienne Coffinier and Ed Ku have designed plenty of bars, for both restaurants and private homes. So they’ve spent a certain amount of time studying the intricacies of cocktail preparation.

abstract: In Stephen Cassell’s thoroughly modern chicken coop, form follows fowl.

headline: Antiques at Your Fingertips
abstract: A new mobile app from 1stdibs adds location features and browsable collections to the online antique marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom suggests that shoppers would be reluctant to buy something as pricey as, say, a $22,000 Sergio Rodrigues bench in grained jacaranda wood on their smartphones. But 1stdibs, the online antiques marketplace where the bench was sold, isn’t a place for typical consumers, or spendthrifts. And so, after several years with only a website, the company is introducing its first mobile app.

headline: Metal and Concrete Show Their Delicate Sides
abstract: Though made of heavy materials, Joshua Howe’s coffee table appears lightweight enough to float.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy to make a piece of furniture look lightweight enough to float when you’re using materials like steel and concrete. Yet that is exactly what Joshua Howe has done with his Y-series coffee table.

lead_paragraph: Ekaterina Panikanova is a book lover, but not in the traditional sense. A Russian-born artist, she uses the pages of old French and Italian books that she finds at flea markets as her canvases.

lead_paragraph: “It sounds so easy, but it’s not,” Eileen Mockus said. Ms. Mockus, the chief executive of the textiles company Coyuchi, was referring to the rigors of adhering to international standards for manufacturing organic household goods.

headline: Overseer of Fannie and Freddie Takes Cautious Steps to Strengthen Housing Market

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The housing market is finally on the mend, but any major transformation in the government’s role in the housing economy does not appear to be on the agenda of a top federal housing regulator.

headline: Passenger Describes Metro-North Crash
abstract: Steven Lichtenthal, of Bedford Hills, N.Y., rode in the back of a middle car involved in the fatal Metro-North crash on Tuesday. He described how the accident unfolded.
lead_paragraph: Steven Lichtenthal, of Bedford Hills, N.Y., rode in the back of a middle car involved in the fatal Metro-North crash on Tuesday. He described how the accident unfolded.

headline: Fox Reduces Its Forecast for Growth
abstract: 21st Century Fox slashed its guidance for long-term growth because of struggles in its broadcast group, unfavorable foreign currency exchange and shifts in its film group.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-First Century Fox slashed its guidance for long-term growth on Wednesday because of struggles in its broadcast group, unfavorable foreign currency exchange and shifts in its film group, sending shares in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire tumbling more than 5 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Mary Healy, Actress and Singer, Dies at 96
abstract: Ms. Healy and Peter Lind Hayes were a husband-and-wife comedy team on TV in the 1950s and ’60s and portrayed their New Rochelle, N.Y., suburban life on radio.
lead_paragraph: Mary Healy, an actress and singer who was part of a husband-and-wife comedy team with Peter Lind Hayes in the 1950s and ’60s, appearing on television and in a “life in suburbia” radio broadcast from their home in Westchester County, N.Y., died on Tuesday in Calabasas, Calif. She was 96.

headline: Crash on the Tracks
abstract: The morning after a deadly Metro-North accident, riders adjusted their commutes as investigators worked to understand how a sport-utility vehicle became stranded on the tracks in Valhalla, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The morning after a deadly Metro-North accident, riders adjusted their commutes as investigators worked to understand how a sport-utility vehicle became stranded on the tracks in Valhalla, N.Y.

headline: North Korea Says It Sees No Reason to Hold Talks With U.S.
abstract: The North accused the United States of planning to “bring down” its government and threatened to fight back with cyberattacks and nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Wednesday that it saw no reason to negotiate with the “gangster-like” United States any more, warning that it was ready to fight any type of war with Americans, including ones involving cyberattacks and nuclear weapons.

headline: Senate Democrats Again Block Homeland Security Funding Tied to Immigration
abstract: Financing for the Department of Homeland Security has become the proxy for a broader policy disagreement over executive actions on immigration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the second consecutive day, Senate Democrats blocked their Republican colleagues from bringing a bill to the floor to fund the Department of Homeland Security, which has become a proxy for a broader policy disagreement over President Obama’s executive actions on immigration.

headline: Amid Economic Woes and Public Discontent, Putin Critic Sees Opening
abstract: In an interview, Aleksei A. Navalny said economic woes and public antagonism toward the nation’s role in Ukraine have made President Vladimir V. Putin vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Glancing out the window at the swirling snow, Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition activist, mused aloud about how mounting economic problems, along with some public antagonism toward the Kremlin’s role in the war in Ukraine, may have damaged President Vladimir V. Putin’s administration enough to make it vulnerable.

headline: Operator of Drone That Crashed Outside White House May Be Charged
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Secret Service agents investigating the man who operated the drone that crashed on the White House lawn last week said they believed there was enough evidence to charge him with a crime.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secret Service agents investigating the man who operated the drone that crashed on the White House lawn last week believed there was enough evidence to charge him with a crime, and they have presented the case to federal prosecutors, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Governor of Illinois Takes Aim at Labor
abstract: In his first State of the State address, Gov. Bruce Rauner, a Republican, said the state should ban some political contributions by public employee unions and allow local “right to work” laws.
lead_paragraph: Joining the ranks of Republican governors taking aim at the power of labor unions, the new chief executive of Illinois, Gov. Bruce Rauner, said on Wednesday that the state should ban some political contributions by public employee unions and allow local “right to work” laws.

headline: New Challenges to Secrecy That Protects Police Files
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Police']
abstract: A case that seeks to unlock grand jury evidence in the police killing of Eric Garner is part of a national push to pry from law enforcement information long kept secret.
lead_paragraph: A case headed for a Staten Island courtroom on Thursday that seeks to unlock grand jury evidence in the police killing of Eric Garner is part of a national push to pry from law enforcement information long kept secret.

headline: Tiger Woods Is Lost, on Course and in Thought
abstract: After shooting his worst round as a pro last week at the Phoenix Open, Woods tried to regain his mastery of his short game at Torrey Pines, where he has a history of success.
lead_paragraph: LA JOLLA, Calif. — Using his wedge, Tiger Woods hit two dozen balls from just off the second green of Torrey Pines’ North Course. His compulsive chipping called to mind someone hoping that with enough swings of a fly swatter he could silence the buzzing around his head.

headline: Brian Williams Admits He Wasn’t on Copter Shot Down in Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Apologies']
abstract: The NBC anchor said he was on a helicopter behind one that was hit in 2003 and that he had conflated the two.
lead_paragraph: The NBC News anchor Brian Williams apologized Wednesday for mistakenly claiming he had been on a helicopter that was shot down by ground fire in Iraq in 2003.

headline: Walter Liedtke, Curator at Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Liedtke, a curator of European paintings at the Met for 35 years and a Vermeer scholar, was killed in Tuesday’s crash of a Metro-North train.
lead_paragraph: Walter Liedtke, who served for 35 years as a curator of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and was a renowned scholar on Vermeer and the Delft School, died on Tuesday, one of six victims of the crash of a Metro-North commuter train in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: Iran’s President Accuses West of Distorting Atomic Plans
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani, in a speech aimed at domestic critics, denounced the United States and Israel for what he called false and hypocritical warnings about Iran’s atomic ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Portraying himself to be as tough as his domestic critics, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran criticized nuclear-armed powers on Wednesday, singling out the United States and Israel for what he described as false and hypocritical warnings about Iranian atomic ambitions.

headline: Man Accused of Killing His Girlfriend in 2013 Goes on Trial
abstract: Bismark Lithgow’s lawyer argued that her client was in the grip of an extreme emotional disturbance when he stabbed his girlfriend 38 times.
lead_paragraph: They met online, like so many young couples these days, and found they had a lot in common: They were both deaf, young and from the Dominican Republic. She attended a school for the deaf in Rhode Island; he lived with his grandmother in Upper Manhattan, and worked at a sports club.

headline: As Greece Rebels, the Notion of Debt Forgiveness Returns
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Government Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: With Europe grappling with staggeringly high unemployment and stubbornly low growth, showing some mercy on debt may yet gain ground.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s most powerful policy makers dismiss the idea, investors fear it, and it would almost certainly face fierce resistance from within the Continent’s richer countries.

headline: Patriots Parade Through Boston, as Fans Brave Snowstorm’s Aftermath
abstract: Two days after a bear of a snowstorm, Boston shoved the snow aside and got down to the business of celebrating the New England Patriots’ Super Bowl victory.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Rob Gronkowski slurped beer and gyrated. Malcolm Butler, until recently his fairly little-known teammate, grinned at his newly adoring public. Even Bill Belichick, the stoic coach, cracked a smile.

headline: A Day of Grand Displays, but the Pen Is Mightiest
abstract: National signing day, when high school football stars reveal commitments to college programs, has evolved into hours of unmatched pageantry, with elaborate staged announcements and comic gimmicks.
lead_paragraph: On the fourth Thursday of November, Americans gather with their families to give thanks. On the last Monday of May, they remember those who gave their lives for their country. And on the first Wednesday of February, they scan Twitter to find out where several dozen talented 18-year-olds have decided to go play college football.

headline: S.E.C. Commissioners Split on Waiving Financial Industry Punishment
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Two Democratic members criticized their agency for allowing Oppenheimer & Company to avoid a ban that would have disqualified it from most private offerings of securities.
lead_paragraph: Oppenheimer & Company has looked the part of a financial industry recidivist, its rap sheet replete with at least 30 regulatory actions over the last decade.

headline: Lawyers Who Appeared in Anti-Police Video Are Forced to Resign
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Two lawyers from a New York City-funded nonprofit group had appeared in a rap video that endorsed murderous retribution for the death of Eric Garner.
lead_paragraph: Two lawyers from a city-funded nonprofit group have been forced to resign over their appearance in a rap video that endorsed murderous retribution for the death of Eric Garner, the mayor’s office said on Wednesday.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 4, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Barges Sit for Hours Behind Locks That May Take Decades to Replace
abstract: More funding will be needed to modernize a decrepit system that was built mainly in the 1930s and is slowing commerce.
lead_paragraph: PADUCAH, Ky. — On a recent winter morning, Randy Holt piloted the boat Bill Berry as it pushed a group of barges nearly as long as two football fields steadily down the Tennessee River to the Kentucky Lock and Dam here. But then Mr. Holt had to wait several hours at what has become a major choke point as boats moved one at a time through the narrow, cracked, 70-year-old lock.

headline: Jim Harbaugh, Playing Catch-Up, Snares Recruits for Michigan
abstract: Harbaugh had his work cut out for him, inheriting a recruiting class from Brady Hoke that was in shambles and starting with only six verbal commitments.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Jim Harbaugh returned to the college ranks to coach at his alma mater, Michigan, he started a new Twitter account. He sent out motivational messages, occasionally retweeted the pope and offered a glimpse into his intense psyche.

headline: Rail Crossing Accidents Decline Nationwide, but Less So in New York Region
abstract: There were 28 grade-crossing accidents on the three major commuter rail lines in the New York region in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Railroad crossings, with their flashing lights and descending gates, are a fixture of suburban living. The hundreds of crossings along commuter rail lines in New York and New Jersey can be a nuisance for drivers whose journeys are being interrupted, but they are also something to be feared, crossroads that can easily turn dangerous.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Propose Alternative to Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: Under the plan, workers would have to pay federal income tax on the value of employer-provided health benefits that exceed certain thresholds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three influential Republican members of Congress unveiled a comprehensive proposal on Wednesday to replace President Obama’s health care overhaul with an alternative that would halt the expansion of Medicaid and scale back subsidies for middle-income people to buy private insurance.

headline: Guiding Lights
abstract: Mike Buckley weaves his 15-letter entries together.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It’s always impressive when a constructor can intersect 15-letter entries in a puzzle, but when the entire theme is made up of interlocked 15s and they’re all song titles, I think that’s really elegant.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Elizabeth, Prepared to Carry On
abstract: In this episode, Oleg and Stan meet in a dark alley. And yes, there’s a gun.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 2: “Baggage”

headline: In Surprise, Lindsey Vonn Will Race in Super Combined and Giant Slalom
abstract: Vonn announced that she would compete in the super combined and the giant slalom at the Alpine ski world championships, races she has not competed in for more than two years.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Fresh off her third-place finish in Tuesday’s super-G and gearing up for Friday’s downhill, Lindsey Vonn announced that she would also compete in the super combined and the giant slalom next week here at the Alpine world ski championships.

headline: On a Metro-North Train, Passengers Pause Before Picking a Seat
abstract: Some commuters on the 5:49 p.m. to White Plains had second thoughts about riding in the first car, which had been demolished in the previous night’s accident.
lead_paragraph: John Rose has been taking Metro-North trains home to White Plains for 30 years, and he sits in the second row of the first car whenever he can. He paused on Wednesday night at Grand Central Terminal as he boarded the 5:49 train on the Harlem line, but habit won again. The car was nearly empty, he said, and he was not afraid.

headline: Sri Lanka’s New Government Hopes to Revisit Past on Its Own Terms
keywords: ['Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The country hopes that its promise to look into war crimes will forestall the release of a United Nations inquiry that is set to be released in March.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Sri Lanka’s new government, which swept into power in January on a platform of national reconciliation, is lobbying to quash — or at least defer for a few months — a landmark United Nations inquiry into war crimes set to be released in March.

headline: Two Million New Yorkers Have Signed Up for Insurance on Health Exchange
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: While Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo heralded the overall numbers as a sign of the program’s success, having three out of four enrollees on Medicaid could impose a heavy burden on public finances.
lead_paragraph: About two million New Yorkers have signed up for insurance under the Affordable Care Act, with three out of every four of them poor enough to qualify for Medicaid, according to figures released Wednesday by the Cuomo administration.

headline: New York State Attorney General Reaches Deal to Reduce Price of Heroin Antidote
keywords: ['Naloxone (Drug)', 'Heroin', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman had previously criticized Amphastar Pharmaceuticals for doubling the price of naloxone, which is used by many government agencies to reverse overdoses.
lead_paragraph: Two months after sharply criticizing a drug manufacturer for raising the price of its heroin antidote medication, Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, is expected to announce on Thursday an agreement with the company to offset those rates, as well as any new increases, for one year.

headline: Pre-9/11 Ties Haunt Saudis as New Accusations Surface
abstract: American officials have praised the Saudi government for cracking down on terrorism, but suspicions of a past, tacit alliance with Al Qaeda burst into the open again this week.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — During the 1980s and ’90s, the historic alliance between the wealthy monarchy of Saudi Arabia and the country’s powerful clerics emerged as the major financier of international jihad, channeling tens of millions of dollars to Muslim fighters in Afghanistan, Bosnia and elsewhere. Among the project’s major patrons was Prince Salman Bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, who last month became Saudi Arabia’s king.

headline: Law Professor Opposes Grand Central Tower Plan
abstract: Laurence H. Tribe, a professor of constitutional law at Harvard, testified on behalf of Grand Central’s owner against a planned office tower and rezoning.
lead_paragraph: In the long-running battle over a proposed 65-story office tower next to Grand Central Terminal, a little-known real estate investor has lobbied New York City officials, supported community opposition and offered to buy the project site from the developer.

headline: South Korea Vows ‘Strong Crackdown’ on Uber
abstract: The government rejected a proposal to register Uber drivers, saying it would create more taxis in an already crowded market.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean government on Thursday rejected a regulatory compromise suggested by Uber and vowed a “strong crackdown” on its ride-hailing services.

headline: The Sounds of the Downhill
abstract: Some of the top ski racers in the world describe the sounds of a World Cup downhill.
lead_paragraph: Some of the top ski racers in the world describe the sounds of a World Cup downhill.

headline: Cuba: Artist Awaits Decision on Charges
abstract: Tania Bruguera, a Cuban artist based in New York who was arrested in December in Havana, said Wednesday that she had not been able to find a lawyer willing to defend her.
lead_paragraph: Tania Bruguera, a Cuban artist based in New York who was arrested in December in Havana, where she planned to stage an open-mike performance to ask citizens to speak about their visions for Cuba, said Wednesday that she had not been able to find a lawyer willing to defend her and that prosecutors had been given 60 more days to decide whether to charge her. The charges being considered include inciting public disorder. She has been released, but her passport has been confiscated. She said six lawyers had refused to represent her because they believed that her case was a lost cause or feared that defending her might hurt their careers.

headline: Greece: Rightists Ordered to Stand Trial
abstract: A panel of judges ruled Wednesday that the leader of the neo-fascist party Golden Dawn and more than a dozen party lawmakers are among 72 people who would stand trial on charges that include participation in a criminal organization, murder and assault.
lead_paragraph: A panel of judges ruled Wednesday that the leader of the neo-fascist party Golden Dawn and more than a dozen party lawmakers are among 72 people who would stand trial on charges that include participation in a criminal organization, murder and assault. The ruling followed a 15-month investigation into the party, which is widely regarded as one of Europe’s most violent far-right groups. The defendants include 18 Golden Dawn lawmakers who were elected to Greece’s Parliament in the 2012 general elections, including two who have since left the party, as well as 54 members or supporters of Golden Dawn. Golden Dawn dismissed the charges, saying the party and its supporters are victims of “persecution” and a “political frame-up.”

headline: Claims Against Saudis Cast New Light on Secret Pages of 9/11 Report
abstract: Accusations by the former Qaeda operative Zacarias Moussaoui have fueled calls for President Obama to declassify a section of the 2002 report.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A still-classified section of the investigation by congressional intelligence committees into the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has taken on an almost mythic quality over the past 13 years — 28 pages that examine crucial support given the hijackers and that by all accounts implicate prominent Saudis in financing terrorism.

headline: Q. and A.: Matt Ferchen on China and the Price of Oil
abstract: Matt Ferchen, an associate professor of international relations at Tsinghua University in Beijing, discusses how oil prices will affect China’s relations with other countries and its transition to a more energy-efficient future.
lead_paragraph: The recent global drop in oil prices has made winners of consumers in places like the United States and Japan, and losers of countries that depend heavily on oil exports such as Russia, Iran and Venezuela. China, a leading crude oil importer and the world’s largest energy consumer, has responded to the fall in oil prices — the steepest since 2009 — by going on a buying spree to ensure that its strategic oil reserves at the end of 2014 were twice what they were the year before. Last month, in another move to bolster the country’s supplies, China’s top economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, directed domestic oil refiners to stock up on crude oil and to provide the government with monthly updates on their inventories.

headline: Justin Peck  Finds a Sub for Injured Dancer: Himself
abstract: Dancer injured, Justin Peck fills in during debut of his work at New York City Ballet
lead_paragraph: Justin Peck does not lack for causes of anxiety. As the resident choreographer for New York City Ballet, the 27-year-old is perpetually auditioning for the role of rightful heir to George Balanchine. So imagine what Mr. Peck must have felt when he learned that Andrew Veyette, one of the lead dancers in his “Rodeo: Four Dance Episodes” was injured and could not perform on Wednesday evening at its premiere at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Kiko Lopez’s Gift for Glass
abstract: The Puerto Rican-born artist makes pieces that feel completely modern, sometimes tweaking the patina with an accidental coffee spill or cigarette ash.
lead_paragraph: Kiko Lopez makes mirrors that combine an 18th-century technique with a renegade spirit. Using the painstaking process of verre églomisé, he covers engraved glass with gold and silver leaf, a skill he mastered in the South of France while apprenticing for several retired artisans after, he says, “they realized I was serious and wasn’t just going to make reproductions.” Although he’s committed to respecting tradition, the Puerto Rican-born artist makes pieces that feel completely modern, sometimes tweaking the patina with an accidental coffee spill or cigarette ash. Decorators such as Alberto Pinto, Chahan Minassian and Caroline Sarkozy have commissioned his work, which includes lustrous large-scale mirrors and Jean-Michel Frank-inspired glass fireplaces, and which is now available in America through the New York design shop Maison Gerard.

headline: Haunting Portraits of Abandoned Places
abstract: The photographer Aurélien Villette explores spaces that have been left behind, from the sacred to the industrial.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: More College Freshmen Report Having Felt Depressed
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: High numbers of students are beginning college having felt depressed and overwhelmed during the previous year, according to an annual survey released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: High numbers of students are beginning college having felt depressed and overwhelmed during the previous year, according to an annual survey released on Thursday, reinforcing some experts’ concern about the emotional health of college freshmen.

headline: The Broad Museum in Los Angeles to Open in September
abstract: After two years of delayes, Eli and Edythe Broad’s museum for contemporary art will open on Sept. 20.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a series of construction setbacks, the billionaire art collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have announced that their new art museum downtown will open this year on Sept. 20. The Broads originally expected the building, designed by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, to be completed about two years ago, but they never issued a specific date. (A $19.8 million lawsuit by the museum against the German manufacturer Seele, which fabricated the building’s intricate honeycomb-like facade, is pending.)

headline: The Broad Museum in Los Angeles to Open in September
abstract: After two years of delayes, Eli and Edythe Broad’s museum for contemporary art will open on Sept. 20.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a series of construction setbacks, the billionaire art collectors Eli and Edythe Broad have announced that their new art museum downtown will open this year on Sept. 20. The Broads originally expected the building, designed by Diller Scofidio & Renfro, to be completed about two years ago, but they never issued a specific date. headline: Millions of Anthem Customers Targeted in Cyberattack
abstract: The insurer said hackers were able to breach a database that contained as many as 80 million records of current and former customers, including names, Social Security numbers and income data.
lead_paragraph: Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, said late Wednesday that the personal information of tens of millions of its customers and employees, including its chief executive, was the subject of a “very sophisticated external cyberattack.”

headline: Twitter and Google Said to Reach Deal on Search
abstract: The microblogging service is expected to announce a partnership that will make tweets easier to find in Google search results.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is expected on Thursday to announce a new partnership with Google, clearing the way for tweets on the microblogging service to be easier to find on the world’s most popular search engine.

headline: ‘Mystery Science Theater 3000’ Among Offerings From Shout! Factory Streaming Service
abstract: Shout! Factory TV will offer dozens of episodes of “Mystery Science Theater 3000,” as well as other classic movies and TV shows, through a new streaming service.
lead_paragraph: Wherever there is a strong Internet connection, there will be “The Beast of Yucca Flats.”

headline: Doc Fix: The Budget Gimmick That Actually Isn’t So Bad
abstract: A much-reviled budget measure has worked in reducing the deficit, but not in the exact way that was intended.
lead_paragraph: Here comes one of Washington’s least favorite rituals: the “doc fix.”

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (E!) LANCE LOVES MICHAEL: THE LANCE BASS WEDDING In what is being billed as the first gay celebrity marriage to be televised, Mr. Bass of ’N Sync fame and his fiancé, Michael Turchin, look back on their relationship and their Dec. 20 ceremony, where they exchanged vows before 300 guests at the Park Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. The actresses Jamie-Lynn Sigler and JoAnna Garcia officiated. Mr. Bass involved his former bandmates as well: J. C. Chasez performed “Can’t Help Falling in Love,” and Joey Fatone was the ring bearer.

headline: Jeb Bush, Evangelicals and the Pandering Question
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: For all of his support among party elites, there is new evidence of his weakness with the Republicans’ evangelical base.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the early establishment favorite for the Republican nomination, has suggested that he doesn’t want to have to pander to the party’s base to win the nomination.

headline: What Causes Girls to Enter Puberty Early?
abstract: Stress and being overweight are the most likely culprits.
lead_paragraph: RECORD numbers of girls not yet old enough for middle school are starting puberty. Almost by definition, puberty arrives at an awkward age, but these are grade-school girls, thrown into a developmental gantlet before they are ready for the change.

headline: Bruce Jenner’s Courage
abstract: The 1976 Olympic gold medalist is showing a champion’s mettle in preparing to come out as a transgender woman.
lead_paragraph: When I was a growing up, yearning with my pals to be a track star, one of our heroes was Bruce Jenner. He won a gold medal at the 1976 Olympics in the decathlon, and he adorned our Wheaties boxes. We all wanted to be Bruce Jenner.

headline: The Supreme Court at Stake
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Interstate Commerce', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: If the Supreme Court overturns the Affordable Care Act, it will first have to suspend its own settled approach to interpreting statutes. From Feb. 5, 2015.
lead_paragraph: In the first Affordable Care Act case three years ago, the Supreme Court had to decide whether Congress had the power, under the Commerce Clause or some other source of authority, to require individuals to buy health insurance. It was a question that went directly to the structure of American government and the allocation of power within the federal system.

headline: Lessons From a Deadly Train Crash
abstract: Readers offer ideas for avoiding future collisions at railroad crossings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Do It, Harper Lee
abstract: Why one perfect book from the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird” is all we need.
lead_paragraph: THE news was greeted online with tweets and tumbles of enthusiasm and joy: Harper Lee, the writer who swore she would never publish another book after the instant classic “To Kill a Mockingbird,” had changed her mind. Her new book will be released in July.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Talks Reform
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'State Legislatures', 'Campaign Finance', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: His recent promises to push New York lawmakers to enact stricter income disclosure and campaign finance rules offer some hope in a time of corruption.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo sounded this week a lot like the candidate he was in 2010, when he promised that his first job as governor would be “restoring public trust and accountability” in state government. He has done little to fulfill that pledge, and worse, he canceled the Moreland Commission midway through its investigation of ethical lapses by lawmakers last year. With the arrest of the former Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, on corruption charges, Governor Cuomo, the reformer, has reappeared on the scene.

headline: Will Anyone Pay for Abu Ghraib?
keywords: ['Editorials', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Detainees', 'Torture']
abstract: A civil trial does not guarantee that anyone would be held accountable for the crimes committed at the American prison in Iraq, but it would be an important start.
lead_paragraph: What happened at the Abu Ghraib prison during the early days of the Iraq war is no secret: The whole world has seen the appalling photos.

headline: Abe Is Said to Have Plans to Revise Pacifist Charter
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has said that he wants to seek changes to the Constitution after a parliamentary election, a lawmaker in his party said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has said that he wants to start the process of revising Japan’s Constitution as early as next year, a senior lawmaker in his party said Thursday, giving the clearest indication yet that the Japanese leader will seek to change a document that has undergirded the country’s postwar pacifism.

headline: BNP Paribas Finishes Dismal Year on an Up Note
abstract: Profit rose sharply in the fourth quarter, as the French bank closed out a year in which it paid a record fine in the United States in a sanctions-violation case.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – BNP Paribas, the largest French bank, on Thursday reported strong fourth-quarter profit, putting a positive finish on a year in which it paid a record fine in the United States and pleaded guilty to having traded illegally with blacklisted countries.

headline: TransAsia Airways Faces Scrutiny After 2nd Fatal Crash
abstract: The crash, which killed 31 people and left 12 unaccounted for, was the second deadly accident for TransAsia Airways in less than seven months.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The crash of a passenger plane into a river in Taiwan on Wednesday, which killed at least 31 people, has renewed questions about the safety of the airline, TransAsia Airways. It was the carrier’s second deadly accident in less than seven months.

headline: After Argentine Leader’s Comments, a Challenge to Try Speaking Chinese

headline: E.U. Raises Its Forecast for Growth

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials on Thursday nudged up growth forecasts across the 28-nation bloc amid optimism that falling oil prices, a weaker euro and intervention by the European Central Bank were brightening the outlook for a region wrestling with economic stagnation.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund and Brookfield Property Partners said on Thursday that they had received enough support from investors to move ahead with their $3.9 billion offer for the owner of the Canary Wharf office and retail development.

headline: Takata, Maker of Faulty Airbags, Expects Wider Loss
abstract: The Japanese company has set aside about $425 million to cover recall-related costs and is stepping up production of replacement parts.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Takata, the Japanese car parts supplier embroiled in a crisis over dangerously defective airbags, added $50 million on Thursday to its loss forecast for its fiscal year, saying that it was facing growing costs to replace faulty components in millions of affected vehicles.

headline: U.S. and Europe Working to End Ukraine Fighting
abstract: As the White House weighs sending arms to bolster Ukraine’s forces, Secretary of State John Kerry is joining the leaders of Germany and France in Kiev to bolster peace efforts.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With fighting intensifying in eastern Ukraine and the White House weighing whether to send arms to bolster the government’s forces, Western leaders embarked on a concerted diplomatic effort on Thursday aimed at ending a conflict that has strained relations with Russia.

headline: For A.L.S. Patients, a Hopeful Drug That Is Out of Reach
abstract: When I first noticed I couldn’t type with my left hand, the doctors narrowed down it down to two options: a treatable autoimmune disease or A.L.S. It turned out to be A.L.S., but I’ve recently found a new reason to hope.
lead_paragraph: After the height of the Ice Bucket Challenge last fall, I found myself at a dinner party where the conversation turned to A.L.S. — amyotrophic lateral sclerosis — the disease for which millions were dousing themselves to raise awareness and money.

headline: Stranger in a Strange Land: An Internship Gone Bad
keywords: ['Internships', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Eighteen years old and looking for the “next extraordinary” in Bolivia: one intern’s cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: On my first night in La Paz, Bolivia, I was indoctrinated into the intern culture. Five fellow interns and an 18-year-old staff assistant smoked a blunt until two of them threw up. Over the following weeks, whether it was imbibing San Pedro mescaline around the Tiwanaku ruins or snorting at the underground cocaine bar, Route 36, our social agenda almost always involved substances.

headline: Internships Abroad: Unpaid, With a $10,000 Price Tag

headline: François Hollande Vows to Defend France’s Republican Ideals
abstract: The French president said that the country would fight Islamic radicalism, train imams and reinforce the curriculum in schools to foster a stronger sense of civic identity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France on Thursday sought to reassure a nation still shaken by the recent terrorist attacks in and around Paris, saying that the country would not be cowed by terrorists and would defend its republican ideals of liberty and free expression against those who sought to undermine them.

headline: Daily Report: F.C.C. Proposes Strong Rules to Regulate the Web
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The proposal would create legal authority to ensure that no content is blocked and that the Internet is not divided into fast and slow lanes.
lead_paragraph: For the last year, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been working on new rules to ensure so-called net neutrality, or an open Internet. Over that time, his hints and comments have shown a steady shift toward stronger regulation — and a more direct confrontation with the cable television and telecommunications companies that provide high-speed Internet service to most American homes, Steve Lohr reports.

headline: My Dad, the Pornographer
keywords: ['Pornography', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: What Andrew Offutt, the king of 20th-century smut novels, left his son.
lead_paragraph: My father, Andrew Jefferson Offutt V, grew up in a log cabin in Taylorsville, Ky. The house had 12-inch-thick walls with gun ports to defend against attackers: first Indians, then soldiers during the Civil War. At 12, Dad wrote a novel of the Old West. He taught himself to type with the Columbus method — find it and land on it — using one finger on his left hand and two fingers on his right. Dad typed swiftly and with great passion. In this fashion, he eventually wrote and published more than 400 books. Two were science fiction and 24 were fantasy, written under his own name; the rest were pornography, using 17 pseudonyms.

lead_paragraph: IDEA OF FORGIVING GREEK DEBT RETURNS | Talk of slashing the government debt loads of European countries, beginning with Greece, is back, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. “For all the opposition, the idea has resurfaced with a vengeance in recent days as the new government in Athens, facing a cash squeeze and aiming to make life easier for its citizens, looks for immediate ways to reduce what it owes,” he adds.

headline: Pfizer Bets $15 Billion on New Class of Generic Drugs
keywords: ['Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: Pfizer is making a $15.2 billion bet on the drug industry’s new, more elite class of generics: costly, complex copies of already expensive biotech drugs.

headline: Where Camaraderie Never Gets Old
abstract: At perhaps the most persistent game of pickup basketball in New York City, at the Y.M.C.A. on West 14th Street in Manhattan, age is relative.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Herman was pursuing an angle against a familiar defender when he raised for a hook shot. Harry Bogdos, a 5-foot-8-inch guard who, by his own admission, has shrunk a bit in recent years, did what he could to force Herman into a difficult attempt by extending his arms.

headline: Ordinary People, Wayward Son
abstract: In Anne Tyler’s new novel, “A Spool of Blue Thread,” a middle-class Baltimore family is shaken up by the unexpected return of its problem child.
lead_paragraph: Anne Tyler’s novels tend to walk a narrow line between the moving and the sentimental, the sympathetic and the maudlin, the evocative and the banal. Her best work — like “The Accidental Tourist,” “Breathing Lessons” and the ambitious “Digging to America” — gives us intimate portraits of middle-class life, tracing the centrifugal and centripetal forces of family that can propel individuals outward into the world at large or hold them close at home. Her lesser books, like “A Patchwork Planet” and “Noah’s Compass,” stumble into predictability and cliché. Ms. Tyler’s latest novel, “A Spool of Blue Thread,” unfortunately falls into that category. It recycles virtually every theme and major plot point she has used in the past and does so in the most perfunctory manner imaginable.

headline: Anne Tyler: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “A Spool of Blue Thread” says reading her own books “always feels like lying awake in a bedroom I’ve painted myself; the mistakes are so noticeable and so upsetting.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “A Spool of Blue Thread” says reading her own books “always feels like lying awake in a bedroom I’ve painted myself; the mistakes are so noticeable and so upsetting.”

headline: Petit St. Vincent, a Dot of Green in the Ocean Blue
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Diving and Divers', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Reefs', 'Water']
abstract: A new dive center on the private Caribbean island, opened by Jean-Michel Cousteau, is not just a resort, but an educational facility.
lead_paragraph: When our dive boat captain cut the engine, just east of the island of Mayreau, we lurched for a few minutes in the cyan waters as we prepared to jump overboard. Beneath our hull, our small group had been told, were Mayreau Gardens, a sweep of coral reef massed with gorgeously colored sponges and vibrant sea life, and one of the most beautiful dive sites in St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

headline: Veterans Pan, and Cheer, Their Counterparts on the Screen
abstract: Television and movie portrayals of veterans vary widely, to the frustration of many vets. Here, they say, are some of the best and worst recent examples.
lead_paragraph: Chris Marvin, 35, a retired Army helicopter pilot who broke his legs, an arm and bones in his face in a crash in Afghanistan in 2004, says he often does not recognize the veterans he sees portrayed in movies and television shows. He has had enough of the “broken hero” story lines about the grunt who did incredible things but is now forever damaged.

headline: China Holds a Canadian It Says Stole State Secrets

headline: The Secret World of a Well-Paid ‘Donor Adviser’ in Politics

headline: Greek Debt Diplomacy Doesn’t Sell Well in Germany

headline: Rapping a Revolution
abstract: The composer-performer Lin-Manuel Miranda meets with cast members from his new musical, “Hamilton,” to discuss hip-hop hustle and the founding fathers.
lead_paragraph: “If Hamilton were on Twitter, he would have been a worse oversharer than me,” said the composer-performer Lin-Manuel Miranda recently over lunch at Fraunces Tavern in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Miranda, who won a Tony for the score of “In the Heights,” was holding forth on Alexander Hamilton, the nation’s first treasury secretary, who is the unlikely subject of his new musical, “Hamilton,” now in previews at the Public Theater. In contrast to such relatively taciturn rivals as Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr, Mr. Miranda said, “Everything we know about Hamilton, we knew when he was alive, because he told us.”

headline: In Delicate Dance With Gravity, Downhill Racers Are Soothed by Cacophony
abstract: Downhill racers’ lone companion is noise, and in their merciless and nervy world, sometimes the louder things are the better.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — In an Alpine downhill race, there is no more lonely and solitary position than standing over a pair of skis hurtling down the mountain at 80 miles an hour.

headline: 1915: Germans Threaten Shipping
abstract: Highlight from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany “declares war” on neutral commerce in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Amplifying its programme of attempting to torpedo hospital ships and sink merchantmen without warning and without giving a chance to their non- combatants aboard to escape, Germany has now issued the following amazing proclamation, which is in effect a declaration of war on the neutral commerce, and therefore on the neutral nations of the world: ‘‘The seas surrounding Great Britain and Ireland, including the whole of the English Channel, are hereby declared to be a military zone. On and after February 18, the merchant shipping of the belligerent nations navigating these waters will be destroyed, even when it may not be possible to preserve the crews and passengers from danger.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 6, 1915

headline: Subprime Borrowers Often Lured by High-Fee Credit Cards
