abstract: The actions of a provider of fee harvester cards, recently ordered to pay a civil penalty, highlights the big fees faced by those with low credit scores.
lead_paragraph: UNSOLICITED credit card offers can sound especially appealing to people with blemished credit, or a sparse borrowing history, since they lack alternatives.

headline: First Draft Focus: Dalai Lama and Golden Rule
abstract: President Obama spoke about the Dalai Lama at the National Prayer Breakfast this morning.
lead_paragraph: — President Obama, speaking at the National Prayer Breakfast this morning.

headline: A Ride for the Trees in Florida
abstract: A weeklong bicycle ride in Florida will raise money for the Tree Fund.
lead_paragraph: Registration is open for the annual bicycling fund-raiser for the Tree Fund, a nonprofit that sponsors a weeklong ride in a different North American location each year. This year’s ride is being held in Florida.

headline: Business Books Reveal a Billionaire Obsession
abstract: Everyone may want to be rich, but two new titles have different approaches and advice on how to achieve success, writes Jonathan A. Knee in the Book Entry review column.
lead_paragraph: Who wants to be a billionaire? Everyone it seems, and not always to good effect.

headline: Applied Art
abstract: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal.
lead_paragraph: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal.

headline: Lorne Michaels Looks Back on ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: As he prepares an anniversary special, Lorne Michaels recalls four decades of “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: The ninth-floor office of Lorne Michaels at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, overlooking the storied Studio 8H where “Saturday Night Live” is performed, is furnished with framed photographs of the current “S.N.L.” cast and ready supplies of popcorn and Tootsie Rolls and Pops. But it is also a war room where, on a recent Friday night, Mr. Michaels, the creator and longtime executive producer of the show, was simultaneously planning a new broadcast of this NBC sketch-comedy institution and a 40th anniversary special, to be shown Feb. 15, that will bring alumni including Bill Murray, Tina Fey, Eddie Murphy and Will Ferrell back to the studio. NBC will also re-air the 1975 debut episode of “S.N.L.” on Feb. 14.

headline: Kerry and Poroshenko Meet in Ukraine
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine held talks on what they said was continuing Russian aggression in the east of the country.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry and President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine held talks on what they said was continuing Russian aggression in the east of the country.

headline: George Takei to Star in Broadway Musical About Interned Japanese-Americans
abstract: George Takei, best known as Mr. Sulu in “Star Trek,” will start in a Broadway musical about Japanese-American internment camps in World War II.
lead_paragraph: “Allegiance,” a musical about Japanese-Americans in United States internment camps during World War II, will begin performances on Broadway in October at a Shubert theater to be announced later, the show’s producers said Thursday. The musical, which will cost a relatively hefty $13 million to mount, will star George Takei, who is best known as Mr. Sulu in the original “Star Trek” television series, and whose personal experiences in internment camps in Arkansas and California inspired “Allegiance.”

headline: Critics Seize On Obama’s ISIS Remarks at Prayer Breakfast
abstract: Republicans condemned President Obama’s comparison of the atrocities of the Islamic State to the bloodshed in the name of Christianity in centuries past.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama may have thought he was giving a straightforward history lesson at the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday when he compared the atrocities of the Islamic State to the bloodshed committed in the name of Christianity in centuries past.

headline: Damage to Records in Brooklyn Warehouse Fire Is Less Than Feared, Officials Say
abstract: The cause of the fire, which was fueled by thousands of boxes of paper, is still under investigation, but fire marshals do not suspect arson, a spokeswoman for the Fire Department said.
lead_paragraph: New York City has reassessed the extent of the damage to public records caused by a seven-alarm warehouse fire in Brooklyn over the weekend and expects it to be less than initially feared, city officials said Thursday.

headline: Amy Pascal Lands in Sony’s Outbox
abstract: Ms. Pascal, who was embroiled in a hacking scandal in which her email was leaked, will leave her post as the top executive at Sony Pictures Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Amy Pascal, an old-style studio chief who was undercut by new Hollywood economics and bruised by the airing of private emails in a devastating cyberattack, said on Thursday that she would resign her post as the top film executive at Sony Pictures Entertainment.

headline: Drone Strike in Yemen Said to Kill Senior Qaeda Figure
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Harith al-Nadhari, who had praised the Paris terrorist attacks, was killed with three other members of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula when their car was hit Jan. 31.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — A senior member of Al Qaeda who had issued a statement saying the group had encouraged the terrorist attacks in Paris last month was killed in a drone strike on Saturday, the militant group said on Thursday.

headline: Wine and Chocolate Pairings for Valentine’s Day
abstract: The question of which wine and chocolate combinations are best is a good one, with some excellent answers.
lead_paragraph: With the arrival of February comes a question as inevitable as long-stem roses, come-hither lingerie and ridiculously bad Valentine’s Day restaurant deals: What wine goes best with chocolate?

headline: Standard & Poor’s Was Let Off Easy
abstract: It did not admit to any wrongdoing, and no individuals were named in the settlement.
lead_paragraph: In its self-described vigorous pursuit of wrongdoing in the financial crisis, the Justice Department has announced with fanfare the settlement of one case after another, proudly extolling the seemingly large penalties it has extracted.

headline: Checking Your Own References
abstract: Having confidence in the people you have selected as references is important, so, in case of doubt, conduct a reference checkup.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘Falsettos’ to Return to Broadway in 2016
abstract: The Tony Award-winning musical, about a man who leaves his wife and son to be with another man in the early years of the AIDS crisis, will be revived on Broadway in the spring of 2016, the show’s producer, Jordan Roth, announced.
lead_paragraph: “Falsettos,” the Tony Award-winning musical about a man who leaves his wife and son to be with another man in the early years of the AIDS crisis, will be revived on Broadway in the spring of 2016, the show’s producer, Jordan Roth, announced on Thursday.

headline: Disney’s Head of Parks Is Named to No. 2 Spot
abstract: Thomas O. Staggs will spend the next three years proving himself to Disney’s board, which has been acutely focused on a careful transfer of power.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Succession at Disney became clearer on Thursday, as Thomas O. Staggs beat out a rival to become the company’s No. 2 executive, a post that makes him the favorite to replace Robert A. Iger as chief executive in 2018.

headline: Iowa Republicans See Renewed National Clout
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Likely presidential candidates from the party’s establishment have indicated they will compete in Iowa, whose caucuses have long been dominated by conservatives and libertarians.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — In the early jockeying among presidential candidates, Iowa’s Republican leaders see signs that their state, which once seemed on the brink of political irrelevance, is back in the game.

headline: ‘Marijuana Can Be Helpful,’ Admits Surgeon General
abstract: Unlike many in the Obama administration, Dr. Vivek Murthy accepts at least some of the science on marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Although the Justice Department under President Obama has given states some breathing room on marijuana—whether it’s used for medical or recreational purposes—the administration has held the line where federal law is concerned. In public, administration officials continue to say they think the drug should be illegal, and that they won’t consider rescheduling it even though it’s in the same category as heroin. The nominee for attorney general, Loretta Lynch, suggested at her confirmation hearing that marijuana was more dangerous than alcohol, an opinion that goes against available evidence.

headline: Singer Gary Glitter Convicted of Sexual Abuse in Britain
abstract: The 70-year-old former glam rocker, whose real name is Paul Gadd, was found guilty of sexually abusing three girls decades ago and could spend the rest of his life in prison.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The former glam rocker Gary Glitter was found guilty on Thursday of sexually abusing three young girls decades ago, and he could spend the rest of his life in prison.

headline: Venezuela Files Charges Accusing Pharmacy Executives of Economic Sabotage
abstract: The authorities claim that a pharmacy chain is trying to destabilize the economy by allowing a long line to form outside one of its stores.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Amid a government campaign to blame Venezuela’s capitalist enemies for deep economic problems, the authorities have filed charges against two executives of the country’s largest pharmacy chain, accusing them of seeking to destabilize the economy by allowing a long line to form outside a store.

headline: MoMA Cuts Out Closing Hours for Last Look at Matisse Show
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art will be open from 10:30 a.m. Friday through 5:30 p.m. Sunday so people can see the popular Mattise exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The immersive dose of color that is the Museum of Modern Art’s show on Matisse’s cutouts has been a potent antidote to these gray days of winter, and now museum-goers can get their fix any time during the coming weekend. The exhibition will be open to the public 24 hours a day from 10:30 a.m. Friday through 5:30 p.m. on Sunday. It closes for good on Tuesday.

headline: Jordanians Step Up Bombing Raids on ISIS
abstract: Black Hawk helicopters have been sent to Erbil to speed the rescue of downed pilots in Islamic State territory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jordan sharply increased airstrikes against the Islamic State in Syria on Thursday in retaliation for the immolation of one of its pilots, as the United States sent additional Black Hawk helicopters to Erbil in northern Iraq to increase the number of aircraft and personnel on call to rescue downed pilots.

headline: Obama at National Prayer Event
keywords: ['Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president stressed the importance of religious speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The president stressed the importance of religious speech at the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington on Tuesday.

headline: 301 Prompts for Argumentative Writing
abstract: For our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest, in which teenagers are invited to write on an issue they care about, we have gathered a list of 301 writing prompts that may help — an update to last year’s popular list of 200.

headline: Ex-Spymaster Is Called to Testify in Investigation of Argentine Prosecutor’s Death
abstract: The former intelligence official was said to have helped Alberto Nisman, found dead last month, in his inquiry into a 1994 bombing in Buenos Aires.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The lead investigator in the mysterious death of Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused Argentina’s president of trying to shield Iranians from responsibility over the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center here, summoned an ousted spy chief to testify in the case on Thursday.

headline: In Bedbugs, Scientists See a Model of Evolution
abstract: New research indicates that some bedbugs are well on their way to becoming a new species.
lead_paragraph: In the closing sentence of “The Origin of Species,” Charles Darwin marvels at the process of evolution, observing how “from so simple a beginning endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved.”

headline: Paying With ‘Lovin’’: A McDonald’s Mistake?
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Company Reports', 'Dancing', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Football', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Restaurants', 'Super Bowl', "Valentine's Day", 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Critics say the chain’s new campaign is embarrassing, futile and unfair to workers.
lead_paragraph: Between now and Valentine’s Day, some customers at McDonald’s will get the opportunity to pay for their food not with money but with “lovin’” — that is, by performing one of a variety of interpersonal acts including dancing, fist-bumping an employee, or calling their mothers. McDonald’s laid out some of the possibilities in an ad during Sunday’s Super Bowl:

headline: 1940: War Council Meeting in Paris
abstract: Highlight from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Supreme War Council discusses the military and political aspects of the war in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The fifth and most important Allied Supreme War Council met yesterday at the War Ministry in Paris to study the military and political aspects of the war, as well as to survey the European situation generally in view of possible early developments with the end of the winter. The question of supplies was given special emphasis, and the communiqué issued at the end of the day’s meetings stated that there was complete agreement on all questions taken up. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 6, 1940

headline: London Stock Exchange Looks to Sell Russell Asset Management Business
abstract: The move to sell the asset-management arm of Russell Investments was widely anticipated after the Lodnon Stock Exchange bought the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The London Stock Exchange said on Thursday that it planned to put the investment management arm of Russell Investments up for sale, a move that was widely anticipated after it bought the owner of the Russell 2000 stock market index last year.

headline: A Deal That Could Reverse Pfizer’s History of Value-Destroying Acquisitions
abstract: The pharmaceutical giant’s $15 billion purchase of Hospira should bolster Pfizer’s own generics unit – and open the way for spinning it off, says Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer has made more than its share of value-destroying acquisitions. The pharmaceutical giant’s $15.2 billion purchase of Hospira could reverse that history. The injectable-drug maker’s strength in non-branded medications should bolster Pfizer’s own generics unit – and open the way for spinning it off.

headline: Pfizer Deal and Other Mergers Show a Case of the Mondays, on a Thursday
abstract: In what might be called “transaction Thursday,” some $25.7 billion of deals were recorded, according to Thomson Reuters, including Pfizer’s purchase of Hospira and BT’s acquisition of the mobile carrier EE.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has a late-in-the-week case of the Mondays.

headline: Promise of Europe Lures Syrians and Smugglers
abstract: An operative in a Turkish-based smuggling operation who organizes cargo ships for migrants says he and his associates are driven by a desire to help.
lead_paragraph: SIDE, Turkey — He left his home in Syria over a year ago and set out more than a dozen times, he said, on perilous and ill-fated seaborne journeys to the promised lands of Western Europe. He never made it. In his last attempt, the fishing boat he was on capsized, killing 44 people, including one of his best friends.

headline: Lawmakers Aim to Protect Farm Animals in U.S. Research
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Livestock', 'Law and Legislation', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Meat']
abstract: A new bill responds to accounts of mistreatment of farm animals used in federal experiments to help the meat industry.
lead_paragraph: Farm animals used in federal experiments to help the meat industry would receive new protections against mistreatment and neglect under legislation introduced on Thursday by a bipartisan group of lawmakers from both houses of Congress.

headline: ‘Boys Who Tricked Me,’ at the Musical Theater Factory
abstract: “Boys Who Tricked Me,” a musical by Ben Bonnema, has the feel of a sleepover, encouraging audience members to wear pajamas and share their dating tales for 90 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has a story when it comes to love. Ben Bonnema has enough tales to write an entire musical, but he still needs your help.

headline: Haunting Portraits of Abandoned Places
abstract: The photographer Aurélien Villette explores spaces that have been left behind, from the sacred to the industrial.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Aurélien Villette explores spaces that have been left behind, from the sacred to the industrial.

headline: A Love for Vintage Dolls That Never Grows Old
abstract: An exhibition at the Mingei International Museum showcases African-American dolls made between 1850 and 1930, from the collection of Deborah Neff.
lead_paragraph: Deborah J. Neff, a toy collector in suburban Connecticut, has acquired hundreds of antique cloth dolls depicting African-Americans. They were handmade from the 1850s to the 1930s, but little information has survived about their seamstresses and original owners. About 125 of Ms. Neff’s dolls, as well as vintage photos of white and black children holding the playthings, go on view Saturday at Mingei International Museum in San Diego.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: In 1960, “To Kill a Mockingbird” was an instant critical and commercial success.
lead_paragraph: 55 YEARS AGO

headline: Gauguin Painting Is Said to Fetch $300 Million
abstract: The sale of an 1892 Gauguin oil painting, “Nafea Faa Ipoipo (When Will You Marry?),” was confirmed by the seller, Rudolf Staechelin.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A sensuous Paul Gauguin painting of two Tahitian girls has been sold from a Swiss private collection for close to $300 million, one of the highest prices believed to have been paid for an artwork, according to European and American art world insiders with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Modern Love College Essay Contest
abstract: We invited college students nationwide to open their hearts and laptops and write an essay that tells the truth about what love is like for them today.
lead_paragraph: We invited college students nationwide to open their hearts and laptops and write an essay that tells the truth about what love is like for them today.

headline: The Moral Appeal of P.C.
abstract: On the power of moral clarity in a spiritual vacuum.
lead_paragraph: By way of a parting thought on the political correctness debate, I’m going to quote from a 2011 argument from Brendan O’Neill, the editor of the British magazine Spiked, in which he talks both about the essential appeal of the strident moralism inherent in a lot of what gets labeled as P.C., and about why it can exert so much effective pressure on institutions that seem like they should be better equipped to resist. Here’s O’Neill:

headline: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
abstract: MoMA PS1’s outdoor courtyard in Long Island City will be temporarily transformed this summer by Andrés Jaque/Office for Political Innovation.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of MoMA PS1’s outdoor courtyard in Long Island City by an emerging architect has become one of the art world’s rites of summer. The popularity of these temporary installations has made its architectural competition increasingly stiff. In this, the 16th year of the Young Architects Program, the lucky winner is Andrés Jaque/Office for Political Innovation.

headline: Shared Custody: So Even on Paper, So Hard on the First Night
abstract: If there was a mothering switch, I hadn’t yet found the dimmer.
lead_paragraph: The first night I spent away from my son, I was certain I would never sleep. He had left with his father only a few hours before and was less than a mile away, but still my own crying was keeping me awake.

headline: How We Write About Love
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Writing and Writers', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: A closer look at the Modern Love column and its contributors.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I read several articles touting the health benefits of writing in a deeply personal way. Studies had shown that writing introspectively on a regular basis can lead to lowered blood pressure, improved liver function and even the accelerated healing of postoperative wounds. The study’s subjects had been told to write for short periods each day about turbulent emotional experiences.

headline: Contraceptive Coverage for Women in the Military
abstract: A new bill would improve access to family planning counseling.
lead_paragraph: “We owe female service members the same access to contraception and family planning services as the women they fight to protect,” said Representative Jackie Speier of California, summing up the principle behind a bill she and another Democrat, Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, introduced on Wednesday.

headline: Board Strife Compounds Failed Deal for GFI
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Court documents show apparent lines of division among GFI’s independent and management directors after shareholders rejected a takeover by the CME Group, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Open warfare appears to be breaking out on the board of the GFI Group, according to a filing on Thursday in a Delaware court.

headline: Doctor, Have You Had Your DNA Tested?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As a doctor who studies how patients make decisions about genetic testing, I often get asked whether I’ve had my own DNA tested.
lead_paragraph: Several people have recently asked me if they should get their DNA sequenced. “Have you had yours tested?” they ask.

headline: Boehner Expects House G.O.P. to Accept Gay Marriage Ruling
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner said on Thursday that he expected House Republicans to accept the decision on same-sex marriage that the Supreme Court is scheduled to issue later this year.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner said on Thursday that he expected House Republicans to accept the decision on same-sex marriage that the Supreme Court is scheduled to issue later this year.

headline: Corcoran Gallery Art Transforms National Gallery
abstract: As the National Gallery essentially digests the Corcoran Gallery, the process is unlike anything an American museum has undertaken before.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the six months since a court allowed the Corcoran Gallery of Art here to dissolve, a victim of financial struggles, about 17,000 works in the museum’s overall collection — by masters like Degas, Sargent, Albert Bierstadt and Cy Twombly — have been in a highly unusual institutional limbo. Their fate is being adjudicated by a group of veteran curators from the National Gallery of Art, which agreed last February to bring as many Corcoran pieces under the museum’s own roof as appropriate and to help find homes for others in Washington-area public collections.

headline: Mike Nelson: ‘Gang of Seven’
abstract: “Gang of Seven,” Mike Nelson’s exhibition at 303 Gallery, includes works made from driftwood, skulls and other items found off the coast of British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: The British artist and two-time Turner Prize nominee Mike Nelson has filled the spacious 303 Gallery with a lively crowd of lyrical sculptural assemblages made of flotsam and jetsam collected from the coastal waters of British Columbia. (The exhibition’s title, “Gang of Seven,” refers to a collective of early-20th-century Canadian landscape painters known as the Group of Seven.) They’re made of bottles, driftwood, chunks of plastic foam, lengths of frayed rope, bald tires, pieces of rusted iron, animal skulls and many other sorts of detritus.

headline: T’s Newest Pinterest Board: Full of Love, Courtesy of Aerin Lauder
abstract: In honor of Valentine’s Day, we debut our first guest pinner.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Valentine’s Day, Aerin Lauder donned her rosiest lenses to curate a Pinterest board exclusively for T. It’s filled with inspired objects, delectable eats and swoonworthy fashion — all things pink, red, heart-shaped and sweet. Lauder, T’s first guest pinner — whose own eponymous lifestyle label just released a new rose-scented parfum in time for the holiday — shows that from the runway to the kitchen, love really is all around us.

headline: James Benning and Peter Hutton: ‘Nature Is a Discipline’
abstract: Three moving-image installations by James Benning and Peter Hutton make up “Nature Is a Discipline.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s and 2000s, when celluloid film was being eclipsed by digital technology, there was an efflorescence of 16-millimeter film installations, with loud projectors and richly colored images, and a revival of interest in deceased pioneers like Paul Sharits and Hollis Frampton. One thing curiously absent — at least in galleries — was work by living artists revealing how they had (or hadn’t) made the switch from film to video.

headline: Michael Kors Earnings Exceed Analysts’ 3rd-Quarter Estimates
abstract: Driven by strong international and online sales, results posted by the handbag brand topped predictions.
lead_paragraph: The logo-emblazoned handbags of Michael Kors are seemingly everywhere these days — and that is a growing cause of concern for the affordable luxury brand.

headline: ‘On Kawara — Silence’
abstract: A look at the new retrospective on the Japanese artist at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new retrospective on the Japanese artist at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Madcap Stratagems of Songful Siblings
abstract: “Lady, Be Good!” at City Center, an Encores! version of the Gershwins’ 1924 hit Broadway musical, features Tommy Tune and a daffy array of romantic contrivances.
lead_paragraph: Sporting a sleek fire-engine red suit, Tommy Tune appears suddenly, like an exotic bird just flown in from the tropics to brighten our frigid winter, in “Lady, Be Good!,” the George and Ira Gershwin musical that’s the first production of the City Center Encores! season.

headline: Aide to Representative Schock Resigns Over Facebook Posts
abstract: Benjamin Cole, a senior adviser to Representative Aaron Schock, resigned after racially charged posts were discovered on his Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Cole, a senior adviser to Representative Aaron Schock, resigned Thursday after racially charged posts were discovered on his Facebook page.

headline: Bode Miller Crashes in Return, Putting His Career in Doubt
abstract: Miller skied too close to a gate, hooking his left hand around one pole, and crashed out of the men’s super-G at the Alpine world ski championships on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Hurtling down the super-G course at the Alpine world ski championships at 60 miles an hour on Thursday, Bode Miller was putting down the kind of daring, electric run for which he was famous. Then came a terrifying crash that severed his right hamstring tendon and most likely ended his brilliant career.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Ballet 422’
abstract: The director Jody Lee Lipes narrates a sequence from his documentary “Ballet 422,” about the choreographer Justin Peck staging a new dance for New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: The director Jody Lee Lipes narrates a sequence from his documentary “Ballet 422,” about the choreographer Justin Peck staging a new dance for New York City Ballet.

headline: Devin Troy Strother: ‘Space Jam’
abstract: After impressive earlier shows, the young artist Devin Troy Strother, in his latest solo gallery display in New York, just wants to have fun.
lead_paragraph: Originality takes a holiday in Devin Troy Strother’s latest solo gallery show in New York. Apparently after an impressive debut at the Monya Rowe Gallery in 2011 and an even better sophomore follow-up at Marlborough Broome Street in 2013, this young, talented artist just wants to have fun. He does, but he also stoops to entertain, mostly abandoning his quirky little tableaus and painted cutout figures for a more generic approach to appropriation and art-about-art-about-black-popular-culture.

headline: Boko Haram, and Massacres Ruled by Whim
abstract: Refugees fleeing the rule of Boko Haram militants in Nigeria describe a grim world of abduction, forced marriage and casually meted-out death.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — They came in the dead of night, their faces covered, riding on motorcycles and in pickup trucks, shouting “Allahu akbar” and firing their weapons.

headline: Jess Fuller: ‘Planet Without a Body’
abstract: In this show at Martos Gallery, Jess Fuller invents her own way to make paintings.
lead_paragraph: In this terrific show, Jess Fuller exuberantly meets the challenge of inventing her own way to make paintings. Combining a parodic masculinity with intimations of women’s work, these big, squarish canvases boast a generous internal scale. They initially look simple and ham-handed but then reveal many subtle details.

headline: ‘Zero Tolerance’ at MoMA P.S. 1
abstract: This show examines a range of protest art, from Pussy Riot to a video in which neo-Nazis harass gay-pride demonstrators in Serbia and Croatia.
lead_paragraph: ‘ZERO TOLERANCE’

headline: Lincoln Center to Open Great Performers Series With Schubert
abstract: The tenor Mark Padmore and the pianist Paul Lewis will open the series in October by performing the three Schubert song cycles: “Die schöne Müllerin,” “Schwanengesang,” and “Winterreise.”
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center announced Thursday that it would open the 50th season of its Great Performers series in October with the acclaimed tenor Mark Padmore and pianist Paul Lewis performing the three Schubert song cycles: “Die schöne Müllerin,” “Schwanengesang” and “Winterreise.”

headline: Janice Guy: ‘Janice With Camera’
abstract: Janice Guy photographed herself nude, assuming the position of both author and subject, in this show at Cleopatra’s.
lead_paragraph: On the one hand, Janice Guy’s photographs from the late 1970s, on view at Cleopatra’s, are similar to what other artists, particularly women, were doing at the time. Like Francesca Woodman, Ana Mendieta, Adrian Piper, Hannah Wilke, Urs Lüthi or Cindy Sherman, Ms. Guy turned the camera on herself. And like many of these artists, she photographed herself nude, assuming the position of both author and subject of the work.

headline: Paris Calls a Halt to Outdoor Filming of Some Action Scenes
abstract: Film shoots involving actors in police or military uniforms barred by Paris authorities after terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Authorities have imposed new restrictions on filming movies or television shows in the city of Paris nearly a month after shootings that killed 17 people in and around the French capital. Outdoor scenes of actors in police or military uniforms and the use of fake weapons or explosives have been banned, underlining the heightened level of security after the attacks.

headline: Jody Lee Lipes Narrates a Scene From ‘Ballet 422’
abstract: The director of the documentary “Ballet 422,” about the choreographer Justin Peck, discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: In the documentary “Ballet 422,” the director Jody Lee Lipes chronicles the staging of a new dance by the choreographer Justin Peck, of New York City Ballet. This scene looks at a moment in the rehearsal process. Mr. Lipes discusses how the sequence was shot and what intrigues him about capturing the process of art creation.

headline: Dusting Off Gems From the Attic
abstract: Two introductory exhibitions suggest that the transfer of the Corcoran Gallery’s artworks gives the National Gallery of Art not only new holdings but also new vigor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the closing of the Corcoran Gallery of Art here, we’ve lost a venerable museum but gained access to an eclectic, in odd corners brilliant, time capsule of a collection. Long housed in a block-filling chunk of Beaux-Arts granite that also held an art school, the museum had limited exhibition space and could show only a fraction of its holdings of 17,000 works. Now nearly half of them are being absorbed into the National Gallery of Art. And maybe just as important, the remainder will be parceled out to other Washington-area museums, raising the chances that, with a little schlepping, we’ll eventually be able to see more of the Corcoran than we could when it was intact.

headline: Twitter’s Revenue Grows Despite User Stagnation
abstract: The company said it had 288 million regular users in the last quarter, fewer than analysts’ expectations of about 291 million.
lead_paragraph: Twitter just can’t seem to catch a break.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: running speed, supplements and depression. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: running speed, supplements and depression. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Who Rosa Parks Was, Not Just What She Meant
abstract: Thousands of her personal letters, photographs and other items became accessible to researchers for the first time this week at the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Newly released papers offer a look at the feisty spirit of the seemingly mild Rosa Parks, who helped set off one of the seminal events of the civil rights movement, the Montgomery bus boycott.

headline: A Winding Road to the Yankees
abstract: Images of Rob Refsnyder, a top Yankees prospect, who was born in Seoul, South Korea, and whose adoption story has made him an inspiration to some adopted children and their parents.
lead_paragraph: Images of Rob Refsnyder, a top Yankees prospect, who was born in Seoul, South Korea, and whose adoption story has made him an inspiration to some adopted children and their parents.

headline: 1950 | A Times Casualty in a Railroad Nightmare
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: David W. Dunlap looks back at train crash on the Long Island Rail Road that was particularly shocking for The Times.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: After Sony Hacking, the M.P.A.A. Considers Major Changes
abstract: Proposals are being discussed that might jolt the Motion Picture Association of America, the 93-year-old policy front for Hollywood’s major studios, into line with the realities of a changing entertainment business.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fissures revealed by the hacking at Sony Pictures Entertainment have raised the prospect of profound change at one of Hollywood’s oldest institutions: the Motion Picture Association of America.

headline: Meth King’s Lawyer: The Early Years
abstract: Walter White’s sleazy lawyer from “Breaking Bad” returns to AMC in the two-part premiere of “Better Call Saul.”
lead_paragraph: Nobody wanted it to end, so the creators of “Breaking Bad” came up with a new beginning.

headline: Family Sues Pop Warner Over Suicide of Player Who Had Brain Disease
keywords: ['Football', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Concussions', 'Sports Injuries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The wrongful-death suit, filed in Wisconsin, accuses the youth football league of failing to warn players about, and protect them from, the dangers of head trauma.
lead_paragraph: The family of a football player who committed suicide and was later found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease, has sued the youth league Pop Warner, claiming that it failed to warn players about, and protect them from, the dangers of head trauma.

headline: Which Movies and Television Shows Get Veterans Right? Or Wrong?
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Movies', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: A retired Army pilot has started a program to grade television shows and movies on how fairly and accurately they portray military veterans. If you’re a veteran, tell us what onscreen portrayals of post 9-11 veterans got it right, or made you cringe.
lead_paragraph: Whenever movies about the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan come up when I’m interviewing veterans, talk inevitably turns to “The Hurt Locker.” Almost everyone who has deployed tells me they found the portrayals of life on an Explosive Ordnance Disposal team in Iraq laughably over the top: Since when do bomb techs ride out into the desert solo in full sniper gear?

headline: ‘Surround Audience’
abstract: The New Museum’s 2015 triennial is digital and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The New Museum’s 2015 triennial is digital and beyond.

headline: As the World Embraces Diesels, Americans Still Play Hard to Get
abstract: Diesel-power vehicles have become more civilized, leaving their noisy, smoky past behind, but even with their impressive fuel economy, they still don’t sell well in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING to increase his fuel economy, Roderick Smith of Woonsocket, R.I., who works in information technology, bought a new Volkswagen Golf at the beginning of the year. Unlike most Americans, Mr. Smith opted for a model equipped with a diesel, rather than a gasoline, engine.

headline: ‘American Masterworks From the Corcoran’
abstract: Works in the new show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Works in the new show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

headline: Where Virtual Equals Real
abstract: The New Museum’s Triennial show focuses on artists for whom the Internet is the air they breathe and the world they see.
lead_paragraph: It is early 2009. Hope and change are in the air. President Obama stands before the camera delivering his Inaugural Address, but within seconds something seems off. The speech is not the pragmatic one he gave on that cold January day but a fiery message in which he excoriates “peddlers of hate whose stock-in-trade is xenophobia, homophobia, racism, sexism and isolationism, and who define America by our differences rather than our common bonds.”

headline: The Righteous Ranter, Howling at Left and Right
abstract: Andrew Napier’s “Mad as Hell,” a documentary about the commentator Cenk Uygur, takes an admiring approach toward his combative style and political philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Napier’s “Mad as Hell” takes its title from Howard Beale’s famous rant in “Network” exhorting viewers to vent their anger. But the reference sets the stakes a little high: Will this documentary about the political pundit Cenk Uygur have as much to say about the media as Sidney Lumet’s 1976 classic, “Network,” did?

headline: No, More Running Probably Isn’t Bad for You
abstract: A new study receives widespread attention, but its conclusions are based on the deaths of only 17 runners.
lead_paragraph: Don’t run less hard. Don’t run less often. Don’t run less distance. And don’t be persuaded by underpowered medical studies — a habit that really could harm your health.

headline: A Life Captivated by the Wonder of Time
abstract: The Conceptual giant On Kawara’s first full-dress retrospective is at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: The seemingly dry, narrow-gauge art of the Conceptual giant On Kawara is profound — profoundly simple, human and deep. And, as proved by that artist’s first full-dress retrospective, “On Kawara — Silence” at the Guggenheim Museum, its quality is most apparent when it is seen in quantity.

headline: With an Apology, Brian Williams Digs Himself Deeper in Copter Tale
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Television', 'Apologies', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Veterans challenged Mr. Williams’s assertion that he made a mistake when he spoke about having been in a military helicopter forced down by enemy fire in 2003.
lead_paragraph: For years, Brian Williams had been telling a story that wasn’t true. On Wednesday night, he took to his anchor chair on “NBC Nightly News” to apologize for misleading the public.

headline: An Internet-Age Music Collective Beloved by Telfar and Hood by Air
abstract: Future Brown, a bicoastal R&B group, has also collaborated with Pérez Art Museum Miami.
lead_paragraph: Everything about the R&B group Future Brown’s self-titled debut album, out Feb. 24 on Warp Records, comes across as perfectly calculated. The group strikes a balance between male and female vocals, between futuristic, icy beats and incisive lyrics and even between coasts: It consists of the Los Angeles producers Asma Maroof and Daniel Pineda (who also perform together as Nguzunguzu) and their New York counterparts, Fatima Al Qadiri and J-Cush. But in fact, according to Al Qadiri, the group’s modus operandi is less deliberate than it seems. “It’s all on accident,” as Al Qadiri says, backstage at a show at Los Angeles’ Catch One disco. “The thing that unites Future Brown is that there’s very little agenda.” The four D.J.s, who sit at the intersection of music, art and fashion, are linked through their ties to DIS Magazine, a tongue-in-cheek lifestyle webzine that Al Qadiri describes as an incubator for artists working in different mediums. “We’re indebted to curators that want to bring fresh air into the art world,” Al Qadiri says.

headline: Adrift in a Disaster Zone
abstract: The documentary “Call for Help” trails five people, all in their 20s, who went to Haiti after the 2010 earthquake as volunteers for a group calling itself Global DIRT.
lead_paragraph: If the point of “Call for Help” is to glorify a handful of off-the-grid heroes, it fails. If the point is to follow some young people who took their aimless wanderlust to a trouble spot and perhaps created more problems than they solved, it succeeds.

headline: On Deck for the Yankees, From South Korea, Rob Refsnyder
abstract: Refsnyder, a second baseman in the Yankees’ farm system, may become an even greater inspiration to adopted children and adoptive parents if he reaches the kind of success he and the Yankees expect.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — At the end of all those baseball showcases in Orange County, Calif., the format would often be the same. Few of the coaches and children who had come together for the day knew one another. The director would stand in front of the players and call out the names of those who had excelled that day: the best fielder, the best arm, the best hitter.

headline: Meditative to Clamorous, but Always in Control
abstract: Ravi Coltrane, adding some new instrumentalists, is playing an engagement at Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: There’s a set of qualities in Ravi Coltrane’s sound on tenor saxophone — dark, dry and cool — that extends to the character of his bands. That’s bands, plural, despite his decade-long run with one quartet in particular, which ended a few years ago. Mr. Coltrane has experimented with other lineups since, bringing in new partners who can acclimate quickly to the limber, even-tempered shadow dance of his style.

headline: Tappan Zee Bridge Graces Cover of the Federal Budget
abstract: The image of the bridge marks the first time that a photo has appeared on the cover of the federal budget, which customarily has been a plain blue.
lead_paragraph: To much surprise and with little fanfare, the Tappan Zee Bridge assumed a place in national politics this week, a new ironclad symbol of President Obama’s federal budget for the 2016 fiscal year, of all things.

headline: Governor of Florida Turns Aside Accusations
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott conceded that he could have handled better the resignation of a top law enforcement official, but called accusations of impropriety “ridiculous and untrue.”
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Facing a lawsuit, an ethics complaint and repeated demands for an investigation into the ouster of a top law enforcement official, Gov. Rick Scott admitted on Thursday that he could have handled the official’s resignation better but called accusations of impropriety “ridiculous and untrue.”

headline: Before the First Bell, a Nearly 10-Mile Walk
abstract: “On the Way to School,” a documentary by Pascal Plisson, trails children from three continents on their daily journeys to classrooms.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “On the Way to School” declares its importance from its opening title card. “Too often we forget how lucky we are to go to school,” it says. To illustrate this point, the movie trails children from three continents on what, in most cases, are their daily journeys “toward knowledge.” As they set off, we are given the distance and the duration of their travels.

headline: Rituals: Reader Submissions
abstract: Share a photo of your campus ritual. View submissions. Submit yours.
lead_paragraph: Share a photo of your campus ritual. View submissions. Submit yours.

headline: It’s Tradition
abstract: We asked for a look at one of your campus’s traditions, and the story behind it.
lead_paragraph: What would college be without its crazy customs?

headline: Texas Museum to Build Ellsworth Kelly Design
abstract: The Blanton Museum of Art will build Ellsworth Kelly’s first free-standing building design on its grounds at the University of Texas, Austin.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, the painter and sculptor Ellsworth Kelly conceived his first free-standing building for a private collector, but it was never realized. Now, as Mr. Kelly prepares to turn 92 in May, the Blanton Museum of Art will acquire and construct his design for a 2,715-square-foot stone building, which will rise on the museum’s grounds at the University of Texas, Austin.

headline: A Family on a Mission, Zipping Through Space
abstract: A new animated space adventure for the pint-size set follows Miles and the rest of the Callisto family on their spaceship travels.
lead_paragraph: Every generation, it seems, has its animated space adventure series, and today’s pint-size set gets an enjoyable one beginning Friday morning when “Miles From Tomorrowland” has its debut on Disney Junior.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Terrorist Detainees Should ‘Rot in Hell’
abstract: Senator Tom Cotton delivered an impassioned speech about Guantanamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, insisted at a hearing on Thursday that the Guantanamo Bay detention facility should stay open and that, if anything, it was too good for terrorist suspects.

headline: His Own Threatening Soundtrack
abstract: “Enter the Dangerous Mind” explores the tenuous grip on reality of a paranoid schizophrenic immersed in electronic dance music.
lead_paragraph: The psychiatric thriller “Enter the Dangerous Mind” (originally titled “Snap”) tries to plumb the extremities of mental illness and childhood trauma for nerve-scraping frights. But despite a novel pursuit for its troubled protagonist — he’s a part-time composer of electronic dance music — the filmmakers, Youssef Delara and Victor Teran, fall back on some familiar beats.

headline: Jordan, Unabashed, Announces Latest Bombing Raid on ISIS Targets
abstract: After the brutal killing of a pilot, Jordan appeared to be redoubling its participation in the anti-Islamic State coalition.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordanian warplanes bombed Islamic State targets on Thursday, the Jordanian military said, after King Abdullah II promised a “harsh” response to the militant group’s brutal killing of a captured Jordanian pilot.

headline: He’s Smitten, and That’s the Problem
abstract: In “Lovesick,” Matt LeBlanc is a school principal who becomes undone whenever he falls in love.
lead_paragraph: With the reek of straight-to-video wafting from every frame, “Lovesick” astonishes most by its appearance in an actual theater. But it’s February, and pickings are slim, so this soulless, sterile romantic comedy has slipped under the wire to give audiences a headache and Matt LeBlanc’s reputation a relapse.

headline: The Art Fair Scene Heads South of the Border
abstract: Mexico City’s most established art fair, Zona Maco, kicked off last night and is accompanied by several smaller, hipper fairs elsewhere in the city.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of Los Angeles’s expanding art week, sun-chasing aesthetes push south to Mexico City’s Distrito Federal for Zona Maco and all the festivities organized around the city’s most established art fair. The main event was inaugurated last night at the Centro Banamex, an imposing conference complex on the outskirts of the posh northern regions of the city. Now on view to the public until Sunday, the fair counts David Zwirner, Zurich’s Mai 36, Bogotá’s Casas Riegner and local heavyweights like Kurimanzutto, Labor and OMR among its exhibitors. With sections siloed for new galleries, the southern hemisphere, modern art and design, Maco models itself after the department-store variety of mega-events like Art Basel and Frieze, where all of the visitors’ shopping needs are met under the roof of one neighborhood-sized building.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Feb. 5, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Germany, Switzerland and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Germany, Switzerland and Spain.

headline: Did He at Least Say Thank You?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Dogs', 'Homeless Persons', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: Questions about splitting a bill post-breakup, helping a homeless man and his dog, handling a needy boss and dealing with an annoying greeting.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend of one year broke up with me a week after I paid $700 for his birthday dinner. I can’t afford luxuries, so I will be paying it off for months. He ended our relationship because he was “not at my commitment level.” I’m glad he was honest, but I can’t shake the feeling that he deliberately waited to enjoy the dinner before breaking up. (It was long planned.) I think the decent thing would be for him to split the cost with me. May I ask?

headline: Verbatim: President Ernst? She’s Honored
abstract: A new poll in The Des Moines Register finds that 58 percent of Republican caucusgoers in Iowa think that Senator Joni Ernst has what it takes to be president one day.
lead_paragraph: – Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, responding to a new poll that said many Republican caucusgoers at home think she has what it takes to be president.

headline: Mandy Grunwald to Join Clinton Team
abstract: Mandy Grunwald, an adviser to the Clintons for over two decades and a top strategist to Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, is expected to serve as a senior adviser for communications to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s all-but-certain presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Mandy Grunwald, an adviser to the Clintons for over two decades and a top strategist to Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, is expected to serve as a senior adviser for communications to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s all-but-certain presidential bid.

headline: RadioShack Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy After a Deal With Sprint
abstract: The long-ailing 94-year-old electronics chain struck a deal to sell up to 2,400 of its stores to the wireless service provider Sprint and a hedge fund that is its biggest shareholder.
lead_paragraph: For years, RadioShack — the retailer that helped bring personal computers to the masses — outlasted untold predictions that it would buckle in the face of bigger rivals and online competitors.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: The Spreading Rage at ISIS
abstract: If regional fury translates into a broader fight against jihadism, the barbaric death of Moaz al-Kasasbeh may prove not to have been in vain.
lead_paragraph: Terrorism has long had a gruesome role in conflicts, often among revolutionary groups so fanatically certain of their ends that they readily justify the most barbaric of means. But it can also turn with a vengeance against those who inflict it, as the Islamic State is learning with its most recently publicized atrocity — murdering a Jordanian air force pilot by burning him alive. The video of the killing was meant to dissuade Arabs from participating in the Western coalition against the group; instead, it has succeeded in fostering rage and revulsion against the jihadists throughout the Arab world.

headline: East and West Meet, Checking Norms at the Door
abstract: In the art exhibition “Araya Rasdjarmrearnsook,” at SculptureCenter, videos featuring dogs and human corpses are used in discomfiting ways.
lead_paragraph: After a leave of absence in 2003, the Thai artist Araya Rasdjarmrearnsook returned to Chiang Mai University, where she teaches, apparently pregnant. Her friends and co-workers reacted joyfully to this surprising turn of events. Then, nine days later, she announced that she wasn’t with child at all, and that her fake pregnancy was a work of performance art called “The Nine-Day Pregnancy of a Single Middle-Aged Associate Professor.” She documented it in a fragmentary five-minute video, in which viewers hear her thoughts on pregnancy and about her colleagues’ disappointed and angry reactions to her deception.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of Black Indie Film
abstract: A sprawling survey of black independent film of New York from 1968 to 1986 is part time capsule, part news bulletin.
lead_paragraph: To watch Kathleen Collins’s “Losing Ground” — a 1982 film making its long-awaited theatrical debut at Lincoln Center on Friday as part of “Tell It Like It Is,” a sprawling survey of black independent film of New York from 1968 to 1986 — is to experience a curious blend of nostalgia and novelty. The clothes the characters wear, how they talk and what they talk about, the grainy texture of the images and the weariness of the world they capture — all of these emerge from a time capsule devoted to an era that doesn’t quite have a name. But partly because those images have remained unseen for so long, and partly because Ms. Collins, who died in 1988, was such a bold and idiosyncratic filmmaker, “Losing Ground” also feels like news, like a bulletin from a vital and as-yet-unexplored dimension of reality.

abstract: While its revenue failed to meet analysts’ estimates in the fourth quarter, the boutique investment bank is bullish about deal-making activity going forward.
lead_paragraph: The boutique investment bank Moelis & Company on Thursday reported a higher fourth-quarter profit, though its results fell short of Wall Street’s expectations.

abstract: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockey’s most popular genres.
lead_paragraph: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockey’s most popular genres.

headline: After a Decade Building Trust, an Anchor Starts a Firestorm With One Wrong Move
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Brian Williams’s tale-telling about being aboard a chopper that took fire in Iraq could shake his career as NBC News anchor.
lead_paragraph: It is a “thing that you build slowly, over time,” according to grandiloquent promos last fall that extolled Brian Williams’s 10th anniversary as anchor of “NBC Nightly News.” Over shots of Mr. Williams talking to soldiers and small children in war zones and disaster areas, the narrator, Michael Douglas, adds, “And what you build, if you work hard enough, if you respect it, is a powerful thing called trust.”

lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: With Back Problems, Tiger Woods Withdraws After 11 Holes
abstract: Woods withdrew at two-over par after 11 holes of the Farmers Insurance Open at Torrey Pines Golf Course, complaining of back tightness.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Tiger Woods’s latest comeback suffered another setback Thursday when he quit after 11 holes of his opening round at the Farmers Insurance Open, citing a stiff back.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 6-12
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: BAMkids Film Festival

headline: A Visit to McDonald’s, Celebrity Chef in Tow
abstract: As fast-casual chains soar in popularity, the iconic burger chain is under pressure. A well-known food expert and a designer have some ideas for improvement.
lead_paragraph: With all the recent excitement over Shake Shack — its share price more than doubled the day it went public last week — and Habit Burger, whose share price also more than doubled when it went public in November, you’d think America was entering a new golden age of the burger.
