abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Jupiter Ascending,” “The Voices” and “Ballet 422.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Jupiter Ascending,” “The Voices” and “Ballet 422.”

headline: A Student and a Principal Pay a Visit to the White House
abstract: The online photography project “Humans of New York” aims to tell the story of the city’s residents. One particular string of photos, however, featuring a young student and a principal from Brooklyn, made it all the way to the White House.
lead_paragraph: The online photography project “Humans of New York” aims to tell the story of the people of the city, one photo at a time. While each picture is shared and liked thousands of times across social media, one recent string of photos, featuring a young student and a principal from Brooklyn, made it all the way to the White House.

headline: Investigators Ask Why So Many Died on Train in Metro-North Crash
abstract: A briefing highlighted the many unanswered questions about the unusual role of the third rail in the accident, which killed five people aboard the train in Valhalla, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Two days after the deadliest train crash in the history of the Metro-North Railroad, investigators on Thursday sought to shed light on a central mystery of the crash: how a train-on-car crash spread its devastation to the interior of the train.

headline: Designing a World of His Own
abstract: The man who once billed himself as the “world’s greatest photographer” has a new exhibit that shows lesser-known work with a quiet, classical bent.
lead_paragraph: The man who once billed himself as the “world’s greatest photographer” has a new exhibit that shows lesser-known work with a quiet, classical bent.

headline: A Fly on the Wall, Watching a Troupe Work Toward Seamless Grace
abstract: “Ballet 422,” a documentary about choreographing a new dance work for New York City Ballet, forgoes interviews for a fly-on-the-wall approach.
lead_paragraph: Works of art are made from the inside out, as the passions, ideas and instincts of artists blossom into objective forms. Most movies about the making of art tend to proceed in the opposite direction, inviting us, as we observe the labor of creation, to infer what we can about the inspiration behind it.

headline: 9 Recent Cyberattacks Against Big Businesses
abstract: Cyberattacks have become an ever-increasing threat, and the F.B.I. now ranks cybercrime as one of its top law enforcement activities. Here are some of the major attacks on United States businesses in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Cyberattacks have become an ever-increasing threat, and the F.B.I. now ranks cybercrime as one of its top law enforcement activities. Here are some of the major attacks on United States businesses in recent years.

headline: A World Premiere of Pure Dance to a Familiar Score
abstract: New York City Ballet unveiled the world premiere of “Rodeo: Four Dance Episodes,” by Justin Peck, its resident choreographer.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Justin Peck had choreographed no professional ballet. Today his works (new commissions and existing pieces) are in demand across America, and he has been resident choreographer at New York City Ballet since July. Not everything he has made, however, has succeeded. It seems fair to ask this season if he will prove one of those rare artists who, having begun with several important successes, can grow further.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses 4 in Silicon Valley of Insider Trading
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans']
abstract: The scheme involved illegally trading in options ahead of merger announcements and generated nearly $750,000 in illicit profit, regulators say.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As an in-house financial specialist at two Silicon Valley technology companies, Christian B. Keller was privy to confidential information he agreed not to share.

headline: Obama Budget’s Call for Increased Funding for N.H.T.S.A. Faces Uncertainty
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Transportation']
abstract: The agency has fallen under scrutiny as more than 60 million vehicles were recalled in the United States last year, double the previous record set in 2004.
lead_paragraph: After a year of a record number of recalls in the auto industry, the Obama administration is aiming in its proposed budget to nearly triple the funding for defect investigations at the government’s auto safety agency and increase its overall budget by 20 percent annually over six years.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ballet 422’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Ballet 422.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Ballet 422.”

headline: Patricia Arquette Grows Into ‘Boyhood’
abstract: After 25 years in show business, Patricia Arquette has reached a high point in her career with “Boyhood,” in which she allowed herself to age naturally onscreen.
lead_paragraph: After 25 years in show business, Patricia Arquette has reached a high point in her career with “Boyhood,” in which she allowed herself to age naturally onscreen.

headline: In a Setting Well Suited to Humility
abstract: Performing in recital at Alice Tully Hall, the Met tenor Matthew Polenzani sang works by Beethoven, Ravel, Satie and others.
lead_paragraph: The bright-toned, openhearted tenor Matthew Polenzani, who returned to his native New York in recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, rose through the ranks at the Metropolitan Opera the old-fashioned way. He started in the late 1990s in truly tiny roles — remind me, who’s Khrushchov in Mussorgsky’s “Boris Godunov”? — then gradually moved into minor but noticeable parts, the likes of Arturo in Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” and Jaquino in Beethoven’s “Fidelio.”

headline: A Difficult, Technical Subject (Personal Meta)
abstract: Being clever isn’t enough.
lead_paragraph: In his incredible essay “The Great Slump of 1930” – an essay that reads remarkably well to this day, as an analysis of our crisis as well as his – Keynes briefly vents a bit of frustration. “For — though no one will believe it—economics is a technical and difficult subject.”

headline: Old Tradition of Secularism Clashes With France’s New Reality
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Education (K-12)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Discrimination', 'Terrorism']
abstract: In the aftermath of the Charlie Hebdo killings, there are new questions about the concept of state secularism and whether it is being fairly applied in a France where an estimated five million Muslims live and worship.
lead_paragraph: ROSNY-SOUS-BOIS, France — Laïcité, the concept of state secularism, is a defining principle of the French republic, right up there with the national motto of liberty, equality and fraternity. Developed in the French Revolution, which targeted the Roman Catholic Church as much as the monarchy, laïcité governs the public life of a nation that sharply delineates the realms of Caesar and God.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Voices’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Voices.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “The Voices.”

headline: The Cat Made Him Do It
abstract: In Marjane Satrapi’s horror comedy “The Voices,” Ryan Reynolds is a small-town misfit with pets who talk to him and a collection of severed heads.
lead_paragraph: Is Jerry, who works in the shipping department of a small-town bathtub factory and who is played by Ryan Reynolds, a quirky misfit or something more dangerous? This question hovers for a little while over “The Voices” but resolves itself even before Jerry starts filling his refrigerator with severed heads of women.

headline: In Statement, Harper Lee Backs New Novel
abstract: The author of “To Kill a Mockingbird” has issued a statement expressing her happiness with the publication of her second novel, “Go Set a Watchman,” amid growing speculation that she may have been pressured into signing over publication rights for the book.
lead_paragraph: Harper Lee has issued a new statement expressing her happiness with the publication of her second novel, “Go Set a Watchman,” amid growing speculation that the fiercely private novelist may have been pressured into signing over publication rights for the book.

headline: Protecting Yourself From the Consequences of Anthem’s Data Breach
abstract: There are strategies for limiting potential damage, although all involve greater vigilance and at least some degree of inconvenience.
lead_paragraph: Given the steady beat of security breaches, consumers may assume that a cybercriminal already has at least some of their personal information. But in the latest intrusion, at the health insurer Anthem, hackers got their hands on an especially valuable collection of sensitive information on millions of people.

headline: What Oscar Nominees Do to Pass the Time
abstract: In “Seventh Son,” Jeff Bridges roars, Julianne Moore fumes, and Kit Harington leaves early. There are also dragons.
lead_paragraph: Every year, in between the big heave known as the fall awards season and that folly we call the Academy Awards, the major movie companies turn into a cinematic slag heap of the bad, the risible and the inexplicable. Even on paper, the latest February throwaway, “Seventh Son,” sounds like a bad idea, even if it does feature the wasted talent of the veteran production designer Dante Ferretti and was directed by Sergei Bodrov, who has a few fine credits to his name. As it turns out, there are those, including this reviewer, who can be seduced into seeing just about anything if it comes with name actors like Jeff Bridges and Julianne Moore, a herd of digital dragons and the cute guy who plays that incurably know-nothing Jon Snow in the HBO show “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Jupiter Ascending’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jupiter Ascending.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jupiter Ascending.”

headline: Security Strategy Recognizes U.S. Limits
abstract: In his second, and final, national security strategy on Friday, President Obama will be making a stronger case than he did five years ago for robust American leadership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to release his second, and final, national security strategy on Friday, laying out a blueprint for robust American leadership for his remaining time in office while recognizing limits on how much the United States can shape world events.

headline: Cleaning Lady Has No Idea of Her Crucial Role in the Cosmos
abstract: In “Jupiter Ascending,” Mila Kunis plays an earthling who turns out to be the reconstituted queen of the universe.
lead_paragraph: “Jupiter Ascending,” the latest from Lana and Andy Wachowski, is a big, woozy, spacey fairy tale with a science-fiction exoskeleton and a core of pure mush. With its nods to the original “Star Trek” and David Lynch’s proto-steampunk hallucination “Dune,” it seduces the eye with filigreed flourishes even as the mind reels from some of the mildewy storytelling. Mila Kunis plays Jupiter Jones, an earthling who turns out to be the reconstituted queen of the universe or some such, which apparently means that she needs to be repeatedly rescued. An uncomfortable-looking Channing Tatum plays her hybrid honey, Caine Wise, a man-wolf with pointy ears and, my, what big, bulging muscles.

headline: Jordan: Jihadist Cleric Freed From Jail
abstract: Jordan released Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a leading jihadist cleric, from prison on Thursday, according to the official Petra news agency.
lead_paragraph: Jordan released Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, a leading jihadist cleric, from prison on Thursday, according to the official Petra news agency. Mr. Maqdisi, who was arrested in October, was accused of “using the Internet to promote and incite views of jihadist terrorist organizations.” It is unclear why he was released. Considered a spiritual mentor to Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq until his death in 2006, Mr. Maqdisi later renounced the killing of civilians and has spoken out against the Islamic State group, calling it “deviant.”

headline: New Middle East Envoy Is Appointed
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Thursday that he had appointed Nickolay E. Mladenov, a Bulgarian diplomat and statesman who has been his special representative in Iraq, as his new special Middle East peace envoy.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said on Thursday that he had appointed Nickolay E. Mladenov, a former foreign minister of Bulgaria who has been his special representative in Iraq, as his new Middle East peace envoy. Mr. Mladenov succeeds Robert H. Serry, a Dutch diplomat who has been in that post for more than seven years. A statement on the appointment, posted on the United Nations website, said Mr. Ban thanked Mr. Serry for “his dedicated service and excellent leadership” but gave no indication about Mr. Serry’s future, precisely when the change would take effect or who would replace Mr. Mladenov in Iraq.

headline: An Heir Finds Trouble on His Way to the Throne
abstract: In “Outcast,” set in medieval China, a prince needs to foil his murderous older brother.
lead_paragraph: The main thing to be learned from “Outcast,”  Nicholas Powell’s loony directing debut about two former Crusaders hanging out in medieval China, is that Hayden Christensen’s portrayal of opium addiction is not appreciably different from his take on clean and sober.

headline: All Hail the Lordling Dolphin!
abstract: “The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water” sends SpongeBob and his whole world into post-apocalyptic chaos.
lead_paragraph: Explaining the appeal of SpongeBob SquarePants is a fool’s errand, but then that’s also a pretty good description of the adventures had by this irrepressible, highly absorbent hero. “The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water” is the show’s second feature-length installment, and while less fluid and fresh than its 2004 predecessor, the new film displays enough nutty writing and sheer brio to confirm the stamina of its enduring and skillfully voiced characters.

headline: Fewer Top Graduates Want to Join Teach for America
abstract: The group has warned school districts and charter school chains that the size of its corps of teachers this fall could be down by as much as a quarter.
lead_paragraph: Teach for America, the education powerhouse that has sent thousands of handpicked college graduates to teach in some of the nation’s most troubled schools, is suddenly having recruitment problems.

headline: U.S. Business Group Urges Resistance to Chinese Policy
abstract: U.S. trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China.
lead_paragraph: United States trade groups gave the Chinese government an earful last week about new policies that could hamper the ability of major technology multinationals to do business in China. Now, in a letter addressed to key United States officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, 17 trade groups headlined by the United States Chamber of Commerce urged the government to resist the Chinese policies, according to a copy of the letter viewed Thursday by The New York Times. The letter called for the United States government to take “immediate action to work with Chinese officials to reverse an alarming number of troubling, new Chinese government policies impacting the information and communications technology sector.”

headline: A Top Aide Who Helped Mold de Blasio’s Public Image Is Leaving
abstract: The departure of Peter Ragone, the powerful steward of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s public image, is the most significant shake-up yet at a close-knit City Hall.
lead_paragraph: The powerful steward of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s public image is leaving the administration, the most significant shake-up yet at a close-knit City Hall.

headline: Small Rise in New Cases Shows Ebola Hanging On
abstract: A weekly increase in new cases, the first this year, was worrisome because some of them were patients who had not been listed for monitoring, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: Officials from the United Nations and the World Health Organization expressed concern on Thursday over data showing the first weekly rise in new Ebola cases this year, countering the downward trend in the disease that has ravaged three West African nations.

headline: A Leader’s Legacy Outside the Shadow of Mandela
abstract: “The Other Man: F. W. de Klerk and the End of Apartheid,” a Nicolas Rossier documentary, assesses the actions of the man who presided over South Africa’s transition to a democracy.
lead_paragraph: “There are not that many examples in history of leaders who negotiate the end of their own system,” an interviewee says in “The Other Man: F. W. de Klerk and the End of Apartheid.” But the man who presided over South Africa’s historic transition from white minority rule to fully participative democracy — and effectively ended his own presidency — remains little known, even among his countrymen.

headline: Shifting the Spotlight Back to the Man They Knew
abstract: “Matt Shepard Is a Friend of Mine” seeks to return a human symbol of hate crimes against gay people to a state of ordinary but beloved individuality.
lead_paragraph: A tender reconstruction of personal loss, “Matt Shepard Is a Friend of Mine” retraces the life of the University of Wyoming student whose 1998 murder put a national spotlight on hate crimes against gay people. Variably effective, this debut feature documentary from Michele Josue seeks to restore the Matt Shepard of his friends’ and family’s memories, and in so doing return a human symbol to a state of ordinary but beloved individuality.

headline: New Harvard Policy Bans Teacher-Student Relations
abstract: The move comes as the Obama administration investigates the handling of accusations of sexual assault at dozens of colleges, including Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University has adopted a ban on professors’ having sexual or romantic relationships with undergraduate students, joining a small but growing number of universities prohibiting such relationships. The move comes as the Obama administration investigates the handling of accusations of sexual assault at dozens of colleges, including Harvard.

headline: Anthem Hacking Points to Security Vulnerability of Health Care Industry
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The insurer failed to protect data in its computers through encryption in the same way it protected medical information, and 80 million records were accessed.
lead_paragraph: The cyberattack on Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, points to the vulnerability of health care companies, which security specialists say are behind other industries in protecting sensitive personal information.

headline: Review: ‘Boy Meets Girl,’ Directed by Eric Schaeffer
abstract: The film “Boy Meets Girl,” written and directed by Eric Schaeffer, places sex and gender identity at the center of almost every conversation.
lead_paragraph: “Boy Meets Girl,” or — as the subtitle should say, “Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Being Transgender” — is a romantic comedy that’s so progressive it hurts. Placing sex and gender identity at the center of almost every conversation, the writer and director, Eric Schaeffer, is so keen to demythologize that the film’s potentially most affecting moments are too often smothered by the hackneyed characters and setups that surround them.

headline: Ally Financial Seeks Brisker Profit Under New Leadership
keywords: ['Automobile Financing', 'Automobiles', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The former GMAC has separated painfully from General Motors and paid off the Treasury. Now with a new chief executive in place, it is aiming to ramp up performance.
lead_paragraph: Auto sales are booming. Low gas prices are enticing more people to buy higher-priced sport utility vehicles. All this means it could be another stellar year for banks that make auto loans.

headline: Harassment Suit Against Former Assemblyman Vito Lopez and Sheldon Silver Is Settled
abstract: Two former aides had accused Vito J. Lopez of sexual harassment while he was in office, and Mr. Silver, who was at the time the Assembly speaker, of essentially facilitating it by not acting forcefully to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The two former legislative aides at the heart of a sexual harassment scandal in the New York State Assembly settled their legal claims on Thursday against the disgraced former Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez and the recently deposed speaker, Sheldon Silver.

headline: Malcolm Smith, Ex-New York Senate Chief, Is Convicted of Corruption
abstract: Mr. Smith, a Democrat from Queens, was accused of conspiring to pay bribes to Republican leaders in an effort to run for New York City mayor in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm A. Smith, the former majority leader of the New York State Senate, was convicted on Thursday of federal corruption charges including bribery, wire fraud and extortion.

headline: Best Friends, but Wanting More
abstract: In “Love, Rosie,” childhood friends, clearly infatuated with each other, don’t declare their love and then separate for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Whether the material is “Much Ado About Nothing” or “When Harry Met Sally,” if your story requires keeping true loves apart, it is often polite to pass the time with a steady flow of comedy.

headline: Democrats Exercise ‘No’ Power in Senate to G.O.P.’s Dismay
keywords: ['Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now that they control both houses of Congress, Republicans are beginning to learn the limits of their newfound power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — You could see the mischievous delight in John A. Boehner’s face as soon as he heard the question Thursday.

headline: Stolen Documents That Cast a Spotlight on Surveillance
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The documentary “1971,” directed by Johanna Hamilton, examines a group of ordinary people who stole and leaked F.B.I. files about illegal surveillance of citizens.
lead_paragraph: In the age of encryption, computer hacking, WikiLeaks and Edward J. Snowden, the theft of typewritten government documents from an unlocked file cabinet 44 years ago by ordinary citizens may seem quaint.

headline: Bode Miller’s Crash
abstract: Bode Miller had a spectacular crash in the super-G at the Alpine world ski championships on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Bode Miller had a spectacular crash in the super-G at the Alpine world ski championships on Thursday.

headline: Among New York Subway’s Millions of Riders, a Study Finds Many Mystery Microbes
abstract: Researchers at Weill Cornell Medical College mapped DNA found in New York’s subway system, finding that almost half the genetic material did not match any known organism.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been on the subway and seen something that you did not quite recognize, something mysteriously unidentifiable?

headline: White House Accelerates Drive to Improve Data Privacy
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'E-Commerce', 'Net Neutrality', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The push came after Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, said that the personal data of tens of millions of its customers had been compromised.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House accelerated its efforts on Thursday to bolster data privacy laws and announced a bid to scrutinize discriminatory pricing on the Internet, pressing to exert control on the use of data in Americans’ lives.

headline: Where Metro-North Railroad Fuels Life, and Takes It
abstract: The train makes life in this bedroom community possible. But the crash on Tuesday that claimed six lives — three with Chappaqua connections — upended the sense of security, in a single, savage instant.
lead_paragraph: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — In a hamlet that can seem sprung from a Currier & Ives lithograph, residents are drawn by many things: top-rated schools, safety, a picturesque setting — and the convenience of a train station.

headline: The Lives of 3 Crash Victims Who Shared a Metro-North Routine
abstract: Friends and family members spoke about Aditya Tomar, 41, Joseph Nadol, 42, and Robert Dirks, 36.
lead_paragraph: The routine was the same, Monday through Friday. A man who, like generations of suburban commuters before him, had built his working life around the Metro-North timetables left the JPMorgan Chase tower on Park Avenue. He boarded his Harlem line train at Grand Central Terminal. He texted his wife: I’m on my way home.

headline: A Rocky Romance
abstract: Anton Dudley’s “City Of” focuses on four Americans stumbling around Paris, and a gargoyle named Pierre.
lead_paragraph: There are many gargoyles jazzing up the exterior of the Cathedral of Notre-Dame. But only Pierre, stony and lonesome, is hopelessly in love with a pigeon.

headline: ‘Tis the Voice of the Lobster
abstract: Kyle Mahowald returns after a long absence.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some puzzles are “chattier” than others. There are those you hear nary a peep out of, and those that you simply can’t shut up.

headline: Human Behavior and Physics Hamper Rail Safety Systems
abstract: Experts are working to reduce the dangers of grade-level rail crossings like the one in Valhalla, N.Y., that was the scene of a deadly accident on Tuesday. But human behavior can defeat even the safest system, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Engineers and transportation safety experts around the world are working to reduce the dangers of grade-level rail crossings like the one in Valhalla, N.Y., that was the scene of a deadly accident Tuesday evening. But human behavior and the laws of physics can defeat even the safest system, researchers say.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 8-14, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 8-14, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Martin Gilbert, Churchill Biographer With a Populist Bent, Is Dead at 78
abstract: Mr. Gilbert wrote many books about a range of historical topics, but Winston Churchill was a favorite subject.
lead_paragraph: Martin Gilbert, the official biographer of Winston Churchill, who also wrote histories of many of the signal events of the 20th century, including both world wars, the Holocaust and the Middle East conflict, died on Tuesday in London. He was 78.

headline: Ike Schambelan, Director Who Brought Disabled Artists to the Stage, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Schambelan started the company Theater Breaking Through Barriers as a vehicle for vision-impaired actors to perform their craft.
lead_paragraph: Ike Schambelan, a theater director who for more than three decades was the guiding force behind a professional Off Broadway company that featured blind and otherwise disabled actors in prominent roles, died on Tuesday in the Bronx. He was 75.

headline: Effects of Ancient Custom Present New Challenge to U.S. Doctors
abstract: As the number of African immigrants in the United States has grown, so too has the number of women living in this country who have undergone genital cutting.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — One immigrant woman told of visiting five gynecologists in recent months, each of whom gasped audibly at her anatomy.

headline: In Patz Trial, Witness Says Defendant Confessed to Him
abstract: A man who attended a religious retreat with Pedro Hernandez in 1979 testified that Mr. Hernandez, who is charged with murdering Etan Patz, told him he had killed a boy in the basement of a grocery store.
lead_paragraph: Some months after 6-year-old Etan Patz disappeared in 1979, the man now accused of his murder told another man attending a religious retreat that he had killed a little boy in the basement of a grocery store, the second man testified on Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Events in Connecticut for Feb. 8-14, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Sayreville Football Coach Is Ousted After Scandal
abstract: George Najjar, the head coach at Sayreville War Memorial High School in North Jersey, led the team for 20 years, but allegations of hazing and sexual assault have upended the program.
lead_paragraph: The embattled head football coach of Sayreville War Memorial High School has been ousted from his job in the wake of a hazing and sexual abuse scandal that drew national scrutiny, led to charges against seven players and upended a quiet New Jersey town that has long revered its top-flight program.

headline: Events in Westchester for Feb. 8-14, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Overruns Are Focus at Public Meeting on Boston Olympic Bid
abstract: In response to skeptical questions, Mayor Martin J. Walsh pledged that Boston taxpayers would not pay a dime in cost overruns if the city ended up hosting the 2024 Summer Olympics.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In response to skeptical questions, Mayor Martin J. Walsh pledged Thursday night that Boston taxpayers would not pay a dime in cost overruns if the city ended up hosting the 2024 Summer Olympics.

headline: On Coney Island, Taking In the Sand and the Snow
abstract: Tunga Takavarasha of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, and his father, Bernard Takavarasha, visiting from Zimbabwe, took a walk on the Coney Island beach on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Tunga Takavarasha, left, of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, and his father, Bernard Takavarasha, visiting from Zimbabwe, took a walk on the Coney Island beach Thursday.

headline: On Atonement
abstract: In a mirror’s reflection, the artist Tatiana Trouvé finds a metaphor for the poet Fady Joudah’s musing on the thin line between desire and disaster.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the artist Tatiana Trouvé finds a metaphor for the poet Fady Joudah’s musing on the thin line between desire and disaster.

headline: In the Flesh
abstract: Embrace the tonal subtlety of a rose gold timepiece with a nude band against bare skin.
lead_paragraph: Embrace the tonal subtlety of a rose gold timepiece with a nude band against bare skin.

headline: Notes on a Scandale
abstract: For years, France’s leaders have been caught up in a sex farce of their own making, proving that bedfellows make for very strange politics.
lead_paragraph: For years, France’s leaders have been caught up in a sex farce of their own making, proving that bedfellows make for very strange politics.

headline: An Addictive, Momofuku Milk Bar-Approved Snack for the Grammys
abstract: Christina Tosi shares a recipe for rosemary nuts, excerpted exclusively for T from her next cookbook.
lead_paragraph: With her last cookbook, “Momofuku Milk Bar,” the pastry chef Christina Tosi let her fans into her bakery, sharing the secrets behind her addictive Crack Pie, polarizing Cereal Milk ice cream and everything-but-the-kitchen-sink Compost Cookies. Three and a half years later, the founder and owner of Milk Bar will unveil her next treasure trove of recipes, “Milk Bar Life,” ($35, April 2015) which brings us instead into her home kitchen. And in honor of this Sunday’s Grammy Awards, Tosi shares a simple recipe from the book, one which has already become a T favorite and can easily be doubled or tripled for larger viewing parties (she quadruples the recipe for her Milk Bar team).

headline: Word of the Day | brawn
abstract: This word has appeared in 81 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: brawn • \ˈbrȯn\ • noun

headline: Investigation Finds Problems With Work on New York City 911 System
abstract: The city’s Department of Investigation cites mismanagement, overdependence on contractors and tampering with status reports in a new report on a halted project.
lead_paragraph: New York City employees were pressured by supervisors to “ ‘sanitize,’ ‘soften’ or ‘spin’ ” failures surrounding the long-delayed, $2 billion upgrade of the city’s 911 system by tampering with color-coded ratings, a new investigation has found.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) SHAKESPEARE UNCOVERED Morgan Freeman, who played Petruchio in “The Taming of the Shrew” in the Public Theater’s 1990 Shakespeare in the Park production, looks at some famous Petruchios (Richard Burton, John Cleese and Raul Julia) and Kates (Elizabeth Taylor, Fiona Shaw, Sinead Cusack and Meryl Streep) and reunites with his own sparring partner, Tracey Ullman (above with Mr. Freeman). Julia Stiles reflects on her role in the 1999 teenage comedy adaptation of the work, “10 Things I Hate About You.” And the Royal Shakespeare Company takes the play to a school near where Shakespeare grew up to find out what children make of the adult shenanigans. At 10, David Harewood, the first black actor to star in the title role of “Othello” at the National Theater in London, looks at the history behind the play; talks to Adrian Lester, the National Theater’s latest Othello, about the reaction to the 1825 performance of Ira Aldridge, the first black man to play the role in Britain; and ponders Laurence Olivier’s use of blackface in his acclaimed film portrayal in 1965.

headline: Carl J. Rubino, Lawyer in Quiz-Show Scandal, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Rubino accompanied Charles Van Doren, his legal client, to Washington in 1959, when he admitted before a congressional subcommittee that he was fed answers on the NBC show “Twenty-One.”
lead_paragraph: In October 1959, a tormented 33-year-old named Charles Van Doren returned to his Greenwich Village apartment after driving around New England for days to escape the paparazzi camped on his doorstep. A letter from a complete stranger suggested a self-evident solution to his crisis of conscience: Just tell the truth.

headline: Tony Abbott, Australian Premier, Vows to Fight Leadership Challenge
abstract: The embattled prime minister urged members of his Liberal Party on Friday to choose “stability” after a junior lawmaker called for a vote to contest him.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s embattled prime minister, Tony Abbott, said Friday that he would fight an attempt to contest his leadership next week, after a junior politician from his conservative Liberal Party called for the vote.

headline: East Timor’s Prime Minister, Xanana Gusmão, Resigns
abstract: Mr. Gusmão, who was the young country’s first president, submitted his resignation Friday as part of a reshuffling expected to bring more opposition figures into power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — East Timor’s prime minister, Xanana Gusmão, submitted his resignation Friday as the government began a political restructuring meant to ease the young country’s often-fraught politics.

headline: Corrections: February 6, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, February 6, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Saudis and 9/11
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Walter B. Jones calls for the release of portions of the Joint Inquiry report into 9/11.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Heritage
abstract: An aide to the senator objects to a sentence in an Op-Ed essay questioning how Hispanic he is.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Ending Slavery, the Abolitionists Came First
abstract: A Yale history professor and another reader disagree with a Sunday Review article, “Was Abolitionism a Failure?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Research on Mental Illness
abstract: Dr. Jeffrey Borenstein of the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation writes that money to support brain research should be included in New York City’s plan to find new ways to detect and treat mental illness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Conflict and Ego
abstract: The best way to successfully respond to hate, even from the likes of ISIS, is to step outside the logic of vengeance.
lead_paragraph: If you read the online versions of newspaper columns you can click over to the reader comments, which are often critical, vituperative and insulting. I’ve found that I can only deal with these comments by following the adage, “Love your enemy.”

headline: A Game of Chicken
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Europe faces a moment of truth as it deals with a debt-ridden Greece.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the European Central Bank announced that it would no longer accept Greek government debt as collateral for loans. This move, it turns out, was more symbolic than substantive. Still, the moment of truth is clearly approaching.

headline: Stupid Pills
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some of the country’s largest retailers, counting on the stupidity of consumers, are selling dietary-supplement junk, a step removed from sawdust.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — One pill makes you smarter. One pill makes you thin. One pill makes you happy. Another keeps you energized. And so what if tests conducted by scientists in New York and Canada have found that the substances behind these miracle enhancements may contain nothing more than powdered rice or houseplants. If enough people believe they’ll be healthier, well, it’s a nice racket.

headline: How to Handle the Vaccine Skeptics
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'States (US)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Measles', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Don’t try to punish them. Just make getting an exemption harder.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — THE alarming number of measles cases — a record 644 last year, and 102 last month, the most since the disease was declared eliminated in the United States in 2000 — has focused scrutiny on parents who refuse vaccinations for their children. There are some who want state and local governments to sue, or even criminally charge, such parents. A bill in California would end all nonmedical exemptions to immunization requirements.

headline: Heraclitus Hikes the Andes
abstract: With global warming, you truly can’t step in the same river twice.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — I HAVE recently been able to confirm, through sad and indisputable evidence, that Heraclitus was right when he wrote that we can never step into the same river twice. I doubt, of course, that that pre-Socratic philosopher, when coining the phrase two and a half millenniums ago about the implacable flux of time, had in mind the ecological destruction of the planet, the abyss toward which our greed and inability to courageously confront global warming are leading us.

headline: Courage and Good Sense at the F.C.C.
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Regulators should be applauded for trying to stop companies from blocking or slowing down information on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission will soon put in place regulations designed to prevent cable and phone companies from blocking or slowing down information on the Internet. The companies and their congressional allies are using scare tactics to stop this from happening.

headline: Dartmouth vs. Drinking: Will It Work?
abstract: Readers react to news that Dartmouth is banning hard liquor.

headline: The Texas Way on Juvenile Justice
abstract: The state clearly gets better results with local, community-based rehabilitation programs than incarceration.
lead_paragraph: Texas has made huge strides in reforming its once hellish juvenile justice system. Young offenders in state facilities were once subjected to brutality, neglect and sexual abuse. But after revelations of those conditions led to a public outcry in 2007, elected officials moved quickly to make sure that troubled young people were more likely to find the services they needed — and to keep as many young people as possible from entering state facilities in the first place. As important, the state now has the data to prove that it has made progress and to point to where it might make more.

headline: Investing in Energy Efficiency Pays Off
abstract: Colleges are finding that refitting buildings with greener heating and ventilating systems can pay for itself in a few years.
lead_paragraph: A junior and senior economist are walking down the street. The junior one spots a $20 bill on the ground and says, “Hey, look, 20 dollars! Should I pick it up?” The senior economist replies: “Don’t bother. It can’t be real. If it were, someone would have taken it already.”

headline: Test Yourself | Red Carpet Resistance
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 4 article, “On the Red Carpet, a Revolt Builds Over the Pageantry.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 4 article, “On the Red Carpet, a Revolt Builds Over the Pageantry.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Why Google Glass Broke
abstract: Why is there still hope for Glass, even though Google announced in January that it was shuttering its Glass Explorer program?
lead_paragraph: In “Why Google Glass Broke,” Nick Bilton reveals the mystery about what ended up happening with Glass.

headline: Pilots in Crash May Have Shut Wrong Engine, Finding Suggests
abstract: A finding by safety investigators showed that the TransAsia flight’s pilots discussed shutting down the functioning engine, not the one that had triggered a cockpit alarm.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A finding by safety investigators suggested on Friday that pilots of the twin-propeller plane that crashed in Taiwan’s capital, killing at least 35 people, might have reacted to a stalled-engine alarm by shutting down the wrong engine.

headline: Siemens to Cut 7,800 Jobs Worldwide
abstract: The move is part of a broader reorganization, announced last year, which included reducing the number of main business units to 10 from 16.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Siemens, one of Germany’s flagship industrial companies, said on Friday that it planned to cut 7,800 jobs, or 2.3 percent of its work force worldwide, as it eliminates layers of management in an attempt to become as profitable as its main competitors.

headline: Amid Gains in Jobs and Pay, Americans Rejoin the Work Force
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy']
abstract: American employers added 257,000 jobs in January, showing that signs of economic momentum late last year carried into 2015.
lead_paragraph: The economy cruised into the new year with a burst of fresh momentum, adding jobs at the fastest pace since the boom of the late 1990s and lifting employment and wage prospects for millions of Americans left behind in a long but mostly lackluster recovery.

headline: Designing a World of His Own
abstract: The man who once billed himself as the “world’s greatest photographer” has a new exhibit that shows lesser-known work with a quiet, classical bent.
lead_paragraph: The quiet stillness of Eliot Elisofon’s pictures of New York can be deceiving. Mr. Elisofon, who died in 1973 at age 61, was neither quiet nor still. An early member of the Photo League and a staff photographer for Life magazine from 1940 to 1964, he called himself the “world’s greatest photographer” and hired a publicist to spread the word.

headline: A Civil War Story With a Twist
abstract: In “The Whipping Man,” in New Brunswick, as three men try to make sense of their faith in the postwar world, tensions rise.
lead_paragraph: The whole is not as powerful as the best parts of “The Whipping Man” at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Here, you’ll sit through intense scenes and inert sections, in a production that is both laudable and lackluster.

headline: A Political Animal
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Pets', 'ANIMALS', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: In January, the de Blasio administration named a point person to handle issues of animal well-being in New York City.
lead_paragraph: From everything you have been reading lately — O.K., overhearing on the sidewalk, because technically speaking, science has yet to engineer the literate basset hound — you think you like this Bill de Blasio creature. A year ago, when he dropped that groundhog at the Staten Island Zoo, an event soon followed by the groundhog’s death, you weren’t so sure. But hey, correlation is not causation (as you were forced to keep reminding that irritating Lhasa apso, Noam Chomsky, always with his conspiracy theories, in Prospect Park).

headline: Chancellor Carmen Fariña Changes New York City Schools’ Course
abstract: Ms. Fariña has rolled back Education Department policies adopted by the Bloomberg administration, but hasn’t spelled out what will come next.
lead_paragraph: A dozen principals and New York City education officials were gathered in an office early last year, sorting through a database to look for schools to use as models — those scoring highest on tests, graduation rates and other measures, compared with schools of similar demographics.

headline: How Should the Media, and the Public at Large, Respond to the News About Bruce Jenner?
abstract: This week, the Style section and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof raise questions about how we should react to widespread reports that Bruce Jenner is transitioning from male to female. Have you followed this news and noticed the way it has been covered in the news media? What has been your reaction?
lead_paragraph: This week, both the Style section and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof raise questions about how we should react to widespread reports that Bruce Jenner is transitioning from male to female.

headline: Limit ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ to Europe, Panel Tells Google
abstract: An eight-person committee advising Google on complying with a landmark privacy ruling by Europe’s highest court said it should apply only in the 28-nation European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe’s so-called right to be forgotten should apply only in Europe.

headline: Made in China: Fake IDs
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Identification Devices', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Drivers Licenses', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Forget old-school resources like an older sibling or Photoshop. In today’s global economy, students import their fake IDs.
lead_paragraph: The small package was wrapped in Chinese newspaper when it arrived, protecting a thin light blue jewelry box holding a beaded bracelet. But the bracelet was cheap. What was important was hidden under a layer of foam: fake driver’s licenses.

headline: A Few of Their Favorite Things
abstract: “What’s in on campus,” according to Student Monitor.
lead_paragraph: Student Monitor, the market research firm, asked 1,200 undergraduates last fall to choose “what’s in on campus” from a list of 77 options, including brands, things and activities. At left are the top 15. (Among the less popular: smoking cigarettes, doing drugs, reality TV shows, volunteering, blogging, being eco-friendly.)

headline: A Campus Guide’s Guide
abstract: Learning to lead parents around.
lead_paragraph: Can you project your voice? Memorize dates? Respond to questions while walking backward? If yes, you might just have a chance of becoming a college tour guide.

headline: Film Studies: The Academia Awards
abstract: Test your knowledge of Oscar-winning movies, with questions from Dana Polan, a professor of cinema studies at New York University.

headline: Skipping Class at Harvard
abstract: How many are actually going to lectures.
lead_paragraph: Secret cameras trained on Harvard lecture halls to study attendance raised quite a stir last fall. To some professors, the research methodology used by the Harvard Initiative for Learning and Teaching clearly invaded the sanctity of the classroom, despite a noble goal: to find out how often students skip lectures. So how hot, or cold, were the seats? Results are out.

headline: Cauliflower: Marinated, Mashed and Smashed
abstract: Cauliflower is a versatile vegetable that can be marianted, mashed like a potato or smashed into a delicious vegetarian patty, writes Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Cauliflower is a vegetable that I have no qualms about buying on impulse. It keeps very well in the refrigerator – I have made perfectly good meals using florets I found lingering in my produce drawer that had been there for more than a week. Not that I recommend this approach, but it is good to know that you need not use it up right away, especially when you find large heads weighing anywhere from 1 1/2 to 2 pounds.

headline: Lani Guinier Redefines Diversity, Re-evaluates Merit
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Income Inequality', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Ms. Guinier, the first tenured woman of color at Harvard Law School, argues in a new book for a rethinking of the “testocracy” that is college admissions.
lead_paragraph: Lani Guinier, the first tenured woman of color at Harvard Law School, went through a trial by fire in 1993, when President Bill Clinton withdrew her nomination for assistant attorney general for civil rights.

headline: Pop Quiz Answers
abstract: Stumped? Here are the answers to the quiz.
lead_paragraph: Blackboard Jumble

headline: How to Raise a University’s Profile: Pricing and Packaging
abstract: The transformation of George Washington from humble commuter school into nationally known university has served as a model for other striving campuses. The direction: up!
lead_paragraph: One day in 2013, I sat down in a Starbucks in the Foggy Bottom neighborhood of Washington with Hugh Moren, then a junior at the nearby George Washington University. I asked him how much money he was borrowing to go to college.

lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from a fire in Williamsburg and a deadly train crash on a Metro-North Railroad line.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.
