abstract: A restaurateur’s art show in Beijing, a performance of Verdi’s Requiem in Mumbai and an underground festival in London are in this week’s lineup of international art events.
lead_paragraph: London

headline: New Yorkers Clamor for IDs, Swamping Mayor’s Key Project
abstract: The introduction of municipal identification cards, one of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s signature initiatives, has been anything but smooth.
lead_paragraph: First there were long lines and waits that lasted hours, followed by website errors, protracted hold times on telephone information lines and extreme difficulty in arranging appointments.

headline: Obama’s Prayer Breakfast Words to Dalai Lama Ruffle China and India
abstract: A public encounter with the Dalai Lama and comments about acts of religious intolerance in India cause pique.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Prayer breakfast speeches in Washington are rarely, if ever, the source of bruised feelings overseas. Not so this year.

headline: When Hospitals Buy Doctors’ Offices, and Patient Fees Soar
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Medicare', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: When the same test is reimbursed more when done by a hospital, it gives doctors a reason to go work for hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a Medicare patient, and you go to your doctor for an ultrasound of your heart one month. Medicare pays your doctor’s office $189, and you pay about 20 percent of that bill as a co-payment.

headline: New York Today: Pictures on the Shore
abstract: Friday: Photographing the debris left by a fire, frigid weather, and it’s Alligators in the Sewer Day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this frozen Friday.

headline: Enthusiasm for I.P.O.s Returns in Europe as 4 Companies Debut
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Private Equity', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Since the new year, I.P.O. activity is off to its best start since the financial crisis, with 16 offerings raising $3.84 billion in gross proceeds, according to Thomson Reuters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Enthusiasm for initial public offerings returned with strength in Europe on Friday after having dimmed somewhat in the fourth quarter of last year.

headline: Daily Report: Revenue at Twitter Rises, but User Growth Slows
abstract: The company said it had 288 million regular users in the last quarter, fewer than analysts’ expectations of about 291 million.
lead_paragraph: Twitter just can’t seem to catch a break, Mike Isaac reports.

headline: A Herder Strikes Gold, in the Shape of China
abstract: Chinese state news media reported that an ethnic Kazakh herder had stumbled across an enormous gold nugget, which weighed 17 pounds and was shaped like a map of China.
lead_paragraph: The mountains of the remote Altay area of northwestern China have a storied history of gold mining. People in the region talk about mines that Russians helped build and operate in the first half of the 20th century. The Russians left the area after the People’s Liberation Army took over the vast Xinjiang region. Altay sits near the borders with Russia, Mongolia and Kazakhstan, and it is a place from which legends travel far.

headline: British Court Says Spying on Data Was Illegal
abstract: The ruling, the first of its kind against the British intelligence services, relates to data that was shared with the United States National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The court that oversees intelligence agencies in Britain ruled on Friday that the electronic mass surveillance of cellphone and other online communications data had been conducted unlawfully.

headline: Chinese Student to Contest Expulsion From Norway, Lawyer Says
abstract: The Norwegian authorities had ordered the doctoral student to leave the country on grounds that his research could be used for military purposes, charges that his lawyer called “incomprehensible.”
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for a Chinese doctoral student who was expelled from Norway last month on the grounds that his research could be used for military purposes said that the student would contest the Norwegian government’s decision and that the case “will be sent to the court” on Monday.

headline: The Saudi Game
abstract: Washington’s ties with Saudi Arabia are being further strained by assertions that people in the Royal family have close ties to Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s ties with Saudi Arabia are being further strained by assertions that people in the Royal family have close ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Reply All: The 1.25.15 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE MEGYN KELLY MOMENT

headline: Can We Reverse-Engineer the Environment?
abstract: Trying to undo the damage of our hubris.
lead_paragraph: Across the top of the map, above the Arctic’s Mer Glaciale, there floats a banner inscribed with a legend that in translation reads “New Discovery of Many Nations in New France in the years 1673 and 1674.” This legend is a bit misleading. Although the terrestrial features seem to have been distorted by a fun-house mirror, the aquatic features are strikingly recognizable and strikingly out of scale, as if we were peering down through a magnifying glass poised over the Great Lakes. Read the semi-legible calligraphic names along the coasts and riverbanks, and you begin to perceive that this isn’t really a map of North America nor of New France. It’s a navigation chart and a relic of a time when waterways assumed out-of-scale proportions in our geographies.

headline: The Hazards of Other Planets
abstract: Defining true agency.
lead_paragraph: The company Mars One is trying to establish colonies on Mars by offering one-way trips there within the next 10 years. I’ve gotten into heated debates about the ethical implications of sending people on these trips. Even though the people selected signed up knowing they would never return to Earth, I believe the entire endeavor is unethical because they will not really have a full grasp of what they’ve signed up for until they get to Mars, at which point, return to Earth is impossible. Do you agree? ANNIE LUBIN, BROOKLYN, N.Y.

headline: Blow Up
abstract: A decade after my uncle died, I went looking for him.
lead_paragraph: One October afternoon in 1996, when I was 10, my mom sat me down at the kitchen counter and told me that Uncle Wolfgang had died. He fell asleep while smoking in bed, and his Upper East Side apartment caught fire. It was the smoke inhalation that killed him, not the flames. No one else was injured. He was 45.

headline: Kid Rock: ‘There’s No Winning That Battle’
abstract: The musician on “American Sniper” and aging gracefully.
lead_paragraph: The musician talks with Jeff Himmelman about how his music, lifestyle and political mindset have changed.

headline: Today in Politics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Who is President Obama going to choose to lead the Secret Service and the agency’s efforts to repair its image?
lead_paragraph: Obama Homes In on a New Secret Service Director

headline: Gun Debate Reignites in Colorado, 2½ Years After Aurora Theater Shooting
abstract: Newly empowered Republican lawmakers have proposed measures to undo background checks and allow gun owners to carry concealed handguns without permits.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Two years after Colorado tightened its gun laws in response to mass shootings at a Connecticut elementary school and a suburban Denver movie theater, newly empowered Republicans here at the State Capitol are trying to repeal those measures, reviving an emotional debate over gun violence.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | January 2015
abstract: We present the January edition of Teenagers in the Times, a feature that presents almost everything published in The Times about young people during that month.
lead_paragraph: We present the January edition of Teenagers in The Times, a feature that presents almost everything published in The Times about young people during that month.

headline: Morning Agenda: RadioShack’s Bankruptcy Filing
abstract: RadioShack files for bankruptcy. | Ally Financial is looking to ramp up performance. | Pfizer makes a big bet on a new class of generics. | Dysfunction continues at GFI.
lead_paragraph: RADIOSHACK FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY | RadioShack has filed for bankruptcy, but is poised to live on in a diminished form, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The Chapter 11 filing, in federal bankruptcy court in Delaware on Thursday, had long been expected for the 94-year-old electronics retailer, which has not been profitable since 2011.

headline: Rates and Ratings
abstract: No relationship.
lead_paragraph: The big story in the bond markets these days is the emergence of negative interest rates for a number of sovereigns, which is pretty amazing. But there’s another story that shouldn’t be overlooked: borrowing costs for supposedly risky debtors not named Greece have plunged below those of supposedly safe borrowers. Here’s the view this morning:

headline: Ukraine Insists Any Pact With Russia Must Adhere to Terms of September Accord
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: As French and German leaders met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, Kiev’s stance underscored the formidable obstacles to an accord.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As the leaders of Germany and France met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Friday to discuss a deal to end the war in eastern Ukraine, officials in Kiev insisted that any agreement must hold to the cease-fire lines and to other terms of a truce negotiated in September but that never took hold.

headline: As Jindal’s G.O.P. Profile Grows, So Do Louisiana’s Budget Woes
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: With talk of Bobby Jindal’s presidential aspirations, questions have been raised about what caused a shortfall estimated to hit $1.6 billion next year.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — In recent weeks, the office of Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has issued news releases about the “mindless naïveté” of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the folly of opening diplomatic relations with Cuba and the threat of radical Islam in Europe, prompting a flurry of commentary about what it all might mean to Republican voters in Iowa and South Carolina should Mr. Jindal decide, as has long been expected, to run for president.

headline: In Pond Hockey, No Reason to Have One Big Fish
abstract: A 10-year-old tournament in Minnesota has grown from a curiosity into a phenomenon, but without a single national champion, the attractions are bragging rights, camaraderie and beer.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — For one long weekend every January, nearly 1,500 men and women in skates converge on frozen Lake Nokomis to revisit their childhoods.

headline: Debt Is Money We Owe To Ourselves
abstract: Even if saying that makes you furious.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Fatas, commenting on recent work on deleveraging or the lack thereof, emphasizes one of my favorite points: no, debt does not mean that we’re stealing from future generations. Globally, and for the most part even within countries, a rise in debt isn’t an indication that we’re living beyond our means, because as Fatas puts it, one person’s debt is another person’s asset; or as I equivalently put it, debt is money we owe to ourselves — an obviously true statement that, I have discovered, has the power to induce blinding rage in many people.

headline: Q. and A.: Andrew Small on the China-Pakistan Relationship
abstract: Mr. Small, a policy researcher at the German Marshall Fund of the United States in Washington, explores China’s ties with Pakistan, past and present, in a new book.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Small, a policy researcher at the German Marshall Fund of the United States in Washington, explores China’s ties with Pakistan in a new book that delves into the relationship’s history, the Chinese origins of Pakistan’s nuclear weapons, extremism in the two countries and how the future might develop as the United States recedes from Pakistan and Afghanistan.

headline: Harris Corporation to Buy Defense Contractor Exelis for $4.7 Billion
abstract: Together, the companies will have more than $8 billion in annual sales and serve both business and government clients.
lead_paragraph: The Harris Corporation, which makes satellite and other communications equipment for businesses and governments, said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire Exelis for $4.7 billion in cash and stock.

headline: In Key West, a Taste of Cuban Coffee Culture
abstract: The Florida Straits island offers the next best cafe con leche beyond Havana.
lead_paragraph: We were sitting on benches, my new coffee mate, Anthony, and I. Side by side, half-listening to the baritone rumble of washers and dryers in the laundromat behind us, we watched the cars on Key West’s busy White Street glide by as the island slowly woke up on a Saturday morning.

headline: A Road Hog Advertises
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Exiting Central Park, a driver was cut off by another car, which had a very appropriate license plate.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Lure of the Gold Coast
abstract: The Gold Coast suburbs of Long Island’s North Shore have been discovered by wealthy Chinese. And some developers are going out of their way to make properties more attractive to them.
lead_paragraph: For the past several years, wealthy buyers from China have been purchasing investment properties and pieds-à-terre in luxurious Manhattan high-rises. Lately, though, some have moved their portfolios east to the exclusive enclaves of Long Island, springing for the pricey houses of the North Shore’s Gold Coast.

headline: Revenge Tales Drawn from Everyday Indignities
abstract: “Wild Tales,” the Argentine Oscar nominee, proved cathartic for its writer-director, Damián Szifron.
lead_paragraph: Emerging from a bakery where he has just bought a birthday cake for his daughter, a man discovers his car has been towed. At her wedding reception, a bride realizes her new husband has been cheating on her. On an empty highway, the drivers of an Audi and a jalopy jockey for position and insult each other. Each of the six episodes in “Wild Tales,” an Argentine movie nominated for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, begins with a disagreeable incident drawn from daily life — but escalates from there into an almost baroque tale of revenge.

headline: Cynthia Nixon on Her Directorial Debut, De Blasio and How Miranda’s Doing These Days
abstract: The “Sex and the City” alum will premiere “Rasheeda Speaking” with the New Group theater company on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: This Wednesday, Feb. 11, the New Group theater company will open “Rasheeda Speaking,” an exquisitely tense (and often cringingly funny) portrait of racial paranoia in a small doctor’s office, starring the incomparable Tonya Pinkins and Dianne Wiest. The play also marks the directorial debut of the “Sex and the City” veteran Cynthia Nixon, who since the release of the franchise’s second film in 2010 has appeared on Broadway in “Wit” and on TV in “The Big C,” and has crusaded hard for marriage equality and for the election, in 2014, of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. Nixon chatted with T about launching her career as a director, the other projects that will keep her busy this year — and, of course, the latest news about Miranda.

headline: Perversity in Wartime and After
abstract: The director Liliana Cavani explores psychosexual complexities in “The Night Porter” and “The Skin,” both now on disc.
lead_paragraph: Liliana Cavani is a filmmaker of ideas, but at least one of her images has proved indelible: a topless Charlotte Rampling wearing an SS officer’s cap and suspendered trousers, shielding her breasts with long leather evening gloves. The poster for “The Night Porter” made this Italian writer-director’s work synonymous with what some called “Nazi chic.”

headline: Four Stops Across Morocco
abstract: Planning a seven-day journey across Morocco, from Atlantic shores to Saharan dunes, can be an odyssey. Here’s how to do it.
lead_paragraph: Planning a seven-day journey across Morocco, from Atlantic shores to Saharan dunes, can be an odyssey. Here’s how to do it.

headline: Enrolled at Her Majesty’s Spy School
abstract: The director Matthew Vaughn talks about his collaboration with the screenwriter Jane Goldman. Their latest project, “Kingsman: The Secret Service,” stars Colin Firth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British director and producer Matthew Vaughn and the screenwriter Jane Goldman have worked together on several film projects, beginning with “Stardust” in 2007 and including their newest, “Kingsman: The Secret Service,” which opens in the United States on Feb. 13. “We’ve written five and a half things, and they have all actually been made into films,” Mr. Vaughn said proudly. (The half refers to “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” which Mr. Vaughn was hired to direct but ultimately didn’t; the two received story credit.)

headline: Judge Hears Case Over Release of Garner Grand Jury Materials
abstract: Five groups are seeking the release of testimony before a grand jury that did not indict an officer in the chokehold death of a Staten Island man in July.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Staten Island on Thursday weighed arguments for the release of evidence, testimony and instructions presented to the grand jury whose decision in December not to charge a police officer in the chokehold death of Eric Garner touched off weeks of protests.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Philippine President Accepts Police Chief’s Resignation After Deadly Raid
abstract: The president has faced searing public criticism since a raid left 44 police officers dead and put the country’s peace agreement with rebels in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — President Benigno S. Aquino III accepted the resignation of the Philippines’ national police chief on Friday, two weeks after a disastrous raid left 44 police commandos dead and put the country’s peace agreement with rebels in jeopardy.

headline: From Agadir to Merzouga
abstract: Scenes from across Morocco.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from across Morocco.

headline: Morocco, From Coast to Desert
abstract: A seven-day journey turns up a kaleidoscope of centuries-old souks, dusty colonial-era outposts, livestock markets and luxury restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The temperature was easily 90 degrees as Mohamed wrapped my head with a long blue chech, the sun protection worn by Moroccan desert nomads. Nearby, camels snorted and moaned while handlers outfitted them with saddles for the imminent journey. Behind us loomed a long two-story dune and an ocean of sand, undulating toward the vanishing point. After a weeklong voyage across southern Morocco, I was about to venture at last into the Sahara, the culmination of a personal two-decade dream.

headline: Watching Youth Fly By, in Fiction and Fact
abstract: Long before ‘Boyhood,’ the ‘Up’ documentaries checked in on a group of people in seven-year intervals.
lead_paragraph: The slacker mirror sees what it wants to see.

headline: Chanel Raises the Stakes in the Young Designers Game
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Contests and Prizes', 'Design', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The fashion house will take over this year as mentor to the winner of the Association Nationale de Développement des Arts de la Mode, or Andam, grant.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize — and what is increasingly looking like a horse race to make nice with the next generation of maybe-possible fashion stars (and win their loyalty and affection for a maybe-possible future) — Chanel is putting ever-more assets into the game. Its latest vehicle: the Andam award, the second-largest grant to a young designer, albeit one willing to be based and working in France.

headline: Connections Become Clear, Given Time
abstract: The documentarian Stanley Nelson discusses his new film, “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: Stanley Nelson has to admit that his timing was good. His new documentary, “The Black Panthers: Vanguard of the Revolution,” is starting to play at festivals — it had its premiere at Sundance last month — in the wake of the nationwide protests over police killings of African-American men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island. The moment is right for a documentary history of the Panthers, with its images of armed black men patrolling the streets and walking onto the floor of the California Legislature.

headline: This Is a Great Jobs Report Across the Board
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The good news was not only in the hiring numbers themselves, but also in signs of a growing labor force and rising wages.
lead_paragraph: Now that’s more like it.

headline: Open-Skies Agreements Challenged
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: United States air carriers see growing rivals in the Persian Gulf and Europe as a threat.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, domestic airlines and successive administrations have pushed for, and achieved, broad international agreements that have fostered greater competition, lower airfares and more flights to hundreds of destinations like Tokyo, Beijing and Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Madam C.E.O., Get Me a Coffee
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Discrimination', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: The sad reality in workplaces: Women help more but benefit less from it.
lead_paragraph: LATE one Friday afternoon at a leading consulting firm, a last-minute request came in from a client. A female manager was the first to volunteer her time. She had already spent the entire day meeting with junior colleagues who were seeking career advice, even though they weren’t on her team. Earlier in the week, she had trained several new hires, helped a colleague improve a presentation and agreed to plan the office holiday party. When it came time for her review for partner, her clear track record as a team player combined with her excellent performance should have made her a shoo-in. Instead, her promotion was delayed for six months, and then a year.

headline: Power Lifting of a Residential Kind
abstract: Jay Wright and his Wright Fit company are behind several high-end fitness centers in luxury residential projects.
lead_paragraph: Izak Senbahar, the president of the Alexico Group and co-developer of 56 Leonard, the undulating tower that redefined TriBeCa’s skyline, didn’t hesitate when it came time to select a fitness guru to assemble what, in his opinion, is the most pivotal amenity component of a luxury residential project: its fitness center.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Jupiter Ascending,’ ‘The Voices’ and ‘Ballet 422’
abstract: Times film critics review “Jupiter Ascending,” “The Voices” and “Ballet 422.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Jupiter Ascending,” “The Voices” and “Ballet 422.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Bearing Witness to Sorrow in Jordan
abstract: Rod Nordland describes the tough situation that he and his colleague, Ranya Kadri, found themselves in as they worked on a profile of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, the Jordanian pilot who was burned to death by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Islamic State released a video showing the execution of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh, a Jordanian pilot the group had been holding hostage. Rod Nordland, a foreign correspondent, and Ranya Kadri, a Times contributor, were working on a profile of the pilot and were with Lieutenant Kasasbeh’s family members when they learned of his death.

headline: How Obama’s Tax Plan May Not Work as Intended
abstract: The president’s proposed offshore earnings tax may fuel an increase in foreign acquisitions of midsize American companies, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: Companies’ offshore cash holdings are a tempting target for American tax writers, as President Obama’s proposal this week to tax deferred offshore earnings proves. Those same offshore earnings may attract foreign buyers as well.

headline: The Scott Walker Boomlet
abstract: This was the week that the political world woke up to the potential strength of Scott Walker, the Wisconsin governor, as a presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Pond Hockey: They’re Naturals
abstract: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockey’s most popular genres.
lead_paragraph: Images from the United States Pond Hockey Championships in Minneapolis. The sport has grown from a curiosity into one of hockey’s most popular genres.

headline: Stuff We Liked: From Health to Hues
abstract: Web gems this week included a map of bacteria on New York subways and a visualization of how men and women describe colors.
lead_paragraph: Our staff found loads of stuff elsewhere on the web that we wanted to share. Let's start with disease and move on to happier fare from there.

headline: China’s Fog Weighs Heavily on Shoulders of Its Premier Architect
abstract: For 70 years, Wu Liangyong has ridden out the country’s political storms to establish himself as its most influential urban planner.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — IT is a winter day in China’s smoggy capital, and Wu Liangyong is wondering what went wrong.

headline: 1890: A Catastrophe in the Pits
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: An explosion occurred at a mine in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT — A colliery explosion of the most appalling character in South Wales within living memory occurred early this morning [Feb. 6] at the Llanerch pits at Abersychan. Three hundred men went down at seven o’clock, and the last man had scarcely settled to work when a terrific explosion took place. The work of rescue continued all day, body after body being sent up to the surface. From the less injured men the explorers ascertained that the seat of the explosion was in a remote patt [sic] of the workings, known as Cook’s slope. The efforts of the explorers were now directed to this point. On their way they came upon mutilated bodies and wreckage. Some of the corpses were legless, from others arms had been torn violently, and all were hideously burned or otherwise injured about the face, rendering identification difficult or impossible. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 7, 1890

headline: Dark Chocolate Pudding
abstract: Melissa Clark makes this rich dessert with bittersweet chocolate, heavy cream and brown sugar.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes this rich dessert with bittersweet chocolate, heavy cream and brown sugar.

headline: Rebels in Yemen Say They Intend to Form a New Government
abstract: The Houthi rebels who seized the capital in January said they would take control of the country, which does not now have a functioning government.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The Houthi rebels in Yemen, who effectively forced the country’s president and cabinet to resign last month, announced on Friday that they intended to dissolve Parliament and take control of the country, which does not now have a functioning government.

headline: The Dollar and the Recovery (Wonkish)
abstract: How much of a drag should we expect?
lead_paragraph: Good news in today’s jobs report, and the dollar shot higher. But a stronger dollar will make US goods less competitive, and act as a brake on further recovery. So how do we think about this? How much of the US recovery will be diffused to other countries via dollar strength and a bigger trade deficit?

headline: The Bittersweet Kiss of Chocolate
abstract: When making chocolate confections, let luscious be the beacon. Then bump up the chocolate content. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: I once baked heart-shaped chocolate shortbreads for my sweetie at the time. The cookies were a recipe of my own invention — crisp, crumbly, seasoned with sea salt and near-black cocoa powder, and utterly delicious.

headline: Translating in Tongues
abstract: Len Rix, who translated Magda Szabo’s novel “The Door,” decided to pick up Hungarian at the age of 47.
lead_paragraph: The Hungarian language, or Magyar, is notoriously difficult to learn for nonnative speakers: Meanings are tucked away in multiple suffixes; word order often has more to do with context than predictable rules of syntax; and as part of the Finno-Ugric language group, Hungarian has few linguistic relatives.

headline: Debut Novels
abstract: New books by Emma Hooper, Quan Barry and Dimitry Elias Léger.
lead_paragraph: ETTA AND OTTO AND RUSSELL AND JAMES  By Emma Hooper  Simon & Schuster, $26.

headline: ‘Right of Boom,’ by Benjamin E. Schwartz
abstract: How would the government respond to a nuclear terrorist attack? A national security specialist considers the options.
lead_paragraph: Nuclear terrorism has long been a staple of movies and television shows. But typically, Hollywood productions end with the bomb being defused. What would happen if heroes didn’t save the day and the United States experienced the worst 24 hours in its history?

headline: ‘Love and Lies,’ by Clancy Martin
abstract: Clancy Martin fuses personal memoir and philosophy in this study of deceit, especially in romantic relationships.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to personal life, even the smartest people, those most capable of irony, humor and subtlety, may well show a weakness for the kind of thinking that precludes all three. This is one explanation for “Love and Lies: An Essay on Truthfulness, Deceit, and the Growth and Care of Erotic Love,” a new and remarkably insight-free book of self-reflection by the novelist and philosophy professor Clancy Martin.

headline: ‘Stella by Starlight’ and ‘Moonpenny Island’
abstract: For two young girls — in the Jim Crow South and on an island in Lake Erie — the world changes suddenly and irrevocably.
lead_paragraph: Childhood may be the easiest time to go to bed as one person and wake up feeling like someone else. In two new middle-­grade novels, young heroines discover that adults are not always truthful, and that the world is more dangerous than anyone has been letting on. They’re life-­changing realizations, for sure, and in both books they present an opportunity to find a moral compass.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: KINDER THAN SOLITUDE,  by Yiyun Li. (Random House, $16.) Li’s intricate mystery spans the two decades after the Tiananmen crackdown of 1989. Shaoai, a brash student protester in Beijing, is poisoned, and three members of her circle are implicated: Ruyu, her orphaned teenage cousin, and their friends Moran and Boyang. As Shaoai lingers for years, brain-damaged and uncommunicative, the three become separated by distance and estrangement, haunted by what happened in their youth.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO DIARY,  by Mohamedou Ould Slahi. Edited by Larry Siems. (Little, Brown, $29.) A longtime captive has written the most profound and disturbing account yet of what it’s like to be collateral damage in the war against terror.

headline: ‘The Door,’ by Magda Szabo
abstract: First published in 1987, Magda Szabo’s novel follows the relationship between two very different women in Communist Hungary.
lead_paragraph: Magda Szabo, who died in 2007, was one of Hungary’s most important 20th-­century writers. Not that most of us Anglophones would know it, as very little of her work has been translated into English. “The Door,” her best-known novel, which appeared in Hungary in 1987, was initially translated by Stefan Draughon and brought out here by an academic publisher in 1995. Subsequently translated into French, the book won the Prix Femina Étranger in 2003 and was beautifully retranslated by Len Rix for British publication in 2005. A decade later, New York Review Books Classics — acting, yet again, in its capacity as the Savior of Lost Greats — has now delivered this version to an American audience.

headline: Mo Yan’s ‘Frog’
abstract: The novelist and Nobel laureate Mo Yan depicts the horrors of China’s one-child policy.
lead_paragraph: In October 2012, Mo Yan became the first citizen of mainland China to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. Since then, he has been attacked both inside and outside China for his collaboration with the Communist literary establishment: for his vice chairmanship of the state writers’ association, for remarking that censorship falls in the same category as airport security. In the summer of 2012, he controversially hand-copied, for a special commemorative edition, part of the 1942 “Talks at the Yan’an Forum on Literature and Art,” Mao Zedong’s statement of orthodoxy on the arts that became the theoretical ur-text of Chinese socialist realism and literary censorship. Yet readers will find little in “Frog,” Howard Gold­blatt’s fluent translation of Mo Yan’s 2009 novel about his country’s one-child policy, that validates the society created by the Chinese Communist Party. It is an anarchic, brutal book about the inhumanity of servants of the Communist state, the inadequacy of Chinese men and the moral vacuum at the heart of post-Mao China.

headline: ‘My Name Is Truth,’ ‘Chasing Freedom’ and ‘The Case for Loving’
abstract: These works of biography and historical fiction immerse young readers in the 19th- and 20th-century struggles for equal rights.
lead_paragraph: At home in the world. The first time I heard this expression, I reveled in the very idea of it. It felt like the perfect life goal for all humankind: a feeling of complete belongingness and freedom, unconstrained by society’s perceptions of your capabilities, wherever you happen to be — at home or in public. The phrase resonates in three new picture books that highlight issues of race, gender and justice. These stories — about Sojourner Truth, Harriet Tubman and Susan B. Anthony, and the Loving v. Virginia case that struck down laws prohibiting interracial marriage — all have main characters with a steadfast determination to change their lives. They are willing to fight their known hell for an unknown, possibly harsher fate. In each book, the law looms as a character, too, a force that can save lives or kill spirits. And all three books are, in different ways, interracial tales, reminding us that diverse coalitions have always worked together to achieve racial progress.

headline: Letters: Books at War
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of “When Books Went to War,” “The Forgotten Depression” and more.
lead_paragraph: Books at War

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jill Leovy, whose “Ghettoside” is No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list, once kept a blog tracking every murder in Los Angeles County.
lead_paragraph: Equal Weight: Jill Leovy’s “Ghettoside,” a true-crime narrative about a murder case in South Los Angeles that opens into a larger exploration of black-on-black violence, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8. Leovy is a longtime reporter for The Los Angeles Times, where for years she maintained the Homicide Report blog to track every murder in the county, in an effort to “communicate the horror of it,” as she said on NPR’s “Fresh Air” recently. “I don’t like blogs very much,” she told the host Dave Davies. “You can scan a newspaper front page and get an idea of what you need to be thinking about very quickly. A blog is just a stack, an undifferentiated stack of news. You can’t tell the trivial from the weighty. And so it doesn’t work for a lot of things — but it occurred to me that it would work for this, that the form would suit what I was trying to say exactly, which is to give everything equal weight. . . . This is not a new story about the sensational case, about the case getting attention. This is just all of them stacked up in a row so that the reader can peruse them and get an idea of who’s dying.”

headline: ‘The Last Time We Say Goodbye’ and ‘I Was Here’
abstract: Two books for young adults explore the guilt, anger and overwhelming sadness that follow a teenager’s death.
lead_paragraph: This review comes with a disclaimer: The subject is radioactively sad. There are no silver linings or surprise resurrections in either of these devastating novels in which teenagers take their own lives. Even if you think you have a high tolerance for gut-wrenching fiction, the tragedy may knock you flat.

headline: ‘Founders’ Son: A Life of Abraham Lincoln,’ by Richard Brookhiser
abstract: Richard Brookhiser casts Lincoln as what might today be called an originalist, a leader who acted in accordance with the founders’ intentions.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Ford’s Theater, the site of Lincoln’s assassination, erected an unusual tribute to the 16th president: a 34-foot tower, eight feet around, created from some 7,000 of the more than 15,000 books about Lincoln that have been published since his death. Richard Brookhiser, the award-winning author of biographies of the founding fathers, now adds to that list, venturing past the Revolution into a new era to explore the life of this most written-about American. In many ways, however, this is less a book in which Brookhiser moves forward in time than one that endeavors to pull Lincoln back into the 18th century, claiming him, in the title’s words, as fundamentally the “founders’ son.” Brookhiser casts Lincoln as what might today be called an originalist, a leader who applied the doctrines of both the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in accordance with the founders’ intentions in order to chart his way through a new national crisis.

headline: The Poet’s Keeper
abstract: A critic rereads “Poets in Their Youth,” Eileen Simpson’s memoir about John Berryman and his circle of friends, and sees Simpson as a heroic figure.
lead_paragraph: W. H. Auden said that a great book reads you. Eileen Simpson’s beautiful, recently reissued memoir of her doomed marriage to the poet John Berryman, “Poets in Their Youth” (1982), read me twice, just a few weeks ago and about 30 or so years before that, when I was in my early 20s. I might well have been two different people.

headline: ‘X,’ a Novel About Malcolm X
abstract: A young-adult novel based on the black leader’s early years, co‑written by one of his daughters.
lead_paragraph: It would be fascinating to get Malcolm X’s take on the current surge of racial tension in America. At first glance, we seem to have made great strides toward equality since the civil rights movement. We elected Barack Obama, a black man, president. Twice. We almost universally condemn outright racism. But is it possible that racism (most notably against African-­Americans) hasn’t receded so much as it has evolved and become more refined? “The elegant racist,” Ta-Nehisi Coates has written, “knows how to injure nonwhite people while never summoning the specter of white guilt.” Housing segregation, for instance, is both devastating and hard to detect. And according to the Sentencing Project, a group that advocates for prison reform, racial minorities are more likely than whites to be arrested, to be convicted and to face stiff sentences. With recent racially charged events like the deaths of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., and Eric Garner in New York City — as well as the rising plea for more representation of minorities in children’s literature from the We Need Diverse Books movement — I can’t think of a more appropriate time for a book about the early years of Malcolm X.

headline: Bookshelf: Love
abstract: New books include “Love Always Everywhere” and “There’s This Thing.”
lead_paragraph: New books include “Love Always Everywhere” and “There’s This Thing.”

headline: Republicans Look for the Dark Side on the Jobs Report
abstract: Economists called it one of the best monthly jobs reports since the recession, with hiring and wages on the rise, but for Republicans on Friday the challenge was how to tamp down the cheers.
lead_paragraph: Economists called it one of the best monthly jobs reports since the recession, with hiring and wages on the rise, but for Republicans on Friday the challenge was how to tamp down the cheers.

headline: Lawmakers Call for Investigation Into Verizon’s Use of Mobile ‘Supercookies’
abstract: Three senators sent letters to the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Communications Commission, saying that the tracking technology may violate consumers’ privacy and asking regulators to investigate Verizon’s practices.
lead_paragraph: Three Democratic lawmakers on the influential Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation are calling on federal regulators to investigate Verizon for its practice of using unique customer codes to track the online activities of its wireless subscribers.

headline: Can Narendra Modi Keep Winning?
abstract: On Saturday, voters in New Delhi are due to elect their 70-member legislative assembly.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – Narendra Modi became India’s prime minister after his Bharatiya Janata Party won a parliamentary election in May, crushing the Indian National Congress that had controlled Indian politics for most of the past 60 years.  Propelled by his popularity, the BJP then extended its mandate by sweeping a succession of state elections.

headline: A Fashion Designer Stages an Erotic Exhibition in Lieu of a Runway
abstract: Bernard Wilhelm opens a show at MOCA, in which he presents his fall/winter 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: The German designer Bernhard Willhelm may have grown up near the Bauhaus stronghold Ulm School of Design, where lecturers included Mies van der Rohe and Buckminster Fuller, but he’s since become the fashion world’s champion of form following a different sort of function. In Willhelm’s hands, geometric cuts and experimental textiles explore not utility, but the sometimes messy rules of attraction — and he’s quick to cite the adage that we put on clothes hoping someone else will take them off later. “I think if you have sex with somebody it’s very, very important that you have a little laugh together,” says Willhelm, noting that he was the first cover boy for the magazine Butt. “When sex gets too serious it’s unbearable, and that’s the same with sexy fashion.” This good-humored dedication to liberation is on full display in Willhelm’s exhibition “When Fashion Shows the Danger Then Fashion Is the Danger,” co-conceived with his longtime collaborator Jutta Kraus, and opening this weekend at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

headline: 1940: Canadian Ship Torpedoed
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A Canadian ship was lost in the war in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The first Canadian ship of the war to be lost, the 9,874-ton Beaverburn, of the Canadian Pacific Steamship Company, was torpedoed by a German submarine off the southern coast of Ireland today [Feb. 6]. Other ships in the vicinity hurried to the scene and rescued all but one of the seventy-seven members of the crew. Constructed in 1928, the Beaverburn was one of the fastest Canadian freighters and carried the most modern equipement for fruit refrigeration. Its attacker was believed to be the same submarine unofficially reported in the trans-Atlantic shipping lane off Cornwall peninsula. Fifty-four members of the 100-man crew of the 875-ton British minesweeper Sphinx were lost when it foundered yesterday as it was being towed to port, after having been attacked by German planes. The captain and four seamen were killed during the attack and the other forty-nine were drowned. During the week ending February 5, eight British merchant-ships, totaling 25,069 tons, and six neutral ships totaling 17,546 tons, were lost by enemy action. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 7, 1940

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Love and Lies’
abstract: This week, Adelle Waldman discusses Clancy Martin’s “Love and Lies”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Dana Goldstein talks about Anya Kamenetz’s “The Test”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Adelle Waldman discusses Clancy Martin’s “Love and Lies”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Dana Goldstein talks about Anya Kamenetz’s “The Test”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: ISIS Declares Airstrike Killed a U.S. Hostage
abstract: The Islamic State said Friday that Jordanian bombings in Syria intended to avenge the immolation of a captured pilot had killed an American hostage, Kayla Mueller, who was held by the group.
lead_paragraph: She had always been the unidentified, lone female American hostage of the Islamic State. For nearly 17 months, while her fellow American captives were beheaded one after another in serial executions posted on YouTube, Kayla Mueller’s name remained a closely guarded secret, whispered among reporters, government officials and hostage negotiators — all fearing that any public mention might imperil her life.

headline: Finding the ‘Right’ Way to Dispose of Ill-Gotten Gains
abstract: After an audit revealed a questionable $12 million surplus, a company hired a law firm to help it get rid of the money by giving it away.
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL years ago, a large European company asked Thomas M. DiBiagio to run an internal audit on its South African operations. The company suspected that something might be amiss. And it was right. In the course of the audit, he discovered about $12 million that might best be described as ill-gotten gains.

headline: Should Children Be Forced to Perform?
abstract: Children need to learn how to read, but do they really need to learn to sing Do-Re-Mi in front of two hundred people with flashing cameras?
lead_paragraph: Cai came to the front of the stage, his skin pale, his eyes void of their usual joy. He looked up and blinked excessively. The blinking became more rapid and his eyes stayed shut for longer periods and suddenly it looked as if his eyes were rolled back. For a few horrible moments, my husband, Matt, and I believed our son was having a seizure. Then the song ended and a new group of first graders came to the front. Cai receded to the back row, disappearing from view.

headline: Ask Well: Measles and Day Care
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Day Care Centers', 'Measles', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: You asked: Can a vaccinated child bring measles into your home?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Care Is the X Factor at Work
abstract: The most powerful influence on people’s engagement at work is feeling genuinely cared for by their supervisor, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, a midlevel employee at a company I work with got on a plane at his own expense, prompted by a decision that he felt had not been fair to one of his colleagues, and flew several thousand miles across the ocean to discuss the situation directly with his supervisor.

headline: Alan Gilbert to Leave New York Philharmonic in 2017
abstract: Mr. Gilbert will step down as music director of the Philharmonic after eight seasons, and the search is on for his successor.
lead_paragraph: Alan Gilbert will step down as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2017, after eight seasons, the orchestra said on Friday, setting off what promises to be an intense search for a successor to lead the ensemble through the planned renovation of Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Carpetbagger Video: Patricia Arquette on Leaving the Ingenue Behind
abstract: The actress explains why she has always been quick to move on from the roles Hollywood expects of her.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Arquette has been among the consistent front-runners this awards season for her performance as the mother in “Boyhood,” the coming-of-age tale filmed over 12 years. In part, she has been celebrated for agreeing to age on camera. But as the Oscar-nominated Ms. Arquette tells the Bagger, she has long been leery of following the rules Hollywood dictates for actresses’ careers.

headline: Premature Babies With Asthma Outgrow It
abstract: By the time they reach adulthood, their risk of asthma is no greater than that of full-term babies, a Danish study has found.
lead_paragraph: Parents of premature babies worry about many things, including an increased risk of asthma. But a large Danish study has found that asthma, common in premature babies, disappears as the children grow older. By the time they are adults, their risk of asthma is no greater than that of babies born full term.

headline: Bufflehead Ducks Bob Along the Atlantic Shoreline
abstract: The bufflehead (Bucephala albeola) is a tiny, tough little duck, with a tight, stocky body that is well proportioned and beautifully suited to a life diving for food along the frigid shoreline of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: The cure for winter blues is often trudging right in, so with only the slightest north wind and the light babble and hiss of clear green wavelets for company, I started a short walk along the Rockaway Inlet on a recent break in the snow. A cool fog, which sometimes follows a warm winter day, reduced anything beyond my immediate surroundings to haze. I had to stop at one point to admire this trick of the Atlantic — making a thousand-mile horizon vanish — and as I did, five buffleheads appeared as if fashioned just that moment on the limpid seawater. They bobbed like corks, sharply defined in black and white, and I resisted the urge to make them agents with greater intentions. Finally, unable to resolve their vague message, I spent my time figuring out the birds instead.

headline: A Reading of “Almost Your Life” by Fady Joudah
abstract: The Palestinian-American poet reads his meditation on love and longing.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian-American poet reads his meditation on love and longing.

headline: Gap Persists in Homeownership
abstract: Low-income and minority households have gained no ground in homeownership over the last few years, and are actually doing worse in many states.
lead_paragraph: The rising tide of economic recovery is not lifting those most in need, according to an annual scorecard of financial security and opportunity put out by the nonprofit Corporation for Enterprise Development. Low- to moderate-income households and households of color remain far behind on a number of measures of financial well-being, especially when it comes to homeownership.

headline: In Upper Manhattan, Restoring the Golden Halo of Mother Cabrini
abstract: A sparkling mosaic mural, depicting the life of America’s first saint, Frances Xavier Cabrini, patron saint of immigrants, was recently restored to its original luster.
lead_paragraph: In the apse of a midcentury chapel in Upper Manhattan, there is a sparkling mosaic mural that depicts the life of America’s first saint, Frances Xavier Cabrini. The mural was recently restored to its original luster using period tiles, or tesserae, made of various types of marble (Carrara, Botticino) as well as gilded Venetian glass tiles, made by fusing 22-karat gold leaf between layers of glass and crystal.

headline: What I Love | David and Cherilyn Frei
abstract: After a false start, David and Cherilyn Frei find a home their dogs can live with. For starters, it’s near a park.
lead_paragraph: After a false start, David and Cherilyn Frei find a home their dogs can live with. For starters, it’s near a park.

headline: Home Loan Programs Let Buyers Put Less Down
abstract: New options from Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the F.H.A. require some research by would-be borrowers, who may decide it’s better to wait and save.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest hurdles to buying a home is accumulating the pile of cash for a down payment. By some estimates, it could take two decades to come up with a respectable 10 percent.

headline: Never-Before-Seen Photos of John & Yoko
abstract: Kishin Shinoyama took the snapshots, one of which became the cover of their album “Double Fantasy,” just months before Lennon’s death in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Kishin Shinoyama took the snapshots, one of which became the cover of their album “Double Fantasy,” just months before Lennon’s death in 1980.

headline: Debate on Arming Ukraine Fractures Washington Think Tank
abstract: Ukraine isn’t the only place consumed by civil war thanks to Russia. The venerable Brookings Institution, long one of Washington’s most prestigious research centers, has fractured very publicly this week over Russia as well.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine isn’t the only place consumed by civil war thanks to Russia. The venerable Brookings Institution, long one of Washington’s most prestigious research centers, has fractured very publicly this week over Russia as well.

headline: Ex-Federal Prosecutor in New York Joins Ackman’s Hedge Fund
abstract: The move reflects a growing trend of seasoned prosecutors’ bypassing the traditional career path of a job at a big law firm.
lead_paragraph: Until a few weeks ago, Jenna Dabbs was a federal prosecutor in Manhattan, leading the charge in prosecuting some of the biggest and toughest drug kingpins in the world.

abstract: The Masthead of The New York Times.

headline: Pandora Readies for Another Royalties Battle, This Time With BMI
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The music-streaming service is being sued by BMI, a giant licensing agency, which wants a higher cut of Pandora’s revenue. The trial begins next week.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Sunday, the eyes of the music world will be on the Grammy Awards in the Staples Center. But shortly afterward, the industry’s attention will shift to a much less glamorous location: a federal courtroom in Manhattan, where Pandora will square off against the giant licensing agency BMI in the latest fight over music royalties in the digital age.

headline: The Well-Housebroken Seal of Approval
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Dogs', 'Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show']
abstract: Cherilyn and David Frei were brought together by their love of dogs.
lead_paragraph: Angel and Grace Frei live in a one-bedroom condominium near the river on East 72nd Street. The setup is beyond perfection, what with a sectional that fairly begs to be flopped on, and a flat-screen television that’s always set to their favorite channel, NY1. Even better, they’re on the fourth floor, which means it’s a quick elevator ride to the great outdoors, and a very short walk to the park where all their friends hang out.

headline: How Elementary School Teachers’ Biases Can Discourage Girls From Math and Science
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Education (K-12)', 'Science and Technology', 'Mathematics', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Research', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Early educational experiences have a quantifiable effect on the courses students choose later, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: We know that women are underrepresented in math and science jobs. What we don’t know is why it happens.

headline: Sochi, Russia, a Year After the Games
abstract: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.
lead_paragraph: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.

headline: No Need to Be Afraid. It’s Only a Performance Review.
abstract: Through hard experience, Nancy Morris, a consultant in business psychology, has learned how to streamline systems, not fire people, when workplaces aren’t working.
lead_paragraph: NANCY MORRIS has been on the giving and receiving end of bad feedback.

headline: Photos: Hardly a City Frozen in Time
abstract: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.
lead_paragraph: A year after the Sochi Olympics, the flags of the competing nations continue to flutter in the breeze rolling in from the Black Sea, and oversize cuddly mascots still roam the vast expanse of the Olympic Park’s central plaza, the heart of Russia’s monumental Olympic effort.

headline: Chocolate Gifts for Valentine’s Day
abstract: Sweet confectionery gifts in every shape and size in time for Feb. 14.
lead_paragraph: Sweet confectionery gifts in every shape and size in time for Feb. 14.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Love and Lies’
abstract: This week, Adelle Waldman and Dana Goldstein.
lead_paragraph: This week, Adelle Waldman and Dana Goldstein.

headline: College Kids Are Getting More Depressed
abstract: In 2014, only 18% of students reported spending at least 16 hours per week socializing with friends.
lead_paragraph: An annual survey of college freshmen released on Thursday shows that a worrisome proportion of them had felt depressed and overwhelmed during the previous year. An intensifying pressure to succeed is taking a toll on college-bound high school seniors. The pressure is worsened by the fact that they have lost the ability to kick back and relax among friends.

headline: $25,925,000 for a Perch Above Central Park
abstract: A three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath apartment at 15 Central Park West was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A spacious three-bedroom apartment with stunning park, city and river vistas at 15 Central Park West, the exclusive twin-towered limestone condominium designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, sold for $25,925,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Larry Kramer to Be Honored by Gay Men’s Health Crisis
abstract: Mr. Kramer, who was ousted from the group in 1983, will be the first recipient of its new Larry Kramer Activism Award for lifetime achievement.
lead_paragraph: Larry Kramer and Gay Men’s Health Crisis are coming full circle. The volunteer AIDS organization, which grew out of a gathering in Mr. Kramer’s living room in 1982, but whose leaders ousted him the next year due to his confrontational tactics for drawing attention to the epidemic, will honor him at its annual spring gala on March 23 by creating a lifetime achievement award bearing his name, the group announced on Friday.

headline: 4 Accounting Firms’ China Affiliates Agree to S.E.C. Settlement
abstract: The Chinese affiliates of the firms failed to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under S.E.C. inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese affiliates of the Big Four accounting firms have agreed to pay a combined $2 million as part of a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over their failure to produce documents from their audits of Chinese companies under investigation by the agency.

headline: Brooklyn Trust Company Building Condos
abstract: The building, at 177 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, is undergoing conversion to condos on its upper floors.
lead_paragraph: The building, at 177 Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights, is undergoing conversion to condos on its upper floors.

headline: Books on a Ramone, the Algonquin Set and Weegee’s New York
abstract: Recently published books detail Marky Ramone’s life; the rich literary legacy of the Algonquin Round Table; and Weegee’s gritty street scenes from the 1930s and ’40s.
lead_paragraph: Marc Bell grew up in Crown Heights, the grandson of the head chef at ‘21’ and son of a longshoreman. He and his twin brother shuttled to nursery school in a converted Cadillac hearse. In 1961, when he was 9, he got a transistor radio (AM only) as a Christmas gift, and by the time he was 13, as a self-taught drummer, he started a band that began playing gigs at Ditmas Junior High and eventually worked its way out of the neighborhood.

headline: Concerns Over Safety of Air Travel in Asia
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 17']
abstract: Fatal crashes of five planes in the past year have raised questions about the security of Asian carriers.
lead_paragraph: Fatal crashes of Malaysia Airlines, AirAsia and TransAsia Airways planes in the past year have prompted travelers to raise questions about the safety of Asian carriers and whether steps are being taken to ensure their security.

headline: ‘Palazzo’ Living in Brooklyn
abstract: Work is underway to transform the upper floors of the imposing Brooklyn Trust Company Building on the edge of Brooklyn Heights and Downtown Brooklyn into a boutique condominium.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Trust Company Building, an imposing structure on the edge of Brooklyn Heights and Downtown Brooklyn, was built to resemble an Italian palazzo, with a grand banking hall meant to impress patrons. Soon, it will also be a place to live, as work is underway to transform the upper floors into a boutique condominium.

headline: Republicans, Feeling Shut Out, Question Obama’s Legislative Intentions
keywords: ['Community Colleges', 'Tuition', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican lawmakers, who say they were not consulted on President Obama’s plan for free community college, wonder whether he is trying to pass legislation or simply burnishing his legacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four days before President Obama unveiled a sweeping $60 billion vision of free community college for millions of Americans, his staff reached out to Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, a former education secretary and a Republican authority on the issue.

headline: MacArthur Award Recognizes Documentary Film Company
abstract: Firelight Media, a New York City documentary film company, was among nine organizations named as recipients of the MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions.
lead_paragraph: Firelight Media, a New York City documentary film company, was among nine organizations named as recipients of the MacArthur Award for Creative and Effective Institutions on Friday by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

headline: Elite Horses Keep Going, and Fans Are Set to Follow
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: All 10 horses in the season-ending National Thoroughbred Racing Association poll for premier 3-year-olds remain in training and are expected to race this year, setting up several appealing events.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — At 77, Art Sherman is old enough to recall horse racing’s heyday. A half-century ago, he was an exercise rider for Swaps, nicknamed the California Comet, and marveled at the supercharged throngs lured to the track by the thoroughbred.

headline: Even Young Werther Would Be Happy: Goethe-Institut New York to Return to Renovated Home
abstract: The Goethe-Institut New York will reopen its headquarter on March 28.
lead_paragraph: The Goethe-Institut New York  will reopen in renovated headquarters on Irving Place on March 28, after spending the last five years in a temporary residence on Spring Street. The institute, part of an international network of similar institutions sponsored by the German government to promote German language and culture abroad, plans to expand its programs and to offer its own language courses for the first time. In the past language students attended courses at Deutsches Haus at New York University.

headline: Landscapes, After Katrina’s Storm
abstract: Colleen Mullins’s photos of post-Katrina New Orleans chronicle a changing landscape, focusing on how people are working to undo damage to the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Colleen Mullins’s photos of post-Katrina New Orleans chronicle a changing landscape, focusing on how people are working to undo damage to the ecosystem.

headline: Ellen Brody, S.U.V. Driver in Metro-North Crash, Is Mourned
abstract: At a funeral service Friday, family and friends gathered to focus on the life of Ms. Brody, whose sport utility vehicle was at the center of a fatal Metro-North Railroad train crash.
lead_paragraph: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y. — The woman whose sport utility vehicle was at the center of the train crash that claimed six lives, including her own, was remembered on Friday morning in a packed funeral service here for what was described as a larger-than-life personality and her devotion to family and friends.

headline: Still Giving the Joint Class
abstract: Charlotte White, whose long career as a pianist took her on many travels, runs a salon series to promote the careers of budding classical musicians.
lead_paragraph: “It’s called chutzpah,” said Charlotte White, describing how she, at age 100, could be bustling — with a walker, no less — around the elegant Hungarian Consulate on East 52nd Street one recent weeknight making final preparations for an evening billed as “Charlotte White’s Salon de Virtuosi.”

headline: The New School Divests Fossil Fuel Stock and Refocuses on Climate Change
abstract: The historically progressive school plans to bolster its curriculum to include more attention in its courses to climate change and sustainability.
lead_paragraph: Many universities have decided to drop fossil fuel stocks from their investment portfolios, but the New School in New York City has decided to go a step further.

headline: Child, Bride, Mother: Guatemala
abstract: In Guatemala, many young girls marry far older men and become mothers long before they are physically and emotionally ready.
lead_paragraph: In Guatemala, many young girls marry far older men and become mothers long before they are physically and emotionally ready.

headline: Profiteroles With a Prize Inside
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Chocolate', 'Pastries', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: Pastry puffs encasing chocolate ice cream can charm even an avowed nonchocoholic.
lead_paragraph: I am neither a chocophile nor a chocophobe, but I’m definitely not a chocoholic. You won’t tempt me with a slice of chocolate layer cake or a molten chocolate soufflé, you won’t win my heart with a ribbon-wrapped box of bonbons and you certainly won’t find me participating in a communal chocolate fondue.

headline: Rushing to Cater to America’s Rich
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: As the U.S. economy turns around and upper-income spending falters in other countries, companies chase American millionaires.
lead_paragraph: In Houston, Chanel’s new 5,000 square-foot galleria is styled after Coco Chanel’s Baroque-inspired apartment, with bronze screens, an antique fireplace and a chandeliered shoe salon.

headline: An Upbeat Jobs Report Narrows a Political Debate
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: With job gains revised upward, even the grumpiest Republicans found things to praise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since the midterm elections in early November, in the face of reports on the economy and jobs, politicians from both parties have been struggling to figure out the best way to exploit what is going on.

headline: Alan Nunnelee, Republican Congressman, Dies at 56
abstract: Representative Alan Nunnelee, a Republican congressman from Mississippi, died in his home on Friday. He was 56.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alan Nunnelee, Republican of Mississippi, died on Friday, months after undergoing brain surgery. He was 56.

headline: Resting Place for the High and the Low
abstract: Four former New York mayors, including Edward I. Koch, are among those buried in the Washington Heights graveyard that sits in the shadow of the Church of the Intercession.
lead_paragraph: The remains of an unlikely confederation of aristocrats and scalawags are condensed in a Washington Heights graveyard in the shadow of THE CHURCH OF THE INTERCESSION. The imposing Gothic Revival chapel, at West 155th Street and Broadway, was consecrated in 1915 and designed by a self-taught architect named Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue. His body is entombed in the transept of the soaring sanctuary. Patchworks of stained glass diffuse sunlight, and the altar is inlaid with more than 1,500 stones collected from pilgrimage locations around the world. A cloistered walkway encloses an English-style garden, and a vaulted crypt resembles the Grand Central Oyster Bar without the tables.

headline: John Harwood Talks to Michael B. Froman
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Small Business']
abstract: Highlights from a conversation with Mr. Froman, who is negotiating the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade pact that is considered one of the few points on which Democrats and Republicans can agree.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from a conversation with Mr. Froman, who is negotiating the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade pact that is considered one of the few points on which Democrats and Republicans can agree.

headline: Who Might Replace Gilbert at the Philharmonic
abstract: Here are some types of conductors officials may consider to replace Alan Gilbert at the New York Philharmonic; many are under contract elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: What kind of conductor the New York Philharmonic chooses to succeed Alan Gilbert, who announced Friday that he would step down as music director in 2017, will say a lot about how the orchestra sees its mission in the 21st century. Here are some types of conductors officials may consider, though many of the maestros named are under contract elsewhere.

headline: In Los Angeles, Vintage Houses Are Giving Way to Bulldozers
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Demolition', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The fight over redevelopment is particularly pitched in a home-starved city with a diversity of architectural styles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For 50 years, the science fiction writer Ray Bradbury lived and wrote at 10265 Cheviot Drive, a bright yellow stucco home built in 1937 that is tucked away on a winding street in an eclectic and charming, affluent neighborhood on the West Side of Los Angeles.

headline: They’re Always Borrowing His Stuff
abstract: For a generation addicted to borrowing and sampling, the British composer Thomas Adès provides a way forward beyond Minimalism and the avant-garde.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Adès almost broke up the Punch Brothers. “I wanted to be him,” Chris Thile, the frontman of that progressive bluegrass band, recently recalled of his first encounter with the surreal music Mr. Adès composed. “I was wondering if I should go back to the drawing board: put everything on hold for five years and figure out a way to do something more like that.”

headline: Biden Expected to Miss Netanyahu Speech to Congress
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to miss Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to Congress.
lead_paragraph: Sorry, Mr. Prime Minister, but I’m busy that day.

headline: Striving for Steps That Look Effortless
abstract: Ballet Arizona, led by Ib Andersen, will become the first American company to mount a complete production of the 1842 ballet “Napoli,” a challenging work by August Bournonville.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “If you love the warmth of the sun ... go.” These words, which you might find in a tourist brochure about this desert city, actually come from the 19th-century Danish ballet choreographer August Bournonville, recounting in his memoirs a trip to southern Italy, not the American Southwest. Yet there is a connection between those sentiments and him and Phoenix, or there will be on Thursday, when Ballet Arizona becomes the first American company to mount a complete production of the 1842 ballet inspired by that Italian journey, Bournonville’s “Napoli.”

lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

abstract: Sky View Parc, a mixed-use project in Flushing, Queens, is barreling ahead with its next phase to a very strong reception.
lead_paragraph: Sky View Parc, a mixed-use project in Flushing, Queens, that stumbled during the recession, only to right itself quickly in subsequent years, is barreling ahead with its next phase to a very strong reception.

lead_paragraph: DuPont has driven a wedge between shareholders and the billionaire activist Nelson Peltz.

headline: Finding a Balance Between Two Worlds
abstract: Ibeyi, made up of the twins Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz, prepares for a performance in New York.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The 20-year-old Díaz twins, who make up the Franco-Cuban duo Ibeyi, are almost comically different. Lisa-Kaindé, far right, with her dramatic halo of hair, is chatty and easygoing; Naomi is almond-eyed and enigmatic. They live with their mother, who is also their manager, but have never attended the same school and have different social circles. “People never called us ‘the twins,’ ” Lisa-Kaindé said. “We aren’t detached, but ...”

headline: The Politics of Trade: The Top U.S. Negotiator Answers 10 Questions
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A conversation with Michael B. Froman, who is negotiating the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade pact between the United States and a dozen countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States trade representative, Michael B. Froman, a Harvard Law School classmate of President Obama’s, is scrambling to complete the one big deal that appears ripe for compromise between Republicans and Democrats — the Trans-Pacific Partnership with a dozen countries from Canada to New Zealand. The deal, being negotiated, forms the core of Mr. Obama’s much-promoted “pivot” toward Asia.

headline: 2 Down, 3 to Go as Skier Pursues a Singular Feat
abstract: Tina Maze of Slovenia captured the women’s downhill at the Alpine world ski championships in Beaver Creek, Colo., to earn her second medal there. She has hopes of three more.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — After Tina Maze of Slovenia won the silver medal in Tuesday’s women’s super-G at the Alpine world ski championships, she insisted she could win a medal in each of the five women’s races during the 13-day competition.

headline: English Premier League Rights Could Cost U.K. Broadcasters Billions
abstract: The price of soccer TV rights for British broadcasters is expected to rise more than 50 percent for the three-year period starting in 2016.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For many, soccer remains the beautiful game. But for others, it has become more like moneyball.

headline: In Yemen, Hard Times Remain a Constant as Rebels Take Charge
abstract: Yemenis have always had to struggle to get through their days in a country where the government is incapable of delivering essential services.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Twelve-year-old Nefisa Nasser lined up four jerrycans by a faucet on the side of a busy street, patiently waiting her turn to fill them with water. She completed the daily routine, capping each container and sliding it into a wheelbarrow that she pushed back home through the clamor of morning traffic.

headline: Giving Something Back to the Kids
abstract: Felipe Lopez, a basketball prodigy in high school and at St. John’s who later played professionally, now works with teenagers in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Felipe Lopez, a basketball prodigy in high school and at St. John’s who later played professionally, now works with teenagers in the Bronx.

headline: For Felipe Lopez, a Basketball Ambassador, a Day to Pray
abstract: Mr. Lopez, a former St. John’s star and professional player who works with teenagers through N.B.A. Cares, attends Sunday services at his evangelical church and, later, at St. Patrick’s.
lead_paragraph: Felipe Lopez has a special place in New York’s basketball pantheon: a gravity-defying phenom at Rice High School in Manhattan in the early ’90s, a star at St. John’s University in Queens. His National Basketball Association career, less prolific, lasted five journeyman seasons before an injury cut it short. Now, as the N.B.A. All-Star festivities return to New York Feb. 13 to 15, Mr. Lopez will be making a different kind of star turn, working with city teenagers as an ambassador for the league’s N.B.A. Cares program. “The goal is to reach over a million kids in the five boroughs,” Mr. Lopez, 40, said. He also runs a free Saturday basketball clinic at the Evangelical Spanish Church, near his childhood home in the Bronx. He moved to Astoria, Queens, last year with his girlfriend, Marija Kero, 30, a math teacher at Mott Hall Charter School in the Bronx.

headline: Chef Jamie Oliver Said to Hire Bankers to Find New Investors
abstract: Mr. Oliver’s company has hired the Raine Group, a boutique investment bank, to sell a minority stake in his media and publishing business, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: For years, diners have flocked to Jamie Oliver’s restaurants and made his recipes. Now Mr. Oliver, the British celebrity chef, is hoping to draw in new investors.

headline: New York’s New Speaker Is One of the Nation’s Most Liberal State Lawmakers
abstract: Two political scientists have mapped state legislators in all 50 states on an ideological spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Carl Heastie, the new speaker of the New York State Assembly, isn’t just the first African-American in the state’s history to hold that leadership post. He’s also one of the most liberal state lawmakers in the nation, according to an analysis by two political scientists.
