lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The Supreme Court of Canada on Friday struck down laws banning physician-assisted suicide for patients with “grievous and irremediable” medical conditions.

headline: At Diplomatic Conference, Turkey-Israel Rift Worsens
abstract: The minister withdrew at the last minute from an international security conference in Munich after learning that Israeli diplomats might take part.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish foreign minister withdrew at the last minute from a high-profile international security conference in Munich on Friday, after learning that Israeli diplomats might take part. The abrupt move was the latest twist in a bilateral relationship between Israel and Turkey that was once friendly but has become strained and bitter.

headline: Writing Around Gender
abstract: Julie Scelfo, a Times contributing writer, details the challenge of writing an article about gender neutrality.
lead_paragraph: This week, Julie Scelfo’s article on how the University of Vermont has recognized students outside the traditional male/female norm presented special concerns. The story had to be written without using the pronouns “she” or “he” to identify Rocko Gieselman, its main character.

abstract: Baby boomers are turning to the growing number of firms that specialize in placing older workers in part-time or temporary positions in specific industries.
lead_paragraph: CAROL BERNING’S career as a consumer psychologist was ahead of the curve for her generation. She received a doctorate 40 years ago when few women were in graduate school. Her sole employer for 34 years was Procter & Gamble, where she focused on consumer research.

headline: A Cozy Living Room With a Barista: Roots Cafe in the South Slope
abstract: A sign in Roots Cafe, in the South Slope in Brooklyn, conveys the cafe’s motto: “He who enters here is a stranger but once.”
lead_paragraph: On a slushy Saturday morning, Ashley Brazenor, 30, was babysitting for 2-year-old Beckett Abbott at Roots Cafe. She ordered a cold-brew iced coffee and a tofu scramble with vegan cheese — no toast, extra Sriracha — while Beckett nibbled on a berry muffin. Bluegrass riffs bounced off walls lined with washboards, acoustic guitars and mounted driftwood. A line snaked almost to the door, as patrons waited to order ginger apple cider or egg-and-cheese burritos slathered with mashed avocados and black beans.

headline: The Pitfalls in the Greek Debt Proposal
abstract: Greece’s debt swap plan harks back to the Gilded Age, when J.P. Morgan (the man) and his lawyers restructured insolvent American railroads, Stephen J. Lubben writes in the In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: Greece and Germany are heading at each other at high speed, fundamentally disagreeing about Greece’s need to stick to the austerity provisions in its loan agreements. The question is whether either will turn off at the last second. Domestic political concerns in both countries argue against it.

headline: New Data Shows Apple’s Explosive Growth in China
abstract: Both Kantar Worldpanel and Canalys, research firms that track global smartphone sales, said Apple’s mobile operating system gained market share in China at the expense of Google’s Android.
lead_paragraph: When Apple reported a record-shattering profit of $18 billion last month, the company said its growth came largely from sales in greater China. This week, some research firms gave a clearer picture of just how big Apple has become in China.

headline: Observing a Matterhorn Milestone
abstract: Zermatt, Switzerland, will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the first ascent of the Matterhorn in July; a play about the climb will be performed in three languages
lead_paragraph: The Swiss town of Zermatt will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the first ascent of the Matterhorn with a show.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Love and Lies’
abstract: Adelle Waldman discusses Clancy Martin’s “Love and Lies,” and Dana Goldstein talks about Anya Kamenetz’s “The Test.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Adelle Waldman reviews Clancy Martin’s “Love and Lies: An Essay on Truthfulness, Deceit, and the Growth and Care of Erotic Love.” Ms. Waldman writes:

lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Mexico, Jordan and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Mexico, Jordan and Taiwan.

headline: In a New Book, Never-Before-Seen Photos of John Lennon and Yoko Ono
abstract: Kishin Shinoyama took the snapshots, one of which became the cover of the album “Double Fantasy,” just months before Lennon’s death in 1980.
lead_paragraph: A little over 30 years ago, the Japanese photographer Kishin Shinoyama walked through Central Park with one of the most famous couples in the world. It was sunset, autumn; they sat on a bench just in front of the pond, bordered by trees, a sliver of New York skyline visible in the distance, including the building where they lived. He asked them to kiss, and he clicked the shutter. Three months later, on Dec. 8, 1980, John Lennon was fatally shot at the entrance to the Dakota, home to him and his wife, Yoko Ono. Just three weeks prior to Lennon’s death, Shinoyama’s photograph of John and Yoko’s kiss at Central Park Pond had appeared on the cover of what would be their final studio album, “Double Fantasy.” Shinoyama made other photographs that day, of course — 800 in all, in fact — but many of them have never been shown until now, on the occasion of Taschen’s forthcoming publication of “Kishin Shinoyama. John Lennon & Yoko Ono. Double Fantasy” ($700), out this month. A video trailer for the book premieres here.

headline: Saluting the Rodgers Songwriting Dynasty
abstract: Judy Kuhn sang music from three generations of the Richard Rodgers dynasty as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: From father to daughter to grandson: The Lincoln Center American Songbook program “Judy Kuhn Sings Richard Rodgers, Mary Rodgers and Adam Guettel” on Wednesday evening convincingly portrayed the lineage of the composer Richard Rodgers as more than bloodline; it is a proudly romantic musical tradition. The performer making the connections was that top-of-the-line singer Judy Kuhn, whose approach to theater music might be described as one of passionate restraint.

headline: Chastised at Home, Iranian Diplomat Refrains From ‘Intimacy’ With U.S. Counterpart
abstract: Foreign Minister Mohammed Javad Zarif was criticized for taking a walk with Secretary of State John Kerry during a break in talks last month.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, was assailed by hard-liners in Tehran last month for talking a widely photographed walk in Geneva with Secretary of State John Kerry during a break in their talks on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Netanyahu’s ‘Bibi-Sitter’ Ad Draws Praise From U.S. Conservatives
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, stars in an online comedy sketch as the nation’s babysitter in chief.
lead_paragraph: As campaigning intensifies ahead of elections next month in Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is making his case to stay in office by playing the role of the nation’s babysitter in chief in an online comedy sketch posted on Facebook and YouTube.

headline: Persevering in Love
abstract: Saira Hussain and Assad Akhter were married on Jan. 3, at the Hilton Garden Inn New York in Graniteville, Staten Island. The bride had initially rebuffed the groom’s advances, but he never stopped pursuing her.
lead_paragraph: Saira Hussain and Assad Akhter were married on Jan. 3, at the Hilton Garden Inn New York in Graniteville, Staten Island. The bride had initially rebuffed the groom’s advances, but he never stopped pursuing her.

headline: Rachmaninoff’s Comeback Work, Sprawling Onstage
abstract: Lisa Batiashvili played the Barber Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, conducted by David Zinman at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Beauty of tone proved one of many impressive elements that distinguished Lisa Batiashvili’s performance of the Barber Violin Concerto on Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic, conducted by David Zinman at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Gov. Walker’s ‘Drafting Error’
abstract: The Wisconsin Legislature must resist the governor’s ideologically driven thrust at the state university system.
lead_paragraph: It was not enough for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin suddenly to propose a destructive 13 percent cut in state support for the University of Wisconsin’s widely respected system. His biennial budget plan, released Tuesday, reached gratuitously into the university’s hallowed 111-year-old mission statement to delete a bedrock principle: “Basic to every purpose of the system is the search for truth.”

headline: Wanted: Better Jobs, Higher Pay
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Will job growth continue to accelerate? Is optimism warranted?
lead_paragraph: Job growth got off to a good start in 2015. The economy added 257,000 jobs in January and tallies for November and December were revised upward, for an average monthly gain of 336,000 jobs over the past three months — a clear acceleration in the growth trend, at long last.

headline: Diana Taurasi Can Rest Easy, but W.N.B.A. Can’t
abstract: Taurasi’s decision to sit out the 2015 W.N.B.A. season for more pay from her Russian team says much about the state of the pro women’s game in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Diana Taurasi announced recently that she would not play in the W.N.B.A. in 2015, she did not have to explain herself to Sue Bird. After all these years, rest for rubles, Bird knew what Taurasi had earned.

headline: Letting Go With Spins and Swirls
abstract: The choreographer Suzanne Beahrs explores what it means to “be yourself” in “Rise,” her new piece at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: In yoga, the act of letting go is just as important as perfecting a downward dog. It’s a slippery sensation, but you know it when you feel it. A similar quality is found in “Rise,” a new dance by the choreographer Suzanne Beahrs that explores the idea of surrendering to one’s true nature — how, when you strip away the layers, you just might uncover your essence.

headline: A Little ‘Star Wars’ and Pop Energy
abstract: The choreographer Ben Munisteri has re-emerged with a program at the Actors Fund Arts Center in Downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ben Munisteri, an accomplished choreographer with a reputation for formal invention, has been lying low for the past couple of years. On Thursday, he re-emerged with a short, self-produced program at the Actors Fund Arts Center in Downtown Brooklyn. It was a modest showing, less like a butterfly emerging from a chrysalis than like a groundhog peeking out from its burrow.

headline: Beyond a Rink, a World
abstract: “Of Miracles and Men” on ESPN tells the story of the American hockey team’s 1980 Olympic victory over the Soviet Union and the forces of history that surrounded it.
lead_paragraph: “Of Miracles and Men,” Sunday’s installment of ESPN’s “30 for 30” documentary series, is a much deeper, more thoughtful film than a pocket description might lead you to believe.

headline: Finding Balance in Braying, Shattering, Crackling Electronics
abstract: The Tinnitus concert series at the Wick in Brooklyn has most recently included Noveller, Container and Vessel.
lead_paragraph: Tinnitus, a new concert series organized by the editor and writer Brandon Stosuy and the producer Adam Shore, focuses on what it has called “composers of extreme sound.” What’s that mean?

headline: Knee Replacement Device Unapproved, but Used in Surgery
abstract: The maker of the OtisKnee surgical guides started selling them before seeking clearance from the Food and Drug Administration, which later rejected the application.
lead_paragraph: Carla Muss-Jacobs didn’t give much thought to the tools her surgeon would use to replace her knee. Like most patients, she just wanted to feel better and trusted that any devices in the operating room would be safe.

headline: Soldiers in Brian Williams’s Group Give Account of 2003 Helicopter Attack
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The NBC News anchor was nowhere near the helicopter that was hit and crash-landed, they say, suggesting Mr. Williams is obfuscating even in his apology.
lead_paragraph: In the earliest days of the Iraq war, in March 2003, two convoys of helicopters left a base in Kuwait, flying toward Najaf and the front line. One convoy was hit by enemy fire, and the other was not, according to four people present that day.

headline: Boko Haram Widens Fight, Striking Niger
abstract: Boko Haram struck Bosso, a local seat of government in Niger, extending the conflict to a fourth country; an officer from Niger said the attackers had been repelled.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The Islamist terrorist group Boko Haram on Friday morning struck across Nigeria’s border into Niger for the first time, broadening the regional conflict to a fourth country in West Africa.

headline: Chopping Up the Body, Then Walking
abstract: In “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst,” Andrew Jarecki tells the story of a wealthy real estate heir with a strange and violent history.
lead_paragraph: The title of “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst” appears to come from a short exchange in this six-part HBO documentary’s second segment. Mr. Durst, the very rich New York real estate heir with the very strange and violent history, is discussing children — or his lack thereof. “I didn’t want to raise children,” he says. “I — somehow I thought it would be a jinx.”

headline: Change in Management at Petrobras Does Little to Appease Its Investors
abstract: The company has been struggling ever since a police investigation last year revealed that suppliers bribed its executives.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s scandal-ridden petroleum giant, Petrobras, has new management and the markets are not pleased.

headline: Debt: A Thought Experiment
abstract: Not that it will help.
lead_paragraph: I’m getting some outraged/confused responses to my post on debt as money that we owe to ourselves. Many people seem to find it hard to step outside the misleading analogy between an individual and the economy as a whole. If I owe money, that’s a claim on my future. But debt levels in the economy as a whole are not a claim by some outside party on the economy as a whole.

headline: Insider Tips: Best TV Right Now
abstract: The television critic Alessandra Stanley cites some of the best new shows.
lead_paragraph: Best new network drama: “The Slap,” a mini-series on NBC. A little like “The Affair,” on Showtime only it’s a cultural collision, not an extramarital clinch.

headline: Friday Night Music: Rhiannon Giddens
abstract: Wow.
lead_paragraph: No words necessary:

headline: Spank Mixes Artsy Gay Party With Zine
abstract: This roving gay club has grown from underground roots into a multifaceted night life institution with its own zine and blog and museum collaborations.
lead_paragraph: Around 2 a.m. last Sunday at the Bell House in Gowanus, Brooklyn, the barnlike backroom was packed with well-toned gay men dancing to house music when something mildly shocking happened: A seven-foot-long Italian sub was carried in by two bespangled go-go boys and devoured by the crowd in 10 minutes, carbs be damned.

headline: Iowa Gets a Vice Presidential Visit Next Week
abstract: Iowa has been crawling with potential Republican presidential candidates in recent months, but a big name Democrat is heading there next week.
lead_paragraph: Iowa has been crawling with potential Republican presidential candidates in recent months, but a big name Democrat is heading there next week.

headline: Falling Marriage Rates Reveal Economic Fault Lines
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Income Inequality', 'Personal Finances', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Those who are not married — now about half of U.S. households — tend to have less wealth, making the married-unmarried divide one more dimension of America’s growing inequality.
lead_paragraph: Will Valentine’s Day, always a popular moment for popping the question, see fewer marriage proposals this year than in generations past?

headline: Unsure You Need a Measles Shot? Get Vaccinated
abstract: Unsure whether you have had measles, or the vaccine for it? A blood test might help, but it is cheaper, simpler and faster to just get the shot.

abstract: The way men handled the snow and slush on Wednesday spoke volumes about their sartorial habits.
lead_paragraph: The way men handled the snow and slush on Wednesday spoke volumes about their sartorial habits.

headline: In the End, No Matchmaker Need Apply
abstract: Saira Hussain and Assad Akhter started out tentatively, but finally the sparks ignited.
lead_paragraph: At times it seemed as if everyone in Assad Akhter’s universe had but one goal in mind: to find him a suitable wife.

headline: The Best Decade Ever? The 1990s, Obviously
abstract: Nostalgia for that time is more than mere nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: BACK in the late 1980s, when I was a co-editor of Spy magazine, we published a cover story about the 1970s. Spy being Spy, it was a grand feast of love-hate celebration: “A Return to the Decade of Mood Rings, Ultrasuede, Sideburns and Disco Sex-Machine Tony Orlando.” One of its implicit premises was the silliness of the pandemic of American nostalgia, especially for a culturally dubious decade that had ended less than a decade earlier. Over the last half century, we Americans have come to create and consume automatically and continuously a kind of recent-past wistfulness.

headline: A Famed Restaurateur’s Grand Return
abstract: Chris Cannon’s sprawling new venture, Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen, in Morristown, combines four distinct dining experiences in one glamorous mansion.
lead_paragraph: A successful comeback makes for an inspiring, feel-good story. This isn’t a television show or movie we’re talking about — it’s the real-life tale of Chris Cannon and his four month-old contemporary American dining venture in Morristown, Jockey Hollow Bar & Kitchen.

headline: A Raunchy Comedy Club Crawl With Whitney Cummings
abstract: A night out with Ms. Cummings, who went from one comedy club to another in New York recently, with a not-so-tame act.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Whitney Cummings visited New York recently, where she appeared on the “Late Show With David Letterman” and was the guest host for “The Late Late Show.”

headline: Art and the African-American Experience
abstract: Here is a sampling of Long Island events — including exhibitions, lectures, musical performances and films — that commemorate the black experience this month.
lead_paragraph: Those planning to attend the Feb. 8 concert at Hofstra University commemorating Black History Month, be prepared: There will be a vocal “call and response” moment during the otherwise instrumental performance of Imani Winds.

headline: How to Be a Friend in Deed
abstract: What to do when you want to be an old-fashioned friend to someone in need.
lead_paragraph: A single mother of two teenage boys loses her job. Then she loses her car. Then her house. Then she can’t pay her bills. When this happened to Michelle Bergeron a few years ago, it was a slow-motion spiral out of control.

headline: Engineer Helped Passengers Escape Burning Train, Federal Investigator Says
abstract: Steven Smalls helped five or six people clamber out the side doors to safety, he told federal investigators, before the Metro-North train car was incinerated.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — He saw the car pull onto the track. He hit the emergency brake. He saw that a woman was at the wheel, felt the impact as the train he was driving hit the vehicle. As fire tore toward the front of the first car of a crowded commuter train on Tuesday evening, the engineer set to evacuating passengers. He had helped five or six people clamber out the side doors, he told federal investigators, before the smoke overwhelmed him.

headline: Extracting Data from a Dead Tablet
abstract: Exploring alternatives to taking a hammer to that glossy electronic brick.
lead_paragraph: Q. My tablet just died and nothing I’ve tried can revive it. When asked, the I.T. staff at my place noted there may be a risk that if I recycle the device, someone else might be able to either revive it or get personal information off it. Their advice was to work it over with a hammer. While that sounds like fun, are there better and greener alternatives?

headline: Judith Regan Is Back. Watch Out.
abstract: A decade after her well-publicized exit from News Corporation, Judith Regan has a new publishing imprint backed by Leon Black, and is making deals and taking on enemies — both old (Rupert Murdoch) and new (Amazon).
lead_paragraph: In Judith Regan’s corner office on the eighth floor of an office building on Bleecker Street is a picture frame with a quote inside it that reads, “Against the ruin of the world, there is only one defense: The creative act.”

headline: Her Art, Her Passion, Her Torment
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato offered the premiere of Jake Heggie’s “Camille Claudel: Into the Fire,” based on the life of the French sculptor, at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The life of the French sculptor Camille Claudel is a tangle of art, passion, madness and betrayal. A student and lover of Rodin’s, Claudel was a critically acclaimed artist when she began to show signs of mental distress, which led her family to commit her to an institution, where she spent the remaining 30 years of her life.

headline: Geir Helgemo Plays at the Rosenblum Open Teams
abstract: Mr. Helgemo, a Norwegian by birth who plays for Team Monaco, is a bridge player who can think outside the box.
lead_paragraph: There are some bridge players who can, to use a hackneyed term, think outside the box. Geir Helgemo, a Norwegian by birth who plays for Team Monaco, is one of the few — as exhibited by his decision in the diagramed deal.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Evening Hours | Global Celebrations
abstract: Enchanting music, international pride and deserving honorees.
lead_paragraph: Enchanting music, international pride and deserving honorees.

headline: A Rogue by Any Other Name
abstract: Three companies — the Metropolitan Opera, the Canadian Opera Company and the Paris National Opera — offer three interpretations of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni.”
lead_paragraph: Lately, the news has been filled with reports of privileged men, from star athletes to venerated comedians, using their power, in some cases their physical power, to seduce and control women. So, by comparison, the sex-fiend side of the charming Don Giovanni, the title character of Mozart’s most complex opera, can seem not so threatening.

headline: Herzog’s New World: A Woman’s Story
abstract: The Berlin International Film Festival features Werner Herzog’s latest movie, “Queen of the Desert,” a love story about the British historian Gertude Bell.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Werner Herzog has made films about swashbuckling men contending with some of the most extreme environments on earth, from the Amazon to Antarctica. But with “Queen of the Desert,” which made its debut here on Friday at the 65th annual Berlin International Film Festival, the director has ventured into previously uncharted territory for him: a love story starring a woman.

headline: For Two Aloof Neighbors, All the Wrong Moves
abstract: Mark St. Germain’s “Dancing Lessons,” in Hartford, is a blend of comedy, romance and homily on understanding autism.
lead_paragraph: There are New York minutes and New York strip steaks, but the man and woman in “Dancing Lessons” are New York neighbors — that is, they live in the same building two floors apart and have never exchanged a word or a nod.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Men’s Winter Wear
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Men and Boys', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The way men handled the snow and slush on Feb. 4 spoke volumes about their sartorial habits.
lead_paragraph: The way men handled the snow and slush on Wednesday spoke volumes about their sartorial habits. Men who were otherwise conservatively clothed refused to change their dress shoes to storm-appropriate footwear. Meanwhile, men exploring fashion frontiers had a new dare: loafers without socks. For the first time, the Bryant Park fountain’s base froze with mini-icebergs forming in the corners.

headline: 15 Minutes of Fame? More Like 15 Seconds of Nanofame
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Celebrities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: As social media platforms value ever-smaller snippets, Internet fame is shrinking from micro to nano.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you remember Jeremy Meeks, the handsome felon turned Internet sensation.

headline: Fondly Squabbling Harmony. Enter a Movie Star.
abstract: Christopher Durang’s comedy “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike” is at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.
lead_paragraph: It is not essential to know the Russian plays of Anton Chekhov to like the all-American charms of “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” Christopher Durang’s amiable comedy about a wacky weekend spent in Bucks County with three middle-aged siblings and a boy toy.

headline: For New York Fire Department’s 150th Anniversary, a Special Insignia
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: The design includes the isosceles triangles of the new 1 World Trade Center, the twin beams from the annual “Tribute in Light” and the Liberty head logo used by the New York Rangers.
lead_paragraph: The occasion is a celebration of the New York Fire Department’s past, all 150 years of it. But a commemorative patch designed by a veteran firefighter speaks more to the present and the future.

headline: Crossing an Ocean in Attitudes
abstract: In “Texas in Paris,” Lillias White and Scott Wakefield play very different singers on a music tour in France.
lead_paragraph: It always seems slightly superhuman, that luminosity some actors possess. Lillias White had it back in 1997, when she won a Tony Award for playing a middle-aged prostitute in “The Life,” and she is incandescent still as an elderly poet-songstress in Alan Govenar’s “Texas in Paris,” at the York Theater Company.

headline: An Oboist Who Sees Beyond His Own Reeds
abstract: As a performer, conservatory lecturer and sometime programmer, James Austin Smith has emerged as an ambitious young voice on the stages of the State University of New York at Purchase, and in the surrounding community.
lead_paragraph: For an oboist, James Austin Smith can deliver a punch line. That much became clear last month when Mr. Smith, a slim, smiling figure, found himself onstage at the Tenri Cultural Institute in Greenwich Village during a party for the release of his latest CD, “Distance,” where he recalled with feigned horror the conservative teachers who had been mortified at his youthful predilection for modern music.

headline: Highlights of the Sharjah Biennial
abstract: A look at some of the artists and exhibits featured.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the artists and exhibits featured.

abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay that was skeptical about the benefits.

headline: Rep. Nadler to Music Industry: Get It Together on Copyright Issues
abstract: Representative Jerrold Nadler, a New York Democrat, spoke at a Grammy-related lunch for lawyers and executives about the challenges facing music interests in Washington.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The events leading up to the Grammy Awards have plenty of glamour and glitz. But there are also industry gatherings over important but decidedly unglamorous topics like online royalty rates and legislation.

headline: Iraq After ISIS: Is a Civil War on the Horizon?
abstract: Readers, including the historian Joseph J. Ellis, respond to an Op-Ed article.

headline: What Anthem Customers Should Do Next After Data Breach
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Identity Theft', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Consumers can take steps to protect themselves and their medical information after a hacking attack like that on Anthem Health.
lead_paragraph: Consumers’ first worry in a major security breach is usually about their financial and credit accounts. But cyberthieves can do some serious damage with medical information as well.

headline: Nursing Home Payments
abstract: Scott P. LaRue, the president of ArchCare, the health system of the Archdiocese of New York, discusses how nursing homes collect debts owed by patients..
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Stylish Setting for Thai Classics
abstract: First-time restaurateurs opened Krung Tep Thai Bistro in a storefront in Great Neck in November.
lead_paragraph: Describing a restaurant as a “storefront” can sometimes be misleading; it can suggest anything from an order-at-the-counter spot to an elegant, white tablecloth affair. Krung Tep Thai Bistro, a typical-looking storefront that opened near the train station in Great Neck in November, falls somewhere in the middle.

headline: Tips That Are Over the Top
abstract: An economics professor says customers should calculate tips themselves, rather than be swayed by suggested high rates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guardrail System Passes First Tests, U.S. Agency Says
abstract: The agency said that the tests would not be the end of its work to determine whether the roadside devices are safe.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials said on Friday that the first tests of a guardrail system, banned by more than 30 states after safety concerns were raised, had met the tests’ criteria.

headline: Asbestos Lawsuits
abstract: A trial lawyers organization says that asbestos continues to endanger the public’s health and that its makers should be held accountable.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Former Siemens Executive Dies; Cause Appears to Be Suicide
abstract: Heinz-Joachim Neubürger, 62, joined Siemens in 1989 and recently settled a lawsuit filed against him by the company related to a bribery case.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A former chief financial officer of Siemens died this week, apparently by suicide, only days after settling a long-running legal dispute stemming from a bribery scandal in 2006.

headline: Space Age Relic Enters Astronomical Real Estate Market
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The redevelopment of a former NASA building is providing a window into the high-stakes real estate of Kendall Square in Cambridge, Mass., one of the most valuable markets in the country.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When President John F. Kennedy wanted his home state to benefit from the emerging space program in the early 1960s, it was simple enough: He put an item in the federal budget, and in short order, NASA built an Electronics Research Center near M.I.T. in Cambridge’s Kendall Square.

headline: Report Finds No Evidence of Abuse at Immigration Center in Texas
abstract: Accusations of widespread sexual misconduct by guards were lodged at a center for women and children who were caught crossing the Southwest border illegally.
lead_paragraph: After investigating complaints of widespread sexual misconduct by guards in an immigration detention center in Texas for women and children, the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security found no evidence of abuse, according to a report published Friday.

headline: A Greek Spot Where Salads Reign
abstract: A small Greek restaurant with an outsize menu, Petra, in Scarsdale, offers Mediterranean comfort foods besides those fresh, colorful salads.
lead_paragraph: On a Scarsdale street packed with Asian restaurants, Petra fills a need for an informal spot that offers both small and large plates and good strong coffee at modest prices. At the moment, however, the place has a few problems.

headline: Egyptian Gets 25-Year Term in 1998 Embassy Bombings; Judge Calls Plea Deal Generous
abstract: Adel Abdul Bary, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to kill Americans, received “an enormously generous plea bargain,” a federal judge in Manhattan said.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian man who admitted to helping Osama bin Laden issue threats and make claims of responsibility for terrorist bombings was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Friday, a result of a deal that the judge said was generous.

headline: On Campus, Obama Makes Case for Plans Including Free Community College
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Community Colleges', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The president said voters should keep pressure on members of Congress to reach across party lines and ensure initiatives in his budget are enacted.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — President Obama on Friday pressed voters to demand that their representatives reach across the political aisle to pass initiatives in his budget including free community college, more generous child care subsidies and new roads and bridges, making the case for his agenda in a heavily Republican state.

headline: Strains Grow Between Israel and Many Jews in the U.S.
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: As Israel becomes more stringent on religious issues, including marriage, it risks alienating American Jews, who lean liberal on most social and economic issues.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, an uncharacteristic rift has opened between the United States and Israel, provoked by the announcement that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will address Congress in March at the invitation of House Republicans. His speech, contrary to diplomatic custom, was planned without notifying the White House and the president, who happens to be a Democrat.

headline: In Defense of Annual School Testing
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'No Child Left Behind Act']
abstract: Without yearly assessments, students fall through the cracks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DURING a recent hearing by the Senate Education Committee, its Republican chair, Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, questioned whether the federal government’s annual standardized testing requirement, embodied in the No Child Left Behind law of 2001, may be too much. He pointed out that students now spend 1 to 3 percent of their school year taking federal, state and local tests in reading and math.

headline: Sochi, Russia, a Year After the Games
abstract: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.
lead_paragraph: Common to the postscript of every Olympics, and especially the very expensive Games in Sochi, Russia, is the difficult task of moving beyond past glories and recouping the investment.

headline: Houthis Dissolve Parliament in Yemen
abstract: A member of the Houthi group that recently took power in Yemen announced on Yemeni television the dissolution of Parliament and the creation of an interim assembly.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Houthi group that recently took power in Yemen announced on Yemeni television the dissolution of Parliament and the creation of an interim assembly.

headline: Beyond the Burrito
abstract: Valencia Luncheria, in Norwalk, offers, among other items, wraps, empanadas and 30 different kinds of arepas.
lead_paragraph: When Valencia Luncheria moved from its modest storefront location on Main Street in Norwalk to a stand-alone building a block away, out went the paper plates and plastic cutlery and in came the conventional dishes and silverware.

headline: China Opposes Dalai Lama’s Foreign Visit
abstract: A spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Hong Lei, condemned any country that allowed the Dalai Lama to visit or that used the Tibet issue “to interfere in China’s domestic affairs.”
lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, Hong Lei, condemned any country that allowed the Dalai Lama to visit or that used the Tibet issue “to interfere in China’s domestic affairs.”

headline: Is the Professor Bossy or Brilliant? Much Depends on Gender
abstract: An interactive chart of words taken from millions of student reviews of their instructors offers a vivid illustration of unconscious gender bias.
lead_paragraph: Male professors are brilliant, awesome and knowledgeable. Women are bossy and annoying, and beautiful or ugly.

headline: The Labor Picture in January
abstract: The unemployment rate edged higher to 5.7% from 5.6%, but the U.S. economy added a better-than-expected 257,000 jobs in January, according to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate edged higher to 5.7% from 5.6%, but the U.S. economy added a better-than-expected 257,000 jobs in January, according to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Thriving After a Ban, Notre Dame’s Jerian Grant Impresses a Hall of Famer
abstract: Grant, whose previous season at Notre Dame ended in an academic-related suspension, has returned to average 17.3 points and 6.4 assists a game, drawing praise from Adrian Dantley.
lead_paragraph: At his home in Maryland, Adrian Dantley was a proud alumnus as he watched the Notre Dame men’s basketball team overcome a 10-point second-half deficit to defeat Duke last week. The victory continued the Fighting Irish’s improbable success this season, made the senior guard Jerian Grant a national player of the year candidate and brought back memories of when Dantley starred for Notre Dame four decades ago.

headline: Obama, Trying to Add Context to Speech, Faces Backlash Over ‘Crusades’
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Crusades (Christianity)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When he mentioned the Crusades in condemning Islamic terrorists this week, the president ignited a firestorm on television and social media about the validity of his observations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama personally added a reference to the Crusades in his speech this week at the National Prayer Breakfast, aides said, hoping to add context and nuance to his condemnation of Islamic terrorists by noting that people also “committed terrible deeds in the name of Christ.”

headline: U.N. Prepares Resolution to Confront Islamic State on Oil and Antiquities
abstract: The Security Council resolution, which could be adopted next week, is intended to choke the terrorist group’s ability to trade in oil, antiquities and hostages.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In a show of unity by the world powers against the Islamic State, the United Nations Security Council is preparing to adopt a legally binding resolution intended to choke the terrorist group’s ability to trade in oil, antiquities and hostages.

headline: Can the Church Return to the Faithful?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Out of my 25 new Catholic cousins, only one is still practicing.
lead_paragraph: I ONCE had a friend with a boomerang. One day we took it to the Jersey Shore and I watched as he whupped it around. It was beautiful: the young man and the boomerang, the bright sun and the water. Then, late in the day, he tossed it out over the ocean, and the boomerang didn’t come back. For a while we stood together, looking out, wondering whether we might just have lost sight of it. We glanced around nervously, on the off chance that it might yet clock us on the head, returning from a direction we had not anticipated.

headline: A Walk Through the Gallery

lead_paragraph: This is the last weekend of an exhibition of Henri Matisse’s painted-paper works in New York. Can’t make it? Explore the art in this wall-to-wall experience.

lead_paragraph: After an online attack on Anthem, by far the largest breach in the industry, security experts warned on Friday that more attacks on health care organizations were likely because of the high value of the data on the black market.

abstract: It’s been a long time since a prince toppled a prime minister, but this is what could happen in Australia.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A record number of packages that were delivered over the Christmas holidays and an increase in prices for other products helped the Postal Service’s operating revenues rise by 4.3 percent for the first quarter, which ended Dec. 31, the agency reported on Friday.

headline: Shivering, Hungry and Tearful in Rebel-Held Eastern Ukraine
abstract: A new separatist offensive and the government’s push to isolate the region are intensifying problems as the fiercest winter weeks arrive on the Ukrainian steppe.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Nikita, who has been living for several months with his mother and 1-year-old sister in a basement labyrinth of makeshift tents and rubber-bucket lavatories, explained why he cannot return to his toy-filled apartment.

headline: Don Covay, Performer and Writer of R&B Hits, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Covay wrote soul standards for his own use, but other musicians did even better with them, including Chubby Checker with “Pony Time” and Aretha Franklin with “Chain of Fools.”
lead_paragraph: Don Covay, a singer and songwriter whose rhythm-and-blues compositions — among them “Pony Time,” “Chain of Fools” and “Mercy, Mercy” — became hits for a variety of performers and standards of rock ’n’ roll and soul music, died on Jan. 31 in a hospital in Valley Stream, N.Y., not far from his home in Queens. He was 78.

headline: Politics by Restaurant Review
abstract: The first entry in the 2016 presidential primary book club comes from Mike Huckabee. We read it so you don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: Today, we’re going to talk about “God, Guns, Grits and Gravy,” Mike Huckabee’s entry into the presidential book-writing sweepstakes. These tomes are going to be piling up soon, and remember: We read them so you don’t have to.

headline: Lizabeth Scott, Film Noir Siren, Dies at 92
abstract: In films like “Dead Reckoning” and “Too Late for Tears,” Ms. Scott played unsympathetic yet seductive schemers convincingly.
lead_paragraph: Lizabeth Scott, a sultry blonde with a come-hither voice cut out for the seething romantic and homicidal passions of her Hollywood film noir roles in the late 1940s and early ’50s, died on Jan. 31 in Los Angeles. She was 92.

headline: The Transition of Bruce Jenner: A Shock to Some, Visible to All
abstract: Though Jenner, a 1976 Olympic gold medalist, has not confirmed it, he is widely reported to be in the midst of making a transition from male to female.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Jenner has been an Olympic superstar, the hunk on the Wheaties box, a Playgirl cover boy, the author of inspirational sports books and a sometime actor and celebrity game-show contestant. In recent years, he has also been an ancillary but vivid participant in the bizarre public spectacle that is the Kardashian family.

headline: Can New York Be Affordable Again?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Editorials', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Gentrification']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s mission to create housing for all, including working- and middle-class families, is timely and exciting.
lead_paragraph: The New York of the 1950s and early ’60s, for all its grime and problems, was far more hospitable than today’s city to working-class and middle-class families, full of stable and affordable neighborhoods where they could live and strive.

headline: 2 Troubled Brothers Are Reunited, Then Torn Apart by an Errant Bullet
abstract: Shane Van Williams is accused of fatally shooting Rendell Cassimy and his brother Sean with the same bullet, nine days after Shane was released from prison.
lead_paragraph: Shane Van Williams was born in 1991; his brother Sean followed three years later, with a second brother born in between. They were the sons of a no-nonsense correction officer named Roger Van Williams, who worked in state prisons.

abstract: Citing overseas travel plans, Vice President Biden will not be in Washington next month for the Israeli prime minister’s address, adding to the tension between the two administrations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced on Friday that he would not attend the speech to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel next month, further escalating a diplomatic flap that has already soured relations between the Obama administration and one of America’s closest allies.

abstract: An investigation in New York holds a message for consumers and legislators countrywide.
lead_paragraph: An investigation of herbal supplements by the New York State attorney general’s office carries a sobering message for the rest of the nation as well.

headline: Top Aide Leaps to Defense of Obama Security Stance
abstract: As President Obama officially rolled out a new national security strategy, Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, denounced “alarmism” over various international crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama officially rolled out a new national security strategy for his final two years in office, his top foreign policy aide on Friday denounced “alarmism” over various international crises, saying the challenges now facing the United States are nothing like those presented in the past by Nazi Germany or the Soviet Union.

headline: Dustin Johnson Falls Short in a Return After a Mysterious Hiatus
abstract: Johnson and the PGA provided no explanation for his six-month disappearance from the tour. In his return, Johnson missed the cut at Torrey Pines.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — If the six-month gap in Dustin Johnson’s golf career were any more mysterious, Rose Mary Woods would be summoned from the afterlife to explain it. In his first competitive start in six months, Johnson missed a birdie putt on his last hole Friday that would have put him above the cut line at the Farmers Insurance Open.

headline: Bubonic Plague in the Subway System? Don’t Worry About It
abstract: New York health officials contested a finding by researchers who said they had discovered in stations evidence of the deadly disease that ravaged 14th-century Europe.
lead_paragraph: No human being has caught it in New York City for at least a century, but still, there it was, researchers said, in places touched by hundreds, maybe thousands, of people every day.

headline: Mexico: State Officials Find 60 Bodies Inside an Abandoned Crematorium
abstract: The bodies of 60 men, women and children have been found piled in an abandoned crematorium in Acapulco, the authorities in Guerrero State said Friday.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of 60 men, women and children have been found piled in an abandoned crematorium in Acapulco, the authorities in Guerrero State said Friday, but they appeared to have been prepared for cremation and then left behind rather than dumped there by drug gangs. “It is another kind of crime,” said Osbaldo Berber, an adviser to the state prosecutor. The crematorium, Cremaciones Pacífico, above, had been closed for a year, and the bodies, which were found Thursday night, had been embalmed and doused with quicklime to cover the scent of decomposition, officials said. Investigators are gathering local funeral home records to determine the identities of the bodies, the prosecutor’s office said, and are considering charges of improper burial and abuse of a corpse. The owner of the crematorium, Guillermo Estua Zerdain, is missing, officials said. With no sign of organized crime, the discovery of the corpses appears to be unconnected to the case of 43 missing college students believed to have been rounded up by corrupt police officers and turned over to a drug gang in Guerrero in September.

headline: Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The F.C.C. finally made the right decision on how to regulate the Internet.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, President Obama nominated Julius Genachowski, a trusted friend who had acted as candidate Obama’s technology adviser, to be the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. They both firmly believed in the importance of “net neutrality,” in which Internet service providers, or I.S.P.s, would not be able to give one website an advantage over another, or allow companies to pay to get into a “fast lane” ahead of competitors. That was the surest way to allow innovation to flourish, they believed.

headline: United Arab Emirates, Key Ally in U.S. Fight Against ISIS, to Rejoin Air Campaign
abstract: The Mideast nation had suspended airstrikes because it was worried about the safety of its pilots.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The United Arab Emirates has informed the United States that it plans to resume its participation in the American-led airstrikes against the Islamic State group, a senior State Department official said Friday.

headline: Venezuela: Grocery Chain to Be Seized
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro on Friday ordered the government takeover of a supermarket chain that officials have accused of hoarding products as part of an “economic war” against his government.
lead_paragraph: Ratcheting up a conflict with retailers of basic goods, President Nicolás Maduro on Friday ordered the government takeover of a supermarket chain that officials have accused of hoarding products as part of an “economic war” against his government. Mr. Maduro did not name the company, which he said had 35 medium-size stores in seven states, but it was clear that he was referring to the Día a Día chain. The stores are generally located in lower-middle-class or poor neighborhoods. Promising to use an “iron fist” in tackling economic problems, Mr. Maduro said the chain, which had a warehouse full of cooking oil and other items, was “making war on the people” and would be taken over by a government supermarket network known as Pdval. Venezuela has been hit hard by the drop in the price of oil, its only major export, and shortages and long lines at stores are common. Also on Friday, the government filed criminal charges against a manager of the supermarket chain, accusing him of destabilizing the economy. It filed similar charges this week against two executives of the country’s largest pharmacy chain, Farmatodo.

headline: Providers of Housewarmings
abstract: Gird your loins. Byron Walden is back, and on a Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It seems kind of weird to be grateful for cheesy Madonna movies, but today that’s what got me my toehold in Byron Walden’s twisty Saturday puzzle. So, just for today, I am grateful for cheesy Madonna movies.

lead_paragraph: For the singer Anita Darian, getting to Carnegie Hall not only took practice; it also took a kazoo.

lead_paragraph: When Skye Rothstein gazes out her window, she is reminded of winter’s chill and the long, dark nights.

headline: Aaron Schock, a Lawmaker Used to Attention, Draws a Little More Than He Wanted
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Aaron Schock’s congressional office, racially charged comments by an aide and a real estate transaction put him in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aaron Schock was 27 years old, a fresh-faced and ambitious Republican from Peoria, Ill., when he joined Congress in January 2009. Today, Representative Schock has earned a reputation — not for legislating, but for his ripped ab muscles, shirtless poses, racy Instagram account and, now, a Capitol Hill office decorated like a drawing room from “Downton Abbey.”

lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge have issued subpoenas that appear to focus on allegations that the former chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pushed an airline to reinstate the flights he used to travel to and from his weekend home.

headline: In Patz Case, 2 More Testify to Defendant’s Confession in 1979
abstract: Pedro Hernandez, who is accused of murdering 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979, broke down during a religious retreat that year and confessed to killing a child, witnesses at his trial said.
lead_paragraph: It was the last thing any of the men in the prayer circle were expecting to hear. They had gathered on a New Jersey farm for a religious retreat in the summer of 1979, all working-class Puerto Ricans from Camden, all seeking spiritual solace.

lead_paragraph: More than a quarter of schools in California have measles-immunization rates for kindergarteners that are below the standard the C.D.C. says is needed to maintain so-called herd immunity.

headline: In an Ocean of Cynicism, Sturdy Faith
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: In “Believer: My Forty Years in Politics,” David Axelrod, who guided Barack Obama to the presidency, still thinks his former boss is a winner.
lead_paragraph: The three dominant characters in this political memoir by David Axelrod, one of the Democratic Party’s best-known strategists, are Mr. Axelrod, his once-in-a-lifetime client Barack Obama and belief. Mr. Axelrod believes “in politics as a calling; in campaigns as an opportunity to forge the future we imagine; in government as an instrument for that progress.” Though he does not expound on this theology, it is manifest in his unswerving fidelity to the president.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance in Paris (“Before Sunset”) that began nine years before that in Vienna (“Before Sunrise”), Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke) are in Greece, at the end of a vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and Hank (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick), the son Jesse left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with Hank. Celine sees his question as a demand. And so they will fight about this — and the meaning of love, the nature of time and the difference between men and women — throughout the course of a day. “ ‘Before Sunrise,’ ‘Before Sunset’ and ‘Before Midnight’ are modest, charming movies that together add up to the great romantic epic of a generation defined, in the popular mind and our therapists’ offices, by hedged bets, easy ironies and perpetual confusion,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. This final installment, he added, “is a wonderful paradox: a movie passionately committed to the ideal of imperfection that is itself very close to perfect.” “Before Sunset” will be shown at 8:40 a.m. on HBO2.

headline: Western Nations Split on Arming Kiev Forces
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']

lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Differences within the Western alliance over whether to send defensive arms to Ukraine were thrust into the open on Saturday when Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, bluntly opposed providing lethal military support to Kiev and called instead for continued efforts to persuade Russia and separatist forces to cease fire.

headline: Curfew’s End Brings Hope and Fear to Baghdad
abstract: Hours before the government planned to lift a nighttime curfew, explosions ripped through three neighborhoods in the capital.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As the curfew expired on Sunday, one famed Iraqi musician celebrated by playing his cello for bystanders in the street. Elsewhere, dozens of men, too young to remember life before the nighttime restrictions, jumped into their cars and toured the city in a roaring convoy, suddenly freed.

headline: Are C.E.O.s That Talented, or Just Lucky?
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Using the so-called Jed Clampett defense, Harold Hamm tried to persuade a judge he was less the astute businessman than the blessed beneficiary of surging oil prices.
lead_paragraph: The divorce of the oil billionaire Harold G. Hamm from Sue Ann Arnall has gained attention largely for its outsize dollar amounts. Mr. Hamm, the chief executive and founder of Continental Resources, who was worth more than $18 billion at one point, wrote his ex-wife a check last month for $974,790,317.77 to settle their split. She’s appealing to get more; he’s appealing to pay less.

headline: The Near Death, and Revival, of Monticello
abstract: Monticello’s uncertain fate after Jefferson’s death illustrates some of the dangers of leaving a national treasure to the vagaries of the private real estate marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Jefferson designed his beloved Monticello (“little mountain” in Italian) as an expression of his political and aesthetic values. And yet, 50 years after Jefferson died in 1826, his shrine to American democracy in Charlottesville, Va., was enmeshed in weeds, with the main house in danger of collapse.

headline: The Shrinking American Labor Union
abstract: While labor union participation in the public sector has held relatively steady in the last three decades, it has fallen significantly in the private sector, for a number of reasons.
lead_paragraph: 24.2%: private sector union membership rate, 1973

headline: London Theater Journal: Crawling Inside a Family Saga and a Jacobean Noir
abstract: “Three Winters,” a time-traveling tale about a Croatian family, and “The Changeling,” a revenge tragedy performed in candlelight, are expressly theatrical endeavors, fully realized here.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Certain plays allow you to crawl inside them in the way that good books do. You come to inhabit such productions so completely that when they end you experience that glazed resentment that arrives when you have to put down a novel that’s consumed you for the length of a plane or train ride.

headline: André Brink, South African Literary Lion, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Brink’s work was often cited alongside that of Nadine Gordimer and J.M. Coetzee as an exemplar of South Africa’s ability to transform the experience of harsh racial politics into literature with a global reach.
lead_paragraph: André Brink, a towering South African literary presence for decades whose work in English and Afrikaans fell afoul of apartheid-era censors, died Friday, South African news reports said, citing his publisher, N.B. Publishers. He was 79.

headline: A Summary: The Hidden Money Buying Condos at the Time Warner Center
abstract: An influx of global cash, much of it anonymously held, is helping to drive the growth in luxury real estate sales, a New York Times investigation has found.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, The New York Times examined the influx of global cash fueling the city’s high-end real estate boom. The investigation pierced the secrecy of more than 200 shell companies that have owned condominiums at one complex, the Time Warner Center. Spurred in part by a series of stories by The Times, the de Blasio administration imposed new disclosure requirements on shell companies buying or selling property in New York City.

headline: Stream of Foreign Wealth Flows to Elite New York Real Estate
abstract: Shell companies are used to shield the identities of buyers in the competition to secure condos at the Time Warner Center and other high-end buildings. This is the first installment in a five-part series.
lead_paragraph: On the 74th floor of the Time Warner Center, Condominium 74B was purchased in 2010 for $15.65 million by a secretive entity called 25CC ST74B L.L.C. It traces to the family of Vitaly Malkin, a former Russian senator and banker who was barred from entering Canada because of suspected connections to organized crime.
