headline: Trouble, on Field and Off, for Mighty U.S. Before Women’s World Cup
abstract: During the past nine months, the United States players have navigated a coaching change, a failed lawsuit over the use of artificial turf at the World Cup, and troublesome injuries to key players.
lead_paragraph: QUIBERON, France — The slow buildup to this summer’s Women’s World Cup has not featured the same level of competitive worry for the United States national team as it did for the men’s team in 2014. The women’s team qualified easily for its tournament, which begins in Canada in June, and will enter the field as one of the clear favorites to win the trophy.

headline: Paul Ryan Finds New, Unlikely Role as Gatekeeper of Obama’s Agenda
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s committee is at the junction where the White House and Republican agendas overlap — trade, taxes and possibly health care.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin has been many things in his political career: Republican vice-presidential candidate, uncompromising budget hawk, conservative policy maven and, for Democrats, the breathing symbol of draconian fiscal policies.

headline: Saudis Unswayed by Houthi Rebels’ Overture in Yemen
abstract: Rebel leaders announced on Saturday that they had appointed four key ministers from the Yemeni government they had overthrown, but Saudi Arabia and its allies denounced the plan.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Leaders of the Houthi rebels announced on Saturday that they had appointed four key ministers from the recently ousted government to a national security committee, part of their efforts to begin building institutions to replace those disbanded by their effective coup.

headline: After Geno Auriemma’s Reign, UConn Could Lose Clout
abstract: The presence of Auriemma may compensate for now, but eventually Connecticut’s lack of affiliation with a Power 5 football conference could spell an end to the Huskies’ dominance.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina travels to Connecticut on Monday night for a meeting of the top two N.C.A.A. women’s basketball teams. The matchup will tell us something about the present and raise a thorny question about the future.

headline: Ohio State Freshman Has Fun, and Seizes the National Stage
abstract: The Buckeyes’ D’Angelo Russell has been one of the most electrifying players in college basketball, Ohio State’s go-to option late in games since the start of the season.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Russell said he lost track of time Friday sitting at a computer in his Louisville home, captivated by a YouTube highlight reel of his son.

headline: 1896: A Call for Reader Submissions
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Readers describe their holidays in popular spa locations in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Long before social media called 0ut for contributions, The New York Herald ran a contest in 1896 asking its readers to report on their holidays in famous “watering places” in Europe. “The letters should be full of news and gossip of interest to the HERALD readers” the paper wrote, a requirement that a reader with the pen name “Causeur” took very seriously. He won 1,000 francs for the following account of life in Ostende, Belgium.

headline: In a Game of Honor, a Cry for a Fair Share
abstract: The lawsuit against the PGA Tour with more than 80 plaintiffs spotlights the question of whether golf is more a business or a game of sportsmanship and honor.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In the 1969 Ryder Cup, Jack Nicklaus took a strong hand and, through the alchemy of grace, turned it into golf’s trump card. On the 18th hole, Nicklaus conceded Tony Jacklin’s 2-foot par putt to halve the final match and create the first tie in the event’s history.

headline: Differential Recovery and the Dollar (Wonking Continues)
abstract: Does America have a Europe problem?
lead_paragraph: Rereading my post on the dollar and the recovery, I realize that it’s probably a very difficult read even for professionals; a bit too much writing down my own thought processes. So can I make my basic point using an off-the-shelf standard model, with only minor tweaking?

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
keywords: ['Measles', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Escalating violence between Jordan and the Islamic State will drive the conversation on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: The Jordanian military bombed Islamic State targets this week after the terrorist group released a video showing a captured Jordanian pilot being burned to death. On Friday, the Islamic State said the Jordanian attacks had killed an American hostage, the aid worker Kayla Mueller.

headline: Anchors Aweigh
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Did Brian Williams embellish to be seen as Indiana Jones, part scholar and part adventurer?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THIS was a bomb that had been ticking for a while.

headline: Sandy McGill
abstract: BMW’s color guru on watching documentaries and listening to her mother.
lead_paragraph: Sandy McGill is the lead designer in the color and materials area of the BMW Group’s DesignWorksUSA studio, which determines not only how the company’s cars look but also the appearance and feel of products in a range of other industries, including aviation, marine and telecommunications.

headline: The Futility of Vengeance
abstract: Why are some people bent on avenging every perceived wrong?
lead_paragraph: LAST month an Australian entrepreneur created a service that allows you to send your enemies an envelope full of glitter. When opened, bits of sparkly spite will fall out and stick — as glitter and grudges do. A rush of customers crashed the company’s website within 24 hours. The owner then made a tidy profit, selling the days-old business for $85,000.

headline: Ageism in Our Society
abstract: Readers respond to a letter decrying the ageism and stereotyping that affect how older people are perceived and treated.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a letter decrying the ageism and stereotyping that affect how older people are perceived and treated.

headline: Confusion About College Sexual Assault
abstract: When the Department of Education audits universities, reports of sex crimes rise dramatically. More transparency would be useful.
lead_paragraph: The exact size of the campus sexual assault problem remains unclear. The commonly cited statistic that one in five women who attend college is assaulted before she graduates — repeated by the White House — comes from a flawed 2007 study based on undergraduates at just two unnamed public universities. That figure often shocks, yet there is no reliable alternative estimate. Under the federal Clery Act universities are required to publish data on campus crime, but activists have long suspected that administrators underreport sex crimes.

headline: Medicine Just for You
abstract: President Obama is right to push a personalized approach to health care forward, though high costs remain a concern.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s new budget contains a farsighted proposal that could ultimately transform the practice of American medicine. The proposal seeks to design treatments for the individual, which are sometimes called “personalized medicine” or “precision medicine” to distinguish them from the one-size-tries-to-fit-all approach.

headline: Do Gays Unsettle You?
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: I want to hold his hand. And that’s still a loaded gesture.
lead_paragraph: WHAT an altered world we live in. What an advanced one. The man I love and I can be married in New York or 35 other states if we ever get organized enough, if we decide that we want public vows and a gaudy cake — I’m thinking devil’s food, for a host of reasons — to seal our commitment.

headline: Good Lovers Lie
abstract: In relationships, the truth matters less than we think.
lead_paragraph: VALENTINE’S DAY is not a celebration of truth telling. God forbid! Relationships last only if we don’t always say exactly what we’re thinking. We have to disguise our feelings, to feint, to smile sometimes when we want to shout. In short, we have to lie.

headline: Another Outbreak of ‘False Balance’?
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Measles', 'Autism', 'News and News Media']
abstract: To avoid “he-said, she-said” vaccine coverage, it’s important to clearly state the settled science.
lead_paragraph: ON the list of journalistic subjects that New York Times readers care about most, false balance is surely in the top 10. It may even be in the top three, right after fairness and accuracy.

headline: The Pentagon’s Excess Space
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Lawmakers have been putting their political interests ahead of good stewardship of public money.
lead_paragraph: For the past three years, officials at the Pentagon have asked Congress for permission to take stock of how many of the military’s vast network of installations across the country have become obsolete and ought to be shrunk or shuttered. The Defense Department, by far the nation’s largest and costliest bureaucracy, estimates that it could operate far more efficiently and save billions of dollars each year by shedding at least 20 percent of its real estate.

headline: The Best Way to Address Campus Rape
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Colleges have to resist misguided federal policies. The solution is to work with the local police.
lead_paragraph: THE campus rape debate took another hairpin turn last week when The Daily Beast published an interview with Paul Nungesser, the Columbia student accused of raping a fellow student, Emma Sulkowicz. She has been carrying a mattress around the campus to raise awareness about sexual assault and to protest the school’s failure to expel Mr. Nungesser, who was cleared by a campus tribunal.

headline: Obama the Theologian
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The president’s focus on past sins has diminishing returns in the present.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA, like many well-read inhabitants of public life, is a professed admirer of Reinhold Niebuhr, the famous mid-20th-century Protestant theologian. And more than most presidents, he has tried to incorporate one of Niebuhr’s insights into his public rhetoric: the idea that no society is innocent, and that Americans in particular need to put aside illusions about our own alleged perfection.

headline: The Dangers of Vaccine Denial
abstract: Getting vaccinated is not a “personal choice.” It’s a public health duty and civic obligation.
lead_paragraph: IN a few backward parts of the world, extremists resist universal childhood vaccinations. The Taliban in tribal areas of Pakistan. Boko Haram militants in Northern Nigeria.

headline: When ‘Doing Everything’ Is Way Too Much
abstract: He could never have imagined that we could keep his body going even while it was trying its hardest to die.
lead_paragraph: In trying to honor Vincent’s autonomy, we abandoned him in hell. A decade ago, as a doctor in the intensive care unit at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, I met Vincent — I’m using this name to protect his privacy — on his ninth stay of the year. He was a “frequent flier,” back and forth between the I.C.U. and his nursing home down the street. He would come in dying, we’d plug him into life support, treat his infection, pump up his blood pressure and send him back to the nursing home. But then he’d deflate like an old tire and be rolled back in by paramedics within anywhere from three days to three weeks.

headline: The Fraud Years
abstract: Not a normal time.
lead_paragraph: As the Bush II administration fades in the rear view mirror, there’s a tendency — indeed, an avid desire on the part of many people in the media — to blur the reality of what happened, to make it seem as if were just an ordinary time when a Republican happened to be president.

headline: Surviving the Nazis, Only to Be Jailed by America
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Prisoners of War', 'Concentration Camps', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: “Displaced persons” were still behind barbed wire and under armed guard.
lead_paragraph: WORLD leaders gathered at Auschwitz last month to mark the liberation 70 years earlier of the Nazis’ most infamous concentration camp. More ceremonies will follow in coming months to remember the Allied forces’ discovery, in rapid succession, of other Nazi concentration camps at places like Bergen-Belsen that winter and spring of 1945.

headline: How to Be Invisible
abstract: Stop demanding attention. Be like the arctic fox.
lead_paragraph: IN one of the most popular ads shown during the Super Bowl last weekend, the Indian-American actress Mindy Kaling thinks she’s become invisible. Cabs pass her by, and men barely look up on the sidewalk. And yet she embraces her invisibility as a kind of liberation. More of us should do the same.

headline: Ancient Savagery, and How It Worked
abstract: As blood sports go, the Super Bowl has nothing on the Colosseum and its events.
lead_paragraph: As blood sports go, the Super Bowl has nothing on the Colosseum and its events. Built near Nero’s onetime pleasure palace by the emperor Vespasian as a symbol of Roman military might, the amphitheater (capacity: 50,000 or so) boasted gladiators, wild beasts, crucifixions and elaborately staged Greek myths that often didn’t end well for the performers, as when criminals were catapulted above the arena to recreate Icarus’s flight toward the sun. The pièce de résistance might be a mock sea battle, the better for mass drownings, in which the amphitheater would be flooded in the morning and drained in time for the afternoon mayhem. But how, exactly, was all this achieved? With a labyrinthine system of underground pulleys, lifts and trap doors to rival the most elaborate Broadway show, says Heinz-Jürgen Beste of the German Archaeological Institute in Rome. In “Colosseum: Roman Death Trap,” the first installment of “Building Wonders” on “Nova,” Wednesdays on PBS, Mr. Beste proves his point, recreating an ancient lifting machine to release a wolf into the arena. (Check local listings.)

headline: From ‘Iphigénie’ To Modern Morsels
abstract: Gluck’s operas don’t get enough hearings, but the Juilliard School has done well by him in its collaborations with the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Gluck’s operas don’t get enough hearings, but the Juilliard School has done well by him in its collaborations with the Metropolitan Opera. The early-music specialist Jane Glover conducted a Met-Juilliard “Armide” in 2012, and she returns with semi-staged performances of “Iphigénie en Aulide” on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. The cast includes Yunpeng Wang, Liv Redpath, Ying Fang, Andrew Stenson, Takaoki Onishi and Brandon Cedel. (8 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday, and 2 p.m. Saturday, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Lincoln Center, 212-769-7406, juilliard.edu.) On Monday, the brilliant keyboard performer Richard Egarr plays Bach and Handel at Carnegie Hall. (7:30 p.m., Weill Recital Hall, carnegiehall.org.) The same night, the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series offers new music from Israel jointly presented by the 92nd Street Y, including chamber pieces by Josef Bardanashvili, Avner Dorman, Yotam Haber and Shulamit Ran. (7:30 p.m., SubCulture, 45 Bleecker Street, near Lafayette Street, East Village; 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

headline: Weeklong Tribute to a Genre Juggler
abstract: John Boorman, now in his 80s, may not be the most prolific director in movie history, but he has certainly shown versatility.
lead_paragraph: John Boorman, now in his 80s, may not be the most prolific director in movie history, but he has certainly shown versatility, with a résumé that includes the crime drama “Point Blank,” the fantasy “Excalibur” and the lighthearted “Hope and Glory.” Film Forum begins a weeklong tribute to him on Wednesday that includes screenings of those three films and several others, including the movie that provided perhaps the biggest jolt of all, “Deliverance,” the 1972 survival adventure based on James Dickey’s novel.

headline: Outliers Defying Easy Definition
abstract: Masculinity and tradition can seem like stable formulas in modern country, but there will always be those who complicate the math.
lead_paragraph: Masculinity and tradition can seem like stable formulas in modern country, but there will always be those who complicate the math. Sam Hunt is a former football star whose debut album, “Montevallo” (MCA Nashville), is chock-full of aw-shucks entreaties — including some, like “Take Your Time,” that sound about as indebted to R&B as to any country norm. On Wednesday, he performs at Irving Plaza. (7 p.m., irvingplaza.com.)

headline: Glories of Japan, Aglow at the Met
abstract: In 1881, a year after opening its building on Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, the Metropolitan Museum of Art received its first official bequest of Japanese art.
lead_paragraph: In 1881, a year after opening its building on Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, the Metropolitan Museum of Art received its first official bequest of Japanese art: a collection formed by Stephen Whitney Phoenix, scion of a New York merchant and political family. The Met has since amassed a world-class Japanese collection. That story will be told in “Discovering Japanese Art: American Collectors and the Met,” opening at the museum on Saturday.

headline: The Only Partner He Really Trusts
abstract: As a child growing up in Taiwan, Huang Yi both longed for and identified with robots.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in Taiwan, Huang Yi both longed for and identified with robots. To meet his parents’ high expectations, he says, he found himself adopting the obedient, emotionless characteristics of a machine. He was also lonely and sought the companionship of something selfless and reliable. These strong emotional currents flow through “Huang Yi & KUKA,” presented by 3-Legged Dog, making it more than just an amusing exercise in blending dance and technology.

headline: The Unreal America
abstract: The Starbucks don’t stop here.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my. Gail Collins tells us — my words, not hers — that Mike Huckabee is running for president as, basically, a Sarah Palin wannabe. He’s the candidate of real Americans, who shoot guns, cook with propane, and would never think of ordering a latte or eating sushi.

headline: A Startling Announcement in Yemen
abstract: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.

headline: At Grammys Event, Bob Dylan Speech Steals the Show
abstract: In an extremely rare and revealing speech, Mr. Dylan, 73, touched on the roots of his songwriting, the musicians who inspired him, and the naysaying of critics and others along the way.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the Grammys’ annual charity gala on Friday, Bob Dylan stole the show without singing a single note.

headline: Appeal to Be Heard in ‘Serial’ Murder Case
abstract: The case of Adnan Syed, whose murder conviction was investigated on the popular podcast “Serial,” will be heard by the Maryland Court of Special Appeals.
lead_paragraph: A Maryland court has agreed to hear an appeal by Adnan Syed, the man whose murder conviction was investigated in the popular “Serial” podcast.

headline: District of Columbia Sees Loophole in Congress’s Move to Halt Marijuana Law
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: After voters in the district approved legalization last fall, a federal provision seeking to block it may hang on the interpretation of a single word.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last fall, voters in the District of Columbia chose to join a handful of states in legalizing the growth and possession of small amounts of marijuana. But unlike in the states, the free will of district voters — no matter how overwhelmingly expressed — is never the end of the story.

headline: An Elaborate Tale of Broken Rims and Moxie
abstract: With its All-Star Game to be played in New York, a map chronicles the long lineage and affiliations of local players, from Dolph Schayes to Kemba Walker.
lead_paragraph: With the N.B.A. All-Star Game returning to Madison Square Garden next Sunday, there is sure to be a good deal of talk about New York, and the way the city and its famous arena have long been viewed as basketball meccas, even if many of the best players now come from elsewhere. Mention will surely be made of the city’s playgrounds and the formidable players who graced them.

headline: Insured, but Not Covered
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: New health insurance policies have many Americans scrambling.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Karen Pineman of Manhattan received notice that her longtime health insurance policy didn’t comply with the Affordable Care Act’s requirements, she gamely set about shopping for a new policy through the public marketplace. After all, she’d supported President Obama and the act as a matter of principle.

headline: A Year Later, Stumbling Creighton Grasps at Hope
abstract: Against a St. John’s team that it beat for its first conference win 10 days earlier, the Bluejays found themselves in trouble from the opening tip.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long season for Creighton Coach Greg McDermott, one filled with disappointing days and disappointing performances and disappointing results. Saturday was no exception. As he leaned against the wall outside his team’s locker room after an 84-66 loss to St. John’s at Madison Square Garden, McDermott wiped his face and exhaled.

headline: U.S. Men Make Stunning Leap in the Downhill in the Alpine Championships
abstract: Just when it was looking bad for the Americans on their home snow in the world championships, the men’s team came up with three top-10 finishes in the downhill.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — When the Alpine world ski championships were last on American soil, in 1999, no member of the United States team won a medal. With the championships back in Colorado this month, the event was expected to be a chance for the American racers to show how far they had come as an international power.

headline: New Generation of N.B.A. All-Stars Will Add to Legacy at Madison Square Garden
abstract: The N.B.A. All-Star Game will return to Madison Square Garden next weekend for the first time since 1998 and build on the history of the four previous games in the city.
lead_paragraph: The 1968 N.B.A. All-Star Game, at Madison Square Garden, was a special one for Lenny Wilkens, whose deep respect for the arena started when he was growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

headline: Brian Williams, Under Scrutiny, Will Take Leave From ‘NBC Nightly News’
keywords: ['Television', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'News and News Media', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: In a memo to the NBC News staff, Mr. Williams said that Lester Holt, the anchor for “Dateline,” would step in.
lead_paragraph: Brian Williams, acknowledging that the scrutiny and criticism he was attracting was becoming a distraction for his network, said on Saturday that he was stepping aside as anchor of NBC’s “Nightly News” for the next several days.

headline: In N.H.L. Terms, Snipers Skate Alongside Danglers
abstract: Since the sport has deep roots in Canada, players coming from other regions must learn the intricacies of the North American lexicon.
lead_paragraph: Washington Capitals Coach Barry Trotz knows an “honest” game when he sees one — and it has nothing to do with officiating.

headline: ESPN Anchor’s Tenacity Permeates Unexpected Memoir
abstract: Stuart Scott’s coming book, “Every Day I Fight,” chronicles his brave struggle with cancer and serves as a gift of love to the daughters he left behind.
lead_paragraph: When the longtime ESPN anchor Stuart Scott quietly agreed to write a memoir last year, appendiceal cancer and chemotherapy were weakening him. His appearances on the network were dwindling. His life was slipping away.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: ‘No More,’ From N.F.L., Only Begs For Action

headline: Norm Drucker, Referee Who Felled N.B.A. Giants, Dies at 94
abstract: Drucker gave Wilt Chamberlain a technical foul that caused his ejection from a game in 1962, accounting for the only minutes the star center missed that season.
lead_paragraph: Norm Drucker, one of pro basketball’s most prominent referees, who notoriously ejected Wilt Chamberlain from a game — the only minutes Chamberlain missed in his epic 1961-62 season — died on Friday. He was 94.

headline: New York’s New Assembly Leader Vows to Aid Blacks
abstract: At a rally in Harlem, Carl E. Heastie, the first African-American speaker of the New York Assembly, cited reforming the criminal justice system as one of his goals.
lead_paragraph: Carl E. Heastie, the first African-American to serve as speaker of the New York Assembly, vowed on Saturday to use his powerful new position to call attention to the needs of black New Yorkers.

headline: Bruce Jenner Involved in Deadly Car Crash in Malibu
abstract: The former Olympian was involved in a three-vehicle crash in Malibu that left one person dead and five injured. Mr. Jenner was not injured.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bruce Jenner, the former Olympic champion and reality television star, was involved in a multicar collision in Malibu, Calif., on Saturday that left one person dead and five people injured, the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department reported.

headline: Shiite Militia Drives Back Islamic State, but Divides Much of Iraq
abstract: The Badr Organization, a Shiite militia, has been effective in fighting the Islamic State, but stands among the most divisive in Iraq, accused of atrocities against Sunnis and known for its close ties to Iran.
lead_paragraph: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq — At their victory rally, the Shiite militiamen used poetry, song and swagger to sweeten their celebration of an ugly battle.

headline: The Mysterious Death of Alberto Nisman
abstract: A prosecutor in Argentina accuses the president of attempting to cover up a secret deal to shield terrorists. Days later, the prosecutor is found dead and the president alleges a conspiracy. An overview of key developments in the case.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in Argentina accuses the president of attempting to cover up a secret deal to shield terrorists. Days later, the prosecutor is found dead and the president alleges a conspiracy. An overview of key developments in the case.

headline: Whodunit? In Obsessed Nation, Question Becomes Who Didn’t
abstract: Argentina has been awash in theories about who killed Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor who accused President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of conspiring with Iran to cover up responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish community center.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The president did it. No, it was the Argentine spymaster plotting against her. Maybe it really was a suicide, the tragic fall of a man whose case was coming undone. Or was it Iran, the Israeli Mossad, the C.I.A.? And what about the lingering influence of the Nazis who fled here after World War II?

headline: Multifaceted
abstract: A sparkling puzzle by Jeremy Newton.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you have a fondness for sparkly jewels, this is the Sunday puzzle for you.

headline: Health Law Case Poses Conundrum for Republicans
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A Supreme Court decision to strike down subsidies for insurance could carry political risks, pushing the party to try to come up with alternatives to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the one hand, Republicans in Congress are urging the Supreme Court to strike down subsidies for health insurance provided to millions of people in more than 30 states. On the other, they are chiding the Obama administration because it has no plan to avert the hardship that could occur if they win in court.

headline: In Gaza and the West Bank, Love Struggles to Bridge the Separation
abstract: An inability to travel freely between Gaza and the West Bank affects thousands of Palestinians, human rights groups say. Since Hamas came to power in Gaza, exit into Israel has been allowed only for humanitarian cases.
lead_paragraph: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip — He said he fell for “her ideas, her thoughts.” She said he made her forget she was overweight, and “feel beautiful.”

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Sleepless Night’s Fancy Nears Space After 17 Years
abstract: The Deep Space Climate Observatory, a 1,250-pound satellite intended to serve as a sentinel for solar storms, is to lift off Sunday from Cape Canaveral.
lead_paragraph: GoreSat is going to space at last.

headline: A Startling Announcement in Yemen
abstract: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Houthi rebels in Yemen announced on Saturday that a national security committee would include four key ministers from the government they ousted last month.

headline: Mayor of Paris Grows Into Her New Role as Comforter in Chief
abstract: Mayor Anne Hidalgo, a soft-spoken but ambitious politician pushed into the spotlight by a horrific terrorist attack, has developed a new swagger.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even after Fox News apologized for broadcasting false claims that Paris was blighted by dangerous Muslim-ruled “no-go zones,” the mayor of Paris could barely conceal her indignation.

headline: Economic Plan Is a Quandary for Hillary Clinton’s Campaign
abstract: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Mrs. Clinton is trying to figure out how to address the anger over income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: With advice from more than 200 policy experts, Hillary Rodham Clinton is trying to answer what has emerged as a central question of her early presidential campaign strategy: how to address the anger about income inequality without overly vilifying the wealthy.

headline: Alex Vraciu, ‘Indestructible’ Ace of World War II, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Vraciu, a Navy pilot, downed 19 Japanese planes in all, including six in eight minutes during the “Great Marianas Turkey Shoot” in the Philippine Sea.
lead_paragraph: Alex Vraciu, who was just 25 when he reigned as the Navy’s top World War II fighter ace after downing 19 Japanese aircraft and destroying 21 more on the ground in only eight months in 1944, died on Jan. 29 in West Sacramento, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Stewart Stern, 92, Screenwriter of ‘Rebel Without a Cause,’ Dies
abstract: Mr. Stern was nominated for Oscars for his work on two other films, “Rachel Rachel” and “Teresa,” and won an Emmy for the mini-series “Sybil.”
lead_paragraph: Stewart Stern, an Academy Award-nominated screenwriter who wrote “Rebel Without a Cause,” “Rachel, Rachel” and other acclaimed films before forsaking Hollywood three decades ago, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 92.

headline: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention
abstract: A Pakistani court has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the houbara bustard, a favorite pastime of Arab royals, in response to complaints from conservationists.
lead_paragraph: For decades, royal Arab hunting expeditions have traveled to the far reaches of Pakistan in pursuit of the houbara bustard — a waddling, migratory bird whose meat, they believe, contains aphrodisiac powers.

headline: The Real America, Continued
abstract: Of guns and poses.
lead_paragraph: Not the most reliable numbers, but still: 13.7 million hunters, 20.4 million yoga practitioners.

headline: Nigeria Postpones Elections, Saying Security Is a Concern
abstract: The closely contested presidential election, originally scheduled for next Saturday, will be held March 28, an official said. And analysts say that the ruling party feared losing the vote.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Nigeria’s election agency on Saturday night put off a closely contested presidential election after weeks of pressure to postpone it from the ruling party, which analysts say was facing potential defeat for the first time in more than 15 years.

headline: Christine Valmy, Builder of U.S. Skin-Care Business, Dies at 88
abstract: Forbidden to practice law in Communist Romania, Ms. Valmy took up dermatology and brought European ideas of skin care to a beauty market largely unaware of exfoliation and clogged pores.
lead_paragraph: Christine Valmy, an immigrant from Communist Romania who helped build the professional skin-care industry in the United States from the ground up in the 1960s, founding the country’s first licensed skin-care school and becoming a sought-after authority in the field, died on Jan. 18 in Bucharest. She was 88.

headline: Australia’s Leader Expedites Vote Threatening His Job
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia moved forward a vote that would declare his position vacant in an effort to reduce uncertainty before Parliament returns from summer recess.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott on Sunday moved forward by a day a vote challenging his leadership, calling for an end to uncertainty before Parliament goes back into session after the summer recess.

headline: Jimmy Walker Chases Victory at Event That Has Mowed Down Top Talent
abstract: Walker posted a two-under-par 70 on Torrey Pines’s difficult South Course to put himself in the hunt for his second victory of the season and the fifth of his late-blooming career.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Jimmy Walker interrupted golf’s youth migration Saturday with this news flash: He did not take his first formal lesson until his junior year in college.

headline: Shared Belief Edges California Chrome in Showdown at Santa Anita Park
abstract: California Chrome was the people’s choice at the San Antonio Stakes, but the bettors’ choice was Shared Belief, who went off at even money to take his eighth victory in nine starts.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — As California Chrome surged in front on the backstretch, the persistent buzz from the crowd at Santa Anita Park escalated to a small roar.

headline: Greek Austerity Spawns Fakery: Playing Nurse
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Hospitals', 'Black Markets', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: When patients go to a hospital in Greece, they often must hire their own nurses just to receive basic care, and many of those nurses are untrained and illegal.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Fotini Katsigianni wears a white nurse’s hat that protrudes prominently from the top of her head. She is head nurse at Evangelismos Hospital, one of the city’s most prominent.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 7, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: John C. Whitehead, Who Led Effort to Rebuild After 9/11, Dies at 92
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States International Relations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A Navy veteran, Mr. Whitehead became a chairman of Goldman Sachs, deputy secretary of state and head of the corporation charged with rebuilding the World Trade Center site.
lead_paragraph: John C. Whitehead, for decades one of New York’s most prominent citizens, a veteran of D-Day who capped a lauded career on Wall Street and in the State Department by shepherding the first years of the city’s fractious effort to rebuild after the 2001 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at his home in New York. He was 92.

headline: Against Knicks, Steve Kerr Sees What Might Have Been. It Isn’t Pretty.
abstract: Asked by Phil Jackson to coach the Knicks, Steve Kerr chose Golden State instead, and his decision looked solid as the Warriors rolled at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: Steve Kerr hesitated for a split-second and smiled as he walked out of the visitors’ locker room at Madison Square Garden late Saturday afternoon and noticed a pack of reporters, several rows deep, waiting to speak to him before his Golden State Warriors played the Knicks.

headline: New York City Teaching Assistant Charged With Rape of Mentally Ill Student
abstract: Maria Contreras, 29, was arrested on Saturday evening in the Bronx and charged with six counts of second-degree rape. The student, a male, is 14 years old.
lead_paragraph: A New York City substitute teaching assistant was fired on Saturday night hours after she was accused of having sex with a mentally ill 14-year-old student inside her apartment in the Bronx.

headline: Billy Casper, Overlooked Titan of Golf, Dies at 83
abstract: A superb putter, Casper also claimed a Masters title and finished with 51 PGA Tour victories, but he was overshadowed in his prime by other stars.
lead_paragraph: Billy Casper, a two-time United States Open victor, a Masters champion and the player with the seventh most wins in PGA Tour history, died on Saturday at his home in Springville, Utah. He was 83.

headline: Devon Bundy and Clovis Maalouf
abstract: The couple was married at the home of the bride’s parents in Liberia, Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: Devon Anais Bundy and Clovis Christopher Maalouf were married Thursday at the summer home of the bride’s parents in Liberia, Costa Rica. Priscilla Solano Castillo, a Costa Rican lawyer and notary, officiated. On Saturday, Mark Maalouf, the groom’s brother, who is a minister of the American Marriage Ministries, led a ceremony that included Arabic wedding traditions.

headline: Tulika Mehrotra and Mohit Chopra
abstract: The couple was married at the Arlington County Courthouse in Arlington, Va.
lead_paragraph: Tulika Mehrotra and Mohit Chopra were married Wednesday by Carla F. Ward, a magistrate, at the Arlington County Courthouse in Virginia. The couple had a Hindu ceremony Jan. 25 at the Leela Palace hotel and resort in New Delhi, where Pandit Rajendra Shastri officiated.

headline: Allegra Ouroussoff and Morgan Eifler
abstract: The couple was married at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Allegra Cecilia Ouroussoff, the daughter of Cecilia Cobb Clarke of Brooklyn and Nicolai Ouroussoff of Manhattan, was married Saturday to Carl Morgan Eifler, a son of Elizabeth Reese Eifler of New Canaan, Conn., and Carl Morgan Eifler of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Victor L. Austin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

headline: James Brodsky and Philip McCarthy II
abstract: The couple were married Saturday at St. James’ Church in New York.
lead_paragraph: James Sharp Brodsky and Philip Edward McCarthy II were married Saturday at St. James’ Church in New York. The Rev. Adrian Dannhauser, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Katherine Tyler, Joshua Monroe
abstract: The bride is an account manager for Droga5, an advertising agency; the groom is a product manager for Franklin Templeton Investments
lead_paragraph: Katherine Davis Tyler and Joshua James Monroe were married Saturday at St. Anthony’s Chapel in Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Timothy H. Sherwood, a cousin of the groom and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Allison Bailey and Alexander Tanton
abstract: The couple was married at Barr Mansion in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Allison Kay Bailey and Alexander Herrick Tanton were married on Saturday at the Barr Mansion, an events space in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Christina Branum-Martin, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

headline: Their Breakups Wouldn’t Take
abstract: The couple was married at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Ross Anmuth and Demetrios Peter Yatrakis were married Saturday evening at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. The Rev. Katherine Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary, officiated.

headline: Jodie Mendelson and Gregory Kay
abstract: The bride is an architect in South Pasadena, Calif.; the groom is a law associate in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Jodie Anne Mendelson and Gregory Steven Kay are to be married Sunday at the Los Angeles River Center and Gardens, an event space in Los Angeles. Rabbi Shimon Paskow is to officiate.

headline: Finally, a Keeper
abstract: It took him only one date to know she was the one and four dates to tell her.
lead_paragraph: Marcia Marie Larson and Eric Nathan Peiffer were married Saturday at Camelback Bible Church in Paradise Valley, Ariz., where Pastor Tim Savage, a minister ordained by Emmanuel Faith Community Church in Escondido, Calif., officiated.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 57TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J (above) returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Leading the pack with six nominations each are Sam Smith, Pharrell Williams and Beyoncé, who, with 53 nominations now has more than any other female performer in the award’s history. Iggy Azalea, Jay Z, Sia, Usher, Jack White, Miranda Lambert, Beck, Drake, Eric Church, Gordon Goodwin and the engineer Tom Coyne follow with four. George Harrison, Buddy Guy and the Bee Gees will be honored as this year’s lifetime achievement recipients. After six years, Kanye West will return to the Grammy stage in a solo performance as well as in a collaboration with Paul McCartney and Rihanna on her new single, “FourFiveSeconds.” Paired performers include Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga; Hozier and Annie Lennox; Jessie J and Tom Jones; and Adam Levine and Gwen Stefani. Katy Perry, AC/DC, Common, John Legend, Mary J. Blige, Juanes, Ariana Grande, Madonna and Ed Sheeran are also scheduled to take the stage. Pre-event coverage begins at 4 on E!; Pop joins the red carpet at 5; and E! moves to the after-party at 11:30.

headline: Corrections: February 8, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, February 8, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Two Lives, in Harmony
abstract: In a Chilean youth orchestra, a conductor and a young musician learn how music lifts them up and changes their lives.
lead_paragraph: Under skies as cloudy as her future, Melody Jerez, a young Chilean girl, discovered music, and with it a world of possibility. Years later, she took over a youth orchestra in an even smaller town, where another child, Georgina Ávila, was similarly entranced.

headline: VPNs Dissolve National Boundaries Online, for Work and Movie-Watching
abstract: A security technology meant to keep communications private is being used to do things like stream Netflix in countries where it is not available.
lead_paragraph: Rod Drury, an entrepreneur in Auckland, New Zealand, regularly visits the United States. Sometimes there are multiple visits a day.

headline: North Korea Tests Five Missiles
abstract: The launchings, reported by South Korea, came a day after the North said that its leader had witnessed the test-firing of a new antiship missile.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired five short-range missiles off its eastern coast on Sunday in a demonstration of its improving missile technology, the South Korean Defense Ministry said.

headline: Childhood Heroes: Once Self-Made, Now to the Manner Born
abstract: Once, the very act of surviving hardship shaped a hero. Now, the powerful, from “Frozen’s” Elsa to “The Incredibles,” are to the manor born. That’s a striking cultural shift.
lead_paragraph: How, I wonder, did I ever miss the difference between yesterday’s popular children’s heroes and today’s?

headline: Deadline Nearing, Iran Presses for Progress in Nuclear Talks
abstract: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, spoke Sunday at a security conference in Munich, where Germany also announced a planned summit meeting on Wednesday to try to resolve the Ukraine crisis.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said Sunday that Tehran did not favor another extension of the talks on limiting its nuclear program and expected economic sanctions to be quickly lifted if an accord was reached.

headline: Iñárritu Takes Directors Guild Prize
abstract: Laura Poitras also win for “Citizenfour.”
lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America on Saturday gave its top prize to Alejandro G. Iñárritu for “Birdman,” his backstage tale of a washed-up movie star seeking a comeback on Broadway. He beat out a field that included Richard Linklater (“Boyhood”) and Clint Eastwood (“American Sniper”). In the documentary category, Laura Poitras took the honors for “Citizenfour,” her film about Edward J. Snowden and his revelations about snooping by the National Security Agency.

headline: Dean Smith, Champion of College Basketball and of Racial Equality, Dies at 83
abstract: Smith built the Tar Heels into a perennial national power in his 36 years at Chapel Hill and became one of the game’s most respected figures.
lead_paragraph: Dean Smith, who built the University of North Carolina men’s basketball team into a perennial national power in his 36 years at Chapel Hill and became one of the game’s most respected figures for qualities that transcended the court, died on Saturday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 83.

headline: 1915: Lusitania Flew Stars and Stripes to Protect U.S. Lives
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Lusitania arrives in Great Britain flying neutral flags in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is now known that the great Cunard liner Lusitania, carrying 700 passengers, including very many prominent Americans, steamed up the Irish Sea under the protection of the American flag, which was only hauled down just before she reached her home port of Liverpool early on Saturday [Feb. 6] morning. Captain David Dow’s actions in substituting Stars and Stripes for the Red Ensign was obviously intended as a precaution taken as a result of a wireless warning from England. The incident has been widely commented on on both sides of Atlantic.

headline: At 50, a Hip-Hop Pioneer Still Has Stories to Tell
abstract: Ricky Walters, better known as the rapper Slick Rick, recalled the early days of hip-hop in the Bronx, and said today’s performers “have been broken to fit into a mold.”
lead_paragraph: When Mandy Aragones watches a movie or television show with her husband, Ricky Walters, she is ready for a running commentary.

headline: Monroeville, Ala., Home of Harper Lee
abstract: In Monroeville, the town square has murals depicting scenes from “To Kill a Mockingbird,” and for several weeks each year, residents perform a play based on the book, acting out some scenes in a former courthouse.
lead_paragraph: In Monroeville, the town square has murals depicting scenes from “To Kill a Mockingbird,” and for several weeks each year, residents perform a play based on the book, acting out some scenes in a former courthouse.

headline: After Harper Lee Novel Surfaces, Plots Arise
abstract: The plan to publish “Go Set a Watchman” has ignited fierce debate, but Ms. Lee’s lawyer, Tonja B. Carter, and other friends say the author is capable of making up her own mind.
lead_paragraph: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — One morning late last summer, Tonja B. Carter was doing some legal work for her prized client, Harper Lee, when she found herself thumbing through an old manuscript of what she assumed was “To Kill a Mockingbird.” The characters were familiar, as they would be to millions of readers — the crusading lawyer, Atticus Finch, and his feisty daughter, Scout. But the passages were different. Atticus was much older. Scout was grown up. The story unfolded in Alabama during the racial turmoil of the 1950s, not the Depression of the 1930s.

headline: Basking in Past and Present, in Whimsical and Raw
abstract: The singer D’Angelo, back in full swing after a long hiatus, brought his version of soul to the Apollo Theater.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the night on Saturday, one by one, D’Angelo’s band members took leave of the Apollo Theater stage. They’d been playing “Untitled (How Does It Feel),” the solemn declaration of lust that had, thanks to its erotic video 15 years ago, transformed D’Angelo from soul music savior to something far trickier, and sweatier. It has become the song that, for many, defines this singer. And it has at times been the song that D’Angelo runs away from.

headline: You Can’t Win Them All? The Globetrotters Beg to Differ
abstract: Despite an almost certain outcome, the famous exhibition team has kept its routine fresh for nearly 90 years.
lead_paragraph: Despite an almost certain outcome, the famous exhibition team has kept its routine fresh for nearly 90 years.

headline: Can’t Win ’Em All? Globetrotters Come Close
abstract: Despite an almost certain outcome, the beloved exhibition team has kept its routine fresh for nearly 90 years.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — Lou Dunbar seems happy. He smiles a lot. He laughs constantly. He claims that his job has never felt like a job because he enjoys it too much. And it all begins to make sense once you consider that Dunbar, who goes by Sweet Lou, is the winningest basketball coach in the world.

headline: In Treating Ebola, Even Using a Stethoscope Becomes a Challenge
abstract: While the stethoscope remains useful, the dangers of Ebola have forced doctors to adapt their methods for obtaining the information it provides.
lead_paragraph: Doctors treating Ebola patients while wearing “the full spacesuit” — protective gear, including waterproof hoods — are struggling with a clinician’s dilemma: what to do if they can’t use one of the oldest, most basic tools in medicine — a stethoscope.

headline: Some Sharp Notes Amid the Performances at Hottest Pre-Grammy Party
abstract: At Clive Davis’s annual pre-Grammy party Martin N. Bandier, chairman of Sony/ATV Music Publishing, took on the subject of copyrights and digital music services.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Clive Davis’s annual pre-Grammy party here is always the most star-chocked event connected to the awards, and this year’s gathering on Saturday night was no exception.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Puerto Rico’s Debt Restructuring Law
abstract: The decision is a victory for hedge funds and other investors in billions of dollars of Puerto Rico bonds.
lead_paragraph: Investors in billions of dollars of Puerto Rico bonds secured a major legal victory when a federal judge ruled that the commonwealth’s recently enacted debt-restructuring law was unconstitutional.

headline: 1940: French Raid Soviet Paris Trade Office
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French officials raid a Soviet office in Paris in 1940.
lead_paragraph: News that the Soviet trade offices in Paris, as well as the Intourist Bureau and the former Soviet School, were raided by the French police Monday was revealed yesterday [Feb. 8] when the press reproduced a German D.N.B. dispatch from Moscow quoting a Tass Agency announcement of the raids. At the same time, it was disclosed that the French authorities rejected the protest of Jacob Souritz, Soviet Ambassador to France, against the raids. The French government took the stand that the three Russian organizations did not enjoy the privilege of extra-territoriality. The raids were justified on the ground that it was necessary to suppress the Soviet propaganda emanating from these premises, which it was stated, was assuming the dimensions of a ‘‘veritable fifth column.’’ It was denied officially that the police action had the ‘‘character of hostility toward a country with which France maintains normal diplomatic relations.’’

headline: As Debaltseve Residents Try to Flee, the Window Closes
abstract: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.
lead_paragraph: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.

headline: Desperation and Destruction in Contested Ukraine City
abstract: Debaltseve, a crucial rail junction, has become the main focus of combat in eastern Ukraine, and has been battered by shelling from rebel forces eager to control it.
lead_paragraph: DEBALTSEVE, Ukraine — A line of furious, bedraggled women, holding tight to their wind-whipped clothes, waited for a chance to fill their plastic jugs from a water truck. Outside city hall, old men and women grabbed desperately at loaves of bread dropped off by Ukrainian troops. A few more gathered inside to recharge their radios and other electronic gear at the community generator.

headline: Legislative Lessons
abstract: A look inside the new Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the new Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.

headline: Tycoon and Mubarak Ally Seeks Return to Parliament
abstract: Ahmed Ezz, who once steered the ruling party for President Hosni Mubarak, was long reviled in Egypt as the personification of crony capitalism.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The steel tycoon who once steered the ruling party for President Hosni Mubarak has filed papers to run again for Parliament in the latest unwinding of the Arab Spring revolt.

headline: At Box Office, SpongeBob Outguns ‘Sniper’
abstract: “The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water” takes over the top spot from “American Sniper.”
lead_paragraph: After successfully returning the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles to the multiplex, Paramount has pulled off the same trick with another aging cartoon crew. “The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water” soaked up a stellar $56 million at North American theaters over the weekend, demonstrating the power of nostalgia and the promotional strength of Nickelodeon, Paramount’s corporate sibling.

headline: Diverging Fates of Two Veterans Encapsulate the Knicks’ Misfortune
abstract: Saturday’s game at Madison Square Garden offered the sight of Amar’e Stoudemire posting up David Lee, a meeting of veteran forwards with similar outlooks on N.B.A. life.
lead_paragraph: It was a night of imagery, not intrigue, at Madison Square Garden, beginning with Carmelo Anthony being ceremonially handed his All-Star jersey by those distinguished Knicks alumni, Walt Frazier, Allan Houston and John Starks. Then Anthony, in a handsome tapered suit, took a seat on the bench, where he should surely remain with his sore knee for the Knicks’ final 15 home games after he exhausts his right shoulder shooting jump shots in Sunday’s dunk-and-pony show at the self-proclaimed World’s Most Famous Arena.

headline: Prime Minister of Greece Will Not Prolong Bailout
abstract: In an address to Parliament on Sunday, Alexis Tsipras promised to carry out his campaign pledges to roll back austerity.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As pressure grows on Greece to reach a deal with its international creditors and avert fears that it will default on its huge debt, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said Sunday that his government would not seek an extension of a stringent bailout program and would carry out its campaign pledges to roll back austerity, but gradually.

headline: Packing Up the Coolers
abstract: With the Islanders set to move from Nassau Coliseum to Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a tailgating culture supported by die-hard fans is nearing an end.
lead_paragraph: With the Islanders set to move from Nassau Coliseum to Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a tailgating culture supported by die-hard fans is nearing an end.

headline: Bidding Farewell to Their Cold Patches of Pavement
abstract: When the Islanders move from Nassau Coliseum to Barclays Center in Brooklyn next season, they will leave behind a tailgating culture supported by die-hard fans.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Alex Klein’s minibus is painted the green and white of the Jets, but it is also festooned with orange and blue flags, towels and other accouterments.

headline: As Debaltseve Residents Try to Flee, The Window Closes
abstract: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.
lead_paragraph: For seven months, the Ukrainian town of Debaltseve, northeast of the rebel stronghold of Donetsk, has been battered by shelling from rebel forces on all sides.

headline: Looking Back, a Horn Player Dips Into Every Mood
abstract: Eddie Henderson led a quintet at Smoke on Saturday ahead of the release of his new album, “Collective Portrait.”
lead_paragraph: Past the midpoint of his second set at Smoke on Friday night, the trumpeter Eddie Henderson announced the first composition he ever wrote, a dose of drifting intrigue titled “Dreams.” His preamble almost could have seemed sheepish, coming from someone else: “I’m not really a composer,” he said. “I just write sketches, and let the band fill them in.”

headline: Seeing Art in the Diagramed Deal
abstract: Bridge is primarily a science, but it can also be artistic.
lead_paragraph: Bridge is primarily a science, but it can also be artistic. In the diagramed deal, for example, how did South play in five clubs doubled after West led his spade ace and continued with a second spade?

headline: In the Mold of a Senator Who Bartered
abstract: The Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston, opening next month, mirrors the senator’s spirit of cooperation in lawmaking.
lead_paragraph: When it opens next month in Boston, the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate will be aiming to restore respect for Congress at a time when rancor and partisanship have seriously damaged its reputation.

headline: O’Donnell Saying Goodbye to ‘The View’
abstract: Rosie O’Donnell is leaving ABC’s “The View” at the end of the week to focus on her health and family.
lead_paragraph: Rosie O’Donnell is leaving ABC’s “The View” at the end of the week to focus on her health and family. Cindi Berger, Ms. O’Donnell’s publicist, told the The New York Post’s Page Six that the 52-year-old comedian and actress wanted to spend more time with her five children after separating from her second wife, Michelle Rounds, in November. “Rosie has teens and an infant at home that need her attention,” Ms. Berger said. “This has been a very stressful situation. She is putting her personal health and family first.” Ms. O’Donnell won’t be walking out of the spotlight completely. “Rosie O’Donnell: A Heartfelt Stand Up,” her HBO Documentary special about cardiac health (she suffered a heart attack in 2012), premieres Feb. 14. And a Tweet posted on “The View” Twitter account said Ms. O’Donnell would “be back often with her unique point of view and updates on her work and family.”

headline: With Dream-Girl Stand-Ins, a Riotous Heyday Recalled
abstract: From Ruby Keeler to Judy Garland, singers retrace a movie-musical history in “Here’s to the Girls!: Hollywood’s Leading Ladies,” at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: In the giddy, goofy history of the movie musical as traced in “Here’s to the Girls!: Hollywood’s Leading Ladies,” the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics and Lyricists program on Saturday, each major studio had its own pantheon and signature style. One of the most clearly defined, identified as the Warner Bros. Dames, were brassy streetwise characters played by the likes of Ruby Keeler and Joan Blondell.

headline: Saucy Temptress Keeps the Temperature Cool
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca and the tenor Roberto Alagna reunited for the first time since 2009 in Bizet’s “Carmen,” and the spectacle was largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: As she has risen to stardom over the past decade the Latvian mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca has been one of the most frustrating singers in opera. There are few voices as sheerly lovely as hers: a smooth, evenly produced instrument, rich but not heavy, with high notes that penetrate without blaring.

headline: Portrait of the Nation as a Panoply of Hope and Clashing Egos
abstract: “Word of Mouth” by Timo Andres, performed by Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, is a chamber symphony suffused with optimism but also conflicting ambitions.
lead_paragraph: In 1842 Charles Dickens published “American Notes,” a travelogue detailing impressions formed during a six-month journey up and down the Eastern Seaboard. “American Notes” is also the title of this season’s commissioning program by the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which invites composers to write works that take the temperature of the country today — not quite a State of the Union, perhaps, so much as a national selfie.

headline: In Vietnam, a Tightening Grip on a Flourishing Sector
abstract: As the government overhauls its information technology policies, running a tech business in Vietnam is getting riskier.
lead_paragraph: As the government overhauls its information technology policies, running a tech business in Vietnam is getting riskier.

headline: Drifters Drop In and Stay for a While
abstract: The play “The Listeners” centers on two drifters, contradictions and shifting identities.
lead_paragraph: To break the fourth wall at “The Listeners,” Matthew Freeman’s new play at the Brick, you’ll need a battering ram. The set is an enclosed, roofless room in the middle of the Brick’s black-box space. Audience members can peer at the play through letterbox slits sliced into the walls. If you come early enough to grab a chair in front of one of the two panels of one-way glass, you’ll enjoy the rare luxury of seeing two or even three characters at once.

headline: Prime Minister Tony Abbott Keeps Hold of Job in Party Vote in Australia
abstract: Mr. Abbott fought off a challenge to his leadership after lawmakers from his conservative Liberal Party voted against a motion to declare the party’s top positions vacant.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Tony Abbott will remain Australia’s prime minister, fighting off a challenge to his position on Monday by lawmakers from his conservative Liberal Party.

headline: Time for All Kinds of Fancy Before the Clock Strikes 12
abstract: New York Theater Ballet’s offered a condensed “Cinderella” for children at Florence Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: Cinderella, everyone knows, has to squeeze in as much fun as she can before midnight. But a ballet production of “Cinderella” intended for young children has to abide by an even more inexorable time constraint: the attention span of its audience. New York Theater Ballet’s  “Cinderella,” which returned to Florence Gould Hall over the weekend, succeeds in condensing the fairy tale and Prokofiev’s three-act score down to just over an hour without sacrificing all the fantasy.

headline: A Play Space for Rhythm Set on the High Seas
abstract: “Cambuyón,” a percussive music-and-dance show at the New Victory Theater, incorporates clogging, tap, hip-hop and salsa in one fast-paced hour.
lead_paragraph: In “Cambuyón,” a percussive dance and music show that opened at the New Victory Theater on Friday, rhythm comes from many sources: wooden crates, metal buckets, matchsticks, glass bottles, kitchen utensils, feet slapping the floor and hands slapping the body. The concept bears more than a little resemblance to “Stomp,” but in this production by Enlace Servicios Culturales, a company based in the Canary Islands and in Barcelona, all of the tapping and clanging happens aboard a ship whose location in time and space remains open to interpretation.

headline: Brooklynite Wins Choreography Award
abstract: The choreographer, performer and musician Steven Reker of Brooklyn is the winner of the American Dance Institute’s second annual Solange MacArthur Award for New Choreography.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer, performer and musician Steven Reker of Brooklyn is the winner of the American Dance Institute’s second annual Solange MacArthur Award for New Choreography, organizers of that Maryland-based nonprofit announced Sunday. The award recognizes a rising American choreographer with financial and administrative support for presenting a commissioned work. Mr. Reker said in a statement that the award, which includes a $10,000 commission, would allow him to create “a piece I have wanted to make for years but could only imagine making since my resources are somewhat limited in NYC.” Mr. Reker was selected by the institute’s artistic advisory board — which includes the choreographers Brian Brooks, David Dorfman and Doug Elkins — after a closed nomination process. The award is named for Solange MacArthur, a former member of American Ballet Theater and supporter of the institute, who died in 2012. The first recipient was Chris Schlichting of Minnesota.

headline: ‘Wolsey Angels’ to Go to the V&A Museum
abstract: The Victoria and Albert Museum surpassed its goal of raising 2.5 million pounds ($3.8 million) to purchase the four statues.
lead_paragraph: The Victoria and Albert Museum surpassed its goal on Sunday of raising 2.5 million pounds ($3.8 million) to purchase four statues created by the Italian sculptor Benedetto da Rovezzano for the tomb of Cardinal Thomas Wolsey, an adviser to Henry VIII and once one of England’s most powerful men. The statues, known as the Wolsey Angels, were commissioned in 1524, just before the cardinal lost his power after failing to convince the pope to annul the king’s marriage. The cardinal appeared in Hilary Mantel’s novel “Wolf Hall.” Ms. Mantel said in a statement that the recovery of the angels “is one of those miracles that historians pray for; something that seems irrevocably lost has been there all the time.” After Wolsey’s death in 1530, Henry VIII acquired the statues for his own tomb, which was never completed. They were eventually sold during the 1640s to raise money during England’s Civil War and were unheard of again until two surfaced at an auction in 1994. The other pair was discovered in 2008 at a country house in Northamptonshire in central England. The majority of the funds for the purchase came from a two-million pound grant from the National Heritage Memorial Fund, while another 500,000 pounds came from the Art Fund, a charity that helps British museums purchase art. Additional funds came from donations and museum supporters — including 33,000 pounds from on-site donations and one-pound “Save the Wolsey Angels” badges. The statutes are on display at the museum but will be temporarily removed to undergo conservation treatment.

headline: Popular Children’s Book Series
abstract: Lynn Lempel, one of the reigning queens of Monday puzzles, hides someone in our puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — We’re looking deeply into our Monday grid today. Lynn Lempel is back, and she’s hidden a famous children’s book character in our puzzle.

But more traffic tickets piled up, as did warrants for failing to appear in court or pay his fines. So Mr. Nelson, now 26, has found himself repeatedly jailed in this St. Louis suburb and in the maze of municipalities nearby — part of a pattern that black residents here complain has grown all too common.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:15 P.M. (HBO Signature) BELLE (2014) The biracial daughter (Gugu Mbatha-Raw) of a British Navy captain (Matthew Goode) struggles to transcend life as a black woman in slave-trading England after being raised in privilege by her aristocratic uncle and aunt (Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson), and alongside her white cousin (Sarah Gadon, above right, with Ms. Mbatha-Raw), in this biopic about the historical figure Dido Elizabeth Belle (1761-1804). Directed by Amma Asante and written by Misan Sagay, the film chronicles the challenging love life of Belle, an educated beauty — including a dashing suitor, John Davinier (Sam Reid), as well as several not-so-charming ones. The movie also covers Belle’s uncle, the lord chief justice who must decide on a case involving a Zong slave ship on which more than 130 Africans were massacred for an insurance payment. “The movie plays with the historical record for dramatic effect, as is often the case when the past is disinterred for entertainment, and its realism at times groans under the weight of too many passionate speeches,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Yet the weave of the personal and the political finally proves as irresistible as it is moving, partly because it has been drawn from extraordinary life.”

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Not a single shot has been fired by the military since generals overthrew a democratically elected government here last May. Instead, they have depended on the force of paperwork, reams of it, to bring their opponents under control.

headline: Landscapes, After Katrina’s Storm
abstract: Colleen Mullins’s photos of post-Katrina New Orleans chronicle a changing landscape, focusing on how people are working to undo damage to the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Colleen Mullins lived in the Minnesota cold for 22 years — her tires got stuck in the snow, as the locals like to say. To escape the harsh weather in 2006, she visited New Orleans for a warm birthday treat. It was a year after Hurricane Katrina, and she wasn’t even planning to take her camera, as she had seen enough disaster porn.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

headline: Let’s Not Mention Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Republicans should focus on growth instead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — REPUBLICANS think they have found a new weapon to use against President Obama: the charge that income inequality has risen on his watch. In recent weeks that criticism has been lodged by the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell; Speaker of the House John A. Boehner; Representative Paul D. Ryan; and the former governors Mitt Romney and Jeb Bush. Three other potential presidential candidates, Senators Ted Cruz, Rand Paul and Marco Rubio, used inequality to indict the Democrats in a January forum.

headline: Trying to Ease End-of-Life Suffering
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Hospice Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Readers respond to an essay by Dr. Ira Byock.

headline: Nobody Understands Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Families who rely on it make themselves poorer, so isn’t that true of nations? No, it isn’t.
lead_paragraph: Many economists, including Janet Yellen, view global economic troubles since 2008 largely as a story about “deleveraging” — a simultaneous attempt by debtors almost everywhere to reduce their liabilities. Why is deleveraging a problem? Because my spending is your income, and your spending is my income, so if everyone slashes spending at the same time, incomes go down around the world.

headline: Children and Technology: How Much Is Best?
abstract: Educators respond to an Op-Ed article, “Can Students Have Too Much Tech?”

headline: After a Guilty Plea, a Prison Term and a Movie, a Sex Abuse Case Returns
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Editorials', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Prosecutorial Misconduct']
abstract: Now that numerous witnesses have recanted, Jesse Friedman deserves a chance to prove his innocence.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Capturing the Friedmans,” the 2003 documentary that tells the harrowing story of a father and son charged in 1987 with the brutal sexual abuse of children on Long Island, one of the detectives on the case recalls her hesitation in the face of intense pressure from parents to prosecute quickly.

headline: The Muslims of Early America
abstract: Like the rodeo, Islam is an indelible part of our culture.
lead_paragraph: IT was not the imam’s first time at the rodeo.

headline: Beyond ‘Black Lives Matter’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'News and News Media', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Michael Brown and Eric Garner are now old news. Where do we go from here?
lead_paragraph: The Black Lives Matter protesters took some criticism for what others viewed as a lack of clear focus and detailed agenda. But in truth, raising an issue to the point where it can no longer be ignored is the grist for the policy mill. Visibility and vocalization have value.

headline: Congress Acts on Veteran Suicides
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As an estimated 22 veterans kill themselves each day on average, Republicans and Democrats have found something meaningful they can agree on.
lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats in Congress have found something meaningful they can agree about: strengthening the nation’s response to the tragic wave of veteran suicides. On Tuesday, by a 99-to-0 vote, the Senate approved a bill to improve suicide prevention and mental health treatment programs at the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: The Case for Aid to Central America
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: If the Obama administration’s billion-dollar funding level is approved, it stands a much better chance of addressing the region’s instability.
lead_paragraph: There are two important policy debates in Washington that deal with the vexing problem of illegal immigration. One is being approached intelligently; the other is decidedly not.

headline: Swan Lovers
abstract: In their multitudes, these birds renew our faith in doing things together.
lead_paragraph: I’m not Leda, so it’s perhaps odd that swans should be involved in my love life, but I happen to live near the Magee Marsh National Wildlife Refuge in Oak Harbor, Ohio. The refuge is not only the self-styled Warbler Capital of the World in spring — when every warbler on Peterson’s list of “Confusing Warblers” flies through, making crowded birders jostle one another’s camera tripods — but is also, during the winter, a way station for thousands of migrating tundra swans.

headline: China Executes Billionaire Who Ran ‘Mafia-Style’ Criminal Gang
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Organized Crime', 'Capital Punishment', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Liu Han, 49, his brother Liu Wei, and three associates were executed on Monday, the state news media reported.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese billionaire who was building a mining empire in Australia was executed Monday after a court last year sentenced him to die for running a “mafia-style” gang that engaged in murder and extortion.

headline: In Video, Communist Party Vows It Wants to Fulfill Your Dreams
abstract: The intent of a slick promotional video is clear: to reassure an international audience that the Communist Party can make the aspirations of the Chinese people come true.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you want an attractive wife? Or to open a little restaurant? Maybe blue skies and clean water? Or, less modestly, a world without war? Be assured: The Chinese Communist Party and its 83 million members are rooting for you.

lead_paragraph: I.

lead_paragraph: For a decade, Zhao Zhihong insisted that he had raped and killed a woman in 1996, and that the man who had been executed for the crimes was innocent.

headline: Should Brian Williams’s Misleading Personal Account of a 2003 Event Cast Doubt on His Journalistic Integrity?
abstract: Does it matter that news anchor Brian Williams told an inaccurate story about something that happened in 2003?
lead_paragraph: “NBC Nightly News” anchor and managing editor Brian Williams is facing criticism for embellishing an account of an incident that occurred when he was working as a reporter in Iraq in 2003. Over the years he came to say that he was in a helicopter that was hit by enemy fire, an assertion he now says is not true. He now says he was in a trailing helicopter, and that he “conflated” the two aircraft.
