abstract: Monday: Freezing rain, sleet and snow; the mayor presents the budget; and a heart sculpture in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this unpleasant Monday.

headline: New Claims That HSBC Aided Tax Evaders
abstract: Documents stolen by a former employee in Switzerland in 2007 show bankers helping clients avoid paying taxes on billions of dollars in their home countries.
lead_paragraph: HSBC found itself under fire again on Monday after news reports over the weekend provided more details about long-running accusations that its Swiss private banking arm helped clients hide billions of dollars in assets from international tax authorities before 2007.

headline: Daily Report: Rivalry Brewing Between Uber and Google
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Maps', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could wind up directly competing.
lead_paragraph: When Google’s venture capital arm poured more than $250 million into Uber in 2013, it looked like a match made in tech heaven, Mike Isaac reports.

headline: How to Prioritize and Save Young Lives
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: There’s a disconnect between what we think kills children and what actually does. In the U.S., it makes sense to focus on accidents, homicide and suicide.
lead_paragraph: In an ad during the Super Bowl last week, Nationwide Insurance chillingly reminded us that accidents are the No. 1 killer of children. Aside from the odd setting for the commercial, one of the reasons that it shocked so many people in the United States is that we have a disconnect between what we think kills children and what really does.

headline: Greece: The Tie That Doesn’t Bind
abstract: The Davos set loses its leverage.
lead_paragraph: Relations between Greece and its creditors are not improving. Was this bad diplomacy on the part of Tsipras/Varoufakis? Maybe, but my guess is that there was nothing they could do to avoid a bitter confrontation short of immediate betrayal of the voters who put them in office. And creditor-country officials are acting as if they still expect that to happen, just as it has repeatedly over the past five years.

headline: Seeking a ‘Beautiful Death’
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: Before making an advance directive, talk with your doctor and your caregiver about just how far end-of-life care should go at the cost of comfort.
lead_paragraph: Virgie Divinigracia had the kind of death last month that most Americans say they want: at home, relieved of physical and mental pain, surrounded by those she loved, “a beautiful death” as those present described it. Alas, this is true for too few Americans. Most still die in costly medical facilities tethered to machines, often unable to communicate, in a futile attempt to prolong their lives.

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Takes On Payday Lenders
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau seeks to limit payday lenders. | The prime minister of Greece says he will carry out his campaign to roll back austerity. | Hidden cash is flowing into high-end real estate. | Shares of HSBC fall on tax avoidance claims.
lead_paragraph: U.S. TAKES ON PAYDAY LENDERS | The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will soon release the first draft of federal regulations to govern a wide range of short-term loans made by the $46 billion payday loan industry, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The rules are expected to address expensive credit backed by car titles and some installment loans that stretch longer than the traditional two-week payday loan, according to industry lawyers, consumer groups and government authorities briefed on the discussions.

headline: From Beyoncé to Sam Smith: The Worst Trend of the Grammys (and Every Other Award Ceremony)
abstract: This red carpet vs. stage vs. exit quick-change thing has gotten out of control.
lead_paragraph: There were many folks who looked surprisingly good at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, managing to combine rock ’n’ roll edge with actual elegance (chief among them in my book: Nicki Minaj in Tom Ford, Iggy Azalea in Armani Privé, and Gwen Stefani in her Versace jumpsuit), but really, who could keep track?

headline: Insiders and Outsiders Redux
abstract: Of Borgs and money.
lead_paragraph: Matt O’Brien praises Larry Summers for his don’t raise rates op-ed, and rightly so — or at least I agree, and have been saying the same thing, and even using the same imagery. But I’m interested in Matt’s remark that Larry would have made a good Fed chairman. Quite possibly — but would he be saying the same thing if he were in fact at the Fed?

headline: Shots Fired Near Marseille on Day of French Prime Minister’s Visit
abstract: The gunmen were believed to have fired their weapons at members of a rival gang and were not targeting police officers, as some news outlets initially reported, a union spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Several men fired shots in the air on Monday in a poor suburb of Marseille while the French prime minister, Manuel Valls, was in the city to defend the government’s local security plan, police officials said. No one was wounded.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As demand dwindles, steel prices in China have fallen 12 percent in the first five weeks of this year, almost as much as in all of 2014.

headline: Egypt’s Leader Seeks Inquiry Into Soccer Stadium Deaths
abstract: The police blamed a stampede, but several fans said the police set off the confrontation by firing tear gas into the throng and birdshot at the fleeing crowds.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi on Monday called for an investigation into a confrontation with riot police officers that killed at least 25 people at the gates of a soccer stadium here, as prosecutors ordered the arrest of the leaders of a fan group.

headline: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court did not stay a ruling overturning Alabama’s ban, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of the state’s chief justice.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Despite a federal judge’s rulings legalizing same-sex marriage, most probate judges in Alabama on Monday refused to issue marriage licenses to gay and lesbian couples, escalating a legal showdown that echoed the battles over desegregation here in the 1960s.

headline: ‘Boyhood’s’ Bafta Wins Put It Neck and Neck With ‘Birdman’
abstract: Richard Linklater and his film won awards at the British ceremony, after losing the Directors Guild of America award to “Boyhood” the night before.
lead_paragraph: Going into Sunday, it looked like Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” would assuredly, in one fell feathered swoop, land the best picture and best director Oscars on Feb. 22. On Saturday night, the Directors Guild of America give the picture and Mr. Iñárritu its top award, the other major guilds — the producers’ and the actors’ — having already done the same. As several Oscar prognosticators noted, the only film that ever won all three guild awards only to lose best picture was “Apollo 13,” in 1996. (It lost to “Braveheart.”)

headline: Twitter Reports a Surge in Government Data Requests
abstract: The report said total government requests for data rose by 40 percent, to about 2,881, compared with the company’s last report, in July.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Monday released its twice-yearly transparency report, showing a surge in government requests for users’ Twitter information.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Season Includes World Premiere by Anne Washburn
abstract: The Off Broadway Playwrights Horizons company announces its 2015-16 season.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway Playwrights Horizons theater company announced the six productions for its 2015-16 season on Monday. They include a world premiere by Anne Washburn – the author of the critically acclaimed drama “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play” – and works by Taylor Mac (“A 24-Decade History of Popular Music”), Danai Gurira (“In the Continuum”) and Jordan Harrison (“Maple and Vine”).

headline: Special Deal on Paul Taylor Tickets Will Leave You Money for Burgers, Too

lead_paragraph: One of the great bargains in New York is coming back: Paul Taylor’s newly reconstituted dance company, Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, is planning a March 10 performance at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center where all tickets will be two for $15.

headline: 1940: Lebrun Visits British Troops
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: President Lebrun visits British troops on the front in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WITH THE BRITISH ARMY IN FRANCE — For the first time since the war began President Albert Lebrun of the French Republic visited the British Expeditionary Force today [Feb. 9]. From Paris, he came to British field headquarters in his own one-car private train. Here at the station he was met by Viscount General Gort, Commander-in-Chief of the B.E.F. The day was one of raw, humid penetrating cold. President Lebrun and his party went to the headquarters of the Welsh Guards. There they inspected some of the troops, visited their billets and chatted with a group of schoolchildren, who heralded the President’s arrival by singing the ‘‘Marseillaise.’’— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 10, 1940

headline: British Pottery, Illustrated

headline: China Tells Schools to Suppress Western Ideas, With One Big Exception
abstract: The nation’s education minister is sounding dire alarms against foreign influence on its campuses, calling for a ban on textbooks that promote Western ideas — except if that idea is Communism.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — They are out there, hiding in library stacks, whispering in lecture halls, armed with dangerous textbooks and subversive pop quizzes: foreign enemies plotting a stealthy academic invasion of Chinese universities.

headline: Dean Smith Was Pioneer in Use of Analytics
abstract: Smith, who died Saturday, was the most prominent early proponent of possession-based analysis, which is now standard operating procedure in college basketball and the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Coach Dean Smith would tell his players, both at halftime and after a game, how many points they had scored and had allowed per possession. In the 1960s, he began to assign managers to track the statistic.

headline: Stressed by Money? Get on the Couch
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Personal Finances', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The young field of financial therapy tries to identify disorders in how people view money, to better advise them on planning and investments.
lead_paragraph: I felt calm as I sat on a blue couch for my close encounter with the nascent field of financial therapy. I watched as Joel Reimer, a fit, 50-something man in a golf shirt, put sensors on my thumb and fingers.

headline: Deloitte Chooses Female Chief Executive
abstract: The choice of Cathy Engelbert makes Deloitte the first of the big four accounting and consulting firms in the United States to be headed by a woman.
lead_paragraph: Deloitte said on Monday that it had chosen Cathy Engelbert as its chief executive, making it the first of the big four accounting and consulting firms in the United States to be headed by a woman.

headline: Former Spy Chief in South Korea Sentenced in Election Case
abstract: A South Korean court convicted the former intelligence chief of illegally helping President Park Geun-hye in the 2012 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: JEJU, South Korea — In a political blow to President Park Geun-hye, a South Korean appeals court on Monday convicted a former government intelligence chief on charges of intervening in the 2012 vote that elected her president.

headline: Obama Awaits Outcome of Ukraine Peace Talks Before Deciding on Arms
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, President Obama expressed hope for a diplomatic solution in Ukraine but said the United States would consider sending weapons if talks failed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday that he would wait for the outcome of peace talks before deciding whether to provide lethal weapons to Ukraine. Such assistance would represent a striking break with European allies who say that arming the country against Russian aggression would make the conflict worse.

headline: Political Talks in Yemen Hit Turbulence From the Start
abstract: The talks are regarded as crucial to reverse the deepening political anarchy in Yemen, the Arab world’s poorest country and incubator of Qaeda militants.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Feuding political parties resumed United Nations-mediated talks with the Houthi militants controlling Yemen’s capital on Monday, but two parties withdrew within hours complaining of threats from the Houthis.

headline: The ’70s-Inspired Rock of Tor Miller
abstract: A video for “Midnight,” from the singer-songwriter’s debut EP, “Headlights,” streams here exclusively.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on a couch under a poster of James Dean at a temporary apartment in West Hollywood, Tor Miller is recalling his journey from New York University student to his current status as a singer-songwriter on the precipice of fame. His debut EP, “Headlights,” out now, has garnered impressive buzz — its lead track, “Hold the Phone,” was recently dubbed the “hottest record in the world” by the influential BBC DJ Zane Lowe.

headline: On the Homeless Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The Metro reporter Winnie Hu writes about her experience covering New York City’s homeless population.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 9, the Metro reporter Winnie Hu wrote an article about the “unsheltered homeless,” a relatively small subset of New York City’s homeless population, and the city’s plan to devote more resources to what homeless advocates say is a growing demographic.

headline: 1965: France Bars Malcolm X
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: France bars Malcolm X from speaking in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French authorities today [Feb. 9] barred Malcolm X from entering the country to deliver a talk. The American black nationalist leader arrived from London at Orly International Airport this morning, learned from French security officials that his presence was ‘‘undesirable,’’ and was put on a flight back to London two hours later. An Interior Ministry spokesman said it was decided that a meeting Malcolm X was to address tonight could ‘‘provoke demonstrations that would trouble the public order.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 10, 1965

headline: It’s Monday. Why Does It Always Have to Be a Snow Day?
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Parenting', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: Monday is my day off. My “me” day. Just me, and my work, alone, in the house. Unless it’s a snow day — and this year, Monday always seems to be a snow day.
lead_paragraph: All around me, doors are swinging open and closed, boots are dripping on the wood floor, the dog is jumping up and down with white flakes on her snout, siblings are arguing over who gets more of the shoveling money, and my husband is reorganizing our books and doing the laundry.

headline: Climate Is Big Issue for Hispanics, and Personal
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Hispanics are more likely than whites to view global warming as a problem that affects them personally and to support policies aimed at curbing it, a New York Times poll has found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alfredo Padilla grew up in Texas as a migrant farmworker who followed the harvest with his parents to pick sugar beets in Minnesota each summer. He has not forgotten the aches of labor or how much the weather — too little rain, or too much — affected the family livelihood.

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Trial Sets Town on Edge
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Movies', 'Jury System', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A trial in Texas will dissect war’s effect on two men — one of them a sniper hailed as an American hero and the other a fellow soldier on trial for two murders.
lead_paragraph: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — The trial of the man charged with killing Chris Kyle, a former sniper for the Navy SEALs, is scheduled to open here on Wednesday at 9 a.m. The blockbuster war movie about Mr. Kyle, “American Sniper,” now playing at Cinemark Cinema 6 three miles from the courtroom, will be showing at 3:40 p.m., 7 p.m. and 10:20 p.m.

headline: After Criticism, India Police Arrest 8 in Haryana Rape-Murder
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Intellectual Disabilities']
abstract: Opposition lawmakers have seized on the case, and the victim’s sister said the police could have saved her life if they had begun a search immediately.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Under mounting criticism for their slow response to a missing persons report filed last week, the police in the Indian state of Haryana arrested eight men on Monday suspected of raping and murdering a mentally impaired woman whose battered body was found in a field.

headline: Airbag Is Approved, but Ski Racers Are Largely Shunning It for Now
keywords: ['Skiing', 'Sports Injuries', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'World Cup (Skiing)', 'ALPINE SKIING']
abstract: The use of an airbag safety device has not gained acceptance among the sport’s professionals yet, despite the risk of serious injury that competitors face in violent crashes.
lead_paragraph: MOLVENA, Italy — Broken collarbones. Shattered shoulders. Internal bleeding. Punctured lungs. Those injuries, and worse, are possible every time a world-class skier plunges out of a starting gate and slides down a snowy racecourse.

headline: Henk Tijms: Dropping Balls Into Bins
abstract: A machine drops balls into bins. When should you stop the machine in order to maximize your winnings? Test your logic with this original puzzle by Dutch mathematician Henk Tijms.
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Henk Tijms, a Dutch mathematician and emeritus professor at the VU University Amsterdam. We first met Dr. Tijms about a year ago through his Devil’s Penny. This new puzzle has a similar feel, but is a bit more challenging. Let’s play —

headline: Whitehead’s Storied Career Beyond Goldman Sachs Is Hard to Reproduce
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: It will take years to repair banks’ credibility enough to produce someone who can move as easily from banking to public service, Antony Currie and Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews write.
lead_paragraph: The storied career that John C. Whitehead led over the past 70 years or so is virtually impossible to imagine on Wall Street today.

headline: The Morning After the Grammys, Kanye West Speaks Out About Beck
abstract: “C’mon, man, I love Beck,” Mr. West said in a paparazzi video published on Monday by TMZ. “But he ain’t have the album of the year.”
lead_paragraph: The morning after the Grammys, Kanye West was still feeling charged.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Hazy Approach to Crime and Punishment
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The S.E.C., which advocates full disclosure for the companies it regulates, has a little trouble with its own transparency, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: In Gilbert and Sullivan’s “The Mikado,” a line expresses the need “to let the punishment fit the crime.” The Securities and Exchange Commission is struggling with that notion when it decides whether to grant a waiver to an automatic bar from certain securities trading.

headline: Comparisons With Others Can Obscure Our Own Goals
abstract: Competition can help us improve, but it can also take us away from what is truly important for us.
lead_paragraph: On and off over the years, I have used a training app called Strava. It allows you to keep track of your performance on different biking, running and skiing trails. You can even break down overall times into sections or compare your performance over the entire trail.

headline: Unearthed From Town’s Archives: Copy of Magna Carta From 1300
abstract: A scrapbook found in the archives of Sandwich, England, is found to contain a copy of Magna Carta.
lead_paragraph: A tattered copy of the Magna Carta has been discovered in the archives of the municipality of Sandwich, a sleepy seaside town in eastern England, according to the local government and a historian at the University of East Anglia.

headline: A Sprawling Manor for $125,000 (Some Disassembly Required)
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Croft, a house in a nature preserve that features antique décor brought from England, is on the market for just $125,000, but the purchaser will have to move it.
lead_paragraph: YORKTOWN, N.Y. — It might just be one of the greatest real estate deals in New York. For $125,000, a roughly 8,000-square-foot Tudor home overlooking lakes and forests in a nature preserve here is up for grabs, the epitome of baronial-bucolic Westchester County living.

headline: Training Birds to Aid a Scientific Breakthrough
abstract: In a first, researchers directly measured the aerodynamic force of a flying animal, as parrotlets were taught to fly into a box and to a perch.
lead_paragraph: Humans have probably been pondering the flight of birds as long as there have been humans. And in the age of science, it would seem that every aspect of flight had been studied in order to build flying machines, from passenger airplanes to tiny robots.

headline: The 10 Best Dressed at the 57th Grammy Awards
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Grammy Awards', 'Music']
abstract: Stars honored a more serious tone than usual at last night’s event and opted for monochromatic, glamorous looks.
lead_paragraph: At the Grammy awards, showstopping red carpet looks are usually only outdone by shocking onstage performance costumes. But this year, the most dramatic trend was the color black; and in a move as respectful and somber as many of last night’s messages (moments during the telecast acknowledged and condemned domestic and racially motivated violence), singers left their gimmicky, theatrical costumes at home. Instead they stepped out in their monochromatic and glamorous best, which was for the most part either marked by cutouts or inspired by men’s dressing.

headline: Afghan Strike Is Said to Kill Commander Linked to ISIS
abstract: If confirmed, a strike against Mullah Abdul Rauf Khadim would be the first known military operation undertaken against the Islamic State in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A former Taliban commander who had recently pledged allegiance to the Islamic State militant group was killed in a military operation in Helmand Province on Monday, according to Afghan officials and a tribal elder in the area.

headline: Jeb Bush Website With 250,000 Emails Will Start Tuesday
abstract: Jeb Bush said he would launch a website that would include the release of roughly 250,000 emails from his time as governor of Florida, as well as the first chapter of an e-book about his administration.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush said he would launch a website on Tuesday on which he will make available about 250,000 emails from his time as governor of Florida, as well as the first chapter of an e-book about his administration.

headline: Charlie Chaplin’s First Oscar Is Reported Stolen
abstract: The statuette was an honorary one, bestowed at the first Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Charlie Chaplin’s 1929 honorary Oscar statuette was stolen in Paris late last month from the offices of the Association Chaplin, according to the organization.

headline: Pope Francis As Unifier
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Beatifications and Canonizations', 'Priests', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: On Oscar Romero, bishop accountability for sex abuse, and the possibility of a depolarizing pope.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Jorge Bergoglio became Pope Francis, I wrote several pieces exploring the idea that the new pope might be striving to effectively transcend the liberal/conservative civil war that’s dominated Catholic life in the West since the Second Vatican Council, and find a new synthesis or center for the church somewhere beyond that post-1960s conflict. I have not written as much on that theme in the last year, mostly because of what’s been happening with the debate around divorce and communion: There the pope’s choices have at least temporarily added fuel to Catholicism’s internal conflict, rather than cooling it, in ways that threaten to overshadow other elements of his agenda, other possibilities for his time as Peter.

headline: Ruble’s Fall Tests Governor of Russia’s Central Bank
abstract: Elvira S. Nabiullina, governor of the Bank of Russia, views the ruble’s steep drop as a painful but necessary step to wean the nation off imports.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Elvira S. Nabiullina, the governor of Russia’s central bank, was deep into a speech about her new currency policy when it became clear nobody was paying attention.

headline: Partying After the Grammys
abstract: Warner Music Group hosted a party at the Chateau Marmont, and GQ and Giorgio Armani joined forces at the Hollywood Athletic Club.
lead_paragraph: Warner Music Group hosted a party at the Chateau Marmont, and GQ and Giorgio Armani joined forces at the Hollywood Athletic Club.

headline: For Its Next Big Project, Creative Time Heads to Central Park
abstract: Following last year’s blockbuster Kara Walker installation, the nonprofit will feature seven to 10 sculptural, social and interactive works in the park.
lead_paragraph: It was hard to miss the nonprofit public arts organization Creative Time’s most recent large-scale production, the artist Kara Walker’s blockbuster “A Subtlety,” staged at the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn last spring. If you didn’t catch it in person, surely you saw it on Instagram, where it seemed every one of its 140,000 visitors took a selfie to commemorate the pilgrimage. This year, Creative Time will head to Manhattan with “Drifting in Daylight: Art in Central Park,” which will feature seven to 10 sculptural, social and interactive works commissioned by the Central Park Conservancy to celebrate its 35 years of stewardship of the island’s largest green space.

headline: My Little Pony and Transformers Toys Help Lift Hasbro Sales, and Its Profit Jumps
abstract: Brian Goldner, the toymaker’s president and chief executive, credited the strength of the company’s Transformers and My Little Pony franchise with helping to drive sales.
lead_paragraph: Strong sales of Transformers action figures, My Little Pony products and other licensed toys helped Hasbro’s revenue rise 5 percent last year, despite negative currency fluctuations and broader industry woes.

headline: Partying After the Grammys
abstract: Barely skipping a beat, when the Grammy ceremonies ended the festivities migrated from Staples Center to parties all over Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: After Sam Smith crooned and Kanye West robo-sang, the Grammy action on Sunday night migrated from Staples Center to parties all over the Los Angeles area.

headline: Lincoln Center Segal Awards Expand Field of Honorees
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Classical Music', 'Dancing', 'Music', 'Segal, Martin E,  Awards']
abstract: The Martin E. Segal Awards will be given to 11 rising artists this year, up from two in past years.
lead_paragraph: In the 28 years since they were established the Martin E. Segal Awards have involved a low-key luncheon that honors two rising artists chosen by two of Lincoln Center’s 11 resident organizations. Each was awarded $7,500, to be used for career advancement and future study.

headline: Twyla Tharp to Debut New Works on Anniversary Tour
abstract: Ms. Tharp and 12 dancers will perform a program of new work, set to music by Bach, Henry Butler and John Zorn, across the country this fall.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Twyla Tharp is celebrating the 50th anniversary of her choreographic debut with a national tour this fall. Ms. Tharp said on Monday that she plans to take 12 dancers on the road performing a program of new works set to music by Bach, Henry Butler, Steven Bernstein and John Zorn. The tour is to open in Dallas on Sept. 18, and will include stops in Beverly Hills, Calif.; Chicago; Denver; and Washington — with stops in at least 15 cities total — before wrapping up at Lincoln Center on Nov. 22. A detailed schedule has yet to be announced.

headline: A Business Plan for Space
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration gave a foundation to U.S. companies seeking a foothold on celestial bodies by saying it would make sure businesses wouldn’t interfere with one another.
lead_paragraph: Who can own the moon? Or an asteroid? Or a homestead on Mars?

headline: Training the Mind Not to Wander
abstract: Students at Princeton had their brain activity monitored, and learned to recognize that their attention was lagging.
lead_paragraph: A wandering mind can lead to accidents and lost productivity. Now, a study finds that real-time brain monitoring can be used to help people regain focus.

lead_paragraph: Richard Trumka is the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation’s main labor federation.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The latest conflict between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel erupted into public view on Monday, as the two leaders clashed from afar over Mr. Netanyahu’s plans to visit Washington next month and the direction of negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: Rubio, Eye on 2016, Hires a Coveted Former Aide to Romney
abstract: Jim Merrill, who directed both of Mr. Romney’s New Hampshire primary bids, is joining Mr. Rubio’s political action committee as a senior adviser, a position that would put him at the helm of the Florida senator’s eventual campaign in the first-in-the-nation state.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio has hired a coveted former aide to Mitt Romney to oversee his political activities in the Northeast and probably in a New Hampshire campaign, signaling that he is serious about a presidential bid.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: More than 100 migrants were rescued in rough seas, but the others perished before the Italian Coast Guard could get them to shore, officials said.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Twenty-nine migrants who were rescued alive in rough seas off the Libyan coast died before the Italian Coast Guard could get them to shore, officials said on Monday.

headline: Joan Didion: From the Face of Céline to the Subject of a New Photography Exhibition
abstract: This Thursday, Julian Wasser’s images of the iconic American author will be on display at New York City’s Danziger Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Last month, an online fracas erupted when Céline released its campaign featuring a sunglass-shaded, 80-year-old Joan Didion photographed by Juergen Teller. Was the image a step forward for feminism, or had Didion’s personal style eclipsed the substance of her work? Julian Wasser, for his part, was merely perplexed. “I don’t know how that happened,” says the photographer from his home in Los Angeles. “I don’t know how she fit into that, because she’s just a down-to-earth, regular person.”

headline: Turning Carbon Dioxide Into Rock, and Burying It

lead_paragraph: HENGILL, Iceland — In a cramped work trailer not far from Iceland’s largest geothermal power plant, a researcher pored over a box of core samples — cylinders of rock that a drilling rig had pulled from deep underground just a few minutes before.

headline: Matt Harvey, in Camp Early, Says His Arm Feels Strong

lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered micro-organisms living beneath the ocean floor that appear to have not evolved for more than two billion years, a finding that nonetheless may support the theory of evolution.

lead_paragraph: In his dissent, Justice Thomas denounced the Supreme Court’s decision not to intervene in Alabama’s legal dispute regarding same-sex marriage.

headline: Justice Thomas’s Dissent Hints of Supreme Court’s Intentions on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Justice Clarence Thomas’s dissent was a strong signal that gay rights advocates are likely to prevail in their quest to establish a nationwide constitutional right to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Monday not to delay same-sex marriage in Alabama offered the strongest signal yet that gay rights advocates are likely to prevail in coming months in their decades-long quest to establish a nationwide constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

headline: Don’t Speak to Congress, Mr. Netanyahu
abstract: A speech will scuttle discussion of Iran’s nuclear program and will not promote Israel’s interests.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — If Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is correct, if the leaks are to be believed, the Obama administration is edging toward an agreement with Iran that would temporarily restrict, but not eliminate, Iran’s capacity to eventually produce nuclear weapons. The government of Israel finds these terms dangerous.

headline: Review: ‘Tuck Everlasting’ Swaps Out the Circle of Life for an Eternally Unspooling Ribbon
abstract: A musical based on a 1975 children’s book focuses on a girl who discovers a local family’s secret: a magical pool of water that confers immortality.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A ballet was once a staple of the American musical in the 1940s, when the form first grew to maturity. But dancers swirling through dream sequences haven’t been seen much for the past few decades or more, as more vernacular movement — or little dance at all — has become standard. So it’s a wonder, and a pleasure, that the stirring climax of the new family musical “Tuck Everlasting,” making its premiere at the Alliance Theater here, consists of a gorgeous, sweeping ballet that dramatizes the life of its heroine, as she grows from young girl to young woman to motherhood and beyond.

headline: Greece to Propose a Debt Compromise Plan to Creditors
abstract: In a shift, the new government will propose accepting its next bailout loan payment and fulfill most — but not all — of its austerity obligations.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Hoping to defuse a standoff that has set Europe and financial markets on edge, Greek officials intend to propose a detailed compromise plan at an emergency meeting with creditors on Wednesday in Brussels, a finance ministry official here said on Monday.

headline: European Leaders Debate Aid to Ukraine, but Not Russia’s Transgressions
abstract: As Angela Merkel and American officials disagree over supplying weapons to Ukraine, John Kerry says “there is no split.”
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — It was at the venerable Munich Security Conference in 2007 that Vladimir Putin first sounded the resentful Cold War blast that now defines his foreign policy, bitterly accusing the United States of seeking a monopoly on global power. Subsequent Munich conferences were marked by desultory efforts to “reset” the relationship, to maintain the appearance at least of collegiality. All that was before Ukraine.

headline: A Never-Ending Genetic Quest
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Breast Cancer', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mary-Claire King discovered BRCA1, the so-called breast cancer gene, and now believes every woman should be tested.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a scientific career quite like Mary-Claire King’s. Years ago, her doctoral thesis concluded that humans and chimpanzees were, genetically speaking, 99 percent the same — a revolutionary thought. Her later work on human cancers resulted in the discovery of the so-called breast cancer gene, BRCA1, which transformed the diagnosis and treatment of the disease.

headline: An Incubator for Innovation

lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — To halt climate change, the world desperately needs advances in clean energy. But in recent years, Silicon Valley, the nation’s engine for technical innovation, has turned its back on investments in the field.

headline: Review: A Jerome Robbins Tribute by New York City Ballet Brims With Brio
abstract: When Americans took their turn in this company’s “Hear the Dance” series, the spotlight was on the choreographer most closely connected with it.
lead_paragraph: This season, New York City Ballet has been organizing some of its repertory programs by nationality of composer. American composers got their turn during the Saturday matinee at the David H. Koch Theater. Yet the American most heavily represented was a choreographer: Jerome Robbins.

headline: Review: ‘Being Mortal’ and ‘The Forgotten Plague’ Explore Death and Disease
abstract: One PBS documentary explores how doctors communicate with the terminally ill and another traces the history of tuberculosis in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The end of life. The very end. The worst-case scenario. What might happen down the road. The issue. The unfixable problem.

headline: Review: In ‘The Whites,’ Richard Price Tries on a Pseudonym in a World of Brooding Cops
abstract: Writing as Harry Brandt, Richard Price follows characters, many of them New York detectives, haunted by, and hunting for, unpunished criminals.
lead_paragraph: “The Whites,” the title of Richard Price’s riveting new novel, is a reference to the great white whale in “Moby-Dick” — a book that seems to be a kind of touchstone for the author (writing here under the pen name Harry Brandt), having popped up, at least glancingly, in such earlier novels as “Clockers” and “Freedomland.” This time, the parallels to Melville’s classic are beyond obvious: All of the story’s main characters are haunted by something terrible that happened in the past, and all are obsessed with hunting down their nemeses.

headline: In Nevada, a Controversy in the Wind
abstract: Scientists and state officials disagree over the risk posed by naturally occurring asbestos, which covers much of the landscape in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, the geologists Brenda Buck and Rodney Metcalf have combed the wild terrain of southern Nevada, analyzing its stony dunes and rocky outcroppings — and to their dismay, tallying mounting evidence of a landscape filled with asbestos.

headline: Was Brian Williams a Victim of False Memory?
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Lying', 'Memory', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Our memories can deceive us — and they often do, studies show.
lead_paragraph: How reliable is human memory? Most of us believe that our memory is like a video camera, capturing an accurate record that can be reviewed at a later date.

headline: Hannibal Buress Evolves From Cult Star to Showman

headline: Review: Gamelan Ensemble Hammers Out Ritual Rhythms of Bali
abstract: A group of keepers and presenters of a cultural and musical tradition of Bali, the Gamelan Dharma Swara ensemble, performed at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: A Balinese gamelan orchestra is an intricate machine of connected parts, speaking in a highly articulated language built over many centuries. The music it plays is composed and vigorous, ceremonial and ritualized, intensely visual and movement-oriented when it includes dancers and singers, bright with the silver sounds of hammers striking metallophones, usually designed with five or seven notes to the octave.

headline: Atlantic Corals: Colorful and Vulnerable

headline: Review: Anna Netrebko Saves the Day for the Met Orchestra

He and his players were also inspired for Elliott Carter’s “Three Illusions,” a nine-minute work in three movements completed in 2004 when the composer turned 96.

headline: A Ceramics Shop Pops Up Under a Neem Tree in India
abstract: The Austrian artist Matthias Kaiser will be selling his handmade wares for a mere $1 and $2 each — decidedly local prices in the city of Ahmedabad.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade after he spent his meandering postcollegiate years on the Indian subcontinent studying Sufi mysticism and following a musical guru, the Austrian artist Matthias Kaiser returns today to open a pop-up ceramics shop under a neem tree in Ahmedabad, India. He’s stocked the roadside stall with art made, as always, of loosely interpreted recollections: a kiln’s worth of functional vessels carrying the echoes of papaya and potato chaat, Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret’s modernist city of Chandigarh and “hairless dogs, three-wheeled tractors and giant moving haystacks that had a truck hidden somewhere underneath,” Kaiser explains.

Ms. McDonald will play the strong-willed Josie, a farmer’s daughter who plots against their alcoholic landlord, James Tyrone Jr. (Mr. Swenson), only to find charged emotional connections with him. Gordon Edelstein will direct the play, which will run Aug. 5-23 on the festival’s main stage.

abstract: A reinvigorated liberal agenda has emerged in the months since the midterm elections, aimed at issues of interest to the middle class.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, one could be forgiven for wondering whether the liberal agenda had run its course. With near-universal health care — the unfinished business of the 20th-century Democratic Party — enacted, there was no obvious next step in the party’s mission of expanding the safety net. The big Democratic policies yet to be fully addressed, like immigration overhaul and restrictions on carbon emissions, pitted the party’s new progressive constituencies against its traditional, white working-class base.

headline: To Save Money on Building Rail, Spend Money on Marketing Buses
abstract: Transit agencies are building rail lines at great expense even when they’re no faster than bus service.
lead_paragraph: “Bus-based public transit in the United States suffers from an image problem.”

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (TCM) CHARADE (1963) A Parisian widow (Audrey Hepburn) tries to find her murdered husband’s hidden fortune with the help of a vacation acquaintance (Cary Grant) while eluding the killers who want it themselves in this romantic, Hitchcockian caper directed by Stanley Donen. And while this film includes scenes of “ghoulish humor” and “gruesome violence,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, “there’s a lot to be said for it as a fast-moving, urbane entertainment.” Hepburn, he added, “is cheerfully committed to a mood of how-nuts-can-you-be in an obviously comforting assortment of expensive Givenchy costumes, and Mr. Grant does everything from taking a shower without removing his suit to fighting with thugs, all with the blandness and the boredom of an old screwball comedy hand.” Henry Mancini and Johnny Mercer received an Oscar nomination for their song “Charade.”

headline: History of Lynchings in the South Documents Nearly 4,000 Names
abstract: After compiling an inventory of 3,959 lynching victims in 12 Southern states from 1877 to 1950, the Equal Justice Initiative wants to erect markers and memorials on certain sites.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — A block from the tourist-swarmed headquarters of the former Texas School Book Depository sits the old county courthouse, now a museum. In 1910, a group of men rushed into the courthouse, threw a rope around the neck of a black man accused of sexually assaulting a 3-year-old white girl, and threw the other end of the rope out a window. A mob outside yanked the man, Allen Brooks, to the ground and strung him up at a ceremonial arch a few blocks down Main Street.

headline: University President Sees Echoes of Cultural Revolution in New Campaign
abstract: A Chinese university president has offered a warning about the Communist Party’s drive to cleanse universities of liberal Western textbooks.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Communist Party’s drive to cleanse universities of liberal Western textbooks and other ideological heresies has assumed the features of an archetypal political campaign. After orders from the party leadership, officials and university administrators, with the education minister leading the way, have lined up to demonstrate their allegiance, and state-run media outlets have offered a chorus of approving commentaries.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — She claimed that her employer kicked her and beat her with a vacuum cleaner pipe. She said that she was given only one bottle of water a day to minimize toilet breaks, was forced to sleep on the floor and became emaciated for lack of food.

headline: Insurance and Its Discontents
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: The company was reluctant to provide coverage. For my patient, fighting back became a kind of treatment.
lead_paragraph: The phone call came two billing cycles after Ben and I had increased his session frequency to twice a week. A woman identifying herself as “an independently licensed care advocate” with a large insurance company left a message asking me to call back. My neck tightened. No psychologist wants to hear from an insurer. Like some ne’er-do-well relative, insurers call only when they want money — or rather, when they want to keep money they’d once promised to disburse.

headline: The Riddle of Powering Electric Cars
abstract: A new book goes inside the race to build the perfect electric car.
lead_paragraph: Steve LeVine became interested in batteries in the wake of the financial crisis. LeVine is the Washington correspondent for Quartz, a news site covering the global economy, and he sensed, he told me recently, “a loss of confidence in the U.S. in our ability to create a real economy” — one based not on financial instruments or a real estate boom, but real products that would help create entire new industries.

keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Measles', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief', 'Epidemics', 'Freedom of Religion']

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — MEASLES is back. Last year, about 650 cases were reported in the United States — the largest outbreak in almost 20 years. This year, more than a hundred have already been reported.

headline: When Colleges Use Veterans as Pawns
abstract: Congress should support a proposal in President Obama’s 2016 budget that would close a loophole that takes advantage of G.I. Bill recipients.
lead_paragraph: For-profit colleges that burden students with crippling debt — often while giving them useless credentials in return — are luring veterans who receive G.I. Bill benefits to take advantage of a loophole in federal law. On the merits, a proposal in President Obama’s 2016 budget that would close this destructive loophole deserves unanimous support in Congress. But because the for-profit industry has considerable power in Washington, veterans may be let down.

headline: Reform After the Ebola Debacle
abstract: To right its anemic performance, the World Health Organization has endorsed changes to respond more quickly to the next outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization’s anemic performance in handling the Ebola outbreaks in West Africa may yield one positive outcome: sweeping, and long overdue, institutional reforms to improve its ability to respond more quickly to the next outbreak of a lethal infectious disease. Scrambling to answer growing criticism, the W.H.O.’s executive board recently endorsed changes to enhance the agency’s rapid response capabilities.

headline: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s Defense: He Didn’t Know Prostitutes Were at the Orgies
abstract: The former I.M.F. chief, who acknowledges a libertine lifestyle, stands accused with 13 others of pimping and of aiding and abetting the prostitution of seven women.
lead_paragraph: LILLE, France — There was testimony about lavish sex parties with high-flying power brokers and prostitutes. There were questions about whether certain sex acts were entirely consensual, and the finer points of libertinage. For good measure, topless protesters threw themselves at the car carrying the chief defendant, a man once expected to be president of France, Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

headline: Kenji Ekuan, Who Gave Soy Sauce Its Graceful Curves, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Ekuan’s work included some of the products most closely associated with postwar Japan, including Yamaha motorcycles and bullet trains.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kenji Ekuan, a Japanese industrial designer whose instantly recognizable soy sauce bottle — red-capped and elegantly teardrop-shaped — became one of his country’s most ubiquitous postwar exports, died here on Sunday. He was 85.

headline: Giving Airbnb a Run for Its Money
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: A handful of upstart sites is striving to disrupt the vacation rental market by appealing to families with children or jet-setters seeking luxury villas.
lead_paragraph: When travelers think about vacation rentals, they almost always think of Airbnb. The easy-to-use site, founded in 2008 and now with more than a million listings worldwide, is the first stop for many tourists — which means properties are snapped up fast, especially during major events such as concerts, games and conferences. Yet a handful of new contenders is striving to disrupt the vacation rental market by targeting specific kinds of travelers, be it families with children or jet-setters seeking luxury villas and airport transfers by helicopter. Below, a guide to some of the upstarts and, at the end of this column, a reminder of some veteran sites that all too often end up in the shadow of Airbnb.

headline: Sophia Loren on Her Life in Hotels
abstract: A decades-long film career has taken the iconic Italian actress around the world. She shares her favorite places.
lead_paragraph: The actress Sophia Loren is a symbol of Italy to generations of moviegoers. Born in Rome on Sept. 20, 1934, as Sofia Villani Scicolone, she was raised outside Naples and suffered intense deprivation during World War II. As Italy entered the postwar “Dolce Vita” era, she became a star of Cinecittá, Rome’s film industry center. She won an Oscar in 1962 for her performance in “La Ciociara,” or “Two Women,” about wartime Italy. Her memoir, “Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow: My Life,” was published late last year by Atria Books. She is the mother of Carlo Jr. and Edoardo, with her husband, the producer Carlo Ponti, who died in 2007. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Loren.

In the final stages of a long-running investigation into corruption in the world’s biggest financial market, federal prosecutors have recently informed Barclays, JPMorgan Chase, the Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup that they must enter guilty pleas to settle the cases, according to lawyers briefed on the matter.

So perhaps it should come as no surprise that just in time for fashion week, which begins on Thursday, there’s a new crossover candidate: Margaret Cho — boundary-pushing comedian/author/actor and, now, jumpsuit designer.

Originally shown as the C-X16 concept drawn by Jaguar’s design director, Ian Callum, the production version remains remarkably true to his vision.

headline: In Performance: Ailyn Pérez of ‘Carmen’
abstract: The up­-and­-coming soprano sings an excerpt from Micaëla’s aria.
lead_paragraph: Ailyn Pérez, an up­-and­-coming soprano who has been making the rounds of major opera houses in Vienna, London, Berlin and Milan, made her Metropolitan Opera debut this month as Micaëla in a revival of Bizet’s “Carmen.” Ms. Pérez, who won the 2012 Richard Tucker Award, was praised for her performance by Zachary Woolfe, who wrote in The New York Times that she was a “confident, forthright presence in a role that can fade into merely demure.” Here she is singing a decidedly non­demure rendition of Micaëla’s aria.

headline: 1940: U.S. Talks With Neutral States
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. begins peace talks with other neutral states in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The beginning of informal diplomatic conversations between the United States and other neutral nations for the purpose of exploring possibilities of ‘‘the eventual restoration of world peace on a sound and lasting basis for all nations’’ was announced today [Feb. 10] by Secretary of State Cordell Hull. The latest American peace venture, Secretary Hull indicated, is aimed at long- term economic objectives rather than an immediate cessation of hostilities. He also declared that there is no connection between the present conversations and the forthcoming European tour of Under Secretary Sumner Welles. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1940

headline: A Van Cleef & Arpels Bracelet That Plays a Pretty Trick on the Eye
abstract: Creating the bangle’s elaborate architecture required nearly 500 hours and the skill of 10 craftspeople.
lead_paragraph: Van Cleef & Arpels’s beguiling, one-of-a-kind bejeweled gold cuff is a riff on 1960s Op Art. When opened and laid flat — dozens of ribs make it as flexible as rope despite its rounded heft — the bracelet appears to be made of small interlocking onyx circles dotted with diamonds. But when clasped around the wrist, the circles part to reveal a dense underlayer of cultured pearls affixed to the armature. A contrasting row of emeralds leads the way to the slyly hidden closure. Creating the bangle’s elaborate architecture required nearly 500 hours and the skill of 10 craftspeople — Van Cleef’s so-called “Mains d’Or,” or golden hands — among them a designer, a model maker, a lapidary, a gem setter and experts in hard stones, pearls and diamonds. Together, they’ve woven a rich illusion indeed.

headline: Pride, Prejudice, Prostitutes and Pickles: Scholars Unearth Two Letters Relating to Jane Austen
abstract: Two previously unpublished letters written by Jane Austen’s brother Charles could shed a suggestive and unexpectedly saucy light on the ways her literary reputation was kept alive after her death in 1817.
lead_paragraph: Newly discovered Jane Austen artifacts can always be counted on to cause a stir, as when a scholar claimed several years ago to have found a previously unknown pencil portrait of the Divine Miss Jane.

lead_paragraph: Let them read Houellebecq! In a push to enhance the profile of French writers and French literary culture, the cultural services of the French Embassy in New York has been signing up independent bookstores across the United States to create special sections, called French Corners, to display French works in the original and in translation.

headline: Kanye West, Beck, Papa John and Other Grammy Awards Stars
abstract: In a special post-Grammys Popcast, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the flap over Beck’s album win, Iggy Azalea vs. Papa John and other highlights.
lead_paragraph: The same old things happened at the Grammy Awards on Sunday night. Popular young musicians were misunderstood and underused, older musicians were framed with indulgent clarity, a soft-edged (and not very popular) choice was voted album of the year. Corniness and bad aesthetics ran rampant. Various factions on Twitter flipped out at regular intervals.

headline: 1965: Bomb Hits G.I. Barracks
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Viet Cong bomb G.I. barracks in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Communist Viet Cong terrorists blew up a U.S. Army barracks tonight [Feb. 10], inflicting heavy loss of life, a U.S. military spokesman reported. One American has already been found dead and 14 others were wounded. Another 30 Americans were missing in the blast and were believed dead under the wreckage. About 60 men lived in the four-story hotel used as a barrack at Qui Nhon, 250 miles northeast of here, but several of them were away when the explosion occurred, the spokesman said. He said the hotel was ‘‘completely destroyed.’’— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1965

headline: What Is the Best Portrayal of a Marriage in Literature?

headline: Terrorist Claims Return Sept. 11 Suit to Spotlight
abstract: In 2002, victims’ families sued the government of Saudi Arabia and the Saudi elite, including banks, charities and even members of the royal family, accusing them of financing Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ron Motley could have come straight out of a John Grisham novel, a charismatic Southern trial lawyer with the swagger of a man who had bet big in life and usually won.

headline: Starwood Hotels to Split Off Time-Share Business
abstract: Starwood said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its time-share division into a separate publicly traded company, joining the swelling ranks of corporations breaking themselves up.
lead_paragraph: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its time-share division into a separate publicly traded company, joining the swelling ranks of corporations breaking themselves up.

headline: Review: In Jorie’s Graham’s ‘From the New World,’ Flux Is a Whirling Constant
abstract: Jorie Graham’s latest collection underlines how important it is to suspend reason while reading her poems and allow the words to wash over you.
lead_paragraph: Wild is the wind that rushes through so many of Jorie Graham’s poems. It sends birds spiraling aloft. It ripples lakes and ponds, making the sun glint. It pushes around the leaves, blades of grass and tree limbs that appear in stanza after stanza. Updraft or downdraft, her gusty poems declare, Hang onto your hat.

headline: In a League of Flying Elbows, the Use of Mouth Guards Soars
abstract: Once the standard of football players, the innocuous piece of equipment has taken the N.B.A. by storm, and the benefits of wearing one may go beyond simply shielding one’s teeth.
lead_paragraph: By joining the growing faction of N.B.A. players who choose to wear a mouth guard in games, a player is forced to confront a certain small issue: Where do you keep the thing when you’re on the bench?

headline: Doulas, a Growing Force in Maternity Culture, Seek Greater Acceptance
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Doulas assist, assure, educate and advocate on behalf of pregnant women, but because of resistance from the medical profession and lack of insurance reimbursement, they are still a small part of the system.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of the day Marisa Pizarro gave birth, the usual tumult reigned in her apartment in Lower Manhattan’s financial district. Her husband, a music producer known as J Grand, in shower sandals and gym shorts, was busy tending to their toddler daughter, the financial news on TV and his iPad, where he was still rearranging tracks on a forthcoming release.

headline: Senate Panel, 25-0, Backs Ashton Carter for Defense Post
abstract: The Senate Armed Services Committee voted in a unanimous, bipartisan 25-0 vote to support the confirmation of Ashton B. Carter as the next Secretary of Defense.
lead_paragraph: The Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday voted unanimously — 25-0 — to approve the nomination of Ashton B. Carter as the next defense secretary.

headline: With Proof From ISIS of Her Death, Family Honors Kayla Mueller
abstract: The Islamic State, which had held Kayla Mueller captive since August 2013, sent her parents at least three photographs of her corpse as proof of death.
lead_paragraph: For one tortured weekend, the parents of Kayla Mueller refused to believe that their daughter was dead. From their home in Prescott, Ariz., they issued an impassioned plea to the Islamic State, which had held her captive since August 2013, and urged the extremist organization to contact them privately with proof of her death. The militants acquiesced and sent at least three photographs of her corpse.

headline: Up Close And Delusional
abstract: Don’t judge politicians by how they come across.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait notes that people are still trying to cast Paul Ryan as reasonable and moderate — hey, he visits bookstores favored by liberals. As Chait says, this sort of political evaluation by personal style is unreliable at best; and Ryan quite clearly deliberately exploits it, too, making moderate noises without ever giving an inch on his hard-line right-wing policies. Remember, this is the guy who pretended to offer a budget based on fiscal responsibility, but when you took out the magic asterisks it was really tax cuts for the rich, severe benefit cuts for the poor, and overall would actually increase the deficit.

headline: Obama Had Statement to Read if Terror Halted Inauguration
abstract: Rahm Emanuel instructed David Axelrod to draft a statement that could be read in place of an inauguration address if an attack turned out to be imminent.
lead_paragraph: The night before President Obama was inaugurated in 2009, David Axelrod got a call from an agitated Rahm Emanuel, the president-elect’s chief of staff, according to Mr. Axelrod’s book, “Believer,” which was released on Tuesday.

headline: Kayla Mueller’s Letter to Her Family
abstract: After news of her death was confirmed, Ms. Mueller’s family released a copy of an unpublished letter that she wrote to her loved ones in the spring of 2014.

headline: U.S. Embassy Shuts in Yemen, Even as Militant Leader Reaches Out
abstract: As the State Department advised Americans to leave, Saleh Ali al-Sammad, a senior Houthi leader, said the group wanted to share power with its political rivals and maintain good relations with allies.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — In his first interview since the Yemeni government collapsed, the leader of the Houthi militants who control Sana, the capital, depicted his movement as eager to share power with its rivals and to reach out to the country’s traditional allies, including the United States and Saudi Arabia — even as the American Embassy prepared to shut down.

headline: From Israel, a Drama That Started a National Debate About Divorce
abstract: The film follows the travails of a wife seeking a gett, the document that she needs under Jewish law to end her marriage.
lead_paragraph: In the early stages of the competition for the Oscar for best foreign language film, Israel’s submission, “Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem,” impressed so many observers that it was considered a shoo-in for the shortlist. That ended up not happening, even though “Gett” was nominated for a Golden Globe. But the film’s writers and directors, the sister-and-brother team of Ronit and Shlomi Elkabetz, have other satisfactions: their film has set off an impassioned debate in Israel about changing that country’s restrictive divorce laws.

abstract: A federal health panel has proposed that the illness now be called systemic exertion intolerance disease, in part to reduce stigma.

The December wind off the harbor that was shaking the little brick buildings in Red Hook, Brooklyn, was keeping everybody at home, ordering pad see ew and massaman curry from the new neighborhood Thai place.

For the 91-year-old Suggs, the wonders never cease. On Tuesday she was one of seven women offered honorary membership in the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, which voted last September to end its all-male policy.

headline: Binders Full of Women Foreign Policy Experts
abstract: U.S. foreign policy, and media representation in general, needs to be disrupted beyond the gender fault-line — ethnically, racially and geographically.
lead_paragraph: As mind-boggling world events dominated headlines last summer, an impressive number of women reported first-hand from various hot spots. Sabrina Tavernise arrived on the scene of downed Malaysian Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine even as the plane still burned. Alissa Rubin escaped death in a helicopter crash in Iraq. Anne Barnard delivered harrowing dispatches from Gaza. And yet, when it came time for round table analysis, grey suits continued to deluge the discussion.

headline: Neil Patrick Harris on Hosting His First Academy Awards
abstract: The actor reminisces about his childhood viewing parties.
lead_paragraph: When I used to watch the Oscars at home with my family, we would print out ballots, write down our predictions and see who won. As I got older, our viewing parties had more of a gambling slant — same ballot, different stakes. Now they just involve more drinking, and when it’s at my house, there’s a lot of Velveeta and Pace Picante.

At the same time, some officials who had refused to issue the licenses, in compliance with a state judicial ruling, reversed course.

headline: For Many Veterans, ‘American Sniper,’ Right or Wrong, Starts an Important Conversation
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Douglas W. Jackson, a former Marine and Iraq veteran, writes that what the movie “American Sniper” gets right — or wrong –depends on who’s watching. But he thinks the film could play an important role in reminding both veterans and civilians of how unresolved the war’s recent history is.
lead_paragraph: This week, the trial of the man accused of killing Chris Kyle opens in a Texas courtroom, even as the Clint Eastwood film based on Mr. Kyle’s life, “American Sniper,” is playing in a theater three miles away. Much as Mr. Kyle’s death shocked the nation, the film has generated fierce debate nationally over the meaning of his life and his death, and the Iraq war itself. To some, Mr. Kyle represents all that was right with the American-led invasion, to others, all that was wrong. Yet to many veterans, his story offers a chance to discuss and debate a remarkable array of complex and personal questions: the mix of motivations that lead people to sign up in the military, the riot of emotions troops feel when they kill or witness death, the struggle to reengage with civilian society upon coming home. A number of people have sent At War essays about how they viewed the film, including the piece below by a former Marine. What do you think? Send us your thoughts: atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: Will Greece Ever Get Out of Debtor’s Prison?
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: It’s time for a joint solution between Greece, which has more debt than it can ever repay, and its creditors.
lead_paragraph: The efforts of the new Greek government to write off a portion of its debt are being cast by powerful European policy makers as a bid for “debt forgiveness.” But the whole concept of “forgiveness” implies that there is a magnanimous creditor and a profligate borrower, and that’s just not true. Greece now has more debt than it can ever repay, and lenders share some of the blame for this.

headline: The Case Against the Case Against the Crusades
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Crusades (Christianity)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Pilgrimages', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: On the problem with comprehensive moral judgments of complicated historical conflicts.
lead_paragraph: In my Sunday column on the controversy surrounding President Obama’s National Prayer Breakfast speech, I tried to explain what I saw as the problems with the president’s “high horse” references to Western Christian sins without letting the column get sucked down too deep into the quicksand of historical-moral controversy. But now (because what else are blogs for?) let’s step a little deeper into that quicksand, and talk a little bit about the Crusades, the most contested of the various examples — the others were Jim Crow, slavery, and the Inquisition — that the president cited as Islamic State-like case studies in which Christianity was used as a license for cruelty and persecution. The references to slavery and segregation inspired debates about how deeply religion was implicated in those institutions (the short answer: a lot more deeply than many Christian conservatives care to admit today, though not in exactly the same way that religion is implicated in the crimes of ISIS; the South was many things, including a home to terrorism, but it was not a utopian theocracy); the reference to the Inquisition inspired some discussion of just how bad the institution really was (the answer: not as bad as Black Legend-style history would have it, but at its worst quite, quite bad enough). But only the Crusades inspired a debate about whether they deserve to be condemned at all.

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuelan officials on Tuesday announced details of what they said would be a free market in which people and businesses could exchange local currency for dollars — an easing of the tightly controlled exchange rates that critics say have fed the nation’s economic crisis.

headline: Twitter Finance Chief’s Account Briefly Seized by Spammer
abstract: The social network says that the account of its chief financial officer, Anthony Noto, was used to send a blast of spam on Tuesday. The company is investigating the incident.
lead_paragraph: A lot of Twitter users find the nuances of the social network difficult to navigate, such as the difference between private direct messages and public replies and what level of access that third-party apps get to your Twitter account if you use it to sign in or post content from them.

headline: Netanyahu Will Proceed With U.S. Speech
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he would give his speech to Congress, as he has a profound disagreement with the United States over negotiations with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he would give his speech to Congress, as he has a profound disagreement with the United States over negotiations with Iran.

headline: Review: In ‘Schitt’s Creek,’ a Spoiled Little Rich Family Starts Over
abstract: It’s nice to see Eugene Levy and Catherine O’Hara working together, although this new show is drab and underwritten.
lead_paragraph: Has anyone given us more pleasure playing perfectly oddly matched couples than Eugene Levy and Catherine O’Hara? As the dog-owning Flecks in Christopher Guest’s “Best in Show” and the folk-singing Mitch and Mickey in his “A Mighty Wind,” they perfected a mix of barbed deadpan (Mr. Levy) and vibrant loopiness (Ms. O’Hara) that was crucial to those films’ special brand of warmly lunatic humor.

headline: Low Vitamin D in Childhood Linked to Later Heart Risks
abstract: Vitamin D deficiency in childhood may be linked to hardening of the arteries in middle age, a study has found.
lead_paragraph: Vitamin D deficiency in childhood may be linked to hardening of the arteries in middle age, a long-term Finnish study has found.

headline: Review: ‘Building Wonders’ Examines Ancient Structures on ‘Nova’
abstract: This series analyzes construction of the Colosseum, Petra and Hagia Sophia.
lead_paragraph: “Building Wonders,” a three-part series within the PBS show “Nova,” tries hard to take the miraculousness out of three formidable ancient structures but, happily, it fails. If anything, the programs leave you even more impressed with their subjects: the Colosseum, the stone city of Petra and Hagia Sophia.

headline: Review: Thomas Hampson’s Conflict Resolutions
abstract: In his Carnegie Hall recital on Monday, this veteran baritone moved easily from topic to topic, often through the lens of war and the works they inspired.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you had this professor in college: the learned, old-fashioned one, long settled in his post, whose lectures would emerge in a stream-of-consciousness ramble. The veteran baritone Thomas Hampson’s recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday felt like one of those lectures, sauntering from topic to topic.

headline: A Duplex Penthouse in Central Vienna
abstract: Atop a turn-of-the-20th-century building, it is on the market for $1.87 million.
lead_paragraph: Atop a turn-of-the-20th-century building, it is on the market for $1.87 million.

headline: Agreement on Ukraine Cease-Fire Deal Is Reported
abstract: Negotiators meeting in Belarus were said to have reached a tentative deal on Tuesday night, according to news reports.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Negotiators meeting in Minsk, Belarus, reached a tentative deal for a cease-fire in Ukraine on Tuesday night, setting the stage for a meeting of the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France to sign the agreement on Wednesday, according to media reports.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,950,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a contemporary in California, a plantation house in Louisiana and a penthouse in Miami.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a contemporary in California, a plantation house in Louisiana and a penthouse in Miami.
