headline: French Muslims, Never Fully at Home
abstract: In the wake of last month’s terrorist attacks, Bharat Choudhary’s photos show how French Muslims struggle to live in a society that they fear will never fully accept them.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of last month’s terrorist attacks, Bharat Choudhary’s photos show how French Muslims struggle to live in a society that they fear will never fully accept them.

headline: Review: ‘Meistersinger,’ Wagner’s Playful Paean to Culture, in London
abstract: “The Mastersingers of Nuremberg,” by the English National Opera, uses a light touch in its staging.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wagner’s “Die Meistersinger” is a long opera about many things and, as hijacked by Adolf Hitler in the 1930s, those included a view of German cultural supremacy so welcoming to the Third Reich that it still bothers some of us. But more broadly it’s an opera about art at a moment of crisis, rooted in past triumphs but needing to move forward to future uncertainties. That makes it an appropriate piece for the English National Opera, whose new production, staged by Richard Jones, opened on Saturday at a moment of unsettling change and possible crisis for the company.

headline: Jury in Patz Murder Trial Views Taped Confession
abstract: As the videotape of Pedro Hernandez’s confession played, some jurors scribbled notes and others leaned forward and stared at the television monitor, studying his face.
lead_paragraph: The confession was not a surprise to jurors: Pedro Hernandez had told several people through the years that he had killed a child in New York City, and five of those people had testified earlier in Mr. Hernandez’s murder trial.

headline: Samsung Tweaks Television Policy Over Privacy Concerns
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Voice Recognition Systems']
abstract: After an outcry over privacy concerns, Samsung has clarified that some of its televisions listen in on the conversations of viewers only if the users permit the devices to do so.
lead_paragraph: After an outcry over privacy concerns, Samsung has clarified that some of its so-called smart televisions listen in on the conversations of viewers only if the viewers permit the devices to do so.

headline: John Boorman Tribute at Film Forum Goes Beyond ‘Deliverance’
abstract: A Film Forum retrospective of the director’s career reflects swings in subject and quality.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unlikely that you think of the British director John Boorman, if you think of him at all, as the man who directed “Deliverance,” a movie that came out 43 years ago. Film Forum is anticipating as much — a news release for the current retrospective of his films begins, “ ‘Boorman,’ Tribute to Director of ‘Deliverance.’ ”

headline: Apple Building Solar Farm to Power California Operations
abstract: The company is aggressively adding to its renewable energy sources, a point of pride for its chief executive, Timothy D. Cook.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is going big on solar.

headline: Grammy Show Ratings Fall
abstract: The Grammy Awards broadcast on CBS Sunday night attracted an audience of 24.8 million viewers, down 13 percent from last year.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards broadcast on CBS Sunday night attracted an audience of 24.8 million viewers, down 13 percent from last year, and the fewest since 19 million watched in 2009.

headline: Richard Price Finds His Pseudonym for ‘The Whites’ Annoying
abstract: Mr. Price is admired for a certain kind of book; when he tried to do something faster and more lucrative under another name, he couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Richard Price is a skilled literary ventriloquist, with a pitch-perfect ear for deadbeat street slang and sardonic cop banter. But when he tried impersonating another writer, with the aim of writing a fast-paced, plot-driven crime novel under the pen name Harry Brandt, he couldn’t quite pull it off.

headline: Review: Music From Japan Brings In Some Neighbors as Well
abstract: The festival, celebrating its 40th anniversary, presented three world premieres, but also delved into traditional music from Korea and China.
lead_paragraph: With Japanese music still lingering in memory from the Juilliard School’s weeklong, storm-abbreviated Focus! festival last month, the New York presenter Music From Japan strutted its stuff with its own festival over the weekend. In two programs at Asia Society, Music From Japan, long a force in opening pathways for Japanese music in the West, was also celebrating its 40th anniversary.

headline: In Paris, a New Exhibition Buttons Up
abstract: “Déboutonner la Mode” at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs explores the fastener’s history and uses, from the Enlightenment to Elsa Schiaparelli.
lead_paragraph: “Buttons can be made from just about anything, from elephant skin to raffia,” announces a text on the wall of “Déboutonner la Mode” (“Unbutton Fashion”), a new exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris. And it’s true: The 3000 buttons on display, gathered by prolific collector Loïc Allio, include pearls, leather, fur, bone, wood, straw, plastic, Wedgwood and papier-mâché. Petite canvases though they may be, each button is a full-fledged artistic work, created by craftsmen ranging from embroiderers and ceramicists to jewelers and silversmiths.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: At Rebecca Minkoff in SoHo, Interface-to-Face Service
abstract: At the brand’s new store, casual clothes in a high-tech setting.
lead_paragraph: There’s a “Simpsons” episode in which Homer presses the Tab key on his computer keyboard and holds a cup to the disk drive, waiting for diet soda to come out. Twenty years after the episode aired in 1995, Homer’s dreams have come true.

headline: Review: Maxine Linehan Transforms the Popular Into the Personal
abstract: Ms. Linehan’s performance on Friday at the Metropolitan Room included works from her latest album, “Beautiful Songs.”
lead_paragraph: “Grounded” is a word that doesn’t describe most cabaret performers. But it applies to Maxine Linehan, the fiercely talented, self-assured theatrical singer who appeared at the Metropolitan Room on Friday evening. Ms. Linehan, who was born in Ireland, exudes the comfortable rootedness of a performer who knows who she is and where she came from. At the same time, Ms. Linehan is an adventurer. On her latest album, “Beautiful Songs,” she takes favorites that you thought you knew and infuses them with an intensely personal point of view.

headline: Natarajan Chandrasekaran of Tata Consultancy Services: Making a Habit of Accountability
abstract: Natarajan Chandrasekaran, chief executive of Tata Consultancy Services, says his father taught him to know the value of everything you get.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Natarajan Chandrasekaran,  chief executive of  Tata Consultancy Services, who is known as Chandra, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Freer Gallery to Close for Renovations in January
abstract: The Smithsonian’s Freer Gallery of Art will improve its lighting and update its technology.
lead_paragraph: The Freer Gallery of Art, a Smithsonian Institution museum that houses one of the finest collections of Asian art, is closing for renovations in January, the Smithsonian announced.

headline: Chico’s Clothing Stores Near Sale to Sycamore Partners
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: If completed, the deal, estimated to be more than $3 billion, would be the largest buyout of the year.
lead_paragraph: Chico’s FAS, the women’s clothing retailer, is nearing a sale to the private equity firm Sycamore Partners for upward of $3 billion, according to a person briefed on the matter. If completed, the deal would be the largest buyout of the year.

abstract: Mr. Minskoff is the founder and president of Edward J. Minskoff Equities, a real estate acquisition and development company.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Minskoff is the founder and president of Edward J. Minskoff Equities, a real estate acquisition and development company that owns and manages nearly six million square feet of office, residential and retail space, mainly in Manhattan.

headline: Living In Tottenville, Staten Island
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']

headline: Phillip Lim’s Meticulous Grooming Regimen Is All About Maintenance
abstract: The designer on grooming, diet and fitness habits.
lead_paragraph: Raised in Huntington Beach, Calif., Phillip Lim, 41, introduced his 3.1 Phillip Lim fashion line in 2005 and quickly found a following for his urbane, wearable aesthetic. Two years later, he won the Council of Fashion Designers of America women's wear award. Today the label, based in SoHo, is a fashion powerhouse with 14 free-standing stores worldwide and three more shops scheduled to open this year. He will show his fall 2015 collection Monday.

headline: The Military Marriage Trapeze Act
keywords: ['ACROBATS AND ACROBATICS', 'Parenting', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Stopping at a highway rest stop, my 4-year-old spotted a group of uniformed Marines paying for snacks. “Mommy!” she exclaimed, “look at ALL those daddies!” We’re never really alone.
lead_paragraph: I clipped in my harness, took a deep breath at the base of the metal ladder and slowly started the long, precarious, 23-foot climb. As the ladder gently swayed with every movement, I tried to create the illusion of composure while getting to the platform at the top as quickly as possible. The mixture of adrenaline and fear is my version of a Long Island iced tea: seems like such a good combination, until you get sick or black out. I remind myself that people (like me) actually pay for this feeling.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The actions of Alabama’s demagogic chief justice, Roy Moore, show an outrageous disdain for the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Major civil rights battles always have their share of setbacks, and the fight for same-sex marriage faced one on Monday in Alabama, where most county probate judges refused to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples, defying last month’s federal court ruling declaring that the state’s ban on such unions violated the U.S. Constitution.

lead_paragraph: John P. Dehlin, the founder and host of a popular podcast for Mormons who question their faith, announced on Tuesday that a 15-member church disciplinary council had unanimously decided to excommunicate him for apostasy.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce Wednesday that he is withdrawing almost all the American troops who were sent to West Africa to help contain the spread of the Ebola virus, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: A Defeat for Prime Minister Modi
abstract: The Bharatiya Janata Party losses on Tuesday in the state assembly election increase the pressure on the prime minister to deliver on his promises.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from the diplomatic high of a successful summit meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been brought down to earth by domestic politics. He and his Bharatiya Janata Party, or B.J.P., were crushed in the election Tuesday for New Delhi’s 70-member state assembly, winning three seats while the upstart Aam Aadmi Party, or A.A.P., captured the rest.

abstract: The suspension, which came after the news anchor acknowledged exaggerating his role in a helicopter incident in Iraq, capped a rapid fall from grace.
lead_paragraph: Brian Williams, the embattled NBC news anchor whose credibility plummeted after he acknowledged exaggerating his role in a helicopter episode in Iraq, has been suspended for six months without pay, the network said on Tuesday night.

lead_paragraph: Divestment, the rallying cry against apartheid in the 1980s, just isn’t what it used to be.

headline: Jon Stewart Will Leave ‘The Daily Show’ on a Career High Note
abstract: Comedy Central said that Mr. Stewart, the longtime host of the satirical news show, was giving up his post, but would remain at the helm until later this year.
lead_paragraph: Jon Stewart, who turned Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show” into a sharp-edged commentary on current events, delivering the news in layers of silliness and mockery, said on Tuesday that he would step down after more than 16 years as its anchor.

headline: Does Helping Condo Developers Hurt the City?
abstract: Have tax breaks, zoning and other policies that have fueled condo development unfairly benefited the rich at the expense of other residents?

headline: New York City Buildings Inspectors Charged in Bribe Schemes
abstract: Prosecutors say 16 city employees exploited their positions to obtain hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes. Dozens of property managers and owners, expediters and other construction workers also face charges.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen New York City buildings inspectors and clerks have been charged with exploiting their positions as gateways to the city’s booming real estate industry to obtain hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes, law enforcement officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C. Offers Clearer Glimpse of Its Plan in an Opening Victory
abstract: New York City F.C. won the first official match in its history as Coach Jason Kreis once again made clear that he intended to construct the team in the mold of Manchester City.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Coach Jason Kreis’s preparations for New York City F.C.’s first season might have been meticulous, but he lacked one vital resource. With his team’s Major League Soccer opener against Orlando City a little more than three weeks away, he had no game footage to pore over.

headline: SpaceX Launch of Solar-Storms Satellite Is Postponed Again
abstract: High-level winds on Tuesday prevented the launch of the Deep Space Climate Observatory. The next attempt will be Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The launch of the Deep Space Climate Observatory, a satellite intended to warn of solar storms shortly before they hit Earth, was postponed on Tuesday because of high-altitude winds at the launch site in Cape Canaveral, Fla.

headline: New York’s Building Horror Stories
abstract: The Manhattan District Attorney announced the indictments of 50 people involved in the building business in New York, and the lineup is stunning.
lead_paragraph: Almost anyone trying to develop a building or repair a brownstone or hold onto a budget-rate apartment in New York City has a horror story to tell.   For the builders, it’s often about strange, excruciating delays and rules that seem straight out of the Charles Dickens Circumlocution Office. For the tenants, it’s the way landlords always seem to have a way with the authorities.

headline: Yelp Pays $134 Million for Food-Ordering Service
abstract: The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews.
lead_paragraph: The online review service Yelp said on Tuesday that it had acquired Eat24, an online food-ordering start-up, for $134 million in cash and stock. The move is a departure for Yelp, whose main business has been selling advertising bought by local businesses with those reviews. But Yelp’s growth is starting to slow, and it reported a decrease in regular visitors in its most recent quarter. In a statement, Jeremy Stoppelman, Yelp’s chief executive, said the purchase would help Yelp customers more easily do business with companies online. Yelp will have plenty of competitors. GrubHub, an online food ordering company and a longtime competitor of Eat24, recently acquired DiningIn and Restaurants on the Run, two delivery services that take food directly to customers who order it through the company. Yelp also faces start-ups like Postmates, which enables customers to order food from almost any restaurant for delivery, and Square, which recently bought the food delivery start-up Caviar. Bigger competitors may be coming, too. Amazon and Google have experimented with on-demand delivery services, and Uber, the ride-hailing start-up, has signaled its own ambitions of becoming a way to deliver anything to anyone.

headline: Richter Leads Sotheby’s London Contemporary Art Sales
abstract: “There are plenty of collectors who can take a painting that big,” a New York dealer said. “There are private museums opening up all over the world.”
lead_paragraph: A Gerhard Richter abstract painting sold Tuesday night at Sotheby’s contemporary art auction in London for £30.4 million, or about $46.3 million, including fees.

lead_paragraph: Doctors have long prescribed a muscle relaxant called cyclobenzaprine to treat injuries like back strains, using five- or 10-milligram pills.

headline: On YouTube, Vivid Evidence of War’s Horror in Ukraine
abstract: The war in Ukraine can be viewed, in all its horror and brutality, by anyone with an Internet connection.
lead_paragraph: Even though the United States is now considering proposals to arm Ukraine’s military, to counter aid to separatists from Russia, the war in the eastern provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk has nearly disappeared from American television screens.

headline: In Thailand, the Ghost Business Thrives

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Shortly after midnight, the phone rang in the cramped radio station where Kapol Thongplub hosts a nightly call-in show dedicated to the supernatural.

headline: Complicated Politics of Medicaid Expansion Are Playing Out State by State
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Pennsylvania’s new Democratic governor is moving to expand the health insurance program for the poor, while similar plans by Republican governors in Tennessee and Wyoming were rejected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Pennsylvania, Gov. Tom Wolf, a newly elected Democrat, is scrapping his Republican predecessor’s conservative approach to expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. Mr. Wolf said this week that he would instead pursue a straightforward expansion of the government health insurance program for the poor, no longer charging premiums or limiting benefits for some enrollees.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Private Equity']

abstract: Two men apprehended in a raid in a Sydney suburb have been charged with planning an act of terrorism and other offenses, officials said.

lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2013, one of Mexico’s top housing officials posted an item on Twitter about an advertising campaign promoting mortgages for low-income Mexicans. The campaign’s message was simple: “The most important thing in life is in your house.”

headline: Val Fitch, Who Discovered Universe to Be Out of Balance, Is Dead at 91
abstract: Dr. Fitch shared the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physics for work that helped explain why the collision of matter and antimatter has not destroyed everything in the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: Val Fitch, who shared the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physics for work that revealed a surprising imbalance in the laws of nature and helped explain why the collision of matter and antimatter has not destroyed everything in the universe, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 91.

headline: As Snow Piles Up in Boston, So Do Frustrations With Beleaguered Transit System
abstract: Record snow in Boston the past 17 days has exposed the vulnerabilities of the debt-ridden Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, as numerous breakdowns and delays have occurred.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Rebekah Adelstone usually drives to work, which takes 15 minutes. Since record snows have fallen, she has not wanted to risk losing her precious parking spot, so she has taken a bus to the subway. But on Tuesday, after even more snow fell, the subway system was shut down. So she ended up taking two buses to work, and her commute stretched to two hours.

headline: Obama to Seek War Power Bill From Congress, to Fight ISIS
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War Powers Act (1973)']
abstract: The Obama administration has informed lawmakers that the president will seek an authorization that would prohibit “enduring offensive ground forces” and limit engagement to three years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has informed lawmakers that the president will seek a formal authorization to fight the Islamic State that would prohibit the use of “enduring offensive ground forces” and limit engagement to three years. The approach offers what the White House hopes is a middle way on Capitol Hill for those on the right and left who remain deeply skeptical of its plans to thwart extremist groups.

headline: Sarah Schleper, Now Representing Mexico, Is Poised for a Second Run
abstract: Schleper, a longtime U.S. ski team member, is set to compete in the giant slalom of the Alpine world ski championships and hopes to establish a training base in Colorado for the Mexican team.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — In 2011, Sarah Schleper was 32 years old and had been a member of the United States ski team for 16 winters, a stint that included four Olympic Games, seven national championships and four World Cup podium finishes.

headline: Impasse on Funding for Homeland Security Is Looming in Congress

headline: A Late-Night Host Seamlessly Mixing Analysis, Politics and Humor
abstract: For an entire generation, “The Daily Show” with Mr. Stewart became the news and his departure represents the end of one of the most impressive and influential runs in talk show history.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a presidential election without Jon Stewart at “The Daily Show,” but we are going to have to get used to it now that the host of the landmark political comedy program of our era is leaving his desk before the first primary of 2016.

headline: Jon Stewart and ‘The Daily Show': A Comedy Launchpad
abstract: Under Jon Stewart, “The Daily Show” became an important incubator of comedic talent.
lead_paragraph: Just over 16 years ago, Jon Stewart took over “The Daily Show,” which has served as a primary source of news and satire for a generation. His mission: to skewer, mock and fact-check what he saw as the inanities of American politics and media. In the process, “The Daily Show” served as a launching pad for some of comedy’s most notable talents to go onto other shows or projects. Jon Stewart must be a happy papa.

headline: Rapper, Shaped by Tumultuous German Youth, Is Designated a Global Terrorist
abstract: Denis Cuspert, a former German gang member and gangsta rapper, is now a “specially designated global terrorist” sought worldwide for his alleged promotion of the Islamic State militant group.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Denis Cuspert was drawn early to gangsta rap, and later to Islam. Born and raised in West Berlin, jeered at as a half-African child and often at odds with his American stepfather, he fell in with Salafists in Germany, left for Egypt in 2012 and made his way, eventually, to Syria. By last spring, the German authorities said, he had joined Islamic State guerrillas and swore allegiance to their leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

headline: Missouri: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Grand Juror’s Lawsuit
abstract: The St. Louis County prosecutor asked a federal judge on Monday to dismiss a lawsuit from a grand juror who wants to speak publicly about the case of Darren Wilson, the Ferguson police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis County prosecutor, with the backing of Missouri’s attorney general, asked a federal judge on Monday to dismiss a lawsuit from a grand juror who wants to speak publicly about the case of Darren Wilson, the Ferguson police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black man last summer and was not indicted. Missouri law prevents grand jurors from discussing their work in most instances, and the 12-member panel that decided not to indict Mr. Wilson for killing Michael Brown, 18, has remained anonymous. One juror sued last month seeking protection from the restrictions, naming the prosecutor, Robert P. McCulloch, as the defendant. That lawsuit, which said that the public’s understanding of the grand jury was “not entirely accurate,” indicated a willingness to discuss what happened during the hearings and “advocate for legislative change to the way grand juries are conducted.” In the lawsuit, the grand juror, who is represented by the American Civil Liberties Union of Missouri, indicated a fear of being prosecuted if he or she spoke publicly.

headline: Decrees Governing France’s Bakeries Prompt a Wider Debate on Work Rules
keywords: ['Working Hours', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Income']
abstract: The decrees governing bakeries play into a serious debate about whether the country can change its work rules and make other adjustments to counter high unemployment and a morose economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Stéphane Cazenave, a baker in Saint-Paul-lès-Dax in southwestern France, was awarded a prize last year for best traditional baguette, in a contest organized by the confederation of French bakers. Back home, business was good, and Mr. Cazenave kept his bakery open seven days a week.

headline: Greek Prime Minister Tsipras Wins Confidence Vote Before Talks With Creditors
abstract: Alexis Tsipras said his government would seek a short-term “bridge” agreement to a new deal and a “necessary” reduction of his country’s debt.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — With Greece preparing for tough talks with creditors in Brussels, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's government easily won a confidence vote in Parliament early Wednesday with assurances that it would reverse an economic program that has slashed living standards.

headline: Midcentury Modernism Arrives in the California Desert
abstract: The auction site Paddle8 has partnered with the design firm Homepolish to create a pop-up series of interiors vignettes at the Ace Hotel and Swim Club.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, design and art lovers will descend on the desert east of Los Angeles for the 10th edition of Palm Springs Modernism Week. Among the lectures, house tours, exhibitions and fairs this year, one unofficial event stands out — and even offers the chance for the snowbound to get in on the action. The auction site Paddle8 has partnered with the design firm Homepolish to create “Desert Living: Icons of Modern Design,” a pop-up series of interiors vignettes at the Ace Hotel and Swim Club’s 4,000-square-foot clubhouse space. The four installations, says Jason Stein, Paddle8’s senior design specialist, reflect “what our favorite homes in Palm Springs would be; a setting we’d want to live in.” And though midcentury art and design are, as expected, well represented, the collectibles on offer extend far beyond the “Mad Men”-era nostalgia typically associated with the region. One California-themed tableau includes Frank Gehry’s cardboard chair, Bill Curry’s “Cattail” lamp, John Baldessari prints and an Ed Ruscha painting; another explores the notion of opulence through such pieces as a chrome 1970s Gucci wine cooler and a Helmut Newton nude photograph. And a future-themed area features Gerald McCabe’s seven-stemmed “Daisy” table and artwork by Kenny Scharf, Sam Francis and David Hockney. The environments will be accessible to visitors this weekend and are, Stein promises, “really layered”; for those stuck in less salubrious climes, everything is up for auction starting Wednesday on the Paddle8 site.

headline: The Perfect Pint (of Ice Cream)
abstract: Just in time for Valentine’s Day, indie purveyors of artisanal scoops offer new flavors to be shipped statewide.
lead_paragraph: It may seem unlikely given the time of year, but a handful of indie ice cream makers across the country introduced new, handcrafted flavors this month. And the small-batch pints, created in collaboration with other American purveyors of artisanal goods and available to be shipped anywhere in the U.S., are a welcome relief from the traditional Valentine’s Day sweets this time of year.

headline: The ‘Damien Hirst of New Delhi’ Brings a Personal Exhibition to New York
abstract: Subodh Gupta's "Seven Billion Light Years" includes ready-made and appropriated objects that reflect on Indian culture.
lead_paragraph: Many of the objects in Subodh Gupta’s career-spanning new exhibition, “Seven Billion Light Years,” are ordinary: The works on display include kitchen utensils piled together as part of a sculpture, a window buried in the ground and a broken stove attached to a painting. But Gupta thinks of them as more than discards; these are also someone else’s memories on display. Because he transforms certain objects into larger-than-life, sometimes shocking sculptures, Gupta has been called the “Damien Hirst of New Delhi”; alternately, his methods of appropriating and displaying other people’s objects could be described as Duchampian. The truth is, Gupta is a sentimentalist at heart. His objects, whether gilded or left as-is, are intimately bound up with Indian culture — agriculture and cooking traditions that are fading away from modern society.

headline: A Lesson in Natural Makeup From the Masterful Pat McGrath
abstract: The backstage beauty expert explains how to get the no-makeup makeup look in 10 steps.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist Pat McGrath is a master of creating bold, hashtag-worthy looks with her whimsical use of sequins, glitter and Crayola-like color, but her most impressive trompe l’oeil might be when her handiwork is completely invisible to the eye. When she’s not pushing the avant-garde with wild materials, McGrath’s makeup can be so subtle that it appears as if the models aren’t wearing any at all. As it turns out, achieving this no-makeup makeup effect (seen on many a runway — and surely many more in the weeks to come during the fall/winter 2015 fashion shows), requires the right mix of products (11 to be exact) and ample blending. Here, McGrath reveals the secrets behind her stealth technique that results in casual perfection.

headline: The Human Touch
abstract: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal. Welcome to a season of exposed topstitching, frayed edges, crinkled linen, drawstring burlap and other disciplines of applied art.
lead_paragraph: As fashion continues to demand ever more output and speed, many designers are finding freedom in the artisanal. Welcome to a season of exposed topstitching, frayed edges, crinkled linen, drawstring burlap and other disciplines of applied art.

abstract: The examination, to determine if Tom Benson is mentally fit, would be part of a fight over the future ownership of the Saints.
lead_paragraph: As part of a fight over the future ownership of the Saints, a district court judge in New Orleans has ordered the team’s owner, Tom Benson, to take an examination to determine if he is mentally fit. Benson said last month that his third wife, Gayle, would inherit the Saints and the New Orleans Pelicans when he dies. Benson’s daughter and two grandchildren sued, claiming Gayle Benson had taken advantage of her husband’s infirmities to wrest control of the teams.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (Reelz) INVICTUS (2009) This rousing drama from Clint Eastwood, based on the book “Playing the Enemy” by John Carlin, was inspired by a true story of reconciliation and athletic triumph. Morgan Freeman portrays Nelson Mandela, newly elected as South Africa’s first black president, and Matt Damon is François Pienaar, the captain of the Springbok rugby team, a source of Afrikaner pride despised by many blacks. Mandela views the team as a vehicle to bring the country’s races together, especially if it can win the Rugby World Cup tournament in 1995, which South Africa is to host. “ ‘Invictus’ has implications beyond its immediate time and place that are hard to miss,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s an exciting sports movie, an inspiring tale of prejudice overcome and, above all, a fascinating study of political leadership.” In “Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom” (2013), Justin Chadwick’s biopic, at 6:35 on Showtime, Idris Elba portrays Mandela and Naomie Harris is his wife, Winnie. “Mr. Elba’s towering performance lends ‘Long Walk to Freedom’ a Shakespearean breadth,” Stephen Holden wrote in The Times. “His Mandela is an intensely emotional man whose body quakes in moments of sorrow and whose face is stricken with a bone-deep anguish. The carefully chosen words in his eloquent declarations of principle, spoken with gravity and deliberation, are deeply stirring.”

headline: A Quiet Fight to Marry
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Now that a judge says we can’t get hitched, we’re getting in line.
lead_paragraph: COKER, Ala. — MONDAY morning began like any other morning on our little farm in Alabama, where we have lived together for more than three decades. We already knew that Roy S. Moore, the chief justice of the State Supreme Court, had commanded the state’s probate judges to refuse to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples. But turning on the radio, we learned that the judge in our county, Tuscaloosa, home to the state’s flagship university, had decided to go along with him.

headline: Lynching as Racial Terrorism
abstract: A new report aims to force Southern towns and the nation to confront an era of racial terror directly and recognize its ramifications today.
lead_paragraph: It is important to remember that the hangings, burnings and dismemberments of black American men, women and children that were relatively common in this country between the Civil War and World War II were often public events. They were sometimes advertised in newspapers and drew hundreds and even thousands of white spectators, including elected officials and leading citizens who were so swept up in the carnivals of death that they posed with their children for keepsake photographs within arm’s length of mutilated black corpses.

headline: Concealed Carry’s Body Count
abstract: A new report reveals that at least 722 deaths since 2007 were attributed to individuals with legal permits to carry concealed weapons.
lead_paragraph: In America’s endless debate about gun rights versus public safety, there should be no disputing the hard facts in a new report on gunshot fatalities showing that at least 722 nonself-defense deaths since 2007 were attributable to individuals with legal permits to carry concealed weapons. Concealed carry by citizens has been a soaring phenomenon as states liberalize laws in the name of lowering crime that allow more permits and easier gun access in public places, even schools, churches and restaurants.

abstract: In the wake of last month’s terrorist attacks, Bharat Choudhary’s photos show how French Muslims struggle to live in a society that they fear will never fully accept them.
lead_paragraph: After the terrorist attacks last month on the offices of Charlie Hebdo and a kosher supermarket, the airwaves and the web were filled with vitriol toward French Muslims. Many demanded that they condemn the violence, which most Muslim organizations and public figures did. But far right-wing commentators in France and beyond attacked Islam itself, insisting that the religion was inherently violent.

headline: Better Fitness Through Your Phone
abstract: While some fitness monitors are accurate when measuring step counts, others are way off. And few are more accurate than the convenient and inexpensive apps you can find on your cellphone, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Many of us have invested in the wristbands or other wearable devices that tell us how many steps we’ve taken, calories we’ve burned and other information. But an interesting new study that compared activity monitors found that while some are accurate when measuring step counts, others are way off. And few are more accurate than the convenient and inexpensive apps you can find on your cellphone.

headline: The Stanford Undergraduate and the Mentor
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: He was supposed to help her break into the tech industry. Instead, they started a relationship. Then came a rape allegation, a lawsuit and an investigation at one of the nation’s top universities.
lead_paragraph: On a weekend in March almost three years ago, Ellie Clougherty flew from London to Rome with Joe Lonsdale. She was a 21-year-old junior at Stanford University, and it was her first trip to Italy. Lonsdale, then 29, was a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, and he booked a room for them for two nights in a luxury hotel — a converted Renaissance mansion in the shadow of the Pantheon — and arranged a special excursion, with a friend of his who is an architect, to an archaeological site amid the ruins of the Golden House on Palatine Hill, overlooking the Colosseum. Under a light gray sky, they stood on plexiglass bridges and looked down at the uncovered remains of what is thought to be a fabled rotating dining room that the Emperor Nero built for extravagant banquets. Lonsdale is a Roman-history buff, and he told Clougherty about the emperors, praising their civilization and engineering feats.

headline: Morning Agenda: Private Equity’s Recruiting Race
abstract: Private equity firms are madly courting young bankers. | Hedge funds take aim at General Motors. | Battling fossil fuels with anti-apartheid divestment strategies.
lead_paragraph: PRIVATE EQUITY’S RECRUITING RACE | Some young bankers on Wall Street are the most sought-after financiers around, with lucrative pay packages dangling before them, DealBook’s William Alden and Sydney Ember write. Junior investment bankers, many of whom graduated from college only last year, are being madly courted by private equity firms like Apollo Global Management, the Blackstone Group, Bain Capital and the Carlyle Group in a scramble that kicked off last weekend. After back-to-back interviews, many are now fielding offers for jobs that won’t start until the summer of 2016.

headline: World Leaders Meet in Belarus to Negotiate Cease-Fire in Ukraine
abstract: The last-ditch effort involving Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany is based on a peace accord signed in September but violated almost immediately.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, France and Germany negotiated through Wednesday night and into Thursday morning, locked in a tough effort to defuse the escalating conflict in eastern Ukraine, though there was little indication that whatever peace deal emerged from these talks would last any longer than a previous truce in September.

headline: An Unblemished Record Is New for Kentucky’s John Calipari
abstract: If the Wildcats become the first undefeated national champions in Division I men’s basketball in almost 40 years, they will help offset controversies over Calipari’s recruiting.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Louisiana State fans began lining up at Pete Maravich Assembly Center nearly two hours before game time on Tuesday, fully expecting that their Tigers, so tough at home, would end Kentucky’s 23-game winning streak.

headline: Shares of Aena and Elis Climb in Strong Demand for European I.P.O.s
abstract: The pace for initial public offerings this year is off to its best start since the financial crisis, with more than a dozen companies making their debuts in the recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Aena, the Spanish airport operator, and Elis, the French provider of rental uniforms and linens, surged in their stock market debuts on Wednesday as investor appetite for initial public offerings remained strong in Europe.

headline: In Chapel Hill Shooting of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Hate Crimes', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: Craig Stephen Hicks, 46, was charged with first-degree murder in the Chapel Hill, N.C., shooting. The police cited a parking dispute, but friends wondered if the victims’ faith played a role.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — It was a little after 5 p.m., a quiet time in a quiet neighborhood, before many people had returned home from work on Tuesday, when two women called 911 to report multiple gunshots and screams echoing through a condominium complex here near the University of North Carolina.

headline: Rite Aid to Buy Pharmacy Benefit Manager EnvisionRx
abstract: Rite Aid will pay the private equity firm TPG about $1.8 billion in cash and $200 million in stock for EnvisionRx, making this one of the year’s early successful exits for a buyout firm.
lead_paragraph: Rite Aid, the big pharmacy chain, agreed on Wednesday to acquire a top pharmacy benefit manager, Envision Pharmaceutical Services, for $2 billion in cash and stock .

headline: ‘Fifty Shades of Grey,’ the Movie, as a Fairy Tale
abstract: E. L. James’s best-selling erotic novel comes to the screen, directed by Sam Taylor-Johnson, who describes the story as “deep, dark, romantic.”
lead_paragraph: If ever a novel could be described as review-proof, it is “Fifty Shades of Grey,” which, with its two sequels, has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide despite being ridiculed by virtually every critic who has read it. (Salman Rushdie, for one, said that it “made ‘Twilight’ look like ‘War and Peace.’ ”)

headline: The Times and Transgender Issues (Part 1 of 2): On Pronouns
abstract: Two recent articles show the need for evolving style guidelines
lead_paragraph: In August 2013, soon after Chelsea Manning announced that she identified as a woman and no longer wanted to be known as Bradley Manning, The Times made a quick – and I thought appropriate – adjustment. Articles began referring to Private Manning with the feminine pronoun and the use of the name Chelsea. It caused a bit of a scramble at the time, because editors were concerned about clarity for readers when referring to the high-profile soldier who had just been sentenced to prison for leaking classified information. But in the end, a ruling principle – the preference of the individual – held sway.

headline: Cloud Software Start-Up AppDirect Raises $50 Million
abstract: The company, which specializes in letting clients sell and manage online software systems, plans to expand its staff worldwide.
lead_paragraph: AppDirect, a start-up focused on helping customers sell software online, said on Wednesday that it had raised $50 million in new financing to help it expand its staff worldwide.

headline: Workout Test: Fitness Apps vs. Trainer
abstract: Fitness apps and calorie counters like MyFitnessPal and FitStar pose a challenge to the traditional personal trainer model, but which stands the test of time? Molly Wood tests them out.
lead_paragraph: Fitness apps and calorie counters like MyFitnessPal and FitStar pose a challenge to the traditional personal trainer model, but which stands the test of time? Molly Wood tests them out.

abstract: As technology starts pushing us to be healthier and fitter, apps like FitStar, Kiqplan and Hot5 are trying to replace personal trainers or even gyms.
lead_paragraph: ACTIVITY trackers. Calorie counters. Phones with heart monitors.

abstract: It appeared to be business as usual for Jon Stewart, host of The Daily Show, on Tuesday night. He was gabbing with David Axelrod about his new book and President Obama’s frustrations with Congress and the media.
lead_paragraph: It appeared to be business as usual for Jon Stewart, the host of “The Daily Show,” on Tuesday night. He was gabbing with David Axelrod about his new book and discussing President Obama’s frustrations with Congress and the news media.

headline: What to Watch for During Fashion Month
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: An F.M.C.S. (Fashion Month Crib Sheet) for the hundreds of shows in four cities on two continents.
lead_paragraph: It’s here: Fashion month (I mean, really, let’s call it like it is; none of this pretend “fashion WEEK” stuff) officially starts on Thursday, though in the inveterate creep of these things, some brands have jumped the gun and are showing on Wednesday in New York.

headline: Malaysian Police Use Twitter in Crackdown on Dissent
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Social Media']
abstract: A cartoonist was taken into custody after a series of critical posts, and the country’s highest police officer called for investigations into messages by two politicians.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Malaysian authorities have detained a cartoonist and ordered an investigation into two prominent politicians in an intensifying crackdown on dissent after the country’s highest court upheld a five-year prison sentence for the leader of the opposition, Anwar Ibrahim.

headline: A New Orleans Neighborhood Takes Off
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: The Freret Corridor barely existed a decade ago. Now it boasts new cafes, bars, shops as well as a comedy club.
lead_paragraph: The Freret Corridor barely existed a decade ago. There was only Freret Street, run-down and with a single restaurant. In recent years, though, the Uptown neighborhood has taken off. The New Freret (pronounced fur-RET), as it’s sometimes called, combs the space of about six blocks. What makes it particularly valuable is the variety of the new spots, more than 20 of them, including a comedy club, a cocktail bar, a pet grooming shop, a boxing gym, and a garden center. And that is to say nothing of the eateries where New Orleans po’ boys are readily found, just in time for Mardi Gras.

headline: A Midwinter Playground in the Hudson Valley
abstract: Historic inns, a family ski center and a renowned art museum can be found amid rolling countryside an hour from New York City.

headline: Close Friend of Russian Leader Takes Role as a Negotiator for Ukraine
abstract: Critics of Viktor V. Medvedchuk, enlisted by Ukraine in talks with separatists, are less troubled by his Soviet past than his close ties with Russia’s leader.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Viktor V. Medvedchuk often turns up in places where only buddies of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia get to go, like the V.I.P. section at a Formula One championship in Sochi, Russia, in October. He sat just a few feet from Mr. Putin, next to the actor Steven Seagal, another pal of the Kremlin leader’s.

headline: The Community College/‘Real College’ Divide
abstract: You know what saddened me when I worked at the community college? Meeting students who sounded apologetic for being there. They had heard the message that community college was not real college, and they listened.
lead_paragraph: I heard it again, another community college putdown. This one came from an educator explaining criteria for high school graduation. She followed her summary with these words to her audience of parents and incoming freshmen: “So that’s the minimum requirement. But here’s what you should take if you want to go to real college — you know, not community college.”

lead_paragraph: PepsiCo, the beverage and snack giant, said on Wednesday that its quarterly earnings fell 24 percent, putting it in the ranks of companies whose finances were dented by currency swings at the end of last year.

headline: Head of Belgian Group Said to Recruit Fighters for Syria Gets 12-Year Term
abstract: A judge in a criminal court in Antwerp, Belgium, ruled that Sharia4Belgium was a terrorist organization.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In a case seen as a test of Europe’s ability to combat Islamic extremism through the courts, a Belgian judge on Wednesday ruled that Sharia4Belgium, a group accused of recruiting fighters for Syria, was a terrorist organization and sentenced the group’s leader to 12 years in prison.

headline: A Neighborhood of Contrasts

lead_paragraph: Tottenville, a self-contained enclave along Staten Island’s southwestern waterfront, can be rich in contrasts.

headline: Carlyle Profit, Weighed Down by Energy Investments, Beats Expectations
abstract: Carlyle, the Washington-based private equity giant, said that its quarterly economic net income — a measure of profit that includes unrealized gains or losses — declined 68 percent, to $180.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group reported lower fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday, weighed down by declines in its energy investments and its hedge funds, but the results exceeded analysts’ expectations.

abstract: Justin Vernon, a Wisconsin native, will organize the inaugural Eaux Claires Music & Arts Festival on July 17 and 18, bringing acts like Boys Noize, Sufjan Stevens and Indigo Girls.

Rescued African Migrants Recount Ordeal in Mediterranean

abstract: More than 300 people are said to have died trying to reach Italy in small boats, and critics said European nations need to improve rescue patrols.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Survivors rescued off the Libyan coast by the Italian Coast Guard gave harrowing accounts of small boats packed with migrants that were overwhelmed by high waves, which washed scores of people overboard to their deaths in cold Mediterranean waters, humanitarian organizations said Wednesday.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In seeking authorization for a campaign against ISIS, President Obama took the unusual step of asking Congress to restrict the ability of the commander in chief to wage war, but he left room for flexibility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In seeking authorization for his six-month-old military campaign against the Islamic State terrorist group, President Obama on Wednesday did something that few if any of his predecessors have done: He asked Congress to restrict the ability of the commander in chief to wage war against an overseas enemy.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration accused China on Wednesday of providing illegal export subsidies to critical industries, flexing its muscle on trade as it presses Congress to expand President Obama’s authority to secure major trade accords.

headline: In the Fall of Saigon, Lessons for Today
abstract: The filmmaker Rory Kennedy says “Last Days in Vietnam” offers truths about how to wind down a war — and how not to.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Vietnam recedes deeper into history, replaced in the American consciousness by more recent conflicts in places like Iraq and Afghanistan, its lessons also seem to fade. That amnesia is what the film director and producer Rory Kennedy is trying to counteract in “Last Days in Vietnam,” one of five nominees for the Oscar for best feature-length documentary.

headline: ‘The B Side,’ by Ben Yagoda
abstract: A social history of the Great American Songbook era.
lead_paragraph: What happened to American music? That often asked question is perhaps more valid now than ever.

headline: Amiri Baraka’s ‘S O S’
abstract: This collection of 50 years of Amiri Baraka’s poetry shows the firmness of his beliefs and the heat of his fury.
lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka eulogized James Baldwin on Dec. 8, 1987, by saying: “He was all the way live, all the way conscious, turned all the way up, receiving and broadcasting. . . . He always made us know we were dangerously intelligent and as courageous as the will to be free.”

headline: Robert L. Grenier’s ‘88 Days to Kandahar’
abstract: Robert L. Grenier, a C.I.A. station chief, had a ringside seat for the early days of the Afghan war.
lead_paragraph: As America’s longest war draws to a close, journalists and diplomats, spooks and soldiers keep turning out books attempting to explain what was lost and won over the last 14 years in Afghanistan. While none so far have synthesized the disparate worlds of American civilian policy, military action and Afghan realities, the latest entry, “88 Days to Kandahar: A CIA Diary,” by Robert L. Grenier, adds another on-the-ground view of how the early events actually unfolded. Grenier, who retired in 2006 after 27 years with the C.I.A., was the station chief in Islamabad, Pakistan, from 1999 to 2002, with practical responsibility for Taliban-dominated ­areas of southern and eastern Afghanistan during the crucial early months of the war. The book’s title refers to the period between Sept. 11 and Dec. 7, when an anti-Taliban tribal leader named Hamid Karzai made a perilous return to Afghanistan to rally Pashtun opposition to the Taliban, which culminated in their surrender.

headline: Obama Administration Plans to Aggressively Target Wildlife Trafficking
keywords: ['Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Ivory', 'Black Markets', 'Smuggling']
abstract: The plan includes using intelligence agencies and putting pressure on Asian countries to stop the buying and selling of rhinoceros horns and elephant ivory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hoping to stem illegal wildlife trafficking, the Obama administration on Wednesday introduced an aggressive plan for taking on traffickers that will include using American intelligence agencies to track and target those who benefit from the estimated $20-billion-a-year market.

headline: 1965: Resignations Over Madras Riot
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: India riots continue in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two cabinet ministers resigned today [Feb. 11] as rioting continued in Madras state against the adoption of Hindi as the official language of India. Five rioters were shot and killed after a mob of 4,000 stormed the railway station at Kumarapalam, a suburb of Madras city, and halted the speeding Indo-Ceylon Express. This brought to 39 the known death toll of the riots. The mob burned six coaches of the train before special armed police arrived and the shooting broke out. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 12, 1965

headline: Review: In ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Movie, Sex Is a Knotty Business
abstract: The film dabbles in romantic comedy and splashes around in melodrama, but the one thing it can’t be is what E. L. James’s novel was, trashily and triumphantly: pornography.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a recent New York sneak preview of “Fifty Shades of Grey” — in the blackout between the final lines of dialogue (“Anastasia!” “Christian!”) and the first breathy notes of the last Beyoncé song — a lot of the audience burst out laughing. The source of that laughter continues to puzzle and intrigue me, perhaps more than the actual movie did. Was it delight? Derision? Embarrassment? Surprise? All of the above?

headline: Chile’s Pablo Larraín Presents Film on Catholic Priests at Berlin Festival
abstract: A Chilean director explores a world of sinning priests sent into exile.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Chilean director Pablo Larraín has a penchant for the dark side. His “Tony Manero” (2009) was about a serial killer, and “Post Mortem” (2012) and the Oscar-nominated “No” (2013) explored the complexities of Pinochet’s Chile. In “The Club,” which debuted at the Berlin Film Festival this week to strong reviews, the director has mined another troubling theme: errant Roman Catholic priests and the system that has helped cover up their misdeeds.

headline: A Measured Approach to Cooking
abstract: When it comes to recipes, remember that everything’s relative.

headline: In Politics of Rebuilding Ground Zero, a Lone Critical Voice

headline: Jewelry Designer Irene Neuwirth Goes to the Gem Show
abstract: Fifteen years after her first visit, the native Angeleno still makes the trip to the Tucson Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase to collect treasures for her line.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, Irene Neuwirth took her first trip to the Tucson Gem, Mineral & Fossil Showcase, a massive exhibition held every winter that spans various venues across the city. At the time, the native Angeleno was teaching horseback riding and picking up beads at her local hippie haunt that she would later turn into jewelry for fun. “I drove there, stayed at the airport Hilton, and had $300,” she says. “I spent $500 and thought I would be in debt for the rest of my life.” Upon returning to L.A., Neuwirth made 10 necklaces, and sent them to Barneys with a note written in Magic Marker that read, “I hope you love them.” Today, her namesake line is one the department store’s best sellers and she has a fanciful Melrose Place flagship store to call her own.

headline: Hostage’s Hometown Is Well Acquainted With Loss
abstract: Almost two years ago, Prescott residents were mourning 19 firefighters. Now the town has lost a young woman killed while being held hostage by ISIS.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — As if in a snow-globe village adjusted for the warmth of an Arizona winter, the gathering place at the heart of this city is a square with a western-wear boutique, a yogurt shop and, on the green lawn of the old courthouse, a scene playing out that is sadly familiar to many people here.

headline: Babies Who Eat to Live, Instead of the Other Way Around
abstract: Obsessing over a baby who is eating enough for her, but not enough to put her on the weight chart.
lead_paragraph: As a parent of a newborn, I was as naïve as they come. I had flowery illusions of bringing my swaddled daughter home, placing her in her monkey-shaped bouncy seat and watching her coo for hours until it was time to tuck her into her crib, lovey in hand.

headline: Composing ‘The Theory of Everything’
abstract: Johann Johannsson discusses his score.
lead_paragraph: It begins with a piano riff and builds into a triumphant orchestral sweep. The piece, “Cambridge, 1963,” introduces audiences to a young, vibrant, bike-riding Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything,” the film about the theoretical physicist’s first marriage, to Jane Hawking. The piece was composed by Johann Johannsson of Iceland, who won the Golden Globe for his now Oscar-nominated score. This piece is the composer’s favorite from the film.

headline: ‘Karate’ Means Empty Hand, but a Handheld Device Is Needed
abstract: These apps offer video, photos and written instructions to train aspiring martial artists.
lead_paragraph: LEARNING a martial art is a true challenge, both mentally and physically, because there is so much to master and remember. Turning to an app for help might not seem like an obvious course, but many apps do provide worthwhile support.

lead_paragraph: If you think it’s chilly in New York City, it’s even colder in Toronto. So it is perhaps not surprising that several theater companies from Ontario are headed south to participate in Frigid New York. Frigid, entering its ninth year, is actually affiliated with the Canadian Association of Fringe Festivals and is modeled on its principles of first-come, first-served access for artists and a 100 percent return of box-office proceeds to those artists.

headline: The World of Pat McGrath
abstract: A close-up of the makeup artist.
lead_paragraph: In the beauty universe, you could say the world spins around Pat McGrath. Over the course of her three-decade career, the prolific, self-taught makeup artist has worked with in-demand models (Naomi, Gisele, Cara, Kendall), major fashion houses (Christian Dior, Versace, Prada) and the top photographers (Steven Meisel counts her among his closest collaborators). A backstage fixture, McGrath can set trends with a wave of her hands — she famously prefers to work with her fingers instead of with brushes — and is nothing if not extremely versatile: dewy, no-makeup skin, custom-made Swarovski crystal face masks and feather-adorned eyelids and brows are all in her wheelhouse. In 2004, she was made global creative design director for Procter & Gamble Beauty, and last spring, Queen Elizabeth II named her a Member of the Order of the British Empire for services to the fashion and beauty industries. (To celebrate, McGrath snapped her first selfie.) Here, a closer look at all things in McGrath’s orbit.

headline: The Case for Buying a Powerball Ticket
abstract: It’s fun to imagine a future of vast wealth, and an unusually large Powerball jackpot means you’re throwing away fewer dollars in economic terms.
lead_paragraph: This article was published last February when the Powerball lottery hit $500 million. The point remains the same with the even larger jackpot this week.

headline: Jerry Tarkanian, 84, N.C.A.A. Foe and College Basketball Force, Dies
abstract: Tarkanian, one of college basketball’s most successful coaches in his 19 seasons at Nevada-Las Vegas, had a long-running feud with the N.C.A.A.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Tarkanian, who built Nevada-Las Vegas into a national powerhouse in college basketball with an insatiable will to win, created the persona of Tark the Shark and ignited a long-running feud with the N.C.A.A. over accusations that he ran outlaw programs at three universities, died on Wednesday in Las Vegas. He was 84.

headline: The Power of Saving: Exploring the Mathematics of Compound Interest
abstract: Students explore the basic mathematics of savings and interest and can build intuition about long-term investment strategies and how they can prepare for retirement.
lead_paragraph: Overview | How do savings accounts grow? How can small, regular contributions add up to sizable retirement accounts? In this lesson students explore the basic mathematics of savings and interest using a simple model inspired by a recently proposed automatic retirement savings plan. By manipulating the parameters of the model and analyzing the consequences, students can build intuition about long-term investment strategies and evaluate the proposed policy from a quantitative perspective.

headline: Would an Emoticon Have Taken Eight Years?
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: How “This American Life” and the filmmaker Bianca Giaever helped a woman express herself to her boyfriend using three words they had never said.
lead_paragraph: Maia Leppo didn’t think that she and her boyfriend, Alex Kobzik, had a problem until they were vacationing with his family on Cape Cod, Mass., last summer, eight years into their relationship, and his mother asked them when they had first said “I love you.”

headline: Obama Seeks an Expansive War Authorization to Combat ISIS
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation', 'Terrorism']
abstract: While indefensibly late, the move is welcome if it triggers debate about the goals and scope of the military intervention.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five months after launching a war against the Islamic State, in Iraq and Syria, the Obama administration has gotten around to requesting formal authorization from Congress to conduct that war.

headline: For Valentine’s Day, Adore Me Takes On Victoria’s Secret and Other Bigger Lingerie Rivals
abstract: In a field with a handful of major players, Adore Me, an online start-up, is following an ambitious plan that includes a TV marketing campaign.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks leading up to Valentine’s Day, the headquarters of Adore Me, a lingerie start-up, are frantic with activity, for good reason: Its daily sales in this period are more than 20 times the typical volume and nearly double those of Black Friday or Cyber Monday.

headline: Marcel Hirscher, a New Kind of Austrian Ski Star, Is Set to Add to His Title Collection
abstract: The 25-year-old Hirscher, a celebrity in his native Austria, could become the first man to win four gold medals in a single year at the Alpine world championships.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — After winning the world title in the Alpine combined on Sunday, and delivering on the high expectations of his ski-crazed country, Marcel Hirscher of Austria was able to relax. So he celebrated his victory the best way he knew how: with steins of beer and plates of Wiener schnitzel at the Austria House, a temporary outpost of his homeland here in the Vail Valley complete with apple strudel, oompah bands and women wearing dirndls.

headline: Some Weekend Wandering Yields Ancient English Coins
abstract: Some of the ancient English coins found by an amateur treasure-hunter are on display at the British Museum.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A cache of 11th-century coins found by an amateur treasure-hunter was unveiled at the British Museum here this week.

headline: A Police Sergeant Is Charged With Sexually Assaulting a Girl
abstract: Vladimir Krull, 37, was arrested and accused of repeatedly performing various sexual acts on a girl, now 14, from late 2013 through 2014.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police sergeant was arrested on Tuesday and charged with several counts of sexual assault, including rape and sexual misconduct, on a girl in the Bronx, the authorities said.

headline: Helen Mirren Returns to Buckingham Palace in ‘The Audience’
abstract: Nine years after her Oscar-winning role in “The Queen,” Ms. Mirren plays Elizabeth II again. This time, she’s on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “You bastard.”

headline: A Supermarket of Choices

lead_paragraph: To look at the spring collections is to see broad categories based on distinct, vintage styles.

headline: Kings of Their Crafts, but on Divergent Paths
abstract: Jon Stewart of “The Daily Show” is leaving on his own terms, while Brian Williams was suspended after an untruth was exposed.
lead_paragraph: Other than timing, Jon Stewart’s triumphant retirement and Brian Williams’s public and humbling disenfranchisement would seem to have little in common.

headline: Newsom Wastes No Time in Run for California Governor
abstract: The election might be four years away, but the race to be the next governor of California is already underway.
lead_paragraph: The election might be nearly four years away, but the race to be the next governor of California is already getting started.

headline: Can Jon Stewart Be Replaced?
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'News and News Media', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Television', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Who should take over when Mr. Stewart leaves “The Daily Show”? And can he or she approach the show the way that Mr. Stewart did?
lead_paragraph: As with many late-night departures in recent years, Jon Stewart’s announcement that he’ll be leaving “The Daily Show” quickly incited speculation about who would take over his job. As Deadline Hollywood puts it, denial is “the first stage of grief” for fans of Mr. Stewart — “Stage 2 is Replacement List Compilation.”

headline: Google, Mighty Now, but Not Forever
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The tech giant is trying to evolve beyond a search behemoth, but it faces the same problems as the once-mighty tech companies that came before it.
lead_paragraph: Technology giants often meet their end not with a bang but a whimper, a slow, imperceptible descent into irrelevancy that may not immediately be reflected in the anodyne language of corporate earnings reports.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Inherent Vice’
abstract: Mark Bridges talks about translating Thomas Pynchon’s descriptions into fashions that will work on screen.
lead_paragraph: There are often misperceptions about what a costume designer does, said Mark Bridges, the Oscar-winning designer of “The Artist” and a nominee once again for “Inherent Vice,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s take on the hemp-infused novel by Thomas Pynchon.

headline: PEN World Voices Festival Returns With Eye on Africa
abstract: Participants in the 11th annual festival will include Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Edwidge Danticat and Michael Ondaatje.
lead_paragraph: The PEN World Voices Festival has announced the schedule for its 11th annual incarnation, from May 4 to 10.

headline: Reducing Blood Pressure Lowers Risk of Diabetes Complications
abstract: Lowering blood pressure can significantly reduce the risk for many of the complications of Type 2 diabetes, a study concludes.
lead_paragraph: Lowering blood pressure can significantly reduce the risk for many of the complications of Type 2 diabetes, a review of data from 40 trials involving more than 100,000 people with diabetes has found.

headline: Premature Delivery Tied to Heart Risks in Mother
abstract: Premature delivery is tied to increased heart risks in the mother, a review of studies has found.
lead_paragraph: Premature delivery is tied to increased heart risks in the mother, a review of studies has found.

headline: On the Strauss-Kahn Trial Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Dan Bilefsky gives a glimpse of the scene at the trial of Dominique Strauss-Kahn in Lille, France.
lead_paragraph: Covering the trial of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former I.M.F chief accused of being part of a freewheeling global sex ring, presented a challenge. How should one cover the case in a manner that would not be too prurient or inappropriate for a family newspaper?

headline: Love and Politics Collide as Scandals Plague Oregon’s Fourth-Term Governor
abstract: Gov. John Kitzhaber is facing two recall efforts, demands for his resignation, an ethics inquiry into the business dealings of his fiancée and now a criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — The allegations swirling around Gov. John Kitzhaber and his live-in fiancée did not seem to bother Oregonians much when they re-elected him last fall to an unprecedented fourth term. But now, with hints of scandal tumbling out almost by the day — about the business dealings of the fiancée, her previous marriage and her role in state government — the reaction has descended into a mix of tittering gossip, outrage and dismay, threatening to tarnish the last years of one of the state’s most enduring politicians.

headline: Director of  Gardner Museum to Step Down
abstract: Anne Hawley, who has led the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston for 25 years, will retire at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Anne Hawley, who has led the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston for 25 years and oversaw an expansion that opened in 2012, more than doubling the museum’s footprint and increasing attendance, announced Wednesday that she planned to step down at the end of the year.

headline: Scott Walker, Traveling Abroad, Avoids Foreign Policy
abstract: In a long question and answer session hosted by the Chatham House, foreign policy was the only topic Gov. Scott Walker considered off limits.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin visited London on Wednesday on a trade mission that some saw as an opportunity to bolster his foreign policy bona fides as he looks toward a presidential run in 2016.

headline: First 911 Call
abstract: The first of two 911 calls, made at 5:11 p.m. on Tuesday, reporting a shooting in Chapel Hill, N.C. The caller describes hearing “multiple, between five and 10” gunshots and “kids screaming.”
lead_paragraph: The first of two 911 calls, made at 5:11 p.m. on Tuesday, reporting a shooting in Chapel Hill, N.C. The caller describes hearing “multiple, between five and 10” gunshots and “kids screaming.”

headline: Steps to Protect Your Tax Data as Refund Fraud Spreads
keywords: ['Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Criminals are filing returns using someone else’s Social Security number and then collecting the refund. The latest attack affected thousands of state returns.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s suspension of some electronic state tax filings because of a sudden increase in fraudulent returns highlights the need for consumers to track potential misuse of their personal information, especially at tax time.

headline: One Great Unknown Steps Into Another
abstract: James Corden, a bubbly, burly, bearded British actor and comedian not widely known in America, must decide what to create, keep or throw away in the program he is inheriting on CBS.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a sunny January afternoon, James Corden stood on the roof of CBS Television City, the boxy building where he will take over as host of the network’s “Late Late Show,” and surveyed his new domain.

headline: ‘My Name Is Rachel Corrie’ to Be Staged Off Broadway in April
abstract: The play, based on the writings of Ms. Corrie, a 23-year-old American woman who was killed by an Israeli Army bulldozer, sparked controversy during a New York run in 2006.
lead_paragraph: “My Name Is Rachel Corrie,” a one-woman drama about a pro-Palestinian activist, will be staged Off Broadway this spring for the first time since an earlier production nine years ago caused an uproar in some corners of the New York theater world. A spokesman for the show announced on Wednesday that the play would run April 2-12 at the Culture Project’s Lynn Redgrave Theater in the East Village.

headline: Kyle Bass Wields New Weapon in Challenging Drug Makers
abstract: It’s not clear, though, how Mr. Bass’s hedge fund, Hayman Capital, has an advantage over experienced generic firms, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Drug makers make unlikely candidates for the next big short. Kyle Bass, a hedge fund manager who bet successfully on a housing market crash in the United States, is aiming at pharmaceutical companies worth a combined $450 billion in market capitalization.

headline: Congress, Don’t Be Fooled; Obama Still Believes in Unlimited War
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Congress must repeal the open-ended authorization of force after 9/11 before considering a new one.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA is going before Congress to request authorization for the limited use of military force in a battle of up to three years against the Islamic State. On the surface, this looks like a welcome recognition of Congress’s ultimate authority in matters of war and peace. But unless the resolution put forward by the White House is amended, it will have the opposite effect. Congressional support will amount to the ringing endorsement of unlimited presidential war making.

headline: Captain of Ship That Capsized Off Italy in ’12 Is Convicted
abstract: Francesco Schettino, who was in charge of the cruise liner when it capsized in 2012, killing 32 people, was sentenced to just over 16 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An Italian court on Wednesday convicted the captain of a cruise liner that capsized in 2012, killing 32 people, of manslaughter and sentenced him to just over 16 years in prison for his role in one of the worst maritime disasters in modern Italian history.

headline: Facebook Takes Its Hardware Designs to a Giant Scale
abstract: The social networking giant has open sourced a new kind of computer networking switch that is says enables big, fast, efficient data centers for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Not content with connecting 1 billion-plus people, Facebook wants to connect millions of computer servers, too. The idea is to create technologies to handle data loads that are tens, even hundreds of times greater than what most companies have to handle today.

headline: Officer Charged in Akai Gurley Case Debated Reporting Gunshot, Officials Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: For four minutes after Officer Peter Liang fired his gun into a darkened housing project stairwell, he argued with his partner over whether to tell their superiors about the shot, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: For four minutes, a New York City police officer who had just fired his gun into a darkened housing project stairwell argued with his partner over whether to tell their superiors about the shot.

headline: Another Week at No. 1 for Taylor Swift
abstract: The singer’s “1989” claimed its 11th week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.
lead_paragraph: In a slow season for new albums, no one can beat Taylor Swift.

headline: Unauthorized Immigrants’ Access to Driver’s Licenses Is at Risk
abstract: With Republicans in control of the State Senate in Colorado, the funding for the licensing program was largely stripped, leaving applicants waiting. And in New Mexico, the governor wants to repeal the law allowing the licenses.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — His driver’s license is an economic lifeline, said Felipe Castro, an unauthorized immigrant from Mexico who commutes 40 miles each morning to his construction job in Northern Colorado. Or it was, until it expired last week.

keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Coral', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Reefs', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']

headline: Withdrawing Troops, Obama Calls for Vigilance on Ebola
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama said that most American military personnel working to fight Ebola in West Africa would soon come home, but that the disease had the potential to flare again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Wednesday that the United States was withdrawing almost all of its troops from the fight against Ebola in West Africa, but he said the world needed to remain vigilant as it sought to eradicate the deadly disease.

headline: Microsoft Continues Mobile Push With Sunrise Acquisition
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Google Phone', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mobile Applications', 'Software']
abstract: The company has acquired Sunrise Atelier, maker of the popular Sunrise calendar app for iOS, Android and Mac. The companies are not disclosing the sale price.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has again turned outside the company to bolster its mobile app offerings.

headline: Vienna, City of Dreams
abstract: Visit one of Europe’s crown jewels, where ultra-modern design mixes with classical music and historical architecture.
lead_paragraph: Known as “The City of Dreams,” Vienna, Austria, is one of Europe’s crown jewels. But modern Vienna is more than just a place for history buffs looking to explore extravagant attractions (though Schloss Belvedere and the Lipizzan ballet at the Imperial Palace certainly fit that description). It’s a host to a burgeoning community of designers and artists. Furthermore, the home city of Sigmund Freud also offers an array of indoor cultural experiences, making it an ideal wintertime destination. Here, in honor of the city’s festive ball season, is a guide to the places worth visiting.

headline: Doris Salcedo, Whose Art Honors Lives Lost, Gets a Retrospective in Chicago
abstract: The Colombian sculptor Doris Salcedo’s first museum retrospective opens this month at the Museum of the Contemporary Art in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When the elevators at the Museum of Contemporary Art here stop on the fourth floor, they usually open on a large, airy lobby with a view of Michigan Avenue. These days, they open onto a vast art installation by the Colombian sculptor Doris Salcedo that evokes a mass grave.
