headline: Where to Caffeinate, Juice Up and Wind Down During New York Fashion Week
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails', 'Coffee', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Restaurants']
abstract: We’ve compiled a list of the best spots to drop by for beverages between the shows.
lead_paragraph: Fashion Week starts tomorrow. And with the dizzying number of shows scattered throughout the city this season, attendees will have even less time than usual to settle in for leisurely breaks and repasts in between presentations. With a focus on what’s mostly new and talked-about this season, we’ve compiled a list of the best spots to drop by for beverages, whether it’s a hot coffee, a healthful juice or smoothie, or a day’s-end cocktail — in other words, the trifecta of Fashion Week drinking.

headline: Review: BalletNext Takes Risks in ‘Baroque’d’
abstract: The experimental dance company’s program at New York Live Arts plays between ballet and hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Despite its live music and the admirable skills of most of its dancers, “Baroque’d,” BalletNext’s program at New York Live Arts, is always less than good. It varies from the blandly vague (the first two items) to the amateurishly pseudo-experimental (the last). That last dance, “Something Sampled,” is sufficiently irksome to be considerably more memorable than the first two.

headline: Review: Janine Jansen and Itamar Golan Balance Power and Nuance at Zankel Hall
abstract: Ms. Jansen, a Dutch violinist, and Mr. Golan, an Israeli pianist, performed works including Prokofiev’s “Five Melodies for Violin and Piano” and Ravel’s Violin Sonata.
lead_paragraph: New York fans of the Dutch violinist Janine Jansen have had it rough in recent years. Illness caused her to bow out of high-profile concerts with the Budapest Festival Orchestra in 2013 and the New York Philharmonic last year. On Tuesday, she was back, in radiant form, with a recital at Zankel Hall alongside the Israeli pianist Itamar Golan, which proved that she is an artist worth the wait.

headline: Classical Playlist: J. S. Bach, Mendelssohn, Wu Man and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘J. S. BACH: CONCERTOS FOR OBOE AND OBOE D’AMORE’Gonzalo X. Ruiz, oboist; Portland Baroque Orchestra, Monica Huggett, violinist(Avie AV2324) The mellow, soulful sound of the Baroque oboe and oboe d’amore is the star attraction of this quietly compelling album of arrangements of Bach keyboard concertos featuring one of the pre-eminent artists on those instruments. The Baroque violinist Monica Huggett, at the helm of the Portland Baroque Orchestra, offers sensitive, stylish support. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Data Security Gaps in an Industry Student Privacy Pledge
abstract: Companies that signed on to an industry student privacy pledge have different interpretations of their obligation to maintain security measures for students’ personal details.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of a congressional hearing to explore the use of new technology in classrooms nationwide, a software engineer has found significant gaps in an industry effort to bolster student data security and privacy.

headline: On Set | Floral, Military Spring Fashion
abstract: T’s senior fashion editor Jason Rider reveals the inspirations behind styling a floral and military trend fashion spread for the magazine’s spring fashion issue.
lead_paragraph: T’s senior fashion editor Jason Rider reveals the inspirations behind styling a floral and military trend fashion spread for the magazine’s spring fashion issue.

headline: At Yale, Trading a Playbook for a Songbook
abstract: Brandon Sherrod, a starting forward for the Yale men’s basketball team, took off this school year to sing, perform and travel with the Whiffenpoofs, the university’s all-male a cappella group.
lead_paragraph: Approaching 10 p.m. on the eve of a recent blizzard, the Rockwood Music Hall, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, was running low on breathing room, packed so tightly that each whoosh of cold air from the opening of the rear door brought sharp-eyed looks from those inside — no more, please. Even the stage was jammed: four musicians (drummer, keyboardist, two guitarists) and four singers, one of whom, stashed in the corner, slapping a tambourine against his hip, stood 6 feet 6 inches.

headline: Smoking’s Toll on Health Is Even Worse Than Previously Thought, a Study Finds
abstract: A new analysis suggests that an additional 60,000 deaths a year in the United States are linked to smoking.
lead_paragraph: However bad you thought smoking was, it’s even worse.

headline: Review: Sara Gazarek Exudes Confidence and Cheer
abstract: This West Coast jazz singer, a rhythmically adept and accomplished scat improviser, offers a far-reaching repertoire.
lead_paragraph: The West Coast jazz singer Sara Gazarek, who appeared at Birdland on Tuesday evening, has many of the right moves. Rhythmically adept, she is an accomplished scat improviser who exudes an engaging blend of confidence and cheer. Her singing, at its most inventive, recalls Jane Monheit’s flights of fancy but without Ms. Monheit’s vocal lushness. She is at ease with tricky samba rhythms that break up phrases into staccato exclamations, and her far-reaching taste in songs encompasses both standards and original collaborations that take her in a pop direction.

headline: On JetBlue, Passengers Can Use Apple Pay
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'iPhone', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Starting this month, JetBlue will allow customers to use Apple Pay for in-flight purchases.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a frequent flier, JetBlue has just given you one more excuse to upgrade to an iPhone 6. This week the airline announced that it would become the first to allow its customers to use Apple Pay to make in-flight purchases.

headline: Beautiful Unrest: Roughed-Up Florals for Spring

headline: Obama on His Islamic State Resolution
abstract: President Obama described the resolution he submitted to Congress for authorization to use military force against ISIS. He said it did not authorize a ground war like those in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: President Obama described the resolution he submitted to Congress for authorization to use military force against ISIS. He said it did not authorize a ground war like those in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Review: ‘Single, Carefree, Mellow,’ Except for That Illicit Affair
abstract: Katherine Heiny’s short stories focus on women who rush into adultery and other things society wouldn’t approve of.
lead_paragraph: The young woman in the first story in Katherine Heiny’s debut collection, “Single, Carefree, Mellow,” has never lived in an apartment with air-conditioning. But that’s about as close to hardship as Ms. Heiny’s heroines get. Most are urban American semi-strivers, worrying a little about work, a little about happiness and a lot about the illicit affairs they’re carrying on. When it comes to these liaisons, Ms. Heiny has a fine way of keeping her women sharply perceptive about details yet too delusional to see the big picture.

headline: They’ll Just Hate to See Jon Stewart Go (So They Say)
abstract: Politicians and others at the end of a Jon Stewart punch line insist that his parting from “The Daily Show” will be such sweet sorrow.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He has all but called them losers and fools, but when Jon Stewart announced on Tuesday that he would leave “The Daily Show” sometime this year, many politicians and news media personalities had something of an unusual reaction: grief.

headline: ‘Deutschland 83’ and ‘Shkufim’ Are Among Exciting International Series
abstract: For the first time, the Berlin film festival showcased a range of television shows that are now being aired in international markets.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Sometimes there are limits to the imagination. Luckily, reality is much more boundless.

headline: A Credit to the Game Leaves a Legacy
abstract: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Ernesto d’Orsi, died last month.
lead_paragraph: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Ernesto d’Orsi, died on Jan. 9 in his hometown, São Paulo, Brazil. He was 78.

headline: Review: In ‘Iphigénie en Aulide,’ a Daughter’s Ultimate Sacrifice
abstract: This concert production by the Metropolitan Opera and the Juilliard School drives home how strong performances outweigh the need for elaborate sets.

headline: For New York Fashion Week, Look-at-Me Style Statements
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Sneakers', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Deep green is having a fashion moment; sneakers give heels the boot and more.
lead_paragraph: As Fashion Week comes to town on Thursday, the streets will fill with look-at-me style statements. But fewer of those, we suspect, will be ratcheted to the heavens on sky-high heels. It’s all about sneakers now. So which will be the most popular of the season? We’re betting on these styles, some of which, like the pastel Stan Smiths reinterpreted by Raf Simons, were previewed by attendees at last month’s fashion shows in Paris. Safer passage across New York’s patches of ice is but a bonus.

headline: By Their Emails Ye Shall Know Them
abstract: Kansas lawmakers are asking why they were kept in the dark even as Gov. Sam Brownback’s office was sharing his pending state budget with lobbyists.
lead_paragraph: The art of legislative power is being in the know before anyone else – which is why rank-and-file Kansas lawmakers are asking why they were kept in the dark for weeks even as Gov. Sam Brownback’s office was sharing his pending state budget with a couple of heavyweight statehouse lobbyists. The sneak preview was allowed for a select few state officials plus David Kensinger, who resigned three years ago as the governor’s chief of staff to become lobbyist for the powerfully conservative Club for Growth, and Mark Dugan, another ranking lobbyist who previously served as Mr. Brownback’s campaign manager.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: A collection of shopping suggestions and sales.
lead_paragraph: Not on Fashion GPS? There are still plenty of ways to take part in New York Fashion Week festivities. On Thursday, from 2 to 6 p.m. at Fivestory, you can sip pink Champagne and shop Valentine’s Day confections — Treat House Rice Krispies bars ($24 for 12), heart- and penguin-shaped New York Cake Pops ($19.99 for six) and Jars by Dani parfait-like creations ($6.25 for a four-ounce Mason jar) — from some purveyors of the fashion flock’s favorite guilty pleasures. They are not the only goodies: There’s a new Kotur x Fivestory glitter globe minaudière ($445), as well as drapey tees from the London cult T-shirt label Rotten Roach with witty slogans by the illustrator Hugo Guinness ($106) for those wanting something a little less, well, sugar-coated. At 18 East 69th Street.

headline: Public School Is Giving Women Their Due

lead_paragraph: “Walk strong,” Piergiorgio Del Moro, the casting agent, urged. Avery, a model, complied, stalking the makeshift runway at Milk Studios in Chelsea the other day with a scissors-like stride and a scowl. Avery didn't make the cut, but those loose-limbed girls who did were invited to walk once more, each cocooned in a flyaway puffer coat.

They named the business Dmitriy & Company, inspired by Mr. Feldman’s Russian-born grandfather, who had a pillow shop on the Lower East Side.

lead_paragraph: On the third try, the Deep Space Climate Observatory rose into the sky above Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Wednesday night atop a Falcon 9 rocket built by the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, or SpaceX.

headline: Fashion’s Racial Divide
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Fewer than 4 percent of the 260 fashion designers showing at New York Fashion Week are African-American.
lead_paragraph: When Michelle Obama stepped onto the stage at the Democratic National Convention in 2012 to talk about her husband and the coming election, the Internet went into an effective group swoon. Words like “spotlight stealing” and “dazzling” were used with abandon. Not about the first lady’s speech, but about her dress: a shimmering pink and silver sleeveless number by the designer Tracy Reese.

headline: In Sort-of-Defense of Roy Moore
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Alabama judge isn’t George Wallace.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice Roy Moore of the Alabama Supreme Court is trying to block same-sex marriage in his state, despite a federal court order allowing it. Moore told “Good Morning America” that he is confident he will “absolutely not” end up on the wrong side of history. The fact that 36 states (apart from Alabama) now allow same-sex marriage, with rising support from the public, suggests he’s probably wrong about that. His central legal claim — that same-sex marriage is a states’ rights issue, rather than one that implicates the guarantee of equality in the Constitution — is also a loser. Moore argued that “redefinition of the word marriage is not found within the powers designated to the federal government,” but Congress makes all kinds of rules involving marriage (and pensions and taxes) and the Supreme Court has previously ruled that marriage is a fundamental right.

headline: The Hollyhock House Comes Into Its Own
abstract: Jeffrey Herr, curator of Hollyhock House, on the restoration and reopening of Frank Lloyd Wright’s first Los Angeles house.
lead_paragraph: Finally, the planets seem to have aligned for Frank Lloyd Wright’s Hollyhock House. On Jan. 30, the United States Department of the Interior announced its decision, seven years in the making, to nominate the 1921 Los Angeles home, along with nine other works by Wright, to the Unesco World Heritage List, which includes icons like the Taj Mahal and Statue of Liberty. And tomorrow, the building, now a house museum, will reopen after a four-year $4.3 million restoration.

abstract: Tylt, Ampl Labs, Phorce and Voltaic Systems offer bags that can protect and recharge smartphones, tablets, laptops headphones and game players.
lead_paragraph: WITH people juggling multiple digital devices that constantly need charging, backpack manufacturers have sensed a market opportunity. Some new backpacks are specifically designed not only to protect our smartphones, tablets, laptops, headphones and game players, but also to recharge them and track their whereabouts.

headline: The Pillow Cure
keywords: ['Beds and Bedding', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Sleep', 'Neck', 'Back (Human Body Part)', 'Pillows']
abstract: Can the right pillow fix what ails you? One reporter tests seven in six nights, in an effort to find out.
lead_paragraph: My neck is killing me. Isn’t yours? My shoulder hurts, too. Not always the same one, but always in the morning. Herniated disks, spinal stenosis, bone spurs: It’s a mess in there. As for the shoulders, one gave out with a horrible popping noise in a yoga class a few years ago; the cause of the other’s decay remains a (very dull) mystery.

headline: Education Is Newest Target of Kansas Budget Cuts
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas, the budget headaches have continued: January receipts fell short of predictions, and Mr. Brownback has responded by cutting funding for public schools and higher education.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — In November, shortly after Gov. Sam Brownback won re-election, experts forecast that the state would bring in $1 billion less than expected over the next two years. He responded by cutting state agency budgets and proposing the transfer of funds among various state accounts. In December came news of a revenue slump, falling to $15.1 million below estimates. Mr. Brownback proposed increasing taxes on liquor and cigarettes, slowed reductions in the income tax and changed the way money was distributed to public schools.

headline: Corruption Scandal at Petrobras Threatens Brazil’s Economy

lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil – The accusations of corruption at Brazil’s state-controlled petroleum giant Petrobras have already led to a political scandal and a change in management. Now, the problems are threatening other Brazilian companies and may even tip the country into recession.

headline: A Black Preacher Addresses Congress
abstract: On Feb. 12, 1865, Henry Highland Garnet gave a searing sermon before the House and Senate. How did he get there?
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Feb. 12, 1865, Henry Highland Garnet, minister of the Fifteenth Street Presbyterian Church in Washington, entered the halls of Congress. He could not escape notice. He was, his friend Alexander Crummell later wrote in his Eulogium on Garnet’s life, “tall and majestic in stature, over six feet in height, with a large and noble head, its front both broad and expansive, his chest deep and strong, his limbs straight and perfectly moulded.” Garnet was in the House of Representatives that morning at the invitation of William Henry Channing, chaplain of Congress, to deliver a sermon. Channing’s request was hardly a surprise; after all, the Capitol had served as a church for many decades, and preachers had long spoken in its halls. What was astonishing was that Garnet was a black man, no longer relegated to the galleries but standing at the speaker’s dais.

headline: Indonesia’s Graft Fight Strikes Fear Even Among the Honest
abstract: The cases of three businessmen imprisoned — wrongly by even government accounts — as part of an anticorruption plan have raised fears that the program has run off the rails.
lead_paragraph: BANDUNG, Indonesia — One is a telecommunications executive, another the former president-director of a state airline, and the third a project manager for Chevron.

keywords: ['Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Racial Profiling', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: James B. Comey will be attempting something that politicians and law enforcement leaders have failed to do without causing a backlash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, on Thursday will wade into the national debate about the relationship between police officers and African-Americans that was highlighted by the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man in Ferguson, Mo., in August. It will be the first time one of the bureau’s directors has publicly addressed the issue of race at length.

The occasion was the inauguration of a new think tank devoted to United States-Russia cooperation on financial and energy security, and the speaker, Andrey Vavilov, had donated money.

headline: In India, Glimpses of Economic Optimism and Frustration
abstract: As India’s economy revs up, it needs to make sure that the poor are not left behind.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Arriving at the new international airport here last month, I felt like I had gotten on the wrong connecting flight and ended up in Shanghai. Instead of the smelly and decaying terminal I remembered from the four years I spent here as a news correspondent, the building was sparkling. The walkway to the immigration counter doubled as a museum filled with paintings, sculptures and handmade crafts from around the country.

headline: Part Villain, Part Victim, Jerry Tarkanian Simply Won
abstract: Tarkanian showed that what we want from our college coaches are, mostly, wins and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: It was strange that Dean Smith and Jerry Tarkanian died within days of each other. They were coaching peers from opposite sides of the reputational spectrum, with Smith, the longtime coach at North Carolina, remembered as the gentlemanly throwback to a time when coaching was done right and Tarkanian cast as the misunderstood pioneer of an era — the same era — when it all went wrong.

headline: Landlord Bribed Inspectors in Ruse to Evict Tenants, Prosecutors Say
abstract: A plot to trick a Brooklyn building’s residents into moving was just one discovery of a bribery and kickback investigation involving city workers and others that resulted in dozens of indictments this week.
lead_paragraph: One night last December around nine o’clock, tenants at 159 Suydam Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, were startled by loud banging on their doors and walls. A man in some kind of uniform was going up and down the four stories of their building, yelling that they had 72 hours to get out.

headline: In ‘Fashions for Men’ and ‘Everything You Touch,’ Clothes Are a Main Player
abstract: “Fashions,” set in a Budapest haberdashery between the word wars, and “Everything,” a decades-hopping fashion fantasia, use costumes to grab the audience’s attention.
lead_paragraph: Many costume designers claim that the best examples of their work are the ones that go unnoticed, that serve the play while staying demurely in the background.

headline: Little League Scandal Shows Why Baseball Is Better Viewed From Afar
abstract: From far away, you can pretend that the game is just the way you remember playing it as a child, and just the way Little League International claims it to be.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a tip on choosing the perfect seats for this summer’s Little League World Series.

headline: Taiwan: Six Inmates Kill Themselves, Official Says
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Armed inmates, who held a warden and a guard hostage at a prison in southern Taiwan, committed suicide early Thursday after releasing the hostages, said a Justice Ministry official, Chen Ming-tang.
lead_paragraph: Six inmates at a prison in southern Taiwan killed themselves Thursday morning, ending an overnight hostage situation, a Justice Ministry official said. Two prison staff members were released unharmed after being held for 14 hours at the Kaohsiung Prison, said the official, Chen Ming-tang, a vice minister in the Justice Ministry. The six inmates, who were all serving lengthy terms for crimes that included drug trafficking and murder, apparently complained about their living conditions to get a meeting with prison officials, whom they then took hostage on Wednesday, according to local news reports. The inmates later took firearms from a prison armory, Taiwan’s Central News Agency reported. Taiwanese news outlets broadcast a series of demands from the men, including that they be provided with vehicles and that former President Chen Shui-bian, who was convicted of embezzlement and taking bribes in 2009, be returned to prison. Mr. Chen was released on medical parole in January. But early Thursday, the six inmates shot themselves, Mr. Chen, the ministry official, said in a brief televised interview. He provided few details about the episode.

headline: Christophe Gbenye, Radical Nationalist in Congo, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Gbenye, a Belgian-trained civil servant, was briefly one of several pivotal players in the seesawing civil wars waged by superpower proxies after the Belgian colonial regime left in 1960.
lead_paragraph: Christophe Gbenye, a radical nationalist whose brutal rebel warriors seized control of eastern Congo in 1964 and held hundreds of foreigners hostage until they were rescued by Belgian paratroopers dropping from American planes, died on Feb. 3 in Kinshasa. He was 88.

headline: In Adolf Hitler’s Hometown, Trying to Overcome a Legacy of Evil
abstract: An Austrian city is struggling, still, with what to do with the house where Hitler was born in 1889.
lead_paragraph: BRAUNAU AM INN, Austria — Days after this city across the river from Bavaria surrendered to the United States Army in May 1945, a group of German soldiers sought to flatten a three-story house here that had served as a Nazi pilgrimage site and shrine since the late 1930s.

Jay Nixon’s response last year to unrest in Ferguson as they opened hearings into how state money was spent and why a swath of suburban St. Louis was burned and looted even after the National Guard had been activated.

headline: Rose E. Frisch, Scientist Who Linked Body Fat to Fertility, Dies at 96
abstract: Dr. Frisch’s work showed that women without enough body fat would have trouble becoming pregnant but also had a lower risk of breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Rose E. Frisch, a scientist whose influential work showed that women without enough body fat would have trouble becoming pregnant, but that they also had a lower risk of breast cancer, died on Jan. 30 at an assisted-living facility in Cambridge, Mass. She was 96.

headline: Threading Needle in Wording of a Military Proposal
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s request was crafted to soothe Democrats who don’t want another war and assure Republicans that the United States will do what it takes to defeat Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In formally asking Congress to authorize a three-year military campaign against the Islamic State, President Obama has carefully worded his request to soothe worried Democrats who do not want another big war. At the same time, he is assuring Republican hawks that the American military will do what it takes to defeat the Sunni militant group.

headline: Review: ‘Rasheeda Speaking’ Finds a Chilling Place to Work

headline: In Ukraine, It’s Putin’s Game

Yet when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia sat down Wednesday in the Belarussian capital of Minsk with the leaders of Ukraine, Germany and France to discuss the conflict in eastern Ukraine, he still held the decisive cards.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE SLAP Hector (Peter Sarsgaard) is a public servant, a father and a potentially philandering husband who has just lost out on a big job promotion. He finds his life in additional turmoil on the day of his 40th birthday party when his hotheaded cousin (Zachary Quinto) slaps the bullying 5-year-old son of another couple, inciting legal action — and resurrecting some long-buried family secrets. Melissa George plays the boy’s mother; Thandie Newton is Hector’s beautiful wife; and Uma Thurman, Thomas Sadoski, Brian Cox and Makenzie Leigh round out the cast of this eight-part mini-series adapted by Jon Robin Baitz from an Australian series based on a novel by Christos Tsiolkas. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called the show “a remarkable feat — a sophisticated, suspenseful comedy of ill manners that seems much more like a Showtime or Netflix drama than a broadcast network offering.” “The Slap,” she added, “connects, but it’s not a harsh blow. It’s more of a bracing surprise.”

The winning image is part of a photo essay on the effects of an anti-gay law passed in Russia in 2013. headline: What Our Paranoia About Drones Says About Us
abstract: Anxiety in the age of democratized aviation.
lead_paragraph: A lazy drift of mist obscured an already gray November morning as I stared skeptically skyward in Morningside Park. It was not, I told myself, technically raining; still, moisture had begun to collect in the folds of my jacket as I surveyed the weather conditions. Driven more by impatience than by prudence, I decided to go ahead with the plan. Carefully following the precise sequence prescribed by the instructions, I switched on my remote controller and then the Wi-Fi transmitter, and finally double-pressed the power button on the back of the DJI Phantom 2 Vision quadcopter I purchased the night before. The copter trilled, then emitted four consecutive beeps. The GPS system began searching for satellites to map its launch coordinates, and a moment later the rotors whirred to life, sending ripples across a nearby puddle. And then the drone was airborne, rising to a hover six feet above me, conducting an aerial choreography to maintain its position despite the wind pushing it toward Manhattan Avenue. The copter streamed an image to my iPhone — me with my cap pulled low against the November drizzle, head tilted to meet the camera’s gaze. A drone selfie. Portrait of a man under self-surveillance.

headline: After Finding 17-Pound Gold Nugget in Shape of China, Herder Waits to See if He Can Keep It
abstract: The Chinese news media have reported that the Qinghe County Bureau of Land Resources has no intention of taking the nugget from the herdsman.
lead_paragraph: Berek Sawut, an ethnic Kazakh herder, was overwhelmed by hundreds of calls a day after the Chinese news media reported last week that he had stumbled across a 17-pound gold nugget in the foothills of the Altay range of northwest China. The nugget, in the shape of China, was the largest discovery of its kind in the vast region of Xinjiang.

headline: Expedia to Acquire Orbitz as Travel Sites Consolidate
abstract: The transaction further solidifies the American market for online travel booking to two companies, Expedia and the much bigger Priceline Group.
lead_paragraph: The online travel booking company Expedia clearly believes bigger is better.

headline: New Hampshire’s Wistful Look at Off-the-Cuff Politics
abstract: When a group of journalists, New Hampshire pols and former presidential candidates got together Wednesday night to honor the 100th anniversary of the first-in-the-nation primary, there was much yearning for the good old days.
lead_paragraph: When a group of journalists, New Hampshire pols and former presidential candidates got together Wednesday night to honor the 100th anniversary of the first-in-the-nation primary, there was much yearning for the good old days.

headline: Bombardier’s C.E.O., Pierre Beaudoin, Will Step Down
abstract: The unexpected shake-up came as the aircraft and railway equipment maker announced a loss of $1.59 billion in its last quarter.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The chief executive of the aircraft and railway equipment maker Bombardier, Pierre Beaudoin, will step down, as the company announced dismal earnings and the need to raise additional capital.

headline: District in Tokyo Plans to Extend Rights of Gay Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Leaders in the Shibuya area unveiled a draft of a new statute on Thursday and said it was expected to be approved in a local assembly vote next month.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A district in Tokyo plans to give same-sex couples the same legal rights as married opposite-sex spouses, becoming the first local government in Japan to do so at a time when gay marriage is a hot-button issue in many countries.

headline: A First-Time Home in the City
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Tori Porpora and Emma Murphy, Columbia students, wanted to share a two-bedroom apartment.
lead_paragraph: As a graduate student at Teachers College, Columbia University, Victoria Porpora commuted to school from her parents’ home in Scarsdale, N.Y., where she grew up. The trip by Metro-North train to New York City took nearly an hour each way, because her arrival and departure point was the Harlem-125th Street Station on the East Side, and Columbia is on the West Side. “The crosstown bus was the killer,” she said. “It stops at almost every corner.”

headline: Harvard and M.I.T. Are Sued Over Lack of Closed Captions
abstract: Federal lawsuits filed by advocates for the deaf says both schools violate antidiscrimination laws by not providing closed captioning in online lectures and podcasts.
lead_paragraph: Advocates for the deaf on Thursday filed federal lawsuits against Harvard and M.I.T., saying both universities violated antidiscrimination laws by failing to provide closed captioning in their online lectures, courses, podcasts and other educational materials.

headline: Simmering Labor Fight Brings Crippling Delays to West Coast Seaports
abstract: Workers and management give opposite explanations for the increasing delays, each side blaming the other in a dispute that is starting to pinch businesses.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The container ships arrive here filled with appliances, toys, apparel, auto parts, computer components and untold other products from Asia, to head out to stores and factories across America.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Valentine’s Days of the Past
abstract: Searching “Valentine’s Day” in Times Machine will turn up all kinds of interesting things: an 1869 article about a “red-hot time” at the Post Office; a piece on a 1932 trend toward insult-valentines; and a report on the math of Valentine’s Day 1937 at Skidmore College.
lead_paragraph: Searching “Valentine’s Day” in Times Machine will turn up all kinds of interesting things: an 1869 article about a “red-hot time” at the Post Office; a piece on a 1932 trend toward insult-valentines; and the report, above, on the math of Valentine’s Day 1937 at one college:

headline: Democrats Pick Philadelphia for 2016 Convention
abstract: The Democrats, anticipating the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall enfolding their presidential nominee in a patriotic glow, chose Philadelphia over New York and Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the private nighttime visit to Independence National Historical Park, where the Democrats’ top national official got to touch the Liberty Bell.

headline: Ryanair Loses Its Latest Challenge on Order to Sell Aer Lingus Stake
abstract: The ruling is Ryanair’s third legal defeat of the case in Britain, and the airline vowed to appeal — on human rights grounds.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A British court on Thursday rejected Ryanair’s latest challenge to a ruling that it sell most of its 29 percent stake in the Aer Lingus, upholding a finding by regulators that the holding gives Europe’s largest low-cost airline undue influence over its smaller Irish rival.

headline: Composer Knows His Competition Quite Well: Himself
abstract: Alexandre Desplat is nominated for best score twice: for “The Grand Budapest Hotel” and “The Imitation Game.”
lead_paragraph: Alexandre Desplat, the highly sought after award-winning French composer who just collected his second Bafta award, has been nominated for an Oscar eight times, but this year he is arguably facing his fiercest competitor yet: himself.

headline: I Don’t Think So: Writing Effective Counterarguments
abstract: How do writers analyze subjects and ideas to make a claim using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence? How does incorporating counterarguments in persuasive writing strengthen one’s claims?
lead_paragraph: Overview | How do writers analyze subjects and ideas to make a claim using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence? How does incorporating counterarguments in persuasive writing strengthen one’s claims?

headline: How Mortgage Fraud Made the Financial Crisis Worse
abstract: A study examines the practice of inflating borrowers’ incomes in order to get them larger loans.
lead_paragraph: The financial crisis was caused in part by widespread fraud, which may seem like an obvious point. But it remains surprisingly controversial.

headline: Funeral for Muslims Killed in Chapel Hill Draws Thousands
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: “Please involve the F.B.I.,” Dr. Mohammad Abu-Salha, whose daughters and son-in-law were killed Tuesday in North Carolina, implored at a service.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The three friends drove here Thursday from Blacksburg, Va., 190 miles to the north. Dressed in hijab and fashionable dresses, carrying a fabric floral arrangement in a gold-colored pot, they came for the funeral of the three Arab-American students who were gunned down at their home a couple of days earlier.

headline: Teaching Students How to Talk Less, and Think More
abstract: Parents often worry that a teacher calls on some students more than others, or that quieter children are overlooked in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: This week’s question comes from a discussion on my Facebook feed, in which Mark North, an instructor at Highline Community College in Des Moines, Wash., asked for suggestions about how to manage students who monopolize class time with their comments. I often get the flip side of this question from parents who say their child’s teacher calls on some students and not others, or from parents who are concerned that their quiet child gets overlooked in class.

headline: Does Your Work Fit Your Life?
abstract: Do you have a flexible schedule, or one that helps you meet your needs or those of your family? Tell us about it!
lead_paragraph: Flexible work schedules have come in for a lot of praise lately. Last year, President Obama called for greater flexibility for federal workers — “to attract, empower, and retain a talented and productive work force in the 21st century,” he wrote in a memorandum, “the Federal Government must continue to make progress in enabling employees to balance their responsibilities at work and at home.” This year, he’s been advocating for paid family and sick leave. In December, a study suggested that work might be contributing to Americans’ sleep deprivation — its authors argued that “making the work start time more flexible may help increase sleep time; even if total time spent working is kept constant.” And in January, Samantha Cole at Fast Company reported on another study, this one finding that employees who were given flexible schedules and the option to work from home slept more than other workers, and also felt more well rested.

headline: Oscars 2015: A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis Discuss the Contenders
abstract: More people watch the Academy Awards ceremony than watch the nominated movies, leading to a question: Why are people often more interested in the politics behind films than the films themselves?
lead_paragraph: A love-fest and a hate-watch, the Academy Awards is one of the few widely seen real-time television events left. Last year, an estimated 43 million Americans watched the ceremony and clearly not because it’s good entertainment. It isn’t even obvious that people love the movies in contention. When “12 Years a Slave” won best picture, only about six million people had seen the film; “Gravity” sold many more theater tickets, but even so, more people watched the Oscars than had seen that movie then. To judge from the recent flurry of culture-war-inflected skirmishes about some of the nominees, it’s clear that it’s no longer a question of whether the Oscars matter but why. Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott have been observing the commotion and offer some late-breaking critical views on the race as it enters its frenzied final stretch.

headline: 1915: Wilson Sends Berlin Ultimatum
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: President Wilson gives Germany an ultimatum in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a firm, but respectful, Message, which New York papers, led by the New York Herald, described as ‘‘an ultimatum to prevent war,’’ President Wilson has notified Berlin that the sinking of an American ship by a German war vessel will constrain the American Government to hold the German Government to strict account, and to take any steps necessary to safeguard American life and property. The Note to Germany reminds the Imperial Government that ‘‘the sole right of belligerents is limited to visit and search unless a blockade is effectively maintained — which this Government does not understand is proposed in this case.’’ To Note continues: ‘‘To declare of exercise the right to attack or destroy any vessel entering the prescribed area on the high seas without first determining its belligerent nationality and the contraband character of its cargo is an act so unprecedented in naval warfare that this Government is reluctant to believe that the Imperial Government of Germany in this case contemplates it as possible.’’— The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 13, 1915

headline: Amy Pascal Says Sony Pushed Her Out of Studio Post
abstract: Amy Pascal, the Sony Pictures head, told a public forum that contract renewal talks played a role in the events that led to her approaching exit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “All I did was get fired,” Amy Pascal said during a public discussion at the Women in the World conference in San Francisco on Wednesday.

headline: I.M.F. Aid ‘a Turning Point for Ukraine’
abstract: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, announced Ukraine is set to receive a $17.5 billion funding package to help the country’s struggling economy.
lead_paragraph: Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, announced Ukraine is set to receive a $17.5 billion funding package to help the country’s struggling economy.

abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French leftists protest American presence in Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations near the American Embassy in Paris against the Vietnam War (britishpathe.com)

abstract: The members-only club, built by men in their 30s and 40s, is reputed to be the largest and most elaborate of its kind in Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: The members-only club, built by men in their 30s and 40s, is reputed to be the largest and most elaborate of its kind in Long Island City.

headline: A Forest’s Family Roots Stand in a Pipeline’s Path
abstract: In 1947, Henry Kernan bought 1,000 acres of land in upstate New York, a tract his family has kept pristine ever since. Now, though, a natural gas pipeline is poised to run through it.
lead_paragraph: HARPERSFIELD, N.Y. — With snowshoes strapped to his feet and a fedora atop his head, Dev Kernan tramped deep into the snowy woods and finally stopped to admire a majestic red oak.

headline: 1927 | ‘Commercial Use in Doubt,’ The Times Said. About Television.
abstract: David W. Dunlap looks back at one of the first mentions of the television in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: ‘The Whites,’ by Richard Price Writing as Harry Brandt
abstract: Richard Price’s new novel, written under a pseudonym, is about a New York detective and an unsolved case that haunts him.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, in a magazine interview, Richard Price (now the author of nine novels, including “Clockers” and “Lush Life”) was asked why he devoted so much of his considerable literary talent to crime fiction and film scripts featuring criminals. He responded by saying that when you circle around a murder long enough you get to know a city. I cut that line out of the magazine and taped it above my computer screen. For several years, it presided over what I wrote in my own novels. With that answer, I believed that Price had crystallized what many writers knew and attempted to practice. That is, he considered the crime novel something more than a puzzle and an entertainment; he saw it as societal reflection, documentation and investigation.

headline: Charles Pétillon’s “Invasions” Animate the Ordinary
abstract: The artist uses enormous balloon installations to change derelict buildings and mundane scenery into works of extraordinary beauty.
lead_paragraph: The artist uses enormous balloon installations to change derelict buildings and mundane scenery into works of extraordinary beauty.

headline: A Sentimental Cover Song From the Singer-Songwriter Jessie Baylin
abstract: The Nashville-based chanteuse’s forthcoming album “Dark Place” ends with a dreamy, sultry version of Bette Midler’s “Do You Want to Dance,” which premieres here.
lead_paragraph: A lot has changed for Jessie Baylin since the release of her 2012 album, “Little Spark.” For starters, the New Jersey-born singer-songwriter has put down some serious roots in Tennessee with her husband, the Kings of Leon drummer Nathan Followill. She also became a mother to their now-2-year-old daughter Violet, and she strongly considered putting her music career to bed for good. “I wasn’t sure if I wanted to make another album,” she recalls from her Nashville home. “I felt something was happening and I had some ideas, but I wasn’t writing as much and my focus was elsewhere.”

lead_paragraph: Despite the recent tumult in Alabama surrounding same-sex marriage, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said on Thursday that it “would not take a large adjustment” for the country if the Supreme Court ruled that same-sex marriage was a constitutional right.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — ONE of the biggest coups of the recent North American International Auto Show in Detroit was Ford’s new GT, a sleek supercar that was developed in secret and revealed to a surprised audience.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A federal appeals court said Thursday that it would hear arguments on whether to move the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the Boston Marathon bombings, out of the city.

headline: A Closely Watched Metric That Can Be More Art Than Math
abstract: Debt issuers are taking unusual license in how they calculate Ebitda — earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization — leading to the mispricing of risk for investors, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: As investors engage in an increasingly desperate global competition for higher-yielding securities, debt issuers appear to be taking advantage of the extraordinary demand by manipulating one of Wall Street’s favorite metrics of profitability.

headline: N.B.A. Is Having an All-Star Party (and You’re Not Invited to the Main Event)
keywords: ['Basketball', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'ALL STAR GAMES']
abstract: With New York set to host the All-Star Game, tickets for the game and other competitions were not made available for public sale for the fifth straight year.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is doing just fine these days. The game is in the hands of immensely popular stars like LeBron James and Kevin Durant. New contenders, like the Golden State Warriors and the Atlanta Hawks, have added appealing story lines to the regular season. And the league’s owners will soon be reaping the benefits of a new television contract that will pay out $2.66 billion a year, nearly triple the amount of the current deal.

headline: Do Millennials Watch Jon Stewart?
abstract: Approximately 780,000 millennials are regular Daily Show watchers.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom is that the millennial generation is infatuated with Jon Stewart’s The Daily Show – to the point where it’s their main news source – but that’s not right.

headline: F.B.I. Director Speaks Out on Race and Police Bias
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Racial Profiling', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

Comey, delivered an unusually candid speech on Thursday about the difficult relationship between the police and African-Americans, saying that officers who work in neighborhoods where blacks commit crimes at a high rate develop a cynicism that shades their attitudes about race.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday confirmed Ashton B. Carter to be the next defense secretary, installing a new Pentagon chief as the United States increases military action against the Islamic State.

headline: Let Children Change
abstract: When parents keep expecting our kids to repeat old mistakes, we’re saying “you can’t change,” or maybe “you can’t change while I’m still here.” Bad plan.
lead_paragraph: For a large part of my life, I was constantly late. I spent hours in detention in high school, and was once threatened with jail for being late to court as a lawyer. Our oldest son was tardy (because of me) more than 50 times during his first semester of kindergarten. I annoyed people, disappointed people, let people down.

headline: Larry Summers Likes the Idea of Bitcoin
abstract: The former Treasury secretary said the virtual currency could help reduce costs and inefficiencies in the global payments system. But so could other payment technologies.
lead_paragraph: As Treasury secretary, Lawrence H. Summers took on complex economic policy.

headline: A Deep Discount on Yahoo’s Alibaba Stake Spinoff
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A calculation suggests that investors are attaching a 34 percent discount to the American company’s holding of Alibaba shares – assuming Yahoo’s core business is worth something. That’s too cautious, says Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo can’t even earn a reward for doing what shareholders wanted.

headline: QE Truthers
abstract: The conspiracy to avoid fiscal crisis.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows about the infamous open letter warning Ben Bernanke not to engage in quantitative easing, lest he cause inflation and currency debasement; many are also familiar with the remarkable unwillingness of that letter’s signatories to admit, after more than four years of low inflation and a rising dollar, that they were wrong. But not many people seem to know about an opinion piece by John Taylor and Paul Ryan, released at about the same time, that is even more revealing about the GOP’s monetary madness.

headline: Disney Tackles Succession, This Time Without Drama
abstract: Robert Iger’s selection of the next chief executive at Disney seems to be made. Or could there be a surprise sleeper candidate?
lead_paragraph: To the growing list of Robert Iger’s accomplishments during his near-decade tenure as Disney’s chief executive, add succession planning.

headline: Review: Tomi Ungerer, Bad Boy of Art, in a Reappraisal
abstract: This author and illustrator is the subject of a survey at the Drawing Center that encompasses his children’s books as well as his political cartoons and erotic drawings.
lead_paragraph: Among New York’s several alternative spaces, the Drawing Center often seems to do the least with the most. Its recently refurbished, overdone SoHo space regularly features exhibitions that end up looking academic, dutiful and dull, regardless of how interesting they may be in concept. They also can seem weirdly repressed, as if the Drawing Center wants to protect us from the deep thrill of perhaps the most intimate and irresistible — and the sexiest — of all art mediums.

abstract: After retrieving a laptop in a strike on a Qaeda leader, American and Afghan commandos increased secret night raids on militants, even as the U.S. has declared the Afghanistan war essentially over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As an October chill fell on the mountain passes that separate the militant havens in Afghanistan and Pakistan, a small team of Afghan intelligence commandos and American Special Operations forces descended on a village where they believed a leader of Al Qaeda was hiding.

headline: A Charming Valentine’s Gift for the Norman Rockwell Museum
abstract: “Boy and Girl Gazing at the Moon (Puppy Love),” a 1926 painting, was donated to the museum’s permanent collection.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for Valentine’s Day, the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., is receiving a sweet gift – sweet in subject matter but made all the sweeter because the museum itself could probably never have afforded to buy the gift. It announced the donation to its permanent collection of “Boy and Girl Gazing at the Moon (Puppy Love),” a 1926 painting that Rockwell created for a cover of The Saturday Evening Post, a heartland scene of a redheaded boy and pigtailed girl sitting side by side on a rickety bench, mooning at the moon.

headline: Car Carrying Bob Simon Sped Up Before Crash, Authorities Say
abstract: Mr. Simon, 73, a CBS News correspondent, was sitting in the back of a Lincoln Town Car and was not wearing a seatbelt at the time of the crash that killed him, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The livery cab that was carrying the CBS News correspondent Bob Simon on Wednesday night when it slammed into metal barricades, killing Mr. Simon, was speeding up in the seconds before the crash, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Patacon Pisao
abstract: Venezuelan street food on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan street food on the Lower East Side.

headline: Plantains, Top to Bottom
abstract: At Patacon Pisao, the headliner is a Venezuelan sandwich bookended by unripe fried plantains that don’t absorb flavor, but provide it.
lead_paragraph: The cachapa is enormous even flopped in on itself, a thick pancake of ground sweet corn with whole kernels peeking through. Inside is mozzarella, caught mid-ooze, and two bands of double-smoked bacon, each as broad as a strop, juicy with brine and curling black at the edges. No distinction is allowed between salty and sweet, as if one could not exist without the other.

headline: Cisco and Texas Instruments Adapt to a New Tech World
abstract: Two of the old giants of the technology world showed this week two very different ways of making a transition to a world where computer intelligence is everywhere.
lead_paragraph: For at least a couple of old tech companies, the week offered some good news. And perhaps some lessons about what survival, even prosperity, will look like.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Going to Cuba
abstract: The Minnesota Orchestra will play two concerts in Havana in May.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra announced Thursday that it would travel to Havana to play two concerts in May, making it the first major American orchestra to play there since President Obama moved to normalize relations with Cuba.

headline: Breaking Up With My Meds
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Sleep']
abstract: The drugs I take for anxiety, depression and insomnia have helped, but I’ve decided to quit.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

headline: Starved for Energy, Pakistan Braces for a Water Crisis
abstract: Climate change and local waste and mismanagement have led to an alarmingly rapid depletion of Pakistan’s water supply, the minister for water and energy said.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Energy-starved Pakistanis, their economy battered by chronic fuel and electricity shortages, may soon have to contend with a new resource crisis: major water shortages, the Pakistani government warned this week.

headline: Obama, a Selfie Stick and the Affordable Care Act
abstract: President Obama has made it abundantly clear that he will do almost anything to make sure the Affordable Care Act is a success.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has made it abundantly clear that he will do almost anything to make sure the Affordable Care Act is a success.

headline: Big City Book Club Discusses ‘The Assistant’
abstract: The Big City Book Club discussed Bernard Malamud’s 1957 novel “The Assistant” on Feb. 12.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to everyone who participated in tonight’s lively discussion. We encourage all who chatted here tonight to sign up as a member of the Big City Club so that you can receive emails and notifications about our upcoming discussions.

headline: A Secret Skate-Park Clubhouse for Grown-Up Brooklynites
abstract: The members-only club, built by men in their 30s and 40s, is reputed to be the largest and most elaborate of its kind in Long Island City.
lead_paragraph: Skateboarding, like playing in rock bands or foregoing health insurance, tends to be viewed as the province of the very young. But for one group of mostly Brooklyn-based men in their 30s and 40s, many of whom came of age on the ramps and rails of lower Manhattan in the ’80s and ’90s, skating is still very much a way of life. And now, in a low-slung Long Island City warehouse, a group of 40 or so of them have erected a monument to their hobby: a secret, members-only DIY club reputed to be the largest and most elaborate skate park in town.

headline: Study Finds Rising Levels of Plastics in Oceans
abstract: The amount of debris is likely to increase tenfold over the next decade unless nations start disposing of trash responsibly, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Some eight million metric tons of plastic waste makes its way into the world’s oceans each year, and the amount of the debris is likely to increase greatly over the next decade unless nations take strong measures to dispose of their trash responsibly, new research suggests.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Documentary Will Kick Off Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: “Live From New York!” explores the 40-year-old show’s history.
lead_paragraph: A documentary about the 40-year history of “Saturday Night Live” will open the 14th annual Tribeca Film Festival, organizers said Thursday.

headline: Few Health System Studies Use Top Method, Report Says
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Research', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Experts expressed frustration that efforts to reform the health care system so rarely relied on rigorous methods of evaluation like the one known as random assignment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gold standard of scientific research, routinely used in the development of new drugs, has been neglected in studies meant to improve the American health care system, researchers reported on Thursday in the journal Science.

headline: Ebola Victims Still Infectious a Week After Death, Scientists Find
abstract: The findings by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases confirm the importance of handling the corpses carefully.
lead_paragraph: People who die of Ebola probably remain infectious for at least a week after death, according to a new study.

headline: Cush Jumbo Summons the Spirit of Josephine Baker at Joe’s Pub
abstract: “Josephine and I,” Ms. Jumbo’s new solo show, tells the story of Josephine Baker, the St. Louis-born performer who became a legend in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Josephine Baker made her professional debut at just a year old, in 1907, joining the finale of her mother’s song-and-dance act in honky-tonks and wine rooms. Cush Jumbo waited until the comparatively advanced age of 4 to step onstage, tap-dancing with her older sister to “When You’re Smiling” at their local South London theater.

headline: In a Shift, Pakistan Pats Afghanistan on the Back
abstract: The acknowledgment signaled a possible sign of closer collaboration between the two countries, which have often been unfriendly neighbors.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In a sign of closer cooperation between often hostile neighbors, Pakistan’s military on Thursday credited Afghanistan with helping to capture the Taliban militants who orchestrated the attack on a Peshawar school in December that killed 150 people.

headline: Details of the Ukraine Cease-Fire Negotiated in Minsk
abstract: The pact forces concessions from Ukraine that will cement recent gains made by the pro-Russian separatist forces in southeastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The 13-point agreement to end the war in Ukraine reached after 16 hours of negotiations in Minsk, Belarus, is no less precarious than previous cease-fire deals.

headline: Debate sobre el biocombustible: ¿reducirá el carbono quemar árboles y cosechas?
keywords: ['Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Muchos gobiernos buscan incorporar la bioenergía a sus combustibles de transportación. Sin embargo, hay un gran problema con esta estrategia.
lead_paragraph: Read this article in English.

headline: As Tiger Woods Motivates Lindsey Vonn, Her Finale Is Positive if Not Medal Worthy
abstract: Anna Fenninger won the women’s giant slalom title at the world championships Thursday, beating Viktoria Rebensburg of Germany by 1.40 seconds. American Lindsey Vonn finished 14th.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Lindsey Vonn and Tiger Woods kissed in the finish area Thursday after Vonn struggled and finished 27th in the first run of the giant slalom at the Alpine world ski championships.

headline: New York Fashion Week Parties: Kick-Off
abstract: AmfAR hosts its annual kickoff to New York Fashion Week and VFIles takes over Space Ibiza.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week unofficially kicked off Wednesday night with the amfAR gala at Cipriani Wall Street. Meanwhile, at Space Ibiza, the VFiles after-party was decidedly not black tie. Here are some photos.

headline: Deal for Orbitz Shows Merger Boom Has Room to Go
abstract: Orbitz offers Expedia multiple benefits, but that does not fully explain investors’ enthusiasm, says Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Expedia’s plan to buy Orbitz Worldwide indicates that some first-class M.&A. tickets remain available.

headline: Easy on the Eyes at Richard Chai
abstract: The makeup artist explains how to get his ’90s-inspired beauty look for the designer’s fall/winter 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: “I wanted it to feel really lived-in, cigarette on one hand, glass in the other, like she’s really having a good time,” explained the makeup artist Mark Carrasquillo about his ’90s-inspired beauty look for Richard Chai’s fall/winter 2015 collection. “What Kate Moss and Shalom Harlow looked like at parties after the shows.”

headline: A Sharp Loss for Kellogg as Sales of Cereal Falter
abstract: Sales were flat at $3.5 billion, and the company reduced its expectations for the year, saying that it did not expect sales to improve much and that its operating profits would be lower.
lead_paragraph: Consumers continued to shun cereal and its snack bar derivatives, causing steep losses at the Kellogg Company at the end of last year.

lead_paragraph: New York

keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Detectives (Private)']
abstract: A private investigator in New York is expected to plead guilty to paying a so-called hacker-for-hire firm to steal email passwords and credentials.
lead_paragraph: Private investigators may be the newest front for federal prosecutors in cracking down on the hacker-for-hire business.

headline: A Shrine to Modi? No Thanks, India’s Premier Says
abstract: Indians sometimes build temples to honor figures who are not, strictly speaking, divine. After recent election losses, Mr. Modi turned thumbs down.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India publicly distanced himself on Thursday from a gesture of idolatry from his followers, a group of whom recently attempted to inaugurate a temple in his honor in the western state of Gujarat.

headline: Professor Biden Expounds on Population Replacement Rates
abstract: The students gathered at Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, were treated to over 90 minutes of Vice President Joseph R. Biden, visiting professor.
lead_paragraph: The students gathered at Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, on Thursday were treated to over 90 minutes of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., visiting professor.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Concern in Denmark as Its Currency’s Peg to the Euro Is Strained
abstract: The country’s fixed exchange-rate arrangement is under extreme pressure as moves by the European Central Bank have caused the euro’s value to fall.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — To better understand the wave of negative interest rates among European central banks, consider the krone.

headline: Ukraine Cease-Fire Leaves Control of Border Unresolved Until Year’s End
abstract: The Minsk accord sets no deadline for the withdrawal of Russian forces, weapons and equipment from eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The cease-fire accord announced in Minsk on Thursday was hailed by Secretary of State John Kerry and European leaders as a potential breakthrough that could finally bring the bitter conflict in Ukraine to an end.

headline: With Convention, Philadelphia Scores Rare Win Over New York
abstract: The Democrats’ choice of Philadelphia to host their 2016 national convention is a rare win in a heated rivalry that most Philadelphians feel passionate about and many New Yorkers tend to ignore.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are in a “Philly state of mind,” having chosen the city to host their 2016 convention, and for the City of Brotherly Love, it is a rare win in a heated rivalry that most Philadelphians feel passionate about and many New Yorkers tend to ignore.

headline: Where to Eat, Stay and Wander in Hollywood
abstract: Suggestions for restaurants, hotels and sights in the Hollywood area.
lead_paragraph: As the film industry has changed, Hollywood as a tourist destination has as well — less defined and more dispersed, not so much a neat geographical dot on the map as a mind-set. Here’s where to find it.

headline: Hollywood Gets Its Groove Back
keywords: ['Movies', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Celebrities', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The nexus of glamour may now be more of a mind-set than a dot on the map, but this section of Los Angeles remains vastly interesting.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s grande dame hotels, the Sunset Tower and the Chateau Marmont, stand like stone sentries on Sunset Boulevard, less than two miles from the decidedly less stylish stretch of Hollywood Boulevard that hustles from morning to night with camera-toting tourists and Spiderman and Batman impersonators. The Tower and the Chateau are as romantic, seductive and happening as ever, at once guardians of an imperiled history but very much of the moment, with deal-making lunches and opening parties drawing clumps of paparazzi outside the driveway of Chateau Marmont, and limousines backed up along Sunset Boulevard in front of the Sunset Tower.

headline: A Peek at the Promised Land
abstract: The best Côte Chalonnaise reds convey what makes Burgundy ideal for pinot noir wines, and often at far more affordable rates.
lead_paragraph: Recent years have been grim for red Burgundy lovers. Rising demand worldwide and several consecutive microscopic vintages have combined to send prices soaring to the vertigo-inducing heights once reserved for cult cabernets and other wines better suited to be status-conferring luxury goods.

headline: ‘Buddhist Art of Myanmar’
abstract: Works in the new show at Asia Society.
lead_paragraph: Works in the new show at Asia Society.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: F.B.I. Director James Comey on How Everyone’s a Little Bit Racist
abstract: How will Republicans respond to his frank speech?
lead_paragraph: The hostility that Republican lawmakers and conservative commentators directed at Attorney General Eric Holder when he spoke openly – and truthfully — about racial profiling was clearly related to the fact that Mr. Holder is black. How will the same politicians and talking heads respond to a similarly frank speech that the F.B.I. director James B. Comey, who is white, delivered at Georgetown University today?

headline: A Collection of Campaign Mementos, Starting With Washington, Goes to Auction
abstract: A collector from New York will begin culling his American political campaign memorabilia in a series of sales.
lead_paragraph: Merrill C. Berman runs an investment firm in Rye, N.Y., that doubles as home to his collection of about 20,000 works on paper. With one full-time employee, he keeps track of prints, posters, drawings, collages, postcards, brochures, buttons, billboards, stationery and sundry graphics produced in the last two centuries. The pieces express strong opinions, whether protesting against capitalists or making ham and spark plugs look glamorous.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Kingsman’
abstract: The director Matthew Vaughn narrates a sequence from “Kingsman: The Secret Service.”
lead_paragraph: The director Matthew Vaughn narrates a sequence from “Kingsman: The Secret Service.”

headline: Hooked on the Freewheeling Podcast ‘Serial’
abstract: The long-form, meticulously reported series defied some of the worst trends in journalism and became an unexpected sensation.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to say what, exactly, made “Serial,” the breakaway podcast about an old murder, so addictive.

headline: Ex-Knick Anthony Mason in Hospital After Serious Heart Attack
abstract: Mason, 48, who played for the tough-minded Knicks teams of the 1990s, has made a slight improvement, his former agent said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mason, a cornerstone of the tough-minded Knicks teams that came close to winning an N.B.A. championship in the 1990s, was in a New York-area hospital on Thursday, battling the effects of a serious heart attack that appeared to put his life in jeopardy.

headline: Matthew Vaughn Narrates a Scene From ‘Kingsman: The Secret Service’
abstract: The director Matthew Vaughn discusses a sequence from his spy thriller.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Matthew Vaughn discusses a sequence from his spy thriller “Kingsman: The Secret Service,” based on the comic book series by Mark Millar. The scene features a group of new recruits vying to become Kingsmen, who are presented with a task that could prove deadly if not completed correctly.

headline: A Millennial Caregiver
abstract: I never thought I would be a caregiver at my age. But let’s face it, we usually don’t have a choice.
lead_paragraph: The bad news from my mother arrived as a text: “In the emergency room all day today. fluid in lung. doctor said it looks suspiciously like cancer.”

headline: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Review: Exploring ‘Buddhist Art of Myanmar’ at Asia Society
abstract: The Buddha-as-monk is a recurrent image in this Asia Society exhibit, which acknowledges the complexities of Myanmar cultural history and the yawning gaps in information available about the country.
lead_paragraph: Religious images live switched-on, switched-off lives. I remember walking through the National Museum in Kyoto, Japan, some years back, taking in its rows of Buddhist sculpture, and being stopped by one piece, not because it was especially beautiful — it wasn’t — but because a vase with a single fresh flower had been placed in front of it, like an offering in a temple. I stayed with the image because someone — a guard? a visitor? — was telling me, in terms I don’t often think of in museums, that it was important, in a personal, spiritual way.

headline: A Valentine’s Day Weekend of Pet Adoptions, Chocolate and Improv
abstract: A dog instead of a date? Yes, and at 90 percent off this weekend, at Best Friends Animal Society. For the commitment-averse, there’s comedy.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, one of the Miser’s single friends celebrated Valentine’s Day by adopting a puppy, a Chihuahua-pug mix named Whiskey. It seemed impulsive at the time, but Whiskey — we’re talking about the dog here — quickly became and remains a source of happy distractions.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
