lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Paris Aims to Embrace Its Estranged Suburbs
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Unemployment', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Terrorism']
abstract: As the city looks to expand its population and remedy inequities, France must confront a history of racism that pushed unwanted people out of central Paris.
lead_paragraph: GRIGNY, France — Paris is about to get bigger, much bigger. Next year, assuming plans move ahead, the city and a ring of inner suburbs will be joined, in an effort to redress a century’s worth of urban decisions that have exacerbated the country’s gaping cultural divide.

headline: Leaders Comment on Minsk Agreement
abstract: The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France, the main players in the cease-fire negotiations in Minsk, discuss the talks.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France, the main players in the cease-fire negotiations in Minsk, discuss the talks.

headline: How Should a Person Handle Heartbreak?
abstract: 10 ways to survive Valentine's Day with a broken heart.

headline: Assaf Shaham: ‘Division of the Vision’
abstract: Mr. Shaham is a digital native fascinated with analog photography, but also testing the technology of his own era.
lead_paragraph: Assaf Shaham’s first solo show in the United States is full of ambitious gestures. Most of them concern the history of photography and its demise as a chemical medium, which as a subject for art making may be on the verge of exhaustion, although Mr. Shaham squeezes out a few more points.

headline: Reaction to Journalists’ Being Freed
abstract: Family members of two Al Jazeera journalists arrested in December 2013, Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed, spoke after an Egyptian court freed the men while the government moved toward a retrial.
lead_paragraph: Family members of two Al Jazeera journalists arrested in December 2013, Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed, spoke after an Egyptian court freed the men while the government moved toward a retrial.

headline: Jan Schoonhoven at David Zwirner
abstract: Mr. Schoonhoven belonged to the Zero Group of European avant-gardists, but lacked their anarchic DNA.
lead_paragraph: This is the largest overview yet mounted in New York of the tender, Minimally inclined art of Jan Schoonhoven (1914-1994), a Dutch artist who emerged in the postwar period and by the early 1960s was making white-on-white wall reliefs of shallow grids. Built from paper, cardboard and wood painted white, these grids dominate the show, their units square or rectangular, their perpendicular divisions thick or thin. Invariably enriched by the play of light — especially when their interior planes are slanted — they achieve both a quietly stunning variety and a sense of timelessness through utmost simplicity.

headline: Susan Bee: ‘Photograms and Altered Photos From the 1970s’
abstract: Resurfaced photographs by Susan Bee show how her interests shifted increasingly toward painting.
lead_paragraph: During the 1970s, the artist Susan Bee was writing a master’s thesis on the photograms of Moholy-Nagy and Man Ray at Hunter College; helping to edit an experimental poetry magazine, L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E, with her husband, Charles Bernstein; and making her own photographic experiments in a cramped studio. As her personal interests shifted increasingly toward painting, she packed the photographs away. They recently resurfaced in storage and Southfirst has been smart enough to make a beautiful show of them.

headline: Tal R: ‘Altstadt Girl’
abstract: The Danish artist Tal R is finally, genuinely, an artist to watch.
lead_paragraph: When the Danish artist Tal R started emerging on the international scene in the early oughties, he had talent to burn and seemed to do just that, frittering it away on works that were both seductive and disposable, fun to look at and easy to forget. But over the past few years, something more fixed and solid has crept into his art. It is especially noticeable in this show of smallish, concentrated paintings of modern life. They stick with you.

headline: Sweet Kitten Heels on Coach’s Tough, Boho-Chic Runway
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: feminine metallic shoes to complement a too-cool-for-school fall/winter 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Off the Runway
abstract: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: At W Hotels, a Room and a New Dating Profile Photo
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Online Dating', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: W Hotels in New York City are offering a Valentine’s Day weekend package that will help guests create more alluring photos to use on online dating sites.
lead_paragraph: Calling all lonely travelers: W Hotels of New York wants to help you. And although the company can’t get into the matchmaking business outright, it can offer guests some assistance with online dating.

headline: Crossing at Your Peril
abstract: When the trains approach and the barriers descend, motorists sometimes have little time to reverse to safety at one rail crossing in Elmwood Park, N.J.
lead_paragraph: When the trains approach and the barriers descend, motorists sometimes have little time to reverse to safety at one rail crossing in Elmwood Park, N.J.

headline: Effortless Hair to Accompany Honor’s Easy, Romantic Fall/Winter 2015 Collection
abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: a beauty look as fresh as the designer’s new crop of floral embroidered dresses and lacy Victorian blouses.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: In New York Area, Points Where Train and Tragedy Are Likely to Intersect
abstract: The recent Metro-North Railroad crash cast renewed attention on the mix of trains, cars and humans that make crossings in the region among the most dangerous in the country.
lead_paragraph: The former police chief in Elmwood Park, N.J., vividly remembers the moment 30 years ago when the gates at the railroad crossing on the edge of town lowered on the bus carrying his son and his classmates on a field trip.

headline: In Rare Show of Consensus, President Signs Veterans Act Into Law
abstract: President Obama on Thursday hosted what has often felt like a rarity in recent years — a bill-signing ceremony — but given the nature of Capitol Hill, such events are likely to remain few and far between.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Thursday hosted what has often felt like a rarity in recent years: a White House bill-signing ceremony.

headline: Review: Stéphane Denève Leads the Philharmonic in What Feels Like an Audition
abstract: The 43-year-old maestro conducted the ensemble for the first time in a program of Fauré, Tchaikovsky and a James MacMillan premiere.
lead_paragraph: With the announcement last week from the New York Philharmonic that Alan Gilbert will step aside as music director in the summer of 2017, every appearance by a guest conductor is going to be seen as a tryout for the job. So it was on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, when the acclaimed French conductor Stéphane Denève made his much-anticipated Philharmonic debut.

headline: Review: Meshell Ndegeocello Hails Nina Simone
abstract: In her refusal to adhere to a style, or to stay within a genre, Ms. Ndegeocello is a direct descendant of Ms. Simone.
lead_paragraph: There were moments of such intensity during Meshell Ndegeocello’s Lincoln Center American Songbook concert on Wednesday evening that she and her musicians seemed to be conjuring a supernatural trance. The show, “Pour Une Âme Souveraine — A Dedication to Nina Simone,” at the Appel Room, focused on material from Ms. Ndegeocello’s 2012 album of the same name. In her refusal to adhere to a style, or to stay within a genre, Ms. Ndegeocello is a direct descendant of Ms. Simone, who played by nobody’s rules and paid dearly for it.

headline: Review: Richard Egarr and Carlo Grante on Keyboards
abstract: Two recitals this week — one wonderful, one not — set a listener to thinking about keyboards, their composers and their players.
lead_paragraph: Two recitals this week — one wonderful, one not — set a listener to thinking about keyboards, their composers and their players.

headline: Why Hacking the Atmosphere Won’t Happen Any Time Soon
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Research', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds', 'Sun']
abstract: More on the “barking mad” idea of blocking sunlight to counter the greenhouse effect.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth spending some more time on the National Academy of Sciences reports on geoengineering prospects and concerns — the concerns mainly being about adding sun-blocking particles to the atmosphere to counteract global warming driven by the buildup of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

headline: Sofia Coppola’s Juicy Red Valentine
abstract: The filmmaker introduces her newest bottle of wine — and suggests some nice chocolates to enjoy with it.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen years ago, the filmmaker and vintner Francis Ford Coppola named a personal batch of blanc de blancs sparkling wine after his effervescent daughter Sofia, who loved it so much that they decided to produce it on a larger scale and sell it to the public. The blend, best known as the bubbly packaged in chic little raspberry-colored cans (accompanied by miniature straws), became the first Coppola wine named after Sofia. To date, the collection has also included a non-alcoholic sparkling beverage, an off-dry riesling, a refreshing rosé and a soft, versatile chardonnay. And this Saturday, on Valentine’s Day, Coppola introduces the first bottle of red to bear her name, with a flavor profile designed, in part, by her.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Revisits a Classic in Gala
abstract: Included in the company’s opening-night show on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater were four variations on Graham’s 1930 “Lamentation.”
lead_paragraph: The Martha Graham Dance Company, founded in 1926, is always searching for ways to stay relevant: cleverly reinventing classics, commissioning new works from trendy choreographers. For its current season at the Joyce Theater, its artistic director, Janet Eilber, has enlisted even bigger, more recognizable names than usual, more determined than ever, it seems, to broaden the troupe’s appeal.

headline: Christie’s and Sotheby’s Auctions in London Keep the Bubble Afloat
abstract: Both houses enjoyed a bump in sales, with high prices for Gerhard Richter and Cy Twombly, and big-spending American buyers.
lead_paragraph: London — When art prices rise and rise, there’s always talk of a “bubble.” But could the 21st-century contemporary art boom be a bubble that never really bursts?

headline: Review: The Reporter Ethel Payne in ‘Eye on the Struggle’
abstract: Ethel Payne, an African-American journalist, is the subject of an important and often absorbing biography by James McGrath Morris.
lead_paragraph: During its heyday in the first half of the 20th century, The Chicago Defender was America’s premier black newspaper. Every issue carried its blazing motto: “American Race Prejudice Must Be Destroyed.”

headline: Review: ‘From Ancient to Modern’ Ponders the Origins of Sumerian Artifacts
abstract: An exhibition at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World focuses on about 50 artifacts made by Sumerian artisans about 4,500 years ago.
lead_paragraph: What happens to ancient artifacts after they’re dug up by archaeologists is more complicated than the casual museumgoer might realize. “From Ancient to Modern: Archaeology and Aesthetics,” a thought-provoking exhibition at New York University’s Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, tells a fascinating tale about the 20th-century discovery and interpretation of some extraordinary objects made by Sumerian artisans about 4,500 years ago.

headline: Ride-Hailing Service Lyft Is Said to Be in Talks to Raise $250 Million
abstract: With the added money, Lyft would be valued at $2 billion. Uber, its rival, is valued at more than $40 billion.
lead_paragraph: In the battle over ride-hailing services, Lyft is preparing a counterpunch against Uber, its much bigger rival.

headline: Celebrating the Chinese Lion Dance
abstract: Jason Lam stepped out from his lion dance costume to document a tradition that serves as a hinge between his Chinese ancestry and his American upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Jason Lam stepped out from his lion dance costume to document a tradition that serves as a hinge between his Chinese ancestry and his American upbringing.

headline: A Room of Their Own
abstract: A look inside the presidential suite at the Waldorf Astoria.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the presidential suite at the Waldorf Astoria.

headline: Security Headaches Doomed Brooklyn Bid for Democratic Convention
abstract: In choosing Philadelphia for the 2016 presidential nominating site, party officials objected to having to erect a security zone in the residential area around the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: In pitching a Democratic National Convention at an arena just blocks from his home in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Mayor Bill de Blasio hoped to capitalize on the alchemy of liberal politics and multicultural cool that propelled his own rise to prominence.

headline: Inside the Waldorf Astoria’s Presidential Suite
abstract: For about $4,000 a night (midweek, off season), anyone can enjoy the 35th-floor three-bedroom Park Avenue getaway where every president of the United States since Herbert Hoover has stayed.
lead_paragraph: YOU probably won’t be eligible for the generous discount accorded federal employees on official business. You’ll have to make do without the monogrammed towels and bedding and the bulletproof panes of window glass. Nor will a special Metro-North train be manned and idling on a siding below Park Avenue to whisk you away in case Midtown Manhattan traffic becomes impassable.

headline: Letters: ‘The Sacrifice’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Joyce Carol Oates’s “The Sacrifice,” Ben Metcalf’s “Against the Country” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Sacrifice’

headline: Greek Debt Standoff Awaits a Decisive Move
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: All sides in the negotiations on Greek debt are firm in the belief that the others will blink first.
lead_paragraph: Clad in snug black pants and his signature untucked shirt, the Greek finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, sauntered into a conference room in the Berlin headquarters of the German finance ministry.

headline: Review: ‘Bosch,’ Amazon Prime’s New Crime Series
abstract: Based on Michael Connelly’s series of novels, “Bosch” stars Titus Welliver as a rule-bending Los Angeles detective scarred by a grim childhood.
lead_paragraph: The list of brooding, taciturn small-screen police detectives is already impossibly long, so you might think Amazon made a mistake in committing to “Bosch,” whose title character is yet another variation. But this 10-episode series, which is being rolled out Friday on Amazon Prime, proves gripping nonetheless.

headline: Obama Signs Suicide Prevention for Veterans Act Into Law
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The measure was designed to make it easier for veterans to find mental health resources and increase accountability for the government programs serving them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed a measure into law on Thursday to fight a wave of suicide among veterans struggling with post-traumatic stress, a problem that has won increased attention as American troops have returned from Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Review: ‘Costa da Morte’ Lustrously Depicts Extreme Coastlines
abstract: The filmmaker Lois Patiño’s subject, the Coast of Death in Galicia, Spain, earned its name from a history of shipwrecks.
lead_paragraph: The Galicia region of Spain may have found a potential filmmaker laureate in Lois Patiño, who lustrously portrays its extreme coastal environments in “Costa da Morte.” In this high-definition series of cinematic landscape paintings, fishermen, woodcutters and other hardy mortals are often mere matchsticks within improbable panoramas of shimmering blue ocean, rock cascades and towering trees shrouded in mist.

lead_paragraph: Ukraine, Germany and More — Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, China, Ukraine and Germany.

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: In ‘White Rabbit,’ a Bullied Teenager Is Pushed to the Edge
abstract: The director Tim McCann’s drama about a disturbed loner stars Nick Krause, Britt Robertson and Sam Trammell.
lead_paragraph: The opening of “White Rabbit” leaves little doubt that a storm is brewing: A teenager named Harlon broods in a car, then turns to the camera with the heavy slowness of a reptile. Like the thickly atmospheric photography, the shot sets a foreboding tone. But all too much of Tim McCann’s drama about this disturbed loner comes to feel like a checklist of warning signs.

headline: In the Studio | Victoria Beckham
abstract: Victoria Beckham chats with Vanessa Friedman about being a working mother in charge of a growing fashion label at her minimal office in the Battersea area of South London.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham chats with Vanessa Friedman about being a working mother in charge of a growing fashion label at her minimal office in the Battersea area of South London.

headline: Review: ‘Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead’ Puts Zombies in the Outback
abstract: A mechanic is pitted against the undead in this go-for-broke style film set in an apocalyptic Australian outback.
lead_paragraph: Like greyhounds after the hare, “Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead” bursts out of the gate panting and doesn’t let up. The hare in this case is a mysterious zombie plague that follows a meteor shower in the Australian outback, and the greyhounds are a pair of siblings whose particular talents — one artisanal, the other supernormal — prove especially useful in battling the undead.

headline: Review: ‘Hits,’ a Comedy, Lampoons Internet Fame
abstract: An upstate New York man’s rant against perceived injustices goes viral in this David Cross film.
lead_paragraph: One bit on David Cross and Bob Odenkirk’s 1990s sketch program, “Mr. Show,” featured a yokel who, after the siege in Ruby Ridge, Idaho, declared his house a sovereign nation. That sharp, even impatient strain of satire returns in full force with Mr. Cross’s modest, focused directorial debut, “Hits,” which also centers on an embattled citizen.

headline: G.O.P. Consultant Pleads Guilty in PAC Case
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plea appears to mark the first coordination case brought by federal prosecutors since the Supreme Court’s decision that allowed for the creation of groups that can raise and spend unlimited money.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia-based Republican political consultant pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges that he illegally coordinated spending between a 2012 congressional campaign and a “super PAC,” federal prosecutors said.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Five Years,’ a Decoupling Starring Anna Kendrick
abstract: In “The Last Five Years,” adapted from the play of the same name, a novelist and an actress grow apart.
lead_paragraph: “The Last Five Years,” the composer Jason Robert Brown’s emotionally fraught musical about a passionate relationship that crashes and burns, almost requires some familiarity with its rarefied milieu: the New York City hothouse of ravenously ambitious performers and writers. Over the years, the show, which had its premiere in Chicago in 2001 and opened Off Broadway the next year, has gained traction as a regional theater staple. It is now a movie adapted and directed by Richard LaGravenese. Its lovers, Cathy Hiatt, an aspiring actress played by a winsome Anna Kendrick, and Jamie Wellerstein, by a fire-breathing Jeremy Jordan, fall in love and marry in a whirlwind of romantic hyperbole.

headline: Clip: ‘Da Sweet Blood of Jesus’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Neighbors Say Suspect in Chapel Hill Shootings Was Threatening
abstract: Craig Stephen Hicks, charged in the killings of three students, was such a disruptive presence in his condominium complex that residents held a meeting to discuss him.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Neighbors knew Craig Stephen Hicks. He was the angry man on Summerwalk Circle, they said — irritated about noise, irascible about parking, hostile to religion. And armed.

headline: Ackman and Dalio, Two Hedge Fund Titans, Size Each Other Up
abstract: At a conference, the two men, who have very different investment approaches, appeared bewildered by the other.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund manager, was trying hard not to talk about himself.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 13-19
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Da Sweet Blood of Jesus,’ Spike Lee’s Vampire Movie
abstract: This remake of Bill Gunn’s “Ganja and Hess” is a stylishly shot, coolly contemplative homage to the original.
lead_paragraph: “Da Sweet Blood of Jesus,” Spike Lee’s new film, is a grisly and ghoulish vampire story. It is also an evident labor of love. The opening images — a solitary dancer undulating on the Red Hook waterfront, the Brooklyn Heights Promenade and other Kings County spots — offer a reminder that no filmmaker has shot this borough as beautifully and fondly as Mr. Lee. Martha’s Vineyard, where much of the action takes place, looks pretty good too. And though there are episodes of bloody mayhem and steamy sex, the mood is contemplative, at times almost serene. Mr. Lee has earned a reputation as a polemicist and provocateur, but he has also been, from the beginning, a sensualist and a visual stylist.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Swept Off Her Feet Solved
abstract: A college student with chronic headaches who suddenly became too dizzy to walk learned she had postural tachycardia syndrome — also called postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome — a condition in which simply being upright causes lightheadedness and an elevated heart rate.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 21-year-old college student with chronic headaches who suddenly became too dizzy to walk. She had a medical history that was complicated by back surgery and a subsequent infection, and chronic headaches after a car accident. More than 300 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses, but only a handful of you noticed the clue that led the medical student who saw the patient to the right answer.

headline: Save the Children’s Insurance
keywords: ["State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Will millions of kids lose health coverage because of gridlock?
lead_paragraph: NO child in America should be denied the chance to see a doctor when he or she needs one — but if Congress doesn’t act soon, that’s exactly what might happen.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Feb. 13, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Fifty Shades of Grey,” “Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem” and “The Last Five Years.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Fifty Shades of Grey,” “Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem” and “The Last Five Years.”

headline: The New School Announces Effort to Defend ‘Arts Integrity’
abstract: Howard Sherman, a former executive director of the American Theater Wing, will head the new project.
lead_paragraph: The New School for Drama has established the Arts Integrity Initiative, a project that will both study and take an active role in instances in which theatrical and other works are censored or altered without authorization.

headline: Egypt Restricts News Coverage of Slain Activist Shaimaa el-Sabbagh
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Media']
abstract: Cairo barred journalists from discussing the case of Ms. Sabbagh, a poet whose killing in Tahrir Square stirred outrage over the rate of civilian deaths from police violence.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian authorities on Thursday barred the news media from discussing the case of a prominent activist whose killing last month has aroused outrage over the rate of civilian deaths from police violence.

headline: For Oscars Telecast, Few Black Nominees Mean Fewer Black Viewers
abstract: The Academy Awards’ lack of a core African-American presence is likely to be reflected in television ratings, Nielsen data shows.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If past patterns hold, the next Academy Awards telecast might be remembered as the Revenge of “Selma.”

headline: Review: In ‘Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem,’ a Woman Fights for Her Freedom
abstract: Ronit Elkabetz plays a woman who is determined to escape her marriage, although the rabbinic power structure is stacked against her.
lead_paragraph: The hypnotic “Gett: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem” is the story of a woman wronged by men and God, if finally, in a sense, redeemed by cinema. Under Israeli law, a woman can be divorced only if her husband presents her with a religious bill of divorce called a gett (sometimes spelled get). No gett, no divorce. The long-suffering title character desperately wants to be free of her husband, who refuses to let her go. So year after year, Viviane pleads her case before a rabbinic court, waiting for her divorce as days slip into weeks and then months, her pacific face glazed with tears and her body occasionally rocked by a laugh tinged with knowing and madness.

headline: Review: In ‘The Rewrite,’ Hugh Grant Is an Author Seeking a Comeback
abstract: Marc Lawrence’s comedy focuses on a formerly successful screenwriter who takes a teaching job at Binghamton University.
lead_paragraph: “The Rewrite,” the fourth screen collaboration of Hugh Grant and the director and screenwriter Marc Lawrence, is a return to form for the long-running team after the debacle six years ago of “Did You Hear About the Morgans?” By “return to form,” I don’t mean to suggest that their pre-“Morgans” films — “Two Weeks Notice” and “Music and Lyrics” — were more than reasonably intelligent romantic comedies buoyed by Mr. Grant’s appeal as a bumbling, sheepish charmer.

headline: Law Students Leave Torts Behind (for a Bit) and Tackle Accounting
abstract: Law schools are adding business-oriented offerings to better equip students to compete in a redefined job market.
lead_paragraph: A group of 170 Brooklyn Law School students cut short their winter break and headed back to campus in January for an intensive three-day training session. But not in the law.

headline: An Auction Debut for Ai Weiwei’s ‘Zodiac Heads,’ in London
abstract: A complete set of Ai Weiwei’s gilded bronze Zodiac heads comes up for sale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A set of 12 gilded bronze animal-head sculptures by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei sold late Thursday night at Phillips in London to one of three telephone bidders for £2.9 million, with fees, or about $4.4 million.

headline: Review: In ‘Kingsman: The Secret Service,’ Colin Firth Get His Suits Splattered
abstract: There’s a fine cast — including Michael Caine, Mark Strong and Samuel L. Jackson — as well as exploding heads and endangered dogs in Matthew Vaughn’s gory action movie.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t mind the church full of parishioners who are slaughtered to the sounds of Lynyrd Skynyrd’s “Free Bird” or the “Arab terrorists” who are blown to smithereens or the guns that are pointed at pet dogs or the human heads that explode like firebombed melons as “Pomp and Circumstance” plays, it may be possible to enjoy “Kingsman: The Secret Service.” That said, as this bludgeoning movie grinds to a halt, its gears clogged by viscera and narrative overkill, even those who enjoy go-go gore may end up yearning for the soft touch and subtleties of Guy Ritchie.

headline: Colorado: Senate Rejects Funding Plan for Driver’s Licenses for Immigrants
abstract: An effort to fund the state program that provides driver’s licenses to undocumented immigrants has failed, leaving the program with little ability to function.
lead_paragraph: An effort to fund the state program that provides driver’s licenses to undocumented immigrants has failed, leaving the program with little ability to function. On Thursday, State Senator Jessie Ulibarri, a Democrat, submitted an amendment that would have assigned funds collected from immigrant applicants to pay for the program. The Republican-controlled Senate voted down the measure. Unauthorized immigrants can receive driver’s licenses in 10 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Colorado’s program began in 2014, and state motor vehicle offices issuing these license have been swamped with requests from immigrants. But critics maintain that the program rewards people who have crossed into the country without authorization. Last month, the state’s joint budget committee voted not to approve about $166,000 in new funds for the program, forcing officials to lay off workers and stop issuing the licenses at four of the five participating motor vehicle offices. One office, in Denver, was left to process the licenses.

headline: Mexico’s Guerrero State Heads Toward Elections
keywords: ['Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Missing Persons']
abstract: As the election season begins, what has been at best a tenuous hold on order in Mexico’s most violent state is fast disintegrating.
lead_paragraph: As the election season begins, what has been at best a tenuous hold on order in Mexico’s most violent state is fast disintegrating.

headline: Apple Backslides on Work-Hour Limits
abstract: A quarter in which Apple sold an enormous number of iPhones also saw compliance with workweek rules decrease.
lead_paragraph: Apple sold more iPhones last year than anyone could have imagined. But the company found that a lower percentage of factories assembling its products complied with a policy preventing excessive work hours.

headline: Review: ‘What We Do in the Shadows,’ a Vampire Comedy
abstract: The film, directed by Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi, is set in New Zealand and follows four ghouls who have problems adapting to the modern world.
lead_paragraph: A daring film crew, armed with crucifixes and guarantees of safety, sets out to record the daily lives of four vampire housemates in “What We Do in the Shadows,” a goofily amusing mockumentary from the New Zealand comedians and actors Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.

headline: Mexican Towns Galvanized by Tragedy
keywords: ['Elections', 'Organized Crime', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: In the aftermath of the disappearance of 43 college students, order is disintegrating in Mexico’s most violent state.
lead_paragraph: CHILPANCINGO, Mexico — A former cattle trader juggles two cellphones to direct truckloads of armed volunteers who have replaced the meager police forces across a swath of small towns.

headline: Fox and Telemundo to Show World Cup Through 2026 as FIFA Extends Contracts
abstract: The two networks already have the rights for the World Cup in 2018 and 2022. FIFA also extended its deal to 2026 in Canada with CTV and TSN.
lead_paragraph: Fox and Telemundo have not shown a second of World Cup action, but on Thursday they added the 2026 Cup to their rights to broadcast the 2018 and 2022 soccer tournaments in the United States.

headline: Missouri House Passes ‘Right to Work’ Bill, Ignoring Threat of a Veto
abstract: The vote in the Republican-controlled House, in which more than 23 Republicans joined Democrats in opposing the measure, suggested that the bill might die this year.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — A bill that would make Missouri the latest state to adopt so-called right-to-work laws or policies passed the Republican-controlled House here on Thursday, but without enough votes to override an expected veto from the Democratic governor.

headline: Egypt to Purchase Fighter Jets and a Warship From France
abstract: The weapons were sold amid growing concerns across North Africa that instability and the rise of jihadist groups in Libya could spread to neighboring countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France on Thursday announced the sale of nearly $6 billion worth of military hardware to Egypt, including two dozen Rafale fighter jets and a naval frigate.

headline: The Making of ‘Wild Tales,’ an Oscar Nominee
abstract: The Argentine director and screenwriter Damián Szifrón discusses the making of his dark and sometimes surrealistic comedy “Wild Tales.”
lead_paragraph: As the Argentine film director and screenwriter Damián Szifrón sees it, “what separates civilization from barbarism” is “a complex battery of social inhibitors” that prevent us from retaliating with violence to the many slights and aggravations of daily life. But that’s definitely not the case with the characters he created for his dark and sometimes surrealistic comedy “Wild Tales,” which has been nominated for the Oscar for best foreign-language film and opens Feb. 20.

headline: A Record Year of Recalls: Nearly 64 Million Vehicles
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The number of recalled vehicles in 2014 exceeded the total for the previous three years combined.
lead_paragraph: The auto industry recalled almost 64 million vehicles for safety problems last year, a record, according to figures released on Thursday by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Saudi Women Free After 73 Days in Jail for Driving
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Two Saudi women detained since Dec. 1 for challenging the conservative kingdom’s ban on female drivers announced on Thursday that they were free.
lead_paragraph: Two Saudi women detained since early December for challenging the conservative kingdom’s ban on female drivers announced on Thursday that they had been released after 73 days.

headline: Owners of Host Teams Can Skip the All-Star Festivities
abstract: Although the N.B.A’s All-Star events will take place in New York City this weekend, fans should not expect to see the host teams’ owners at too many of them.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A.’s All-Star weekend is being co-hosted by the Knicks and the Nets, but if fans expect to see a lot of the teams’ owners, they will be disappointed.

headline: Study Backs Kentucky Medicaid Expansion
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Responding to Republican warnings, the Democratic governor predicted a positive economic impact of $1 billion over seven years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky released a study Thursday predicting that his expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act would generate a positive fiscal impact of nearly $1 billion for the state over the next seven years.

headline: New York Archdiocese Parishioners See System of Secrets as They Fight Church Closings
abstract: An appeal to the Vatican requires a copy of the formal decree ordering the closing, which the archdiocese refused to give out for months. They later called it an “oversight.”
lead_paragraph: For aggrieved parishioners at churches ordered closed or merged by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan last November, it seemed like a simple task: Get a copy of the formal decree of his decision on their parishes, so they could properly appeal to the Vatican.

headline: Todd Snyder: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: A Universal Comeback
abstract: While the movie industry was focused on difficulties at Warner Bros. and Sony Pictures, Universal Pictures has put together a 2015 slate that brings an echo of the studio’s 1980s heyday.
lead_paragraph: While the movie industry was focused on difficulties at Warner Bros. and Sony Pictures, Universal Pictures has put together a 2015 slate that brings an echo of the studio’s 1980s heyday.

headline: Universal Pictures Regains a Bit of Its Old Sheen
abstract: Universal has quietly put together a 2015 slate that brings an echo of the studio’s 1980s glory days, one that analysts say could make Universal the year’s No. 1 studio, at least by ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Lobbed between four owners over the last 15 years, Universal Pictures has lately had a reputation in Hollywood as a reliable also-ran.

headline: Teachers Find Little Grace in Archdiocese’s Latest Offering
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The Archdiocese of New York has offered teachers a contract with no raises for two years, a proposal the teachers’ union sees as coercive and bullying.
lead_paragraph: On her way to teach social studies at a Catholic school on Thursday morning, Alexis D’Angelo paused to do some elementary arithmetic.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 12, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ISIS Releases Interview With Woman Linked to Amedy Coulibaly
abstract: Published in an English-language version of its online jihadist propaganda magazine, the interview is believed to be the first time the group has said anything concerning the whereabouts of Hayat Boumeddiene.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State group said Thursday that a woman it described as the widow of the French gunman responsible for a deadly siege at a Paris supermarket last month — a woman who is now among France’s most wanted fugitives — was living among the group’s followers, presumably in Syria or Iraq. The assertion by the Islamic State, published in an English-language version of its online jihadist propaganda magazine, is believed to be the first time the group has said anything concerning the whereabouts of the woman, Hayat Boumeddiene, 26. French officials suspect that she was an accomplice of the gunman, Amedy Coulibaly, killed in a Jan. 9 shootout with the French police. The article asserted that Mr. Coulibaly had arranged for her travel to lands controlled by the Islamic State before the attack. She was quoted as saying that she was happy to be living in an area controlled by the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, and was quoted as advising other women followers of the group to “be bases of support and safety for your husbands, brothers, fathers, and sons.” Turkish officials have said that Ms. Boumeddiene traveled to Turkey from Spain before the Paris attack and entered Syria through a Turkish border crossing on Jan. 8, one day before the supermarket siege.

headline: Red Cross Faces Attacks at Ebola Victims’ Funerals
abstract: The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies reported Thursday that its burial teams in Guinea have been attacked verbally or physically 10 times a month on average since March.
lead_paragraph: Red Cross volunteers helping to safely bury people who die of Ebola in Guinea have been attacked in recent days by people attending the funerals, complicating efforts to stop the spread of the disease.

headline: After Tina Maze Falters, Lasse Kjus Remains a One-of-a-Kind Racer
abstract: After Maze finished fifth in the giant slalom on Thursday, Kjus remained the only Alpine skier to win five individual medals in the same world championships.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Vail Valley was the happiest valley for Lasse Kjus in 1999, and he returned this year perfectly prepared to share his place in the history books with Tina Maze.

headline: Cellphone Video of Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: A cellphone video uploaded to YouTube appears to show the fatal police shooting of a man who threw rocks at officers before running across a crowded intersection.
lead_paragraph: A cellphone video uploaded to YouTube appears to show the fatal police shooting of a man who threw rocks at officers before running across a crowded intersection.

headline: Obama Heads to Tech Security Talks Amid Tensions
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: President Obama’s cybersecurity meeting with the nation’s top tech firms comes at a time of deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and Washington.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — President Obama will meet here on Friday with the nation’s top technologists on a host of cybersecurity issues and the threats posed by increasingly sophisticated hackers. But nowhere on the agenda is the real issue for the chief executives and tech company officials who will gather on the Stanford campus: the deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and the government.

headline: Police Killing of Man Who Threw Rocks Is Reviewed in Washington State
abstract: The shooting was the fourth fatal police shooting involving Pasco police officers since July, according to the local Tri-City Herald newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Investigators in Washington State were reviewing video taken with a cellphone that appears to show the fatal police shooting of a man who threw rocks at police officers before running across a crowded intersection, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Taking Things Up With the Crew
abstract: Friday fun with Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Most people pooh pooh the kind of words that you only see in crossword puzzles, but not me. If you’re smart, you will remember these words and use them to your advantage. They might give you your toehold in a difficult puzzle.

headline: Review: ‘Everything You Touch,’ a Brash Examination of Self-Image
abstract: Sheila Callaghan’s volatile new work touches on beauty and body image, intimacy and alienation, art and commerce, fantasy and reality.
lead_paragraph: The work of the playwright Sheila Callaghan is not exactly ready-to-wear. Her plots don’t progress along expected lines; her characters don’t stick to a single style. There’s a lot of color and a lot of pattern and some pretty crazy layering.

headline: Review: ‘The Iceman Cometh’ Revived, With Nathan Lane and Brian Dennehy
abstract: Robert Falls’s magisterial staging of Eugene O’Neill’s bleak barroom drama is enacted by a cast that is not likely to be bettered this season.
lead_paragraph: The zombies stomping all over pop culture these days will seem about as scary as Santa’s elves once you’ve met the dead souls inhabiting the sepulchral gloom of Robert Falls’s production of Eugene O’Neill’s “The Iceman Cometh.” The bloodletting and brain-eating in this case may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: None of the suffering men and women seeking comfort in the bottom of a bottle in Harry Hope’s saloon will emerge truly alive.

headline: Review: In ‘The Events,’ a Shooting Leaves a Survivor in Purgatory
abstract: The Scottish dramatist David Greig has written a solemn and searching work about a faith-shattering act of violence.
lead_paragraph: An agitated anguish beats against the walls of ritual in “The Events,” a solemn, searching and ultimately very moving play about a faith-shattering act of violence. This gutsy work by the Scottish dramatist David Greig, which opened on Thursday night at New York Theater Workshop, sets the restless pain of a mass-shooting survivor against the stolid, consoling presence of a community choir.

headline: Jon Stewart’s America
keywords: ['Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A tour guide through the degraded landscape of politics and the press.
lead_paragraph: Since the golden era of fake news is over, does this mean that what passes for real news and real politics are also over?

headline: Hello, I Must Be Going: A Third Miami Museum Director Departs
abstract: Miami’s new Institute of Contemporary Art has lost its interim director, Suzanne Weaver, who has been there only a few months.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Eyebrows were raised in art circles Wednesday at news that Suzanne Weaver had left as interim director of the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami — just over four months after the new private museum announced her arrival, and not even three months after it first opened in its temporary home.

headline: Numbed by Snow, Boston Area Shudders at the Thought of More
abstract: Faced with three major storms in three weeks that have pushed snowfall for this season to 78.5 inches in Boston, removing the snow has become a test of endurance, ingenuity and will across New England.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In this city’s Seaport district, a long, yellow snow melter, recently sheathed in lumpy icicles like the shaggy fur of a yeti, is liquefying 350 tons of snow an hour.

headline: David Carr, Times Critic and Champion of Media, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Carr, a shrewd and well-informed skeptic, wriggled away from the demon of drug addiction to become an unlikely name-brand media columnist at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: David Carr, who wriggled away from the demon of drug addiction to become a journalistic celebrity, a name-brand media columnist at The New York Times and a best-selling author who reported on his own near demise and recovery, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 58.

headline: Anthony Says He Is Likely to Sit Out Rest of Season
abstract: Knicks forward Carmelo Anthony, voted by N.B.A. fans to start the All-Star Game, told ESPN Radio he would probably sit out the remainder of the season afterward because of his injured left knee.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony, who has been dealing with an injured left knee since October, said Thursday that it was “very likely” he would sit out the remainder of the Knicks’ season.

headline: Congress Shows a Lack of Enthusiasm for Giving Obama War Powers to Fight ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One side thinks the president’s request to take on the Islamic State is too brazen and even reckless. The other side thinks it is too spineless and probably ineffectual.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since President Obama ordered American warplanes to begin bombing terrorist targets in Iraq and Syria last year, members of Congress have insisted on having a say in the matter. The president, they declared, could not, or at least should not, take the country back to war without the input of the nation’s elected representatives.

headline: Government Will Change How it Rates Nursing Homes
abstract: The changes are part of a further effort to improve nursing home ratings by raising the bar to achieving a high score in the quality measures area.
lead_paragraph: The federal government on Thursday announced that it was changing the way it measures nursing homes, essentially adjusting the curve that it uses to rate homes to make it more difficult for them to earn coveted four- and five-star government ratings.

headline: Review: ‘Huang Yi & Kuka,’ a Pas de Deux Between Human and Machine
abstract: At 3LD Art & Technology Center, the choreographer Huang Yi dances with a robot, whose moves he has painstakingly programmed.
lead_paragraph: Some lonely children create invisible friends. As a solitary boy growing up in Taiwan, the choreographer Huang Yi pined for a robot. He had good reason: In his poignant artist’s statement for his show “Huang Yi & Kuka,” at 3LD Art & Technology Center, he reveals that when he was 10, his wealthy parents became bankrupt and suicidal. The family moved to a 40-square-foot room; Mr. Huang, feeling compelled to be a perfect child, masked his emotions to become the picture of obedience. In other words, a robot.

headline: Mic News Director Is Fired After Plagiarism Accusations
abstract: In some cases, material was republished with no credit at all, while other articles made passing reference to outside sources but failed to give proper credit when passages were taken verbatim or with minor changes.
lead_paragraph: In the latest plagiarism scandal in journalism, Mic, a news site intended for the so-called millennial generation, has fired its news director after numerous examples surfaced showing that he had lifted material from other sources without proper attribution.

headline: Indictment in an Arson Attempt in Ferguson
abstract: Federal grand jurors indicted Antonio Whiteside on charges that he tried to set fire to a convenience store after it was announced that a white police officer wouldn’t face state charges in the death of an unarmed black man.
lead_paragraph: SEDALIA, Mo. — Federal grand jurors have indicted a man on charges that he tried to set fire to a Ferguson convenience store in November, shortly after it was announced that a white police officer there would not face state charges in the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old.

headline: Trinity Industries’ Full-Court Press on Guardrails
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Since 2012, when allegations surfaced that there might be a safety flaw in a highway guardrail system manufactured by Trinity, the company has significantly expanded its lobbying of state attorneys general, who have the power to investigate and possibly sue the company. Here is a look at parts of that effort.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, when allegations surfaced that there might be a safety flaw in a highway guardrail system manufactured by Trinity, the company has significantly expanded its lobbying of state attorneys general, who have the power to investigate and possibly sue the company. Here is a look at parts of that effort.

headline: Troubled Guardrail Maker Goes on a Lobbying Blitz
abstract: Trinity Industries turns to state attorneys general in an attempt to refute claims that its system has a deadly design flaw.
lead_paragraph: The Four Seasons Hotel on the Las Vegas Strip is known for its steakhouse, its palm tree-decorated rooftop pool bar and its quick access to the sprawling gambling floors at the Mandalay Bay casino, just downstairs.

headline: Style Icons Update a Fendi Classic for a Good Cause
abstract: The Baguette handbag will be artfully reimagined by five powerhouse women, including Rihanna and Sarah Jessica Parker, in celebration of the company’s new Madison Avenue flagship store.
lead_paragraph: The Fendi Baguette was a fashion-world success from the day it was released in 1997 and, thanks to being a favorite of Carrie’s on “Sex and the City,” it became a bona fide pop culture icon soon after. As of 2015, more than 1,000 versions of the design have been created ranging from rare limited editions to mass-market reimaginings. In celebration of Fendi’s new flagship store on Madison Avenue, the Italian brand has now teamed up with five powerhouse women to present yet another unique line of the famous shoulder bag. This time around, Rihanna, Jourdan Dunn, Rachel Feinstein, Leandra Medine and, yes, Sarah Jessica Parker, have each designed their own 3Baguette, the smaller version of the bag. Each piece will be auctioned online from February 13 through March 13 with proceeds going to a charity of each guest designer’s choosing, from the Brain Trauma Foundation (Parker) to the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center (Feinstein).

headline: Philip Johnson’s Not Glass Houses
abstract: The legendary architect and his companion, the curator David Whitney, spent their weekends in the world’s most famous transparent box. Or did they?

headline: China: Motorist Tries to Drive Into American Consulate
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A man crashed into a barrier while trying to drive into the United States Consulate in Shanghai late Thursday, the police said. One Chinese guard was slightly injured, the police added.
lead_paragraph: A man crashed into a barrier while trying to drive into the United States Consulate in Shanghai late Thursday, the police said. One Chinese guard was slightly injured, the police added. The man, who was taken into custody, had no apparent political motive, according to the authorities. His wife told them he had refused to leave their home for nearly a month out of fear that someone was trying to kill him, the state-run Xinhua news service reported. The suspect, Liu Daojie, 35, from Fujian Province in southeast China, told the police he had spotted armed police officers outside the consulate and decided to drive into the compound to draw attention to his concerns, Xinhua reported. A State Department spokesman said that all staff members were accounted for and that the consulate would operate normally Friday.

headline: Harvey Goldschmid, Ally of Ordinary Shareholders, Is Dead at 74
abstract: Mr. Goldschmid, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission from 2002 to 2005, was a strong advocate of corporate responsibility to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Harvey J. Goldschmid, an expert on corporate law who, as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was a strong advocate of making public corporations responsible to shareholders, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: How Arizona State Reinvented Free-Throw Distraction
abstract: Arizona State’s Curtain of Distraction has taken student-section antics to a new level — and it appears to be costing visiting teams one to two points per game.
lead_paragraph: A shark attack. The return of Elvis. Twerking farm animals. A shirtless guitarist. Kissing unicorns. An old lady yelling at you to get off her lawn. Distracted yet? So, too, are college basketball players, who have tried — and often failed — to overcome the creative attempts of students at Arizona State to destroy the focus of free-throw shooters.

headline: California: 22 Hurt in Military Training as Vehicle’s Fire Extinguisher Goes Off
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Twenty-two Marines and sailors were injured at a military base in the Southern California desert on Thursday when a fire-extinguisher system went off during a training exercise, the military said.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-two Marines and sailors were injured at a military base in the Southern California desert on Thursday when a fire-extinguisher system went off during a training exercise, the military said. The accident happened inside an amphibious assault vehicle at the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center in Twentynine Palms, east of Los Angeles, the Marine Corps said. Some of the Marines and sailors were taken to a hospital to be treated for inhaling the fire retardant, and they were in stable condition, according to the Marine Corps. None of the injuries were life-threatening, Capt. Maureen T. Krebs, a Marine Corps spokeswoman, said. The vehicle, which resembles a tank, is used to move troops from ships to land.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3:45 P.M. (TCM) THE BIRDS (1963) A flock of birds never looks quite the same after a viewing of Alfred Hitchcock’s classic horror film about a California town tormented by malevolent fowl. Tippi Hedren stars as a spoiled socialite who follows a handsome man (Rod Taylor) to the home of his mother (Jessica Tandy), where, for no apparent reason, the attacks begin. “Making a terrifying menace out of what is assumed to be one of nature’s most innocent creatures and one of man’s most melodious friends, Mr. Hitchcock and his associates have constructed a horror film that should raise the hackles on the most courageous and put goose-pimples on the toughest hide,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times.

headline: David Carr, a Journalist at the Center of the Sweet Spot
abstract: Mr. Carr managed to see the complexities of digital-age journalism from every angle, and to write about them with unparalleled clarity and wit.
lead_paragraph: For a while, a few years ago, there was a weekly video on the New York Times website called The Sweet Spot, taped during off hours in the cafeteria on the 14th floor. The idea was that it would be an informal, incisive discussion of various developments in the world of culture and media. Sometimes it managed to live up to its name, and sometimes it didn’t, but for me the show — or webcast, or schmooze fest, or whatever it was — had a much simpler reason for being: It guaranteed that I would have a few hours a week in the company of David Carr. For anyone who cared about journalism, there was simply no better place to be.

headline: The Quotable David Carr
abstract: Sometimes, David Carr was more quotable than the personalities he wrote about. Here’s a selection of his writing and public statements.
lead_paragraph: David Carr was often more quotable than the personalities he wrote about. His plainspoken style was sometimes blunt, and searingly honest about himself. The effect was both folksy and sophisticated, a voice from a shrewd and well-informed skeptic.

headline: Chris Martin to Curate Global Citizen Festival for 15 Years
abstract: The Coldplay singer will oversee the lineup for the anti-poverty group’s international music festival for the next 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Chris Martin, the lead singer of Coldplay, has signed on as an ambassador for the anti-poverty group Global Citizen, and will serve as the curator of its international music festival for the next 15 years, said Hugh Evans, the chief executive of the Global Poverty Project, which oversees the campaign.

headline: China to Employ Customs Workers With a Nose for Hard Cash
abstract: As China’s anticorruption campaign enters its third year, the country is developing its first cash-detecting dog program for its borders, with the help of New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: In a country where cash is king but the 100 renminbi note is the highest denomination, it is not unheard of for individuals to make purchases with suitcases stuffed with pink bills emblazoned with Mao’s face. Some have also taken this habit abroad, ready to spend big on real estate or luxury goods, even though China limits the amount private citizens can transfer out of the country to $50,000 a year.

headline: Celebrating the Chinese Lion Dance
abstract: Jason Lam stepped out from his lion dance costume to document a tradition that serves as a hinge between his Chinese ancestry and his American upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Southern Chinese lion dancing comes from an ancient tale: Terrorized by a mythical monster, a horde of villagers descended from the mountains and huddled under an enormous monster of their own in an attempt to repel the beast. Year after year, to the accompaniment of firecracker bursts and drums, the ritual is repeated as protection against evil spirits. At least that’s one version.

headline: Making the Ukraine Cease-Fire Stick
abstract: There should be no easing of sanctions until the Russian president shows a willingness to live by the agreements reached in Minsk.
lead_paragraph: A “glimmer of hope” but “no illusion” was the inauspicious way Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, described the Ukraine cease-fire she and President François Hollande of France brokered in talks in Minsk, Belarus, with Presidents Vladimir Putin of Russia and Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine. Ms. Merkel certainly deserves a lot of credit for her determined shuttling among Kiev, Moscow, Munich, Washington and Minsk in the urgent search for a resolution of the biggest security crisis to confront Europe since the end of the Cold War.

lead_paragraph: Congress has delivered to President Obama a bill commanding him to approve construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada, accompanied by a warning from House Speaker John Boehner to ignore the “left-fringe extremists and anarchists” who oppose the project.

headline: A Woman’s Place Is on Late Night
abstract: Please don’t replace Jon Stewart with another guy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — WHEN Jon Stewart exits “The Daily Show” at some point in 2015, it will be the sixth time in just over a year that a prominent late-night desk will be up for grabs. All this turnover would seem like a great opportunity to throw a female host into the mix. But it hasn’t happened yet. So next time, right? There’s always next time. Except next time probably won’t be for a long time. Most late-night hosts stay put for decades. It’s the closest thing to a Civil Service job in TV.

headline: Money Makes Crazy
abstract: Monetary policy madness is pervasive in today’s Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Monetary policy probably won’t be a major issue in the 2016 campaign, but it should be. It is, after all, extremely important, and the Republican base and many leading politicians have strong views about the Federal Reserve and its conduct. And the eventual presidential nominee will surely have to endorse the party line.

headline: Larry vs. Marco
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Marco Rubio and Larry Summers give us a glimpse of the economic options likely to be on offer in 2016
lead_paragraph: Pride goeth before a fall. Capitalism’s great triumph over socialism has been followed by a series of humbling setbacks since. Capitalism is not necessarily self-regulating, as we learned during the financial crisis. Capitalism does not necessarily lead to democracy abroad. Capitalism does not automatically produce sufficient social mobility.

headline: On Tinder, Taking a Swipe at Love, or Sex, or Something, in New York
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Mobile Applications', 'Single Persons', 'Online Dating']
abstract: The dating app Tinder has not fundamentally changed the local dating scene so much as quickened and coarsened its already abrupt, aggressive nature.
lead_paragraph: On a recent night, with Valentine’s Day looming, I went out for drinks with a woman I know and a few of her friends. It was a Thursday, and the bar they chose, Bondurants, on the Upper East Side, was packed with people just like them: good-looking, semi-affluent millennials, downing craft beer and milling about in hungry-looking, monosexual clusters.

headline: How Christian Rudder, a Founder of OKCupid, Spends His Sunday
abstract: Mr. Rudder, who met his wife in a “totally off-line” way, spends time on Sundays being a dad and playing basketball.
lead_paragraph: The lovelorn this Valentine’s Day can take heart. The dating site OKCupid generates approximately 30,000 first dates every day around the United States. That’s an eye-catching number, even for Christian Rudder, a founder of the website and data geek, whose first book, “Dataclysm: Who We Are When We Think No One’s Looking,” was published in September. Yet Mr. Rudder, 39, met his wife, Reshma Patel, the owner of a public relations firm, in a “totally off-line” way. They hit it off in 1999 when his band was playing a show with her boyfriend’s band in Boston. The couple, who married in 2006, live in North Williamsburg with their 3-year-old daughter, Plum.

headline: Questions Rise on Fate of Chinese Bishop

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For the better part of the last 60 years, Bishop Cosma Shi Enxiang was imprisoned in Chinese jails and labor camps. For the last 14, he was held without charge in a secret location.

keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Euro (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Quantitative Easing']

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European economy ended last year on a better note than economists had expected, an official report showed on Friday. And a surprisingly strong growth figure for Germany suggested a possible turning point for a region still seeking to shrug off the hangover from the financial crisis.

And that’s just what didn’t make it into the final cut. (This interview has been edited and condensed.) VANESSA FRIEDMAN

lead_paragraph: For decades, Democrats have been the party that emphasizes concerns about inequality. So why are many top Republicans — including a number of the party’s presidential hopefuls — talking about the issue?

headline: Daily Report: Obama Heads to Security Talks Amid Tensions
abstract: A long history of quiet cooperation between Washington and America’s top technology companies has been shattered by tension over the government’s use of technology companies for its intelligence purposes.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will meet in Palo Alto, Calif., on Friday with the nation’s top technologists on a host of cybersecurity issues and the threats posed by increasingly sophisticated hackers. But nowhere on the agenda is the real issue for the chief executives and tech company officials who will gather on the Stanford campus: the deepening estrangement between Silicon Valley and the government, David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: China Says Its Soldiers Will Need to Watch Their Weight
abstract: A new policy for military fitness training says that strict guidelines for body weight will be put in place, and that meeting those guidelines will be a consideration in determining eligibility for promotions,
lead_paragraph: China’s military announced last year that it was changing its recruiting standards, to admit enlistees who were slightly stouter than their predecessors. The idea was to ensure that the supply of new cadets would not be restricted by the growing waistlines of young Chinese.

abstract: A new era beckons. But first, a fond farewell.
lead_paragraph: This magazine is about to change. There will be new columns, new columnists, new page concepts and layouts, new features and new typefaces. We’re excited for you to meet them all next week, but first we want to take this opportunity to bid farewell to the magazine we’re leaving behind.

headline: The Short Cut
keywords: ['Barbers and Barbering', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Names, Personal', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: We had a language for everything, except what happened in the barber’s chair.
lead_paragraph: When I was in high school in the Midwest, in the early 50s, we all had crew cuts. Maybe, at times, we simply had short hair — anything other than short hair would have been somewhere between unfashionable and suicidal — but the hairstyle that engaged our connoisseurship was the crew cut. I was convinced that the barber many of us patronized gave the best crew cuts in the city. Anyone who believes that there is no room for artistry when dealing with an inch or so of hair never sat in this man’s chair.

headline: Dorm Wrecker
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Roommates', 'Dormitories', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Three’s company, too!
lead_paragraph: I’m a woman who lives in an on-campus apartment with three male roommates, one of whom was just nominated to run for president of his fraternity. If he is elected, he will be required to move into the fraternity house. My university’s coed housing policy stipulates that if one of the roommates moves out, the other residents could be split up and forced to live with students of the same sex. At the beginning of the year, we were all on the same page regarding our university’s policies with respect to coed living. Is this roommate ethically obligated to stay in order to prevent this? L. RODRIGUEZ, TROY, N.Y.

headline: It’s Buggy Out There
abstract: How micro-organisms make it rain, snow and even hail for their own benefit.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Mountain, a three-hour drive northwest of New York, calls itself the Snow-Making Capital of the World. When operating at maximum capacity, the ski resort’s 1,100 or so snow guns can blanket 240 acres with as much as three feet of snow in just two days. The recipe for all that manufactured powder is pretty simple — mostly water and air. But there’s often another, rather surprising ingredient: a bacterial protein that works like Kurt Vonnegut’s ice-nine, the fictional substance that instantly freezes water. Scientists have long known that certain terrestrial microbes perform this alchemy. In recent years, however, new discoveries have increasingly persuaded them that such micro-organisms live a double life in the sky, manipulating the weather for their own benefit.

headline: Celebrating Theater in London and New York
abstract: An exhibition planned for London and New York will celebrate 40 years of theater in both cities.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition celebrating 40 years of theater in London and New York will be shown in both cities in 2016, Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, will announce on Friday at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

headline: Fifty Shades of Criticism
abstract: A. O. Scott, one of The Times’s film critics, writes about the challenges surrounding his review of the movie “Fifty Shades of Grey.”
lead_paragraph: This week, A. O. Scott, one of The Times’s chief film critics, wrote about what is perhaps the most buzzed about movie of the year thus far: the film adaptation of the novel “Fifty Shades of Grey.” But what challenges are presented when reviewing a movie with as much hype as this one? And what of those presented when writing for a family newspaper about a movie whose main theme is kinky sex?

headline: In Senegal, a Coastal Region Sees a Resurgence
abstract: Casamance, once at the forefront of the ecotourism movement until a separatist movement began in 1982, is drawing people again to its spectacular beaches.
lead_paragraph: As the low-slung pirogue hummed along the Casamance River in the remote southern portion of Senegal, dolphins accompanied us. I had first spotted them on the overnight ferry from Dakar to Ziguinchor. But here they were within reach, companions who swam alongside the boat, nudging their noses toward us as we headed upriver.

headline: Restaurant Report: Miles in Bordeaux, France
abstract: The inventive new bistro is run by chefs whose multicultural backgrounds inform their flavors and styles.
lead_paragraph: For most of the world, Bordeaux and wine are inextricably linked. But with the emergence of reasonably priced, inventive neo-bistros — much like the ones that have been sweeping the Parisian culinary scene — the city’s expanding dining scene is primed to compete with its famed varietals as a reason to visit.

headline: A Park Avenue Address, Not Exactly
abstract: The awning says Park Avenue or Fifth. So why is it that the building actually stands around the corner, midblock on a side street?
lead_paragraph: By rights, mail intended for future residents of a certain luxury condominium under construction on the Upper East Side should read “45 East 60th Street.” After all, the Grolier Club, which is right next door to the persistent din, is 47 East 60th Street.

headline: Surprisingly, a Voluntary Climate Treaty Could Actually Work
abstract: The binding nature of international agreements like the 1997 Kyoto Protocol can do more harm than good by dissuading countries from joining.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators around the world are deliberating proposals for an international climate change treaty that will contain a glaring loophole: It won’t be binding.

lead_paragraph: For the next several weeks, many New York City families will be in a state of apprehension as private schools begin sending out their acceptance letters.

headline: China’s Internet Restrictions Are Hampering Business, Foreign Companies Say

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The new Chinese agency in charge of Internet control and censorship might have recently unveiled a rousing television anthem celebrating its shaping of cyberspace, but foreign businesspeople here say they have little to sing about.

headline: U.N. Envoy Says Assad Is Crucial to Defusing Conflict in Syria
abstract: The representative, Staffan de Mistura, met in Damascus with the Syrian president, who has refused to step down during nearly four years of conflict.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Appearing to address one of the core issues that have derailed peace talks in Syria, the United Nations special envoy for the country on Friday described President Bashar al-Assad as a crucial part of the solution to ending the war there, news agencies reported.

headline: CCTV, China’s Propaganda Tool, Finds Itself at Center of Antigraft Drive
abstract: An inquiry into corruption at CCTV has shaken up the nation’s most influential news organization, with reports involving a seamy mix of celebrities, sex and bribery.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As President Xi Jinping accelerated his sweeping campaign against government corruption, political enemies and Western influences in China, he deployed the Communist Party’s most powerful propaganda tool, the state television network, like a hammer.

headline: Reader Idea | He Said, She Said, I Say: A Researched Argument Essay
abstract: In this Reader Idea, Danielle Harms explains how she uses The Times’s Room for Debate feature to teach her college students how to support their claims while bringing many relevant “voices” into conversation with one another.
lead_paragraph: We are in the middle of our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest, when students practice writing short, evidence-based persuasive pieces similar to the editorials in The New York Times.

headline: A Russian TV Insider Describes a Modern Propaganda Machine
abstract: Peter Pomerantsev believes he has seen many classic propaganda techniques at work in Moscow, and in Russia’s treatment of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — NORMALLY a boisterous sort, Peter Pomerantsev says he kept quiet when he found himself, at the age of 24, in a Moscow meeting room listening to 20 of the country’s top media executives discussing the news agenda for the week.

headline: Tune In, Slim: 50 Ways to Be Entertained by Love
abstract: TV has no shortage of shows ready to help you meet, retain, reinvent, impress or leave your lover.
lead_paragraph: Confused about love as Valentine’s Day weekend arrives? Not sure how to get into, improve, reinvent or get out of a relationship? You obviously haven’t been watching enough television. With all due respect to “Fifty Shades of Grey” on its debut weekend, it’s the “50 Ways” song that comes to mind here, with 50 TV shows standing ready to help you meet, retain, change, impress or leave your lover:

headline: The Mystery of Lower Voter Registration for Older Black Voters
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: An analysis by political scientists suggests that the lower voting rates might not be because of the legacy of Jim Crow.
lead_paragraph: In December, I wrote an article titled “Evidence That the Jim Crow Era Endures for Older Black Voters in the South.” The article, based on voter registration and census data in Georgia, noted that older black voters who reached voting age before the passage of the Voting Rights Act were significantly less likely to be registered to vote compared with whites of similar age and black voters who reached voting age in the years afterward.

headline: Zlata Mangafic Transforms at Creatures of the Wind
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Zlata Mangafic before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Boehmer and hair by Anthony Turner.
