abstract: Pop meets opera in South Africa, video art in Melbourne and the simple pleasures of still life in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Humlebaek, Denmark

headline: Suicide Attackers Kill 19 in Assault on a Shiite Mosque in Pakistan
abstract: The Taliban claimed responsibility for heavily armed militants who stormed a Shiite mosque during Friday Prayer in a suburb of Peshawar.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Heavily armed militants killed at least 19 people and wounded more than 40 after they stormed into a Shiite mosque during Friday Prayer in a suburb of Peshawar, the main city in northwestern Pakistan, doctors and officials said.

headline: 1890: Taxi Tariff Approved in Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Taxis in Paris impose a new, universal tariff and meter in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The committee of the Chambre Syndicale des Cocher has accepted the principle of the ‘‘compteur horo-kilométrique,’’ and all the Paris cabs will have to be supplied within eighteen months. Though the mechanism of the ‘‘compteurs’’ may differ, no special model having been chosen, the exterior plate will be of a uniform type for the convenience of the public. It will be fastened to the box in such a position that it will face the occupant of the cab, and that the light of one of the lamps will fall on it. M.  Alphand will make his report to the Municipal Council on Monday next. He proposes to fix the tariff for a cab at 25 centimes per kilomètre, plus 50 centimes for the hire of the vehicle. The clock is intended to show the amount of time the cab may have been kept waiting. Two francs an hour will be charged in cases of this kind. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 14, 1890

headline: When the First Bagger, David Carr, Hit the Red Carpet
abstract: Paul Thomas Anderson yelled at him, and he stuck to his guns about stars: “They’re not that important.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a dark day at The New York Times, and particularly here on the Carpetbagger beat, which the inimitable David Carr, who died last night, started a decade ago.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: If the Westminster Kennel Club dog show that begins on Monday is the 139th, there was of course a first, and The Times was there to record it.
lead_paragraph: 138 YEARS AGO

headline: A Former Fashionista’s Life as a Florist Blooms
abstract: Georgie Newbery made a name for herself in the fashion world before moving to the country to start Common Farm Flowers.
lead_paragraph: As Georgie Newbery welcomes guests in the fields of her small farm on a rainy winter day in Somerset, England — her Wellingtons muddied and water dripping off the rim of her soggy hat — it’s hard to imagine that she was once a regular guest at Paris fashion shows. During her glamorous previous life in the 1990s, Newbery was the assistant to Susan Train, the legendary Paris bureau chief of American Vogue, and later served as office manager for John Galliano, back when he was being courted by LVMH to take over Givenchy. Next, she moved to London where she penned three rollicking romans à clef about the fashion industry, before leaving that world for good. Today, with her press-shy English husband, Newbery runs Common Farm Flowers, a floral company that delivers cheerful bouquets and centerpieces by mail throughout Britain. They grow most of the flowers organically themselves at Common Farm, a seven-acre spread with a ramshackle house they are restoring. Newbery has also returned to her original love of writing and combined it with her third career as a florist, producing “The Flower Farmer’s Year: How to Grow Cut Flowers for Pleasure and Profit” ($30, Green Books), a richly illustrated how-to guide in which Newbery shares all that she has learned in her 10 years in the fields of southern England.

headline: For Molly Pope, Adventures in Cabaret and ‘Horseplay’
abstract: “Horseplay: Or, the Fickle Mistress, a Protean Picaresque,” at La MaMa, stars Ms. Pope as the audacious 19th-century actress Adah Isaacs Menken.
lead_paragraph: In an 1861 performance of the melodrama “Mazeppa,” the actress Ada Isaacs Menken, playing a man, caused outrage when she appeared to be stripped naked — she was actually wearing a body stocking — and was tied to a horse.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: THERE’S still time to get health insurance this year under the Affordable Care Act. But you’ll have to be quick.

headline: At Baltimore Symphony, a Cello and a Violin Make More Than Music
abstract: Marin Alsop, who lost both of her parents last year, has lent their instruments to members of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, which she leads.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It was a year ago that Marin Alsop, the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, lost both of her parents, who were respected musicians themselves, within the space of 11 days. But whenever she takes the podium here to conduct the orchestra, she finds herself surrounded by audible, often quite mellifluous, reminders of them both.

lead_paragraph: Watch a preview of the 2011 documentary about the paper, “Page One: Inside The New York Times,” featuring the media desk and David Carr.

headline: 20-20 Foresight
abstract: Some of us don’t need to make excuses.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis has a long-form discussion of the “austerity con” in the London Review of Books, which is well worth reading; he also has a sort of commentary on his commentary on the blog, which makes some good points about the difficulty in talking about macroeconomics to a general audience.

headline: Online Dating Rules for My Grandmother: Must Drive, Preferably at Night
abstract: While my grandmother and I have always been close, her online dating experiment brought us closer, mostly because she called me four or five times a week (she kept forgetting her JDate password).
lead_paragraph: “I look like a barracuda,” my then 83-year-old grandmother, Gloria, said, laughing, but rather matter-of-fact. That was her appraisal of an iPhone picture that my husband snapped for her JDate and OurTime.com profiles back in September. We went with a picture of her from our wedding instead.

headline: Modi Voices Concern at Crimes Seen to Target India’s Christians

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India expressed concern on Friday about a series of episodes at Catholic churches in New Delhi that have raised fears among Christians here about a deliberate campaign of violence.

headline: States Consider Increasing Taxes for the Poor and Cutting Them for the Affluent
keywords: ['Governors (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'States (US)', 'Income', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Some G.O.P.-led states may raise consumption taxes, which hit the poor harder, and cut income taxes, which hit the affluent harder.
lead_paragraph: A number of Republican-led states are considering tax changes that in many cases would have the effect of cutting taxes on the rich and raising them on the poor.

headline: Selling America in Jakarta

lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia – In the competition for hearts and minds in Asia, one of the United States’ best weapons may be a storefront in a Jakarta mall.

headline: Minding the Kids
abstract: Laura Lippman’s scrappy Baltimore private eye, Tess Monaghan, is back on the job in “Hush Hush.”
lead_paragraph: Those daring adventures into the treacherous territory of the stand-alone novel are all very exciting, but readers do remain devoted to their series sleuths. So it’s good to see Laura Lippman’s scrappy Baltimore private eye, Tess Monaghan, back on the job in HUSH HUSH (Morrow/Harper­Collins, $26.99), a tough-minded but wonderfully entertaining book that might be called a parenting mystery. During the years she’s been out of commission, Tess has become the mother of a little girl, Carla Scout, now 3 years old and a real handful. (A first-class meltdown in the liquor aisle of a grocery store should endear the child to amused strangers, while piling up sympathy points for her mother.)

headline: Chickpea Stew With Moroccan Spices
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a vegetarian stew with chickpeas and rainbow chard.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a vegetarian stew with chickpeas and rainbow chard.

headline: Democrats’ Convention Choice for 2016 Reflects a Philadelphia Resurgence
abstract: A city long overshadowed by nearby New York and Washington has learned to take pride in the creativity born of its relative affordability.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Cheesesteaks? Never mind. Sichuan shoestring French fries? That’s more like it. Like many American cities, Philadelphia has greatly evolved both economically and culturally since 2000, the last time a major political party held its national convention here, not to mention the days when W. C. Fields made it a national punch line.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WORLDLY PHILOSOPHER: The Odyssey of Albert O. Hirschman,  by Jeremy Adelman. (Princeton University, $24.95.) Shaped “by modern horrors and hopes,” Hirschman (1915-2012) spent his life in constant motion. Born in Berlin, he studied at the London School of Economics; fought in the Spanish Civil War; helped spirit thousands of refugees out of Nazi-occupied France; and blended economics, politics and culture in a pathbreaking 30-year academic career. Adelman’s superb biography brings every twist and turn of this story to life.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MOURNING LINCOLN,  by Martha Hodes. (Yale University, $30.) In her lyrical and important study, Hodes finds little evidence of national unity in the face of the assassination, but rather shock, jubilation, confusion and disagreement.

lead_paragraph: The Elm, a Brooklyn hotel restaurant that hoped to bring the art-influenced, French-tinged cuisine of the chef Paul Liebrandt to the booming neighborhood of Williamsburg, will serve its last meal on Sunday.

headline: Law Enforcement Concerns Create Unlikely Alliances in Missouri and Beyond
keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Local Government', 'Minorities', 'State Legislatures', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police']
abstract: After Ferguson, white Republicans and leaders from conservative groups joined black lawmakers in backing a bill to limit the revenue Missouri towns can keep from traffic fines.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — For years, poor black residents of St. Louis County have complained bitterly about being jailed when they could not pay traffic fines. Protesters in Ferguson, after the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by the police last year, even cited those fines — and related trips to jail — as a major reason for their anger.

abstract: The essay “To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This,” which repeated a psychologist’s 20-year-old experiment, drew 8 million readers who found the combination of romance and science irresistible.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a few days before Mandy Len Catron’s essay “To Fall in Love With Anyone, Do This” appeared in Modern Love, she aired some concerns about the coming exposure on her blog, writing that while a few hundred people may see one of her blog posts, thousands would see this column.

headline: Irish Animators in a Strange Land (Los Angeles)
abstract: “The Song of the Sea” filmmakers were told not to be so self-deprecating on the Oscar campaign trail — because Americans might take them at their word.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Hollywood was mildly gobsmacked when “The Secret of Kells,” an obscure animated Celtic film from a teeny studio in southeast Ireland, came from nowhere to land a nomination for the best animated feature Oscar. The young filmmakers were, too. This year, the same filmmakers put a little more muscle into getting a nomination for their second effort, “Song of the Sea,” by spending time with Academy members and so on. That, too, worked: they earned their second nod.

keywords: ['Boats and Boating', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A lot goes into choosing the right boat, crew and destination. For those who can afford it, there’s also the question of whether to buy or rent.
lead_paragraph: ADAM ROSENFELD, a lifelong Miami resident, needed a vacation, but he was struggling to persuade his wife to go anywhere with their toddler in tow. Gone were the days when the couple could jet around Asia, jamming as many things into a vacation as they wanted.

headline: Breathing Life Into Dragons

headline: ‘Chasing the Scream,’ by Johann Hari
abstract: Johann Hari surveys the devastation wrought by the decades-long war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: On July 9, 2001, the British newsweekly New Statesman published a column by a 22-year-old named Johann Hari titled “Just You Wait Until I Grow Up.” It began with Hari’s announcement that he’d celebrated his recent graduation from Cambridge University “with a few tabs of Ecstasy and the odd line of coke.” After that casual boast, Hari argued that the legalization of narcotics was not only inevitable but would save lives, create a more just society and help rectify “the disengagement of young people from politics.”

headline: Tributes From All Over for the Incomparable David Carr
abstract: From readers and writers, an outpouring of appreciation
lead_paragraph: The Times did right by its brilliant media columnist, David Carr, on Friday, featuring a beautifully written obituary on the front page, above the fold, with a perfect black and white photograph. It was accompanied by a perceptive appraisal from his friend the film critic, A. O. Scott. On the home page, there were other offerings, too: Links to some of the best Carr quotes, to an excerpt from his book, to the video of a panel he moderated just before he died, and to the trailer for “Page One,” the documentary in which he played a starring role.

headline: From Syria, an Atlas of a Country in Ruins
abstract: A satellite image analysis reveals vast devastation in major cities across Syria from the civil war that started nearly four years ago.
lead_paragraph: A satellite image analysis reveals vast devastation in major cities across Syria from the civil war that started nearly four years ago.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The board of Aer Lingus urged the Irish government on Friday to support a takeover bid by the parent of British Airways, saying the offer will accelerate the Irish airline’s growth plans and enhance Ireland’s position as hub for trans-Atlantic travel.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The War on Drugs

headline: Stuff We Liked: Surprising Facts About Vaccination and Beer
abstract: Interesting items from around the web this week also include a historical look at neighborhood segregation and Valentine equations.
lead_paragraph: Here are the things we found on the web this week that you might enjoy as much as we did.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Nick Hornby, whose novel “Funny Girl” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 9, has lately embraced Hollywood in a big way.
lead_paragraph: Adaptation, Part I: Readers who have kept tabs on Nick Hornby’s career might not be surprised that his new novel, “Funny Girl” — new at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list — devotes considerable attention to a couple of scriptwriters. That’s because Hornby, who made his name with the 1995 novel “High Fidelity,” has lately embraced Hollywood in a big way. He received an Oscar nomination for his screenplay for the 2009 movie “An Education” (adapted from Lynn Barber’s memoir), then went on to adapt Cheryl Strayed’s “Wild,” currently in theaters, and Colm Toibin’s novel “Brooklyn,” which had its premiere last month at Sundance. (Interestingly, Hornby did not write the screenplay for “High Fidelity,” which jumped to film in 2000, or any of his other books to become movies — confirming the wisdom that it’s better to operate on other people’s children than your own.) In a recent online interview with The Atlantic, Hornby, who is British, explained why he had actively pursued the “Wild” gig: “There’s a side of me that responds very deeply to American things,” he said. “The book to me felt like a Springsteen album. I always loved Springsteen, but he’s very American. That kind of directness is really interesting to me because it doesn’t have to be unsubtle. It’s just a different way of being, a different way of thinking. The great thing about adaptation is it gives you a chance to be someone else.”

headline: ‘A Bad Character,’ by Deepti Kapoor
abstract: A Delhi woman embraces desire, social and erotic.
lead_paragraph: The title character of Deepti Kapoor’s searing debut is dead by Line 1, but I still read “A Bad Character” in one frantic sitting. I wasn’t desperate for details about his mysterious death or his relationship with the narrator; it was Idha, a woman ready to defy societal conventions, who kept me on the line.

headline: Kelly Link’s ‘Get in Trouble’
abstract: The stories in this collection are not realistic, but neither are they fantasy; they focus on the small stuff of life.
lead_paragraph: So come on then, what’s your superpower? You must have one — everyone does. And who is your nemesis? What’s your origin story? Have you managed to find a reliable sidekick? How many shadows do you have? Do you currently have a boyfriend, or would you prefer a Boyfriend? And have you been to the pocket universe that’s like Florida, only better?

headline: Greg Baxter’s ‘Munich Airport’
abstract: Far from home, an American father and son contend with the incomprehensible death of a loved one.
lead_paragraph: Imagine being in a foreign airport with your father, and your sister is somewhere in the same airport in a coffin waiting for you to fly her home, but the airport is fogbound and heaving with unhappy souls and you are given hours and then days to contemplate her death and your life. This is the plot, such as it is, of Greg Baxter’s second novel. The airport in question is Munich, and the fog is a confusion that seeps into the whole novel — Baxter is the fog machine and we the readers are also fogbound.

headline: ‘The Patient Will See You Now,’ by Eric Topol
abstract: Smartphones will empower patients to take charge of their health care, a cardiologist argues.
lead_paragraph: With his previous book, “The Creative Destruction of Medicine,” Eric Topol, a cardiologist and director of the Scripps Translational Science Institute, established himself as one of medicine’s most innovative thinkers about the digital future. In “The Patient Will See You Now,” his exhaustively researched follow-up, Topol turns his attention to medicine’s “democratization” via “unplugged digitization, with the smartphone as the hub.” With approximately two billion users worldwide, smartphones, Topol says, “are the most rapidly adopted technology in the history of man.”

headline: Flipping Through Film School
abstract: Matt Zoller Seitz described his new book about Wes Anderson’s “Grand Budapest Hotel” as “film school in book form.”
lead_paragraph: The film critic Matt Zoller Seitz met the filmmaker Wes Anderson in 1994 in Dallas, after seeing the short film “Bottle Rocket,” an expanded version of which would become Anderson’s first full-length feature. In 2013, their long relationship yielded “The Wes Anderson Collection,” Seitz’s lavishly illustrated book about Anderson’s seven feature-length movies up to that point.

headline: ‘The Jaguar’s Children,’ by John Vaillant
abstract: Abandoned by their smugglers, a group of Mexican immigrants are left trapped and clinging to life in John Vaillant’s novel.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, a trailer truck crammed with immigrants trying to cross the United States border illegally was abandoned on the outskirts of Victoria, Tex. As the heat inside climbed over 100 degrees, 19 people died of asphyxiation and heatstroke — one a 5-year-old boy and one believed to be his father. Holes, which people had made by taking turns attempting to scratch their way toward breathable air, were visible in the insulation of the locked door.

headline: Love
abstract: New books by Roger Rosenblatt, Eve Pell and Tim Dowling.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF LOVE  Improvisations on a Crazy Little Thing  By Roger Rosenblatt  Ecco/HarperCollins, $22.99.

headline: ‘Bonita Avenue,’ by Peter Buwalda
abstract: Lies and madness slowly tear a family apart in this first novel.
lead_paragraph: The title of the Dutch writer Peter Buwalda’s volatile, time-scrambling first novel alludes to a residential street in Berkeley, Calif., where its central characters, the Sigerius family, once experienced a fleeting year or two of happiness before returning to their native Netherlands. But an equally apt title might be “Breaking Glass.”

headline: A Moroccan Stew With Spice and Sweetness
abstract: A recipe with chickpeas and chard is satisfying and light at the same time, as a vegetarian main course or as a side dish to roasted meats or fish. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been to Morocco — at least not physically. But it’s the first place my mind goes when my body has become thoroughly fed up with February’s damp chill.

headline: Confessions of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Wine Connoisseur
abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg admitted Thursday night to not being “100 percent sober” when she dozed off at last month’s State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg admitted Thursday night to not being “100 percent sober” when she dozed off at last month’s State of the Union address.

headline: Exclusive | 26 East 80th Street
abstract: A restored townhouse at 26 East 80th Street has returned to the sales market at $21 million.
lead_paragraph: A restored townhouse at 26 East 80th Street has returned to the sales market at $21 million.

headline: Classic and Contemporary
abstract: A restored 1888 townhouse at 26 East 80th Street has returned to the sales market after spending two years as a specialized rental.
lead_paragraph: An exquisitely preserved townhouse at 26 East 80th Street that was built in 1888, became part of a landmark district in 1977 and was restored and updated inside and out in 1995, has returned to the sales market after spending two years as a specialized rental — the tenant was the Argentine mission to the United Nations.

headline: Drug Maker Salix Is Once Again a Potential Takeover Target
abstract: Valeant, which failed in its attempt to acquire the Botox maker Allergan last year, is now in talks with Salix, according to a person briefed on the matter. The British drug maker Shire, too, is interested.
lead_paragraph: Salix’s stock is up 50 percent in the last three months on speculation about a deal.

headline: For Hip-Hop Radio and Its Voices, Change Is on the Air
abstract: Some recognizable names have left Hot 97, while outside voices have come in. And that raises concerns about the station’s status as a top rap outlet.
lead_paragraph: Two familiar New York voices shared the radio airwaves on Thursday, talking as usual about hip-hop, but up higher on the dial.

headline: Gene-Altered Apples Get U.S. Approval
abstract: It will probably be several years before the fruit, which resists browning when sliced or bruised, shows up in grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: The government on Friday approved the commercial planting of genetically engineered apples that are resistant to turning brown when sliced or bruised.

headline: Peak Times for Loan Closings
abstract: The most popular times to close on a mortgage are Fridays and the end of the month — even though there is not necessarily any financial advantage in doing so.
lead_paragraph: The most popular times to close on a mortgage are on Fridays and at the end of the month — even though there is not necessarily any financial advantage to borrowers in doing so.

headline: Deleting Files From Microsoft’s OneDrive
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Computer Security', 'Desktop Computers', 'Windows (Operating System)', 'Data Storage']
abstract: Tips on how to remove a file or folder from Microsoft’s cloud-storage service, and advice on how to confirm that your computer’s firewall is turned on.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have Windows 8.1 on my desktop computer. I moved a document to the OneDrive, which I did not mean to do, so how do I delete it?

headline: Posing for Fashion Houses, N.B.A. Stars Feel at Home
abstract: New York Fashion Week is sharing the city with All-Star weekend and the N.B.A., whose most stylish players aspire to be icons of an industry other than basketball.
lead_paragraph: Nick Young was slouched in a booth inside Santina, a restaurant under the High Line park, where the Italian fashion house Ermenegildo Zegna had organized a private dinner Thursday to fete the Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony, a featured face in one of its coming campaigns.

headline: ‘A Spool of Blue Thread,’ by Anne Tyler
abstract: The characters in Anne Tyler’s novel, four generations of them, are drawn to a commodious house in suburban Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Picture a middle-class American family, four generations, living in the suburbs. The “founder” is an upstart with a murky past, a hard-working construction guy in a bleak marriage. Next in line are his son and the son’s wife — he’s a chip off the old patriarch, inherits the construction business, soldiers on. She’s the maddening, meddling family fixer-upper, determined that her four children will, against all odds, tolerate if not love one another. And then there are the children, at midlife and with children of their own: a couple of daughters who annoy each other, an “acquired” son (the product of a “crazy arrangement”) and of course the obligatory black sheep, Denny, the prodigal son who surfaces intermittently to provide the drama, which, after all, is his job — in the family as in the plot of Anne Tyler’s graceful and capacious new novel, “A Spool of Blue Thread.”

headline: ‘Once Upon a Revolution,’ by Thanassis Cambanis
abstract: A journalist investigates the Tahrir Square revolution and the reasons for its disappointing aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Western coverage of the Arab Spring was often simple-minded, as journalists focused on the dramatic confrontations between the police and protesters in Tahrir Square in Cairo or on Libyan militiamen fighting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s soldiers on the road south of Benghazi. Uprisings were reported like scenes out of “Les Misérables,” with an oppressed people battling a brutal tyranny everywhere from Tunis to Bahrain.

headline: To a Friend, on His Divorce
abstract: Welcome to your new life as a middle-aged single dude. Here’s what it will be like.
lead_paragraph: YOU were 7 and I was 6 when we met near the jungle gym. After becoming bandmates in high school and enjoying a brief twinkle of local stardom, we became men and did man things, one of which was each finding someone we loved enough to marry. I have proof that both of us were happy then. The photos from our weddings show us laughing, smiling, greeting friends and relatives, eating cake, smoking cigars and dancing.

headline: Making Brokers Toe the Mark
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Financial Planners', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans']
abstract: The financial services industry is marshaling opposition to the proposed regulation, which has been percolating for years in the Labor Department.
lead_paragraph: If you are in the market for financial advice, good luck figuring out which financial advisers are legally obligated to act in your best interest. There is a big difference between glorified salesman and true investment advisers, and yet the onus is on consumers to sort it all out.

headline: When Italy’s Bad Bank Is a Good Idea
abstract: A bank that takes in bad loans in Italy could help lending and spur consolidation in the country’s fragmented banking system, Neil Unmack writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s bad bank is a good idea. Rome wants to set up a vehicle to sweep up banks’ toxic loans. It’s risky; government-funded bad banks can wind up losing taxpayers’ money. Yet it could also help lending and even spur consolidation in Italy’s fragmented banking system.

headline: Drexel, 25 Years After Its Collapse, Only Helps a Résumé
abstract: Alumni of the investment bank occupy some of the most powerful positions in finance. In fact, an association with Drexel is now worn as a badge of pride.
lead_paragraph: Edwin Kantor, the onetime head of trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert, told The New York Times in 1995, “People used to be afraid to put Drexel on their résumé.”

headline: Meatloaf That Conquers the Mundane
abstract: Polpettone, or Italian meatloaf, is always well seasoned, made with care and served with gusto.
lead_paragraph: I was raised on Midwestern meatloaf. My mother’s dependable recipe did not vary: Ground beef, grated onion and carrot and a little oatmeal were the main ingredients, along with a dash of “seasoned salt.” A ribbon of bottled chili sauce ran down a gully in the center.

lead_paragraph: Join us in reveling in the work of our beloved colleague, the media columnist David Carr, who died on Thursday. He was 58.

lead_paragraph: True to form, Costco customers may come out ahead in a valuable commercial arrangement. That’s at least one way to read the market tea leaves from this week’s divorce between the warehouse retailer and American Express, its longtime exclusive payments partner.

headline: An Accomplished Home Design Firm Brings Its Modernist Aesthetic to Clothing
abstract: BassamFellows, known for its work with Bally and the James Hotel, is now releasing a line of apparel and accessories.
lead_paragraph: It’s not uncommon for fashion designers to branch out into home accessories — but rarely does a home design company make the reverse move. Enter Craig Bassam and Scott Fellows, the founders of the design brand BassamFellows, known for their work with the James Hotel and their aid in reviving the Swiss luxury brand Bally (and designing its corporate headquarters). On Monday, the duo will introduce its first line of apparel and accessories, imbued with the same attention to detail and craft as their rigorously Modernist furniture, interiors and architecture.

abstract: For Arlene and Alan Alda, the keys to a long life together include luck, good timing, lots of laughter and a healthy dose of forgetfulness.
lead_paragraph: Arlene Alda, 81, and her husband, the actor Alan Alda, 79, say that one secret to a long-lasting marriage (theirs has been going for almost 58 years) is forgetfulness, which comes naturally to them at this point.

headline: Close but No Cigar
abstract: Questions about email etiquette, helping out a minimum-wage earner, whether to give a second gift and how to ask a friend to wear his hearing aid.
lead_paragraph: I have been close with a family member since she was a little girl. She is now the mother of two young children. I am also a mother, so I know how time-consuming that is. But I don’t understand why she has time to post on Facebook but doesn’t have time to answer my emails. I have tried commenting on her posts, but that doesn’t work, either. I am a baby boomer, and she is a Gen X-er. Can you explain what’s going on? Anonymous

headline: Not Your Bubbe’s Kasha
abstract: Everything changed when I bought a box of medium-grain kasha at the supermarket and took another stab at making a kasha dish.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday I cooked up a big pot of nutty-tasting kasha, the cooked cereal made with toasted buckwheat groats. I enjoyed it all week. I stirred some into a frittata along with leeks and spinach, added it to two different salads and to buckwheat pancakes. I ate it plain, with a little milk and maple syrup as porridge for breakfast, and made a dinner in a bowl of kasha topped with mushroom ragout and kale.

headline: Roger Goodell’s 2013 Pay of $35 Million Keeps Him in Top Tier of Executives

lead_paragraph: Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was paid $35 million in 2013, a year in which the league signed major television and sponsorship deals and settled a landmark concussion lawsuit, and in which two teams began work on new stadiums.

headline: The End of Trend
abstract: With no clear guidelines for our sartorial choices and an endless array of options, the solution is to rely on our own instincts.
lead_paragraph: Typically, fashion editors sit at shows seeking out common threads or ideas to bring back to their offices and translate into fashion spreads that tell us what we ought to be wearing that season. This service is what you might think that we, at T, are here to provide. But times have changed. Technology and the economics of fashion have overthrown the old hegemony in which what was fashionable was proposed by designers, decreed by editors and proselytized for by department stores.

headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon Resigns Amid Crisis
abstract: Mr. Kitzhaber stepped down amid a scandal that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — Gov. John Kitzhaber, long regarded as a wily survivor of Oregon politics, resigned Friday amid a spiraling crisis that included a criminal investigation of the role that his fiancée played in his administration and crumbling support from his Democratic Party colleagues.

headline: 1915: Britain Hails Air Raid’s Success
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Largest British air raid to date is incredibly successful in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — All England is rejoicing to-day [Feb. 13] at the superb flight of her great air fleet, thirty-four strong, across the Channel, with not a serious injury to a pilot, and accidents to only two of the machines. It seems almost incredible that it was only five years ago that Blériot made the pioneer aeroplane trip across the Channel, so vast and rapid has been the progress since. The raid not only represents the largest fleet of air craft that has ever operated together, but it is a fitting reply to the German bombardment of British towns, and a warning to the Kaiser’s forces in Belgium of further damage. One fact well demonstrated by the raid is that in case of such an attack, land guns are unreliable defences, and it is necessary to meet aeroplanes with aeroplanes. The attack probably puts an end to Germany’s reputed intention to use Zeebrugge and other places on the Belgian coast as bases for submarines. The Admiralty states that no submarines were seen. This indicates that German preparations are too incomplete for them to trust these craft in Belgian harbors. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 14, 1915

headline: Can ‘Battery Geniuses’ Transform Cars and the Grid?
keywords: ['Batteries', 'Books and Literature', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Can batteries spark a clean-energy revolution? A new book says, maybe.
lead_paragraph: Early this week, I enjoyed discussing a brewing, but halting revolution in battery technology with the journalist and author Steve LeVine, who spent the last several years exploring the frontiers of energy-storage innovation for his new book, “The Powerhouse: Inside the Invention of a Battery to Save the World.”

headline: Alan Gilbert’s Exit From the New York Philharmonic Sends Uncertain Signals
abstract: More than any of his predecessors since Leonard Bernstein, Mr. Gilbert has tried to expand the template for what a major American orchestra can be.
lead_paragraph: Taken at face value, the reasons both Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic are giving for his decision to step aside as music director in the summer of 2017 make some sense. Still, this move raises questions about how satisfied the administration is with Mr. Gilbert’s work and sends uncertain signals about the orchestra’s future.

headline: Refuse to Vaccinate? Little Religious Ground to Stand On
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood', 'Religion and Belief', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Measles', 'Autism', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Though parents in New York are allowed vaccination exemptions for religious reasons, there is virtually no canonical basis for vaccine aversion; the Bible, the Quran and the texts of Sanskrit were all written long before the creation of vaccines.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a bill surfaced in the New York State Legislature proposing that parents be permitted to reject vaccinations for their children simply because they opposed them philosophically, as one might oppose Oreos or the Disney Channel. The bill had emerged before and gone nowhere; in the unlikely event that it was enacted, it would give parents even greater leeway to reject science for children who were ostensibly in school to gain an understanding of it.

headline: New Music From Pops Staples, George Ezra and Others

headline: Carpetbagger Video: Voicing Dragons and Other DreamWorks Stars
abstract: The Bagger gives voice acting with Craig Ferguson a try.
lead_paragraph: DreamWorks Animation’s “How to Train Your Dragon 2″ has been a boon for the studio, earning more than $600 million worldwide, winning a Golden Globe and taking its place among the frontrunners for the Oscar for best animated feature. The Bagger visited the studio shortly after its Globe win, meeting the film’s animators and even trying voice acting with one of the film’s stars, Craig Ferguson.

headline: Michele Mariotti to Conduct at the Metropolitan Opera
abstract: Mr. Mariotti will bring his interpretation of Rossini’s “La Donna del Lago” to New York.
lead_paragraph: The young conductor Michele Mariotti’s precocious eminence in bel canto opera isn’t, perhaps, such a surprise. As a child, he made batons out of skewers and Champagne corks, waving them along to recordings.

headline: Ready to Travel the World Together
abstract: Emma Marwood was in the middle of a two-year assignment in Mexico as a foreign service worker when she found Miguel Palafox, who decided he was more than happy to travel the world with her.
lead_paragraph: Emma Marwood found her calling early. A high school exchange trip to Mexico first sparked her interest in living abroad, and the war in Iraq opened her eyes to the complexities of international affairs.

headline: New York Theater Ballet Moves Its Relevés Downtown
abstract: Diana Byer’s company begins a new chapter with a studio at St. Mark’s Church, an updated repertory and a season at New York Live Arts in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: At a recent informal performance hosted by New York Theater Ballet at St. Mark’s Church, 40 or so people crammed into a studio on the second floor. Children sat cross-legged. Two company members danced an Agnes de Mille pas de deux. The production manager, also a puppeteer, did a melancholy number with a wooden board as a prop.

headline: Signs of a Push Against ISIS, Amid Doubts on Iraqi Troops
abstract: American officials say they are trying to balance the desire to move quickly against the Islamic State while also addressing concerns that Iraqi ground forces may not be prepared.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi and American military officials have intensified talk in recent weeks of a major offensive against Islamic State militants, casting it as a quickly approaching operation that is likely to target the extremists’ stronghold in the northern city of Mosul.

headline: An Uzbek Wave, ‘Made for Wrestling’
abstract: At least nine high schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens have Uzbek immigrants on their wrestling squads.
lead_paragraph: At least nine high schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens have Uzbek immigrants on their wrestling squads.

headline: In New York, Uzbek Immigrants Invigorate High School Wrestling
abstract: An influx of immigrants from Uzbekistan, which has a long history of success in fight sports, has transformed New York’s high school wrestling competition.
lead_paragraph: The smartphone with the earbuds blasting rap and rock music during warm-ups was set aside. The easy smile vanished. Zafar Iskandarov, 18, was all focused aggression, knowing his match was the decisive one for the Brooklyn International School in the season’s final meet.

headline: Oil Prices Up 3% on News of Economic Growth in Europe, but Supplies Rise
abstract: Nevertheless, analysts warned that growing stockpiles could easily force prices down again.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The global benchmark price for oil rallied above $60 a barrel on Friday for the first time in 2015, but analysts warned that growing stockpiles were hanging over the market and could easily force prices back down.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Alibaba About Dispute With Chinese Regulator
abstract: Alibaba disclosed on Friday that it has received a request from the S.E.C. for more information about the clash with China’s State Administration for Industry and Commerce.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group’s dust-up with one of its Chinese regulators may have settled down, but the Securities and Exchange Commission is still interested in more information about the dispute.

headline: Lynn Hershman Leeson Explores Technology and the Split Self
abstract: A broad sweep of the artist’s unsettling work will inaugurate Bridget Donahue, a new gallery on the Bowery.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher Isaiah Berlin once described David Hume’s idea of the self as a pure fiction, “a name for the concatenation of experiences out of which human personality and human history were formed, simply a kind of string which held together the onions, except that there was no string.” For decades, the artist and filmmaker Lynn Hershman Leeson has been playing with this un-string, which technology has rendered all the more evanescent. Starting Thursday, a broad sweep of her unsettling work will inaugurate Bridget Donahue, a new gallery on the Lower East Side being opened by a longtime director at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, the West Village gallery. Ms. Donahue said she had been drawn to Ms. Hershman Leeson as a kind of prophet of “our cybernetic condition,” through early interactive works that delved into artificial intelligence and surveillance and yearslong performances that blurred the line between acting and life. The show, “Origins of the Species,” through April 5, will span from the late 1960s to recent work exploring the implications of genetic manipulation. (99 Bowery, 2nd floor; bridgetdonahue.nyc.)

headline: Why Movie ‘Facts’ Prevail
abstract: Our minds are not well equipped to sort good sources from bad ones.
lead_paragraph: THIS year’s Oscar nominees for best picture include four films based on true stories: “American Sniper” (about the sharpshooter Chris Kyle), “The Imitation Game” (about the British mathematician Alan Turing), “Selma” (about the passage of the Voting Rights Act in 1965) and “The Theory of Everything” (about the physicist Stephen Hawking).

headline: Review: Douglas Dunn’s ‘Aidos’ Is Set to Bach at BAM Fisher
abstract: Accompanied by cello suites, Mr. Dunn’s choreography crouches, crawls and pokes beneath the vestments of propriety.
lead_paragraph: It’s about halfway through Douglas Dunn’s “Aidos” that things get weird. This 75-minute work, which had its debut on Wednesday at BAM Fisher, is set to 12 movements from Bach’s six suites for unaccompanied cello, played live and out of their original order by Ha-Yang Kim. Much of the choreography is politely balletic, its decorum ruffled only momentarily by a rough outburst here, a flash of louche hip motion there.

headline: Jason Wu Lets His Models’ Hair Down
abstract: On his fall/winter 2015 runway, for the first time ever, natural locks flowed free.
lead_paragraph: It’s a new wave for Jason Wu, who usually sends his models down the runway in some sort of low ponytail but opted instead for a natural hairstyle on his fall/winter 2015 runway. “It was nonchalance and sexiness having their hair just the way it is, letting the girls really shine through,” explained the designer. “The clothing is very glamorous, very sexy. The hair down felt like the girls did it themselves.”

Then he interrupts himself. “I know you’re not following what I’m saying anyway, right?” he says, laughing at an audience he considers too unsophisticated to understand.

abstract: The Off Broadway company Second Stage Theater asked the New York State Supreme Court on Friday to prevent the owners of the Helen Hayes Theater, a Broadway house, from scuttling a $25 million deal under which Second Stage would buy the Hayes.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway company Second Stage Theater asked the New York State Supreme Court on Friday to prevent the owners of the Helen Hayes Theater, a Broadway house, from scuttling a $25 million deal under which Second Stage would buy the Hayes. In a legal filing, Carole Rothman, the artistic director of Second Stage, argued that the owners were trying to get a higher price, given that the theater’s value has probably grown since the deal was negotiated in 2007, but then faced multiple delays.

headline: The First Victims of the First Crusade
keywords: ['Crusades (Christianity)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Terrorism', 'Religion and Belief', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle Ages (Historical Period)', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: A bloody story of medieval violence against Jews in the name of the Christian god.
lead_paragraph: THE first victims of the First Crusade, inspired in 1096 by the supposedly sacred mission of retaking Jerusalem from Muslims, were European Jews. Anyone who considers it religiously and politically transgressive to compare the behavior of medieval Christian soldiers to modern Islamic terrorism might find it enlightening to read this bloody story, as told in both Hebrew and Christian chronicles.

abstract: The troupe is also presenting works by nine choreographers as part of its season at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In its season at the Joyce Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company is presenting works by nine choreographers other than its founder, most of them acquired over the last two years. Next to this increasingly varied repertory, Graham’s work can stand out as drearily dated or intensely urgent. The mind jumps between asking, “Why does this still exist?” and “Can this please never go away?”

lead_paragraph: The ratio of laughs to eye rolls runs about three to one in the whimsical romantic comedy “Love/Sick.” A pessimist would say, that’s a lot of eye rolls. An optimist would say, it’s just a play, shut up and stop keeping score.

headline: Inside T’s Spring Women’s Fashion Issue
abstract: Our latest issue, in the New York Times on Sunday, celebrates the free thinkers whose distinct visions shape our culture today.
lead_paragraph: T’s spring women’s fashion issue celebrates the free thinkers whose distinct visions shape our culture today. On the cover is Bjork, whose genre-bending songs and mastery of design, technology and visuals have been pushing music forward for the past three decades, and who is being honored with her first retrospective at MoMA next month. We pay a visit to Sharjah, where the progressive sheikh’s daughter, Hoor Al Qasimi, has inherited — and subsequently boosted the profile of — a humble but growing art expo with some serious indie cred. Stateside, we take a closer look at Philip Johnson’s iconic Glass House, which may be the late architect’s greatest achievement (even if it’s not quite right to call it his home). And in the never-dull French capital, where politicians have been known to air their laundry for all to see, Liesl Schillinger spins a true-life tale of sex, lies and presidents truly befitting the City of Light. Elsewhere, Cathy Horyn assesses the promise and perils of a post-trend fashion world; a pair of authors and a visual artist spill secrets from their diaries; a writer with a rare skin condition that keeps her isolated from the outside world sheds light on her life in the darkness; the talented and at-times controversial French-Canadian filmmaker Xavier Dolan sets his sights on Hollywood; and the prolific makeup artist Pat McGrath gets a close-up of her own in By the Numbers. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Argentine Debt Dispute Remains Murky Even as London Court Sheds Some Light
abstract: A judge rules that $257 million set aside to pay Argentine bonds is governed by English law. But the judge did not rule that money could pass to the bondholders.
lead_paragraph: A stalemate in the bitter dispute over Argentina’s bonds looks set to drag on, even after a ruling on Friday in an English court gave one side a small victory.

headline: Drake and Kanye West: Proven Paths to Stardom
abstract: The rapper Drake, who has released his new mixtape, “If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late,” has built his career on Kanye Westian principles.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West’s debut album, “The College Dropout,” ends with a rambling recitation, “Last Call.” In it, he recalls the conspicuous consumption of his younger years: “Get a Pelle Pelle off layaway, get some Jordans or something/Or get a TechnoMarine, that’s what we wore back then.”

headline: Review: Joan Shelley Offers Celtic-Tinged Melodies
abstract: Ms. Shelley, whose new album is “Electric Ursa,” sings with the centered clarity of a mountain balladeer.
lead_paragraph: Stars shine overhead, and rivers flow nearby in songs by Joan Shelley, who performed on Thursday night at Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Her music is folky and pastoral, with a sense of scale that makes her humble about her place in mankind and the universe, and her songs are serene but never complacent. In “Electric Ursa,” the title song of her current album (No Quarter Records), Ms. Shelley sang, “Under your stars, your earthless movement/We are only feeble humans.”

headline: What Makes a Celebrity Gaffe Stick?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'National Book Awards', 'Apologies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Daniel Handler, better known as the children’s writer Lemony Snicket, is one of the more recent celebrities to make insensitive remarks in public and seemingly come out unscathed.
lead_paragraph: At the National Book Awards last November, Daniel Handler, better known as the children’s author Lemony Snicket, bounded onstage after Jacqueline Woodson won a top prize for “Brown Girl Dreaming,” the chronicle of her family’s history from slavery to civil rights. As the applause for her award died down, Mr. Handler, the evening’s M.C., told the crowd that Ms. Woodson had once shared with him over lunch that she was allergic to watermelon.

abstract: After months of searching for a new location, Alex’s MVP Cards and Comics has found a new home in Yorkville.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not a big change guy,” said Alex Gregg, the owner of Alex’s MVP Cards and Comics. The depth of that understatement becomes clear as you get to know Mr. Gregg, who has been married for 28 years, tended bar at Elaine’s for 22 years and ran his comic store at 256 East 89th Street for 26 years.

abstract: A night out with the alt-cabaret performer included her cradling an audience member’s head in her bosom and admitting that when she was 8, she flirted with high school boys.
lead_paragraph: An encounter with Bridget Everett, for some of us at least, means acquiring a new vocabulary, terms like “meatballs,” “slingshots,” “low-riders” and “slip-and-sliders.” Turns out that in Ms. Everett’s colorful lexicon, they are synonyms for “breasts,” expressions she drops routinely in “Rock Bottom,” her wildly ribald thrice-weekly cabaret show at Joe’s Pub.

lead_paragraph: The names of most great bridge players are well known in the game. A few experts, however, fly under the radar — their talent being recognized primarily by their peers. One of those was Garey Hayden, who died on Feb. 5 in Tucson, his hometown. He was 70.

headline: Catching Up at Upholstery Store, the Bar That Got Itself a Kitchen
abstract: Upholstery Store: Food and Wine, which recently reopened in the West Village after a year of renovations, “always wanted to do something with oysters and with fish,” one of its owners said.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even the best old neighborhood haunt can use a little sprucing up. So it went with Upholstery Store: Food and Wine, once a narrow wine bar on a quiet block in the West Village, which reopened in late January, after a year of renovations, with a new food menu. “We always wanted to do something with oysters and with fish,” said Leo Schneemann, who owns the reincarnated Upholstery Store with the chef Kurt Gutenbrunner. But the bar had no kitchen.

lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Whether three young students were shot and killed in North Carolina this week in a parking dispute or, as their families believe, because they were Muslims, online commentators here and outside the Middle East say the victims’ religion makes it a hate crime.

headline: Love Is in the Air

lead_paragraph: Over the past several years, the photographer Todd Heisler has captured moments of affection in New York, everywhere from baseball stadiums to subway stations.

headline: Betsey Johnson: A Role Model, Still
abstract: For a generation of women new to both New York and adulthood, there was no more exciting designer than Ms. Johnson. Fifty years later, she maintains that sway.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, the designer Betsey Johnson — part rebel, part cheerleader — got herself from proper Connecticut to New York City, as many a respectable female adventurer was wont to do. She arrived in Manhattan by way of a 1964 Mademoiselle magazine guest editorship. (She was in good company: Joan Didion and Sylvia Plath preceded her.) But that wasn’t the New York she was searching for. She had been staying at the white-gloved Barbizon Hotel for Women, and knew there was another New York. Soon she found it: the dark new bohemia that was just then supplanting the earnest folk-singing scene of Macdougal Street. She was home.

headline: In Praise of the Cute Animal Video
abstract: Addicted to homemade videos about animals, the author knows he is not alone. Many viewers seem to connect such joys to a healing experience.
lead_paragraph: It started with the wombat. Or was it the big blackbird that for reasons unexplained, landed and loitered on a man’s guitar while he skillfully played “Blackbird” by the Beatles? Or did it start with the raccoon sitting up on its hind legs and putting its agile little paws in the mouth of a beagle to give what looked like an unusually thorough checkup?

headline: Smoke-Free Policies
abstract: Patrick Kwan, an antismoking advocate, writes that “there is no safe level of secondhand smoke exposure.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Iran: Delays Feared in Reporter’s Trial
abstract: The mother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated without publicly explained charges since July 22, said Friday that she feared new delays in his trial.
lead_paragraph: The mother of Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s Tehran correspondent, who has been incarcerated without publicly explained charges since July 22, said Friday that she feared new delays in his trial, and that the Iranian authorities had sharply curtailed prison visits from Mr. Rezaian’s Iranian wife. Mr. Rezaian was formally charged in January, even though the judiciary has not disclosed any details. His mother, Mary Rezaian, said that under Iranian law, Mr. Rezaian should be put on trial by early March, within 60 days after formal charges are set. But now, she said, “there are rumblings” that her son’s case will not be heard until after the Persian New Year holiday, which falls on March 21 and lasts for about two weeks, “so it can only be assumed his trial date might not be set before April 6.” Mrs. Rezaian, an American who lives in Turkey, made the assertions in a written commentary posted on CNN’s website. American officials and The Post have repeatedly called on Iran to release Mr. Rezaian, 38, a dual Iranian-American citizen.

lead_paragraph: Chario Antonio, 79, a longtime waiter at Dangerfield’s comedy club on First Avenue in Manhattan, loaded a stack of dishes into a small dumbwaiter behind the bar, then turned the joke on himself.

abstract: Guess what color is suddenly big on the runways.

lead_paragraph: There’s one group, at least, that won’t be happy about the designer David Hart’s new men’s wear collection, and that’s the anti-man-spreading brigade.

headline: Lagat, 40, Seeks Different Kind of Millrose Triumph
keywords: ['Track and Field', 'Millrose Games', 'Age, Chronological', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: In the Wanamaker Mile at the New York meet, a chief source of interest is whether Lagat, an eight-time winner, can post a time under 3:58.15, breaking the record for runners 40 and older.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Lagat, who has won the Millrose Games’ signature Wanamaker Mile a record eight times, will probably finish toward the back when the race is contested Saturday at the 168th Street Armory. But he has his sights set on another significant accomplishment.

headline: What Happened to the Big Armchairs in Grand Central Terminal?
abstract: The disappearance of popular furniture from the dining concourse Grand Central Terminal is explained, and a question about tugboats is answered.
lead_paragraph: Q. I live near the Throgs Neck Bridge. I watch the container ships passing under on a regular basis. They all have a tugboat either pulling or pushing them. How is the decision made to push or pull?

headline: Multicolored Snow in Russia? No Worries, Officials Say
abstract: In Chelyabinsk, which was hit by a meteor in 2013, snow on the ground turned blue. But residents were reassured that there was no cause for alarm.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In some places, say New York, the panic over snow often begins as soon as there is a forecast for it. In Russia, where it is a bit more familiar, there is typically no fear, unless the snow on the ground happens to be blue, as it was in Chelyabinsk this week, or orange, as it was earlier this month in Saratov on the Volga River.

headline: At Brooklyn Police Station, Using Inmates’ Video (and Pizza) to Prevent Youth Crime
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Convicted killers from Sing Sing, taking an emotional approach, urge viewers to stay away from guns in a film that city departments are showing to teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Instead of the evening tour of officers gathering in the muster room of the 73rd Precinct station house in Brownsville, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, a group of 10 teenagers slumped on folding chairs, joking and fidgeting as lights were dimmed for a video.

headline: A New Fix for Obamacare

abstract: What to do if the Supreme Court rejects the law’s subsidies.
lead_paragraph: EARLY next month the Supreme Court will hear arguments in King v. Burwell, the latest significant legal challenge to the Affordable Care Act. The petitioners argue that under the statute, the federal government is not allowed to provide health insurance subsidies in the 37 states that have either declined or failed to establish their own exchanges.

headline: Banana Republic Arrives at Fashion Week
abstract: Marissa Webb has been charged with refreshing the Banana Republic brand. She’ll bring her line to New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Webb, flanked backstage this week by assistants, stylists and a constant stream of admirers, has a lot riding on her shoulders at New York Fashion Week. There is her own designer label to manage, and then there is Banana Republic, set to make its Fashion Week debut this weekend.

headline: Tapas for a Winter Break
abstract: At times, the inexperience of two first-time restaurant owners shows at Xunta Tapas España in Caldwell, but so does their passion for the food of the Galicia region of Spain.
lead_paragraph: I first ate at Xunta Tapas España in Caldwell on a bleak day in January. It was the same day I had come to the realization that hibernating bears were onto something.

headline: Taking Risks in Love
abstract: Put down the phone and treat romance as if it were a start-up.
lead_paragraph: SHE was 25. I was 24. We spent only a couple of days together and shared no language in common. But when I returned to the United States from that European music festival, I announced to my parents that I had met my future wife.

headline: Gary Owens, Droll Announcer on ‘Laugh-In,’ Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Owens, who was a disc jockey and writer as well, also voiced characters in thousands of cartoon broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: Gary Owens, a television and radio announcer best known as the droll, deadpan voice of “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

abstract: All sorts of things can push crime statistics this way or that for brief periods: crime-busting strategies by the police, bursts of violence by gangs and sheer coincidence.
lead_paragraph: Police commanders are almost afraid to mention it. One said on Friday that he was too superstitious to talk about the string of days without a killing in New York City.

lead_paragraph: Superheroes wage some of their deadliest fights on the big screen.

lead_paragraph: When Senator James Inhofe took the floor of the Senate on Wednesday to argue for arming the Ukrainian military, he brought with him what he called indisputable proof of Moscow’s support for the separatists in eastern Ukraine — a poster with three large photographs of “Russian tanks entering Ukrainian territory.”

lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. may be a tall man’s league, but in the slam dunk contest, the taller you are, the harder it is win.

lead_paragraph: A bus driver with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was arrested and charged with failing to yield after his bus struck a 15-year-old girl on Friday, severely injuring her leg, officials said.

abstract: Officials in Arizona are battling over control of the Board of Education and the state’s schools, just one example of an increasingly fractious landscape of state education politics.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Diane M. Douglas, a Republican, was elected state schools superintendent in Arizona after vowing to repeal the Common Core, a set of reading and math standards intended to guide teachers from kindergarten through high school graduation.

headline: Scott Walker Needs an Eraser
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The governor of Wisconsin had a teaching moment after stepping into the spotlight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the big star in the race for the Republican presidential nomination has been Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin. He gave a rip-roaring speech at a conservative confab in Iowa last month, and it’s been his moment ever since.

headline: A Suburban Bistro Born of an East Side Legend: P. J. Clarke’s in Woodbury
abstract: The famous East Side Manhattan saloon P. J. Clarke’s now has a number of branches, and the one in Woodbury, on Long Island, opened in December.
lead_paragraph: Early on in James Salter’s recent novel “All That Is,” the hero, Philip Bowman, meets two women in an East Side Manhattan bar. “I was thinking of going over to Clarke’s,” he tells them. He is, of course, referring to P. J. Clarke’s, the 130-year-old saloon at Third Avenue and 55th Street. Bowman, recently back from the war in the Pacific and newly minted as an editor at a major publishing house, is meant to symbolize the romance and optimism of the “Greatest Generation.” That his preferred watering hole is P. J. Clarke’s is testimony to the author’s keen eye for detail. For a character like Bowman, there would be no other bar.

headline: Assia Djebar, Novelist Who Wrote About Oppression of Arab Women, Dies at 78
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Arabs']
abstract: Ms. Djebar, frequently mentioned as a contender for the Nobel Prize in Literature, often focused on gender inequality.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Assia Djebar, an Algerian-born writer and filmmaker whose widely admired work explored the plight of women in the male-centric Arab world, died here on Feb. 7. She was 78.

headline: Ending Secrecy on Police Misconduct
abstract: It’s way past time to rescind a uniquely strict New York State disclosure law.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of unarmed civilians like Eric Garner in New York City and Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., led to demands for greater transparency in the workings of police forces all over the country. The need for more openness is especially pressing in New York, where a uniquely strict disclosure law has shielded from public view the records of individual officers, even those who have committed crimes.

headline: A Shopper’s Guide to Asian Treasures
abstract: From fabrics to gems, experts offer advice on the one thing your should choose from a variety of destinations in Asia.
lead_paragraph: The best things in life may be free — if the lyrics from the 1927 musical “Good News” are to be believed — but few people can resist the siren song of shopping.

headline: New Hotels in Asia for Surf and Sand
abstract: Resorts that offer various room styles and beach-front activities in China, Indonesia, Thailand and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Whether your idea of going coastal involves surf spray intensity, paddleboard calm or some gently lapping middle ground, this new crop of Asian hotels and resorts celebrates the sea in a range of moods. Room styles vary too, from dwelling above coral heads to fronting an industrial wharf. (Dollars are accepted at these properties unless otherwise noted.)

headline: Discovering Lodge Hospitality in New Zealand
abstract: Julian Robertson, a luxury hotel proprietor, talks about building lodges in the country and what makes a great hotel stay.
lead_paragraph: As the co-founder, chairman and chief executive of the $30 billion investment firm Tiger Management L.L.C., Julian Robertson, 82, has achieved a high profile in the world of finance. His role as a luxury hotel proprietor, however, has been more under-the-radar.

headline: County Coroner in Washington Plans Inquest Amid Furor Over Police Killing
abstract: The shooting of the orchard laborer in Pasco, who the police say threw rocks at officers, has stirred outrage among the Hispanic population in southeastern Washington.
lead_paragraph: The coroner in Franklin County, Wash., plans to order an inquest into the killing of a Mexican-born orchard laborer who, a cellphone video shows, was fleeing police officers and was then shot by them from what appeared to be no more than 20 feet away as he turned toward them with his hands held out in front.

headline: A War on Workers in Illinois
abstract: Ultimately, all working people will suffer if unions are not able to assess “fair share” fees.
lead_paragraph: As one of his first official acts, the new Republican governor of Illinois, Bruce Rauner, issued an executive order this week that would weaken state unions by barring them from assessing fees on some of the workers they represent in collective bargaining. Worse, the damage from the order could reach far beyond Illinois.

headline: Basis for Case in Brooklyn Police Shooting: No Threat Led Officer to Fire
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The indictment of Officer Peter Liang, who killed an unarmed man, differs from other police shootings because he did not claim he was acting against a threat and therefore can’t claim he was using legitimate force.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, the police shooting of an unarmed man in a housing project stairwell in Brooklyn seemed like a freakish accident.

headline: An Uzbek Wave, ‘Made for Wrestling’
abstract: At least nine high schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens have Uzbek immigrants on their wrestling squads.
lead_paragraph: At least nine high schools in Brooklyn and one in Queens have Uzbek immigrants on their wrestling squads.

lead_paragraph: A former Army sergeant with the nickname Rambo pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to murder a federal drug agent and another man, in what the government has said was his post-military role as a contract killer.

headline: Sport Works to Stay Relevant in Changing N.C.A.A.
abstract: Collegiate sports like swimming that do not generate revenue are left feeling vulnerable as profitable programs like football and basketball take a bigger share of the profits created by blockbuster television contracts.
lead_paragraph: Michael Phelps is an outlier for reasons beyond his record haul of 22 Olympic medals. On the United States national team, he stands apart as one of the few swimmers not to use college as a stepladder to scale the world rankings. Of the 49 athletes who represented the United States in swimming at the London Olympics, only Phelps and the freestyler Chloe Sutton had pasts or futures, or both, not tied to N.C.A.A participation.

headline: An Infamous Gap
abstract: A satisfying Saturday puzzle by David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I need to apologize to David Steinberg for saying in the past that the fill in his puzzles makes him seem older than his years.

headline: Craft Beer in an Unlikely Location: At the DeCicco’s Grocery Store in Armonk
abstract: It is easy to forget you are in a grocery store when you are at the bar on the second level of DeCicco’s in Armonk.
lead_paragraph: On the steps leading to the second level of the DeCicco’s grocery store in Armonk are these names:

headline: The Double All-Nighter for Matisse
abstract: Crowds thronged for a last chance to see a master’s works at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: It made perfect sense: Henri Matisse did so much of his cutout art in the restless dead of night, why not view it in the exhibit’s unusual all-night visitation hours offered last weekend at the Museum of Modern Art?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 13, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Elevating the Ubiquitous
abstract: With unexpected ingredients and preparations, Artisanal Burger Company, in Manchester, puts a twist on usual pub food.
lead_paragraph: In Connecticut there’s no better culinary success story than that of Dorjan Puka, a self-taught chef who immigrated from Albania at 23 after winning a green-card lottery, labored a dozen years in various restaurants, then opened two superb places of his own, Treva and À Vert Brasserie, in West Hartford. Now Mr. Puka has taken his act east of the river, with the Artisanal Burger Company, just off the highway in Manchester’s Buckland Hills.

headline: Dr. Marcy’s March
abstract: How the diary of a Union doctor foretold the difficulties of post-Civil War reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: As January 1865 drew to a close, Lt. Gen. William T. Sherman readied his army, then camped around Savannah, Ga., to march north into South Carolina. Some 60,000 men strong, Sherman’s troops sensed the Confederacy’s flagging will. Four years of carnage had cost Southerners dearly, and Sherman’s campaign across Georgia had dealt the Confederacy a devastating blow. With the Army of Northern Virginia crouched in defensive positions around Richmond and Confederates scrambling to defend the Palmetto State, Sherman’s men prepared to push on, determined to bring the long and bloody war to an end.

headline: High School Recruits Think Twice About Signing Letters of Intent
abstract: Recruits who sign the letters sometimes find, to their dismay, that the coaches most active in recruiting them have moved on to other jobs.
lead_paragraph: MONTEZUMA, Ga. — In a crowded gymnasium at Macon County High School on Feb. 4, Roquan Smith, one of the top high school linebackers in the country, picked up a U.C.L.A. hat and put it on his head, signaling his intention to play for the Bruins.

headline: Braving the Freezing Temperatures for Love, Religion and Chocolate Sales
abstract: On Friday, temperatures hovered in the teens, and on Sunday it could get as low as 2 degrees with a wind chill factor as low as minus 20.
lead_paragraph: One hundred couples plan to get married on the 86th floor of the Empire State Building on Saturday. Outside.

headline: Suspension Rules Altered in New York City’s Revision of School Discipline Code
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration on Friday announced long-awaited revisions to school discipline policies, including new suspension procedures.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration on Friday announced changes to the discipline code that governs New York City’s public schools, an attempt to further rein in some of the most severe punishments while also keeping schools safe.

headline: Canada: Attack Plot Is Foiled, Police Say
abstract: The police said Friday that they had disrupted a plot by four people to kill a “large number of individual citizens” in the Halifax area of Nova Scotia.
lead_paragraph: The police said Friday that they had disrupted a plot by four people to kill a “large number of individual citizens” in the Halifax area of Nova Scotia. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the Halifax police offered few specifics about the planned attack except to say that its two leaders also planned to commit suicide at the conclusion of their armed assault, which was scheduled for Saturday. “There’s nothing in the investigation to classify it as a terrorist attack or terrorist incident,” said Assistant Commissioner Brian F. Brennan, the commanding officer for the mounted police in Nova Scotia. He said the plotters were motivated by “some beliefs,” which he declined to identify. A 23-year-old woman from Geneva, Ill., was arrested at the Halifax airport along with a 20-year-old man from Nova Scotia. A 17-year-old man was arrested separately, and a fourth man, 19, was found dead in a house.
