lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Selling Cure for Being Gay Found Illegal in New Jersey
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Ruling in a high-profile lawsuit, a State Superior Court judge said that those selling the idea that homosexuality was a curable mental disorder were engaged in consumer fraud.
lead_paragraph: The plaintiffs described the methods used by the counseling group in Jersey City from which they had sought help: One of them, a young man hoping to overcome his attraction to other men, said he had been told to grab a tennis racket, scream and beat an effigy of his mother as if killing her.

headline: De Blasio Chief of Staff to Leave City Hall for U.N. Job
abstract: Laura Santucci recently was charged with New York’s failed bid to host the Democratic National Convention in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio is set to lose another senior member of his inner circle as his administration reorganizes for its second year.

headline: At Vassar College, Canvases So Big They Are Seldom Seen
abstract: An exhibition includes 19 works from the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center’s permanent collection, many of which have rarely been displayed because of their size.
lead_paragraph: Back and forth, side to side — visitors to “XL: Large-Scale Paintings From the Permanent Collection,” at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, may find themselves moving around while viewing each of the works on display. That’s because many of the paintings are so vast that it can be hard to grasp their entirety from a single vantage point.

headline: When the Islanders Call, a Gritty Fourth-Line Wing Delivers
abstract: Casey Cizikas, Matt Martin and Colin McDonald all paid their dues in the American Hockey League, and they now form a hard-working and effective line for the Islanders.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Missing Kyle Okposo on their top line and scuffling to manufacture goals, the Islanders continue to win with the grit and determination embodied by their fourth line of center Casey Cizikas and wings Matt Martin and Colin McDonald.

headline: Nothing New Here: Anthony Endures Meaningless Loss
abstract: With Carmelo Anthony watching as an assistant coach, the East team fell to the West in the N.B.A. All-Star Celebrity Game at Madison Square Garden despite an M.V.P. performance from Kevin Hart.
lead_paragraph: Robert Pera was among the first participants to arrive at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, and he wore the determined look of a welder.

headline: In Huntington, an Exhibition of Pioneering Photography Through the Ages
abstract: An exhibition of 54 works by 37 photographers at the Heckscher Museum of Art is a good reminder that experimental photography did not begin in the age of the digital camera.
lead_paragraph: “Modern Alchemy,” a small gem of an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, is a good reminder that experimental photography did not begin in the age of the digital camera, although technology has certainly helped it evolve. A selection of diverse images, accompanied by thorough explanations of how various photographers worked, starting with Man Ray in the 1930s, supports this idea.

headline: A Celebrity Facialist’s Recipe for Remedying Winter Skin
abstract: Joanna Vargas, who prepped Julianne Moore and Maggie Gyllenhaal for the Golden Globes this weekend, shares at-home applications to combat dryness.
lead_paragraph: On the red carpet this weekend, the New York-based stars Julianne Moore and Maggie Gyllenhaal appeared untouched by winter as they arrived at the 2015 Golden Globe Awards. Their skin was radiant, almost dewy — not dry like most faces in Manhattan these days. And not coincidentally, they were each prepped for the evening by the celebrity facialist Joanna Vargas, who also counts Naomi Watts as a regular client. The expert, who just launched her newest anti-aging solution — the Forever Facial ($700), designed to improve the skin’s elasticity through the use of heat and radio waves (“they push your collagen fibers back together again and trigger collagen production,” she explains) — says the secret to great skin, no matter the time of year, is a facial once a month. “Nothing you do at home can replace a professional exfoliation, extraction and attention,” she says.

headline: A Wedding Weekend and a Family Crisis
abstract: Money and race issues simmer amid the turmoil in Danai Gurira’s latest play, “Familiar,” in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: Every wedding weekend needs a family crisis, and the one in Danai Gurira’s “Familiar” is the arrival of an eccentric aunt from Zimbabwe with dollar signs in her eyes. But this play, having its world premiere at Yale Repertory Theater, already has other sources of tension: The bride is a 34-year-old virgin, and the groom, marrying into a Zimbabwean family, is white.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 14, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I had those normal jitters you have when you are going to say your vows. All of that was just crushed.”

headline: A Game of Young Standouts Favors Dunks Over Defense

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4 P.M. (TBS) UN-VALENTINE’S DAY MARATHON Seven hours of disastrous dates, screwball romances and awkward moments come just in time for those looking to counter all the saccharine of Valentine’s Day. The marathon begins with four episodes of “Friends,” including the first date Rachel (Jennifer Aniston) had with Ross (David Schwimmer). In “Seinfeld,” beginning at 6 p.m., four episodes bring back some of Jerry’s most memorable girlfriends — including “Man Hands” and the one whose name he can’t remember. And major breakthroughs in science and love are the highlights of six episodes of “The Big Bang Theory,” beginning at 8 p.m.

headline: The Coming Silly Season: Baseball’s 2015 Calendar of the Absurd

We’ll have plenty of time for serious predictions — Could the Mets have more wins than the Yankees? Could the Giants win the title in an odd-numbered year? — but here’s a look at a calendar of the absurd:

headline: His Eyes Fixed Straight Ahead, Tony Stewart Plans Resurgence After Two Trying Years
abstract: Those who know Stewart say he is getting back to his old, playful self after a struggle to recover from a broken leg and a crash in which he struck and killed a young driver at a dirt-track race.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months after badly breaking his right leg in a crash, Tony Stewart is still not fully healed. He has had four operations so far — the latest on Dec. 1 to replace a rod in the leg — and another is planned after this season. It will be the third straight Sprint Cup season in which Stewart is not physically 100 percent.

headline: The Epidemic of Facelessness

abstract: The anonymous communication social media creates both provokes and mitigates our inherent capacity for monstrosity.
lead_paragraph: A PART-TIME delivery driver named Peter Nunn was recently sentenced to 18 weeks in a British prison for tweeting and retweeting violent messages to Stella Creasy, a member of Parliament. He never saw his victim but the consequences of his virtual crime were real enough. In a statement, Ms. Creasy described fears for her physical safety, going so far as to install a panic button in her home. Mr. Nunn has been physically separated from the rest of society for posting abusive words on a social media site.

headline: The Lies Heard Round the World
keywords: ['Lying', 'Ebola Virus', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Last year was a banner year for falsehoods from presidents, prime ministers and pundits.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — LYING may be an age-old part of politics, but it’s becoming easier to spot the fibs, fictions and falsehoods. A growing army of fact-checkers around the world is busy debunking falsehoods from presidents, prime ministers and pundits — and if their results are indicative, 2014 was a banner year. Some of the claims were so absurd that fact-checking groups honored them with awards, like Australia’s Golden Zombie and Italy’s Insane Whopper of the Year.

headline: Wildlife Slaughter Goes Unabated
abstract: A much larger budget is needed to stem the illicit trade in rhino horn, ivory and other prized animal parts.
lead_paragraph: As the world’s booming black market for body parts from endangered species continues to elude effective policing, rhinoceros deaths quadrupled in four years to the 1,215 killed by African smugglers in 2014. These magnificent animals were slaughtered so that urbanites in places like China and Vietnam can take a dose of powdered rhino horn, which fetches tens of thousands of dollars a pound as a luxury cure for hangovers.

headline: What Libya’s Unraveling Means
abstract: The growth and radicalization of Islamist groups raise the possibility that large parts of Libya could become a satellite of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Largely overshadowed by the crises in Syria, Iraq and Ukraine, Libya’s unraveling has received comparatively little attention over the past few months. As this oil-rich nation veers toward complete chaos, world leaders would be wise to redouble efforts led by the United Nations to broker a power-sharing deal among warring factions.

headline: Too Much Prayer in Politics
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Faith should be inspiration, not instructions for governing or a legislative manual.
lead_paragraph: GOD had a busy week. Alabama alone was a heavy lift, what with all those God invocations by state leaders trying to cast out the demon of gay marriage, then London called as well. Scott Walker was on a trip there, and he tugged God into the picture when he was asked about evolution and declined to answer, as if embracing it would be a heathen outrage.

headline: The Caligulan Thrill
abstract: The success of “Fifty Shades of Grey” is about more than cuffs and whips. E.L. James’s franchise sets off questions about egalitarianism and sexual revolution.
lead_paragraph: IN a society where almost every cultural phenomenon ends up interpreted through an ideological lens, the success de scandale of “Fifty Shades of Grey” — the books, the movie, the branded cuffs and whips — has left culture warriors a little bit confused. Is this another transgressive breakthrough — the latest blow to whatever remains of traditional morality, the mainstreaming of a lifestyle long locked away from view? Or is the now-famous story, with its alpha male gazillionaire and his punished female prize, actually a reactionary fairy tale, encouraging submission to the latest version of the patriarchy?

headline: Unpaid, Unarmed Lifesavers in Syria

abstract: Side by side with the worst of humanity you often see the best. In Syria, the best is an extraordinary group called the White Helmets.

headline: Did a Text Kill My Brother?
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: At the murky intersection of texting, driving and the law.
lead_paragraph: ONE Wednesday afternoon in 2013, I received a frantic call. My older brother Bob had been in an accident. He had been babysitting for two of his granddaughters until just after lunch. Then, sensing it was one of the final bursts of summer, he put on his helmet, hopped on his 2007 Harley and headed down lazy back roads toward the New Jersey shore.

headline: Gunman Believed to Be Behind 2 Copenhagen Attacks Is Fatally Shot, Police Say
abstract: The police said Sunday they had shot a suspect who killed a man at a free-speech event in Copenhagen and another man outside a synagogue.

headline: In Spanish Abuse Scandal, a More Open Vatican
abstract: The case, which includes allegations of a sex ring and a cover-up involving as many as 10 priests, has become one of the most serious abuse scandals to emerge under Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: GRANADA, Spain — David Ramírez Castillo first met his parish priest, the Rev. Román Martínez, as a 7-year-old catechism student. Later, he became one of his altar boys. Step by step, Mr. Ramírez says, the priest convinced him that to deepen his faith he should spend more time with him and the other clergy members.

headline: At North Carolina, Throwing Javelins and Running for Office
abstract: Houston Summers, a former pro baseball player who hopes to become student body president and a doctor, said sports helped him cope with chaos.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Time is precious for Houston Summers, a 27-year-old junior at North Carolina, and not just because he is majoring in psychology, with two minors, in the hopes of attending medical school. Summers, a former professional baseball player, is now a walk-on javelin thrower on the track team, and he is also trying to become the student body president.

headline: After a Nap, Mikaela Shiffrin Plods, Then Bursts to a Slalom Repeat
abstract: Shiffrin, 19, won her second world championship in two tries and now has three major ski championship before her 20th birthday.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Early this winter, Mikaela Shiffrin was beaten three times at her best event, the slalom. The youngest Olympic champion in the history of the event, Shiffrin was not even making it to the podium.

headline: Greece’s Excess Burden
abstract: The troika’s demands are much more onerous than they seem.
lead_paragraph: What’s the state of the Greek crisis? I have no idea, or at any rate no idea beyond what any diligent reader of press reports might glean. I do, however, have a pretty good idea of what Greece is asking for on the fiscal side, and it might be useful to talk about the arithmetic behind that position.

headline: Roger Goodell Looks to the Future, but Troubles Cloud the View
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell has tried to turn the page on 2014, but the problems he faces — from off-field violence to team malfeasance — are stubborn and complicated.
lead_paragraph: During his address last month on the state of the league, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell appeared eager to turn the page on 2014, a year when he was under siege for mishandling several domestic violence cases and for seemingly every other misstep that befell the league.

headline: Koos van den Akker Dies at 75; Designed Bill Cosby’s Vivid Sweaters
abstract: The Dutch-born designer was called the “master of couture collage” for his creations, most notably the sweaters popularized by Bill Cosby on his long-running sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Koos van den Akker, a Dutch-born fashion designer with a celebrity clientele who was called the “master of couture collage” for his prismatic creations, notably the bold sweaters popularized by Bill Cosby on his long-running sitcom, died on Feb. 3 in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Military and ISIS Clash Over Iraqi Town Near a Base Housing U.S. Troops
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Iraqi soldiers and militants of the Islamic State group clashed again over the weekend in a Iraqi town that has changed hands several times near a military base where American troops are providing training.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi soldiers and militants of the Islamic State group clashed again over the weekend in a western Iraqi town that has changed hands several times in skirmishes near a military base where American troops are training Iraqi soldiers.

headline: Experiencing the Alpine World Ski Championships From Above
abstract: A longtime skiing reporter tried an unfamiliar perspective, from atop the course, at the world championships in Beaver Creek, Colo.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — The first ski race I covered was the Olympic women’s downhill in Meribel, France, in 1992, and I watched it from the finish area amid the cheers, the groans and the rubbing shoulders in the close-quarter mixed zone.

headline: Tim Duncan Is a Five-Time Champion. Enough Said.
abstract: The Spurs’ Duncan is perhaps the least celebrated all-timer in the history of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Tim Duncan did not sound overjoyed to be in New York for his 15th N.B.A. All-Star weekend, or maybe it was more the company he was forced to keep late Friday morning.

headline: James L. Dolan, a Consummate 1 Percenter
abstract: The owner of the Knicks has offered no apologies for his caustic email reply to a fan.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver paused in preparations for the corporate branding orgy that is his league’s All-Star Game and tossed a spray of a bouquet at James L. Dolan, the owner of the Knicks.

abstract: The latest women’s collection from Alexander Wang at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the live stream.]

headline: Mara Hoffman’s Messy and Majestic Braids
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: a goddesslike update to the fishtail braid.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: From Diabelli, a Variety of Variations
abstract: Pianists from the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University will perform seldom-heard pieces by composers including Schubert, Czerny and Liszt at Weill Recital Hall.
lead_paragraph: Two adventurous smaller events, both on Tuesday, look especially intriguing this week. One explores the context of Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations, which he composed after the publisher Anton Diabelli sent a little waltz he had written to the leading composers of the Austrian empire, asking them each to write a variation, with the idea of publishing the entire set. Beethoven turned out a stand-alone colossus of a piece.

headline: Fresh Cut Orchestra, a Jazz Band That’s Hard to Define
abstract: The group will celebrate the release of its first record, “From the Vine,” at Rockwood Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Fresh Cut Orchestra is a new young 10-piece Philadelphia-jazz municipality, a little hard to define and very much worth looking into. It’s a well-drilled band with three different leaders: the trumpeter Josh Lawrence, the bassist Jason Fraticelli and the drummer Anwar Marshall. (You might know them from records or bands led by Orrin Evans, Taylor McFerrin, Erykah Badu and Dave Douglas).

headline: Films by Jessie Maple in Lincoln Center Series
abstract: Ms. Maple’s two features are part of the center’s series “Tell It Like It Is: Black Independents in New York, 1968-1986.”
lead_paragraph: The work of Jessie Maple, a filmmaker and the first African-American woman to join New York’s camera operators union in 1975, will be celebrated on Monday with the program “An Evening With Jessie Maple” at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center (144 West 65th Street). Ms. Maple, who wrote a book, “How to Become a Union Camerawoman,” about her life and hard-fought battle to join the union, directed two narrative features.

headline: ‘Havana Rakatan’ at City Center Offers a History of Cuba
abstract: A rhythmically rich production condenses 500 years of Cuban musical history into two hours.
lead_paragraph: City Center begins its three-week festival of Spanish and Latin American dance, A Bailar, with “Havana Rakatan,” a lively, rhythmically rich production that condenses 500 years of Cuban musical history into two hours. The show was bound for New York before the United States and Cuba renewed diplomatic ties, but that news should only bolster its feel-good spirit, as embodied by the exceptional dancers of Ballet Rakatan and the live music of the Cuban son band Turquino. Before Wednesday’s performance, a panel of Cuban and Cuban-American artists — including Eduardo Vilaro, the artistic director of Ballet Hispanico — will discuss the countries’ shifting political and cultural relations.

headline: ‘Vikings’ on the History Channel Returns With a New King
abstract: The well-acted epic about Vikings, their lusts and their power struggles, resembles a PG-13 “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: The History channel remains a grab bag where you can find quirky reality shows like “Down East Dickering,” decent mini-series like last year’s “Houdini,” and assorted schedule-fillers about extraterrestrials and people who live in swamps. Amid this hodgepodge, “Vikings,” a scripted series that begins its third season on Thursday night, has emerged as an anchor.

lead_paragraph: New York

abstract: During his father’s terms as vice president and president, Jeb Bush, then a businessman and emerging Florida politician, used his White House connections to make special requests and recommend allies for appointments.
lead_paragraph: During his father’s terms as vice president and president, Jeb Bush, then a businessman and emerging Florida politician, used his White House connections to make special requests and recommend allies for appointments.

headline: As Dynasty’s Son, Jeb Bush Used His Connections Freely
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For the 12 years that George Bush held national elective office, Jeb Bush used his unique access to seek favors and make suggestions, helping bolster his own nascent career.
lead_paragraph: The stream of requests to the White House from Jeb Bush, a young but well-connected Republican leader in South Florida, ranged from the weighty and urgent to the parochial and mundane.

headline: Split Ends
abstract: Ellen Leuschner and Jeff Chen entertain us and then split.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — How do you feel when your crossword answers go wandering off in different directions? Are you one of those solvers who likes their answers either Across or Down, but never the twain shall meet? You’re out of luck today, my friends.

headline: Yale Restricts a Fraternity After Sexual Misconduct
abstract: The university has banned Sigma Alpha Epsilon from conducting on-campus activities until August 2016 after learning about inappropriate remarks made at an initiation ceremony.
lead_paragraph: A Yale fraternity has been banned from conducting on-campus activities until August 2016 as punishment for violating the university’s sexual misconduct policy at an initiation ceremony last year and then trying to impede the resulting investigation, the university announced this week.

headline: Autopsy Cites Cancer as Cause in Death of David Carr, Times Reporter
abstract: Mr. Carr had lung cancer and he died of complications from the disease, according to the results of an autopsy released on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: David Carr, the New York Times media columnist who died unexpectedly Thursday night, had lung cancer, and died of complications from the disease, according to the results of an autopsy released Saturday evening.

headline: Heavy-Metal Hair and Makeup at Alexander Wang
abstract: Intentionally lank hair and dark undereye circles complemented a beautifully gothic, gloomy collection.
lead_paragraph: What a dynamic duo the makeup artist Diane Kendal and the hairstylist Guido Palau made this evening at Alexander Wang’s fall 2015 show. Inspired by heavy metal, they together created a beautifully gothic and gloomy look. “I’m keeping the skin very pale, with a dark brown and gray greasy feel on the eye,” Kendal explained. With a clean brush, she dragged the eye makeup (Aigle Noir Velvet Shadow Stick, Transvaal Eye Paint, Bellissima Duo Eyeshadow and Vientiane Matte Multiple, all by Nars) downward, to create the effect of “a hint of dark circle,” as Kendal put it, around the models’ eyes.

headline: India Blocked an Activist From Traveling to Britain
abstract: A Greenpeace India activist was stopped from boarding a flight to Britain in January, where she was scheduled to brief members of Parliament on the effect of mining on indigenous communities in central India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Ministry of Home Affairs has said it prevented a Greenpeace India activist from boarding a flight to Britain in January, where she was scheduled to brief members of Parliament on the effect of mining on indigenous communities in central India, because her visit was “prejudicial to the national interest” and would hurt India’s image abroad.

headline: Threatened Smelt Touches Off Battles in California’s Endless Water Wars
keywords: ['Water', 'Drought', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Rivers']
abstract: Drought and the pumping of water have depleted the delta smelt and the delicate ecosystem they inhabit, prompting limits on the amount of water sent to farmers and cities.
lead_paragraph: RIO VISTA, Calif. — On a boat in the heart of California’s biggest river delta, a researcher pored over a sample of murky, weed-infested water, looking for a rare fish about the size of a finger. Spotting one, he shouted in triumph — then measured it and quickly tossed it overboard.

headline: Sexual Abuse Allegations Against Imam Stir Rifts in Insular Illinois Community
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Sexual abuse allegations and a planned lawsuit against Mohammad Abdullah Saleem in Elgin have divided segments of the imam’s followers and those in the community who reject the idea that the case should be handled privately.
lead_paragraph: ELGIN, Ill. — She ordinarily did not wear a veil. But it was required at the Islamic school where she worked, and she remembers being surprised when the head of the school, a conservative imam, suggested that she remove it.

headline: A Community Mediator
abstract: Omer Mozaffar, an Islamic scholar in Chicago, acted as a mediator last year when a woman accused a prominent local imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Omer Mozaffar, an Islamic scholar in Chicago, acted as a mediator last year when a woman accused a prominent local imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, of sexual assault.

headline: Obama to Intervene in Dispute at West Coast Ports
abstract: At the president’s request, the secretary of labor will travel to California to “meet with the parties to urge them to resolve their dispute quickly at the bargaining table,” according to a White House spokesman.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Seeking an end to a protracted labor dispute that has led to costly delays in West Coast shipping, President Obama has decided to intervene, the White House announced on Saturday.

headline: Delhi’s Air Is Often More Polluted Than Beijing’s
abstract: The levels of harmful fine particulate matter, called PM2.5, are significantly higher in Delhi during the winter months than they are in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The levels of harmful fine particulate matter, called PM2.5, are significantly higher in Delhi during the winter months than they are in Beijing.

headline: Museum Rules: Talk Softly, and Carry No Selfie Stick
abstract: Institutions including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden have begun to adopt rules against this enhanced form of picture taking.
lead_paragraph: In a famous lab trial, a chimp named Sultan put two interlocking sticks together and pulled down an elusive prize, a bunch of bananas hanging just out of arm’s reach.

headline: Delhi Wakes Up to an Air Pollution Problem It Cannot Ignore
abstract: While Beijing’s air quality has generated more headlines worldwide, scientists say New Delhi’s air is often significantly worse, but only now are residents turning to surgical masks and air purifiers.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For years, this sprawling city on the Yamuna River had the dirtiest air in the world, but few who lived here seemed conscious of the problem or worried about its consequences.

headline: Raw Eggs and No Husband Since ’38 Keep Her Young at 115
abstract: Emma Morano of Italy, who has survived two world wars, says her elixir for longevity consists of eating three raw eggs a day and being single.
lead_paragraph: VERBANIA, Italy — Celebrity came late to Emma Morano. Her routine life, in fact, might have raised barely an eyebrow were it not for the fact that she’s managed to hold on to it for so long.

headline: Dikembe Mutombo and John Calipari Are Among 12 Finalists for Basketball Hall of Fame
abstract: Mutombo, a four-time N.B.A. defensive player of the year, and Calipari, a two-time college coach of the year, joined Tim Hardaway, Lisa Leslie and others on the 2015 ballot.
lead_paragraph: As famous for his wagging finger and charitable work as he was for his play on the court, Dikembe Mutombo, a four-time N.B.A. defensive player of the year, headlined a list of 12 finalists announced Saturday for induction into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

headline: G.M. Expands 2014 Recall for Power Steering Failure
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The recall affects the 2006-7 Chevrolet Malibu and Malibu Maxx and the 2006-7 Pontiac G6, a total of more than 81,000 vehicles in North America.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling more than 81,000 cars because their power steering systems could suddenly fail, making the vehicles harder to turn. The action expands a recall from last March that covered 1.3 million vehicles in the United States.

headline: Hundreds Protest Fatal Police Shooting in Washington
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: About 500 people gathered at a local park to protest the death of Antonio Zambrano-Montes, 35, who was shot by the police on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PASCO, Wash. — A protest held here Saturday over the police killing of a Mexican-born apple picker had the air of a mournful family picnic.

headline: LaMarcus Aldridge Will Replace Anthony Davis in West’s Starting Lineup
abstract: Steve Kerr, the Western Conference’s coach in Sunday’s All-Star game, opted for Aldridge instead of Kevin Durant to start in place of the injured Davis.
lead_paragraph: After recently labeling himself a “boring All-Star,” LaMarcus Aldridge can add “starter” to that moniker. He replaces the injured Anthony Davis, who just happens to be one of the most exciting young players in the N.B.A.

lead_paragraph: Bernard Lagat, in his return to the event he has owned for more than a decade, did not disappoint the local fans jammed into the 168th Street Armory’s New Balance Track & Field Center in Manhattan on Saturday.

headline: Facing the N.B.A.’s Best 3-Point Shooters, Stephen Curry Finishes First
abstract: Curry hit 13 consecutive shots, finishing with 27 points and outshooting Kyle Korver, Wesley Matthews and Klay Thompson in the 3-point contest.
lead_paragraph: In one of the best groupings of shooters to ever participate in the N.B.A.’s 3-point contest, Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors cruised to victory Saturday, at one point hitting 13 consecutive shots, much to the delight of a Brooklyn crowd that seemed to be rooting for him from the start.

headline: Allison Polland, Adam Roth
abstract: The bride is a doctor; the groom is a lawyer.

Roth and Dr. Stuart M. Roth of Columbia, Md. Cantor Daniel Neiden is to officiate at the home of the bride’s parents.

abstract: An executive at Barclays and a doctor who specializes in emergency medicine are to be joined in a commitment ceremony in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Raymond Hird and Dr. John Reed Caldwell are to affirm their partnership Sunday with a commitment ceremony at Las Caletas Hideaway Beach in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Andrew A. Hopping, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to lead the event.

lead_paragraph: Irene Beren Jefferson and Jake Sherman are to be married Sunday at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington. Rabbi David J. Saiger, the bride’s brother-in-law, is to officiate.

lead_paragraph: Khadija Hinda Ali and Fritz Emmanuel Charles were married Monday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Alisa Fuentes, a staff member in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

abstract: Beverley was more tortoise than hare, catching up to Brandon Knight of the Milwaukee Bucks in the final.
lead_paragraph: In an N.B.A. take on Aesop’s “The Tortoise and the Hare,” Patrick Beverley of the Houston Rockets proved that patience can triumph over speed as he lumbered his way to victory Saturday in the N.B.A.’s revamped skills competition.

lead_paragraph: Kelly Elizabeth Linehan and Noah Emmanuel Solomon were married Saturday at St. Jude Parish in Waltham, Mass. The Rev. Stephen J. Linehan, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

abstract: The couple was married at the Memorial Church at Harvard University.
lead_paragraph: Mary Ellen Webster Hammond and Andrew Richard Mondi were married Saturday at Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. George Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Zach LaVine, With Nod to Michael Jordan, Soars to Victory in Slam Dunk Contest
abstract: LaVine, of the Minnesota Timberwolves, was the favorite before the contest and delivered a series of creative dunks, at one point wearing Jordan’s jersey from “Space Jam.”
lead_paragraph: Showing off an ability to seemingly jump out of the building, Zach LaVine of the Minnesota Timberwolves lapped the competition Saturday night on his way to winning the N.B.A. slam dunk contest at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: Rachel Cohen Grunberger and Evan Kraig Tyroler are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Lyle A. Fishman at B’nai Israel Congregation in Rockville, Md.

abstract: The couple work in the White House. She coordinates trips for the president; he is executive director of the first lady’s Reach Higher initiative.

Aran Santana, a minister of the Missionary Churches of Christ, led a ceremony that included Catholic and Jewish wedding traditions. Colin J. Callahan, a friend of the couple, took part.

abstract: Under newly relaxed regulations governing travel to Cuba, Cuba Cruise is offering Americans seven-night trips that circumnavigate the island.
lead_paragraph: Under newly relaxed regulations governing travel to Cuba, Cuba Cruise is offering Americans seven-night trips that circumnavigate the island.

lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Up on the slalom course on Saturday afternoon, Mikaela Shiffrin was staring down the moment on home snow and winning her latest gold medal.

headline: Terror Attacks by a Native Son Rock Denmark
abstract: The police identified the suspect in Saturday’s attacks, at a cafe and near a synagogue in Copenhagen, as a 22-year-old with a violent criminal record.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — After killing a Danish film director in a Saturday afternoon attack on a Copenhagen cafe and then a Jewish night guard at a synagogue, the 22-year-old gunman responsible for Denmark’s worst burst of terrorism in decades unleashed a final fusillade outside a four-story apartment building before dawn on Sunday.

headline: Slice and Carve: The Next Wave in Computer-Aided Creativity
abstract: Laser cutters and computer-controlled milling machines are coming out of industrial workshops and planting themselves on desktops.

headline: Review: Paul McCartney Offers an Intimate Valentine’s Day Gift
abstract: Mr. McCartney performed a sudden show Saturday night ahead of a scheduled appearance Sunday on a “Saturday Night Live” special.
lead_paragraph: A holiday, a song title and a free night before a TV appearance were pretext enough for Paul McCartney to book a sudden show on Saturday night at Irving Plaza; its capacity, about 1,000, is an order of magnitude smaller than the arenas he usually headlines. The audience, he said joshingly, was “so close you can see my dental work.” On Sunday, Mr. McCartney was scheduled to perform on “Saturday Night Live’s” 40th-anniversary prime-time special. But Saturday was also Valentine’s Day, and Mr. McCartney announced, “Tonight it’s all about love.”

headline: 1915: Amputation Scheduled for Sarah Bernhardt
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The actress was scheduled to have her right leg amputated in 1915 after years of osteoarthritis.
lead_paragraph: In connection with the postponement of the operation which Mme. Sarah Bernhardt was to have undergone Sunday [Feb. 14], it is now announced that it’s a question of amputating her right leg, and the delay is occasioned because of a decision to carry out a preparatory treatment lasting about ten days. Mme. Bernhardt was lately taken from Arcachon to a private hospital in Bordeaux, where the operation was to have taken place on Sunday, but after a consultation, a postponement was thought advisable.

headline: Adopted as a Child, Now a Mother, Finally ‘Lucky’
abstract: Countless times, well-meaning friends, relatives, and acquaintances told me I was “lucky” to have been adopted, “lucky” even to live in America.
lead_paragraph: Moments after my daughter’s birth, nurses began commenting about our physical similarities.

headline: London, L.A., Beijing, Delhi, Nairobi… Is Smog an Inevitable Urban Growing Pain?
abstract: Does the urban climb from developing to developed economies have to be smoggy? So far, yes.
lead_paragraph: Gardiner Harris has a detailed story in The Times on what could be seen as New Delhi’s race to outdo Beijing in the deadly flows of air pollution from its traffic, industries, garbage dumps and kitchens. The soupy air is, on closer look, deadlier than that in China’s cities, he reports:

headline: Weimar and Greece, Continued
abstract: Comparable devastation.
lead_paragraph: Try to talk about macroeconomics, and you’re sure to encounter accusations that your policies would turn us into Weimar Germany; those wheelbarrows full of cash remain the ultimate bogeymen for many, despite years of being wrong about everything. As some of us have noted, however, there’s a peculiar selectivity in the use of Weimar as cautionary tale: it’s always about the hyperinflation of 1923, never about the deflationary effects of the gold standard and austerity in 1930-32, which is, you know, what brought you-know-who to power.

headline: Marvin David Levy, Composer Who Rose, Fell and Rose Again, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Levy’s career went into a spiral after the failure of “Mourning Becomes Electra,” and he was imprisoned for two years for his role in a drug ring.
lead_paragraph: It was only after he entered Dante’s Inferno — his name for the series of federal penitentiaries that became his home for two years — that the composer Marvin David Levy marshaled the resolve to write the kind of music he had always wanted.

headline: ‘Taxi’ by Jafar Panahi Takes Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
abstract: Coming in second were Chilean director Pablo Larraín’s “The Club,” about a home for errant priests, which took the grand jury prize, the Silver Bear, and “Ixcanul Volcano,” by the Guatemalan director Jayro Bustamante.
lead_paragraph: “Taxi,” in which the Iranian director Jafar Panahi mounted a dashboard camera in a yellow cab and drove it around Tehran, took the top prize, the Golden Bear, at the 65th Annual Berlin Film Festival on Saturday. Mr. Panahi’s young niece, who appears in the film and steals the show with her luminous curiosity, accepted the award on her uncle’s behalf.

headline: Philip Levine, a Poet of Grit, Sweat and Labor, Dies at 87

lead_paragraph: Philip Levine, a former United States poet laureate whose work was vibrantly, angrily and often painfully alive with the sound, smell and sinew of heavy manual labor, died on Saturday morning at his home in Fresno, Calif. He was 87.

Also included in the episode will be a report on the French neighborhood and prison that gave rise to the terrorists who attacked the Charlie Hebdo offices in Paris last month; and Steve Kroft interviews Bradley Cooper about his role in the Oscar-nominated movie “American Sniper.”

abstract: Mr. Levine’s spare, ironic poems of the industrial heartland evoked the drudgery and hardships of working-class life in America.

Mr. Levine had toiled in auto plants as a young man. “I saw that the people that I was working with,” he told Detroit Magazine, “were voiceless in a way.”

headline: Derek Lam’s Simple, Pretty ’70s-Inspired Ponytail
abstract: The hairstylist Orlando Pita was inspired to create the style by a pair of bell-bottom trousers in the designer’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by a pair of bell-bottom trousers from Derek Lam’s fall 2015 collection, the hairstylist Orlando Pita mimicked the wide shape in a textured ponytail. To get the look, Pita blow-dried the hair using, depending on the density of the model’s tresses, either Phyto’s Phytovolume Actif or Phyto’s Intense Volume mousse for texture. He kept the top portion slick and tidy, with an off-center, controlled part, and pulled the rest back into a ponytail at the nape of the neck, finishing the look with Phyto Phytolaque Soie hairspray. And, for a little extra interest: “We have this accessory in the hair, in the ponytail, which women would use in the ’70s when I went to high school,” Pita said. “We made a streamlined New York version for today.”

headline: 1940: Spy Plot, Including a Beautiful Blonde, Revealed
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A romantic spy ring is uncovered in 1940.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in five-and-one-half months of war, romantic Frenchmen were given the details yesterday [Feb. 15] of an espionage affair which conforms to all the traditional demands of fiction: an allegedly faithless government employee, a beautiful blonde and a number of enemy spies. What made the case more interesting was the fact that it occurred before war broke out and not until yesterday was it revealed that a certain Baroness von Einem was supposedly the ringleader of the gang. All Paris was surprised to learn of the implication of the beautiful young Baroness von Einem and of Gaston Amourelle, a stenographer in the French Senate.

headline: Review: In ‘Green on Blue,’ an Afghan Boy Narrates Story of War
abstract: In his debut novel, Elliot Ackerman, a veteran of five tours of duty in Afghanistan and Iraq, conveys the toll of war on ordinary Afghans.
lead_paragraph: This haunting debut novel by Elliot Ackerman — a decorated veteran who served five tours of duty in Afghanistan and Iraq — is told not from the point of view of an American soldier, but in the voice of an Afghan orphan named Aziz who is forced to join a United States-funded Afghan militia called the Special Lashkar after his beloved older brother Ali is gravely wounded. “Green on Blue” is a novel that conveys, with harrowing power, the fallout that decades of war (going back through the Soviet occupation of the 1980s) has had on that country’s people, and at the same time, it’s a kind of Greek tragedy about the cycles of revenge and violence that can consume families and tribes, generation after generation.

headline: Review: Original Leads Return in City Ballet’s ‘Romeo + Juliet’
abstract: Robert Fairchild and Sterling Hyltin danced the leads as their company’s production began a two-month run at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: It was 2007 when Peter Martins unveiled his “Romeo + Juliet.” At the time, the New York City Ballet production — which began a run of nine performances on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater — had one thing going for it: Mr. Martins’s decision to cast his leads, particularly Juliet, young. (His Romeos required more experience and strength for partnering.) He worked with students at the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, including the now-esteemed soloist Russell Janzen, but eventually settled on two fresh company members for the premiere: Robert Fairchild and Sterling Hyltin.

headline: Review: Summation Dance, in a Kaleidoscope Repeatedly Snapping Into Focus
abstract: The young ensemble presented two pieces characterized by overlapping solos, duets, oppositional groups and full-ensemble poses at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, when Sumi Clements and Taryn Vander Hoop founded Summation Dance Company, they were just about to graduate from the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. Five years later, their all-female ensemble still looks young, and the choreography by Ms. Clements retains the feel of high-level student work, adeptly constructed but emotionally and artistically immature.

headline: Imprint on a Dirt Road
abstract: An otherwise normal puzzle by David J. Kahn, with an extra layer of solving goodness.

But then you would remember that it’s Washington’s birthday, or Presidents’ Day, or whatever they’re calling it these days, and you would probably say, “Hey! Where my presidents at?”

headline: Writers Guild Chooses Top Screenplays of 2014
abstract: “The Grand Budapest Hotel” and “The Imitation Game” were named best original and adapted screenplay, respectively, at the Writers Guild of America Awards.
lead_paragraph: “The Grand Budapest Hotel” and “The Imitation Game” were named best original and adapted screenplay, respectively, at the Writers Guild of America Awards, given out Saturday in Los Angeles and New York. The script for “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” a comedic caper about a charismatic concierge and a young bellboy at a popular 1930s European ski resort, was written by Wes Anderson. “The Imitation Game” was written by Graham Moore and based on Andrew Hodges’s book about the British code-breaker Alan Turing. Other winners included Brian Knappenberger’s “The Internet’s Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz,” about a computer programming prodigy and information activist, for best documentary screenplay; Nic Pizzolatto’s “True Detective,” the HBO mini-series that revisits a 1995 murder case in rural Louisiana 17 years later, for best drama series and best new series; and “Louie,” a fictionalized series starring the comedian Louis CK, for best comedy series (written by Louis CK and Pamela Adlon) and best episodic comedy.

headline: Auction May Reveal Secrets of ‘American Pie’
abstract: Decades of speculation about the meaning behind of one of the 20th century’s most renowned and enigmatic songs could finally end.
lead_paragraph: Decades of speculation about the meaning behind of one of the 20th century’s most renowned and enigmatic songs could finally end when the notes and manuscripts of Don McLean’s “American Pie” go up for sale this spring — that is, of course, if the highest bidder chooses to publicly share what insights they may hold. The auction house Christie’s announced last week that the original working manuscript and typed drafts to the song — 16 pages total — would be auctioned on April 7 in New York. Mr. McLean, 69, told Reuters he decided to sell the documents on a whim. Other than admitting that a line in the song, “the day the music died,” refers to the Feb. 3, 1959, deaths of Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens and J. P. Richardson, known as the Big Bopper, Mr. McLean has been mostly vague about the meaning of other parts of the song. He told Reuters that the “writing and lyrics will divulge everything there is to divulge.” “American Pie” was released in 1971. The manuscript is estimated to fetch between $1 million and $1.5 million.

headline: David Carr’s Last Word on Journalism, Aimed at Students
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Journalism Schools', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mr. Carr, who died Thursday, was a funny, demanding, optimistic teacher of reporters-to-be at Boston University, and his syllabus distills his sense of an unfolding digital age. Excerpts here serve as the final Media Equation column under his byline.
lead_paragraph: David Carr was known at The New York Times as a supreme talent scout, a mentor to young reporters and a blunt critic of those who didn’t measure up. He was a natural teacher, and right up until the day he died last week, he was bent on minting the next generation of journalists. Last fall, David joined the faculty at Boston University’s communications school. While David did not write his curriculum as a column, it has all the essential ingredients of one. So here it serves as the final Media Equation under David’s byline.

abstract: After patiently abiding a steep increase in research and development spending, Wall Street is starting to wonder when — and if — Google’s science projects will pay off.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s research arm, Google X, is called the company’s Moonshot Factory. One reason the company picked the word “Moonshot” was to remind people to tackle big problems that may well blow up in their faces.

headline: The Rangers’ Cam Talbot Proves Himself, Over and Over
abstract: Talbot’s potential has not always been recognized, but while replacing the injured goalie Henrik Lundqvist, he is again making the most of an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Cam Talbot, thrust into the role of the Rangers’ starting goaltender after an injury to Henrik Lundqvist, was passed over by a premier junior hockey league, was overlooked by the biggest N.C.A.A. Division I programs and was not drafted by any N.H.L. team.

headline: A Korean Auto-Racing Debacle, but Hope Around the Bend
abstract: A remote South Korean province’s $375 million experiment on Formula One has been a failure, but boosters say it has left a legacy: the seeds of a car-racing culture in the country.
lead_paragraph: YEONGAM, South Korea — Eight years ago, the South Korean province of South Jeolla, which includes this sleepy coastal county, cleared 1,000 acres of rice paddies and embarked on a $375 million experiment: building a Formula One track.

headline: Dangers, Frustrations and Snow Keep Piling Up in New England
abstract: With 20 inches of snow in Boston over the weekend on top of the seven feet already on the ground, it is hard to remember when the snows began, and even harder to imagine when they might end.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Leaden skies tested the patience and sanity of winter-weary New Englanders once again over the weekend, unleashing more than two feet of new snow on parts of the region. It was the latest installment in a relentless string of storms that have blended, one into the next, enveloping every car and every home so that nothing has a distinct shape anymore; the landscape is just one seamless blanket of white.

headline: Bestival Will Enter North American Music Festival Market in Toronto
abstract: The a British import has a tradition of electronic dance music, alternative rock and dressed-up crowds.
lead_paragraph: The North American pop festival market is about to get more crowded this year with the arrival in Toronto of Bestival, a British import with a tradition of electronic dance music, alternative rock and dressed-up crowds.

abstract: John D. Podesta, a veteran infighter who has galvanized the struggling Clinton and Obama White Houses, is preparing to bring his strong hand to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not that he’s competitive or anything, but one Friday evening, John D. Podesta, a top adviser to President Obama, announced at a White House meeting that he would finish a 10-mile race that weekend in so many minutes. Needling Denis McDonough, the president’s chief of staff, Mr. Podesta added: “I don’t know what Denis is going to run.”

abstract: The purchase plan, which began in 2005 and involved a secretive seller, yielded at least 400 warheads, some containing the nerve agent sarin, officials said.

headline: In New York City, Jobs Come Back Without Wall Street
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Unemployment', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: A rise in employment in tourist-based and tech companies has outstripped the high-paying securities sector, which once fueled job creation in the city.
lead_paragraph: New York City has created more jobs over the past five years than during any five-year period in the last half century. But the city is not pulsing with the same boomtown swagger it radiated in past growth spurts.

headline: U.S. Revels in Victories and Its Rising Status in a Sport
abstract: The United States had an impressive all-around showing at the Alpine world ski championships in Beaver Creek, Colo., and international ski officials are talking about holding more events in America.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — When the Alpine world ski championships came to the United States this month for the first time since 1999, the 13-day event was quickly defined by two competitive challenges taking place simultaneously.

headline: Louis Jourdan, Suave Star in Europe and Hollywood, Dies at 93
abstract: In the 1940s and ’50s, Mr. Jourdan embodied Hollywood’s idea of the cultured, worldly European man.
lead_paragraph: Louis Jourdan, a handsome, sad-eyed French actor who worked in films and on television in Europe and the United States for more than 50 years, as a romantic hero in movies like “Gigi” and later as a suave villain in movies like “Octopussy,” died on Friday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 93.

lead_paragraph: Reporters who uncovered systemic failure within the Secret Service and the Department of Veterans Affairs, and whose work led to reforms at both federal agencies, were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2014, announced on Sunday by Long Island University, which administers the prizes.

headline: Bo Ryan Is Weaned to Win in Wisconsin
abstract: Ryan has five decades of college basketball success by staying local, this time with the Wisconsin Badgers.
lead_paragraph: PLATTEVILLE, Wis. — As one approaches this town of 11,000 in the southwest corner of Wisconsin, the largest letter M in the world looms to the north. Made of 400 tons of whitewashed limestone, measuring more than 200 feet in each direction and symbolizing the University of Wisconsin-Platteville’s mining tradition, it is peaked on the kind of hill not ordinarily seen in the northern Midwest.

headline: Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon and His Fiancée Walked Tangled Path to Exit
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']

keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Newspapers', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Urdu Language', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Mumbai edition of an Urdu newspaper has closed and its editor faces charges and death threats for having reprinted a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad from the satirical French weekly.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The Charlie Hebdo slaughter in Paris has reverberated into the multireligious ethnic sprawl of Mumbai, where an Urdu newspaper has closed and its editor faces charges and death threats for having reprinted a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad from the satirical French weekly.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Rural Areas', 'Suburbs', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)']

headline: Richard Meryman, Journalist and Wyeth Biographer, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Meryman conducted the last interview with Marilyn Monroe and collaborated with Joan Rivers on her memoir.
lead_paragraph: Richard Meryman, a former Life magazine writer and editor who conducted the last interview with Marilyn Monroe, wrote an intimate portrait of the reclusive artist Andrew Wyeth, collaborated with Joan Rivers on a memoir about her quest for stardom and recounted a wrenching emotional journey after his first wife became fatally ill, died on Feb. 5 in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: An All-Natural Beauty Site With a Cult Following Opens Up Shop
abstract: This weekend, CAP Beauty opened the doors to its new West Village outpost, where wellness comes first.
lead_paragraph: It’s barely a year old, but the wellness web store CAP Beauty has already gained a cult following among the celebrity set, including Helena Christensen and Brooke Shields, for its all-things-natural approach. And this weekend, the brand opened its first brick-and-mortar boutique-spa hybrid in New York’s West Village. “The available means of discovery in New York has really been limited,” says the cofounder Kerrilynn Pamer, who teamed up with her friend Cindy DiPrima Morisse to launch the shopping platform last May. “There’s a health food store, a grocery store, and bits and pieces of different brands in different outlets — but if you wanted to take on a clean beauty routine, that experience of going to one place to smell perfume and try eye cream, all while feeling safe, has been missing.”

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) INDEPENDENT LENS Thomas Allen Harris’s documentary “Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People” tells the story of the men and women who have captured African-American culture over the past 170 years, including Carrie Mae Weems, Lorna Simpson, Anthony Barboza, Lyle Ashton Harris, Hank Willis Thomas (“Crossroads,” above), Coco Fusco and Clarissa Sligh. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the movie “a family memoir, a tribute to unsung artists and a lyrical, at times heartbroken, meditation on imagery and identity.” He added, “The film is always absorbing to watch, but only once it’s over do you begin to grasp the extent of its ambitions, and just how much it has done within a packed, compact hour and a half.”

headline: Save the Wisconsin Idea
abstract: Scott Walker’s budget cuts are an assault on the public university system.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — EARLIER this month, Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin and potential Republican presidential candidate, unveiled a proposed budget that would cut $300 million of funds to the University of Wisconsin system and shift power over tuition from the Legislature to a new public authority controlled by appointed regents. The initial draft of Mr. Walker’s budget bill also proposed to rewrite the university’s 110-year-old mission statement, known as the Wisconsin Idea, deleting “the search for truth” and replacing it with language about meeting “the state’s work-force needs.”

headline: Weimar on the Aegean
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Recession and Depression', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Reparations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Greek debt and the lessons of history.
lead_paragraph: Try to talk about the policies we need in a depressed world economy, and someone is sure to counter with the specter of Weimar Germany, supposedly an object lesson in the dangers of budget deficits and monetary expansion. But the history of Germany after World War I is almost always cited in a curiously selective way. We hear endlessly about the hyperinflation of 1923, when people carted around wheelbarrows full of cash, but we never hear about the much more relevant deflation of the early 1930s, as the government of Chancellor Brüning — having learned the wrong lessons — tried to defend Germany’s peg to gold with tight money and harsh austerity.

headline: How to Force Prosecutors to Play Fair
abstract: The Supreme Court should make the government pay when prosecutors ignore the Constitution and convict defendants as a result of prosecutorial misconduct.
lead_paragraph: When prosecutors cheat and lie repeatedly to win convictions, should their office be held accountable?

headline: George Washington, Slave Catcher
abstract: Our first president relentlessly pursued the fugitive Ona Judge.
lead_paragraph: AMID the car and mattress sales that serve as markers for Presidents’ Day, Black History Month reminds Americans to focus on our common history. In 1926, the African-American historian Carter G. Woodson introduced Negro History Week as a commemoration built around the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass. Now February serves as a point of collision between presidential celebration and marginalized black history.

headline: Goodbye to the Electronics Store
abstract: Internet-based retailers, especially Amazon, have had a particularly devastating impact on electronics retailers, many of whom have struggled to adapt to the technological age they helped usher in.
lead_paragraph: I was assembling a home audio system recently and needed speaker wires. A friend recommended RadioShack. I went to two — in Manhattan and in Brooklyn — but, to my surprise, neither carried any. How could RadioShack, the place Americans go to for cables, connectors, circuits and all kinds of other electronic doodads, not have speaker wires?

headline: A Kaffeeklatsch on Race
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The F.B.I. chief, James Comey, enters the debate.
lead_paragraph: In our collective imaginations, we tend to conceive of the constantly called-for “national conversation on race” as having the formality of some grand conclave of consciousness — an American Truth and Reconciliation equivalent, a spiritual spectacle in which sins are confessed and blame taken and burdens lifted.

headline: Nigeria’s Miserable Choices
abstract: A presidential election between a lousy incumbent and a former autocratic leader was postponed because of fears over the safety of voters, but that may not help matters.
lead_paragraph: The Nigerian government was supposed to hold presidential elections this past weekend, which presented voters with the dispiriting choice of keeping a lousy incumbent or returning to power a former autocratic leader. Now they will have to wait at least six weeks to cast votes.

headline: What Alabama’s Roy Moore Got Right
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Philosophy', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The nation’s courts don’t have the power to ‘redefine marriage.’ We do. And that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Roy Moore, the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, escalated the conflict over same-sex marriage last week, when he ordered probate judges in the state not to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, even after a federal judge struck down Alabama’s ban on the practice. In a recent radio interview, Moore said that he would continue to resist federal intervention: “There’s nothing in the U.S. Constitution that authorizes the Supreme Court of the United States or any federal court anywhere to misinterpret the word marriage to include something outside that.” The government, he added, does not have the power to “redefine marriage.”

headline: Hong Kong Ferry Captain Sentenced to 8 Years in Prison for Deadly Collision
abstract: The accident killed 39 people on Oct. 1, 2012. The captain of the second vessel was acquitted of manslaughter but found guilty of endangering the safety of others.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The captain of a ferry involved in Hong Kong’s deadliest maritime accident in more than four decades was sentenced on Monday to eight years in prison after being found guilty of 39 counts of manslaughter.

headline: Happy Presidents’ Day
abstract: Besides resources for Presidents’ Day, we provide a few to remember the New York Times media columnist and journalism teacher David Carr, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: We’re taking the day off on this national holiday — but we’ll be back with most of our regular content, including the Weekly News Quiz, on Feb. 17.

abstract: The firm, which is focused primarily on metropolitan areas in Germany, said the acquisition of Conwert Immobilien Invest would be a good strategic fit.

headline: Recording Music, With a Camera
keywords: ['Music', 'Musical Instruments', 'Photography', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The members of Austin’s Mother Falcon are multi-instrumentalists, especially Tamir Kalifa, who is their man on accordion, piano, bouzouki, guitar and camera.
lead_paragraph: As with any scrappy aspiring rock band, when Mother Falcon goes on tour, its members endure the hardships of the road — sleeping in the van, hauling instruments, recouping after canceled shows, eating cheaply, quickly, and imprudently, and taming the tensions that flare up in close quarters among musicians.

headline: British Gambling Website 888 Holdings Ends Takeover Talks
abstract: 888 Holdings and its larger rival, William Hill, were unable to reach a deal because of a “significant difference of opinion on value” by a top investor, 888 said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British online gambling company 888 Holdings said on Monday that it had ended takeover discussions with its larger competitor, William Hill.

headline: Aid to Needy Often Excludes the Poorest in America
abstract: Government aid to low-income workers has increased, but those without jobs, who are in the direst straits, are receiving scant attention, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The safety net helped keep Camille Saunders from falling, but not Charles Constance.

headline: Astro Teller, Google’s ‘Captain of Moonshots,’ on Making Profits at Google X
abstract: Astro Teller, the head of the Google X research group, talks about the company’s efforts to commercialize projects like the self-driving car and why the Glass wearable device will still impact technology.
lead_paragraph: Google is all over the place. From biotechnology and robots to satellites and space exploration, the company has dipped into a dizzying and often confusing range of projects, especially when you consider that the core business is to sell advertising.

headline: Islam and the West at War
abstract: The Danish prime minister speaks of a “dark ideology.” This vagueness undermines the Muslims fighting the Islamist scourge.
lead_paragraph: After a Danish movie director at a seminar on “Art, Blasphemy and Freedom of Expression” and a Danish Jew guarding a synagogue were shot dead in Copenhagen, Helle Thorning-Schmidt, the prime minister of Denmark, uttered a familiar trope:

headline: What to Expect on the Fifth Day of New York Fashion Week
abstract: A full day of with shows from The Row, Carolina Herrera, Tommy Hilfiger, Thom Browne and more.
lead_paragraph: It’s a race to the starting line this frigid Monday morning, and anyone hoping to make a clean sweep of the day’s events will have to be up by cock’s-crow, or just about.

headline: When Grief Won’t Relent
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Grief (Emotion)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Complicated grief, as it is known, is more than just a life-disrupting emotional response. It can result in a physical and psychological decline.
lead_paragraph: Bereavement — how one responds and adjusts to the death of a loved one — is a very individual matter. It is natural to experience a host of negative reactions in the weeks and months following the loss of a loved one: among them, sadness, difficulty sleeping, painful reminders of the person, difficulty enjoying activities once shared, even anger.

headline: Anger of Suspect in Danish Killings Is Seen as Only Loosely Tied to Islam
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Omar Abdel Hamid El-Hussein is remembered as a young man of intelligence who harbored a growing rage against Danish society.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — When Aydin Soei, a sociologist in Denmark, met members of an inner-city gang in 2008, one teenage tough stood out as more intelligent than his peers, and more mercurial. He showed little interest in Islam, but a deep loathing for Denmark, the country where he was born and spent his entire life.

headline: Matthew Lightner Will Leave Atera
abstract: A change of chefs at a restaurant known for its tasting menus.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Lightner, the well-traveled chef whose tasting menu at the tiny TriBeCa restaurant Atera has won huge acclaim, will leave there after March 28 to embark on a new project.

headline: Veteran Communist Leader Is Shot in India
abstract: Govind Pansare, 81, was shot along with his wife as they were out walking. He was in critical but stable condition, while she was less seriously hurt.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A veteran Communist leader and critic of right-wing groups was shot along with his wife in central India on Monday morning as they were out for a stroll, the police said.

headline: SNS Reaal Agrees to Sell Dutch Insurance Arm to Anbang of China
abstract: The Anbang Insurance Group said it would pay about $171 million for all of Vivant Verzekeringen’s shares and inject as much as $1.1 billion into the Dutch insurer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – SNS Reaal, a state-owned Dutch financial services company, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Vivat Verzekeringen insurance arm to a unit of Anbang Insurance Group of China.

headline: Fatal Accidents as a Global Health Crisis
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Falls', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Drownings', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: A worldwide study that tracked accidental deaths shows countries where they can improve relative to their peers.
lead_paragraph: Worried about what to worry about? Accidents should move higher up your list.

headline: Restaurant Critic Pete Wells on How He Does His Job
abstract: Times restaurant critic Pete Wells talks about how he does his job.
lead_paragraph: Pete Wells has been restaurant critic for The New York Times since January 2012. As restaurant critic, he says that he has probably eaten close to 800 meals. (And he says, miraculously, he hasn’t gained weight.) Here he gives Insiders a sense of how he does the job.

headline: Daily Report: Two Start-Ups Offer Calls Via Wi-Fi First
abstract: Two companies are trying to lower cellphone costs by relying on Wi-Fi routers. Now some of the bigger companies are looking to follow their lead.
lead_paragraph: It would not be an insult to say Republic Wireless and FreedomPop are obscure little companies. But they dream big, Brian Chen reports.The two companies are at the forefront of a tantalizing wireless communications concept that has proved hard to produce on a big scale: Reduce cellphone costs by relying on strategically placed Wi-Fi routers. And when there are no routers available, fall back on the traditional cellular network. Read more »

headline: Good Odds But Odd Goods
abstract: A guide to the singlelarity.
lead_paragraph: This paper using a dynamic search model to explain why “most single people are crazy” is brilliant — and I don’t just say that because it starts with homage to a classic forerunner.

headline: Bard SummerScape to Feature Work of the Composer Carlos Chávez
abstract: Some of Chávez’s best-known works — including his “Sinfonía india” and “H.P.,” a ballet symphony — will be played, along with works by Silvestre Revueltas, Alberto Ginastera, Heitor Villa-Lobos, and an overview of Mexican choral music.
lead_paragraph: The music of Carlos Chávez, a key 20th-century Mexican composer whose works blended modern, folk and pre-Columbian influences, will be explored this summer at the Bard SummerScape Festival in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., the festival announced Monday.

headline: 1940: Women Called to New Fight
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Women’s rights activist calls for action in 1940.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — A call to leaders of American women to meet in New York next fall for a Woman’s Centennial Congress to make plans for a campaign to extend feminine rights during the next century was issued today [Feb. 16] by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, president of the National American Woman’s Suffrage Association. Mrs. Catt announced that the congress was also intended to commemorate ‘‘the almost unbelievable changes that have taken place in the status of women’’ in the last 100 years. She said the fight for women’s rights had been so successful in this period that it might well be called the ‘‘Women’s Century.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1940

headline: New York Diversifies
abstract: Some surprising good news.
lead_paragraph: One thing I learned from Ed Glaeser’s fine work on the economy of New York was that the city, after a complex past, had become essentially a monoculture. That is, its export sector — the part of the economy that sells to other locations, as opposed to providing local, nontraded goods and services — was basically finance and nothing else.

headline: ‘Imitation Game,’ ‘Grand Budapest Hotel’ and Decorum Win Over Writers Guild
abstract: Unlike more freewheeling ceremonies of the past, this year’s awards were a buttoned-down affair.
lead_paragraph: Stories of freewheeling Writers Guild Awards ceremonies of yore was one of the reasons the Bagger traveled to the tourist-chocked confines of Midtown Manhattan on a frigid Saturday night. The event isn’t broadcast, booze freely flows, and writers supposedly can be a devilish bunch. Antics of years past included a tipsy Patton Oswalt letting rip and a sloshed Jonathan Ames railing against the cancellation of his HBO show “Bored to Death.”

headline: 1965: Anti-U.S. Rally in Indonesia
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 5,000 students rally against the United States in Indonesia in 1965.
lead_paragraph: DJAKARTA — About 5,000 high school students, including President Sukarno’s daughter Rachmawati, 15, staged an anti-American demonstration today  [Feb. 16] in Djakarta streets. The students paraded after attending a rally at the hall of the Communist-inspired Youth Front Organization, where they burned effigies personifying Americans and Prime Minister Tengku Abdul Rahman of Malaysia. The rally and demonstration were sponsored by the Communists. The demonstrators did not attempt to go near the U.S. embassy. —New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1965

headline: In Hospitals, Board Rooms Are as Important as Operating Rooms
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: A hospital’s quality is deeply influenced by its top management. But too often, hospital boards and C.E.O.s are focused on the wrong things.
lead_paragraph: If you or a loved one is having a heart attack, your most pressing concerns probably include how quickly you can get to the hospital and the quality of care you’ll receive. You’re probably not thinking about the hospital’s board room, even though quality of care for heart attacks and many other conditions may be determined in large part by decisions made there.

headline: Research Finds a Reason Leprosy Has Persisted
abstract: The bacteria that causes the disease can survive for months in amoebae that are common even in human eyes and noses, Colorado State scientists found.
lead_paragraph: The bacteria that cause leprosy can survive for months inside amoebae that are common in water and soil, and even in human eyes and noses, scientists at Colorado State University have found.

headline: Triumph of the Chart
abstract: Facts, figures, and L. Ron Hubbard.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been behind the curve on the Vox interview with President Obama. But the reactions to that interview — not just from the right, but from centrists — are remarkable. Jack Schafer compares it to a Scientology recruitment film; Rich Lowry compares it to Leni Riefenstahl. Why?

headline: Meeting on Greek Debt Produces an Ultimatum
abstract: Greece dismissed its creditors’ proposals as “unreasonable and unacceptable,” a signal that resolution of its debt crisis is not near.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The standoff between Greece and its European lenders appeared to reach a new low on Monday as European officials handed Athens an ultimatum: Agree by Friday to continue with a bailout program or risk the funding that the country needs to avoid a default.

abstract: The latest women’s collection from Tommy Hilfiger at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the live stream.]

headline: Up to 14 Years of Hot Flashes Found in Menopause Study
abstract: The median length of time women endured symptoms was 7.4 years, according to researchers in the largest examination to date of the menopausal symptom.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that hot flashes, which afflict up to 80 percent of middle-aged women, usually persist for just a few years. But hot flashes can continue for as long as 14 years, and the earlier they begin the longer a woman is likely to suffer, a study published on Monday in JAMA Internal Medicine found.

headline: Health Care Success for Midwest Co-op Proves Its Undoing
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: The insolvency of CoOportunity Health raised the question of whether a major Affordable Care Act experiment in holding down insurance costs was in trouble beyond Iowa and Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: RED OAK, Iowa — A few days after Christmas, Lisa Lovig’s doctor called with jarring news. The health insurer covering her cancer treatments had run out of money, and its future was at best uncertain.

headline: What Children Think of the Internet (and Why It Matters)
abstract: Question I haven’t yet asked my 5-year-old: is the Internet a more reliable source of information than I am?
lead_paragraph: On a recent late afternoon, my 5-year-old son requested pizza for dinner, as he does pretty much every day. I wasn’t sure if we had one in the freezer. “Let’s ask the Internet,” he suggested. A few days later, he proposed consulting Google to find out what time his father would be home from work.

lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Atop a steep hill on the University of Wisconsin campus is a granite boulder affixed with a bronze plaque honoring the university system’s lofty mission: to benefit the entire state by promoting public service and a search for truth.
