headline: The Handicap
abstract: Can you crack these puzzles from Futility Closet creator Greg Ross?
lead_paragraph: Our puzzles this week were suggested by Greg Ross, periodic Numberplay contributor and curator of the incredibly popular Futility Closet, the online compilation of the most addicting tidbits from history, literature, language, art, philosophy and mathematics. This week’s challenges are from Greg’s recently-released Futility Closet 2. Let’s give them a try, starting with —

headline: Sweetest Violins Explained: Holes Fill In Blanks
abstract: What was it about the exquisite instruments produced in Cremona, Italy? Researchers conducted experiments to find out.
lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s most prized violins were made in Cremona, Italy, in the 17th and 18th centuries by the Amati, Guarneri and Stradivari families. Researchers at M.I.T. wanted to know what accounted for the instruments’ unique acoustical properties.

headline: Disorder Rules the Universe
abstract: In a rich and entertaining new book, a philosopher and a physicist describe how the new physics changed our world.
lead_paragraph: “On or about September 1927,” wrote the philosopher Ray Monk, “the physical world changed.” Until then, according to Robert P. Crease and Alfred Scharff Goldhaber’s rich and entertaining new book, “The Quantum Moment,” we lived in a homogeneous, continuous, Newtonian world in which all objects moved seamlessly from the past to the future, governed by universal mathematical laws.

headline: At the Fall/Winter 2015 Shows, Designers Are Pushing Buttons
abstract: Oversize buttons are shaping up to be fall wardrobe fixtures.
lead_paragraph: What is in a button? It’s functional and fastens, usually without being noticed — until now. On the fall/winter 2015 runways in New York, the utilitarian little notions have been upgraded from behind the scenes to front and center. We saw them first at Victoria Beckham, who sewed large horn buttons onto knit shift dresses and sculpted outerwear. A few hours later, Derek Lam introduced double-breasted vests fastened with oversize white buttons and turtlenecks dotted with black ones. And at Edun, buttons embellished extra-large pea coats and the necks of dresses. Practical or not, they’re poised to be a fixture for fall.

headline: In Arena’s Shadow, Holdouts at Atlantic Yards Site Must Now Leave
keywords: ['Atlantic Yards (Brooklyn)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Eminent Domain', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A business owner and a homeowner, among others, are losing their properties near the Barclays Center in Brooklyn to the development, now called Pacific Park.
lead_paragraph: Last week was a busy one at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. The rusticated arena lost its shot at hosting the 2016  Democratic National Convention, but there was still plenty to cheer during its first N.B.A. All-Star celebration.

headline: The ‘S.N.L.’ 40th-Anniversary Show: Very Funny, Except When It Wasn’t
abstract: NBC’s star-studded three-and-a-half-hour tribute to “Saturday Night Live” was a mostly satisfying blend of self-congratulation and self-mockery.
lead_paragraph: Humor, like beauty, doesn’t always last. Chevy Chase and Eddie Murphy proved that.

headline: Wimpy Kid Musical to Have Premiere in Minneapolis
abstract: The production will cap off the 50th anniversary season of Children’s Theater Company in Minneapolis
lead_paragraph: “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” Jeff Kinney’s series about the misadventures of a misfit middle schooler, has sold more than 120 million books and inspired a Hollywood franchise. Now, a musical version will hit the stage next spring, capping off the 50th anniversary season of Children’s Theater Company in Minneapolis.

headline: The Afghan Militant in the Photo? The Wrong Man, and He’s Not Happy
abstract: When the Afghan spy agency trumpeted the death of an Islamic State recruiter, it distributed a photograph of a man who was actually a former Guantánamo detainee who was trying to lie low.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — After an airstrike killed a prominent recruiter for the Islamic State in Afghanistan last week, the Afghan spy agency issued a triumphant news release announcing his death and providing a picture of a man it identified as the wanted militant, Mullah Abdul Rauf Khadim.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What everyone at “The Daily Show” really wants to do, apparently, is direct.

headline: A Cancer Cluster Is Tough to Prove
abstract: The genetic mutations that cause cancer can take decades to manifest themselves but the laws we cobble together often trump those of science.
lead_paragraph: Last month, thousands of Marines and their families were blocked in federal court from pursuing their claim that the government had given them cancer. The decision, involving people exposed to contaminated drinking water while stationed at Camp Lejeune, a base in North Carolina, didn’t consider the science.

headline: Jewish Graves Vandalized in France
abstract: As many as 250 gravestones were overturned, but the police said it was not clear the cemetery was targeted because it is Jewish.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Teenage vandals are suspected of overturning as many as 250 gravestones in a cemetery in a rural part of eastern France near the German border, where many Jews once lived but have long since left.

headline: Quiz: Westminster Dog Show Look-Alikes
abstract: Do dogs really look like their owners? Put the theory to the test by trying to guess which dog from the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show belongs to which owner.
lead_paragraph: Do dogs really look like their owners? Put the theory to the test by trying to guess which dog from the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show belongs to which owner.

headline: A Moth’s Tail Can Deceive Bats
abstract: With its tail, assuming it has one, the luna moth can frustrate a bat’s ability to use echolocation to hunt.
lead_paragraph: Like a caterpillar blending into a leaf to escape a bird’s gaze, luna moths that have tails can use them to generate a noise that guides attacking bats away from their bodies. Using high-speed infrared cameras, researchers at Boise State University watched big brown bats hunt moths by means of echolocation. The ones with tails had a 47 percent survival advantage over those without, the researchers reported Monday in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: An Angular, Runway-Inspired New Track From New York’s White Prism
abstract: The musical project is the brainchild of the sometime fashion stylist Johanna Cranitch.
lead_paragraph: There’s an undeniable visual quality to White Prism’s sound. The project features cool, breathy vocals that float above a bed of icy, angular synths and syncopated beats, simultaneously harkening back to ’80s dance pop and conjuring something strangely futuristic. “I really wanted to concentrate on marrying the two things that I love, which are fashion and music,” says White Prism’s lead singer and songwriter Johanna Cranitch, whose blunt bleached bob and shockingly blue eyes even seem suited to the music she makes.

headline: Review: In ‘Paradox of the Urban Cliché,’ Verse Melts Into Drama
abstract: This thoughtful new play by Craig Grant follows a young black couple in nongentrified Harlem, where their love story becomes a Kafkaesque nightmare.
lead_paragraph: The soft sound of snapping fingers rippled through the audience at “Paradox of the Urban Cliché,” a thoughtful new play by Craig Grant, as a character named Smiles laid down her rhymes. The pain-filled verses flowed with an easy grace, and the snaps on a recent night at the Wild Project were a sign of approval borrowed from the world of performance poetry.

headline: U.N. Delays Release of Report on Possible War Crimes in Sri Lanka
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The release of the report was deferred after intense lobbying by the country’s newly elected government, which is said to be prepared to cooperate with the investigation.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Human Rights Council on Monday agreed to defer the release of a landmark inquiry into possible war crimes in Sri Lanka, after an intense lobbying campaign by the country’s newly elected government and what the United Nations’ top rights official described as “signals of broad cooperation” from Sri Lankan officials.

headline: Genes Tell Only Part of the Story
abstract: The lives of patients are far more complex, and messier, than science can explain.
lead_paragraph: I had intended to discuss President Obama’s plans for personalized precision medicine with my patient Barbara last week, but she missed her appointment. Or, more accurately, she arrived two hours late, made the usual giant fuss at the reception desk and had to be rescheduled.

lead_paragraph: Despite freezing temperatures, the fashion faithful kept the parties going. Diane von Furstenberg held a party at her meatpacking district studio that included Cindi Leive, the editor in chief of Glamour. See the photos.

headline: The Science of Online Dating
abstract: Two researchers discovered ways to make your profile stand out. One of them proved just how well they worked.
lead_paragraph: One in 10 American adults is registered with an online dating service. The number of people looking to find love online has never been greater, but the wealth of options also means that singles can spend months combing through hundreds of profiles without ever securing a successful date.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — After five tumultuous years at the helm, Steven L. Newman, the chief executive of Transocean, a leading offshore drilling service company, has abruptly stepped down.

headline: Taps Start to Run Dry in Brazil’s Largest City
abstract: A lack of political will, poor environmental management and a long dry spell have conspired to put São Paulo, a metropolitan area of 20 million, on the verge of a harsh rationing plan.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Endowed with the Amazon and other mighty rivers, an array of huge dams and one-eighth of the world’s fresh water, Brazil is sometimes called the “Saudi Arabia of water,” so rich in the coveted resource that some liken it to living above a sea of oil.

headline: Steep Fees and First-Class Prices, but Private Jets Are Available to More
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mobile Applications', 'Private Aircraft', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Start-ups', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Capitalizing on dissatisfaction with commercial airlines, a number of new ventures are using smartphone apps to upend the private jet market.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Smart flies two or three times a week and prefers private jets, but he doesn’t own a plane. He has a smartphone for that. Mr. Smart, who is an owner of Manhattan’s ArtNowNY and Joseph Gross galleries, has homes in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., and New York, making for a lot of time spent on planes.

headline: In Town Where Pitcher’s 266 Wins Were Part of Fabric, One Big Loss
abstract: After the Hall of Famer Bob Feller died in 2010, the business model for his museum in Van Meter, Iowa, began to fail. The building was sold to the city for a new city hall.
lead_paragraph: For as long as Bob Feller, the Hall of Fame pitcher for the Cleveland Indians, remained alive, the business model for the Bob Feller Museum in Van Meter, Iowa, his hometown, worked perfectly.

headline: Listening to Bad Pitches and Asking One Question Too Many
abstract: Akos Jankura is a host of the radio show “My Cool Inventions,” where he helps inventors develop their ideas. On the road, however, he hears even more.
lead_paragraph: I’M in the inventions business, hosting a radio show called “My Cool Inventions,” and I’m a frequent guest on HSN and QVC International showcasing inventions. I work in the product development end of things, too. All of these ventures involve a lot of travel, about 150,000 to 200,000 miles a year.

headline: Amar’e Stoudemire’s Time With Knicks Done After Buyout
abstract: The veteran forward was waived after requesting that the Knicks buy out the remainder of his contract, which was set to expire after this season.
lead_paragraph: Amar’e Stoudemire’s tenure with the Knicks came to a bittersweet conclusion on Monday when the team announced that it had bought out the remainder of the 33-year-old forward’s contract.

headline: Scene City: When NBA All-Star and Fashion Week Collide
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ALL STAR GAMES']
abstract: LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony, Russell Westbrook and other All-Stars party alongside the stars of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: With the NBA All-Star game in New York on Sunday, the weekend was jammed with roundball-related festivities. On Thursday night, Zegna hosted a dinner that drew players like Serge Ibaka, a power forward on the Oklahoma City Thunder. See the photos.

headline: Debating the Rules and Ethics of Digital Photojournalism
abstract: The disqualification of a large number of images from this year’s World Press Photo contest has sparked a debate over the need for more explicit rules on what is — and is not — acceptable in digital photography.
lead_paragraph: The disqualification of a large number of images from this year’s World Press Photo contest has sparked a debate over the need for more explicit rules on what is — and is not — acceptable in digital photography.

headline: Dillon Gee Arrives in Mets Camp With Status Unsettled
abstract: The Mets will enter training camp with six established starters, and Dillon Gee has emerged as the one mostly likely to be traded.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Dillon Gee spent his off-season at home in Texas, hunting and spending time with his family. It was relaxing for the most part. But whenever he saw his agent calling, he would become anxious. The Mets had been shopping him in trades, and on more than one occasion, he thought a deal might be close.

headline: With Ukrainian Troops Trapped, a Cease-Fire Grows More Fragile
abstract: Separatist forces apparently control a key road near Debaltseve, meaning that as many as 8,000 Ukrainian soldiers are surrounded.
lead_paragraph: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — The plight of as many as 8,000 Ukrainian troops trapped in the vicinity of Debaltseve, as well as the prospects for an already fragile truce, look decidedly dimmer on Monday after a Russian television correspondent strolled down what was supposed to be a hotly contested road.

headline: Scenes From the All-Star Game
abstract: The 64th N.B.A. All-Star Game, played at Madison Square Garden, was a typically high-scoring affair, with celebrities not only on the court but also in the stands.
lead_paragraph: The 64th N.B.A. All-Star Game, played at Madison Square Garden, was a typically high-scoring affair, with celebrities not only on the court but also in the stands.

headline: U.S. Embedded Spyware Overseas, Report Claims
abstract: A Russian firm said that the United States had found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers in nations like Iran, Russia, Pakistan and China.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The United States has found a way to permanently embed surveillance and sabotage tools in computers and networks it has targeted in Iran, Russia, Pakistan, China, Afghanistan and other countries closely watched by American intelligence agencies, according to a Russian cybersecurity firm.

headline: At Opening Ceremony, the Clothes Are Only the Start
abstract: Who but Mr. Leon and Ms. Lim, two of the best-connected designers in fashion, could hope to keep up with the Jonze?
lead_paragraph: It’s not at all unusual to be invited to a Chelsea gallery during fashion week. Designers love to rent out the galleries that line the far-west blocks of Chelsea — even in February, when frigid winds blow off the nearby river — to stage their fashion shows.

headline: Review: Ballet Arizona’s ‘Napoli’ Embodies a Culture of Exuberance
abstract: As the first American ensemble to stage Bournonville’s 1842 work, the company seems to revel in its action-packed vitality.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Naples, a city I adore, and its environs burst to life onstage in “Napoli,” a ballet choreographed in 1842 by August Bournonville. When the curtain rises on Act I, the audience applauds the view of the city’s famous bay, with Vesuvius dominating the horizon. When it rises on Act II, the applause is accompanied by gasps, because here we’re in the Blue Grotto of Capri. Act III is not set in any location so famous, but there’s something so picturesque about its bridge and pilgrim shrine that the audience applauds anyway.

headline: Your Letters: Carbon Dioxide Storage, H.I.V. Drugs and Ebola Management
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Geothermal Power', 'Solar Energy', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Ebola Virus']
abstract: Your letters to the Editor.
lead_paragraph: Climate: Energy Use

headline: On the Fall 2015 Runways, Fresh Takes on an Old Standby: Black Eyeliner
abstract: Models at Coach, DKNY and Cushie et Ochs all appeared with boldly outlined eyes.
lead_paragraph: Black lines are defining the eyes in unexpected ways at the fall/winter 2015 shows. Last Thursday at Coach’s presentation, a seamless, symmetrical cat-eye immediately drew attention; the black stroke went across the top lid and back down halfway along the lower lid, with just enough of a pull at the corner of the eye. DKNY explored the trend with a little more adventurous oomph, outlining the outskirts of the eye with a thick black line; and at Cushnie et Ochs, it was more rock-n-roll, a smoky eye that stole the beauty moment – thick and smeared, with a slight interruption at each corner that separated the top and the bottom portion of the eye like the ends of a brushstroke.

headline: Review: Berlin Philharmonic Goes to London in Simon Rattle Homecoming
abstract: The orchestra’s residency last week again raised a question of whether London could be Mr. Rattle’s next stop.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Whenever the conductor Simon Rattle takes his Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra to London, there’s a sense of reckoning: about the boy who went away, made good and is now bringing home the proof. For British audiences, the very idea that a conductor from England — what Germans used to call “the land without music” — is in charge of Germany’s flagship orchestra is a continuing source of national delight. British music lovers are always curious to know how the relationship has worked out.

headline: Review: ‘Rap Guide to Religion’ Examines Why Humanity Created God
abstract: In his solo show at the SoHo Playhouse, Baba Brinkman considers the need for, and consequences of, religious belief.
lead_paragraph: You know what would make Baba Brinkman happy this weekend? If just one winner would get up at the Oscars and make an acceptance speech that began not with an expression of gratitude to God but with “I want to thank Charles Darwin.”

headline: Review: Auryn Quartet Forges a Radiance at the Frick
abstract: The string quartet played a program of Mozart, Ravel and Brahms at the Frick Collection’s Music Room on Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: A warm sound is invariably an appealing attribute of solo or ensemble playing — and as temperatures plummeted on Sunday afternoon, it felt particularly welcome to bask in the Auryn Quartet’s glowing timbres in the snug acoustical cocoon of the Frick Collection’s intimate Music Room.

headline: A Bold, Punky Lip at 3.1 Phillip Lim
abstract: The oxblood color is reminiscent of the red leather Doc Martens popular in the late ’80s and early ’90s.
lead_paragraph: It’s unquestionable (and understandable) that designers have lately preferred to keep their beauty looks simple, and the choice to eschew that effortless style in favor of a bold one feels innovative and inspired. During a season that’s so far been filled with natural-looking lips, it’s refreshing to see a color speak for itself, as we did at 3.1 Phillip Lim’s fall 2015 show today. Backstage, the makeup artist Francelle Daly professed her love affair with Nars Cosmetics’ newest lip color, VIP Red, taking us down a nostalgic burgundy punk path. “I fell in love with this shade when they showed it to me,” Daly said. “I remember in the ’90s and late ’80s, it was all about my red leather Dr. Martens boots.” The oxblood red lipstick is also the perfect complement to the clothing Lim showed: “It really fits into all these beautiful gold, brown and green tones that you see in the collection,” Daly said.

headline: Vaccinations Are States’ Call
abstract: Laws attempting to balance freedom with the common good have led to numerous personal religious exemptions that states have the power to eliminate or tighten.
lead_paragraph: Henning Jacobson just said no. Even though Massachusetts required it, he did not want to be vaccinated. He had had a bad reaction to a vaccine, and he opposed vaccination in general.

headline: Review: Estelle, Adam Birnbaum, and Sonny and the Sunsets Release New Albums
abstract: The latest from Estelle, the band Sonny and the Sunsets, and a collaboration led by Adam Birnbaum are among notable new albums.
lead_paragraph: ESTELLE

headline: Prison Architecture and the Question of Ethics
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Legality and morality are rising issues for architects who design solitary-confinement cells and death chambers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Faced with lawsuits and a growing mountain of damning research, New York City officials decided last month to ban solitary confinement for prison inmates 21 and younger. Just a few weeks earlier, the American Institute of Architects rejected a petition to censure members who design solitary-confinement cells and death chambers.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Company Displays Unorthodox Humor
abstract: Laughter, a sound not often heard at performances by this troupe, rippled through the crowd during Annie-B Parson’s “The Snow Falls in the Winter.”
lead_paragraph: On Friday at the Joyce Theater, an unusual sound rippled through the audience, a sound not often heard at performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company: laughter.

headline: Review: Dianne Reeves Leads Journey of Jazz History at Rose Hall
abstract: Ms. Reeves paid tribute to the past powerhouses Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan, while pushing the borders of the genre on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Trains of musical thought that wind from one part of the world into another and from one century to the next: A sense of boarding and changing trains on a far-reaching journey ran through Dianne Reeves’s concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Rose Hall on Friday evening.

headline: Hand of a Superhero
abstract: Three-dimensional printers create inexpensive, striking prosthetics that hint at comic-book superpowers for children who are missing fingers.
lead_paragraph: Dawson Riverman’s parents tried to help him make the best of it.

headline: Review: ‘A Kim Jong-il Production’ Recounts a Bizarre Legacy
abstract: Paul Fischer’s elaborately complicated book delves into the North Korean dictator’s grand passion for the film industry.
lead_paragraph: What do Laurence Olivier, Ingrid Bergman and Kim Jong-il have in common? “A Kim Jong-il Production,” Paul Fischer’s elaborately complicated book about that North Korean dictator’s grand passion for cinema, may be the first and last time anybody answers that question.

headline: Review: Jessye Norman’s Salute to the Love Song at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The soprano dabbled in the popular canon at a Valentine’s Day concert featuring songs by Jerome Kern, George Gershwin, Duke Ellington and others.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment late in Jessye Norman’s Carnegie Hall recital of popular standards on Saturday evening when the clouds parted, a shaft of lightning illuminated the hall, and an adoring audience that had waited patiently for a burst of vocal fireworks erupted in a spontaneous standing ovation.

headline: A New Copyright Complaint Against Richard Prince
abstract: The photographer Donald Graham has sent cease-and-desist letters to the artist Richard Prince and the Gagosian Gallery, requesting that they stop displaying or disseminating any artworks or other materials that include Mr. Graham’s images.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for the photographer Donald Graham has sent cease-and-desist letters to the artist Richard Prince and the Gagosian Gallery, requesting that they stop displaying or disseminating any artworks or other materials that include Mr. Graham’s images.

lead_paragraph: As consumers change the way they use their smartphones, surf the web and watch television, Vodafone is finding itself in need of a face-lift.

headline: At New York Fashion Week, Whatever Looks Warm Will Work
abstract: A review of collections from Carolina Herrera, Diane von Furstenberg, Prabal Gurung, Thakoon, The Row and Tommy Hilfiger.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like extreme weather to focus the mind. When you are freezing, or thinking about the fact that you are about to be freezing, or defrosting from being freezing, suddenly clothes take on whole new meaning. It’s cold outside! Where’s the design proposition to solve that?

headline: Preet Bharara’s Wall St. Task Force Has a Shifting Roster of Lawyers
abstract: Lawyers who have helped bring down big Wall Street targets are leaving public service for private law firms, but prosecutors say hungry talent is filling the gap.
lead_paragraph: They indicted the powerful hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, cracked down on insider trading and sent Bernard L. Madoff’s accomplices to prison.

headline: Water Crisis in São Paulo
abstract: The largest reservoir system serving São Paulo, Brazil, is near depletion. Drastic water rationing for millions of people may be needed.
lead_paragraph: The largest reservoir system serving São Paulo, Brazil, is near depletion. Drastic water rationing for millions of people may be needed.

keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: After several acquisitions, the international cable and wireless operator is reported to be a takeover target.
lead_paragraph: With operations in more than a dozen countries and a market value topping $40 billion, Liberty Global, the international cable and wireless operator, is hardly a start-up. Assembled by the media mogul John C. Malone, its chairman, the company quietly exerts its influence across a vast portion of the European media business.

headline: Troubles Mount for Kurt Busch, Accused of Domestic Assault
abstract: A protective order requiring Busch to stay away from his former girlfriend was granted, and Nascar could discipline him if he is charged with domestic assault.
lead_paragraph: A protective order requiring the Nascar driver Kurt Busch to stay away from his former girlfriend was granted Monday by a Delaware Family Court commissioner.

headline: Canadian Rail Strike Ends as Parties Agree to Arbitration
abstract: With the return to the bargaining table, Canadian Pacific Railway said it had begun the “ramp-up process” to resume train service.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A strike by about 3,000 locomotive engineers and conductors at the Canadian Pacific Railway unexpectedly ended on Monday, its second day, as both sides agreed to arbitration. The announcement came about half an hour before a bill was to be introduced in Parliament ordering the members of the union, the Teamsters Canada Rail Conference, back to work.

headline: Inside Man in Paris Jewelry Holdups Admits to His Role, and Stupidity
abstract: When diamond thieves disguised in women’s clothing struck a Harry Winston jewelry store with clockwork precision, it at first appeared to be a perfectly executed $100 million robbery.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When diamond thieves struck a Harry Winston jewelry store with clockwork precision, it appeared to be a perfectly executed $100 million heist. But a video of their 2008 caper in the capital’s golden triangle of luxury boutiques, playing in a courtroom here, offers a grainy trailer of comedy and greed.

headline: Westminster Dog Show Offers No Joy for Fans of a Charming Galoot
abstract: Nathan, a dog who was trying to become the first bloodhound to win the Best of Show prize, failed to defend his hound group title. He finished second to Miss P, a beagle.
lead_paragraph: Nathan, a 4-year-old bloodhound, was relaxing in his carrier on Monday morning at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. He had already won his breed competition and was biding his time — it would be nearly 12 hours — before he had to face group competition at night against other hounds.

headline: Southeast Region Hit by a Heavy Blast of Snow, With an Icy Cold Follow-Up
abstract: As snow, sleet and freezing rain continued falling, officials across the Mississippi Valley and the mid-Atlantic Seaboard, were shuffling their plans.
lead_paragraph: A winter storm churning through the Southeast dumped sleet, snow and freezing rain from the Mississippi River Valley to the mid-Atlantic Seaboard into the night on Monday. Flights were canceled, schools closed, Mardi Gras parades were rescheduled, and at least two state legislatures, in Kentucky and Tennessee, announced they would not meet on Tuesday as the storm continued into North Carolina.

headline: Numbers May Not Give a Complete Picture of Passenger Unruliness
abstract: While government statistics show a decline in reported incidents, an international body says they have been on the increase in recent years.
lead_paragraph: IN 2014, reported incidents of so-called unruly passengers were at the lowest level in 20 years, down 60 percent from the high of 310 in 2001, according to new data from the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: Lesley Gore, Teenage Voice of Heartbreak, Dies at 68
abstract: Ms. Gore’s hits included “It’s My Party,” “Judy’s Turn to Cry” and “You Don’t Own Me,” which became a feminist anthem.
lead_paragraph: Lesley Gore, who was a teenager in the 1960s when she recorded hit songs about heartbreak and resilience that went on to become feminist touchstones, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 68.

headline: Killing in Washington State Offers ‘Ferguson’ Moment for Hispanics
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The shooting of a man who threw rocks at the police in Pasco, Wash., has led to comparisons to Ferguson, Mo., and drawn condemnation from the Mexican president and multiple investigations.
lead_paragraph: PASCO, Wash. — Members of the Zambrano family began arriving here three decades ago, picking apples in nearby orchards. Over time they have become part of the fabric of this harvesting town, growing to more than 50 and settling in tiny candy-colored homes, some ringed by white picket fences.

headline: Shortage of Snow Aside, China Jumps Into Bid for 2022 Winter Games
abstract: With Kazakhstan as its only competition, Beijing stands to follow up its 2008 Summer Games with a new chance at spotlighting its wealth and power.
lead_paragraph: CHONGLI, China — Out here, in the land of China’s Winter Olympics ambitions, there is more propaganda than snow.

headline: Forget Barefoot; New Trendsetter in Running Shoes Is Cushioning
abstract: Some dismiss maximalist shoes as gimmicky or silly-looking. Others, from injury-prone joggers to Olympians, are converts.
lead_paragraph: Athletes who spent the past few years embracing or scorning barefoot running can now consider whether increasingly popular “maximalist” shoes — with their chunky, heavily cushioned soles — are the sport’s new wonder product.

headline: Arnaud de Borchgrave, Journalist Whose Life Was a Tale Itself, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. de Borchgrave was the son of a Belgian count and a storied foreign correspondent who covered, by his estimate, at least 18 wars.
lead_paragraph: Arnaud de Borchgrave, a Belgian count’s son and storied foreign correspondent who cabled back bell-ringing scoops throughout the Cold War decades, often from the battlefield, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 88.

headline: Despite Amenities, South Street Seaport Redevelopment Plans Stall Over a High-Rise
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Affordable Housing', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A $1.5 billion project that promises to build a school and affordable housing has run up against opposition at a time when high-rise development seems to be proceeding unchecked in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: For years, a developer at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan has been planning a $1.5 billion redevelopment that it said would rehabilitate crumbling piers, preserve landmark buildings and bring new vitality to the 400-year-old historic district on the East River.

headline: As One Knicks Experiment Ends, Trying to Guess What the Next Will Be
abstract: As the Knicks part ways with Amar’e Stoudemire and prepare for the likelihood of losing Carmelo Anthony for the season, the shape of things to come is increasingly unclear.
lead_paragraph: By late Sunday night, the energized atmosphere that had engulfed Madison Square Garden for the All-Star Game weekend had been replaced by the furious activity of workers preparing for the Westminster Dog Show.

headline: European Stocks Shrug Off Faltering Talks on Greek Debt
abstract: A standoff between Greece and its European lenders appeared to reach a new low, causing stocks in Japan and Australia to drop on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European stocks fell early Tuesday, then recovered by midday despite weakness in Athens, as investors reacted to news that Greece and its European creditors appeared to have reached a fresh stalemate over whether to continue with a bailout that expires at the end of the month.

headline: Lance Armstrong’s Ugly Detour From Road to Redemption
abstract: Armstrong’s blueprint to win back public trust — by admitting his wrongs and showing contrition — didn’t last long.
lead_paragraph: Lance Armstrong once told me that it would take maybe six months to a year for him to rebuild his reputation after he admitted lying to the world about his drug use.

headline: Men Seeing ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Have the Same Reason as Women: Curiosity
abstract: The much-hyped film adaption of the erotic novel, whose target audience is women, attracted men, too, though they were far outnumbered.
lead_paragraph: The romantics, the film aficionados, the ones left holding their girlfriend’s purse outside the ladies’ room. Though they were far outnumbered, they, too, were submissive to the hype. They were the men in Grey.

headline: U.S. Intensifies Effort to Blunt ISIS’ Message
abstract: A tiny State Department agency will be revamped and expanded to coordinate existing attempts to counter the Islamic State’s propaganda machine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is revamping its effort to counter the Islamic State’s propaganda machine, acknowledging that the terrorist group has been far more effective in attracting new recruits, financing and global notoriety than the United States and its allies have been in thwarting it.

headline: Yankees Plan to Honor Four Former Players
abstract: Bernie Williams, Willie Randolph, Andy Pettitte and Jorge Posada will be honored with a plaque in Monument Park, and all except Randolph will have their numbers retired.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the Yankees may do on the field this season to generate interest and ticket sales, it is clear that they will also lean heavily on their recent history. On four separate home dates this season, the Yankees will honor four different players, three of whom will have their numbers retired, the team announced Monday.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: 2000 Novelty Hit
abstract: Bruce Haight brings man’s best friend to heel in today’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It has been a rough winter so far, with a seemingly endless supply of bad news, weather-wise. We could use a puzzle that puts a smile on our collective faces, yes?

headline: Hurricane Sandy Victims Say Damage Reports Were Altered
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Flood Insurance', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Lawyers in suits related to the storm say they have found at least 500 cases in which engineering reports were altered to minimize payments.
lead_paragraph: When Frank Johnston’s insurance carrier rejected his claim that flooding from Hurricane Sandy had severely damaged the foundation of his Fire Island home, the company cited an engineering report that seemed to establish his problems were “unrelated” to the storm, and were caused instead by the “long-term deterioration” of wooden piers beneath his house.

headline: With Lunar New Year Show, Another Link to China for a New York Fireworks Family
abstract: Planning a show to commemorate the Lunar New Year is just the latest deal with China for the Gruccis, who have been doing business with the country since 1979.
lead_paragraph: Viewed from one angle, a hopeful tableau of Chinese-American relations unfolded over the weekend on a pier in Red Hook, Brooklyn: American and Chinese pyrotechnicians loading three barges with equipment for a major fireworks display in honor of the Lunar New Year, using Chinese-made explosives and American-made hardware.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 16, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Sam Andrew, Guitarist for Big Brother and the Holding Company, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Andrew, a musician who played a key role in Janis Joplin’s early career, was a founder of the band, part of the San Francisco sound.
lead_paragraph: Sam Andrew, who as a founder of the band Big Brother and the Holding Company was a mainstay of the fertile San Francisco rock scene of the 1960s and played a key role in Janis Joplin’s early career, died on Thursday in San Rafael, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Federal Offices in Washington Shut Down Over Snow
abstract: Snow shuts the federal government’s offices in Washington for the day.
lead_paragraph: Boston may be digging out of nearly seven feet of snow, but in Washington, predictions of about seven inches of snow are enough to force the federal government to close its District of Columbia offices.

headline: Rangers Erupt Late and Shock Islanders
abstract: The Rangers were down by two early in the third period, but they scored three times to move within 2 points of the first-place Islanders.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Solving the Islanders has been a conundrum for the Rangers. Three straight decisive losses would drive any team into frustration mode.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Recap: Help a Nacho Out
abstract: An episode that briefly shows the limits of Bob Odenkirk’s acting range.

abstract: A lot of voltage running through this episode. And not all of it is from Tasers and cattle prods.

headline: Villanova Serves Notice With Romp Over Seton Hall
abstract: Despite being one of the top-ranked teams in the country for the entire season and earning 24 wins, the Wildcats have gone virtually unnoticed.
lead_paragraph: VILLANOVA, Pa. — After Monday night’s game at the Pavilion, Villanova Coach Jay Wright and Seton Hall Coach Kevin Willard exchanged back slaps and compliments. Willard laughed at a joke by Wright but then turned serious.

headline: Jim Jarmusch Soundtracks Surrealism With His Rock Band Sqürl
abstract: The independent film icon has created a live score for the silent films of the visual artist Man Ray.
lead_paragraph: “Music is very much a release for me because it’s so immediate,” says the director Jim Jarmusch. Though Jarmusch is best known as the radically independent mind behind art-house classics like “Down by Law” and “Dead Man,” the filmmaker is also a member of the “amorphous” post-rock group known as Sqürl. (The band composed the scores to the recent Jarmusch films “The Limits of Control” and “Only Lovers Left Alive.”) Tonight, Sqürl will debut a new soundtrack — not to one of Jarmusch’s own films, but to four silent works from the surrealist Man Ray. The concerts are part of WNYC’s New Sounds Live series, Silent Films/Live Music, which pairs movies, both classic and contemporary, with performances from acclaimed musicians. (The current run of shows also features the composer Alfonso Villalonga and the Wordless Music Orchestra performing the score to the Spanish film “Blancanieves.”)

abstract: The group, Move NY, recommends fees at the East River bridges and on Manhattan roads crossing 60th Street. Its plan could raise $1.5 billion in annual revenue.
lead_paragraph: A group of transit advocates will release a proposal on Tuesday to overhaul New York City’s bridge toll system and to raise money for the region’s transportation needs.

headline: Measuring Inequality Trends During the Great Recession
abstract: A more detailed look at the data on incomes since the financial crisis began in 2007.
lead_paragraph: This post discusses in some more technical detail the issues that are the subject of David Leonhardt’s Feb. 17 column.

headline: Inequality Has Actually Not Risen Since the Financial Crisis
abstract: The income declines for the rich were steeper than for any other group, while the government has done more to help the middle class and poor.
lead_paragraph: The notion that income inequality has continued to rise over the past decade is part of the conventional wisdom. You’ve no doubt heard versions: The rich just keep getting richer. Inequality is higher than ever. Nearly all of the gains from the economic recovery have gone to the top 1 percent.

headline: Enrollment Period for Health Insurance Ends; Now the Tax Penalties Start
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Fines (Penalties)']

lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act’s second open enrollment period ended on Sunday. Well, almost. Some computer problems over the weekend have led the administration to give a one-week extension to people who tried and failed to sign up.

headline: Dealt Setback, Obama Puts Off Immigrant Plan
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: President Obama vowed to appeal a federal judge’s decision to block his administration’s sweeping immigration plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day before hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants were to begin applying for work permits and legal protection, administration officials on Tuesday postponed President Obama’s sweeping executive actions on immigration indefinitely, saying they had no choice but to comply with a federal judge’s last-minute order halting the programs.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE ITALIAN AMERICANS More than four million Italians emigrated to the United States from 1880 to 1924, mostly coming from southern Italy and Sicily to escape poverty. This series, narrated by the actor Stanley Tucci and written by John Maggio, spans four generations of Italian-Americans, beginning with the large wave of immigration in the late 19th century and continuing to the present day. Along the way, the two-part series uses archival material and interviews with experts and prominent Italian-Americans (like Mario M. Cuomo, above; Tony Bennett; and Gay Talese, to name a few) to tell the stories of those who played important roles in shaping the relationships between Italians and Americans, and how immigrants, once considered outsiders, have risen over time to become leaders in business, politics and the arts.

headline: Debating the Rules and Ethics of Digital Photojournalism
abstract: The disqualification of a large number of images from this year’s World Press Photo contest has generated a debate over the need for more explicit rules on what is — and what isn’t — acceptable in digital photography.
lead_paragraph: Significant questions have arisen after a large number of images were disqualified from this year’s World Press Photo competition because of excessive — and sometimes blatant — post-processing. After independent experts examined the images being considered for prizes in the final rounds, and presented their findings to the jury, 20 percent of the photos were disqualified by the judges. This was often because of significant addition or subtraction to the image content.

headline: The Roadblock to Sentencing Reform
abstract: The new chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee opposes almost any reduction of mandatory minimum sentences.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, members of Congress have been doing a lot of talking about the need to broadly reform harsh federal sentencing laws, which are a central factor in the explosion of the federal prison population. It’s an overdue conversation, and one of the few in which Democrats and Republicans find some agreement — but, so far, they have nothing to show for it.

headline: The Moral Injury
abstract: The horrors of PTSD are more complex than most of us know. Sufferers feel exile, and healing must be moral as well as psychological.
lead_paragraph: David J. Morris returned from Iraq with a case of post-traumatic stress disorder. The former Marine turned war correspondent was plagued by nightmares. His imagination careened out of control; he envisioned fireballs erupting while on trips to the mall. His emotions could go numb, but his awareness was hypervigilant. Images and smells from the war were tattooed eternally fresh on his brain, and he circled back to them remorselessly.

headline: Reform the Condominium
abstract: It’s become too much of a vehicle for financial speculation.
lead_paragraph: FROM New York to Miami, from South Padre Island, Tex., to Park City, Utah, the American condominium has become the hot new investment for global capital. In Manhattan, the trend is so pronounced that a whole new category of real estate has emerged around the southern edges of Central Park: supertall, ultraluxury buildings, with more than half of the homes being sold to anonymous buyers (some perhaps looking to stash ill-gotten gains) who rarely, if ever, occupy them. The city, meanwhile, struggles to produce sufficient housing for those who do live here.

headline: Morning Agenda: Greek Bailout Talks Collapse
abstract: European officials hand Athens an ultimatum. | A shifting roster at Preet Bharara’s elite Wall Street unit. | Liberty Global is reported to be a takeover target. | The government is being secretive about its decision to expropriate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac earnings.
lead_paragraph: GREEK BAILOUT TALKS COLLAPSE | European officials handed Athens an ultimatum on Monday: Agree by Friday to continue with a bailout program or risk the funding that the country needs to avoid a default, James Kanter and Liz Alderman write in The New York Times. The demand appeared to be part of a strategy by eurozone creditors to get Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece and his finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, to back away from their anti-austerity pledges. In exchange, eurozone officials said they would consider rolling back some of the austerity terms at a later date.

headline: ‘Animated Life: Pangea’
abstract: This animated documentary tells the story of the polar explorer Alfred Wegener, the unlikely scientist behind continental drift theory.
lead_paragraph: Just as biology tells us about the origin of life, geology tells how our physical world came to be. The field explains how the mountains and rivers, oceans and shores were born. Surprisingly, one of the first people to propose one of the most important theories in geology, continental drift — the idea that the continents were once pressed together and have since drifted apart — wasn’t a geologist at all.

headline: 1965: Troops Clash After Bombing
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Ugandan and Congolese troops clash in 1965.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Congolese troops crossed the border and exchanged fire with Ugandan troops south of Lake Albert, Uganda Minister of Internal Affairs Feli Onama announced today [Feb. 17]. Other Congo troops crossed the Ishasha river into southwest Uganda and tried to enter the Uganda customs post there. ‘‘In both cases they were forced to return into the Congo,’’ Mr. Onama said. The border with the Congo is already closed following a weekend bomb attack of two Uganda villages. In Nairobi, Kenya, the government there warned the United States of ‘‘the serious repercussions arising from its policy on the Congo.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1965

lead_paragraph: Among seven potential Democratic presidential contenders, Hillary Clinton is the overwhelming favorite — and the third-most liberal candidate. How the other candidates are arrayed on an ideological spectrum could make her run for the White House easier than the last time out.

headline: IBM, G.E. and Others Create Big Data Alliance

headline: Medicine Given Even Before Smokers Are Ready to Quit Is Found to Help Them
abstract: A study has found that even for people who are not ready to stop smoking immediately, medicine taken over time can improve their chances of eventually quitting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Doctors typically wait until smokers are ready to quit before prescribing pills to help them do it. But a new study has found that even for those who are not ready to stop smoking immediately, medicine taken over time can substantially improve their chances of eventually quitting.

Eyeing an open door, one bird made a vague attempt to wander away, before it was gently returned to the brood.

headline: Dibbly-Dobbly? Silly Mid Off? Slog Sweep? What It All Means
abstract: With the Cricket World Cup underway in Australia and New Zealand, here is a quick look at a small fraction of the marvelously weird lexicon of cricket.
lead_paragraph: The Cricket World Cup is underway in Australia and New Zealand. But unless you are from Britain, India, South Africa or a few other places, you are very likely so cricket-challenged that you don’t know a googly from a doosra. Fear not! Here is a quick look at a small fraction of the marvelously weird lexicon of cricket.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Property Taxes', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals']

lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Lamborghinis, Porsches and Bentleys fill the driveways of multimillion-dollar villas in Sentosa Cove. Yachts line the 400-berth marina nearby. A number of homes have guardhouses for security.

headline: Fast Action Needed to Stave Off Greek Tragedy
abstract: Compromise is needed by both Greece’s radical new leftist government and its eurozone creditors to avoid a disaster, Hugo Dixon writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Greece desperately needs a quick fix. Time is running so short that a deal is needed in the next few days to stop Athens from going bust. That will be, at best, a short-term patch while a long-term solution is worked out.

headline: Sharp Rise in Occupational Therapy Cases at New York’s Schools
abstract: Nearly 42,000 public school students have been referred to the treatments, designed to help with things like managing sensitivities to noise or improving fine motor skills.
lead_paragraph: A class of first graders at Public School 503 in Brooklyn sat on the floor one recent Friday, cross-legged on an alphabet-themed rug.

headline: Shuko
abstract: Kaiseki and omakase sushi surprises in this new restaurant south of Union Square.
lead_paragraph: Kaiseki and omakase sushi surprises in this new restaurant south of Union Square.

headline: Restaurant Review: Shuko in the East Village
abstract: The chefs Jimmy Lau and Nick Kim prepare elevated and memorable Japanese food at the new restaurant Shuko.
lead_paragraph: “You like spicy?” Jimmy Lau asked from behind the counter at Shuko, the new restaurant just below Union Square where he and his partner, Nick Kim, prepare an elevated and memorable species of Japanese food. Before I could answer, he handed me a spicy tuna roll that would casually knock over my ideas about spicy tuna rolls, and spice, and tuna.

headline: For Fall/Winter 2015, Designers Cozy Up to Buffalo Plaid
abstract: Cool, downtown versions of the unofficial hunter’s uniform graced the runways at Coach, Alexander Wang and 3.1 Phillip Lim.
lead_paragraph: Uniform dressing, from military greens to prep-school pleats, has always been a popular inspiration for designers, and this season, several have taken on the unofficial uniform of hunters: the oversize checks of buffalo plaid. First, at Coach, Stuart Vevers put a spin on the classic American print with pastel hues, balancing out the mostly black collection. Buffalo plaid also brightened another show consisting otherwise of almost entirely black looks: Alexander Wang’s, to which the designer added a splash of color with a red buffalo plaid coat shown halfway through. And the 3.1 Phillip Lim show featured the print expressed in multiple colorways: a classic black and white with red accents near the beginning, and an earthier version in beige, black and ochre near the end. Lim’s eye-catching interpretation, cool and a little tough, was perfect for his downtown girl.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Maleficent’
abstract: The costume designer was brought in late and then asked to do not one but eight looks for the main character. That’s when Team Maleficent was born.
lead_paragraph: Though nominated twice for an Oscar already, the costume designer Anna B. Sheppard was taken by surprise last month, she said, when her assistant interrupted a fitting with Morgan Freeman to announce it had happened again: she was up for her costume design for “Maleficent,” Disney’s “Sleeping Beauty” tale told from the antagonist’s point of view.

headline: Review: With ‘Queen and Country,’ John Boorman Continues a Tale
abstract: Mr. Boorman’s new film picks up where “Hope and Glory” left off, with a young Briton as he comes into adulthood during the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: To appreciate “Queen and Country,” John Boorman’s gently nostalgic, quasi-autobiographical film about Britain in the early 1950s, it isn’t entirely necessary to have seen his earlier “Hope and Glory.” You should, of course, see it, if you haven’t already: One of a handful of great movies that look at World War II through the eyes of a child, “Hope and Glory” is distinguished by mischievous good humor and by the unashamed acknowledgment that war can be fun as well as horrible.

headline: Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans
abstract: Alex Rodriguez made his first public comment on his long suspension since he issued a defiant statement in January 2014, on the day the suspension went into effect.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Preparing to make a highly scrutinized return to baseball after a long suspension for drug use, Alex Rodriguez issued a brief, handwritten statement on Tuesday afternoon to say he was sorry for his behavior.

lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after announcing that it would accept the gift of an art collection amassed by a Nazi-era dealer, including several pieces known to have been looted from Jewish families, the Kunstmuseum Bern expressed frustration Tuesday that a dispute over a will was preventing it from taking possession of the works.

headline: Reclaiming Puerto Rico’s Food Paradise
abstract: A movement of loosely affiliated cooks, farmers and activists is trying to reclaim the gastronomic paradise at their fingertips.
lead_paragraph: VIEQUES, P.R. — The sun was starting to recline on the horizon, but as the chef Jose Enrique slid a beaten-up Ford Explorer into a parking space here at an easygoing beachside hotel called El Blok, he admitted that his menu for this Saturday evening was still up in the air. What would he be cooking?

headline: Princeton Gets a $300 Million Trove of Rare Books
abstract: The collection, given by William H. Scheide, includes a Gutenberg Bible, an original printing of the Declaration of Independence, all four of Shakespeare’s Folios and more.
lead_paragraph: Princeton University has announced the largest gift in its history: a trove of rare books valued at nearly $300 million, including a Gutenberg Bible, an original printing of the Declaration of Independence, all four of Shakespeare’s Folios and significant musical manuscripts written by Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, Schubert and Wagner.

The state paid about $2,000 a month to clean the Netanyahus’ private home in the seaside town of Caesarea, though the family spent most of its time in Jerusalem.

headline: Rethinking Money, Not as Good or Bad but as a Tool
abstract: A shift in thinking changes attitudes about saving and spending; we are no longer focused on positive or negative but on the outcome of our actions.
lead_paragraph: Almost everything we’re taught about money is focused on spending it and saving it. Parents, teachers and even personal finance books discuss saving money as keeping it, increasing it and controlling it. Saving money involves figuring out ways to get more of it, to build a bigger cushion. We’re taught that’s the ultimate goal.

headline: Southeast Snowstorm Leaves Beauty and Danger
abstract: The governors of Kentucky, North Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia declared states of emergency, and drivers were urged to stay off the roads.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Communities across the Southeast were paralyzed by snow and ice, left without power and rushing to clear frozen roadways Tuesday morning after a pounding winter storm, with officials warning of more trouble that may come with a second round of cold weather later this week.

headline: Coach’s Ph.D. in Psychology Is Applied on Court and in Classroom
abstract: John Tauer of Division III St. Thomas in St. Paul is one of the few men’s basketball coaches who teach courses, and he uses his academic expertise to help motivate his players.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Thirty-two students sat at long tables in a University of St. Thomas classroom one recent morning, reviewing notes or checking their smartphones, when John Tauer walked in. Tauer wore a purple dress shirt and gray pleated slacks under his black topcoat, but not the tie and blazer he would wear that night for his other job, coaching the St. Thomas men’s basketball team.

keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Whales and Whaling']
abstract: A determined filmmaking team reaches out to the crowd to finance a film on a mysterious and lonely whale.
lead_paragraph: If a crowd-funding push succeeds, a unique and solitary whale known as “52” may soon have its silver screen moment.

headline: ​Advice for Finding Your Groove
abstract: Getting an email “obsession” under control, focusing on the task at hand, and finding time for gratitude and exercise.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I invited Christine Carter, author of “The Sweet Spot: How to Find Your Groove at Home and at Work,” to coach a few of us through the real world issues that get in our way when it comes to settling into a happy, functional routine at home and at work.

headline: Fishing for Sweaters for Fall 2015
abstract: A crop of fresh takes on the classic fisherman’s sweater appeals to a freezing fashion set during the New York shows.
lead_paragraph: Never have the runways looked so tempting, as designers continue to introduce fur-hooded parkas, oversize shearling coats and rugged boots for fall — an appealing lot for the fashion set, which continues to trudge through snow and slush from one venue to the next. And a few fresh takes on the classic fisherman cable-knit sweaters are in the running for the coziest crop yet of winter-weather staples on fall 2015 runways. At Coach and Alexander Wang, the cream-colored tops — decked out with fringe and stud details, respectively — brightened up otherwise dark collections. And in Vera Wang’s gender-bending fashion show today, her oversize rendition of the traditional knit again lightened things up — especially paired with long shorts and high booties.

headline: The Chevrolet Trax Is a Crossover in a Smaller Package
abstract: The vehicle, which shares its architecture with the Buick Encore, is like a small hatchback dressed in North Face gear.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS shun station wagons and hatchbacks, but they cannot get enough of sport utility vehicles and crossovers. The Chevrolet Trax, a name that word processors desperately want to correct, is much like a small hatchback dressed in North Face gear. It’s something you’ll be seeing much more of — the subcompact crossover. Look for Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3 and Honda HR-V at a campsite (or Jamba Juice) in the near future.

headline: Shake-Up at Mattress Company May Be Due
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Mattresses', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The investment firm H Partners raises reasonable questions about the board, chief executive and earnings of Tempur Sealy, Stephanie Rogan of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: The “burning bed” is flaring up again. The investment firm H Partners, complaining of a dormant stock price at Tempur Sealy and private equity directors asleep on the job, wants the top executive replaced and a seat on the board. A torturous financial history suggests it’s probably time to shake up the mattress company and the industry again.

headline: U.N. Envoy to Syria Announces Possible Truce in Aleppo
abstract: A senior United Nations envoy said Tuesday that he had persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing and shelling the northern city of Aleppo as part of a proposed six-week truce.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In what could be a diplomatic breakthrough in the Syrian conflict, a senior United Nations envoy said Tuesday that he had persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing and shelling the northern city of Aleppo as part of a proposed six-week truce.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments Over G.M.’s Exposure to Recall Suits
abstract: A federal judge will determine if a provision of the company’s July 2009 bankruptcy agreement shields it from lawsuits over a defective ignition switch.
lead_paragraph: In the fraught summer of 2009, the federal bankruptcy judge Robert E. Gerber proved to be a crucial figure in General Motors’ struggle for survival. With the economy in deep recession and the once-dominant automaker bleeding red ink, he presided over a fast-track bankruptcy process that allowed G.M. to remake itself — with the help of $49 billion from federal taxpayers — as a new company free of onerous liabilities.

abstract: A market inspired by a Japanese depachika, a lavish department store food hall, is opening in Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal; a Polish sandwich; a pie shop; and more.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo must soon schedule a special election to fill the vacant congressional seat representing Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, or a federal court will do it for him, a judge ordered on Tuesday.

headline: Getting Closer to the California Print Junkie Who Designed Jay Z’s “Holy Grail”
abstract: The artist Brian Roettinger, who brings his ‘zine-inspired sensibility to some of music’s biggest acts, on his greatest influences.
lead_paragraph: From a young age, the artist, graphic designer and California native Brian Roettinger grew up acutely aware of design in his daily life — in large part, he says, “because of the stuff my parents and grandparents had around the house, including a vast record collection, not to mention quintessential suburban ’70s furniture. Looking and talking about photos was a common affair in our household. My mother, meanwhile, would make macramé and paint.”

abstract: Bermuda shorts and bucket hats usher in the season of the septuagenarian.
lead_paragraph: Bermuda shorts and bucket hats usher in the season of the septuagenarian.

headline: When Consumers Don’t Spend
abstract: Economists have lowered their projections for growth in the first quarter, as well they should.
lead_paragraph: Consumer spending is at the heart of a strong economy. It is the source of pay and profits. It is the engine of economic activity.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Crusades (Christianity)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: A response to Ta-Nehisi Coates on the president’s prayer breakfast speech.
lead_paragraph: Finishing up business left undone last week, I’m grateful to Ta-Nehisi Coates for taking the time to critique my own critique of President Obama’s prayer breakfast speech. A few thoughts in response, working my way around his points.

headline: Ashton Carter Sworn In as Secretary of Defense
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The oath of office took place in a small White House ceremony presided over by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who called Mr. Carter “a thinker and a doer.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ashton B. Carter was sworn in Tuesday as the 25th secretary of defense — and the fourth to serve the Obama administration — taking the oath of office in a small White House ceremony where Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called him “a thinker and a doer.”

headline: Carter Sworn In as Defense Secretary
abstract: Ashton B. Carter pledged his commitment to help the president “make the best possible decisions” during his swearing-in ceremony as defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Ashton B. Carter pledged his commitment to help the president “make the best possible decisions” during his swearing-in ceremony as defense secretary.

headline: Nashville’s Clandestine Black Schools
abstract: The lost history of black-owned and -operated schools in the antebellum South.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, March 4, 1833, the nation’s seventh president and Tennessee’s most famous son, Andrew Jackson, was sworn in for his second term. On that same day another Tennessean, Alphonso M. Sumner, clandestinely opened a school for black children in Nashville. It was a bold move: In the wake of Nat Turner’s uprising two years earlier, Southern whites had begun a particularly violent reign of terror against black efforts at organizing institutions like schools and churches – were critical to the black struggle for freedom, justice and civil rights. But Sumner, a free black barber, bet that the paternalistic sympathies of white Nashvillians would allow them to turn a blind-eye to a school for free black children, owned and operated by him.

headline: An Encore of Over-the-Knee Boots at Rodarte
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a pair in step with the Mulleavy sisters’ fall 2015 collection — a mashup of textures and materials.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Wheeldon Nutcracker for the Joffrey
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon will choreograph a new “Nutcracker” for December 2016 for the Joffrey Ballet in Chicago, replacing Robert Joffrey’s version.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Wheeldon will create a new “Nutcracker” in December 2016 for Chicago’s Joffrey Ballet, the company announced on Tuesday. The new production will mark the end of a Chicago tradition; Robert Joffrey, who founded the Joffrey Ballet with Gerald Arpino, choreographed “The Nutcracker” for the company in 1987, and it has been performed each December since the company moved to Chicago from New York in 1995.

headline: Re-election Bid Offers Test of Mayor’s Appeal to ‘Two Chicagos’
abstract: Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s incumbent mayor, is viewed as the front-runner for re-election next week, but a worry for his campaign is how he will do with black voters.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In some of this city’s predominantly black neighborhoods on the South Side, Rahm Emanuel was not well known when he swept into the mayor’s office in 2011. After all, he had been a congressman from the other, mostly white side of town. But most voters knew that President Obama, himself a South Sider, had trusted him to be White House chief of staff, and that backing went a long way. Mr. Emanuel won every majority black ward in the city.

headline: Israeli Girl Injured in Palestinian Rock-Throwing Attack in 2013 Dies
abstract: The 4-year-old girl, Adele Biton, died after severe pneumonia that relatives said was complicated by neurological trauma caused by the attack.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A 4-year-old Israeli girl who was critically injured in a car accident caused by Palestinian rock throwers two years ago died on Tuesday after a severe bout of pneumonia that relatives said was complicated by her neurological trauma.

headline: Fallout Over Argentine Prosecutor’s Death Draws International Tensions
abstract: Foreign Minister Héctor Timerman warns the United States, Israel and others to stay out of the case of the mysterious death of the prosecutor Alberto Nisman.
lead_paragraph: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina — Fallout from the mysterious death of a federal prosecutor raised diplomatic tensions between Argentina and the United States on Tuesday, on the eve of a controversial march in the prosecutor’s honor that has fueled unease between the government and parts of the judiciary.

headline: Spanish Judge Drops Charges Against 9 Priests in Sexual Abuse Case
abstract: A Granada judge said only one of the 12 people indicted in the case would be tried because the statute of limitations had expired against the others.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A Spanish judge leading an investigation into accusations of sexual abuse against priests in the southern city of Granada has decided that the case can proceed against only one of the priests because the statute of limitations has expired for the lower-level criminal charges filed against 11 other people, including nine priests.

headline: A Child, Coping, with Autism and Everything Else
abstract: Every once in a while, I can help him. Mostly by getting off his back about what helps him.
lead_paragraph: My son has started turning. Turning his body, I mean, pivoting 360 degrees on the threshold before going through doors, mostly, though sometimes it’s an N.B.A.-like fake left or right just before he starts to move forward. Once we noticed, we asked him about it and got, eventually, a pretty clear answer: “I was turned the wrong way.” Ah.

headline: ‘How Can We Find More People Like You?’
abstract: Airbnb tries to take its trust revolution to Japan.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb tries to take its trust revolution to Japan.

headline: To the Readers: Alex Rodriguez Is Not Going Away. Sorry.
abstract: Rodriguez won a ring but never did find a moral compass, going right back to cheating and lying to all who would listen when he was caught. He served a yearlong suspension, and here we are again.
lead_paragraph: Tents are perfect for the circus. If Alex Rodriguez had used one for his latest apology, he might as well have shown up in grease paint, floppy shoes and a rainbow wig. Rodriguez, the clown prince of baseball, would be setting himself up for laughs.

headline: Review: Matthew Perry in an ‘Odd Couple’ Refitted for a New Century
abstract: The CBS remake of the classic TV series, with Matthew Perry as Oscar Madison and Thomas Lennon as Felix Unger, isn’t so bad. It may even work.
lead_paragraph: In comedy, opposites don’t attract. Instead they repel each other attractively. And by that standard, the CBS remake of “The Odd Couple,” that has its premiere on Thursday, isn’t so bad. It may even work.

headline: Review: A ‘La Donna del Lago’ With Melting Tenderness at the Met
abstract: Joyce DiDonato stars in Rossini’s tale of Scottish rivals in love and politics.
lead_paragraph: For years, the superb mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato has sung “Tanti affetti,” the final showpiece aria from Rossini’s “La Donna del Lago” (The Lady of the Lake), as a surefire encore in recitals. But on Monday night on the Metropolitan Opera stage, vocal display seemed the last thing on her mind.

headline: Review: Ensemble ACJW Performs Meredith Monk’s Instrumental ‘Backlight’
abstract: There was much to admire in “Backlight,” but it barely hinted at the sense of adventure and startling elements integral to much of Ms. Monk’s work.
lead_paragraph: The composer Meredith Monk is known for her uncanny ability to coax the human voice into sonorities both ethereal and startling. Ms. Monk, also a dancer, singer, choreographer, director and filmmaker, has been honing this extended vocal technique since the 1960s, championed by her own ensemble. Her otherworldly vocal quilts are often a patchwork of noises, cries and ululations, interwoven with chanting and humming. Other works are more lyrical, with plaintive, folk-tinged vocal lines stretched over somber, spare accompaniments.

headline: Review: Blue Heron Performs ‘Missa De plus en plus’ at Corpus Christi Church
abstract: The Boston ensemble delved into Johannes Ockeghem’s Mass of that title, which was influenced by a love song with the same name by an earlier composer.
lead_paragraph: Clever or pretty? Spiritual or erotic? When it comes to the music of the 15th-century Franco-Flemish composer Johannes Ockeghem, certain distinctions become moot.

headline: Review: ‘Cop Show,’ Colin Quinn’s Police Procedural Satire
abstract: In this web series, Mr. Quinn skewers TV police shows and himself.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Colin Quinn is a cunning self-deprecator: He makes fun of his own middling level of fame with an aggressive edge that suggests that he really ought to be bigger by now. On Twitter, he draws attention by encouraging his haters, retweeting their most imaginative insults. (Recent sample: “My girlfriend and I are going to play the CQ game. Every time you come on screen, we drink arsenic.”)

headline: Mac Wellman, a Playwriting Mentor Whose Only Mantra Is Oddity
abstract: A professor at Brooklyn College has helped to turn out some of the city’s most wildly inventive young playwrights by shooing them out of their comfort zones.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Mac Wellman, the Donald I. Fine Distinguished Professor of Play Writing, sat at the head of a table in a Brooklyn College classroom. It was the first meeting of the semester, and he needed to arrange tutorials with his graduate students. He asked them to draw up a plan for the term’s work: something small, something secret.

headline: Robert E. Herzstein, Who Foiled Nixon Over White House Tapes, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Herzstein successfully sued on behalf of historians and journalists to prevent former President Richard M. Nixon from removing or destroying his White House papers and tapes after his resignation.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Herzstein, who successfully sued on behalf of historians and journalists to prevent former President Richard M. Nixon from removing and even destroying his White House papers and tapes after his resignation, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

headline: Hungary Keeps Visit by Putin Low-Key as It Seeks to Repair Relations With West
abstract: A trip to Hungary by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was a far cry from the triumphant reception he received in Serbia in October. Mr. Putin kept largely out of public view in Budapest.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — When Vladimir V. Putin played host at the Kremlin early last year to Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, the notion of a reciprocal visit that would bring the Russian president onto European Union soil seemed perfectly in keeping with a whole series of stick-in-the-eye moves toward Europe by the two leaders in recent years.

headline: Rand Paul Is Looking to April to Announce Plan to Run for President, Associates Say
abstract: The timing of the announcement would position him ahead of his potential Republican rivals and allow him to begin raising money directly for his campaign 10 months before the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul is eyeing April 7 as the day he will announce his plans to run for president, people close to him said, a step that would position him ahead of his potential Republican rivals as a declared candidate and allow him to begin raising money directly for his campaign 10 months before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: After Public Acrimony, Quieter Steps by Mayor de Blasio and Police to Mend Rift
abstract: A secret meeting between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Edward D. Mullins of the Sergeants Benevolent Association, an outspoken critic, helped achieve détente.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusual lunch date, powered by political winds and a heap of pastrami: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police union leader who had, weeks earlier, appraised the mayor publicly as a “total nincompoop.”

headline: Facing Suits, a Nursing Home in California Seeks Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Nursing Homes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']

lead_paragraph: A California nursing home fined by the state for substandard care and facing multiple lawsuits by patients and their families has taken the extreme measure of filing for bankruptcy protection in the face of millions of dollars in potential payouts.

headline: Give Greece Room to Maneuver
abstract: European lenders must give Greece some slack in repaying its debt to prevent the dangerous possibility of a default and a crisis in the euro system.
lead_paragraph: Greece’s lenders, most notably Germany, insist that they are defending important principles: a country must pay its debts, and the long-term success of the euro depends on everyone abiding by the rules.

headline: Veterans in Congress Bring Rare Perspective to Authorizing War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'War Powers Act (1973)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan now serving in Congress have emerged as some of the most important voices in the debate over whether to give President Obama a broad authorization for a military campaign against the Islamic State or something much more limiting.

headline: Americans May See Appeal of Medical Tourism in Cuba
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Medicine and Health', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Americans Abroad', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']

lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Anuja Agrawal jumped on the phone. President Obama had just announced that he would restore diplomatic relations with Cuba — and Ms. Agrawal, who runs a medical tourism company in Orlando, Fla., did not want to miss her opening.
