headline: Doctors Strive to Do Less Harm by Inattentive Care
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Inattentive medical care is now seen as a real harm. To remedy the situation, many hospitals and doctors are surveying those in their care.
lead_paragraph: Suffering. The very word made doctors uncomfortable. Medical journals avoided it, instructing authors to say that patients “ ‘have’ a disease or complications or side effects rather than ‘suffer’ or ‘suffer from’ them,” said Dr. Thomas H. Lee, the chief medical officer of Press Ganey, a company that surveys hospital patients.

headline: A Different (and Surprising) Economic Tale of New York City Emerges
abstract: By playing to its strengths beyond Wall Street, the city has created jobs and boosted the economy.
lead_paragraph: When Bill de Blasio ran for mayor in 2013, he declared that New York City’s middle class wasn’t just shrinking, but also stood “in real danger of disappearing altogether.” The claim was part of the tale-of-two-cities theme that drove his campaign, the gilded metropolis indifferently snuffing out its gasping work force.

headline: 30 More Problem Days, Boston Transit Chief Says
abstract: And, officials warned, if another big storm hits the region — one is expected over the weekend — it could take even longer.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As if the record snowfall and piercing subzero temperatures were not bad enough, residents here awoke Tuesday to reports that the already crippled Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, one of the largest transit systems in the country, would not be fully functional for at least 30 more days.

headline: Anne Moody, Author of ‘Coming of Age in Mississippi,’ Dies at 74
abstract: Ms. Moody’s memoir powerfully described growing up black in the Jim Crow era and taking part in the civil rights movement as a young woman.
lead_paragraph: Anne Moody, whose searing memoir, “Coming of Age in Mississippi,” told what it was like to grow up black in the era of Jim Crow, died on Feb. 5 at her home in Gloster, Miss. She was 74.

headline: Celebrating Oscar de la Renta and His Successor
abstract: The old guard and the new warmly received the first show by Peter Copping, who took the reins of the house after Oscar de la Renta died in October.
lead_paragraph: On one side of the runway sat the old guard, the perfectly coifed, expensively furred women who made Oscar de la Renta a Park Avenue icon, women like Nancy Kissinger and Mercedes Bass. Barbara Walters was settled in their company; Annette de la Renta, the designer’s widow, was too, seated beside Anna Wintour. Bill Cunningham, before the show, hurried over to give her a warm hug.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s national postal service is buying the largest private package and freight delivery company in Australia, Toll Holdings, for 6.5 billion Australian dollars, the two groups said on Wednesday.

headline: Head of New York’s Top Court Says Judges Should Oversee Grand Juries in Deaths Involving Police
keywords: ['Jury System', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Prosecutors, who handle the proceedings now, are seen as too close with law enforcement, Jonathan Lippman, the chief judge of the Court of Appeals, said his annual address.
lead_paragraph: New York’s top judge proposed on Tuesday that judges oversee grand juries deliberating police-related killings of civilians and be granted greater leeway to make the testimony to such juries available to the public.

headline: Review: ‘Little Children Dream of God,’ a Drama of Haitian Refugees
abstract: A pregnant woman flees her country for Miami in this new play by Jeff Augustin, at Roundabout Underground.
lead_paragraph: The presence, or absence, of a presiding deity may be a question we all ponder from time to time, but it’s a matter of daily significance in “Little Children Dream of God,” a warm and fanciful drama by Jeff Augustin about a Haitian immigrant trying to forge a new life on the rough streets of Miami.

headline: Review: In ‘Hamilton,’ Lin-Manuel Miranda Forges Democracy Through Rap
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s independent-minded new musical presents the 18th-century tale of Alexander Hamilton via hip-hop and R&B ballads.
lead_paragraph: They’re brewing up a revolution down on Lafayette Street. And even theater reactionaries seem destined to be swept up in its doubt-defying ardor.

headline: Puzzle the Blogging
abstract: Ed Sessa returns and he doesn’t know which way he’s going.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s tough to construct and edit a midweek puzzle. Your theme can’t really turn too many cruciverbal somersaults, lest it be pushed into Thursday territory (despite Will Shortz’s claim that Thursdays are not meant to be anything special themewise, that’s where the really cool ones tend to hang out). The clues need to wander surreptitiously away from Monday straightforwardness, but not creep into weekend-level brain-twisting. You can see how getting it just right might be difficult.

headline: Islamist Faction in Libya Now Strikes From the Sky
abstract: The Islamist-backed faction Libya Dawn said it had launched its first airstrike, targeting opponents in the town of Zintan in an escalation of the civil conflict.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Islamist-backed faction in Libya’s civil conflict said Tuesday that it had carried out its first airstrike, targeting opponents in the town of Zintan in an escalation of the violence tearing the country apart.

headline: In a Logistical Riddle for the Court, a Terrorism Suspect Is His Own Lawyer
abstract: The decision by Abid Naseer, accused of plotting a bombing attack in England, presents unique challenges for himself, prosecutors and the judge.
lead_paragraph: Abid Naseer, who is accused of being a Qaeda operative and planning an attack in Manchester, England, stood at a table on Tuesday for opening statements in his trial.

headline: Presidents Cup in South Korea May Lack Native Sons
abstract: Incheon will host the competition, which is taking place in Asia for the first time, but based on this week’s rankings, no South Koreans would earn an automatic spot.

headline: New Rules Set on Armed Drone Exports
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism.

headline: Obama Cites Health Plan Tally of 11.4 Million
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The number of people who chose or renewed coverage in the latest enrollment period means “the Affordable Care Act is working,” the president said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Tuesday that 11.4 million people had selected private health insurance plans or renewed their coverage under the Affordable Care Act in the enrollment period that ended Sunday.

headline: Transit Group’s Next Challenge: Selling a New Version of Congestion Pricing
abstract: A plan presented by Move NY includes the introduction of a toll for drivers within Manhattan — an idea rejected in Albany nearly seven years ago.
lead_paragraph: A transit advocacy group unveiled a proposal on Tuesday to remake the way tolls are set across New York City. Now comes the hard part — persuading lawmakers and drivers to embrace an idea that was defeated in Albany nearly seven years ago.

headline: Illinois: Imam Charged With Sex Abuse
abstract: The announcement came hours before four women filed a lawsuit accusing Mohammad Abdullah Saleem of abuse dating back to the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: A Chicago-area imam was charged with sexual abuse on Tuesday in a case that has raised questions about whether a cloistered South Asian community’s conservative views on sex and purity had discouraged women from coming forward with accusations of abuse. The charge was announced hours before four women filed a lawsuit accusing the imam, Mohammad Abdullah Saleem, who founded a school called the Institute of Islamic Education, of a pattern of sexual abuse dating back to the 1980s. A 23-year-old woman who worked as a school secretary last year told the police that Mr. Saleem had repeatedly groped her and once pulled her onto his lap and held her there over her objections. “He categorically denies the allegations,” his lawyer, Thomas T. Glasgow, said after a court appearance. He said the school had investigated and found no evidence for the claims.

headline: Fear of Israeli Leaks Fuels Distrust Over U.S. Talks With Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Aides to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu say they are being kept in the dark about details of the nuclear negotiations, but American officials say that is not true.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Obama administration racing to negotiate the outlines of a nuclear deal with Iran by the end of March, aides to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel have charged in recent days that they are being deliberately left in the dark about the details of the talks. The Americans have said that is untrue, but even one of Washington’s closest negotiating partners reports being warned about being too open with the Israelis, “because whatever we say may be used in a selective way.”

headline: 16 Die in Crush at Carnival in Haiti Capital
abstract: Authorities said a stampede on Tuesday left 16 people dead and 78 injured when a singer atop a Carnival float struck an overhead power line, igniting sparks and panic.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — A stampede on Tuesday left 16 people dead and 78 injured when a singer atop a Carnival float struck an overhead power line, igniting sparks and panic, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: As N.B.A. Trading Deadline Nears, Celtics Have Lots of Picks and Possibilities
abstract: With his team 20-31 but only a game and a half out of a playoff spot, Danny Ainge is ready, willing and more than able to deal.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. trading deadline is Thursday at 3 p.m. Eastern time. Until then, there will be stories on the Phoenix Suns’ potential trade of Goran Dragic, the overhaul of the Denver Nuggets and the Houston Rockets’ ongoing analytic search for better players.

headline: The State of Your New York Block
abstract: The State of the City speech, delivered each winter by the mayor, is a time-honored policy platform. But it doesn’t tell you what’s really going on out there. For that, you need to ask residents.
lead_paragraph: The State of the City speech, delivered each winter by the mayor, is a time-honored policy platform. But it doesn’t tell you what’s really going on out there. For that, you need to ask residents.

headline: A Regal Beagle Seizes the Spotlight
abstract: The Best in Show judge at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show made the surprising choice of Miss P, a grandniece of Uno, who in 2008 became the first beagle to win the big show.
lead_paragraph: It took 20 minutes for David Merriam, the Best in Show judge at the Westminster Kennel Club Show on Tuesday, to give the dog-loving audience at Madison Square Garden a bit of a shock. After a devilishly long route to making up his mind — he seemed to enjoy building the suspense, smiling a bit impishly as he deliberated — he made the surprising choice of Miss P, a 15-inch beagle and the grandniece of Uno, the first beagle to ever win the big show, in 2008.

headline: Gaps in France’s Surveillance Are Clear; Solutions Aren’t
abstract: The nation chose to stop monitoring Saïd and Chérif Kouachi before they struck Charlie Hebdo. But there is no consensus on what lessons to learn.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last June, Patrick Calvar, the head of France’s domestic intelligence service, faced a decision: continue surveillance on a French Islamist who had been viewed as a potential threat for a decade, or shift limited resources to help monitor a swelling new generation of fighters returning from Syria.

headline: Russia: Court Upholds Activist’s Suspended Sentence
abstract: A Moscow appeals court on Tuesday upheld a suspended three-and-a-half-year prison sentence against Aleksei A. Navalny, a leader of Russia’s opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin who was convicted last year of fraud in a case widely seen as politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: A Moscow appeals court on Tuesday upheld a suspended three-and-a-half-year prison sentence against Aleksei A. Navalny, a leader of Russia’s opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin who was convicted last year of fraud in a case widely seen as politically motivated. The court also released Mr. Navalny, an organizer of an opposition rally planned for March 1, from house arrest. A three-and-a-half-year prison sentence handed down to Mr. Navalny’s brother, who was convicted in the same case, remained unchanged. Mr. Navalny called his brother “a hostage.”

headline: Miu Miu Women’s Tales Taps a Cannes Grand Prix Winner
abstract: Alice Rohrwacher’s “De Djess” is the ninth short film in the brand’s ongoing series.
lead_paragraph: For the latest installment of the Miu Miu short-film series Women’s Tales — an ongoing project that has included commissions by Miranda July, Ava DuVernay and Zoe Cassavetes — the brand enlisted Alice Rohrwacher, the writer and director of “Corpo Celeste” (2011) and the Cannes Grand Prix recipient “The Wonders” (2014). “In fact, it was my first short,” Rohrwacher says of her 15-minute-long piece, “De Djess.” “With a short film, you’re able to do some experimenting and still stay within formal guidelines.” That, and Miu Miu allowed Rohrwacher an enormous amount of artistic freedom; the house’s designer, Miuccia Prada, only asked to see the completed film, a rare occurrence in the movie-making realm.

headline: Critic of N.F.L. Settlement on Concussions Reverses Position
abstract: Joe DeLamielluere, one the biggest critics of the settlement in a lawsuit that accused the N.F.L. of failing to warn players about concussions, joined the agreement, according to a court filing.
lead_paragraph: Joe DeLamielluere, one the biggest critics of the settlement in a suit that accused the N.F.L. of failing to warn former players about the dangers of concussions, has reversed himself and joined the agreement, according to a court filing on Tuesday. DeLamielluere, a former offensive lineman, joined nine others who initially opted out but will now take part in the settlement, which provides up to $5 million for a limited number of severe neurological conditions. In all, 211 retired players, or about 1 percent of the total, opted out of the deal, which lawyers for the N.F.L. and the former players revised Friday to meet some concerns of Anita B. Brody, the federal judge in the case.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (ABC Family) MATILDA (1996) For every child who ever thought the world was unfair, there’s hope that, like Matilda (Mara Wilson), he or she may one day discover a way to even the score. In this film based on Roald Dahl’s novel, Matilda is a clever heroine born to a loathsome set of parents — played here by Danny DeVito, who also directed the film, and Rhea Perlman — who is sent to a school overseen by a monstrous woman who torments her students. But things begin to change when Matilda realizes that she can use her telekinetic powers to defend herself and her fellow underdogs. Though the film may be too twisted for very young children, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, the “sweet, self-possessed little heroine” is someone to admire: “Even when addressed by her father as ‘You lyin’ little earwig,’ Ms. Wilson’s poised Matilda never loses the quiet confidence that guarantees she will prevail.”

lead_paragraph: The 2015 inductees to the Songwriters Hall of Fame will include such varied musicians as Toby Keith, Cyndi Lauper, Linda Perry, Bobby Braddock, Willie Dixon and the Grateful Dead writing duo of Robert Hunter and Jerry Garcia. The ceremony will take place at the Marriott Marquis in New York on June 18.

lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — An under-the-radar media company here called Whalerock could become a threat to the entertainment establishment.

headline: Civilian Toll in Afghan War Rose in 2014, U.N. Reports
abstract: The 10,000 civilian casualties reported by the United Nations, a record since it began its tallies in 2009, reflects the altered nature of a war in which almost no Western troops are still fighting.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Last year was the deadliest for civilians caught up in Afghanistan’s war since the United Nations began keeping records in 2009, the world body said Wednesday — a harbinger of the new dynamic of the conflict, in which insurgents and Afghan forces increasingly engage in face-to-face battles.

headline: Past Imperfect: Lives in the Biographer’s Mirror
abstract: All individual lives entail many stories, and the writer must choose which to tell.
lead_paragraph: “Life,” Soren Kierkegaard observed, “can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.” At first glance, that observation would seem to accord biographers of departed souls an advantage denied their works’ subjects.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Personal Finances', 'Philanthropy', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: People who are economically insecure aren’t galvanized by political messages that mention their financial problems.
lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y. — INTUITION, and a long line of social science research, suggests that citizens are more motivated to become politically involved when an issue is personally important to them.

headline: The Modern Asylum
abstract: We’ve failed the mentally ill and the mentally disabled.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, three ethicists from the University of Pennsylvania argued in the Journal of the American Medical Association that the movement to deinstitutionalize the mentally ill has been a failure. Deinstitutionalization, they wrote, has in truth been “transinstitutionalization.” As a hospital psychiatrist, I see this every day. Patients with chronic, severe mental illnesses are still in facilities — only now they are in medical hospitals, nursing homes and, increasingly, jails and prisons, places that are less appropriate and more expensive than long-term psychiatric institutions.

headline: Democracy Is in Recession
abstract: Turkey’s drift away from democracy is part of a much larger trend around the world.
lead_paragraph: Every month now we get treated to another anti-Semitic blast from Turkey’s leadership, which seems to be running some kind of slur-of-the-month club. Who knew that Jews all over the world were busy trying to take down President Recep Tayyip Erdogan? Last week, it was Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu’s turn to declare that Turkey would not “succumb to the Jewish lobby” — among others supposedly trying to topple Erdogan, the Hurriyet Daily News reported. This was after Erdogan had suggested that domestic opponents to the ruling Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., were “cooperating with the Mossad,” Israel’s intelligence arm. So few Jews, so many governments to topple.

headline: A Stronger Freedom of Information Act
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: Lawmakers have a second chance to enact legislation that would bring more transparency to the workings of government.
lead_paragraph: Congress came tantalizingly close last year to passing a bill to strengthen the Freedom of Information Act, which allows journalists and the public to access federal government records. The legislation, which would have brought more transparency, was blocked in December when the House speaker, John Boehner, refused to hold a vote on the Senate bill with no explanation. Two months later, lawmakers have a second chance.

headline: College, Poetry and Purpose
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Humanities', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: I reconnected with my Shakespeare professor to get her thoughts on the humanities and higher education today.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Over four decades at two universities, Anne Hall has taught thousands of students, enough to know that they come to college for a variety of reasons, with a variety of attitudes. Many are concerned only with jobs. Some are concerned chiefly with beer.

headline: My Mother Is Not a Bird
abstract: Euphemisms of the afterlife weren’t for us. Where she is now is in my mind.
lead_paragraph: I stood watching my mother’s last bellowing breaths. There were three of us holding her — me, my husband and my father — in the room we’d designed just for her. She was propped up in a rented hospital bed, lying on brown cotton sheets with the highest thread count I could find. My mother had been gasping like this for two days — a raspy, gurgling sound that I struggle to describe accurately with metaphors: a choking fish, a crackling microphone, a dying deer. But they all sidestep the truth. That was the sound of my 60-year-old mother dying of cancer.

abstract: Given the slump in oil prices, why has the Obama administration moved to open up the Atlantic coast to offshore drilling exploration?

headline: An Expensive Sunset for the Brent Oil Field
abstract: Shell is dismantling its North Sea project, a step toward what is expected to be a wider phase of costly decommissioning in British waters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Cleaning up an oil field in a forbidding environment like the North Sea may be almost as formidable a task as developing one, and in the coming years, those waters are likely to serve as a laboratory for what happens when the useful lives of oil fields expire.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French media group Vivendi said on Wednesday that Altice had offered to buy its 20 percent stake in Numericable-SFR.

headline: Crédit Agricole Earnings Beat Expectations
abstract: The large French bank said it had worked over the year to increase its financial strength, partly by reinvesting dividends and accumulated earnings.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Crédit Agricole, one of France’s largest banks, on Wednesday reported quarterly profit that beat market expectations, helped by a resurgence in its investment banking activities and a sharp reduction in its provisions against loan losses.

headline: Should Farm Animals Have More Legal Protections?
abstract: Are new laws needed to ensure that animals are raised — and slaughtered — in a more humane way?
lead_paragraph: The Animal Welfare Act, enacted in 1966, protects dogs, cats, rabbits and reptiles — but excludes farm animals. For example, Nicholas Kristof recently wrote about how chickens are often raised to have breasts so large that their legs can’t support their body weight. And other Times writers have written about abuse of pigs, sheep and cattle.

headline: Crossed Fates in Central African Republic
abstract: In “Return to Boda,” Sam Phelps wants to remind viewers how now-warring groups once managed to coexist in a small town in the Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: The moment Sam Phelps left the Central African Republic, he knew he had to return.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader Hails Year of the Sheep —  and Suggests a Role Model
abstract: In a holiday message, Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying urged Hong Kong residents to ‘‘take inspiration from the sheep’s character.’’
lead_paragraph: Just what to call the next Lunar New Year has vexed English speakers, as the Chinese character can represent both sheep and goats. In his official New Year message, Hong Kong’s leader, Leung Chun-ying, opts for a little of both. The video of his statement is filled with goats of all varieties: live, stuffed, illustrated. But Mr. Leung asked residents to look to sheep, the meek creature that lives in flocks, as a guide.

headline: State Media Outlet Faults Billionaire’s Son for Crude Comment
abstract: When Wang Sicong, the son of one of the richest men in China, responded to a reporter’s question about what he sought in a mate, the response shouldn’t have surprised anyone.
lead_paragraph: When the son of one of the richest men in China responded to a reporter’s question about what he sought in a mate, the response shouldn’t have surprised anyone. “That’s simple,” said 27-year-old Wang Sicong. “A big chest is enough.”

headline: To Jump-Start Your Exercise Routine, Be Mindful
abstract: By paying more attention to the experience of exercise itself, even the most reluctant of exercisers might begin to find pleasure in movement.
lead_paragraph: By now, many of us, beset by bad weather and declining motivation, are struggling to maintain our New Year’s exercise resolutions. But a timely new study offers encouragement, suggesting that by paying more attention to the experience of exercise itself, even the most reluctant of exercisers might begin to find pleasure in movement.

abstract: The investigation by the Geneva prosecutor’s office comes amid recent media reports about the HSBC unit’s previous efforts to help wealthy clients seeking to avoid taxes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Local prosecutors in Switzerland conducted a search of the offices of HSBC’s Swiss private bank in Geneva on Wednesday as part of a new investigation into potential money laundering.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Sets New Rules for Export of Armed Drones
abstract: The Obama administration’s move to preserve a lead in a fast-growing market also means wider use of a controversial weapon in the battle against terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Tuesday issued new rules for the international export of armed drones, a move that seeks to preserve an American lead in a fast-growing market but one likely to speed the proliferation of a much-criticized weapon in the battle against terrorism, Scott Shane reports.

headline: Tesco, Britain’s Largest Retailer, Names John Allan as Chairman
abstract: The appointment comes at a critical juncture for the company, which had been mired in investigations after an overstatement of profit of more than $400 million.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tesco, the embattled British retailing giant, said on Thursday that John Allan, a deputy chairman of the electronics company Dixons Carphone, would take over as chairman on March 1.

headline: Ukrainian Soldiers’ Retreat From Eastern Town Raises Doubt for Truce
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko sought to cast the retreat from the strategic town in a positive light, but it was clearly a devastating defeat at the hands of the separatists.
lead_paragraph: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers were forced to fight their way out of the embattled town of Debaltseve in the early hours of Wednesday, casting further doubt on the credibility of a days-old cease-fire and eroding the promise of ending a war in Europe that has killed more than 5,000 people.

headline: Sony Aims for Huge Leap in Profit
abstract: By pursuing a restructuring that emphasizes profitability over volume, the Japanese company is setting a target of $4.2 billion in annual operating profit by March 2018, compared with about $170 million now.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The light at the end of the tunnel may finally be coming into focus for Sony.

headline: Project Sheds Light on What Drives Genes
abstract: Researchers hope the discoveries, described in two dozen papers released on Wednesday, will eventually lead to a deeper understanding of diseases and new ways to treat or cure them.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 scientists working on an ambitious federal project have begun to understand the complicated system of switches that regulates genes, turning some on and others off, making some glow brightly while others dim. They hope these discoveries, described in two dozen papers released on Wednesday, will eventually lead to a deeper understanding of diseases and new ways to treat or cure them.

headline: Morning Agenda: Snapchat Reaches for $19 Billion Valuation
abstract: Snapchat is said to be raising financing that could value the company at up to $19 billion. | Hedge funds are tiptoeing back into the energy sector. | Greek bailout talks drag on.
lead_paragraph: SNAPCHAT REACHES FOR $19 BILLION VALUATION | Snapchat, the start-up with disappearing photo messages, is said to be raising a round of venture capital that could value the company at up to $19 billion, Mike Isaac writes on the Bits blog, citing a person with knowledge of the discussions. Snapchat could raise up to $500 million in the round of financing, the person said. If the round closes, Snapchat’s value will have nearly doubled since last year, when the company was in talks to raise money at a $10 billion valuation.

headline: A Lunar New Year With a Name That’s a Matter of Opinion
abstract: The word for the eighth animal in the Chinese zodiac’s 12-year cycle of creatures in Mandarin does not make the distinction found in English between goats and sheep.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China said goodbye to the Year of the Horse on Wednesday, and on the first day of the new lunar year revelers welcomed the Year of the Sheep.

keywords: ['Extraordinary Rendition', 'Reparations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Detainees', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The foreign minister said his country would abide by a court ruling that ordered it to pay reparations to two terrorism suspects held at a secret site.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland will abide by a European court ruling that ordered it to pay a total of $262,000 in reparations to two former inmates of a “black site” prison run by the C.I.A., the minister of foreign affairs said on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Magnificent Obsessions’ Show at the Barbican Explores Portraits of the Artist as Collector
abstract: An exhibition at the Barbican Art Gallery in London, “Magnificent Obsessions: The Artist as Collector,” displays an array of what creative minds gather and keep.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Their works may be coveted by collectors, but artists often have a predilection for building eccentric collections of their own. Many like to pick up bric-a-brac from curiosity shops, market stalls and auction houses. Predictably enough, Damien Hirst owns skulls and stuffed animals. Less widely known is that Peter Blake hoards vintage shop signs, while Martin Parr boasts an impressive collection of Soviet souvenirs.

headline: High-Spirited Comedies Rush the Stage
abstract: Backers of “Something Rotten!,” “It Shoulda Been You” and “Hand to God” hope jokes (and puppet sex) will fill the seats.
lead_paragraph: To get the gist of the comedy in the coming Broadway musical “Something Rotten!,” about a playwright competing against Shakespeare in 1595 London, consider this exchange between two characters who happen to be named Shylock and Nostradamus about the most avid theatergoers of the Elizabethan era.

headline: Larry David on Broadway Theater, ‘Seinfeld’ and Death Etiquette
abstract: As Mr. David’s opening night for “Fish in the Dark” approaches, he bemoans the play’s enormous advance ticket sales as “a terrible thing.”
lead_paragraph: In his dressing room at the Cort Theater, Larry David started eating dinner, but not before lowering expectations. “I should warn you: I’m not a skilled eater,” he said, leaning forward to grab a white plastic takeout bag. “I have problems getting the food onto my utensil and getting it into my mouth properly. It’s not a pretty picture.”

lead_paragraph: This isn’t a big deal, but it nonetheless had me doing a double-take. lead_paragraph: LONDON — Video footage showing white fans of the English soccer team Chelsea shoving a black subway rider in Paris has revived concerns about racism in what is often labeled “the beautiful game.”

headline: Fox Searchlight Outshines Rivals in Oscar Hunt
abstract: With two films up for best picture at the Academy Awards, the studio is on a winning streak of producing blockbusters with art house appeal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the Academy Awards on Sunday, Fox Searchlight Pictures will have two films in the running for top honors: Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” and Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel.”

headline: Admiring Mount Fuji From a Black-Sand Beach
abstract: Among all the places in Japan claiming to be the best vantage point for seeing Mt. Fuji, Miho no Matsubara stands out.
lead_paragraph: Mount Fuji is a beloved and sacred peak that is an unforgettable sight and easily viewable, which is why I was frustrated when on a visit in 2013 I was able to get to within a few miles of the mountain only to find it obscured by thick clouds.

headline: Island Hopping Off the Coast of Borneo
abstract: Zip-lining from one island to the next, hiking through a rainforest and other active pursuits on four Malaysian islands.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a good idea at the time. Adam Dean, a photographer working for The New York Times, and I had just returned from several back-to-back voyages in the South China Sea last November, reporting on the fishing industry and sleeping on cramped, roach- and rat-infested boats from Thailand and Indonesia. While waiting in Kota Kinabalu, Borneo, for our next boat to arrive, we had a couple of down days. So I suggested we try the Coral Explorer day package on offer from an adventure tours company called Intrepid Travel, based in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: A Call for Law Firms to Go Public
abstract: In a law review article, a founder of a major litigation finance company says law firms should abandon the partnership structure.
lead_paragraph: Many law firms have been seeking new ways to keep themselves financially sound as their clients become more cost conscious.

headline: In Wilton, Conn., Historic Homes and Fine Schools
abstract: The high-performing school system is a draw for buyers who can do without the more convenient commute enjoyed by neighboring suburbs to the south.
lead_paragraph: Heather and Christopher Mah went looking for a place to live in Fairfield County, and wound up choosing a house before they’d chosen a town.

headline: Photoshop at 25: A Thriving Chameleon Adapts to an Instagram World
abstract: Adobe, which introduced the image-editing program in 1990, has moved to a less expensive subscription-based model in an effort to democratize access.
lead_paragraph: The history of digital technology is full of innovations that are praised for having changed the world: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, the Netscape Navigator browser, the iPod and countless others. Then there are the many products that changed the world and were suddenly overtaken by some newer, supposedly better thing: the Mac, Microsoft Windows, Netscape Navigator, the iPod and countless others.

headline: Khmer-Inspired Shopping by Angkor Wat
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'ANGKOR WAT (CAMBODIAN TEMPLE)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Textiles']
abstract: Siem Reap, the gateway city to the temple ruins in Cambodia, is brimming with a clutch of stylish, recently opened boutiques.
lead_paragraph: Siem Reap, the gateway city to Angkor, is renowned for a lot of things — more than 100 ancient temple ruins dot the surrounding jungles — but shopping isn’t one of them. It’s often an afterthought, with visitors snagging the prerequisite temple souvenir. But the heart of the city on the west side of the Siem Reap River is brimming with a clutch of stylish, recently opened boutiques carrying contemporary wares that often reference traditional Khmer culture. The shops are found along narrow lanes and well-trodden streets in a roughly 10-block radius, many owned by well-traveled expatriates breathing new energy into this tourist-oriented city. (Note: U.S. dollars are widely accepted.)

headline: Obama Urges Global United Front Against Extremist Groups Like ISIS
abstract: The president outlined his administration’s efforts to counter what he called “violent extremism” in a speech to law enforcement, community and religious leaders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on Americans and more than 60 nations on Wednesday to join the fight against violent extremism, saying they had to counter the ideology of the Islamic State and other groups making increasingly sophisticated appeals to young people around the world.

headline: Anna Ewers Transforms at Rodarte
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Anna Ewers before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Kaliardos, hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: New Artistic Director for Guthrie Theater
abstract: Joseph Haj, one of the few Arab-American artistic directors in the country, will take over at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis on July 1.
lead_paragraph: The Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis has named its next artistic director: Joseph Haj, who currently leads PlayMakers Repertory Company in North Carolina. Mr. Haj, one of the few Arab-American artistic directors in the country, will take over the Guthrie on July 1, succeeding Joe Dowling, who is stepping down after 20 years. The Guthrie board’s chairman, Lee Skold, said Tuesday that the search team and board members – who spent a year looking for a leadership match – had been drawn to Mr. Haj’s “inspired vision, collaborative spirit, and standard of excellence.”

headline: David Ives's ‘Lives of the Saints’ From Primary Stages
abstract: New Yorkers with a taste for Mr. Ives’s comedy can catch his latest collection of short plays.
lead_paragraph: The playwright David Ives is all over the place. “The Metromaniacs,” his verse adaptation of an 18th-century play, has just opened at the Shakespeare Theater in Washington. His comedy “Venus in Fur,” seen widely at regional theaters, may get another goose from the movie release of a certain hugely popular series of novels about erotic transgression. It has also been announced that Mr. Ives will collaborate with Stephen Sondheim on a new musical adapted from a pair of Luis Buñuel films.

headline: 1915: Italians Clamor for War
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Italians demonstrate for war in 1915.
lead_paragraph: ROME — All adherents of the democratic parties had been convoked for to-day [Feb. 18] to the Piazza Monte Citorio for the purpose of a demonstration in favor of war. The square was barricaded by troops and police, but in the neighborhood of the Chamber a grave demonstration took place in spite of all precautions. Immense crowds gathered and clamored for war, interspersing their cries with shouts of ‘‘Down with Austria!’’ Processions of demonstrators marched through the streets with flags at their heads shouting against Germany and Austria. German and Austrian shops had all had their shutters put up. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 19, 1915

headline: Peter Carey’s ‘Amnesia’
abstract: Peter Carey’s political thriller centers on cyber-saboteurs and the Australian left.
lead_paragraph: Now that the politics of hacking has ­assumed an importance hitherto unknown, the theme Peter Carey has chosen for his latest novel seems especially timely. In many ways, it’s a departure from his previous work, although throughout “Amnesia” he maintains the temper and Rabelaisian fury of a prose we know all too well. You can pick any page at random and locate an energy that never seems to flag. His sentences hit their intended marks with an emotion that often feels like exasperated cruelty, and none of his characters are spared a little bloodletting.

headline: House Hunting In ...Thailand
abstract: A military coup in Thailand last spring and the imposition of martial law, which continues, slowed property sales, but they have rebounded since the beginning of this year.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA WITH WATER VIEWS IN PHUKET, THAILAND

headline: Jeff Augustin on Haiti, Voodoo and Roundabout Underground
abstract: “Little Children Dream of God,” Mr. Augustin’s new play about an immigrant who’s 11 months pregnant, was originally set in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.
lead_paragraph: Magic realism doesn’t work in a world where anything goes as a matter of course. At some point, the magic needs to give way to — or at least nestle alongside — reality.

headline: ‘Head of State,’ by Andrew Marr
abstract: A darkly comic tale of deception and skullduggery at 10 Downing Street.
lead_paragraph: Early in this comic political thriller, an eminent historian is shown round 10 Downing Street. It is mid-September, 2017, a few days before a referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union. (In real life, such a referendum is a virtual certainty if the Conservatives are still in the government after this year’s general election.) The historian, who has been promised “unparalleled access” in order to produce an authorized history of the vote, has come to interview the prime minister, a man whose charisma seems to be all that keeps Britain from decamping. But the prime minister is not available, and instead an aide conducts a tour of the premises — up the famous staircase with portraits of previous occupants and into a grand state room. The historian is unimpressed. “He was all too aware that the real work went on one floor below them, in the cabinet room and the P.M.’s office and the private secretaries’ rooms.”

headline: Michael Kors’s Fall 2015 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Michael Kors at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: [Watch the live stream.]

headline: ‘Mark Twain’s America’ and ‘Huck Finn’s America’
abstract: Two books about Mark Twain and his masterpiece explore his continuing relevance.
lead_paragraph: Fresh and funny today as he was more than a century ago, Mark Twain wittily distrusted everything bogus, inflated, predictable or empty. He was a man of a thousand American parts — novelist, stand-up comic, travel writer, impresario, capitalist, full-time celebrity and coruscating social critic — whose ear for dialogue, nuance, slang and absurdity seldom failed him. No wonder we still read him, debate him, scold him, censor him. William Dean Howells aptly canonized him as the “Lincoln of our literature.”

headline: No Bitterness From Victoria Azarenka After Surprise Split With Coach
abstract: Azarenka, a Belarussian, already has a new mentor after Sam Sumyk, with whom she won two Grand Slam singles titles, left to work with Eugenie Bouchard.
lead_paragraph: In a time of increased shuffling in the coaching ranks of professional tennis, the partnership between Victoria Azarenka and her longtime coach Sam Sumyk ended abruptly, at least from Azarenka’s perspective.

headline: Sketching Shakespeare
abstract: A graphic novel version of Shakespeare’s “Macbeth” brings the story to life for young readers.
lead_paragraph: “Macbeth” — unlike, say, “Hamlet” or “Romeo and Juliet” — doesn’t feature classically adolescent themes, and its main characters are grown-ups. Yet with its simple, linear plot, its witches and its ghosts, its clear-cut moral questions about the lure of evil and whether and how we control our own fates, it is well suited for teenagers. Gareth Hinds’s stellar new graphic-novel adaptation, aimed at a young adult audience, makes that abundantly clear. The play also, of course, features some epic fight scenes and lots and lots of blood, and Hinds makes the most of these opportunities to show how naturally Shakespeare takes to the comics form.

headline: Probing the Mysteries of a Photographer and Her Images
abstract: The documentary makers John Maloof and Charlie Siskel tried to understand why Vivian Maier never showed her pictures.
lead_paragraph: One of the most fascinating art world stories of recent years is the discovery of the work of Vivian Maier and her rapid elevation to one of the great American photographers of the 20th century. It was John Maloof who found thousands of her negatives and undeveloped rolls of film at an auction house in Chicago, and paid $380 for them, and he is also the director, with Charlie Siskel, of “Finding Vivian Maier,” one of five films competing for the Oscar for best feature-length documentary.

headline: 1965: Vatican and Protestants Agree
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Roman Catholic and Protestant churches collaborate in a historic movement toward unity in 1965.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Roman Catholic and Protestant churches today [Feb. 18] reached a historic agreement to try to end their differences and achieve Christian unity. The first giant step toward a common understanding came during the unprecedented visit of a Roman Catholic cardinal to the World Council of Churches this morning. Augustin Cardinal Bea, on behalf of the Holy See, accepted the council’s proposal to establish a mixed committee to determine the principles and methods for future inter-church collaboration. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 19, 1965

headline: Hospitals Try to Reduce Suffering: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Gina Kolata shares the story behind her front-page article about American hospitals’ increased interest in reducing suffering.
lead_paragraph: Gina Kolata wrote a Feb. 18 front-page article about hospitals and their increased interest in reducing suffering. She explains how the story took shape.

headline: Earthquake Dangers in Dutch Gas Field Were Ignored for Years, Safety Board Says
abstract: Shell, Exxon Mobil and the Dutch government put revenue and energy supply from the Groningen field ahead of safety, an independent panel found.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An independent Dutch safety panel has found that the operators of Europe’s largest natural gas field, Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, as well as the Dutch government, for years ignored the dangers posed by earthquakes in the field.

headline: A Bid for Guns on Campuses to Deter Rape
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Firearms', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As lawmakers in 10 states push for so-called campus carry laws, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: As gun rights advocates push to legalize firearms on college campuses, an argument is taking shape: Arming female students will help reduce sexual assaults.

headline: Greece to Propose Extension of European Union Bailout Program
abstract: Athens will push for an extension of several months but will not adhere to an underlying memorandum that prescribed many austerity measures.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greek officials are planning to submit a proposal to eurozone finance ministers for breaking the impasse in debt negotiations between the new government in Athens and Greece’s European creditors.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Odd Couple’
abstract: Matthew Perry and Thomas Lennon star in a CBS update of the classic sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Perry and Thomas Lennon star in a CBS update of the classic sitcom.

headline: Trade Group Accelerates Push for a ‘Fast Track’ Deal
abstract: Members of Congress might be home for the President’s Day recess but they cannot avoid the debate over trade.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress might be home for the Presidents’ Day recess, but they cannot avoid the debate over trade.

headline: New York City Rail Crossings Carry a Deadly Past
abstract: Though there are far fewer accidents at grade crossings in New York City than in its suburbs, the five boroughs have their own dark history with the intersections.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers may not think railroad grade crossings have anything to do with them, but the city owes its immensely popular High Line to a campaign that began more than a century ago against the carnage caused by a street-level freight line.

headline: Memorable Sports Apologies Through the Years
abstract: Alex Rodriguez’s apology may ultimately be remembered for being handwritten, but here are some sports apologies that have endured for other reasons.
lead_paragraph: The most believable part about Alex Rodriguez’s public apology to the Yankees and fans Tuesday for past misdeeds might have been the section in which he acknowledged that most people would not believe anything he said. The most unusual part might have been his chosen medium for the moment: a handwritten letter, in cursive, in 2015. Most offensive, stylistically, was probably his decision to stretch the letter to a second page, making it aesthetically unpleasing on social media.

headline: What You Get for … $1,050,000
abstract: A former hunting retreat in Colorado, a contemporary in Alabama and a cottage in West Virginia
lead_paragraph: A former hunting retreat in Colorado, a contemporary in Alabama and a cottage in West Virginia

headline: $1,050,000 Homes in Colorado, Alabama and West Virginia
abstract: A former hunting retreat in Colorado, a contemporary in Alabama and a cottage in West Virginia
lead_paragraph: MEREDITH, COLO.

headline: What’s the Most Godless State?
abstract: Only 17 percent of Vermont residents say they attend religious services weekly.
lead_paragraph: A new Gallup poll finds that more than half of Utah residents say they attend religious services weekly, the highest percentage of any state in the union. In Vermont, only 17 percent of residents say they attend religious services weekly, the lowest percentage. Click on the Gallup link for a complete list.

headline: New Dr. Seuss Book, ‘What Pet Should I Get?’, Coming in July, With More to Come
abstract: Audrey Geisel, Dr. Seuss’s widow, discovered the manuscript for “What Pet Should I Get?” in 2013. Random House plans to release at least two more books.
lead_paragraph: When Harper Lee’s “Go Set a Watchman” hits bookstores in July, it will face sales competition from another long-lost manuscript by a beloved author: Dr. Seuss.

headline: Nick Hornby’s ‘Funny Girl’
abstract: Nick Hornby’s ingénue pursues her dream of fame in 1960s London.
lead_paragraph: The unassuming title of Nick Hornby’s regular column about books for The Believer magazine perfectly matches its author’s conversational style: “Stuff I’ve Been Reading.” At a literary festival last October, Hornby spoke, not for the first time, in defense of taking the pain out of literature. Struggling through a book out of a sense of duty, he argued, is “reinforcing the ­notion that reading is something you should do but telly is something you want to do. It shouldn’t be like that. Novels should be like TV. It shouldn’t be hard work.”

headline: Kate Brown, New Governor in Oregon, Seeks Public’s Trust
abstract: Ms. Brown, a Democrat like her predecessor, John Kitzhaber, capped a long climb through the ranks of state government but also began what is certain to be a wrenching transition.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — Kate Brown took the oath of office as governor here on Wednesday, capping a decades-long climb through the ranks of state government but also commencing what is certain to be a wrenching transition fraught with political risk. Her predecessor, John Kitzhaber, announced his resignation last week, just weeks into his fourth term, amid an onslaught of criminal and ethical investigations and a collapse of support from his own party.

headline: Amazon Orders Full Seasons for Five New Shows
abstract: Amazon’s television production wing ordered full seasons of its pilot programs for “The Man in the High Castle,” “Mad Dogs,” “The New Yorker Presents,” “Just Add Magic” and “The Stinky & Dirty Show.”
lead_paragraph: In January, Amazon Studios, the online retail giant’s television production wing, posted 10 original pilots for viewers to watch and vote on. This morning, five of them were ordered to series: “The Man in the High Castle,” based on the Philip K. Dick novel that imagines an alternate reality in which the Axis powers won World War II; “Mad Dogs,” a dark comedy executive produced by Shawn Ryan (“The Shield,” “Terriers”); “The New Yorker Presents,” a docu-series overseen by Alex Gibney (“Taxi To the Dark Side,” “We Steal Secrets”); and the kids series “Just Add Magic” and “The Stinky & Dirty Show.”

headline: Real Runners Do Take Walk Breaks
abstract: One runner’s strategy and mind-set about the run-walk-run method during her road races and marathons.
lead_paragraph: When a runner friend suggested I run my first distance race by adding walk breaks, the idea startled me. I didn’t think you were allowed to walk in races, not if you wanted to be a real runner. But the thought of running in New Jersey, all the way to the boardwalk in North Wildwood from Cape May in a single clip, seemed impossible, and I came around.

headline: Below the Line: Editing ‘Whiplash’
abstract: Tom Cross, the editor of “Whiplash,” discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: Those who have seen their fair share of films about musicians may go into a movie like “Whiplash” with certain expectations. But this best picture nominee is not your typical music drama. Instead, in its pacing,  acting and particularly  its editing, the film behaves more like “Bullitt” than, say, “Bird.” The focus is mainly on Andrew (Miles Teller), a jazz drum student at a prestigious music school, and his mentor, Fletcher (J.K. Simmons), an intense, strict and frequently verbally abusive  teacher. The film’s editor, Tom Cross, worked closely with the director, Damien Chazelle, to shape the cuts.

headline: Designers Take Cues From Scottish Lads to Make Fall Skirts for the Girls
abstract: On the New York Fashion Week runways, all-black kilt-inspired bottoms are a chic upgrade from the tartan originals.
lead_paragraph: Designers have always loved borrowing from the boys for women’s collections; and for fall 2015, ​they tapped into the structure of a kilt. At Coach, pleated, knee-length skirts, the default bottoms throughout the collection, added femininity to looks featuring structured shearling coats and heavy boots. Tim Coppens, who got his start in men’s wear,​ kept to his usual sporty aesthetic, topping kilt-inspired bottoms with boyish knits and bombers. And at Diesel Black Gold, Andreas Melbostad added texture to his all-black collection with lace, leather and, in this instance, layers of materials in a miniskirt version of the traditional Scottish garment. In all black, the trending color on this week’s runways, the new iterations are much chicer than the tartan originals.

headline: ‘Infrastructure Joe’ Visits Another 2016 Early Primary State
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday continued his sweep through 2016 early primary states.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday continued his sweep through 2016 early primary states, stopping in Charleston, S.C., to deliver a broad speech on infrastructure as part of the administration’s “Grow America” tour.

headline: Same-Day Delivery Resurges, Adding Alcohol
abstract: Millennials accustomed to ordering food for delivery on smartphones have come of legal drinking age, and niche start-ups are poised to take advantage.
lead_paragraph: There are many bodies in the delivery graveyard. Webvan, Kozmo and Urbanfetch were all seen as the next big thing before crashing spectacularly.

headline: Obama Picks Joseph Clancy to Be Secret Service’s Permanent Chief
abstract: In appointing Mr. Clancy, currently the interim director, the president rejected calls from Capitol Hill and a Homeland Security panel to choose an outsider.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Wednesday appointed Joseph P. Clancy, who had guided the Secret Service on an interim basis for the last four and a half months, to be the agency’s permanent director.

headline: Reader Mailbag: Questions and Comments About Orders at Chipotle
abstract: Readers weigh in on an article that showed what people actually order at the popular restaurant chain.
lead_paragraph: In an article Tuesday, we set out to answer a question that we’ve always wondered about — what do people actually order when they go to Chipotle? We found that a typical order had about 1,070 calories and almost a full day’s worth of sodium and saturated fat.

headline: 8 Tax Loopholes the Obama Administration Could Close
keywords: ['Capital Gains Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Income Inequality', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Retirement', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: The Treasury Department has the legal authority to close some tax loopholes that Congress did not intend, writes Victor Fleischer in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: “Let Bartlet be Bartlet” was the title of a stirring episode of the progressive wish-fulfillment television series “The West Wing.” In the episode, staff members struggle to be taken seriously on Capitol Hill, working in the shadow of the timid and ambivalent president, Josiah Bartlet. In the face of falling job approval ratings, the chief of staff, Leo McGarry, challenges the president to be true to his values and take the staff off the leash. Mr. McGarry asks the staff members if they are ready for the fight. Each responds, “I serve at the pleasure of the president.”

headline: Company in Bangladesh Agrees to Union Peace
abstract: Several Western companies cut off orders to the Azim Group after union leaders were assaulted outside its factories.
lead_paragraph: After wielding intense pressure against a Bangladeshi apparel maker over assaults on union leaders outside its factories, Western companies have agreed to resume business with that manufacturer, on the condition that it stay committed to halting further violence and make peace with its labor unions.

headline: In Philadelphia, Extended Stays With Boutique Touches
abstract: The Roost Apartment Hotel in Philadelphia, designed for extended stays, features loftlike floor plans and boutique-style amenities.
lead_paragraph: The extended-stay hotel category gets a boutique-style update in the form of the new Roost Apartment Hotel, recently opened in Philadelphia.

headline: Chris Christie Makes a Fund-Raising Push in Bush Country
abstract: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, struggling to catch up to the early financial gains of his potential rival, Jeb Bush, made an aggressive fund-raising push last week in Greenwich, Conn., the affluent enclave where residents have been part of the Bush family donor network for years.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, struggling to catch up to the early financial gains of his potential rival Jeb Bush, made an aggressive fund-raising push last week in Greenwich, Conn., the affluent enclave where residents have been part of the Bush family donor network for years.

lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Japan Post Paying a Rich Price to Show Global Expansion
abstract: But the acquisition of Toll Holdings will help spruce up Japan Post’s upcoming initial public offering – and fuel further deal-making, says Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Japan Post Service is paying a hefty price to stamp “global expansion” on its roadshow presentation.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Kill 3 in Suicide Attack at Shiite Mosque
abstract: A suicide bomber struck outside a Shiite mosque near Islamabad, where guards prevented him from reaching the main prayer hall.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least three people were killed and two wounded on Wednesday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives outside a Shiite mosque on the outskirts of Islamabad, officials said. A faction of the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility.

headline: Yemen’s Last Jews
abstract: The rise of the militant Houthis and their anti-Semitism has reduced an ancient and once vibrant community to only a few people.
lead_paragraph: The rise of the militant Houthis and their anti-Semitism has reduced an ancient and once vibrant community to only a few people.

headline: Crew Member Injured in Another Bond Movie Accident
abstract: A crash during the filming of the coming James Bond film, “Spectre,” leaves a crew member with multiple leg fractures.
lead_paragraph: The shooting of the new James Bond movie, “Spectre,” continued along its accident-prone way with an on-set crash Tuesday, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

headline: 36 Hours in Beijing
abstract: Compared with China’s other megacities, Beijing is still a traditionalist at heart, so delve into the shops, galleries and restaurants in the city’s old, alleyway-threaded hutong neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Compared with China’s other megacities, Beijing is still a traditionalist at heart, so delve into the shops, galleries and restaurants in the city’s old, alleyway-threaded hutong neighborhoods.

headline: Persecution Defines Life for Yemen’s Remaining Jews
abstract: With the Houthis dominating the country and the United States and Britain closing their embassies, the population has seldom been so threatened and had so few protectors.
lead_paragraph: RAIDA, Yemen — About all that remain of Yemen’s ancient and once vibrant Jewish community are untended cemeteries, dramatic hillside ghetto villages of thousand-year-old stone houses and a few people like Abraham Jacob and his extended family.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Unveils a Season of Big Stars and 6 New Productions
abstract: The Met will open its season with a new production of Verdi’s “Otello”; and Nina Stemme will star in a new production of Strauss’s “Elektra.”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera said on Wednesday that it would redouble its efforts to attract new audiences to the opera next season with six new productions, a star-filled roster and new initiatives, including one that will offer half-priced tickets to children during the holidays and another to court young professionals with later curtain times, discounts and social events.

headline: An Illinois Budget Chief’s Fond Memories of Jeb Bush’s Florida
abstract: Jeb Bush is in Chicago to talk about foreign policy today, but his former budget director Donna Ms. Arduin is in the local news.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush is in Chicago to talk about foreign policy, but his former budget director Donna Arduin is in the local news.

headline: Three Friends, One Jihadi
abstract: As his dreams crashed into Egypt’s social and political turmoil, Islam Yaken left his friends, family and a life of guilty pleasures for religious extremism, jihad and the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: As his dreams crashed into Egypt’s social and political turmoil, Islam Yaken left his friends, family and a life of guilty pleasures for religious extremism, jihad and the Islamic State.

headline: From a Private School in Cairo to ISIS Killing Fields in Syria (With Video)
abstract: The West is not alone in struggling to understand why young men like Islam Yaken, raised in homes that would never condone violence, are joining the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — He winced at the mere mention of his son’s name, visibly overcome by an unceasing thought that he struggled to articulate. He looked down to hide the tears in his eyes.

headline: U.S. Announces Third Bitcoin Auction
abstract: The U.S. Marshals Service will auction 50,000 Bitcoins seized in connection with the online marketplace Silk Road.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshals Service announced on Wednesday that it would auction 50,000 Bitcoins, worth nearly $12 million, seized in connection with the online marketplace Silk Road.

headline: Facing Demand, Uber Expands Funding Round by $1 Billion
abstract: Investors just can’t get enough of Uber, the ride-hailing service, so the company has expanded the capacity for its latest funding round to $2.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the ride-hailing service, likes to trumpet its popularity with consumers. Their fervor is surpassed, perhaps, only by investors’.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Mozart, Hugo Wolf and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: HUGO WOLF: Italienische Serenade/EDVARD GRIEG: String Quartet in G minor/LEOS JANACEK: String Quartet No. 2Amphion String Quartet(Nimbus Alliance NI 6289; one disc) The debut recording of this exciting young quartet brims with propulsive energy and raw drama. The players bring jaunty exuberance to Wolf’s “Italienische Serenade,” an epic sweep to Grieg’s String Quartet in G minor and fiery temperament to Janacek’s String Quartet No. 2. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: App Smart | Modernize Your Meetings
abstract: A new generation of meeting organizers helps you invite guests, set agendas and distribute shared documents, all from your phone.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of meeting organizers helps you invite guests, set agendas and distribute shared documents, all from your phone.

headline: In Nigeria, Boko Haram Loses Ground to Chadians
abstract: Chadian soldiers fought their way into Dikwa, which had been in militant hands for months, and the army of Nigeria took Monguno, in the northeastern part of the nation.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Chad’s army has made its deepest push yet into Nigeria in a three-front regional war against Boko Haram, entering a town 50 miles from a beleaguered Nigerian state capital that has been surrounded for months by the militant group, Nigerian security officials said Wednesday.

headline: A True Bedhead Look at Michael Kors
abstract: The hairstylist Orlando Pita demanded models sleep in damp hair last night before arriving backstage for the designer’s fall 2015 fashion show.
lead_paragraph: “If I could, I would have started last night,” said the hairstylist Orlando Pita, who instructed the models to wash their hair last night and sleep with it slightly damp before arriving backstage at the fall/winter 2015 Michael Kors fashion show this morning. Pita explained his goal was to achieve a disheveled look — the one you naturally have fresh “out of bed, almost like you didn’t have time to get ready, putting an elastic on your hair and running out the door.”

headline: A Boom in Private Equity’s Secondary Market
abstract: Secondary sales of stakes in private equity, venture capital and real estate funds totaled $47 billion in 2014, roughly 80 percent more than in 2013, research by the investment bank Evercore found.
lead_paragraph: Investors in private equity funds typically have to wait as long as a decade to get their money back. But many are now cashing out ahead of schedule by selling their investments into a secondary market, reflecting the buoyant state of private equity.

headline: John Kirby, Pentagon Spokesman, Will Be Replaced With a Civilian
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

headline: 36 Hours in Beijing
abstract: Soaking up street life in the city’s remaining hutong neighborhoods, among their alleys, temples and traditional dining spots.
lead_paragraph: It seems like only yesterday that Beijing had its much-ballyhooed “coming out” party — the 2008 Summer Olympics — but things don’t slow down much in China’s frenetic capital. Already, the city is eyeing another Olympics bid (it’s one of two finalists for the 2022 Winter Games) and planning a $13 billion airport that is expected to be among the busiest in the world when it opens in 2019. And yet compared with China’s other vertical megacities, Beijing is still a traditionalist at heart. The city may have fantastic new sculptural monuments designed by Zaha Hadid and Rem Koolhaas, but to truly understand Beijing, one has to delve into the remaining hutong neighborhoods — traditional alleyways lined with courtyard homes — and smell the sweet potatoes roasting on coal fires in the winter.

headline: Pussy Riot Releases ‘I Can’t Breathe,’ a Protest Song for Eric Garner
abstract: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova worked with Richard Hell, Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Andrew Wyatt of Miike Snow.
lead_paragraph: Two members of Pussy Riot, the Russian activist group, have made their first foray into English-language protest music, with the help of a who’s who of indie rockers. In a video released Wednesday for a song called “I Can’t Breathe,” Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, who were jailed for protesting in Russia, are buried in black dirt, while wearing Russian police uniforms. Their collaborators on the song, made in memory of Eric Garner and using his last words as its title and closing lyrics, include Nick Zinner of Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Andrew Wyatt of Miike Snow, as well as two Russian acts, Scofferlane and Jack Wood, which supplied the vocals (“It’s getting dark, New York City/I need to catch my breath”). Richard Hell, the punk musician and writer, reads out Mr. Garner’s last words.

headline: Scott Walker on Not Having a College Degree
abstract: He’d be the first president in more than 60 years without at least a B.A.
lead_paragraph: If Scott Walker, the Republican governor of Wisconsin, were to run, and win, in 2016, he’d be the first president in more than 60 years without at least a bachelor’s degree. Given that everything a potential candidate does or does not do, including what he eats at campaign stops, is considered fair game for critics, it’s no surprise that his B.A.-lessness has become a hot topic of conversation. “Is having a college degree a presidential prerequisite?” asked a Washington Post headline.

headline: Walton Street Is Charmingly Old-Fashioned — at Least for Now
abstract: The London enclave, which has remained largely unchanged for 30 years, is a unique destination in the city.
lead_paragraph: London’s Walton Street, in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, to the west of the city, has remained largely unchanged for the last 30 years. But for an increasingly international set of locals, that is its chief delight. Once home to the humorist P.G. Wodehouse, Walton Street still emanates an old-school English charm. Though flanked by Harrods and The Conran Shop, it’s an enclave of independent, if occasionally chichi, antiques and interiors shops, and art galleries and boutiques that has — so far — bucked the trend for high-end homogenization. There are, however, signs that change is afoot: Many of the streets’ stucco homes are straining under the scaffolds of hi-spec redevelopment, and rumor has it that the James Perse store may soon be joined by Charlotte Olympia and Christian Dior.

headline: In Defense of Islam
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Islamic fundamentalism is Islamic, but a traditional Islam need not be fundamentalist.
lead_paragraph: Consider this post a kind of complement, maybe, to my anti-anti-Crusades commentary of late. The big foreign policy piece that everyone is talking about this week, and deservedly, is Graeme Wood’s deep Atlantic dive into the religious premises underpinning the Islamic State’s vision and grand strategy. Wood’s argument is rich enough to defy easy summary, but his core point is that Western analysts tend to understate not only the essential religiosity of ISIS’s worldview, but the extent to which that worldview has substantial theological grounding. It isn’t just a few guys making up a cult out of random bits of scripture; its political-religious vision appeals precisely because it derives “from coherent and even learned interpretations of Islam.” And we ignore the coherence of those interpretations at our peril: The Islamic State’s “intellectual genealogy” is intensely relevant to its political strategy, and its theology “must be understood to be combatted.”

headline: Rosanne Somerson Named RISD President
abstract: After a nine-month search that involved more than 100 candidates, the Rhode Island School of Design announced today that Ms. Somerson has been named its 17th president.
lead_paragraph: When Rosanne Somerson became interim president of Rhode Island School of Design, the job came with a 21-room historic house in Providence, R.I., but not much furniture. Fortunately, Ms. Somerson was a founder and longtime head of the school’s furniture department with close ties to the academic community. As described in the “On Location” feature of Feb. 12, she filled the rooms with dozens of furniture and art pieces made by RISD faculty, students and alumni, creating not only a comfortable second home but also a public showcase of the school’s talent.

headline: Review: ‘Schubert’s Winter Journey’ Allows Ian Bostridge to Obsess
abstract: Mr. Bostridge uses his performance history to help him write about the intricacies of the “Winterreise” song cycle.
lead_paragraph: When Schubert played “Winterreise,” one of the greatest cycles of art songs, or lieder, ever written, for a gathering of his friends, they were puzzled. As one member of his circle recalled decades later, they were “utterly dumbfounded by the mournful, gloomy tone of these songs.”

headline: Paula Hayes Reimagines a Victorian Totem in Madison Square Park
abstract: The artist’s 18 “gazing globes,” with little landscapes inside, are one of two projects she is launching this week.
lead_paragraph: Paula Hayes can see into the future. “I’ve always been a bit witchy,” she squeals. It’s true: Hayes has been infusing her sculptures with a bit of history and magic since she began creating work back in the 1990s. But it wasn’t until her first show in 2004 with Salon 94, which represents her to this day, that it became clear the environmentally focused artist’s iconic medium, the round terrarium, would trickle down into critical mass. These days, retailers like Target unknowingly shill imitations of her work. Now that every twentysomething in Brooklyn (and their mothers elsewhere) own the little glass spheres that contain living plants, succulents and crystals, Hayes has moved on. “I’m contemplating in the realm of nature, but it has moved into sculptural form and illumination,” the 57-year-old says. On top of her terrariums, Hayes is internationally lauded as a landscape artist — even divining the backyards and terraces of the art world’s elite, including the gallerists Jeanne Rohatyn Greenberg (of Salon 94), David Zwirner and Marianne Boesky. For her next project, though, “I’m not using living plants,” Hayes says. “That’s a huge departure for my audience, the aspect of the botanical or horticultural, with more than 15 years in garden design,” Hayes continues. So what is she doing?

headline: Review: Jamie Barton Shows That She’s a Powerhouse of a Mezzo-Soprano
abstract: Ms. Barton displayed her dramatic, voluptuous voice with songs by Dvorak and Chausson in a recital at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: Pity the pianist who has to accompany Jamie Barton. It’s not that Ms. Barton, a dramatic mezzo-soprano who has found stardom in the opera world since her double first prize in the 2013 Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, treats her chamber music partners callously. During her recital debut at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening, she exuded immense likability and down-to-earth charm. No, the predicament for Bradley Moore, her very able pianist on this occasion, was that next to the magnificent power of Ms. Barton’s voice, virtually everything he played came out sounding forlorn.

headline: Reinventing the Rolling Pin

An engineer turned product designer, Mr. Vann recently seized on the rolling pin, which he said was long due for an update. Experience had taught him that two features guarantee the success of any modern object: anodized aluminum and LEDs.

headline: ‘Vikings,’ and Its Discontent Warlord, Begins Its Third Season

You can see it in the “thick, rounded over-sides and legs,” said the designer, Jason Roskey, which incorporate softness while “maintaining a clean shape.” Mr. Roskey’s other new bench, Sawyer (top), is more traditional and less curvaceous, but has a lightness to it as well, with its open back.

That destination, along with three others (Vienna, Bora Bora and Bandol, France), formed the inspiration for her latest collection of wallpaper, out next month.

headline: A Look Behind the Headlines on China’s Coal Trends
keywords: ['Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A reality check on coal trends in China and their implications for the climate.

headline: The Mystery of Moore
abstract: Why not a better hack?
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait seems boggled at an op-ed from Stephen Moore, the chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, attacking Obamacare: Not one alleged fact cited in the piece is right. And we’re not talking about matters of interpretation. CBO has not changed its view that the ACA will reduce the deficit; health costs have not increased faster than before; premiums are not skyrocketing.

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Lauds Cannon Films
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Film Comment Selects series features a tribute to Cannon Films.
lead_paragraph: “My education was Bogart, Cagney and Cooper,” the director and producer Menahem Golan once said. Somewhere along the line, jiggling babes and giggling psychos, Sylvester Stallone and a voracious appetite for schlock became part of the mix, too. Mr. Golan is best known for the Cannon Group, the company he ran in the 1980s with his cousin Yoram Globus. The two men and the strange, wonderful and often terrible cinematic world they made are the subject of the buoyantly funny opening-night attraction of this year’s Film Comment Selects, the annual showcase that invades the Film Society of Lincoln Center on Friday, bringing with it edge and mess, a splatter of guts and some real glory.

headline: A Classic Moment by the Pool

lead_paragraph: No doubt you’ve seen the photo. Two attractive women sit in lounge chairs beside a teal-blue pool, looking fabulous and moneyed. A third, all legs and carefree attitude, strides toward them with a drink in her hand. In the background is a modern glass-and-stone house and purplish mountains. The landscape is idyllic. The sunlight is hazy and golden. You would live inside the photo if you could.
