headline: Obama’s Economic Report Focuses on Income Inequality
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The report defines which problems need urgent attention, and what can be accomplished under the current administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday stepped up his efforts to define which economic problems need urgent attention — and what kind of attention would work — if not under his administration, then the next.

headline: A Sprawling Retrospective for Kehinde Wiley’s Heroic Portraits
abstract: “A New Republic,” featuring 56 works by the award-winning artist, opens this week at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: Barely two months in, it has already been a big year for the Brooklyn-based painter Kehinde Wiley. Last month, the artist received a 2014 U.S. State Department Medal of Arts; and this week, he prepares for his first museum retrospective, “A New Republic,” which will open at the Brooklyn Museum on Friday. Throughout his career, Wiley’s pieces have canonized the people they portray: Descendants from Africa, Haiti, Jamaica and elsewhere, depicted along with emblems of culture and identity. “My work, for a long time, has focused on the ideals that we celebrate in America and abroad,” he says. Many of his paintings outsource their influence from popular movements that predate the 19th century, like Flemish portraiture from the Northern Renaissance. But instead of using dark colors to create a sense of severity or authority, Wiley’s portraits explode with energy and color — particularly in their use of clothing, which occupies a central role in his work. “Fashion is fragile and fleeting,” he notes. “But it is also an indicator for the cultural and social appetites for a nation.”

headline: At Napa Music Festival, Chefs Are in the Lineup
abstract: BottleRock Napa Valley, a music festival in May, will feature chefs and sommeliers in addition to bands like No Doubt and Imagine Dragons.
lead_paragraph: Chefs are often called the new rock stars, and now one California music festival plans to give some culinary headliners their own stage.

headline: Jordan Stakes Role Against Terrorism
abstract: Foreign Minister Nasser Judeh said that Jordan would lead the fight against violent extremism, saying any doubt that “this is our war as Muslims” has been removed.
lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Nasser Judeh said that Jordan would lead the fight against violent extremism, saying any doubt that “this is our war as Muslims” has been removed.

headline: Lucy Skaer: ‘Sticks & Stones’ and ‘Random House’
abstract: In two shows, the excellent British artist Lucy Skaer covers much ground in several mediums with uneven results.
lead_paragraph: In two shows, the excellent British artist Lucy Skaer covers much ground in several mediums with uneven results. The repurposing and recycling of objects, images and forms — from other art, her own work, her life — are prominent in Ms. Skaer’s work, as with many artists today. The strategy yields outstanding results in the five related sculptures at Murray Guy. The tone is set by a low-lying sculpture: two thick, rough-edged slices of mahogany inlaid with smaller objects found around her studio — a tiny prototype, parts of other sculptures, a small lithography stone and an oblong blue ceramic tile. The piece, which evokes sculptures by Carl Andre and Bruce Nauman, is itself a prototype for the next four: an all-ceramic version; one in marble with touches of malachite; another in aluminum with gunmetal; and, finally, an all-wood version (including veneer). Together they form a stunning meditation on processes, materials and craft, on mutating details and textural contrasts, on looking, achieving an almost cosmic scope. I doubt each would seem quite so rich on its own.

headline: Saya Woolfalk: ‘ChimaTEK: Hybridity Visualization System’
abstract: The Afro-futurist artist Saya Woolfalk conjures a better tomorrow in which women create a consciousness free of the present day’s social ills.
lead_paragraph: Saya Woolfalk’s engagingly imaginative exhibition evokes the lobby for a New Age boutique. It includes paintings of psychedelic kimonos, digital animations of archetypal iconography and exotic avatars and colorful mannequin heads decorated with bones and jewelry. Like the young video artist Jacolby Satterwhite among others, Ms. Woolfalk extends the genre known as Afro-futurism, which includes the music of Sun Ra and George Clinton and science-fiction novels by Samuel R. Delany and Octavia Butler.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Reunion, of Sorts
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago, who was the president’s first chief of staff, joined Mr. Obama at a ceremony Thursday proclaiming the city’s Pullman district a national monument.

headline: Helmut Lang at Sperone Westwater
abstract: In time, Mr. Lang may become as forward-looking in his art as he was in his fashion design.
lead_paragraph: In time, Helmut Lang may become as forward-looking in his art as he was in his fashion design. Right now, he only looks back, content with making standard-issue Post-Minimalism derived from ideas and materials pioneered more than 40 years ago by artists like Richard Van Buren, Keith Sonnier, Lynda Benglis, Eva Hesse and Hannah Wilke. Mr. Lang has long been acquainted with contemporary art, but this work evinces an all-too-typical amnesia about the recent past and a seeming disdain for the rigors of finding your own art rather than settling for a pastiche of the achievements of others.

headline: Reuben Cox: ‘Topical Songs’
abstract: Quasi-documentary photographs share the gallery with comments on extinction.
lead_paragraph: Reuben Cox started off in the documentary mode, photographing people from social groups and subcultures: marriages at City Hall, rural transgender women, bands and fans at the club CBGB, or players at a contract-bridge world championship. In this show, he turns the camera elsewhere or discards it entirely and uses changes in photography as a metaphor for his own move cross-country, from New York to Los Angeles, and the onset of middle age.

headline: Photos of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, China and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, China and Pakistan.

headline: Review: August Wilson on His Creative Process as a Playwright
abstract: PBS’s “American Masters” explores the life of this Pulitzer-winning playwright and his significance in chronicling African-American culture on the stage.
lead_paragraph: August Wilson died almost 10 years now, but that doesn’t stop him from giving a mini-master class Friday on — appropriately — PBS’s latest episode of “American Masters.” In archival footage, we hear him describe his writing process.

headline: White Sneakers
abstract: After seasons of loud, colorful trainers comes the welcome respite of quiet leather kicks.
lead_paragraph: After seasons of loud, colorful trainers comes the welcome respite of quiet leather kicks.

headline: Katarzyna Kozyra: ‘Looking for Jesus’
abstract: Ms. Kozyra’s film focuses on people with Jerusalem syndrome, characterized in part by delusional over-identification with characters from the Bible.
lead_paragraph: In “Looking for Jesus,” an entertaining, philosophically intriguing, 70-minute video by the Polish artist Katarzyna Kozyra, the camera follows Ms. Kozyra in Jerusalem, where she finds and interviews men who believe they are Jesus. She’s looking for people with a condition known as Jerusalem syndrome, characterized in part by delusional over-identification with characters from the Bible.

headline: G.M. Names New Counsel After Wave of Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The company has been criticized over how it handled the ignition switch problem, and members of Congress last year called for Michael Millikin to be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: General Motors named a new top lawyer on Thursday to succeed its embattled general counsel, Michael Millikin, who faced scathing criticism on Capitol Hill after the company’s ignition switch scandal.

headline: Review: ‘Western Society,’ It’s a Selfie World After All
abstract: Gob Squad, a media-mixing British-German arts collective, poses the big and not-so-big questions of contemporary civilization in this show.
lead_paragraph: Go ahead. Take a picture. Make a memory. Then send it out into the universe, and maybe it will turn into somebody else’s memory, too. You’ll be a star. You’ll be an interchangeable nobody. These destinies are not mutually exclusive.

headline: Canada Charges SNC-Lavalin in Fraud and Bribery Involving Qaddafi Regime
abstract: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police accused the company of bribing and defrauding the Libyan government.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — SNC-Lavalin, the Montreal-based engineering company, and two of its units were charged on Thursday with fraud and bribery in relation to their dealings with the regime of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan dictator.

headline: Feb. 19, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, South Korea and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Italy, South Korea and India.

headline: Inside the Towers of Secrecy
abstract: Louise Story describes how the series of articles she wrote with Stephanie Saul about powerful shell companies came together, both in and out of the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, Louise Story and Stephanie Saul, two reporters from The Times’s investigations unit, worked on a series of articles about international shell companies that own some of New York City’s most expensive real estate, and the people behind them.

headline: Review: In Reif Larsen’s ‘I Am Radar,’ an Odyssey of Exploding Particles
abstract: The novel opens with the birth of a boy during a power failure at a hospital and follows with a journey through time and space.
lead_paragraph: “I Am Radar” is a big, fat, enticing-looking epic that begins with a hauntingly surreal moment. In Elizabeth, N.J., a place not known for strokes of magic, a woman named Charlene is in a hospital, giving birth to her first son. Her husband, a Serbian refugee named Kermin, is with her. But during the birth, the hospital experiences a power failure, and the frightened doctor has only a flashlight to aid him during the delivery. Even so, the doctor can tell something strange is happening. “Under the pocket light’s dull beam,” the author, Reif Larsen, writes, “the child appeared almost prehistoric.”

headline: Deadly CRE Germs Linked to Hard-to-Clean Medical Scopes
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration warned health care workers that a superbug might be spreading because of diagnostic scopes that are difficult to sterilize.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal officials warned health care providers across the country on Thursday that difficult-to-clean medical scopes inserted down the throat might be infecting patients with deadly drug-resistant bacteria.

headline: Gee’s Bend Quilts in 2 Shows at Lehman College
abstract: The quilts, made by generations of African-American women in a remote Alabama town, and Linda Day Clark’s related photographs have traveled to the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Many people are familiar with the Gee’s Bend quilts by now. Made by generations of African-American women who were the descendants of slaves, and later sharecroppers, the quilts developed on an isolated peninsula carved out by the Alabama River southwest of Selma. Over the last decade and a half, however, the art world has discovered Gee’s Bend, and the quilts have been exhibited in museums nationwide. A small show at the Lehman College Art Gallery of 14 quilts by seven artists, all made since 1990, and an accompanying exhibition of photographs, offers an update.

headline: Chinese New Year Returns With Bargain Meals, Music and Parades
abstract: Choose from various ways to celebrate the Lunar New Year in New York’s neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Chinatown is whatever you make of it. There is the strange blend of chain restaurants and knockoff clothing outlets on Canal Street. There are the popular restaurants, like Joe’s Shanghai or Golden Unicorn, where an hour’s wait is the price of authenticity. Then there are the narrow side streets and uninviting storefronts where the real treats lie: feasts that reward the adventuresome and often cost less than an appetizer anywhere else.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Weekend entertainments from the archives of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: 62 YEARS AGO

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: food recommendations, varicose veins and persistent grief. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: food recommendations, varicose veins and persistent grief. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Corporate Crimes, Individual Accountability Is Elusive
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Books and Literature', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Deferred Prosecution Agreements']
abstract: Thanks to Brandon L. Garrett, author of “Too Big to Jail,” we know the notion that the government has been lax on corporate wrongdoers isn’t just folk wisdom.
lead_paragraph: “We have never hesitated to investigate and prosecute any individual, institution or organization that attempted to exploit our markets and take advantage of the American people,” Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. proclaimed this month when the Justice Department announced that Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, had agreed to pay $1.375 billion to settle civil charges that it inflated ratings on mortgage-backed securities at the heart of the financial crisis.

headline: Review: ‘Kehinde Wiley: A New Republic’ at the Brooklyn Museum
abstract: You can love or hate the artist’s works, which often insert black individuals into classic Western portraiture, but it is hard to ignore them.
lead_paragraph: You can love or hate Kehinde Wiley’s bright, brash, history-laden, kitsch-tinged portraits of confident, even imperious young black men and women. But it is hard to ignore them, especially right now, with scores of them bristling forth from “Kehinde Wiley: A New Republic,” the artist’s mind-teasing, eye-catching survey at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Before Oscar Night, Playing the Odds With a Bettor’s Mind-Set
abstract: Several betting markets publicly list Oscar odds, and their record over the past decade is remarkably good.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Awards ceremony will emphasize the suspense of the unknown on Sunday night. But Hollywood insiders are well aware that many nominees have little chance of winning — and know who those nominees are.

headline: World Music Institute, a Tour for the Ears and Hips
abstract: The organization’s artistic director, Par Neiburger, has developed a different vision for programming.
lead_paragraph: STANDING inside a large ring of amateur dancers in front of a stage cluttered anticipatorily with brass instruments and conga drums, Chris Rogicki demonstrated Cuban salsa moves that could have been mistaken for dating strategies.

headline: Fall/Winter 2015’s Golden Girls
abstract: Donna Karan, Michael Kors and Ralph Lauren all showed sparkling showstoppers, just in time for Oscar night.
lead_paragraph: Throughout New York Fashion Week, which comes to a close today, and just in time for this Sunday’s 87th Academy Awards, designers have presented red-carpet gowns befitting the most smoldering of starlets. A selection of gold looks, reminiscent of the Oscar itself, appeared first at Donna Karan, then at Michael Kors and today at Ralph Lauren. And on each runway, the sparkling gowns were one-of-a-kind showstoppers.

headline: ‘American Sniper,’ the People’s Choice for Best Picture
abstract: When asked about the best movie they had seen in the last year, people in a Google survey cited “American Sniper” far more than any other film.
lead_paragraph: The public has a clear favorite heading into the Academy Awards on Sunday night: “American Sniper.”

headline: Egypt’s Crisis Across the Border With Libya
abstract: Cairo’s airstrike against the Islamic State could endanger the United Nations’ fragile peace effort.
lead_paragraph: Egyptian armed forces on Monday carried out a predawn airstrike in Libya in response to the beheading of as many as 21 Egyptian Coptic Christians by the Islamic State, the extremist group also known as ISIS or ISIL. The Egyptians attacked camps, training facilities and weapons depots belonging to the group near the Libyan town of Derna, a militant stronghold.

headline: Assembling Micro-apartments
abstract: Tiny prefabricated apartments are assembled at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for use in My Micro NY, New York, a building to rise at East 27th Street in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Tiny prefabricated apartments are assembled at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for use in My Micro NY, New York, a building to rise at East 27th Street in Manhattan.

headline: Fraternity Sues Wesleyan University Over Order to Admit Women
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Delta Kappa Epsilon and its alumni organization filed the suit seeking a temporary injunction, saying the policy put in place by the Connecticut university in the name of equality was, in fact, discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: Almost five months after fraternities at Wesleyan University in Connecticut were ordered to admit women as both members and residents, one organization announced on Thursday that it was suing the university, saying the policy put in place in the name of equality was, in fact, discriminatory.

headline: Obama Designates Monument in Chicago and Backs Its Mayor, Rahm Emanuel
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The president supported the re-election bid of Mr. Emanuel, his former chief of staff, while visiting Chicago to create the Pullman National Monument.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — President Obama on Thursday offered a hearty White House embrace to his friend and former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, who is running for re-election as mayor here and faces voters next week.

headline: A Twist on a Very French Chignon for J. Mendel
abstract: Backstage at today’s fall/winter 2015 show, the hairstylist James Pecis was inspired by ’70s chic.
lead_paragraph: “She is that French Vogue ’70s woman,” explained the hairstylist James Pecis backstage, of his beauty inspiration for J. Mendel’s fall/winter 2015 show. “Back then there was a reoccurrence of this type of look — all the girls were side parting and rolling their hair back.” So for today’s runway, he updated the classic chignon to complement the designer’s ultra-feminine collection. After parting the hair to the left, he divided it into several sections, saturating each one with Phyto Professional Wet Gel for a smooth, sleek texture. Pecis then used a blowdryer to add volume to the front of the hair before pulling it all into two ponytails, which he twisted together, pinning them up into a sleek, smooth variation on the elegant chignon. The effect: très magnifique.

headline: Review: In Britten’s ‘The Rape of Lucretia,’ a Savage Act With Resonance Today
abstract: Juilliard Opera’s production draws parallels between this harrowing work and college “rape culture.”
lead_paragraph: Juilliard Opera’s production of Britten’s “The Rape of Lucretia” has arrived at a time when disturbing reports about sexual assault on college campuses have been in the news. In a program note, the director Mary Birnbaum, says she and her cast drew a clear parallel between “college ‘rape culture’ ” and this harrowing Britten chamber opera, with a libretto by Ronald Duncan, first performed in 1946.

headline: Oscars 2015: The Carpetbagger’s Predictions
abstract: Cara Buckley makes educated Oscar guesses.
lead_paragraph: Get your Oscar ballot ready. Here are the Bagger’s coin tosses and sure things and likely winners:

headline: Obama Makes Pullman a National Monument
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama designated the Pullman District in Chicago a national monument and spoke about the history of the area, which helped create a new American middle class.
lead_paragraph: President Obama designated the Pullman District in Chicago a national monument and spoke about the history of the area, which helped create a new American middle class.

headline: Off the Runway
abstract: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the last day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Review: In ‘The Jack and Triumph Show,’ a Mama’s Boy Faces Temptation
abstract: This irreverent new comedy focuses on a former child star trying to stay on the straight and narrow path after recovering from a downward spiral.
lead_paragraph: Let’s begin with a hat-tip to June Squibb, an Oscar-nominated actress, for being willing to play third fiddle to an undereducated man-boy and a vituperative dog puppet. That’s what she does in Adult Swim’s irreverent new comedy, “The Jack and Triumph Show,” which begins Friday night. The show is hilarious with a capital If: It’s hilarious If you like Triumph the Insult Comic Dog.

headline: Review: ‘Legends & Visionaries’ by New York Theater Ballet
abstract: New York Theater Ballet’s production at New York Live Arts includes two premieres, along with a 1964 work by Merce Cunningham and a touch of Lewis Carroll.
lead_paragraph: For a small company that seemed near to closing not long ago, New York Theater Ballet is looking almost indecently healthy. I went to its “Legends & Visionaries” program at New York Live Arts this week hoping to enjoy maybe two of the four works; I left not only having enjoyed three or four (I will explain this ambiguity) but also with affectionate admiration for the dancers. Never before in my experience of this troupe have its performers made so engaging and memorable an impression.

headline: Exclusive | 1045 Fifth Avenue
abstract: A 10-room penthouse on the 14th and 15th floors is poised to enter the market for the first time ever.
lead_paragraph: A 10-room penthouse on the 14th and 15th floors is poised to enter the market for the first time ever.

headline: Denim, Remixed
abstract: These crisp trousers, flowy topcoats and fitted blazers make us see indigo in a whole new hue.
lead_paragraph: These crisp trousers, flowy topcoats and fitted blazers make us see indigo in a whole new hue.

headline: The Shame of Solitary Confinement
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: People are angry that South Carolina is isolating inmates for using Facebook. They should be angry about much more than that.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Dave Maass, an investigative researcher for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, found a document on the website of the South Carolina Department of Corrections that listed nearly 400 inmates in the state’s prisons who had broken a rule against posting on social-media sites. Prisons often bar inmates from Facebook, Twitter and other sites, citing a concern that they could use social media to plan contraband drops or intimidate witnesses — and also because their presence online is evidence that they’re using contraband cellphones, since prisoners generally lack Internet access through other means.

headline: N.F.L. Suspends Use of Helmet Sensors
abstract: The league will not use sensors in helmets next season to measure hits, ending — temporarily — one effort to better understand concussions.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. will not use sensors in players’ helmets next season to measure head hits, ending — at least temporarily — one effort to gain a better understanding of concussions.

headline: Malaria in Widening Area Resists Drug, Study Finds
abstract: If resistance to the drug, artemisinin, were to spread, it could hamper treatment of a disease that kills hundreds of thousands a year, mostly in Africa.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The world’s best drug for treating malaria, a medicine that is the key to saving millions of lives in Africa and beyond, is losing its efficacy in a much larger swath of territory than was previously known, according to research that was released Friday.

headline: At New York Fashion Week, the Last Looks Are Diverse
abstract: Fashion week ended with collections from Ralph Lauren, Boss Woman, Calvin Klein and more, with inspirations from every direction.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week drew to a close in an odd and fractured state: decentralized and unfocused.

headline: Review: ‘Hot Tub Time Machine 2’ Heads Back to the Bubbles
abstract: The sequel to “Hot Tub Time Machine” features Rob Corddry and Craig Robinson playing characters who have benefited from learning about the future in the first film.
lead_paragraph: Who knows what the world will look like in 2025? The goofballs from the smart-dumb 2010 guy comedy “Hot Tub Time Machine” are accidentally given an advance peek in the frenzied, chaotic sequel. As could have been predicted, “Hot Tub Time Machine 2” is vastly inferior to the first “Hot Tub,” but it’s not stupid so much as desperately frantic.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the chief executive of Allianz Global Investors, one of Europe’s biggest money managers, Elizabeth Corley is familiar with suspense.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservative donors, including those who once encouraged Gov. Chris Christie to seek the White House, say the governor’s style has driven them to support others.
lead_paragraph: He does not return phone calls. He does not ask for support. He arrives late for meetings. And he acts as if he has all the time in the world.

headline: Review: In ‘McFarland, USA,’ Kevin Costner Coaches Cross-Country Runners
abstract: In “McFarland USA,” Mr. Costner leads a team of Hispanic high schoolers to a championship, while getting closer to them and their families.
lead_paragraph: An entirely predictable, mostly honorable movie, “McFarland, USA” tells the story of a washed-up coach who turns a bunch of misfits into a team of champions. It’s “Hoosiers,” more or less, relocated to a poor agricultural town in California’s Central Valley in 1987. The sport is not basketball, football or baseball — the usual athletic pursuits in this genre — but cross-country running. The director, Niki Caro, who is originally from New Zealand and whose earlier films include “Whale Rider” and “North Country,” has an eye for dramatic landscapes, which lends some visual grandeur to the training and racing scenes.

headline: Researcher Discovers Superfish Spyware Installed on Lenovo PCs
abstract: The malicious code was buried deep inside the machines, where regular security software would have a hard time finding it. Lenovo says it stopped including the software in January.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo, the Chinese tech giant, was shipping PCs with spyware that tracks its customers’ every move online, and renders the computers vulnerable to hackers.

headline: Tech Investors Create a Billion-Dollar-Baby Boom
abstract: Less than a year after Snapchat was valued at about $10 billion, the hunt is on for the next proverbial “unicorn,” a nascent business worth $1 billion or more — on paper, at least.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a year makes.

headline: MSNBC Removes Two Hosts to Focus on Straight News
abstract: The change is a strategy shift at MSNBC, which long has filled its schedule with left-leaning political commentary and now is moving toward straight news from 9 a.m. until 3 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Facing weak ratings for its afternoon shows, MSNBC is shaking up its daytime schedule to focus on straight news coverage. The cable news network said on Thursday that it was canceling its 1 p.m. broadcast hosted by Ronan Farrow, as well as its 2 p.m. broadcast hosted by Joy-Ann Reid. In their place will be a two-hour block of news with Thomas Roberts, host of MSNBC’s “Way Too Early” at 5:30 a.m. Ms. Reid will work as a national correspondent, and Mr. Farrow, the 27-year-old son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, will work on a series of prime time specials and interviews. The change is a strategy shift at MSNBC, which long has filled its schedule with left-leaning political commentary and now is moving toward straight news from 9 a.m. until 3 p.m.

abstract: The New York Times Company announced two new nominees for its board, Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Expedia, and Rebecca Van Dyck, a Facebook executive.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company announced two new nominees for its board, Dara Khosrowshahi, the chief executive of Expedia, and Rebecca Van Dyck, a Facebook executive, on Thursday.

headline: Long-Term Care Insurance: Costs Are Up but Vary Widely
abstract: A report by the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance finds that rates rose this year an average of 9 percent.
lead_paragraph: Rates for long-term care insurance, which can help pay for care in your own house or in a nursing home, rose this year an average of nearly 9 percent, a new industry report finds.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Howard University Fills in Wikipedia’s Gaps in Black History
abstract: Students and faculty at the university, one of the nation’s pre-eminent historically black higher education institutions, set out Thursday to expand entries and create new ones.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wikipedia is a vast ocean of erudition, with entries on virtually every subject, obscure to earth-shattering, and, it may seem, every human being of even vague renown. It is also, its leaders concede, very white.

headline: Review: ‘Wild Tales’ Explores the Blurred Limits of Morality
abstract: This Argentine anthology, an Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, looks at human behavior when pushed to the extremes.
lead_paragraph: As high-spirited as its title suggests, “Wild Tales” opens on a savage note and ends, well, that’s for you to find out. In between its shocker start and equally startling windup, this Argentine anthology offers up a scabrous, often unsettlingly funny look at human behavior in extremis. It’s a mad, mad social Darwinian world, churning with men and women who, whether pushed a lot or just a little, are all eager to do the worst to one another. They pounce and then they pummel, engaging in drag-down fights that leave them black and blue and sometimes stone-cold dead.

headline: For Nascar Drivers, Switching Teams Has Paid Off Before
abstract: As the latest high-profile driver to switch racing teams, Carl Edwards may be the competitor to watch in this year’s Sprint Cup title hunt.
lead_paragraph: When Kyle Busch was dropped by Hendrick Motorsports after 2007 and signed to race for Joe Gibbs Racing, few could have predicted what happened next. Busch went from one win with Hendrick in 2007 to eight victories with Gibbs in 2008.

headline: Review: ‘All the Wilderness,’ a Tale of a Teenage Outsider
abstract: The gangly antihero of the director Michael Johnson’s first feature is a teenage misfit stumbling is way through tragedy and isolation to companionship.
lead_paragraph: The kind of kid who’s a dinner bell for bullies, James (Kodi Smit-McPhee), the gangly antihero of “All the Wilderness,” wears the teenage-misfit badge on his bony frame like a romantic totem. A recent tragedy has exacerbated James’s already ingrowing personality, and now his quirks — quoting Carl Sandburg; drawing pictures of dead houseflies — have acquired a morbid cast that neither his therapist (Danny DeVito) nor his concerned single mother (Virginia Madsen) can pierce.

headline: In Turkey, Even Snow Can Be Tainted by Politics
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: After a snowball broke his window, a shopkeeper is accused of killing the offender, and some say a speech by the president may have planted the seeds of the killing.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — “You are free to throw snowballs at this window,” the signs say in the Kadikoy district on the Asian side of Istanbul, and not because the shopkeepers here love the sound of breaking glass.

headline: Review: In ‘Approaching the Elephant,’ an Experimental Classroom Jungle
abstract: By simply observing and making no judgments, a documentary explores how children behave when classroom routines — or a lack thereof — are totally up to them.
lead_paragraph: In “Approaching the Elephant,” the director Amanda Rose Wilder embeds herself in a tiny New Jersey “free school” that practices a style of self-directed learning, an idea originated by anarchists in Barcelona in the 1900s. Her film invites questions about what makes good schooling, or a strong documentary, but she seems most enamored by what children do, period.

headline: Review: In ‘The DUFF,’ a Wounded Teenage Girl Combats Mockery
abstract: When a student learns she is called the “designated ugly fat friend,” she sets out on a makeover without realizing that vindictiveness is the real problem.
lead_paragraph: Adapted from a novel by Kody Keplinger, whose website says that she wrote the book as a senior in high school, “The DUFF” begins, in an apparent nod to “The Breakfast Club,” by informing us that teenage stereotypes have changed: “Jocks play video games, princesses are on antidepressants.” You could have fooled these characters, who ruthlessly enforce the traditional pecking order.

headline: Moves Don’t Get Knicks and Nets Too Far
abstract: The Knicks and the Nets appeared to improve their overall states by Thursday’s trade deadline but fell short of their primary objectives.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the wildest N.B.A. trade deadline days in recent memory, with 11 transactions taking place across the league before the 3 p.m. cutoff time, and both New York teams had a small hand in it.

headline: Iraqi Assault to Retake Mosul From Islamic State Is Planned for Spring
abstract: The assault, expected to begin in April or May, will require 20,000 to 25,000 Iraqi and Kurdish troops, an official from the United States Central Command said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The assault to retake Mosul, Iraq, from the Islamic State will require 20,000 to 25,000 Iraqi and Kurdish troops and is expected to begin in April or May, an official from the United States Central Command told reporters on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Kung Fu Elliot’ Documentary Follows a Martial Arts Enthusiast
abstract: The film, directed by Matthew Bauckman and Jaret Belliveau, tracks Elliot Scott as he seeks to become an action hero.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Bauckman and Jaret Belliveau’s gritty documentary, “Kung Fu Elliot,” feels at first as if it’s gently parodying a “making of” movie. Its subject, Elliot Scott, is a quirky, sweet-faced martial arts enthusiast and filmmaker from Nova Scotia who hopes to become, he says, “Canada’s first action hero.” Hey, everyone needs a hobby.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Inevitability: This Time Is Different
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Her standing among Democrats was far weaker eight years ago than it is today, based on polls and on the actions of other potential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I mention that Hillary Clinton is an overwhelming favorite for the Democratic nomination — and would be even if Senator Elizabeth Warren ran — the conversation usually comes back to 2008. “She was supposed to be inevitable last time,” the refrain goes, “and she lost.”

headline: Addressing Dysfunction, Port Authority Plans to Install ‘Nonpolitical’ C.E.O.
abstract: The move is to reduce the influence of the governors of New York and New Jersey in the agency, among other changes announced by the Port Authority.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has been a house divided, an agency overseen by people who owed loyalty to one governor or another. The internal division often devolved into dysfunction and has occasionally led to misfeasance, such as the move in 2013 to close some traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: Utilities Push Into Fuel Stations for Electric Cars
abstract: Their goal is nothing less than making the electric car a viable alternative for millions of consumers and, in the process, helping shore up their own flattening business of supplying electricity.
lead_paragraph: Since hitting the mass market about five years ago, electric vehicles have failed to take off, largely, experts say, because a robust network of public charging stations has not been built.

headline: India Deploys Expert Teams to Study Rise in Flu Cases
abstract: Officials are trying to determine the extent of illness, which has caused 700 deaths since the beginning of the year.
lead_paragraph: JAIPUR, India — Indian officials this week scrambled to cope with a rise in cases of the flu, which they say has sickened thousands of people and caused the deaths of 700 since the beginning of January.

headline: N.F.L. Teams With Eye to Future Train a Lens on Marcus Mariota
abstract: Mariota, the soft-spoken Oregon quarterback who is a top prospect in the N.F.L. draft, enters this weekend at the combine with an opportunity for teams to inspect and dissect him.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Inside a luxurious lounge that had been transformed into an area filled with cameras, laptops and seemingly endless ropes of cable cords at Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota faced a line of questioning that ended with his being asked whether he possessed the skills to succeed in the N.F.L.

headline: Giuliani: Obama Had a White Mother, So I’m Not a Racist
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his remarks accusing President Obama of not loving his country.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York on Thursday defended his assertion that President Obama did not love America, and said that his criticism of Mr. Obama’s upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by “a white mother.”

headline: Turkey: Deal Set to Aid Syrian Rebels
abstract: Turkey and the United States signed an agreement to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels to fight militants from the Islamic State, Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said, according to the Anadolu News Agency.
lead_paragraph: After months of talks, Turkey and the United States on Thursday signed an agreement to train and equip moderate Syrian rebels to fight militants from the Islamic State, Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said, according to the Anadolu News Agency. Mr. Cavusoglu also suggested that the fighters could join the rebellion against the Syrian government, although American officials have emphasized that the primary goal is to combat the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. Turkey, along with Jordan and Saudi Arabia, will provide training sites for the program, which is scheduled to begin in March and is expected to train about 15,000 fighters over three years, Turkish and American officials have said. The United States has said that it plans to send about 400 soldiers and other military personnel to train the fighters.

headline: Ideology Seen as Factor in Closings in University of North Carolina System
abstract: A panel in North Carolina has recommended closing three academic centers, including a poverty center and one dedicated to social change, sparking outrage among liberals.
lead_paragraph: An advisory panel of the University of North Carolina’s Board of Governors has recommended closing three academic centers, including a poverty center and one dedicated to social change, inciting outrage among liberals who believe that conservatives in control of state government are targeting ideological opponents in academia.

headline: After Shake-Up Last Year, Sanofi Names New Chief
abstract: Olivier Brandicourt, head of Bayer’s health care business, will have to restore growth in Sanofi’s important diabetes franchise.
lead_paragraph: The French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi on Thursday named Olivier Brandicourt, a top executive at Bayer, as its new chief executive, replacing Christopher A. Viehbacher, who was fired in October.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Not Invited to Meeting on Countering Violent Extremism
abstract: The White House did not want a summit meeting to appear to be too focused on law enforcement issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House did not invite the most senior American official charged with preventing terrorist attacks — the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey — to the three-day conference this week on countering violent extremism in the United States and abroad because the administration did not want the event too focused on law enforcement issues, according to senior American officials.

headline: Yann Demange, Director of ’71,’ Poised for Cinematic Breakout
abstract: For his first feature film, Mr. Demange chose the story of a British soldier lost in Belfast during the conflict in Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, UTAH — By his own admission, the director Yann Demange has a fetish for darkness. Night photography, urban decay, ghostly sodium lighting — he incorporated it all into his debut feature, “ ’71,” set in that tumultuous year in Belfast during the Troubles, as the conflict in Northern Ireland was known.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Traffic Law Vilifies Bus Drivers, Union Says
abstract: The union says arrests in recent accidents involving pedestrians were unfair and called on lawmakers to exempt drivers from a new right-of-way law.
lead_paragraph: A new law penalizing drivers who fail to yield and injure or kill a pedestrian who has the right of way is a central piece of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to eliminate traffic deaths. But the arrest last week of a bus driver who struck a 15-year-old girl angered union officials, who sent a memo to members this week warning that bus drivers were under attack and were being treated like “criminals.”

headline: The Man Who Knows Too Much
abstract: After working in Los Angeles, the writer Peter Mehlman found that he knew all about script structure, studio notes, budget overruns, star quakes and fired directors. It was like seeing a movie before its release.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The first mistake, ordering tickets a day in advance, left 24 hours for the second: telling anyone in this town you’re seeing “The Judge.”

headline: New Details Revealed in Shooting by Police in Washington State
abstract: A spokesman from the investigations unit examining the case said the man killed last week by Pasco, Wash., officers, Antonio Zambrano-Montes, had not been seen for two weeks by his family.
lead_paragraph: New details emerged Thursday about the fatal police shooting of a man in Pasco, Wash., that was captured on video and has resulted in local and federal investigations.

headline: ‘In the Land of the Head Hunters,’ a Recreated Artifact of Ancient Ways
abstract: The movie, out on Blu-ray and DVD, is the reconstruction of a reconstruction, restoring the photographer Edward S. Curtis’s early 1900s feature about the Kwakwaka’wakw Indians of British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: “In the Land of the Head Hunters,” out on Blu-ray and DVD from Milestone, is the reconstruction of a reconstruction. It preserves an artifact that used a once advanced technology to document a no longer extent way of life, and was itself all but lost to history.

headline: Apple Is Forming an Auto Team
abstract: The company has collected about 200 people over the last few years to develop technologies for an electric car, according to two people with knowledge of the company’s plans.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While Apple has been preparing to release its first wearable computers, the company has also been busy assembling a team to work on an automobile.

headline: Awarded Stolen Wages, Workers Struggle to Collect
abstract: A report to be released next week calls for legal changes aimed at giving workers a fighting chance to actually receive stolen wages awarded by authorities.
lead_paragraph: After due consideration of records and testimony, the State of New York found that Marco Lino, who chopped vegetables and mopped floors and hoisted crates six days a week in a Bayside, Queens, greenmarket, was owed $51,025.20 in unpaid wages. For Gregoria Geronomina Jimenez and 34 other workers at three restaurants in Upper Manhattan run by the same owners, the Industrial Board of Appeals ruled that $385,364.34 in earnings had not been paid over four years. Jin Ming Cao, a waiter at a Chinese restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, was underpaid by $142,812.05, part of $1.8 million that a federal judge decided was due to 26 employees of that restaurant and two others run by the same people.

headline: N.J.I.T. Will Get an Arena, but It Still Needs a Home
abstract: N.J.I.T., the only independent Division I college in the country, announced Thursday that it would break ground on a new, long-awaited $100 million multipurpose athletic facility this summer.
lead_paragraph: For a man who was dealing with no heat upstairs and frozen pipes in his basement at home, Lenny Kaplan was remarkably upbeat on Thursday.

headline: Roger’s Cousin
abstract: Friday fun with David Woolf, who is clearly rethinking his avocation.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s not often that a constructor expresses his regrets so clearly in a crossword puzzle, but today we need to lend some support to David Woolf, who is rethinking his avocation of choice.

headline: New York City and State Officials Joining Forces to Combat Tenant Harassment
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the new Tenant Harassment Prevention Task Force, a multiagency effort aimed at weeding out and punishing bad landlords, was a “game-changer.”
lead_paragraph: With tenant harassment complaints against landlords on the rise, New York City and state officials announced on Thursday the creation of a multiagency task force aimed at weeding out and punishing bad landlords.

headline: Jerome Kersey, Stalwart of Top Trail Blazers Teams, Dies at 52
abstract: Kersey was a hard-working forward from a small college who overachieved in pro ball, spending 11 of his 17 seasons in the N.B.A. with Portland.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Kersey, a hard-working forward from a small college who overachieved in pro basketball, starting on two Portland Trail Blazers teams that reached the N.B.A. finals, died on Wednesday in Tualatin, Ore., near Portland. He was 52.

headline: In Hearing, Judge Revisits a 1990 Killing on a Subway Platform
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Confessions', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Johnny Hincapie, who was one of seven men found guilty of killing a tourist from Utah, says his confession in the case was coerced.
lead_paragraph: The victim was a tourist from Utah, and his murder on a Manhattan subway platform seized the city in a way that few killings of the era did. Now, almost 25 years after the man, Brian Watkins, was stabbed to death, the case is back in State Supreme Court.

headline: Owner of the Colts Pays Six Figures for a Les Paul Six-String
abstract: Jim Irsay of the Indianapolis Colts paid $335,500, far below some estimates, to buy the electric guitar known as Black Beauty at an auction in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The owner and chief executive of the Indianapolis Colts — who has a collection of guitars that were played by the likes of Bob Dylan, Jerry Garcia and Elvis Presley — added another on Thursday night, a 60-year-old electric guitar that some musicians say occupies an important place in guitar history.

headline: Never an Islander, Eric Nystrom Returns Home to Nassau Coliseum
abstract: Drafted 10th over all by the Flames in 2002, Nystrom, a Long Island native, is a key player for the Predators, who lost to the Islanders, 5-2, on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Skating at Nassau Coliseum without igniting a flood of memories is most likely impossible for the Long Island native Eric Nystrom of the Nashville Predators, the N.H.L.’s best team.

headline: Plaques, Yes. Pennants, No.
abstract: The Yankees have missed the playoffs the last two years, but for the second straight they will add four plaques to Monument Park in celebration of better days.
lead_paragraph: A busy year at Monument Park once meant adding one or two plaques to its walls. And every so often, a Yankee uniform number would be retired.

headline: F.D.A. Reverses Course on 23andMe DNA Test in Move to Ease Restrictions
abstract: The agency approved a test that would be administered to parents to see if they carry mutations that could cause a rare disorder called Bloom syndrome in their children.
lead_paragraph: The genetic testing company 23andMe on Thursday took a step toward being able to offer consumers health-related information again, winning approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a test for mutations that cause a rare disease.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 19, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Driver Faces Life Sentence in Crash That Killed Expectant Brooklyn Couple
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Julio Acevedo, accused of plowing his car into a livery cab carrying a pregnant Orthodox woman and her husband, was convicted Thursday of second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of plowing his car into a livery cab carrying a pregnant Orthodox woman and her husband, killing the Brooklyn couple and their newborn son, was convicted Thursday of second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said.

headline: Harris Wittels, Television Comedy Writer, Is Dead at 30
abstract: Along with writing for “Parks and Recreation” and “The Sarah Silverman Program,” Mr. Wittels was known for popularizing the term “humblebrag.”
lead_paragraph: Harris Wittels, a producer and writer for the NBC sitcom “Parks and Recreation” who also performed as a stand-up comic and musician, died on Thursday. He was 30.

headline: Rangers, Again Prolific Late in Game, Are Beaten at Their Own Game
abstract: The Rangers added two third-period goals to their recent run of late-game scoring but lost to the Canucks, while picking up a point by extending the game to a shootout.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers were unbeaten on a four-game trip, scoring 11 third-period goals, including three in a come-from-behind 6-5 win over the Islanders on Monday.

headline: Illinois: Cubs Allowed to Continue Renovations
abstract: The Chicago Cubs can proceed with a construction project at Wrigley Field, a federal judge ruled Thursday, but the project’s future remains uncertain as a lawsuit continues by property owners.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Cubs can proceed with a construction project at Wrigley Field, a federal judge ruled Thursday, but the project’s future remains uncertain as a lawsuit continues by property owners who say the renovations will block their views of the stadium. Owners of properties across the street from the outfield have long sold tickets to spectators who watch from their rooftops. Some owners have argued in federal court that a renovation project underway at the stadium, which includes large signs that would be placed in the outfield, violates a contract between them and the team. Judge Virginia M. Kendall of United States District Court in Chicago said Thursday that she did not have the evidence needed for a temporary restraining order to stop construction, as the rooftop owners requested. Both sides will be back in court next month for a hearing on a preliminary injunction that could derail the renovations. “We’ve got Opening Day on April 5,” Judge Kendall said. “I’m going to get my job done before then.”

headline: Big Hello for the Year of the Yang
abstract: The Hung Sing Kwoon Kung Fu and Lion Dance Club stopped at Jade Asian Restaurant in Flushing, Queens, on Thursday to celebrate the Chinese Lunar New Year.
lead_paragraph: The Hung Sing Kwoon Kung Fu and Lion Dance Club stopped at Jade Asian Restaurant in Flushing, Queens, on Thursday to celebrate the Chinese Lunar New Year, symbolized this year by a zodiac animal whose Mandarin name, yang, is translated into English variously as sheep, goat or ram.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended Through Saturday
abstract: Because of snow cleanup, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Because of snow cleanup, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel: The Artist That Never Was
abstract: The late-night television host, whose tenth consecutive “Live: After the Oscars” special airs on ABC this Sunday, illustrates responses to a small set of personal questions.
lead_paragraph: In this new series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment illustrate their responses to a brief questionnaire, revealing their favorite things, darkest secrets — and how they see themselves and the world around them.

headline: The Art and Allure of Marc Jacobs’s Dramatic Stage Sets
abstract: A look back at some of the house’s recent feats of interior design.
lead_paragraph: New York’s fall/winter 2015 Fashion Week went out on a high note, as per usual, with Marc Jacobs’s presentation at the Park Avenue Armory last night. As big a draw as the clothes (a darkly opulent ode to Diana Vreeland) and the people-watching (Nicki Minaj and Deborah Harry sat front-row) was the set: a Stefan Beckman-designed backdrop inspired by Jeremiah Goodman paintings of Vreeland’s famous red room, the latest in a series of immersive — and sometimes provocative — installations. Here, a look back at some of the brand’s other memorable set designs.

headline: Word of the Day | clout
abstract: This word has appeared in 824 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: clout • \ˈklau̇t\ • noun and verb

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 A.M. (CUNY) A TIMESTALKS CONVERSATION: DAVID CARR INTERVIEWS LAURA POITRAS, GLENN GREENWALD AND EDWARD J. SNOWDEN On Feb. 12 Mr. Carr, who wrote about media for The New York Times, sat down at the New School with Ms. Poitras, the Oscar-nominated director of the documentary “Citizenfour,” about Mr. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower; Mr. Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowden’s revelations; and Mr. Snowden himself, who joined the discussion via a video link from Russia. Mr. Carr died later that night. (Repeats at 4 and 9 p.m.) In “Science Goes to the Movies,” a new series at 7:30 p.m., Faith Salie, an NPR host, and Heather Berlin, a neuroscientist, dissect the science portrayed in some current films, starting with hallucinations in “Birdman,” black holes and gravity in “Interstellar” and the work of the theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything.” Emily Rice, an astrophysicist with the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History, weighs in.

headline: Slowly Learning to Fill Big Shoes
abstract: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.
lead_paragraph: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.

headline: Corrections: February 20, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, February 20, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 20, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “If I talk to him for an hour, they undo him in two hours.”

headline: Girls, Math and Science
abstract: Caroline Erisman, head of the Dana Hall School, writes that “it is crucial that we prepare women to assume future leadership positions” in the STEM disciplines.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Our Remaining Days
abstract: James Veras, a reader, writes that “faith and the love of family and many friends are paramount” in his continuing survival.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Guns on Campus?
abstract: Isabelle Leipziger, a college student, writes that “there is no way that the solution” to campus rape “lies in the arming of female students.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Plot to Kill Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Republicans are attempting a manipulation of the legal system that would make a mockery of all that conservative legal scholars profess to believe.
lead_paragraph: Republicans hate activist judges — those black-robed elites who are willing to upset the lives of millions of people just to further a political cause. Ditto trial lawyers trolling for clients, the ambulance-chasing, “Better Call Saul” guys. They hate them, until they need them.

headline: Cranking Up for 2016
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Taxation', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: As any ambitious Republican must do, the early contenders in the presidential race are courting the charlatan caucus.
lead_paragraph: Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, is said to be a rising contender for the Republican presidential nomination. So, on Wednesday, he did what, these days, any ambitious Republican must, and pledged allegiance to charlatans and cranks.

headline: Helping to Heal the Trauma of War
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about veterans and “moral injury.”

headline: Separate Philanthropy From Political Clout
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Money has been flowing from abroad into the Clinton Foundation, which raises too many questions about potential conflicts of interest for a probable presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton Foundation has become one of the world’s major generators of charity, mobilizing global efforts to confront issues like health, climate change, economic development and equality for women and girls.

headline: In Boston, 50 Shades of White Snow
abstract: How to survive when it snows and snows and snows some more in Boston.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — THE first snow day was perfect. My husband and I lay in bed in January and watched the falling snow cover trash cans and quince bushes and pine trees alike, a democratizing force on the landscape. Downstairs, our three kids watched cartoons (or pretty much whatever they wanted) and raided the usually off-limits snack shelf.

headline: When Americans Lynched Mexicans
abstract: Blacks weren’t the only victims of violence by white mobs.
lead_paragraph: THE recent release of a landmark report on the history of lynching in the United States is a welcome contribution to the struggle over American collective memory. Few groups have suffered more systematic mistreatment, abuse and murder than African-Americans, the focus of the report.

headline: Indonesia’s Corruption Fighters in the Fight of Their Lives
abstract: The country’s investigators have often withstood attempts to weaken them. But nothing has seemed as perilous as the most recent turn of events.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Over the past decade, Indonesia was so determined to erase the tainted legacy of Suharto, the strongman forced to resign in 1998, that it established one of the world’s more effective anticorruption agencies. Now the future of that agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission, known as the K.P.K., is under serious threat in a standoff with the police and President Joko Widodo.

headline: Boston’s Winter From Hell
abstract: Boston is used to snow — but nothing like this year’s blizzards.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — BY now you’ve seen the starkly beautiful shots of Boston buried under snow: the panoramic city under a white blanket; snowbanks so high they crest over parked cars; piercing icicles glinting for two full stories from gutters dammed with ice; coat-muffled people dwarfed by snow-walled corridors that once were sidewalks.

headline: Empathy, not Expulsion, for Preschoolers at Risk
abstract: Children who misbehave are increasingly being expelled from preschool. But trained consultants can show teachers how to ease emotional strains that often underlie the behavior.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A few years ago, a boy here was on the verge of being expelled because his teacher felt he was a danger to his classmates.

headline: The Nationalist Solution
abstract: Alienated young men will continue to be drawn to violent extremism unless and until we provide a compelling heroic alternative.
lead_paragraph: The struggle against Islamic extremism has been crippled by a failure of historical awareness and cultural understanding. From the very beginning, we have treated the problem of terrorism through the prism of our own assumptions and our own values. We have solipsistically assumed that people turn to extremism because they can’t get what we want, and fail to realize that they don’t want what we want, but want something they think is higher.

headline: Test Yourself | An Apology Letter From Alex Rodriguez
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 17 article, “Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 17 article, “Exchanging Sword for Pen, Rodriguez Apologizes to Yankees and Fans.”

headline: Man Group to Buy London-Based Investment Manager
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The agreement to acquire NewSmith, which also has offices in Tokyo, is the latest move in a flurry of acquisitions by the British hedge fund company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British hedge fund company Man Group continued its recent spending spree on Friday, reaching a conditional agreement to acquire the investment management business of NewSmith. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Year of the Goat
abstract: When did the Lunar New Year start in 2015?
lead_paragraph: To mark the beginning of the Year of the Goat (or is it the sheep?), we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

headline: Is the Minimum Wage Too Low?
abstract: Does a higher minimum wage lift families out of poverty? Or would it force employers to hire fewer workers?
lead_paragraph: About half of all workers in the United States who are at or below the federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour are ages 16 to 24. Would a higher minimum wage help young people get ahead? Would it help lift families out of poverty? Or would it unintentionally have the opposite effect by dampening hiring? Economists disagree about the effects of a higher minimum wage. What do you think?

headline: Children, Caged for Effect, to Mimic Imagery of ISIS
abstract: Broadcast to frighten and manipulate, the Islamic State’s flamboyant violence consumes the world’s attention while more familiar threats kill far more people.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The killings have been both deliberately lurid and strangely intimate. Designed for broadcast, they have helped the Islamic State militant group build a brand of violence that shocks with its extreme brutality, yet feels as close to viewers as the family images on their smartphones.

headline: At New York Private Schools, Challenging White Privilege From the Inside
abstract: In a new type of diversity initiative at elite institutions, students explore privilege and power and are encouraged to think about social justice in a personal way.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, 20 or so high school students, most of them white, milled about the meetinghouse at Friends Seminary, a private school in Manhattan. They were trying to unload on their classmates slips of paper on which they had jotted down words related to the topic “Things I don’t want to be called.”

headline: Mariam Ghani, a Brooklyn Artist Whose Father Leads Afghanistan
abstract: In her life and her career, Ms. Ghani lives between the labels. A New York-born visual artist, she is also the daughter of Ashraf Ghani, the president of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Mariam Ghani’s apartment is a map to her layered identity.

headline: Looking Back With Intensity
abstract: Shalmon Bernstein was attuned to the “show within a show,” where people were revealed by their costumes or context. He is now rediscovering the gems in his own archives.
lead_paragraph: Shalmon Bernstein arrived in the New York magazine world in the early 1970s with a fully developed eye, a clear, sober voice and a sense of purpose. “I thought in terms of being able to change people’s perceptions,” he said. Then, a decade later, he simply stopped, for reasons that even now are hard for him to explain. “What made me stop?” he asked the other day from his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. “What was more important to me?” Money was a part of it, he said. But looking back now, he saw another force at work.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Feb. 20
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Chinese New Year and Niagara Falls.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Chinese New Year and Niagara Falls.

headline: Internet Taxes, Another Window Into the Net Neutrality Debate
abstract: Congress wants to permanently ban taxes on high-speed Internet service. But will the F.C.C.’s plan for utility-style regulation open a door to new charges?
lead_paragraph: In a rare act of bipartisan unity, Republican and Democratic senators last week presented legislation that would permanently ban taxes on high-speed Internet service to American homes.

headline: Punch Lines and Laughs as TV Show in Vietnam Mocks Government Policy
keywords: ['Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Lunar New Year', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: A hugely popular annual program featuring folkloric figures is embraced for its light, but sharp, mockery of official misdoings.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — The Kitchen Gods were asked by the emperor’s assistant: “What curves gently?”

headline: J. W. Anderson: Clear Desks, Full Days
abstract: The designer discussed the need for efficiency, the difference an LVMH investment makes, and the problem with desks.
lead_paragraph: In episode two of our “In the Studio” series, we go inside the workspace of Jonathan Anderson, the 30-year-old British designer behind J. W. Anderson, to discuss the need for efficiency, the difference an LVMH investment makes and the problem with desks (among other burning questions that did not make the final cut). This conversation has been condensed and edited.

headline: Eurozone Economy Gains Momentum, Survey of Private Sector Shows
abstract: Purchasing managers reported improvement in demand, leading companies to add workers at the fastest pace since 2011, according to Markit Economics.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The eurozone economy perked up again this month, a private sector report showed on Friday, powered by continuing strength in Germany and surprisingly strong growth in France.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Student Crossword | Virus Outbreaks
abstract: Test your knowledge of virus outbreaks by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of virus outbreaks by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: New York’s Forecast: Rising Seas, Continual Heat Waves, and a Little Hope
abstract: Reports project warming mean temperatures, rising sea levels and what would happen if New York City’s buildings lost power in extreme heat and cold.
lead_paragraph: As you went spelunking through snowdrifts in recent days, pondering the moral necessity of pet-friendly ice melt and perhaps noting in horror the story of a Manhattan woman who froze to death hiking in subzero New Hampshire temperatures over the weekend, you were thinking about the future, defined in the moment as July. City functionaries were looking further ahead to a potentially more “Hunger Games” epoch.

headline: Fears Persist That Violence Against Albinos in Tanzania Will Grow
abstract: With elections due in the country in October, the risk of persecution could increase as politicians turn to witchcraft to enhance their prospects.
lead_paragraph: The boy was just a year old when five men with machetes snatched him from his home. Two days later, the police found his body with the arms and legs lopped off.

headline: New York Today: The Lunar New Year, in Pictures
abstract: Friday and the weekend: Chinatown celebrations, just one more freezing day, and a snow shoveling scandal in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this frigid Friday.

headline: Daily Report: A Boom in Technology Investments in Hunt for Next Blockbuster Company
abstract: For investors, the hunt is on for the next proverbial “unicorn,” a nascent business worth $1 billion or more — on paper, at least.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a year makes, Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac report.

headline: Raul Rodriguez, Who Showered Rose Parade With Bouquets on Wheels, Dies at 71
abstract: In addition to designing floats, Mr. Rodriguez also illustrated children’s books, created facades for casinos and made installations for stores and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Raul Rodriguez, who designed more than 500 floral floats for the Tournament of Roses Parade and conceived dazzling confections for other private and public celebrations around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Today in Politics
abstract: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tells us why his inflammatory comments about Mr. Obama’s love (or not) for America can’t be construed as racist.
lead_paragraph: Giuliani Counters Criticism of Obama Comments: ‘This Isn’t Racism’

headline: GFI Group’s Board to Support BGC Partners Takeover Bid
abstract: Howard Lutnick’s BGC Partners wins long battle for the New York brokerage and clearing house.
lead_paragraph: The board of the GFI Group, the New York brokerage and clearing house, threw its support on Friday behind a takeover bid by BGC Partners after shareholders rejected a tie-up with the CME Group last month.

headline: Ask Well: Sick With Two Kinds of Flu?
abstract: Is it possible to get two different strains of flu in the same season?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Emerging From a Father’s 7-Foot-6 Shadow
abstract: Bol Bol wants to finish the humanitarian work his father, Manute, started, but he also wants to get out of his high school coach’s doghouse and into the varsity rotation.
lead_paragraph: ROELAND PARK, Kan. — It is not by happenstance that toy basketball hoops are scattered about the house of 15-year-old Bol Bol, or that his bedroom in the basement is home to about 40 pairs of basketball shoes. His love for the game was passed down by his father, Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6 shot blocker whose impossibly long arms and lighthouse smile made him a fan favorite for 10 N.B.A. seasons before he died in 2010.

headline: With High-Profile Departure, Kerry’s Team Faces a Transition
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: John Kerry’s State Department team is in transition.
lead_paragraph: The departure of Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman, is only part of a larger transition for Secretary of State John Kerry and his team two years into his tenure.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets Await Greek Deal
abstract: Markets await a deal between Greece and its eurozone creditors. | The F.T.C. is challenging Sysco’s takeover of US Foods. | Investors are on the hunt for the next proverbial so-called unicorn.
lead_paragraph: MARKETS AWAIT GREEK DEAL | Uncertainty over the outcome of negotiations between Greece and its European creditors made for nervous markets on Friday morning, as shares in Europe eased off seven-year highs. Germany rejected Greece’s formal request on Thursday to extend its loan program by six months, with one German official describing the Athens proposal as “a Trojan horse, intending to get bridge financing and in substance putting an end to the current program,” according to a Greek government official. Eurozone finance ministers will try again on Friday to break an impasse over Greece’s need for further financing.

headline: The Unsinkable R.B.G.
abstract: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s woman-hear-me-roar history, her frail appearance and her role as leader of the Supreme Court’s liberals have rallied her new fan base.
lead_paragraph: RUTH BADER GINSBURG isn’t planning on going anywhere any time soon.

headline: Kevin Spacey, Star of ‘House of Cards’ and a Bromance With Bill Clinton
abstract: The friendship continues to grow between the former president and the actor who plays Frank Underwood on “House of Cards.”
lead_paragraph: Before Kevin Spacey got into character as Francis Underwood, the fictional congressman who by the third season of “House of Cards” has murdered and manipulated his way into the Oval Office, he liked to portray a real-life president: Bill Clinton.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Q. and A.: Barnett Rubin on China’s Role in Afghanistan
abstract: A veteran Afghanistan scholar and former American adviser shares his thoughts on China’s growing engagement with the troubled country.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, China has made pronouncements that reveal it is willing, perhaps even eager, to grow its engagement with troubled Afghanistan, whose remote Wakhan Corridor abuts China’s western border. On Feb. 12, while visiting Pakistan, Foreign Minister Wang Yi reiterated China’s desire to play a “constructive role” in a hypothetical peace process.

headline: Eurozone Officials Reach Accord With Greece to Extend Bailout
abstract: European finance ministers announced the agreement after an emergency meeting, giving Greece breathing room on its economic and financial troubles.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Ending an acrimonious standoff, European leaders hashed out a deal on Friday to extend Greece’s bailout by four months, giving the troubled country a financial lifeline and avoiding a bankruptcy with potentially destabilizing consequences for the region.

headline: An Engineer Creates for Fun After a Lifetime of Workaday Rules
abstract: Seth Goldstein, 75, holds degrees in engineering and patents for biomedical innovations. But in retirement, he uses his engineering skills for whimsy and art.
lead_paragraph: I don’t need your rockin’ chair,

headline: Giuliani Comments Draw Tweets From Martina Navratilova, Judd Apatow and Others
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s comments on President Obama’s love of America and his upbringing have attracted an array of commentary from prominent figures in the worlds of sports, media and politics.
lead_paragraph: In the rapid-response world of social media, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York caught fire this morning. By defending his assertion that President Obama does not love America — and by arguing that his criticism of Mr. Obama’s upbringing should not be considered racist because the president was raised by “a white mother” — he has attracted an array of commentary from prominent figures in the worlds of sports, media, movies and, of course, politics.
