abstract: Hold your stomach in! Mini-apartments may be one way to solve New York’s housing shortage.
lead_paragraph: For most single New Yorkers, the tyranny of living in a small space, or worse, a shared space, is all too familiar.

headline: Mystery Solved: The Man Behind a G.O.P. Trend-Setting Poll
abstract: A poll commissioned by a former partner at Goldman Sachs has shaped the early race for the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: The source of the extensive, private polling data on the 2016 Republican presidential field was shrouded in secrecy. But its conclusions were widely felt.

headline: Citi’s Mexico Chief to Retire After Rough Year of Scandals
abstract: Manuel Medina-Mora has overseen the profitable but recently scandal-plagued unit since 2001.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of Citigroup’s Mexico operations, Manuel Medina-Mora, is retiring in June, after a tumultuous year at one of the bank’s most profitable units.

headline: Chip Maker to Investigate Claims of Hacking by N.S.A. and British Spy Agencies
abstract: The American and British intelligence agencies were said to have stolen the encryption codes to chips manufactured by Gemalto, the world’s biggest manufacturer of SIM cards.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gemalto, a French-Dutch digital security company, said on Friday that it was investigating a possible hacking by United States and British intelligence agencies that may have given them access to worldwide mobile phone communications.

headline: Obama Asserts G.O.P.’s Actions Fail to Match Its Words
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The president, who was addressing fellow party members at the Democratic National Committee, said the G.O.P. talked about helping the middle class but passed bills to benefit the wealthy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama ridiculed Republicans on Friday, describing them as seeking to mimic the Democratic Party’s message to the middle class even as they pursue policies that enrich the wealthy.

headline: Midtown Condo, Brooklyn ‘Lab’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Buildings (Structures)']
abstract: To help work out any kinks, the developer of a luxury residential tower in Midtown creates a full-scale mock-up of one of its apartments in a Brooklyn warehouse.
lead_paragraph: In an industrial section of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where the street ends at the waterfront, an unassuming door opens to a cold and cavernous warehouse. There, beyond a labyrinth of boxes and dark hallways, lies an unexpected piece of Midtown Manhattan: a full-scale mock-up of a $10 million apartment planned for 53W53, an ultraluxury residential tower being built next to the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Reading Restaurant Wine Lists, for Blockbusters and Values
abstract: Here are some ways good sommeliers find the right wine for a customer out of hundreds or thousands of bottles.
lead_paragraph: THE chief executive who oversees one of the world’s most highly sought Tuscan wines was in New York this month, trying to persuade people to buy one of his less expensive brands, something that would seem counter to his interests.

headline: Muslim Scholar, Looking to ‘Speak the Truth,’ Teaches the Holocaust and Islam
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Mehnaz Afridi, the director of the Holocaust and genocide center at Manhattan College, has drawn praise and criticism from both Jews and Muslims.
lead_paragraph: Early in the summer of 2007, a doctoral student named Mehnaz M. Afridi traveled from her California home to a conference in southern Germany. Her official role was to deliver a paper on anti-Semitism in Egyptian literature, a rather loaded subject for a Muslim scholar. Seventy miles away, she had another appointment, and an even riskier agenda.

headline: How to Fill Out Your Oscar Ballot
abstract: We put together a ballot composed of all the prediction-market favorites. You can tweak it as you like.
lead_paragraph: We at The Upshot have entered our share of friendly Oscar pools over the years. We’ve done so even in years when we have not seen many of the nominated movies. If you find yourself in that position this year — or if you have seen a lot of movies but still aren’t sure how to fill out your ballot — we’re here to help.

headline: Bush or Christie in 2016? Giuliani Says He Hasn’t Decided
abstract: Rudy Giuliani, who has made headlines this week for comments he made about President Obama’s fealty to America, is uncertain who he will support to replace him in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has made headlines this week for comments he made about President Obama’s fealty to America, is uncertain about whom he will support to replace the president in 2016.

headline: 1915: Dardanelles Forts Bombarded
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Allied fleet bombards forts in the Dardanelles in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Admiralty announces that yesterday [Feb. 19] morning a British fleet of battleships and battle cruisers accompanied by flotillas and aided by a strong French squadron, the whole under the command of Vice-Admiral Sackville Hamilton Carden, began an attack upon the forts at the entrance of the Dardanelles. The forts at Cape Helles and Kum Kale were bombarded with deliberate long-range fire. Considerable effect was produced on two of the forts, and two others were frequently hit, but, being open earthworks, it was difficult to estimate the damage. The forts, being outranged, were not able to reply to the fire.

headline: Europe Needs To Stop The Clock
abstract: Haste, waste, and possibly avoidable disaster.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been in correspondence with various people trying to track the current Greece/euro crisis, and everyone seems to have reached the same conclusion I’ve reached — namely, that what’s needed above all right now is some way to stop the clock, call a time-out, whatever. We’re talking about weeks, maybe a month or two — but that pause is desperately needed, because otherwise it will be all too easy to stumble into a preventable disaster.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Frederique Morrel Brings French Whimsy to Bergdorf Goodman
abstract: The artist brings an exclusive new collection to the storied department stores.
lead_paragraph: “My inspiration is life and all its aspects,” says the designer and artist Frédérique Morrel. That may sound like a particularly broad subject matter, but Morrel’s work, which is crafted by covering three-dimensional objects with vintage tapestries, does have an all-encompassing approach to its pastoral aesthetic. And beginning today, her newest pieces will be on view at Bergdorf Goodman’s 5th Avenue flagship store in New York — the result of an exclusive partnership with the department store (“We share the same values of exclusivity, rarity and the love of well done savoir-faire,” she says). The shoppable exhibition (prices range from $900 to $120,000) also marks her U.S. debut.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

abstract: Times critics on this week’s new releases.
lead_paragraph: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Hot Tub Time Machine 2,” “McFarland, USA” and “Wild Tales.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: 1940: Sweden Divided Over Aid to Finland
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: King Gustav of Sweden refused military assistance to Finland in 1940.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — The domestic situation in Sweden tonight [Feb. 20] was tense as the result of King Gustav’s refusal to give military aid to Finland. Despite the King’s effort to keep Sweden at peace, as he has during the thirty-three years of his own reign and as it has been kept during more than a century, the undertone of discontent over official aloofness in the aggression on Finland was distinctly audible.

headline: Chastened Exceptionalism
abstract: Patriotism versus tribalism.
lead_paragraph: Jamelle Bouie has a very good article responding to Rudy Giulani’s attack on Obama’s patriotism, making the point that Obama, while clearly deeply patriotic, does talk about America a bit differently from his predecessors.

headline: Britain and Europe ‘Sleepwalked’ Into the Ukraine Crisis, Report Says
abstract: An analytical failure and a “glaring absence of political oversight” was compounded by a decline in Russia expertise and analysis, the report said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the European Union made a “catastrophic misreading” of Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin and “sleepwalked” into the Ukraine crisis, treating it as a trade issue rather than as a delicate foreign-policy challenge, British lawmakers said Friday in a scathing report.

headline: The Lively Look of Green Chorizo
abstract: Chiles, herbs and vinegar add punch to this specialty from the Toluca region of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Chorizo sausage can be many things, but I did not realize that one of them was green.

headline: The Zen of Plane Crashes
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Books and Literature', 'Meditation']
abstract: Allan Lokos, a meditation teacher, had to put his stress-management skills to the test when the flight he was on went down in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Late in 2012, Allan Lokos, who founded the Community Meditation Center in New York, had to put his meditation and stress-management techniques to the test in a dire situation: The plane on which Mr. Lokos, his wife and 69 other passengers were traveling crashed in Myanmar.

headline: U.S. Agency Sets Fines for Maker of Airbags
abstract: The safety agency said the Japanese manufacturer had failed to respond “fully or truthfully” to demands for documents related to the defect.
lead_paragraph: In an escalating standoff with Takata, federal regulators said on Friday that they would begin to fine the Japanese auto supplier $14,000 a day, saying it had not fully cooperated in an investigation into defective airbags.

headline: Tax Error in Health Act Has Impact on 800,000
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The tax mix-up, affecting taxpayers in 37 states, is the first major problem to surface in an otherwise smooth second enrollment period for the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 800,000 taxpayers who enrolled in insurance policies through HealthCare.gov received erroneous tax information from the government and were urged on Friday to hold off on filing tax returns until the error could be corrected.

headline: Snow Blankets Holy Sites in Jerusalem
abstract: A heavy snowstorm blanketed the city with a rare layer of white, covering landmarks with several inches of snow.
lead_paragraph: A heavy snowstorm blanketed the city with a rare layer of white, covering landmarks with several inches of snow.

headline: Mayor’s Arrest on Sedition Charges Deepens Sense of Crisis in Venezuela
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro accused the mayor, Antonio Ledezma, of abetting what he called an American plot to overthrow him.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The abrupt arrest of the mayor of Caracas on accusations that he had plotted an American-backed overthrow of the government threatened to plunge Venezuela into new political convulsions on Friday, as his supporters rallied in the capital and pockets of protest erupted elsewhere.

headline: New York in a Deep Freeze as Frigid Air Descends on the Nation
abstract: The cold snap is being attributed to a phenomenon called the Siberian Express, with air from the Arctic and Siberian regions causing record lows across the country.
lead_paragraph: From frosty orange groves in Florida to the frozen waters of Niagara Falls, nearly half the nation was plunged into a deep freeze on Friday morning.

headline: How a Friendship Built in Europe Turned Fatal in Queens
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: William Klinger traveled to the United States last month, lured by a dream of a better life than the one he had in Italy. Instead, he wound up dead in a New York park.
lead_paragraph: For William Klinger, Queens was the dream. There, life would be free of the frustrations he had known in Italy, where a stalled academic career had left him working in a highway tollbooth.

headline: A Second Chance to Avoid a Second Tax Penalty Over Obamacare
abstract: Health insurance marketplaces have been reopened so that people won’t be shut out of coverage — and forced to pay a penalty — for a second year.
lead_paragraph: About six million people face a tax penalty this year for failing to sign up for health insurance last year. Now, many of those people will get an extra chance to enroll in coverage for this year and avoid a second penalty.

headline: Eavesdropping on the Seventh Grade ‘Instagram Show’
abstract: As a parent, I hate the app, and I too can’t quit it. When my daughter stops following some kid I know, it’s like she has killed off a character on my soap opera.
lead_paragraph: I may be a little too interested in my seventh grader’s Instagram account. It’s a peephole into the social lives of her classmates. It’s a juicy new reality show: “The Private Lives of Private School Pubescents.” Until it all turned sour, my daughter and I would snuggle up around the iPhone and watch what we called “The Instagram Show,” starring the boys and girls we’ve known since kindergarten.

headline: ‘Khirbet Khizeh,’ by S. Yizhar
abstract: In this novel, an Israeli soldier wrestles with his conscience as Palestinians are driven from their homes.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 70 years ago, an intelligence officer with the newly formed state of Israel moved with a group of soldiers into a Palestinian village whose women, children and old people were rounded up, herded into trucks and sent across the border. The village was demolished to make way for the new Jewish state. The deportation was a small piece of the Palestinian exodus — some of it at gunpoint, some of it not — that accompanied the upheavals of the birth of Israel in 1947 and 1948.

headline: Scouting Teams’ Biggest Holes as N.F.L. Combine Begins
abstract: Before judging players strictly on how fast they run and how high they jump, the teams with the first five picks in the draft might take a look at these options.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s scouting combine moves to on-field drills Friday, and as with every other year, an event where no football is played will heavily influence draft decisions based on various measurements that may not translate to on-field success. The 40-yard dash in particular has a tendency to send some prospects soaring and others reeling. For every Kyle Boller who runs his way into being a first-round pick, there are players like NaVorro Bowman who see their stock tumble when their feet prove a bit slow.

headline: What If We Lost the Sky?
keywords: ['Creativity', 'Emotions', 'Geography', 'Global Warming', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Milky Way Galaxy', 'Photography', 'Research', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Telescopes and Observatories']
abstract: One proposal for reversing climate change could alter the appearance of the sky — and that in turn could affect everything from our physical health to the way we see ourselves.
lead_paragraph: What is the sky worth?

headline: Bombing in Somalia Capital Kills at Least 10 People, and the Shabab Claims Responsibility
abstract: The dead at a hotel in Mogadishu were said to include several government officials and lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — About 10 people were killed Friday and a dozen more wounded, including several government officials and lawmakers, when two explosions ripped through the entrance of a hotel in the Somali capital, officials said. The Shabab, an Islamist rebel group, claimed responsibility.

headline: Superfandom
abstract: A subset of online superfans of the BBC show “Sherlock,” imagine unrequited love between Sherlock Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman).
lead_paragraph: A subset of online superfans of the BBC show “Sherlock,” imagine unrequited love between Sherlock Holmes (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Dr. John Watson (Martin Freeman).

headline: Appraising Solar Energy’s Value
keywords: ['Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Mortgages', 'Solar Energy', 'Sustainable Living', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Research shows buyers will pay more for homes with solar panels — strengthening the case for factoring sustainable features into home appraisals.
lead_paragraph: New research sponsored by the Department of Energy shows that buyers are willing to pay more for homes with rooftop solar panels — a finding that may strengthen the case for factoring the value of sustainable features into home appraisals.

headline: What’s Next for Jon Stewart? Blogging. Or Maybe Not.
abstract: In an interview onstage in New York, Mr. Stewart talked a bit about his future plans.
lead_paragraph: Jon Stewart may not be on our televisions for much longer, but his appearance Thursday night before a packed house at Joe’s Pub on “Employee of the Month”, Catie Lazarus’s long-running talk show, gives hope that he’ll be seen around town a bit more.

headline: Seems Like Old Times for Distillers and Bourbon
abstract: Jimmy Russell, the last of the remaining original master distillers of bourbon, has found cult status among whiskey aficionados.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At 80, Jimmy Russell finds his knees are not quite what they used to be. So he enjoys a comfortable chair where his admirers — millennial mixologists, their arms covered in tattoos; moneyed moms who have jettisoned their cosmopolitans for manhattans; and random professionals toting rare bottles of Wild Turkey — may approach to greet him.

headline: A Thankless Task
abstract: Acknowledgments give up fantastic clues about writers.
lead_paragraph: “A few inquiries remain unanswered. I would still be delighted to hear from: David Cesarani, Liane Dirks (on Polityka), Guido Knopp (on sources), Jörg Müll­ner (on the sound editing of the tapes) and Time Inc.” — Bettina Stangneth, writing in the acknowledgments section of “Eichmann Before Jerusalem.”

headline: A Tour for Introverts: Landmarks and Alone Time
abstract: Sacred Introvert Retreat Tours is offering a trip in England with a balance of group activities (including trips to meditative sites like Stonehenge) and time for travelers to be on their own.
lead_paragraph: For introverts, group travel can be a noisy, rushed, herd-mentality experience of interacting with strangers on a daily basis: a draining, not relaxing, vacation. But a new concept by Sacred Introvert Retreat Tours aims to change that this spring, with a trip to Glastonbury, England, and surrounding areas.

headline: About That Giuliani Uproar: He Wasn’t Even Listed to Speak
abstract: Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wasn’t scheduled to speak at a reception for Gov. Scott Walker in New York City on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Rarely has a political event been so overtaken by someone who wasn’t initially even invited.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘H Is for Hawk’
abstract: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke discusses Heather Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk”; Parul Sehgal has news from the literary world; John Williams talks about Nick Hornby’s “Funny Girl”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke discusses Heather Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk”; Parul Sehgal has news from the literary world; John Williams talks about Nick Hornby’s “Funny Girl”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

lead_paragraph: ‘Founders’ Son’

headline: Chuck Lorre on Charlie Sheen and the Finale of ‘Two and a Half Men’
abstract: The co-creator of the long-running CBS sitcom talks about coming to an end after 12 seasons.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Sheen filed a $100 million lawsuit after getting fired from the CBS sitcom “Two and a Half Men.” Angus T. Jones (the young half-man of the show’s title) made a video for his church that went viral on the Internet in which he said that the show was “filling your head with filth.”

headline: A Pool of One’s Own
abstract: A six-story townhouse on Central Park West, which underwent an elaborate and rigorous renovation, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A six-story Queen Anne townhouse on Central Park West, which underwent an elaborate renovation that included a 60-foot indoor lap pool in the basement, sold for $25,000,000 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘H Is for Hawk’
abstract: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke and John Williams.
lead_paragraph: This week, Vicki Constantine Croke and John Williams.

headline: ‘West of Sunset,’ by Stewart O’Nan
abstract: Stewart O’Nan imagines Fitzgerald in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: F. Scott Fitzgerald was both a perfect and a terrible fit for Hollywood. His youthful fame gave him a shrewd perspective on that shallow, tinselly world. Yet while working there in the last three years of his life, he was a sad case: a debt-ridden genius, alcoholic, selling himself to collaborate on second-rate screenplays. Ever hear of “A Yank at Oxford”? No wonder his great, unfinished novel, “The Love of the Last Tycoon,” deals with the romance, illusion and tawdriness of the movie industry.

headline: ‘The Evil Hours,’ by David J. Morris
abstract: An analysis of PTSD and how the culture responds to it shows effects that extend well beyond the individual sufferer.
lead_paragraph: The field of psychiatric studies exploded during World War II because of an influx of traumatized soldiers. War is a kind of grand opening for studies of the mind. Historically, interest in trauma studies rises sharply during wartime, then wanes in its aftermath. But this time, even as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan recede from public attention, rates of post-traumatic stress disorder have continued to increase. PTSD is currently the fourth-most-common psychiatric disorder in America.

headline: ‘Irritable Hearts,’ by Mac McClelland
abstract: A journalist working in conflict zones becomes overwhelmed by the traumas she reports.
lead_paragraph: The American journalist Mac McClelland has reported from crisis zones like Myanmar and the Democratic Republic of Congo, but in her memoir “Irritable Hearts” she chronicles a crisis she can’t leave behind.

headline: Jeb Bush Turns to Walmart Executive to Help Build Team
abstract: As Jeb Bush recruits a fast-growing team of policy advisers for his presidential campaign in waiting, he is turning to a former chief executive at Wal-Mart, the country’s largest private employer, to help him pull it together.
lead_paragraph: As Jeb Bush recruits a fast-growing team of policy advisers for his presidential campaign in waiting, he is turning to a former chief executive at Walmart, the country’s largest private employer, to help him pull it together.

headline: ‘Fatherland,’ by Nina Bunjevac
abstract: How the actions of the author’s father, a violent Serbian nationalist, shaped her family’s life.
lead_paragraph: In peacetime we enjoy the luxury of imagining our private experiences are separate from public history. We consume the news of wars, regime changes and assassination plots with our morning coffee but consider ourselves, our families and our relationships as self-contained worlds. This luxury was never available to Nina Bunjevac. In her graphic memoir, “Fatherland,” she tells the story of a family torn apart by nationalism and historical trauma.

headline: Experimental Fiction
abstract: New books by Sarah Gerard, Norman Manea, Joe Amato and Mark Doten.
lead_paragraph: BINARY STAR  By Sarah Gerard  Two Dollar Radio, paper, $16.

headline: New Rules Are Set Out to Reduce the Length of M.L.B. Games
abstract: Major League Baseball and the players’ union agreed Friday to new rules designed to produce faster games, including countdown clocks for breaks between innings.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — With spring training camps opening in Florida and Arizona, after a baseball season in which the average major league game lasted a record 3 hours 2 minutes, Major League Baseball and the players’ union took their first formal steps on Friday to quicken the pace of play.

headline: Creature Lit
abstract: A look at memoirs that explore the complicated relationships between humans and animals.
lead_paragraph: Helen Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk,” reviewed on this week’s cover, joins a distinguished list of memoirs that explore the complicated relationships between humans and animals.

headline: ‘Thieves of State,’ by Sarah Chayes
abstract: A former journalist and adviser in Afghanistan says corruption is undermining American foreign policy and breeding insurgency.
lead_paragraph: Across much of the world, populations suffer daily shakedowns by the police. At roadblocks, market stalls and entrances to government buildings, thugs in uniform gather “like spear fishermen hunting trout in a narrows,” as Sarah Chayes writes. But that isn’t the half of it. Globally, the three most important desiderata of our age — security, resilience and poverty reduction — are consistently being hollowed out by structural theft on a much larger scale, operating across corporations, governments, military establishments and civil services.

headline: ‘Street of Thieves,’ by Mathias Énard
abstract: Mathias Énard’s novel follows an anguished young Moroccan coming of age during the Arab uprisings of 2011.
lead_paragraph: Mathias Énard is a French novelist who has gained recognition in Europe for the scale of his ambitions and the hurtling, anarchic energy of his prose. He has a large appetite for disaster, and his books are packed with wars, massacres, terrorism — with human depravity of every kind.

headline: Tom McCarthy’s ‘Satin Island’
abstract: In Tom McCarthy’s novel, a ‘corporate anthropologist’ takes on the habits of homogenized global consumers.
lead_paragraph: After traveling widely throughout the world and studying its various peoples in all their kaleidoscopic glory, Claude Lévi-Strauss, the father of structural ­anthropology, finally arrived at a dispiriting conclusion. “Mankind has opted for monoculture,” he observed ruefully in “Tristes Tropiques,” his classic 1955 ­memoir-cum-case study detailing his years spent among the indigenous tribes of Brazil. “It is in the process of creating a mass civilization, as beetroot is grown in the mass. Henceforth, man’s daily bill of fare will consist only of this one item.”

headline: Jonathan Lethem’s ‘Lucky Alan’
abstract: In the stories in Jonathan Lethem’s third collection, the everyday conceals the absurd.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Lethem’s extraordinary career is a reminder of the not-so-distant past when working novelists published their new creations regularly and with a seemingly free-flowing hand. If one book wasn’t up to snuff, there would be another to redeem it a year or two later. It was all part of the ebb and flow of a lifetime of work.

headline: The Case of Georges Simenon
abstract: In Simenon’s non-Maigret “thrillers,” the central character is lured from the cocoon of himself into a wider world of sexual and philosophical peril.
lead_paragraph: Georges Simenon (1903-89) had, at the very least, two identities. One was the Belgian altar boy who quickly made the transition from failed pastry chef to legendary cub reporter for the Gazette de Liège when he was only 16 and went on to write nearly 200 pulp novels between 1924 and 1931 (he referred to them as his “novels for secretaries”). Then, when he decided to write “good” books, he took the advice of his mentor, Colette — “Get rid of all the literature, and you’ve got it” — and spent the next five decades producing more than 200 serious novels, keeping meticulous accounts of his multitudinous foreign translations and film adaptations, and moving his family from the French countryside to Arizona, New England, Quebec and back to Europe again, even while finding time to enjoy three very French family meals each day, and to walk with his adored children in the local parks.

headline: ‘Lies, First Person,’ by Gail Hareven
abstract: For Gail Hareven’s heroine, an abusive relative’s return to Jerusalem stokes a desire for retribution.
lead_paragraph: Why are so many of our novels so good-mannered these days? Where is Ignatius J. Reilly’s cackle, the self-thwarting abdication of Graham Greene’s comedians, the fear and loathing of Dostoyevsky’s underground man? Where are the lunatics, madmen, misfits and misanthropes, the perfectly good people cracking up and squandering it all to nourish some sweet, unsubtle hatred? With so much enmity in our world, why is there so little in modern American fiction? Is there a liberal bias in books, too?

headline: Wait, Guns Do Kill People?
abstract: A man practicing gun-slinging tricks killed a pregnant woman.
lead_paragraph: Last July, William DeHayes was practicing some innocent gun-slinging tricks in his kitchen in Brooksville, Florida, when he accidentally shot Katherine Hoover, the wife of his old friend, point blank in the temple as she sat eating at the kitchen table. Ms. Hoover was five months pregnant at the time, and doctors tried in vain to save both her and her fetus, a boy she had named Rehlin.

headline: Glass Amid the Limestone
abstract: A 10-room penthouse on the 14th and 15th floors of 1045 Fifth Avenue is poised to enter the market for the first time ever.
lead_paragraph: An anachronism in an Upper Fifth Avenue neighborhood dominated by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and limestone co-ops with prewar pedigrees, 1045 Fifth Avenue, the apartment building the developer Manny E. Duell considered his masterpiece, is a bronze glass column crowned by a duplex penthouse with two levels of panoramic 40-foot vistas across Central Park’s reservoir. From the start, the one-of-a-kind penthouse was reserved and customized for Mr. Duell, who died in 1977 just a decade after moving in, as a present to his wife, Irene, who lived and entertained there until her own death last summer at age 92.

headline: Tina Fey’s ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Heads to Netflix
abstract: The longtime collaborators Tina Fey and Robert Carlock are returning to producing television (albeit the streaming variety) with a new series starring Ellie Kemper.
lead_paragraph: If “30 Rock,” their screwball sitcom about television’s backstage antics, had lasted a bit longer, Tina Fey and Robert Carlock say, they might have pursued a plot about the fatuous executive Jack Donaghy and his further degradation of the traditional broadcast TV model.

headline: Red Cedar: An Urban Pioneer
abstract: The Eastern red cedar, actually a juniper, is a pioneer species, happiest as the first woody plant to root in places like abandoned lots.
lead_paragraph: Show me a dry field and I’ll show you a red cedar. Though it is a common tree in New York City, few ever stop to recognize or appreciate its merits.

headline: What I Love | Carmen de Lavallade
abstract: The dancer, actor and choreographer lives on the Upper West Side surrounded by artwork by her husband, Geoffrey Holder, who died in October.
lead_paragraph: The dancer, actor and choreographer lives on the Upper West Side surrounded by artwork by her husband, Geoffrey Holder, who died in October.

headline: A Spur-of-the-Moment Risotto
abstract: You probably have the ingredients for this winter warmer in your pantry now.
lead_paragraph: When it’s 20 degrees and windy in Manhattan, the closest place to shop for dinner is in your cupboard. Even a minimally stocked pantry can provide a comforting spontaneous feast.

headline: Currency’s Weakness Troubles China’s Policy Makers
abstract: The renminbi’s value reflects money flowing out of the country, as wealthy Chinese move large sums overseas and foreign investors grow skeptical over the economy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Every weekday morning this year, China’s currency has followed the same ominous path.

headline: Oscars 2015: Parties for ‘Boyhood’ and the Beautiful People
abstract: The cast of “Boyhood,” Chris O’Dowd and Gugu Mbatha-Raw were among the celebrities making the rounds of pre-Oscar festivities.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sixty hours till the Oscars are behind us – hurrah! – and if you think the Bagger has been counting this down for weeks now, you’re absolutely right.

headline: Persian Gulf Council Retracts Statement Defending Qatar
abstract: The Gulf Cooperation Council, an organization of Persian Gulf monarchies, had admonished Egypt for accusing Qatar of supporting terrorism.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The organization of Persian Gulf monarchies on Friday withdrew a statement issued the previous day that defended Qatar against Egyptian allegations of supporting terrorism. The turnabout raised questions about possible discord or confusion within the organization, and about what appeared to be signs of reconciliation after a long dispute over Egypt between Qatar and its neighbors.

headline: At Brasserie Favored by Celebrities, Big Mirror Falls, but Lunch Is Served
abstract: A 10-by-8-foot mirror fell off the wall at Balthazar, hitting customers in the breakfast crowd at the SoHo restaurant, though no major injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: As accidents go, it was so very New York.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The protagonist of David Duchovny’s debut novel is a talking cow who sets out for India.
lead_paragraph: Out There: From 1993 to 2002, David Duchovny starred in “The X-Files” as the persistent and slightly paranoid F.B.I. special agent Fox Mulder, investigator of and true believer in paranormal activity. Then, from 2007 to 2014, he took on the even scarier role of Hank Moody, the wild-boy writer in “Californication” — surely the most debauched novelist to appear on television since Angela Lansbury’s Jessica Fletcher in “Murder, She Wrote.” But Lansbury never produced a novel of her own. Duchovny has done just that, and the book — “Holy Cow,” his debut — enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 16. It’s not necessarily the novel you’d expect from the man who played Hank Moody. The protagonist, Elsie Bovary, is a talking cow who sets out for India after she learns that cattle there are viewed as more than hamburger meat; along the way she’s joined by a pig determined to reach Israel (where pork is off the menu) and a turkey bound for Turkey (“That was really just a play on words,” Duchovny told the trade magazine Kirkus Reviews). But beneath the goofy plot, which The Huffington Post described, not wholly favorably, as “a mash-up between ‘Animal Farm’ and ‘Chicken Run,’ ” Duchovny is thinking seriously about environmentalism and animal rights. “It’s an attitude of brotherhood,” he told Kirkus, “not only with other human beings, but with all the animals on the planet. I think it’s because of climate change that everyone is coming around to the idea that this is the finite planet and there’s a lot of unnecessary pain and overconsumption on it and there are things around us that have feelings that we don’t normally ascribe to having feelings. I don’t think rocks have feelings; I draw the line there.”

headline: A Hall of Fame Trainer Seeks to Reclaim His Old Magic
abstract: Nick Zito, a Hall of Fame trainer, will learn Saturday whether he has a player for the Kentucky Derby when Frammento runs in the Fountain of Youth Stakes.
lead_paragraph: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. — When Nick Zito ranked among the most prominent trainers the previous two decades, this time of year was special to him. It brought an unveiling of sorts as his newly turned 3-year-old colts justified his keen eye for talent by distinguishing themselves in prep races ahead of the Kentucky Derby.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE PROBLEM OF SLAVERY IN THE AGE OF EMANCIPATION,  by David Brion Davis. (Vintage, $16.95.) This final volume in an exceptional trilogy on slavery in the Western Hemisphere focuses on 19th-century trans-Atlantic abolitionism and, in particular, the intellectual and theological origins of the antislavery movement in America. Davis explores how the Haitian Revolution respectively terrified and inspired white and black Americans, and examines the significance of the colonization project to move freed slaves back to Africa.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE WHITES,  by Richard Price writing as Harry Brandt. (Holt, $28.) Most readers will never come close to a New York homicide investigation, but they will instinctively know that Price’s insightful crime novel has this world down right.

headline: Former First Lady of Virginia Is Sentenced to Prison for Graft
abstract: Maureen McDonnell, who was convicted last year along with her husband, former Gov. Bob McDonnell, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maureen McDonnell, the wife of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia, who along with her husband was found guilty last year of trading favors in return for loans, vacations and gifts from a wealthy businessman, was sentenced Friday to a year and a day in prison for her role in a bribery case that upended her husband’s political career.

headline: The Government’s Bad Diet Advice
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Cholesterol', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Heart', 'Meat']
abstract: America’s dietary guidelines have long been based on weak science.
lead_paragraph: FOR two generations, Americans ate fewer eggs and other animal products because policy makers told them that fat and cholesterol were bad for their health. Now both dogmas have been debunked in quick succession.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

lead_paragraph: Ever since he was a child, Rodney Foster has coveted all things Bentley.

lead_paragraph: When a woman calls Fidelity about her investments there, her questions are likely to be handled a bit differently from those asked by a man.

headline: Mets Envision Playoffs, and Idea Isn’t So Blurry
abstract: Matt Harvey is back from Tommy John surgery, and Zack Wheeler and Jacob deGrom seem poised to become 15- to 20-game winners.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Sandy Alderson held a news conference Friday morning at the beginning of spring training, his fifth as the Mets’ general manager. Naturally, he was asked about his expectations for the team.

headline: In China’s Modern Economy, a Retro Push Against Women
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Boards of Directors', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: An economic boom that has created opportunities for women has also fostered a resurgence of traditional values, the idea that a woman’s place is in the home.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Fresh out of college, Angela Li was proud of her job as a teller at the state-owned China Everbright Bank — maybe it wasn’t exciting, but it had prospects. After a year and a half she applied for a promotion, along with a male colleague who had joined with her.

headline: Category Close-Up: ‘Citizenfour’ Leads the Race for Best Documentary
abstract: Why the film about Edward Snowden will probably win.
lead_paragraph: If any film other than Laura Poitras’s “Citizenfour,” an unsettling look at pervasive electronic snooping by the United States government, wins the Oscar for best feature documentary, it will constitute a huge upset. With the whistleblower Edward Snowden as its main subject, “Citizenfour” doesn’t just recount recent history, it actually puts a camera in the room as Mr. Snowden makes one explosive revelation after another to Ms. Poitras and other journalists.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 New York Fashion Week
abstract: T’s market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.
lead_paragraph: T’s market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

abstract: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.
lead_paragraph: Bol Bol, Manute Bol’s 15-year-old son, carries high expectations as he begins to navigate high school basketball in suburban Kansas.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Mapping American Diversity, and a Taco Solution
abstract: Web gems this week included maps, designs, histograms and insights into food and drink.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot staff found an eclectic mix of articles and graphics on the web this week.

headline: A Legacy in Paint and Wire
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Art', 'Dancing']
abstract: The dancer, actor and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade lives on the Upper West Side surrounded by artwork by her late husband, Geoffrey Holder.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Holder never lived in the Upper West Side prewar apartment that his wife, the dancer, actor and choreographer Carmen de Lavallade, has occupied since 2011.

headline: A Magician Happy to Reveal the Secrets of His Tricks (on Mondays)
abstract: Eli Bosnick, 27, is a leader of the Magnets, a group of magic enthusiasts in New York who meet for Monday night “jams.”
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, a dozen young magicians gathered around a long table in the Atrium public plaza just off East 54th Street and began fanning decks of cards and making coins disappear.

headline: Waiting for Eurogodot
abstract: Someone is winning, or maybe someone else.
lead_paragraph: So we’ll be hearing from the Eurogroup soon; word is that there will be a deal, which will either be a big defeat or a big win for Tsipras. Huh? Here’s why I think there may be confusion.

headline: Administration to Try to Block Ruling That Postpones Immigration Actions
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The move sends a message to immigration advocates who have been frustrated by the Justice Department’s delay in filing a formal appeal to a judge’s order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday said it would seek an emergency ruling to allow President Obama’s executive actions on immigration to go into effect, underscoring its urgent desire to resolve a legal challenge to the programs and reassure anxious supporters in the immigrant community.

headline: Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka Is Confident His Right Elbow Will Hold Up
abstract: With pitchers and catchers reporting for the opening day of spring training for the Yankees, Tanaka said the torn ligament in his right elbow has healed.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A small, sinewy piece of human anatomy has held precariously in place for several months, and with it perhaps the hopes of the Yankees’ season. The tissue in question is the ulnar collateral ligament in Masahiro Tanaka’s right elbow, the one that tore slightly last July and required more than two months of rest and rehabilitation to repair.

headline: A Friendly Office Debate Over Wages
abstract: Will wages rise at a healthy clip in 2015? Two Upshot writers have different instincts — and one of those is starting to look better than the other.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Salads Don’t Have to Be Green
abstract: In winter, root vegetables, roasted vegetables, grains and year-round vegetable staples like celery are often at the center of my salad plate.
lead_paragraph: I used to insist on making a green salad to go with every meal. It is the way I grew up eating – in fact the first thing I learned to make in the kitchen was a vinaigrette, and my first kitchen tasks were preparing all of the lettuces and vegetables for our mixed green salads. Now my salads are not always green. This is especially true in winter, when root vegetables, roasted vegetables, grains and year-round vegetable staples like celery are often at the center of my salad plate.

headline: Compromise Reached on Yemen Council, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Houthi rebels have agreed to effectively add an upper chamber to Parliament rather than dismiss it, a United Nations mediator said.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Leaders of the Houthi militia that dominates Yemen agreed on a compromise legislative council on Friday, according to a United Nations mediator, but the move fell far short of the goal of forming a new government and choosing a leader.

headline: Designer Paula Gerbase Shares Her Favorite London Haunts
abstract: The 1205 founder and John Lobb artistic director dishes on where to eat, shop and relax in her adopted city.
lead_paragraph: As the mastermind behind the understatedly modern London-based men’s and women’s wear line 1205, Paula Gerbase has, until recently, maintained a profile as discreet as the clothes she creates. Last year, however, the Brazilian-born designer vaulted into the majors when she was named artistic director of John Lobb, the esteemed British footwear house. Though the appointment ruffled a few traditionalist feathers, to Gerbase, the pairing makes perfect sense: The designer, who studied at Central Saint Martins and spent several years training with tailors on Savile Row, retains a reverence for her adopted city’s customs even as she works to reinvent them. “The diversity and wealth of culture present in London is unparalleled and is endlessly inspiring,” she says. “There is also a unique freedom to it that allows you to express yourself creatively without boundaries.”

headline: Building New York’s Future and Its Past
abstract: New books examine the start of Mr. de Blasio’s tenure, case studies in participatory planning, and an early-20th-century fighter for socialist causes.
lead_paragraph: Eric Alterman’s “Equality and One City: Bill de Blasio and the New York Experiment, Year One” (ebookNation) is a de Blasio booster’s handbook to how much the mayor has already accomplished and a sober reminder — no matter how many poor people vote for empathetic local candidates — of just how much Albany and Washington can scuttle his agenda.

headline: A French Education Minister Who Knows Immigrants’ Struggles
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Najat Vallaud-Belkacem, the first woman in her post, is a product of France’s schools whose family history is familiar to many disaffected youths.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — IN late January, shortly after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, Najat Vallaud-Belkacem sat in her office lined with gold leaf in the 18th-century Hôtel de Rothelin-Charolais, reflecting on the identity crisis among young French Muslims.

headline: Raul Rodriguez, Who Showered Rose Parade With Bouquets on Wheels, Dies at 71
abstract: In addition to designing floats, Mr. Rodriguez also illustrated children’s books, created facades for casinos and made installations for stores and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Raul Rodriguez, who designed more than 500 floral floats for the Tournament of Roses Parade and conceived dazzling confections for other private and public celebrations around the world, died on Wednesday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 71.

abstract: Readers ask about parked cars on snowy New York Streets and mail chutes.

abstract: Paul Kazarian, a large investor in Greek bonds, is trying to convince others that the country’s debt is not as burdensome as it might appear.
lead_paragraph: High in a Morgan Stanley office tower, Paul B. Kazarian, one of the largest holders of Greek government bonds, was recently trying to persuade a room full of investors that Greece’s debt load of 318 billion euros was actually a tenth that size.

headline: U.N. Panel Threatens to Name Those It Accuses of War Crimes in Syria
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The Independent International Commission of Inquiry says the release of scores of names would be intended to increase pressure on world powers to act.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A United Nations panel investigating potential war crimes in Syria’s civil war threatened on Friday to release a closely guarded list of names of those it accuses of having raped, tortured and carried out executions during the conflict. The move was part of an effort to increase pressure on world powers to pursue justice for what it calls crimes that “shock the conscience of humanity.”

headline: Advocate for Syrian ‘Moderates’ Changes His Mind
abstract: Robert Ford now believes that efforts to train rebels are doomed to fail.
lead_paragraph: Predictions that so-called “moderates” in Syria could ever prevail over President Bashar al-Assad were always a long shot. Few had military experience. And throughout the civil war, now going into its 5th year, they have been fractured and unable to coalesce under a unified command.

headline: Illustrations by Amy Reeder
abstract: Ms. Reeder, who lives in Greenwich Village, likes to wake up gently and ease into the day.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Reeder, who lives in Greenwich Village, likes to wake up gently and ease into the day.

headline: From ‘Rocket Girl’ to Karaoke Superstar
abstract: Amy Reeder, who created the Image Comics series “Rocket Girl” with Brandon Montclare, spends the day with friends, at the brunch table, podcasting and at karaoke.
lead_paragraph: Amy Reeder, 34, is the artist behind the Image Comics series “Rocket Girl,” which she created with the writer Brandon Montclare. It is about a teenage cop from an alternate, high-tech future (um, 2013) who travels back to 1986 in New York City on a mission to save her world. Ms. Reeder, who lives in Greenwich Village, completed her fifth year in New York City on Friday. A new issue of “Rocket Girl” will be published in May.

headline: Category Close-Up: A Tough Call in the Foreign-Language Race
abstract: “Leviathan” and “Ida” vie in an unusually tight competition for the foreign-language Oscar.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in several years, the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film seems to be a toss-up. The last three winners (Iran’s “A Separation,” Austria’s “Amour” and Italy’s “The Great Beauty”) had victories that seemed pre-ordained, and even before that, it was easy to identify a front-runner. But this year looks like a real horse race between two movies from neighboring countries that are somber in tone but otherwise seem to have little in common.
