headline: Obama Challenges Republicans’ New Plan
abstract: President Obama, speaking at the Democratic National Committee’s winter meeting, said that if Republicans want to rebrand themselves as the party of the middle class, they have to “walk the walk.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking at the Democratic National Committee’s winter meeting, said that if Republicans want to rebrand themselves as the party of the middle class, they have to “walk the walk.”

headline: Popcast: Boots, Beyoncé Producer, Steps Out
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss the 28-year old singer, songwriter and producer.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s self-titled album from late 2013 had an unfamiliar name in many of its credits: Boots. Who is Boots? We were theorizing about it on the Popcast 14 months ago. Jon Pareles said, “I have the feeling he’s holding it together.”

headline: Leandra Medine, Angelo Flaccavento and the Faces of New York Fashion Week, Part Two
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares more impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the city at the fall/winter 2015 shows this week.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the city this week.

headline: Lead Belly, Folk-Music Giant, Has a Smithsonian Moment
abstract: “Lead Belly: The Smithsonian Folkways Collection,” a five-CD set, is scheduled to be released, and “Legend of Lead Belly,” a documentary, will have its television premiere.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, when Bob Dylan was baffling much of his audience by writing and singing gospel songs, he stood on the stage of the Warfield Theater in San Francisco and spoke about the folk singer known as Lead Belly. He explained that Lead Belly had been a prisoner in Texas who was discovered by a musicologist and brought to New York.

headline: Merce Cunningham Revivals, on His Home Ground
abstract: New York Theater Ballet, Juilliard Dance, Stephen Petronio and Compagnie CNDC/Angers are bringing some of Mr. Cunningham’s most notable works back to New York audiences.
lead_paragraph: In July 1999, three months after his 80th birthday, the choreographer Merce Cunningham received this city’s highest honor for a contribution to its intellectual and cultural life, the Handel Medallion. At the presentation, in front of the curtains of what was then the New York State Theater (now the David H. Koch), Mr. Cunningham said how, 60 years before, he had first stepped onto a New York sidewalk and “knew this was home.”

headline: Ernestine Anderson, Colleen Green and Vexx Have New Releases
abstract: Sabisha Friedberg is also among musicians who are releasing new music.
lead_paragraph: Ernestine Anderson

headline: Anticipating Coachella, Bonnaroo, Lollapalooza, Firefly and More
keywords: ['Music', 'Festivals', 'Governors Ball Music Festival', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Sasquatch (Bigfoot)', 'Lollapalooza (Music Festival)', 'Bonnaroo Festival (Manchester, Tenn)']
abstract: Major musical outdoor gatherings encompass highly specialized band lineups and bills offering a rich assortment of choices.
lead_paragraph: Festival season starts to rev up in spring where climate permits, and then it roars along all summer, with far too many choices. At its best, a music festival is more than just a multitude of bands booked for a marathon weekend. It’s inevitably a test of outreach for artists who are getting a chance to perform for casual listeners as well as committed fans. It can also be a site-specific environmental experience, a glimpse of a pop-up community and something like a live playlist from a trustworthy D.J.

headline: Chris Stapleton’s ‘Traveller’ to Be Released This Spring
abstract: The songwriter has often been a backup singer. Now he prepares take the lead position.
lead_paragraph: At the 2013 CMA Awards, Luke Bryan performed “Drink a Beer,” probably the most melancholic number of his brawn-and-booze career. He sat on a stool, surrounded by smoke, in a noncommittal T-shirt and jeans and sang about losing a loved one with a tender, lovely flutter in his voice. He seemed like a man in pain. You wanted to give him a hug.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Village Vanguard Celebrates 80 Years, Not All Jazzy
abstract: Max Gordon, the club’s founder, started with poetry nights, and a music-filled birthday celebration makes a nod to that history.
lead_paragraph: The Village Vanguard, the greatest jazz club in New York and possibly anywhere, opened 80 years ago, in 1935, at 178 Seventh Avenue South. It didn’t book jazz at first. One of the best chapters in “Live at the Village Vanguard,” the 1980 memoir written by Max Gordon, the club’s original proprietor, is about poetry readings.

headline: Christian Gerhaher Sings ‘Winterreise’ Without All the Frills
abstract: Mr. Gerhaher, set to perform at Alice Tully Hall, is considered one of the greatest proponents of the lied tradition since Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau.
lead_paragraph: Schubert’s “Winterreise” (“Winter Journey”), an hourlong song cycle about heartbreak, loneliness and alienation published in 1828, is a masterpiece of austere beauty. In recent years, the work has been subjected to a flurry of stage adaptations, including one by the British director Katie Mitchell that weaves in poems by Beckett, and one, shown at the White Light Festival last November, with animated drawings by the South African artist William Kentridge. Theater and opera companies as far afield as Chicago, Anchorage and Melbourne have put on productions featuring actors, video art, sound design and dancers.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘H Is for Hawk’
abstract: Vicki Constantine Croke discusses Helen Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk,” and John Williams talks about Nick Hornby’s “Funny Girl.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Vicki Constantine Croke reviews Helen Macdonald’s “H Is for Hawk.” Ms. Croke writes:

headline: ‘The Rake’s Progress’ and Anne-Sophie Mutter Are Spring Must-Sees
abstract: Anthony Tommasini looks ahead to the coming season at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: New productions are typically the big news of a Metropolitan Opera season. But this spring I’m especially looking forward to a revival: Jonathan Miller’s production of Stravinsky’s “The Rake’s Progress,” introduced in 1997 and last seen at the house in 2003.

headline: Before Bach at Carnegie Hall: Really ‘Early Music’
abstract: Performers devoted to Purcell, Monteverdi, Lully and Tallis are to demonstrate the old sense of the term.
lead_paragraph: Back in the day, the term “early music” meant pretty much what it said. In the United States, Noah Greenberg and the New York Pro Musica Antiqua started their systematic explorations of medieval and Renaissance repertory in 1952, and the Baroque boom of the ’60s installed a capstone of sorts, the music of Bach.

headline: Marcelo Álvarez Is Twice Unhappy in ‘Cavalleria’ and ‘Pagliacci’
abstract: A new Metropolitan Opera production of this double bill by David McVicar also features Eva-Maria Westbroek and Patricia Racette.
lead_paragraph: Mascagni’s “Cavalleria Rusticana” and Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci” have been yoked together for so long that it is easy to think of them as two halves of the same work. Both are short operas written in response to the literary verismo movement that swept Italy in the final decades of the 19th century with an emphasis on real-life stories featuring ordinary people: unhappy lovers caught in the rigid moral code of a Sicilian village in Mascagni’s work, unhappy lovers in a troupe of traveling comedians caught in the glare of the footlights in Leoncavallo’s. Yet each opera inhabits its own musical and aesthetic universe.

headline: Antonacci, Röschmann and Anonymous 4 in Spring Concerts
abstract: Seasoned singers paying visits to New York soon will be working with new repertory and themes, including Schumann, the French composers and the American Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Spring is said to be about renewal and the birth of fresh things, but three vocal highlights are coming from veteran performers. One, though, is still fairly new to New York: the sometime soprano, sometime mezzo-soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci.

headline: From Mark Morris, Seasonal Rituals Lusty and Solemn
abstract: The company’s April season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music includes the New York debut of “Spring, Spring, Spring” and the world premiere of “Whelm.”
lead_paragraph: Put together, the words “dance” and “spring” may conjure a mental image of barefoot people with flowers in their hair holding hands and skipping in circles. You can find such people in Mark Morris’s 2013 “Spring, Spring, Spring,” which will have its New York debut during his company’s season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (April 22 through 26). What you won’t find is the ritual sacrifice from the original scenario for this work’s score, Stravinsky’s “The Rite of Spring.”

headline: Mastering Basketball in Australia
abstract: The New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.
lead_paragraph: The New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.

headline: A Basketball Outlier With an Inside Track
abstract: An outsider in Australia’s National Basketball League, the New Zealand Breakers overcame a shaky start and a no-frills existence by learning how to win.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The New Zealand Breakers are the most unconventional team in Australia’s National Basketball League. For starters, they are the only team in the league that is not from Australia. It is also worth noting that they practice in a converted power tools warehouse, where they have two full-length courts, a film room, offices for staff and several well-appointed vending machines.

headline: Enough Color to Wake the Dead
abstract: At Fuego 718 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Day of the Dead skeletons and skulls turn up on countless items, including magnets, shadow boxes and Christmas ornaments.
lead_paragraph: At Fuego 718 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Day of the Dead skeletons and skulls turn up on countless items, including magnets, shadow boxes and Christmas ornaments.

headline: Fuego 718 in Williamsburg, a Shop Where Every Day Is the Day of the Dead
abstract: At the store, Day of the Dead skeletons and skulls turn up on countless items, including magnets, shadow boxes and Christmas ornaments.
lead_paragraph: With Day of the Dead art and paper flowers strung everywhere, a section devoted to luchador toys and masks, bags imprinted with Frida Kahlo’s portrait and Latin American keepsakes arranged floor to ceiling, Fuego 718 is more Mexican street market than Williamsburg boutique.

headline: Proenza’s Boy, Fran Lebowitz on Fashion and YSL’s Revenue Doubles
abstract: Plus, the CFDA widens the field, JNCO’s triumphant return and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Hillary Clinton Begins Process of Vetting — Herself
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the subject of intense news media attention and public scrutiny for the last three decades, is preparing for another thorough vetting by her own research team.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, the subject of intense news media attention and public scrutiny for the last three decades, is preparing for another thorough vetting as she plans for a likely presidential campaign. In this case, however, it’s not Republicans trying to thwart her or journalists looking for a juicy scoop, but researchers she herself has hired.

headline: Delphic Demarche
abstract: Something big just happened, or maybe not.
lead_paragraph: OK, we have an agreement re Greece, according to which … what?

headline: Protests in Caracas After Mayor’s Arrest
abstract: Protesters gathered on Friday to demand the release of Mayor Antonio Ledezma, a longtime critic of Venezuela’s government, after the police arrested him at his office on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Protesters gathered on Friday to demand the release of Mayor Antonio Ledezma, a longtime critic of Venezuela’s government, after the police arrested him at his office on Thursday.

headline: Complicating the Picture of Urban Life
abstract: A new exhibit features three Bronx-born photographers whose work explores the idea of community while challenging outdated, lingering notions.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibit features three Bronx-born photographers whose work explores the idea of community while challenging outdated, lingering notions.

headline: Daring Ventures From Four Choreographers
abstract: Experimental dancers find new avenues for expression in spring events.
lead_paragraph: Four experimental choreographers leap out of the pack this spring: Beth Gill, Rebecca Patek, Rebecca Serrell Cyrand Gillian Walsh.

headline: Bahamas Told to Improve Conditions at Center Housing Haitian Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: An international human rights commission said the country must correct a “serious and urgent situation” at a center housing mostly Haitian immigrants in Nassau.
lead_paragraph: An international human rights commission has told the Bahamas that it must take measures to protect people housed at the country’s detention center for immigrants, where a “serious and urgent situation” places migrants’ “lives and physical integrity at risk.”

headline: Ties to Islamic State Cited by Group in Libya Attacks
abstract: At least 38 people were killed in the eastern town of Qubbah, the latest turn of a cycle of retaliatory killings.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Militants pledging allegiance to the Islamic State claimed responsibility for three car bombs that killed at least 38 people in a town in eastern Libya on Friday in the latest escalation in a surge of violence linked to the group.

headline: Medicare Toughens Standards on Nursing Homes
abstract: The previous rating system relied so heavily on unverified information that even homes with a documented history of quality problems were earning top ratings.
lead_paragraph: The star ratings of nearly a third of the nation’s nursing homes were lowered on Friday, as federal officials readjusted quality standards in the face of criticism that the ratings were inaccurate and artificially inflated.

headline: From a Bad First Impression to I Do
abstract: Alicia Menendez and Carlos Odio were married Feb. 15, at the Coral Gables United Church of Christ in Coral Gables, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Menendez and Carlos Odio were married Feb. 15, at the Coral Gables United Church of Christ in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: Jameis Winston, in Job Interview, Tells 32 Bosses They Can Trust Him
abstract: Winston is trying to convince league executives and personnel at the N.F.L. combine that his potential as a professional quarterback outweighs a series of off-field problems.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — On a blustery Friday afternoon, Jameis Winston arrived for his news conference at Lucas Oil Stadium seemingly carrying N.F.L. aspirations on one shoulder and the baggage of Tallahassee, Fla., on the other.

headline: Outdoor Shows on Television for Those With Cabin Fever
abstract: Outside Television, the Outdoor Channel and the Travel Channel all feature programs in warm areas that may cause cabin fever in those of us who are snowbound.
lead_paragraph: Subzero temperatures. Preposterous quantities of snow. Ice storms in places where road crews don’t normally stock salt. For many Americans, the only sane thing to do lately has been to stay inside.

headline: Public-Service Driven, and Into Each Other’s Arms
abstract: Alicia Menendez and Carlos Prío Odio forged a connection after initially spurning each other, forming the next generation of Cuban royalty.
lead_paragraph: Asked about her upbringing in a Union City, N.J., household in which her father, Robert Menendez, was a New Jersey assemblyman and her mother was working in the state’s public schools, Alicia Menendez said: “I grew up driven and nerdy and feeling a sense of responsibility to help people. My mother was a go-getter and guidance counselor, and Dad was an original tiger mom who expected nothing short of excellence.”

headline: Review: Behzod Abduraimov Nurtures and Protects in Full Exposure
abstract: The young Uzbek pianist Behzod Abduraimov has his New York debut recital at Weill Recital Hall.
lead_paragraph: Deep into Chopin’s Ballade No. 4 is a passage of hushed emotion, almost a memory of feeling. When the young Uzbek pianist Behzod Abduraimov reached that moment in his New York debut recital on Wednesday at Weill Recital Hall, he seemed to stretch his entire upper body over the keys, as if suppressing the sound — or, perhaps, protecting it.

headline: Hollywood  Sighting
abstract: The Oscar statuette gets a street artist’s makeover.
lead_paragraph: According to The Hollywood Reporter, the display is courtesy of the street artist Plastic Jesus, who last year created a giant Oscar with a needle in his arm, a commentary on Philip Seymour Hoffman’s death.

headline: An Award to Honor Julius Rudel
abstract: Mannes College the New School for Music will administer the Julius Rudel Award for Conducting Studies to honor the former music director of New York City Opera, who died last year.
lead_paragraph: Before he became the music director of New York City Opera during its heyday and embarked on a conducting career that took him to podiums around the world, the first ensemble that Julius Rudel conducted was the Mannes Orchestra, during his student days there.

headline: Well-Known Faces Honor a Fashion Mentor
abstract: A slew of recognizable faces showed up for Louise Wilson’s memorial service.
lead_paragraph: A slew of recognizable faces showed up for Louise Wilson’s memorial service.

headline: Review: Tovah Feldshuh Embraces Life at 54 Below
abstract: Tovah Feldshuh’s show at 54 Below, a mixture of character comedy and songs, urges us to have fun before it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: Tovah Feldshuh, unlike most performers in their 60s, isn’t afraid to bare her arms. At Thursday’s opening-night performance of her spunky one-woman show, “Aging Is Optional,” at 54 Below, she stepped onto the stage wearing a shiny orange and purple outfit that might be described as an entertainer’s adaptation of a workout suit. Removing the jacket, she displayed her biceps, which are well-toned from her trapeze work in “Pippin.” By any standard, this woman appears almost alarmingly fit. Along the way, she mentioned that she is making plans to climb Mount Kilimanjaro.

headline: Bringing Big Data to the Fight Against Benefits Fraud
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Welfare (US)', 'Medicaid', 'Food Stamps', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: To detect possible abuse of programs or benefits, state and local governments are turning to data-mining techniques long used by financial services companies.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the New York City Human Resources Administration decided to try a new way to root out fraud among people receiving government benefits. Data detectives began running benefit recipients through a computerized pattern-recognition system.

headline: The Reality of Quantum Weirdness
abstract: New experiments confirm that nature is neither here nor there.
lead_paragraph: IN Akira Kurosawa’s film “Rashomon,” a samurai has been murdered, but it’s not clear why or by whom. Various characters involved tell their versions of the events, but their accounts contradict one another. You can’t help wondering: Which story is true?

headline: The Fashion World Remembers Louise Wilson
abstract: A memorial service for Louise Wilson, an influential professor and mentor, drew fond tributes from a wide array of tastemakers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — St. Paul’s Cathedral, rebuilt by Sir Christopher Wren following the reduction of its ancient structure to ashes during the Great Fire of London in 1666, has long been the setting of some of England’s most notable events, from the Jubilee celebration of Queen Victoria, to the wedding of Prince Charles and Diana Spencer, to the funerals of the Duke of Wellington, Winston Churchill and Margaret Thatcher.

headline: The Baroque Anachronisms of Mr. Bronstein
abstract: Pablo Bronstein has created a home that revels in the artist’s favorite things: opulent furnishings, striking juxtapositions and fine examples of historical confusion.
lead_paragraph: Pablo Bronstein has created a home that revels in the artist’s favorite things: opulent furnishings, striking juxtapositions and fine examples of historical confusion.

headline: Making Valentine’s Day a Double-header
abstract: The Vows section of The Times publishes an occasional series of wedding-themed Instagram photos, called Wedding Album. This month’s theme was Valentine’s Day weddings.
lead_paragraph: The Vows section of The Times publishes an occasional series of wedding-themed Instagram photos, called Wedding Album. This month’s theme was Valentine’s Day weddings.

headline: Zinged by Rivals, Indian Prime Minister’s Suit Fetches $693,234
abstract: By auctioning off the outfit he wore while meeting President Obama last month, Prime Minister Narendra Modi cauterized a political problem.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian tycoons jockeyed on Friday to demonstrate their allegiance to Prime Minister Narendra Modi by bidding on a widely discussed item of clothing: the tailored suit that Mr. Modi wore last month to meet President Obama. The suit’s yellow pinstripes, upon closer examination, proved to be tiny lines of script spelling out Mr. Modi’s name.

headline: NEC Bridge Festival’s Last-Day Pair Event
abstract: At the 20th NEC Bridge Festival in Japan, the final day featured the two-session Asuka Cup.
lead_paragraph: At the 20th NEC Bridge Festival in Yokohama City, Japan, from Feb. 10 to Sunday, the final day featured the two-session Asuka Cup. From an entry of 158 pairs, the winners were Dawei Chen and his wife, Masako Sakurai, from Japan.

headline: Did the Torture Report Give the C.I.A. a Bum Rap?
abstract: Blaming one agency was easier than focusing on illegality at the top.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN December, when the Senate Intelligence Committee issued its long-awaited report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program, it seemed to confirm what I and many human-rights advocates had argued for a decade: The C.I.A. had started and run a fundamentally abusive and counterproductive torture program. What’s more, the report found that the C.I.A. had lied repeatedly about the program’s efficacy, and that it had neither disrupted terror plots nor saved lives.

headline: Winter’s Sculptures
abstract: This winter has left much of the U.S. chilled to the bone with record cold, but it has also created its own beauty.
lead_paragraph: This winter has left much of the U.S. chilled to the bone with record cold, but it has also created its own beauty.

headline: Review: Works by Stefano Gervasoni at Miller Theater
abstract: This Italian composer explores the character of sounds, as opposed to pitch or volume.
lead_paragraph: From the serialists to the spectralists, a fascination with timbre has long been a feature of contemporary composition. As the Italian composer Stefano Gervasoni, 52, explained during his worthwhile Composer Portrait at Miller Theater on Thursday, he started dealing explicitly with the character of sounds, as opposed to their pitch or volume, a decade ago.

headline: Review: Ballet Rakatan Delivers Sizzling Cuban Moves
abstract: “A Bailar,” a three-week festival at City Center, celebrates Latin dance.
lead_paragraph: When the Cuban choreographer Nilda Guerra named her company Ballet Rakatan, she created a word to sum up her vision. For her, “Rakatan” refers to rhythm, power and movement. But witnessing the dynamic, ardent members of her company in “Havana Rakatan” brings to mind another word: seduction. Her lively dancers flirt — with one another, with the audience — like there’s no tomorrow.

headline: Giuliani’s Comments Part of a Complicated History on Race
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s road to and through City Hall was punctuated with racial controversy.
lead_paragraph: For those who first dialed into Rudolph W. Giuliani during his “America’s mayor” phase, right after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks — when he wowed the world with his civic leadership, soaring oratory and unifying largess — the former New York mayor’s racially charged comments about President Obama might seem puzzling.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Television']
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Diantha Parker, Amy Chozick and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Friday Night Music: 10,000 Maniacs
abstract: Where on earth is the warmth hid away?
lead_paragraph: Lots of new music I intend to feature soon. But the wonders of online video mean that I also get to watch old live performances, including by bands that I was oblivious about at the time. And here’s the ultimate complain about the weather song, more or less appropriate during the deep freeze we’re in:

headline: Review: In ‘Platform 2015,’ Will Rawls and Kaitlyn Gilliland Perform a ‘Dance Dialogue’
abstract: They opened a series at Danspace Project that explores the overlap of ballet and modern dance.
lead_paragraph: Two people sit opposite each other at a table and talk: Can this be a dance? Tentative answer: Maybe. After all, the speakers are the downtown choreographer Will Rawls and Kaitlyn Gilliland, who danced with the New York City Ballet until 2011. You could feel the question rustling through the audience on Thursday night during this opening event of “Platform 2015: Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets,” a two-month series of performances, workshops and panels organized by Claudia La Rocco and presented by Danspace Projects in St. Mark’s Church.

headline: Imagine Dragons, a Rock ’n’ Roll Survivor by Any Definition
abstract: The band is not striving for a new sound when fans love the old one.
lead_paragraph: Anyone concerned that there is no more opulence left in rock ’n’ roll need only take a look at Imagine Dragons, by some measurements the most popular rock band in the country.

headline: Conferences Consider Restoring Freshman Ineligibility
abstract: Several prominent conferences are exploring the possibility of making athletes ineligible to play men’s basketball and football during their freshman years to discourage the so-called one-and-done phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent conferences are considering rules to make freshmen ineligible in men’s basketball to discourage the so-called one-and-done phenomenon, in which the most talented players, who are prevented by N.B.A. rules from being drafted right out of high school, attend college for only one year.

headline: Times Fashion Director on Oscar Coverage
abstract: The Times’ fashion critic will cover the Oscars from across the Atlantic, in her pajamas.
lead_paragraph: I will watch the Academy Awards from my brother’s basement in London, after flying overnight on Saturday and effectively going straight from the plane to London Fashion Week. I have five shows to make Sunday afternoon, ending with David Koma, a young designer who also moonlights as the creative director of Mugler, around 9 p.m. Which leaves me just enough time to get back to my brother’s house (he moved to London last September, which is very convenient for Fashion Week purposes, if not family) and find E! on his large-screen TV.

headline: Photos of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
keywords: ['Lunar New Year', 'London Fashion Week', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: Olivia Chaney, a Willfully Modern Singer of Folk
abstract: Ms. Chaney, performing at SubCulture, revels in meticulous yet wayward arrangements.
lead_paragraph: In parts of her concert on Thursday night at SubCulture the English singer-songwriter Olivia Chaney sounded like a next-generation bearer of British folk traditionalism. Her voice holds the purity, tension, dignity and sorrow of a heritage full of songs about lost love and cruel fate. She drew material from folk stalwarts like Peter Bellamy, Andy Irvine, Alasdair Roberts and Shirley and Dolly Collins, as well as the Chilean songwriter Violeta Parra. When she introduced a song as “kind of sexy rock ’n’ roll,” it turned out to be from Purcell’s 1692 semiopera “The Fairy Queen.”

headline: Feb. 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, India, China and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, India, China and Ukraine.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Is a Married Man’s Photo on a Hookup App Appropriate?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Online Dating', 'Text Messaging', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Plus: Questions about a lack of courtesy at restaurants, headache-inducing perfume and group texting.

headline: A Festival to Celebrate New Zealand-China Ties
abstract: The Auckland Lantern Festival will highlight Chinese culture in New Zealand, and will include plays on the topic.
lead_paragraph: The Auckland Lantern Festival, now in its 16th year, will raise awareness of Chinese culture in New Zealand from Feb. 26 to March 1 with a series of events designed to welcome the zodiac year of the goat.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic and Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Ensemble Join Forces
abstract: The program included works composed by Osvaldo Golijov, Dmitri Yanov-Yanovsky and others.
lead_paragraph: At a time when symphony orchestras struggle at the box office and surefire audience draws are few, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma continues to work magic. The New York Philharmonic’s three subscription concerts this week, in which the orchestra is joined — all but displaced — by Mr. Ma’s Silk Road Ensemble, were sold out well in advance.

headline: Raiders and Chargers Are Willing to Share Stadium Near Los Angeles
abstract: The N.F.L.’s race to return to the Los Angeles area took a new twist when the two teams said they were willing to build a stadium together if they are unable to get new homes built in their current cities.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s race to return to the Los Angeles area took a new twist Friday when the Oakland Raiders and the San Diego Chargers said they were willing to build a stadium together near the city if they were unable to get new homes in their current cities.

headline: In Iowa, Lindsey Graham Talks Up Threat From Islamic State
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who might plunge into the already crowded pool of Republican presidential hopefuls, made a foray to Iowa this week to test the political strength of his signature issue: the threat from the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who might plunge into the already crowded pool of Republican presidential hopefuls, made a foray to Iowa this week to test the political strength of his signature issue: the threat from the Islamic State, which in his view requires American boots on the ground.

headline: Stocking Up for the Cold
abstract: Gifts for those who enjoy playing out of doors in frigid weather.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for those who enjoy playing out of doors in frigid weather.

headline: Review: In Sheila Heti’s New Play, Canadians Lose Themselves in Paris
abstract: The play, “All Our Happy Days Are Stupid,” features a fanciful set that includes the Eiffel Tower, sidewalk cafes and hotel rooms.
lead_paragraph: How should a person inhabit a perfectly elegant, black-and-white cartoon panel? That’s the issue faced by the cast of “All Our Happy Days Are Stupid,” the play in pursuit of a style by Sheila Heti, best known for the identity-pursuing novel “How Should a Person Be?” It is an issue that’s never resolved.

headline: For Sofia Coppola and Anjelica Huston, Oscar’s a Family Friend
abstract: At lunch with two members of an exclusive club of two: the only third-generation winners in Academy Awards history.
lead_paragraph: No matter who takes home Academy Awards this weekend, Sofia Coppola and Anjelica Huston will remain an exclusive club of two: the only third-generation winners in Oscar history.

headline: Brrrrrrrrrr
abstract: Gifts for those who enjoy playing out of doors in frigid weather.
lead_paragraph: Another Alberta clipper has just swept in from Canada, followed by a blast of air so cold that it brought back predictions by weathermen like Al Roker of another polar vortex. The weather is generating debate as some seek to tie it to global warming, but others declare this effort to be little more than a new left-wing weather conspiracy. But hey, it’s winter, and there are lots of gifts for those who wait for this frigid season to play out of doors.

headline: Two New Cézanne Works Discovered by Barnes Foundation Museum
abstract: Two new unfinished Cézanne works have been discovered, on the reverse side of other Cézannes, by art conservators for the Barnes Foundation Museum in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In 1921, the wily art collector Albert C. Barnes wrote to Paris to his friend and fellow collector Leo Stein, who was in dire need of money and had deputized Barnes to sell some of his holdings in the United States. They included five watercolor landscapes by Paul Cézanne, but Barnes reported that he had failed to find “anybody who seems to think they are sufficiently important to want to own them.”

headline: For Doctors, Less Is More
abstract: Dr. Stephen J. Bergman, the author of a book about medical internship, cites his rule: “The delivery of medical care is to do as much nothing as possible.”

abstract: A hugely popular annual television program featuring folkloric figures is embraced for its light, but sharp mockery of official misdoings.
lead_paragraph: A hugely popular annual television program featuring folkloric figures is embraced for its light, but sharp mockery of official misdoings.

headline: Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao Showdown Is Finally Set
abstract: Mayweather and Pacquiao, widely considered two of the greatest boxers of their generation, have agreed to a bout on May 2 in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The welterweights Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Manny Pacquiao, widely considered two of the greatest boxers of their generation, have agreed to terms for a bout on May 2 at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas.

headline: Cecile Emeke Isn’t Worried About Hollywood
abstract: An email interview with the “Ackee & Saltfish” director.
lead_paragraph: The work of the Jamaican-British filmmaker Cecile Emeke offers a portal into a world rarely seen on American screens: the everyday experiences and culture of black youths in Europe, rendered with a complexity and depth that is exhilarating to watch.

headline: Review: ‘The Groundling,’ a Backstage Farce With Heartbreak
abstract: Marc Palmieri’s half comedy and half tragedy, at Axis Theater, follows a landscaper turned playwright who hires some New York professionals to stage his work in his Long Island garage.
lead_paragraph: Victoria (Kendall Rileigh), a New York actress, was promised a gig “at a regional theater near the Hamptons.” So what is she doing in a garage just off the Long Island Expressway? “This is a nightmare,” she says.

headline: Cuomo Sets Special Election to Fill Grimm’s Seat
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo set balloting for May 5 to pick the successor to former Representative Michael G. Grimm, who pleaded guilty to tax evasion, and for an Assembly vacancy.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Moving to fill offices vacated by a prosecution and a promotion, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced two special elections in New York after being chided by a federal judge for not acting sooner. The elections will be held on May 5, the governor said on Friday.

headline: Shutterbug Parents and Overexposed Lives
abstract: A photograph may distort or even push out our actual memory of an event, studies suggest.
lead_paragraph: In “The Entire History of You,” the third episode of the dystopian British series “Black Mirror,” humans have developed implanted memory “grains” that record everything they see and hear. When users “redo” a memory by playing it back, the recreation even surpasses the original; they can zoom in on details or activate a lip-reading function to decipher unheard speech.

headline: J.B. Smoove: ‘I’m Not on the A-list Yet. And I’m Satisfied Being a B.’
abstract: The comedian and writer prides himself on his “connection to the common man.” (In other words, he notes, he’s not Tom Hanks.)
lead_paragraph: The combustible brew of New York Rangers and Boston Bruins fans at Madison Square Garden was already riled up. Then J. B. Smoove arrived.

headline: When Rewarding Talent Becomes Political
abstract: In “The Most Deserving” in Summit, conflict and comedy develop over who will get an arts grant in a small town in Kansas.
lead_paragraph: A pretty funny comedy about a somewhat angry conflict gets an above-average staging in “The Most Deserving” at Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater in Summit. If the play doesn’t always inspire superlatives, the next level of adjectives — including enjoyable, amusing and capable — is enough reason to see this production.

headline: Hobnobbing Through Fashion Week
abstract: This season parties took the form of intimate cocktails and dinners, at which people complained about the subzero weather.
lead_paragraph: The dance floor at Space Ibiza was open on Wednesday night. A woman with a mohawk mingled by the bar. An androgynous man in a black tank top and platform shoes swiveled his hips, then gave a Beyoncé-like roll of the neck.

headline: Marc Jacobs’s Mind, Live and On Stage
abstract: Mr. Jacobs sent out a relentless parade of ideas that saturated the senses until, whatever you thought in the beginning, you couldn’t help but surrender at the end.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs has somehow become the punctuation mark of New York Fashion Week: the last show by far, scheduled hours after any other equally big name, and at a time many editors have already flown the city for London Fashion Week.

headline: The Making of Celebrity Stylists
abstract: Brooke Wall helped turn hairdressers and wardrobe wranglers into stars.
lead_paragraph: Once a fashion show begins, the front row tends to be as hushed as a pew. But Brooke Wall was maintaining a steady patter of commentary as the latest gowns of Naeem Khan, a designer favored by Jennifer Lopez and Michelle Obama, emerged under the Lincoln Center tents last Tuesday.

headline: How Hypochondriacs Say ‘I Love You’
abstract: They have their own ways of showing their devotion.
lead_paragraph: The evening I convinced my boyfriend that he had leprosy defined a moment in our relationship that I can best describe as glorious. Leprosy represented a gold medal in my lifelong pentathlon of hypochondria, and I had never been remotely close to it before.

headline: Evening Hours | A Fashion Week for All
abstract: More than 200 brands participated in New York Fashion Week, each with its own audience and point of view.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 brands participated in New York Fashion Week, each with its own audience and point of view.

keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Credit and Debt', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The government, an outside lawyer wrote, “is on thin ice and they know it.” But, he said, “who’s going to challenge them on this ground?”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The unusual case playing out in the United States Court of Federal Claims between the former top executive of the American International Group and the federal government took a new and significant turn this week as both sides feverishly prepared their voluminous final written arguments.

headline: What Lies Beneath That Oscars Outfit?
abstract: Celebrities and models are drawn to the smooth silhouette of Commando’s “invisible underwear.”
lead_paragraph: When Hollywood walks the red carpet Sunday night for the Oscars, one label will be worn surreptitiously by many of the A-list stars. But it’s not a secret couture line or, heaven forbid, something from the local mall.

headline: VSCO Cam: Filtered Photos, No Emojis Allowed
abstract: An app has attracted professional and hobbyist photographers as an alternative to Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Last week, as fashion designers staged runway shows in New York City, the street-style photographer Tommy Ton hopped around the city, snapping nattily clad models and other sartorial standouts.

headline: Still Shivering From Deadly Cold, South Awaits More
abstract: The winter weather was responsible for at least 31 deaths across the South, with more snow and ice expected from the West.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The freezing winter weather that has gripped much of the South this week has been responsible for record low temperatures and at least 31 deaths, and officials across the region were bracing Friday for potential snow and ice moving in from the West.

headline: What Would Malcolm X Think?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: My father would urge today’s activists to move from slogans to actions.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — FIFTY years ago today my father, Malcolm X, was assassinated while speaking at the Audubon Ballroom in New York City. I think about him every day, but even more in the last year, with the renewed spirit of civil rights activism after the tragic events in Ferguson, Mo., on Staten Island and in countless other parts of the country. What would he have to say about it?

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York Fashion Week
abstract: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm.
lead_paragraph: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Coats on Display at New York Fashion Week
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm.
lead_paragraph: People at New York Fashion Week had many style ideas and found creative ways to stay warm. This was the last fashion week at Lincoln Center, which provided a spectacular setting for the shows and the attendees.

headline: New Mexico: Board Votes to End Doctor’s Suspension
abstract: Officials cleared the way for an obstetrician-gynecologist to return to work after his license was suspended last year over accusations that he had sex with patients and drank on the job.
lead_paragraph: State medical officials have cleared the way for an obstetrician-gynecologist in Hobbs to return to practice after his medical license was suspended last year over accusations including having sex with patients and drinking on the job. The New Mexico Medical Board voted Thursday to lift the suspension of Christopher S. Driskill, the president-elect of the New Mexico Medical Society and one of the few practicing obstetrician-gynecologists around Hobbs, a city of about 40,000 on the eastern edge of the state. Dr. Driskill, who completed an evaluation at the Sexual Recovery Institute in Los Angeles as part of the settlement, can resume his practice after completing a course on professional and ethical behavior, board officials said. Upon his return, he is required to submit to monitoring, including random drug testing, therapy and having a chaperone with him when he meets patients.

headline: The Gift of Oliver Sacks: A Life in Full
abstract: Sampling the outpouring of responses to Dr. Sacks’s eloquent meditation on living and dying.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Credit Card Balance Transfer Can Reap Savings if Done Cautiously
abstract: Credit card companies are responding to consumers’ debt confidence by offering more attractive balance-transfer offers.
lead_paragraph: Now that consumers are taking on more debt, credit card issuers are responding with more attractive balance-transfer offers, a new analysis finds.

headline: Ukraine Town Eases Back Into Life After Deadly Week of Fighting
abstract: The few residents left in the fiercely contested town, Debaltseve, emerged from basements and other refuges on Friday to a Dickensian scene of destruction and gloom.
lead_paragraph: DEBALTSEVE, Ukraine — While the Ukrainian government accused Russia of sending more tanks and troops into the country despite a cease-fire agreement, the few residents who remained in the fiercely contested town of Debaltseve emerged from basements and other refuges on Friday to a Dickensian scene of destruction and gloom.

headline: New Virus Suspected in Death of Kansas Man
abstract: A new virus appears to have caused the death last spring of a man in Kansas, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday in its journal Emerging Infectious Diseases.
lead_paragraph: A new virus appears to have caused the death last spring of a man in Kansas, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Friday in its journal Emerging Infectious Diseases. The virus, called Bourbon virus after the county where the man lived, is probably spread by ticks; the man was healthy before seeking treatment for fever and fatigue after getting a tick bite. Bourbon virus belongs to a group called thogotoviruses, the C.D.C. said. It is the first time a thogotovirus has been known to make an American ill; there have been seven cases in Africa, Europe and Asia, the report said.

headline: She’s the One, After All
abstract: When Hormis Thaliath saw Devi Nampiaparampil’s profile on a dating site, he knew she was the one. At the time though, she wasn’t even aware she had a profile.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Hormis Thaliath logged into the Indian dating site Shaadi.com for the first time. Dating online had always struck him as awkward, but he learned the process wasn’t half as dubious as it had seemed when his sister first told him she had created an account on his behalf. In fact, it was almost comically easy. After browsing only four profiles, he had found someone interesting enough to stop looking further.

headline: Spider-Man, in Sketch Form, Visits an 8-Year-Old Fan in Harlem
abstract: After a reporter chronicled Jamel Hunter’s birthday party, he received a gift from Stan Lee, one of the famous crime fighter’s creators.
lead_paragraph: The intercom was broken outside the front door at the Washington Houses project in East Harlem on Thursday. No way to buzz a visitor up. Finally, someone leaving held the door open.

headline: In Newly Sophisticated Boko Haram Videos, Hints of Islamic State Ties
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The Nigerian terrorist group has begun using the flag, anthem and production style associated with ISIS.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Until recently, the propaganda videos released by Boko Haram, one of the most feared extremist groups in Africa, were an amateur affair. The videos were grainy, shot on hand-held cameras. They tended to feature the group’s wild-eyed leader screaming or shaking his finger at the viewer, as he delivered an incoherent tirade.

headline: Walmart Gives a Raise
abstract: Though every little bit helps, the move to lift its minimum hourly wage is only a small improvement.
lead_paragraph: Half a million low-wage workers will get a raise in April, when Walmart lifts hourly wages at its stores in the United States to at least $9. The raise, announced this week, appears to be an attempt to stem employee turnover and to respond to pressure for higher wages from politicians, labor groups and employees. Walmart also pledged to raise its wage floor in 2016 to $10 an hour.

headline: Nobel Winner Is Quitting as Head of Revived University in India
abstract: Amartya Sen, the Nobel-winning economist, said he would quit as chancellor of Nalanda University this summer, saying the government wanted him to leave.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Amartya Sen, the Nobel-winning economist and Harvard professor, confirmed on Friday that he would step down as chancellor of Nalanda University this summer, ending his role as head of an ambitious academic project he helped start last year.

headline: At Princeton, Women Make Strides at Clubs That Once Barred Them
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Women and Girls', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Recent elections of female presidents in eating clubs, student government and the newspaper may signal a significant shift on the Ivy League campus.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Princeton University’s 11 eating clubs are where most of its upperclassmen go for dinner every night, as the name implies.

headline: Bold Plans for New York Courts
keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Editorials', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The state’s chief judge has come up with innovative ideas and programs to close the “justice gap.”
lead_paragraph: The “justice gap” in New York State, which leaves many low-income people without the legal help they need to deal with evictions, foreclosures and other serious legal problems, must be narrowed. That is a central message of the state’s chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, who has come up with innovative ideas and programs for making the court system more equitable and accessible.

headline: Mastering Basketball in Australia
abstract: The SkyCity New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.
lead_paragraph: The SkyCity New Zealand Breakers are the only team in the N.B.L. not from Australia, and they have won three of the league’s last four championships.

headline: Obama Proposes Single Overseer for Food Safety
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Food']
abstract: In his budget proposal, the president asks that the number of agencies dealing with food safety be reduced from 15, but many say that a single agency would be unwieldy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To understand America’s fragmented food safety inspection system, consider a slice of frozen pizza. The pepperoni is examined by the Agriculture Department, the cheese and tomato sauce by the Food and Drug Administration, each agency using its own methods for inspecting and testing.

headline: Canada Attack Suspect Is Now Charged in 3 Killings
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation']
abstract: Ian Bush, a human resources manager from suburban Ottawa who was arrested in December in an attack on a 101-year-old veteran, is now accused of murdering three people in 2007
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — His exceptional longevity and vigor had made Ernest Côté something of a celebrity among Canadian military veterans. So in December, when someone posing as a city employee invaded Mr. Côté’s luxury apartment here, tied up the 101-year-old veteran, pulled a plastic bag over his head and left him for dead, the news attracted national attention.

headline: After Ruling, Kurt Busch Is Suspended Indefinitely
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Domestic Violence', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'Daytona 500 (Auto Race)']
abstract: After a Delaware family court judge determined that Busch had choked his former girlfriend during a confrontation last September, Nascar suspended the Sprint Cup driver indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — The Sprint Cup driver Kurt Busch was suspended indefinitely by Nascar on Friday after a Delaware judge determined that Busch had choked his former girlfriend during a confrontation last September.

headline: Celebrating Long Shots and  Outcasts
abstract: At a luncheon in her honor, Rory Kennedy said she fully expected her documentary “Last Days in Vietnam” would not win the Oscar.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Rory Kennedy was fully expecting not to go home with the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday, yet nonetheless she was in high spirits Friday, at a sun-dappled lunch in the courtyard of the famous, and infamous, Chateau Marmont hotel.

headline: Ernest Sternglass, Physicist and Nuclear Critic, Dies at 91
abstract: Dr. Sternglass, whose research in radiation physics laid the foundation for important technological advances, became a prominent critic of nuclear weapons and power.
lead_paragraph: Ernest J. Sternglass, whose research in radiation physics laid the foundation for important technological advances and who became a prominent opponent of nuclear weapons, died on Feb. 12 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: Leaders of Ebola Fight at U.N. Express Worry About Eradication
abstract: The top two health officials managing the Ebola epidemic cast doubt on a pledge by West African leaders to reduce new cases to zero by mid-April.
lead_paragraph: The top two health officials managing the Ebola epidemic cast doubt Friday on a pledge by West African leaders to reduce new cases to zero by mid-April, and expressed concern about a possible rebound of the disease.

headline: Fate and Frailty May Test Miami Heat’s Front-Office Wizardry
abstract: Hours after the Heat signed Goran Dragic, the team learned that Chris Bosh was undergoing tests on his lungs, an unfortunate turn for the successful outfit Pat Riley has built in Miami.
lead_paragraph: According to Dwyane Wade, he and Chris Bosh “got very close over the last year and a half,” suggesting their enhanced bonding began around the beginning of LeBron James’s final season in Miami. Did Wade and Bosh already suspect that James was destined to dissolve the Big 3 partnership and leave them behind?

headline: In Remarks on Obama, Rudy Giuliani to the Core
abstract: Mr. Giuliani, long prone to flamboyant confrontation and rhetorical excess, is less inclined toward self-restraint than ever.
lead_paragraph: He showed up unannounced and was initially not even invited, but he was prepared all the same.

headline: Judge Orders Stop to Detention of Families at Borders
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the Obama administration must stop holding women and children caught trying to enter the country illegally whether or not they had applied for asylum.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington has ordered the Obama administration to stop its practice of detaining most women and children who were caught crossing the border illegally whether or not they had applied for asylum in the United States.

headline: No More Exploding Tank Cars
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Editorials', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Oil Spills']
abstract: The West Virginia event is a terrifying reminder that the industry lacks the ability to safely ship oil from North Dakota’s booming oil fields.
lead_paragraph: By some miracle, considering how close it was to the city of Charleston, the huge fireball from an enormous explosion of oil tank cars in West Virginia this week did not cost lives. But this latest explosion has served as a terrifying reminder that the industry’s ability to safely ship oil from North Dakota’s booming oil fields lags well behind its capacity to get that oil out of the ground.

headline: Lacrosse Star Carries Familiar Mantle in a Transitional Year
abstract: After three successful seasons playing collegiate lacrosse with his brother and cousin, Lyle Thompson will finish his collegiate career at Albany without his familiar teammates.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the office of the Albany lacrosse coach Scott Marr, awards pile up like dishes in the sink. The all-American plaques are scattered across shelves. Assorted trophies fill bookcases and boxes in the corner.

headline: Talking Tough With the Banks
abstract: It is hard to see how the Justice Department’s approach in four currency manipulation cases serves justice.
lead_paragraph: Several big banks are reportedly close to settling charges of price rigging in the multitrillion-dollar market for trading foreign currencies. The settlements being negotiated by the Justice Department are expected to be tougher than past settlements, but that is not saying much.

headline: Focus in Bronx: Stopping Opponents’ Bombers
abstract: The Yankees don’t have as much star power as they once had, or the explosiveness to win about 95 games and score 900 runs.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees did not assign a new player to Derek Jeter’s old locker at Steinbrenner Field. They knocked down the wall instead.

headline: Football’s L.A. Trick Play
abstract: Why the N.F.L.’s savvy capitalists threaten to move to Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Like most big cities in America, San Diego has its share of problems. It has issues with gangs, poverty and income inequality. It needs to do about $2 billion worth of infrastructure repairs. It has suffered through an epic drought.

headline: For Immigrants, Fear Returns After a Federal Judge’s Ruling
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many are anxious now that officials indefinitely postponed an expanded immigration program offering greater protection for young unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — For Tomás Péndola, an immigrant from Argentina, it was a normal week teaching chemistry in a public high school here, filling a whiteboard with dense equations and coaxing his students to decipher them.

headline: Animated Character Who’s Five Apples Tall
abstract: The team of Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson is back.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you had asked me when I started writing Wordplay that a constructor, much less a pair of them, would admit to using former Miss America Bess MYERSON as a seed entry in a themeless puzzle, I would have said you were crazy. But here we are, and it’s not so bad. As my mother used to say, “You live long enough, you eventually see everything.”

headline: Duke Energy Is Charged in Huge Coal Ash Leak
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Coal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Rivers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Federal prosecutors accused the nation’s largest electric utility of violating the federal Clean Water Act in a spill last year in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Federal prosecutors have filed criminal charges against Duke Energy, the nation’s largest electric utility, accusing the company of violating the federal Clean Water Act by illegally dumping millions of gallons of toxic coal ash into the Dan River in North Carolina. They also accused the company of failing to maintain equipment around at least two plants.

headline: Despite Cuomo’s Opposition, de Blasio Requests Housing Proposals for Queens Rail Depot
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio hopes developers will build more than 11,000 units of affordable housing in Sunnyside Yards.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration moved forward on Friday with a plan to reimagine a Queens rail depot as a haven for affordable housing, issuing a request for proposals to study the feasibility of developing the area known as Sunnyside Yards.

headline: Officials Defend Handling of Ferguson Case
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'Law Schools']
abstract: The St. Louis County prosecutor, Robert P. McCulloch, spoke to a law school audience and deflected criticism of his handling of the grand jury process in the shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Last November, as a grand jury was wrapping up its review of the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a police officer in Ferguson, the prosecutor hoped that the decision could be announced on a Sunday morning. At that time, he reasoned, many people would be in church or at home, and the chances of a violent protest might be reduced.

headline: Breaking Ice on the Hudson
abstract: Along the frozen Hudson River, Coast Guard ice cutters clear a channel for barges carrying essential winter supplies such as heating oil and road salt.
lead_paragraph: Along the frozen Hudson River, Coast Guard ice cutters clear a channel for barges carrying essential winter supplies such as heating oil and road salt.

headline: On the Hudson, an Icebreaker Ship Aids Boats
abstract: The Sturgeon Bay, a Coast Guard ship, can break through a field of ice more than a foot thick.
lead_paragraph: The Sturgeon Bay, a Coast Guard ship, can break through a field of ice more than a foot thick.

headline: Under Thick Coating, an Icebreaking Ship Uncovers the Hudson
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ice', 'Icebreakers', 'Rivers', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: The Sturgeon Bay, a 140-foot Coast Guard icebreaker, has been clearing paths through the crystallized river so that boats carrying supplies can reach the communities counting on them.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — As the sun came up on Friday morning, the Sturgeon Bay, a 140-foot Coast Guard icebreaker, creaked and lurched through a frozen river, sending cracks scattering as dark water rose to the surface in pools, spraying beads of water that hit the ice like marbles, solid by the time they landed.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 20, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Bronx Man Sentenced to 50 Years in Killing of Girl, 10, in 2002 Gang Fight
abstract: Edgar Morales has been sentenced to 50 years in prison for fatally shooting Malenny Mendez, a 10-year old girl, and wounding a man outside a church in the Bronx in 2002.
lead_paragraph: It had been more than a decade since Danna Garrido saw her best friend, Malenny Mendez, who was 10 years old, killed by a stray bullet to the head after the two girls attended a christening party at a church in the Bronx.

headline: Heat Roll Past Knicks Amid Concern Over Chris Bosh
abstract: The story on Friday revolved around the All-Star forward Chris Bosh, who did not make the trip to New York after being hospitalized in Miami, with tests being conducted on his lungs.
lead_paragraph: Moments before the national anthem on Friday at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks produced a highlight reel, featuring players whom fans could expect to see over the remaining 29 games of the season. It was not so much an inspirational video as a reminder of who was still on the team.

headline: What to Do if You Got the Wrong Tax Forms
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Tips to manage your taxes if you are one of the thousands who received incorrect tax forms from the federal government.
lead_paragraph: One month into the tax-filing season, the federal government said it sent out incorrect tax forms to about 800,000 taxpayers who bought health insurance through HealthCare.gov.

headline: Ashton Carter, Defense Secretary, in Afghanistan for Security Talks
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Four days after he was sworn in, Mr. Carter arrived on Saturday in Afghanistan to meet with senior American and Afghan officials and make his own assessment of the security situation.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four days after he was sworn in as defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday morning to begin his own assessment of the security situation here since the United States wound down its combat mission last year.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Feb. 22-28, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for Feb. 22-28, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: A Winter Quest With Mythology and a Map
abstract: “Zima!” — an outdoor performance by an East End dance theater company specializes in original site-specific works. In Montauk on Feb. 28, it will start at the gazebo downtown and end at a beach.
lead_paragraph: “We’re doing something magical,” Kate Mueth told the 10 women and three girls on an empty stage at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall in East Hampton a few weeks ago. This was the first rehearsal for “Zima!” — an outdoor performance by the Neo-Political Cowgirls, an East End dance theater company, founded by Ms. Mueth in 2008, that specializes in original site-specific works.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE FAULT IN OUR STARS (2014) Two teenage “cancer kids” — Hazel Grace Lancaster (Shailene Woodley), who expects to die soon from the thyroid cancer that has plagued her since childhood, and Augustus Waters (Ansel Elgort), known as Gus, who lost part of his leg to cancer but has been healthy since — fall in love while trying to lead extraordinary lives in Josh Boone’s adaptation of the young-adult novel by John Green. Willem Dafoe plays Peter Van Houten, the misanthropic author of Hazel’s favorite cancer story, who lectures the couple on the difference between fiction and reality; Sam Trammell and Laura Dern are Hazel’s stricken parents; and Nat Wolff is Gus’s slightly goofy wingman. “Though it is a tragic love story, it is also a perfect and irresistible fantasy,” A. O. Scott wrote of the film in The New York Times. “Hazel and Gus possess an absolute moral authority, an ability to assert the truth of their experience that few can share and many might covet.” He added, “The loudest weeping you hear — including your own — may arise not from grief or admiration, but from envy.”

headline: At the College of New Rochelle, a Show Meant to Provoke Double Takes
abstract: The exhibition “'Not Really’: Fictive Narratives in Contemporary Art” addresses the proliferation of contrivance and manipulation in 21st-century society.
lead_paragraph: Entering the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle, visitors encounter an arrangement of cherry blossoms in a glass vase. At least that’s what it appears to be. Closer observation reveals that the branch holding the flowers is actually a segment of plumbing pipe and that each delicate bud is a tiny pink toilet made of urethane foam.

headline: Tentative Agreement Is Reached in West Coast Ports Dispute
abstract: The deal announced Friday night would end a protracted labor dispute that has taken a toll on farmers, retailers and merchants across the country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Shipowners and dockworkers reached a tentative deal on Friday night to end a protracted labor dispute that had jammed ship traffic at ports along the West Coast and taken a deepening economic toll on farmers, retailers and merchants across the country.

abstract: The site is one of several innovations the league plans for the coming months, representing sweeping changes to the scope of hockey statistics.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L., working with the German software company SAP, unveiled a new statistics website Friday, including a section devoted solely to advanced statistics.

headline: In Service Sector, No Rest for the Working
abstract: As restaurants, retailers and other businesses shrink the intervals between shifts and rely on smaller staffs to shave costs, employees are losing sleep.
lead_paragraph: On the nights when she has just seven hours between shifts at a Taco Bell in Tampa, Fla., Shetara Brown drops off her three young children with her mother. After work, she catches a bus to her apartment, takes a shower to wash off the grease and sleeps three and a half hours before getting back on the bus to return to her job.

headline: Yemen’s Former Leader, Held by Rebels, Leaves Capital
abstract: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi left the capital on Saturday amid conflicting reports about whether he was released voluntarily or had escaped from his Houthi captors.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — To hear the Houthi militants who control this capital describe it, the country’s former president escaped from house arrest on Saturday by dressing as a woman, wearing a long black chador covering all but his eyes.

headline: Somali Deaths Climb to 25 In Hotel Attack
abstract: The Shabab, a rebel group, claimed responsibility for the attack on Friday, which targeted government ministers and lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The death toll in an attack by suicide bombers at a hotel compound in Mogadishu on Friday rose to 25 people, with more than 40 people wounded, Somali officials said Saturday.

headline: Debt’s Two Sides: Riches and Misery
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Personal Finances', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: When it’s used wisely, debt becomes leverage and can increase your investment returns. Used badly, it can land you in the poorhouse.
lead_paragraph: Debt is a double-edged sword. Charles Dickens’s character Wilkins Micawber warned eloquently of debt’s downside: “Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen nineteen and six, result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pound ought and six, result misery.”

headline: Why Giuliani and Other Obama Critics Play the ‘American’ Card
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Rudolph Giuliani’s comments this week weren’t a new tactic. Studies show that many people tend to associate being American with being white.
lead_paragraph: When Rudolph Giuliani said that he does “not believe that the president loves America,” he became the latest in a long line of public figures to question the loyalty or allegiance of the country’s first nonwhite president. While these criticisms are ostensibly directed at Barack Obama’s worldview, as Mr. Giuliani later said, they appear to reflect — or exploit — the tendency to associate being American with being white.

abstract: The grocery chain was ham-handed in its efforts to keep shareholders from voting on a perfectly reasonable proposal at its annual meeting this year.
lead_paragraph: Large, institutional investors in the United States are generally a passive lot. In board elections and other corporate governance matters, they’re hesitant to speak up. All too often they vote their shares in lock step with management.

headline: Battle to Retake Iraqi City Looms as Test of Obama’s ISIS Strategy
abstract: American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle that is becoming a major test of the Obama administration’s strategy to stop the spread of the terrorist group in the Middle East.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Columba Bush wrestled with whether to support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president, her sense of duty was mixed with dread.
lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — For 20 years, Columba Bush anticipated the day she would have to answer one big question: Would she support her husband, Jeb Bush, if he decided to run for president?

headline: Peter Lik’s Recipe for Success: Sell Prints. Print Money.
abstract: Mr. Lik, an Australian photographer, has what many artists crave: buyers willing to spend big. But in the art world, price does not always equal value.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lik is in awe of himself. When he describes his career as a fine-art photographer, he speaks with the satisfaction of a guy who has performed miracles, at the pace of a bystander who just caught a glimpse of Superman. The words tumble forth in self-exalting, run-on sentences, most of them laced with profanity, all of them in the sunny, chummy accent of his native Australia.

lead_paragraph: Tom Ford staged a fashion show in Hollywood on Oscars weekend, and it turns out that, yes, everyone would show up for it.

headline: With Hendrick Motorsports Dominant, Sprint Cup Is Becoming a One-Team Race
abstract: As Nascar heads into Sunday’s season-opening Daytona 500, the question facing the sport is whether Hendrick Motorsports’ dominance has led to a competitive imbalance.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Las Vegas bookmakers have already set the odds for the 2015 Nascar Sprint Cup championship, and the consensus is that Jimmie Johnson is the driver to beat. Kevin Harvick, last year’s champion, and Jeff Gordon are among the other favorites, along with the 2012 winner, Brad Keselowski.

headline: U.S. Open to Slowing Troop Pullout in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The 10,000 American troops are now conducting counterterrorism operations and advising the Afghan military, and most are scheduled to be withdrawn by the end of 2016.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four days into his tenure as defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday morning and opened up the possibility of slowing the withdrawal of the last American troops in the country to help keep the Taliban at bay.

headline: Cavaliers Take Off Behind Soaring Offense
abstract: After a blistering run in the month leading up to the All-Star break, the Cavaliers appear to have hit their stride and are gaining quickly on the rest of the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: As the N.B.A. arrives at the stretch run of its grueling 82-game season, LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers are far from the pole. In fact, if the playoffs started today, they would not even have home-court advantage. But after a blistering run in the month leading up to the All-Star break — at one point they won 12 in a row — the Cavaliers appear to have hit their stride and are gaining quickly on the rest of the Eastern Conference.

headline: Veteran Helps Islanders Win and Laugh
abstract: Johnny Boychuk, a 31-year-old defenseman acquired just before the season opener, brings a booming slap shot, veteran leadership and a sly sense of humor to the first-place Islanders.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Johnny Boychuk brings a booming slap shot, veteran leadership and a vital bonus quality to the first-place Islanders.

abstract: Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made further comments on President Obama in an interview Friday with the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: — Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in an interview Friday with the New York Times.

headline: An Ex-Yankee Starts Over, and May Win a Starting Job
abstract: After a turbulent ride with the Yankees, catcher Francisco Cervelli has earned a second chance with the Pittsburgh Pirates to become a major league starter.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — This is the way it can happen in baseball. An organization signs you at age 16, a decade or more passes, and then you take a phone call from the general manager while working out in the off-season. Just like that, traded to the Pittsburgh Pirates.
