headline: Debating a Change of Faith Under Brutal Captivity
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: After some of James Foley’s fellow Roman Catholics portrayed him as a symbol of faith under brutal conditions, the disclosure that he had converted to Islam in captivity has stirred debate.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The Islamic State’s beheading in August of the journalist James Foley stirred global outrage, fury and despair. But for many of his fellow Roman Catholics, Mr. Foley’s death in Syria transformed him into a symbol of faith under the most brutal of conditions.

headline: Photos: Six Sports and a Cloud of Dust
abstract: For his Powder Sports series, the photographer Steve Boyle shoots athletes in silhouette during action moments exaggerated by colored powder spread on the equipment.
lead_paragraph: Photographing sports is as much about capturing the action as it is about presenting the athlete. These days, I’m off the sidelines for many assignments, instead working in studio environments for editorial and commercial projects. Athlete portraiture is all about showing the athlete’s personality, strengths, weaknesses, motivation, intensity, commitment. But for the Powder Sports series, a personal project, I wanted to step away from all that.

headline: People Aren’t Androids
abstract: To be capital is inhuman.
lead_paragraph: My soon-to-be-colleague Branko Milanovic writes forcefully against the term “human capital”; Elizabeth Bruenig notes an especially unpleasant use of the term by reformicons trying to sell child tax credits to their conservative allies.

headline: Red Carpet Poetry
abstract: Actors and directors recite a standout line from their films during the 2015 movie awards season.
lead_paragraph: Actors and directors recite a standout line from their films during the 2015 movie awards season.

headline: For Tens of Millions, Obamacare Is Working
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.
lead_paragraph: In its second year, Obamacare is proving to be a success. From Feb. 22, 2015.

headline: The Bright Side of Parkinson’s
abstract: To understand this disease is to understand the brain.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — FOUR years ago, I was told I had Parkinson’s disease, a condition that affects about one million Americans. The disease is relentlessly progressive; often starting with a tremor in one limb on one side of the body, it spreads. The patient’s muscles become more rigid, frequently leading to a stooped posture, and movements slow down and get smaller and less fluid. As the disease advances — usually over a number of years — the patient becomes more and more disabled, experiencing symptoms from constipation to sleep disorders to cognitive impairment.

headline: Straight Talk for White Men
keywords: ['Minorities', "Women's Rights", 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Research', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The evidence is overwhelming that unconscious bias remains widespread in ways that systematically offer benefits based on race and gender.
lead_paragraph: SUPERMARKET shoppers are more likely to buy French wine when French music is playing, and to buy German wine when they hear German music. That’s true even though only 14 percent of shoppers say they noticed the music, a study finds.

headline: Uniting Europe’s Financial Markets
abstract: Substantial economic benefits could arise from a capital markets union.
lead_paragraph: The leaders who created the European Union hoped that binding together their economies would increase prosperity and reduce the chance of conflict. But the union is far from complete, especially in the financial sector.

headline: The G.O.P. Policy Test
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Which candidates are true reformers, and which are just giving reform lip service?
lead_paragraph: THE economy is sluggish but improving. President Obama’s approval rating is mediocre but not disastrous. Memories of Mitt Romney’s unsuccessful presidential campaign are relatively fresh — not least because Romney popped up briefly to remind everyone of them. And the Republicans pondering a run for president in 2016 all seem to sense that they need do to things a little, well, differently if they expect to ultimately win.

abstract: With a smaller staff, a deluge of news and David Carr’s death, how will the media desk meet the challenge?
lead_paragraph: AS Dean Baquet sees it, there are some coverage areas at which The Times simply must excel.

headline: Hillary, Jeb and $$$$$$
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: When candidates rake in this much, what do they give away?
lead_paragraph: LAST week began with the comedy extravaganza of the “Saturday Night Live” reunion, but not one of its sketches or jokes was half as funny as four words three days later by Jeb Bush.

headline: Mountaineering’s Greatest Climb Unravels
abstract: Evidence argues against a 1959 ascent of Cerro Torre in Patagonia.
lead_paragraph: ESTES PARK, Colo. — THE greatest climb in the history of alpinism, a story of mythological proportions, occurred on Jan. 31, 1959. Cerro Torre, a 10,262-foot spire of granite, rises from the Southern Patagonia Ice Cap like a sharpened spear, so steep that climbing it had long been deemed impossible.

headline: Don’t Give Up the Gains in Education
keywords: ['No Child Left Behind Act', 'Education (K-12)', 'Editorials', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: It would be a grave mistake for Congress to retreat from the goals of No Child Left Behind.
lead_paragraph: Congress made the right decision a decade ago when it required states to administer yearly tests to public school students — and improve instruction for poor and minority students — in return for federal education aid.

headline: Campus Life and Guns
abstract: Arm college students to prevent rapes? Lawmakers would be wise to resort to common sense and facts, for a change.
lead_paragraph: The gun lobby is flirting with self-parody as it exploits the issue of sexual assaults on college campuses by proposing a solution of — what else? — having students carry guns. Experts who study the complicated issue of predatory behavior and advise colleges point out that rapes often begin in social situations. “It would be nearly impossible to run for a gun,” said John Foubert, the national president of One in Four, a rape-prevention organization.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Brainless Trust
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Can you be your own man if you have to keep insisting you are your own man, while using all your family’s donors and advisers?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I had been keeping an open mind on Jeb Bush.

headline: Beware the Beagle
abstract: The breed, driven by a strong sense of smell, will eat almost anything. Good luck with housetraining.
lead_paragraph: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — A BEAGLE, Miss P, was the surprise winner of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday. What a perfect name for a beagle! Our beagle was Sasha, but we could have called her Miss Pee, because the only solution to our decade-plus struggle to housetrain her was to take away all the rugs.

headline: Establishment Republicans Question Scott Walker’s Handling of Giuliani Comments
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin has been trying to avoid the controversy over Rudolph W. Giuliani and President Obama.
lead_paragraph: While former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York has been criticized for remarks he made at a small dinner event in Manhattan about President Obama and his “love” for America, establishment Republicans also have questioned the reaction of the person being honored at that reception, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, who is a likely Republican presidential contender in 2016.

headline: Deeper Ties to Corporate Cash for Doubtful Climate Researcher
abstract: Newly released documents show the extent of the links between corporate interests and the published work of Wei-Hock Soon, a Smithsonian-affiliated scientist who has tried to debunk the consensus about global warming.
lead_paragraph: For years, politicians wanting to block legislation on climate change have bolstered their arguments by pointing to the work of a handful of scientists who claim that greenhouse gases pose little risk to humanity.

headline: Please Don’t Thank Me for My Service
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Some veterans wince at reflexive gratitude.
lead_paragraph: HUNTER GARTH was in a gunfight for his life — and about to lose.

headline: Eovaldi’s Untapped Potential Has the Yankees Dreaming of Big Things
abstract: Pitcher Nathan Eovaldi had a tough year last season with the Miami Marlins, but his velocity and fire portend a turnaround with the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When pitchers and catchers reported for spring training Friday, there were questions about the frayed right elbow of Masahiro Tanaka, the surgically repaired right knee of C. C. Sabathia and the expected return of Ivan Nova from elbow surgery by June. Then there is the frailty of Michael Pineda, who has been a revelation when he has not been on the disabled list, which is almost constantly.

headline: A Deal That Preserves Greece’s Place in Eurozone, and Fiscal Restraints
abstract: An agreement to extend Greece’s bailout for four months also committed the nation to fiscal targets and other conditions that its new leadership had vowed to scrap.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Just a month ago, after being propelled to power by a wave of anger at Greece’s economic miseries, Alexis Tsipras declared his left-wing Syriza party’s election victory the start of a Europe-wide revolt against austerity. “Europe is going to change,” he said before setting off on a tour of European capitals to rally support for a more relaxed new direction.

headline: An Ex-Coach’s Spirited Ascent of a 140-Character Soapbox
abstract: The former college basketball coach and television analyst Tom Penders has embraced Twitter as a tool for free speech.
lead_paragraph: After winning 648 games as a Division I coach, Tom Penders now retreats to a winter home in Miami during college basketball season.

headline: Disclosures of Battle Plan by Pentagon Startle Many
abstract: A senior official told reporters that Iraqi and Kurdish forces, with help from the United States, were preparing to launch an assault to retake the Iraqi city of Mosul in April or May.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has been eager to show momentum against the Islamic State after a conference last week dramatized the hurdles to countering the terrorist group’s propaganda. But the Pentagon may have gone too far in sharing its military planning.

headline: Not a Splashy Move, but Maybe a Key One for the Thunder
abstract: The three-team trade that landed Oklahoma City Enes Kanter and rid the team of Kendrick Perkins could be among the most significant in terms of the Western Conference playoff race.
lead_paragraph: At the trading deadline, a flurry of activity had some people wondering how Goran Dragic would turn around the fortunes of the Miami Heat and others celebrating Kevin Garnett’s return to Minnesota. Brandon Knight, in the middle of a breakout season for the Milwaukee Bucks, was on the move to the Phoenix Suns, and the Philadelphia 76ers continued their pursuit of players no one has ever heard of.

headline: Party Girl Hair at J.W. Anderson
abstract: For today’s fashion show, the hairstylist Anthony Turner was inspired by dancing queens at the club.
lead_paragraph: Eastern European club girls were the high-energy beauty inspiration backstage for J.W. Anderson’s fall/winter 2015 runway. “It’s like this girl has been up all night dancing, and then goes to the nightclub bathroom to pull her hair back out of her eyes,” explained the hairstylist Anthony Turner of the unfinished feel. After saturating the hair with L’Oreal’s Infinitum mousse, he pulled it back into a chignon, twisting and scrunching it up into a bun. This haven’t-made-it-to-bed hair is aligned with the ’80s, good-taste-bad-taste mood of the show (and its banging techno sound track). Finally, he secured the bun with the kind of cheap, plastic comb that you’d discover in one of London’s discount pound stores. “It’s an antidote to the somber mood of last season,” explained Turner. “It’s not meant to look perfect — she’s having too much fun!”

headline: Flood of Briefs on the Health Care Law’s Subsidies Hits the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Amicus curiae, or friend of the court, briefs are flooding into the Supreme Court ahead of oral arguments March 4 that could determine the fate of the health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Liberal groups are emphasizing states’ rights, a theme calculated to appeal to conservative Supreme Court justices. The insurance industry, once a foe, has come to the aid of President Obama.

headline: Eighties-Inspired, Fire-Engine-Red Boots at J.W. Anderson
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a high-gloss, hard-to-miss pair.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: The Dinner Party as Teachable Moment
abstract: In addition to providing the more typical personal chef service, several businesses in the Westchester area also offer in-home cooking lessons and parties.
lead_paragraph: Chef Matt O’Connor displayed considerable finesse as he puréed broccoli florets and butternut squash at the home of Liza Wang in Irvington on a recent Friday night. But as the evening progressed, he discovered that a dazzling set of kitchen skills does not always guarantee the undivided attention of a roomful of amateur cooks.

headline: The Nose Knows the Way to Barbecue
abstract: The scent of its barbecue telegraphs the presence of Walrus + Carpenter, in Bridgeport.
lead_paragraph: Just approaching the front door at Walrus + Carpenter — an eatery in Bridgeport’s Black Rock neighborhood that is locally famous for its barbecue — gives a good idea of what awaits inside. The rich, greasy aroma of slow-cooked meat drifts from the property’s back-lot smoker; festooning the outer wall of the restaurant building is a painted mural in the shape of a swine. There might as well be a giant overhead neon sign, flashing Abandon Diets, All Ye Who Enter Here.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Hopes His Results Recover With His Knee
abstract: C. C. Sabathia, who lost a career-high 13 games in a poor 2013 and had his velocity fall in 2014 before his season was cut short by knee surgery, acknowledged he had plenty to prove.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia looked as imposing as ever as he walked into the Yankees’ clubhouse Saturday morning. Whether he returns to being so imposing on the mound remains an open question.

headline: Little Bit Country, Lots of Other Stuff
abstract: Thanks to the success of acts like Florida Georgia Line, country is finally moving ever so slightly into the singles era.
lead_paragraph: At the peak of their powers, the country duo Florida Georgia Line took hip-hop attitude, retrofitted with rural twang and concerns, and stomped to the top of Nashville on the backs of the status-quo bros who came just before them. Florida Georgia Line — Brian Kelley and Tyler Hubbard — weren’t any good at the status quo, but it turned out they were positively great at tossing it out.

headline: Art: Scenes Inspired by ‘Don Quixote’
abstract: Cervantes’s comic masterpiece, “Don Quixote,” inspired many artworks, most notably tapestries by Charles Coypel.
lead_paragraph: Cervantes’s comic masterpiece, “Don Quixote,” inspired many artworks, most notably tapestries by Charles Coypel, Louis XV’s artist. Coypel created 28 tapestries woven at the Gobelins Manufactory in Paris. Starting on Wednesday, the Frick Collection will present a complete series of the scenes. The exhibition, “Coypel’s Don Quixote Tapestries: Illustrating a Spanish Novel in Eighteenth-Century France,” will include five of the original paintings they were based on; these have never been seen before in New York and are on loan from the Palais Impérial de Compiègne and the Musée Jacquemart-André, Paris. The museum will also show three Gobelins tapestry panels from the J. Paul Getty Museum and two Flemish tapestries inspired by Coypel from the Frick Collection, which have not been on view in more than 10 years. The Frick’s tapestries — rarely seen, because they take so much room to display — were cleaned in 1999 and restored at the Textile Conservation Lab at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. (Through May 17, frick.org.)

headline: For This Musician, the Time Has Come
abstract: The pianist Leif Ove Andsnes and the Mahler Chamber Orchestra present Beethoven concertos.
lead_paragraph: The excellent Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes waited until his 40s — when he said he felt emotionally ready to perform Beethoven — to begin recording the Beethoven concertos with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. Judging by the result, the wait has paid off. On Monday, Mr. Andsnes and the ensemble offer Beethoven’s second, third and fourth concertos, with Mr. Andsnes conducting from the keyboard. On Wednesday, they perform the first and fifth concertos. (8 p.m. Monday and Wednesday, Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Are You Going to Eat That?
abstract: In the premiere of “Dinner at Tiffani’s,” the running gag is whether the show’s host, Tiffani Thiessen, actually ate the morsels she was shown scarfing down.
lead_paragraph: Shocker: actors consuming food. Or are they? In the premiere of “Dinner at Tiffani’s,” Wednesday night on the Cooking Channel, the running gag is whether the show’s host, Tiffani Thiessen, late of “White Collar,” and her friends Nathan Fillion, Willie Garson and Lindsay Price actually ate the morsels they were shown scarfing down on their hit shows, or even from the catering table off screen. On “Sex and the City,” Mr. Garson reports, cast members had carte blanche at any New York restaurant, with food guaranteed in their trailers in 20 minutes. In “Beverly Hills 90210,” Ms. Price says, no one dared eat. (Bikini bodies, duh.) On the screen in “Castle,” Mr. Fillion prefers to wave his fork around and mime chewing. Whether Ms. Thiessen’s guests applied their sleight of hand to her roasted chicken, brussels sprouts with pancetta and fresh figs drizzled in lavender honey is anyone’s guess. But food isn’t really the point when you’re promising a walk down memory lane with Jason Priestley, Lance Bass, Elizabeth Berkley and Jonathan Silverman.

headline: Watch That Lady and See a Star
abstract: “Vivacious Lady” is a good place to start when contemplating the charms of Ginger Rogers.
lead_paragraph: “Vivacious Lady” (1938) is a good place to start when contemplating the charms of Ginger Rogers, the subject of a MoMA Acteurism series. First there’s that title, a reminder of Rogers’s always welcome presence, whether dancing with Fred Astaire or falling in love, as she does in this movie with Jimmy Stewart, whose own acteurism is also nicely on display. And then there’s the story, which gets at what made Rogers such an invaluable star.

headline: Designed to Miss Their Connection
abstract: The choreographer Pam Tanowitz offers “Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy).”
lead_paragraph: When the choreographer Pam Tanowitz contemplated her commission for Works & Process at the Guggenheim, her first idea was a story ballet. One hitch. She had decided to use music by four composers: David Lang, Ted Hearne, Hannah Lash and Caroline Shaw. And during her research for the piece, “Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy),” she came across J. D. Salinger’s “The Heart of a Broken Story,” a love story about two people who never meet.

headline: Among the Navajos, a Renewed Debate About Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Navajo Indians', 'Native Americans']
abstract: At least one presidential contender favors repealing a 2005 tribal law that prohibits same-sex marriage and cannot be reviewed by the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: TOHATCHI, N.M. — Tradition reigns here on the Navajo reservation, where the words of elders are treated as gospel and many people still live or pray in circular dwellings called hogans.

headline: Navajo Nation’s Gay Marriage Controversy
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Navajo Indians']
abstract: Alray Nelson is an outspoken opponent of the tribal law that bans same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Alray Nelson is an outspoken opponent of the tribal law that bans same-sex marriage.

headline: Polluted Air Cuts Years Off Lives of Millions in India, Study Finds
abstract: Altogether, 660 million Indians could lose 2.1 billion years in life expectancy as a result of air pollution, at enormous cost to the country’s economy, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — More than half of India’s population lives in places with such polluted air that each person loses an average of 3.2 years in life expectancy, according to a recent study by researchers from the University of Chicago, Yale and Harvard.

headline: Icons in the Struggle for Racial Equality
abstract: Pamela Chatterton-Purdy’s gilded panels portraying influential figures like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Rosa Parks can be seen at Les Beaux Arts Gallery, in Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.
lead_paragraph: One day in the summer of 1955, when the artist Pamela Chatterton-Purdy was 15 years old, her father got a call from Jackie Robinson, the Brooklyn Dodgers’ second baseman and the first black man to play Major League Baseball in the modern era. Robinson was planning to buy a home in North Stamford, Conn., near where her family lived, and he wanted to hire her father’s van company for the move.

headline: Herman Rosenblat, 85, Dies; Made Up Holocaust Love Story
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mr. Rosenblat, a survivor of Nazi camps, wrote a tale of a kind girl and an apple that turned out to be false.
lead_paragraph: The first curse on mankind was imposed because of an apple, and for all that happened to Herman Rosenblat in his 85 years — the horrors inflicted in Nazi concentration camps, the gunshot wound he suffered when his Brooklyn television repair shop was robbed, the global fame bestowed by two appearances on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” — it is an apple for which he will be most remembered. That first bite of the fruit was built on a lie.

headline: Fear and Withdrawal
abstract: I cut my dose of lorazepam. The next night I came down with a cold. That was just the start.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

headline: Making a Fresh Start, Keeping the Cozy Feel
abstract: Lawson Pub, having put the damage of hurricanes behind it, remains a welcoming Oceanside staple.
lead_paragraph: There should be no doubt that the setting for the life story of Joseph Bonacore, the owner and chef of Lawson Pub, would be Oceanside. He was born and raised here, and when he was a teenager, he worked in the kitchen of a restaurant on the site of where the Pub is today.

headline: Flip-Flops
abstract: No, I don’t know how Patrick Berry does it. But I can try to explain what he did.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — No, I don’t know how he does it. I wish I did.

headline: In Warwick, N.Y. at Pennings, Finding Ways to Keep Them Down on the Farm
abstract: Pennings Farm Market Pub & Grill in Warwick, N.Y., just over the New Jersey state line in Orange County, has groceries and garden supplies in one corner, craft beers and comfort food at the other.
lead_paragraph: The apples and freshly baked bread had been carefully moved aside. A local cover band played just steps away from shelves of raw honey and refrigerated glass cases, while a large, bearded man watched the door, collecting the $5 cover fee from scores of locals, many bundled in fleece and flannel.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Sophia Ahrens before (left) and after (right) makeup by Sam Bryant and hair by James Pecis.

headline: Old India’s Village of Warriors Becomes Birthplace of Bouncers
abstract: There are few places where historical periods slam into each other quite so forcefully as they do outside New Delhi, where musclemen whose ancestors fought invaders now defend bar patrons.
lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — In a smoky nightclub on the third floor of the Sahara Mall, blowing off steam to the thudding bass line of a Bollywood dance mix, are the inhabitants of the new India — the sales representatives and software developers and call-center cubicle dwellers, all of them dancing giddily, hands flung in the air.

headline: Scenes from Koh Mak and Koh Kut
abstract: Blissfully there is little to do on these islands beyond swimming, sunning and gazing at the coconut groves.
lead_paragraph: Blissfully there is little to do on these islands beyond swimming, sunning and gazing at the coconut groves.

headline: Funding That Climate Researcher Failed to Disclose
abstract: These documents show that Wei-Hock Soon, a part-time researcher at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., received funding from fossil-fuel interests that he subsequently failed to disclose in a string of scientific papers.
lead_paragraph: These documents show that Wei-Hock Soon, a part-time researcher at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., received funding from fossil-fuel interests that he subsequently failed to disclose in a string of scientific papers.

headline: Neighbors Step Up to Help New Yorkers Through Tough Times
abstract: The Neediest Cases Fund supplied donations to help New Yorkers struggling with poverty and loss.
lead_paragraph: The Maley family gets to see a lot more of one another.

headline: Matt Harvey’s Return Brings Rare Buzz to Mets Camp
abstract: The sight of the right-hander Harvey, recovered from Tommy John surgery, put a spring in the step of the team and its fans.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few hundred Mets fans crowded around the chain-link fence Saturday morning, down the right-field line, taking pictures and holding out baseballs to sign. They jockeyed for position just to watch Mets pitchers stand around, just to catch a glimpse of the next step in Matt Harvey’s return tour.

headline: N.F.L. Teams Dissect Differences Between Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston
abstract: The two quarterbacks, who have similar résumés but different approaches, have finished what could be considered a thorough application process at the scouting combine.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — For the last four days, deep within Lucas Oil Stadium, Marcus Mariota and Jameis Winston have had their heights, weights, arm lengths and hand sizes carefully inspected.

headline: Carpetbagger Video: Remembering Their Lines
abstract: Actors and directors recite standout lines from their films during the 2015 movie awards season.
lead_paragraph: Throughout awards season, the Bagger has asked actors and directors on the red carpet to recite standout lines from their films, projects they finished many months before. Watch Ethan Hawke, Alejandro G. Iñárritu, Tilda Swinton and others give it a shot.

headline: In Derby Warm-Up Race, a Favorite Is Disqualified
abstract: Itsaknockout was awarded a victory in the Fountain of Youth Stakes after Upstart, who had finished first, was disqualified for impeding Itsaknockout during the race.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Jack Wolf was not overly disappointed as he watched Itsaknockout, his blossoming 3-year-old colt, seemingly finish second by two and three-quarter lengths to the heavily favored Upstart in the Fountain of Youth Stakes on Saturday at Gulfstream Park.

headline: At Northern Trust Open, Frustration Gives Way to Being in the Hunt
abstract: Sang-Moon Bae, who has twice held the lead at this tournament before being passed up, rallied within three strokes of the leader, Retief Goosen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Thursday, Sang-Moon Bae was so disgusted with his play, he signed for his round of even-par 71 at the Northern Trust Open and left the tournament grounds without bothering to try to find his swing on the range.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Even as Many Eyes Watch, Brutality at Rikers Island Persists
keywords: ['Guards', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: A review of official documents revealed 62 cases in which inmates were seriously injured by correction officers between last August and January, a period of increased attention on conditions at the jail complex.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 2, four correction officers pulled Jose Guadalupe, an inmate classified in medical records as seriously mentally ill, into his solitary-confinement cell at Rikers Island and beat him unconscious.

headline: Retired White Plains Police Officer Said to Kill 2 Daughters and Himself
abstract: Glen Hochman, 52, who had been an officer for the city for 22 years, was found with Alissa and Deanna Hochman at their home on Saturday, according to a report.
lead_paragraph: A retired police officer in White Plains shot and killed two of his children on Saturday before committing suicide, according to a local newspaper.

headline: Turkish Military Enters Syria to Evacuate Soldiers and Move Tomb’s Remains, Reports Say
abstract: The Turkish Army launched an operation targeting the Tomb of Suleyman Shah, which has been besieged by Islamic State militants, an official and Turkish news media reported.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish Army launched an operation into Syria to evacuate soldiers guarding the Tomb of Suleyman Shah, which has been besieged by Islamic State militants, and move the tomb’s remains, an official and Turkish news media reported on Sunday.

headline: Kyle Busch Will Miss Daytona After Crash
abstract: Busch will miss Sunday’s race after breaking his right leg and left foot in a crash at Daytona International Speedway, an accident that quickly led track officials to vow to install safety barriers.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Kyle Busch will miss Nascar’s showcase Daytona 500 on Sunday after breaking his right leg and left foot Saturday in a crash at Daytona International Speedway, an accident that quickly led track officials to vow to install safety barriers.

headline: Inmates to Be Transferred After Riot at Texas Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Immigration Detention', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Inmates at the Willacy County Correctional Center, about 200 miles south of San Antonio, took control of the prison using pipes as weapons.
lead_paragraph: A federal prison in South Texas over the next week will transfer up to 2,800 inmates to other institutions in the area, after a riot on Friday rendered the facility uninhabitable, an official said.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 22, 2015.

headline: Snow, Winds and Freezing Rain Make for Treacherous Weekend in New York City
abstract: The National Weather Service said Central Park reported 3 inches of snow on Saturday evening, with more forecast through late Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A blistering combination of winter conditions — high winds, freezing rain, moderate snowfall — has struck the region as part of a cold snap, but on Friday it was predicted that temperatures will lift enough for the region to experience a warm Sunday afternoon.

headline: Talia Thurm, Michael Abramson

lead_paragraph: Talia Joyce Thurm, a daughter of Deena R. Thurm and Dr. Jonathan S. Thurm of Englewood, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Michael David Abramson, a son of Helene S. Abramson and Ellis J. Abramson of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the Grove, an event space in Cedar Grove, N.J.

lead_paragraph: Marielena Santana and Riccardo Antonio Marroquín were married Saturday at Villa Woodbine, an event space in Miami. The Rev. Joaquin Perez, a priest in the Old Catholic Church, officiated.

Evenson, a cousin of Ms. Brooks Adickman who was appointed as a temporary commissioner of civil marriages by San Luis Obispo County.

lead_paragraph: Gretchen Diana Adelson and Michael Ian Kaplan were married Saturday evening at LaPlaya Beach and Golf Resort in Naples, Fla. Rabbi Adam Miller officiated.

lead_paragraph: Taiyyibah Iftikhar Malik and Christopher Michael Schmitt were married Saturday evening at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology in Philadelphia. Thomas L. Ambro, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Alyssa Diane Murstein and Benjamin Saul Cannon were married Saturday by Rabbi David Baum at the Broken Sound Club in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: Leaving Home, Embracing Extremism
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Photography', 'Propaganda', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Islam Yaken’s friends and family struggle to comprehend how he gave up his middle-class life to become a jihadi in Syria.
lead_paragraph: With no notice, Islam Yaken slipped away from his middle-class home in Egypt to join the Islamic State in Syria. His family and close friends have not seen him since, except in propaganda and training videos.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 87TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, that awards-show wonder, makes his debut as host of the ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are suggesting that Eddie Redmayne will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of the physicist Stephen Hawking in “The Theory of Everything” and that J. K. Simmons will win for best supporting actor as a music teacher from hell in “Whiplash.” In the best actress category, Julianne Moore is the front-runner for her portrait of a professor with early-onset Alzheimer’s in “Still Alice,” while Patricia Arquette, as a mother filmed across 12 years in “Boyhood,” is the favorite for supporting actress. And Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s “Birdman” may squeak by in the best picture category, which is filled out by Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood,” a close contender; Clint Eastwood’s “American Sniper”; Wes Anderson’s “The Grand Budapest Hotel”; Morten Tyldum’s “The Imitation Game”; Ava DuVernay’s “Selma”; James Marsh’s “The Theory of Everything” and Damien Chazelle’s “Whiplash.” Mr. Iñárritu, Mr. Linklater, Mr. Anderson, Mr. Tyldum and Bennett Miller, for “Foxcatcher,” are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 6 on Pop and WGN America; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E!

abstract: The couple was married at the Sanctuary Camelback Mountain Resort and Spa in Paradise Valley, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Allyson Novak and Andrew Charles Spray are to be married Sunday at the Sanctuary Camelback Mountain Resort and Spa in Paradise Valley, Ariz. Robert J. Novak, an uncle of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.

headline: Lenovo and Superfish Penetrate the Heart of a Computer’s Security
abstract: Security companies are doing a better job at surrounding computers with defenses. Now the fight has moved far inside the machine, where unwanted or malicious software is nearly impossible to detect.
lead_paragraph: The same week researchers reported that the National Security Agency had been embedding surveillance tools in the guts of thousands of machines in Iran, Russia and other countries, it was revealed that the world’s largest personal computer company had been doing something similar to its customers.

headline: Sri Lanka Premier Starts With Fixing Civil War Ills
keywords: ['Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'Political Prisoners', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said he has only just begun to grapple with the profound issues of releasing political prisoners and handing back land seized mostly from minority Tamils.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Paintings at Temple Trees, this country’s White House, are still leaning against walls waiting to be hung, and the gated grounds are no longer teeming with guards and stewards who served the home’s previous occupant like supplicants at a royal court.

headline: China Protests India Leader’s Visit to Disputed Border Area
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi went to open a railroad in Arunachal Pradesh, a state in eastern India that borders Tibet to the north. A large part of it is claimed by China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China summoned India’s ambassador in Beijing to protest Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to a border area claimed by both countries, a reminder that the world’s two most populous countries have yet to resolve vast territorial disputes that have simmered for more than half a century.

headline: Turkish Military Evacuates Soldiers Guarding Tomb in Syria
abstract: The Turkish Army rescued its guards and removed remains at the Tomb of Suleyman Shah, which has been besieged by Islamic State militants.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish Army sent armored troops deep into Syria late Saturday to recover the remains of a major historical figure and to evacuate the guards at his besieged tomb, the prime minister announced in a televised news conference on Sunday.

keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Three protesters were detained at the gate of a United States Marine base on Okinawa on Sunday during the largest demonstration yet against the start of construction of a new airfield there, protesters and local news media said.

headline: He Was Ready to Be a Stepdad. Was I Ready to Let Him?
abstract: The first time I let my now-husband “solo” with my 10-year-old daughter, he forgot to feed her, and I “forgot” not to yell at him in front of her. I had to learn to let them become a family.
lead_paragraph: Chris, my fiancé, headed down the steps as my 10-year-old daughter skipped behind him. “Don’t put her in the front seat!” I said. “Make sure she’s buckled in!”

headline: Greece Did OK
abstract: Relaxed conditions now, breathing room for later.
lead_paragraph: Now that the dust has settled a bit, we can look calmly at the deal — if it really is a deal that survives through tomorrow, which some people doubt. And it’s increasingly clear that Greece came out in significantly better shape, at least for now.

headline: ‘Birdman’ and ‘Boyhood’ Split Top Independent Spirit Awards
abstract: But Jared Leto’s jacket steals the show.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The weird thing about the Film Independent Spirit Awards is that they’re genuinely kind of fun. Unlike other awards shows, which can skew stuffy, tedious, forced or odd, there’s a sort of devil-may-care frisson in the air. This is partly because of its locale – a giant tent on the beach here — partly because of the fact that Oscar voting has closed and the awards are a mere 24 hours away (hallelujah!), and partly because of the still scrappy and, yes, independent spirit of it all.

headline: Rip Van Skillsgap

lead_paragraph: Clark Terry, one of the most popular and influential jazz trumpeters of his generation and an enthusiastic advocate of jazz education, died on Saturday in Pine Bluff, Ark. He was 94.

headline: 1915: Germans Own to Big Reverse, Bombard Rheims
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germans bombard Rheims in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Germans admit serious setbacks and heavy losses within the last few days. They admit it according to their now well-established code — by useless bombardment of civilians, or the destruction of a monument of architecture. Sometimes it has been a church destroyed, sometimes it has been women and children slaughtered. Sometimes is has been Arras, sometimes is has been Ypres. When everything else fails there is always Pont-à-Mousson. In admitting their recent reverse, the Germans have turned again to Rheims, where there is both a magnificent church to be shelled and plenty of civilians to be killed. This indicates that they regard their latest defeats as unusually serious, and wish to make their admission of them equally so.

headline: President Obama Has, in Fact, Expressed Love for His Country
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, has challenged the media to find examples of President Obama expressing affection for the United States. Has the president done so? A review of his public remarks provides multiple examples.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the Giuliani-led critique of the president’s patriotism is the suggestion that Barack Obama has never expressed love for the United States.

keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']

lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It was a memorable political ad: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spoke directly into the camera in a 30-second spot last fall and called abortion an “agonizing” decision. He described himself as pro-life but, borrowing the language of the abortion rights movement, pointed to legislation he signed that leaves “the final decision to a woman and her doctor.”

abstract: President Obama’s veto of the pipeline bill this week, the third and most significant one of his six years in office, would most likely be followed by others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wielding the weapon of his pen, President Obama this week is expected to formally reject a Republican attempt to force construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline. But in stopping the transit of petroleum from the forests of Alberta to the Gulf Coast, Mr. Obama will be opening the veto era of his presidency.

headline: 1940: Washington’s Birthday Celebrated in Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The American Club gathers to celebrate George Washington’s birthday in Paris in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Americans in Paris, celebrating Washington’s Birthday in the capital of a country at war, joined in a spontaneous enthusiastic ovation for heroic Finland at the banquet given by the American Club of Paris at the Grand Hotel yesterday evening [Feb. 22]. Rising from their seats, 300 members and guests of the club acclaimed Harri Holma, Finnish Minister, who was one of many foreign diplomats present. Sir Ronald Campbell, British Ambassador, was also given an ovation. It was the largest gathering the American Club has seen for a long time, and oldtimers recalled that during the World War the club rarely mustered 100 members at its function. Representing the French government, Camille Chautemps, Vice-President of the Council, paid tribute to the victims of Nazi aggression and recalled that George Washington was not only a victorious general, but a liberator and hero of democracy, defending individual liberty.

lead_paragraph: Here’s a phrase you probably never expected to read: Highbrow PBS and trashy Investigation Discovery have complementary programs Monday night about race and intolerance. Neither is very satisfying on its own, but put them together and they acquire some substance.

headline: Review: ‘Harlequinade’ Returns to New York City Ballet
abstract: A quaint ballet like this one, presented at the David H. Koch Theater, can be hard to nail perfectly.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this month, when New York City Ballet danced the premiere of George Balanchine’s “Harlequinade,” it was already old-fashioned. Set to the same frothy score by Riccardo Drigo that Marius Petipa had used 65 years earlier for “Les Millions d’Arlequin,” this two-act ballet is one of Balanchine’s affectionate recreations of Petipa style and Franco-Russian tradition. It’s the kind of show that is always described as a confection, and when it returned to the David H. Koch Theater on Wednesday, after an absence of a decade, its antique charm was there, preserved. Yet the taste was not as fresh as possible.

headline: Review: American Symphony Orchestra Revives ‘Mona Lisa,’ Inspired by Leonardo’s Muse
abstract: Leon Botstein led the ensemble and the Bard Festival Chorale at Carnegie Hall in a performance of Max Von Schillings’s “Mona Lisa.”
lead_paragraph: Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa has inspired books, imitations, satirical spinoffs, songs and staged works — among them Max von Schillings’s opera “Mona Lisa.” It received over 1,200 performances in the decade after its 1915 composition, including a production at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Smith and Shumpert Revel in Return to Garden as Cavs

headline: Mary Katrantzou’s Doll-Inspired Eye Makeup
abstract: In a fall 2015 collection where texture and vibrancy loomed large, a low-key but look-at-me beauty moment fit the bill.
lead_paragraph: “A doll lash, but not a dolly look” is how the makeup artist Val Garland described the bold approach to beauty backstage at Mary Katrantzou’s fall/winter 2015 show. Borrowing tricks from the ’90s club kids, who would wear tiny dots beneath their eyes for dance floor drama, Garland followed the direct line of sight, drawing an oblong below the pupil with MAC’s Midnight Well eye shadow in black onyx. False lashes were then chopped into small, square sections and ironed (yes, actually ironed) flat before being layered onto the lower lashline just above the oblong for extra emphasis. The look was finished simply with a careful curl of the top lashes (for prettiness) and a generous dab of lip balm. In a collection where texture and vibrancy loomed large, this low-key but look-at-me beauty fit the bill.

abstract: A critical study of a choreographer who waged a surreptitious battle against the Soviet bureaucracy.

headline: Joey Logano Wins Daytona 500

Those developments had cast a pall over the race, the organization’s showcase event.

headline: A Deal for the Player Who Likes a Challenge
abstract: Geza Ottlik and Hugh Kelsey wrote “Adventures in Card Play” in 1979. It is generally considered to be the toughest bridge book ever published.
lead_paragraph: Geza Ottlik and Hugh Kelsey wrote “Adventures in Card Play” in 1979. It is generally considered to be the toughest bridge book ever published. The deals were provided by Ottlik, from Hungary, and the text written by Kelsey, from Scotland. (Kelsey told me that Ottlik had found one analytical error in the book, but he refused to tell me in which deal. If you find it, please write in.)

headline: Review: ‘Belladonna,’ a Poisonous Duet at the 92nd Street Y
abstract: A work by Adam Barruch inspired by an eerie tale by Nathaniel Hawthorne.
lead_paragraph: It’s all too easy for a dance based on a story to lose its way. In “Belladonna,” the choreographer Adam Barruch finds inspiration in Nathaniel Hawthorne’s spooky tale “Rappaccini’s Daughter,” in which a scientist cultivates a garden of poisonous plants for medicinal purposes. His beautiful daughter, Beatrice, takes care of them; Giovanni, a young student, rents a room overlooking the garden and becomes obsessed with her, only to learn that the reason she can take care of the plants is because she is poisonous herself.

headline: Review: Trinity Wall Street and Julian Wachner Play Carnegie Hall
abstract: Hundreds of musicians, led by Mr. Wachner, interpreted works by Ives and Ginastera at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Julian Wachner, the impressive director of music and the arts at Trinity Wall Street, didn’t seem the slightest bit nervous in his first performance as a conductor at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. He affably welcomed the audience, thanking everyone for braving not just the winter weather but the program he had planned. The concert paired Ives’s Fourth Symphony, generally considered one of the most complex and challenging 20th-century symphonic works, and a rare performance of an intense 60-minute oratorio, “Turbae ad Passionem Gregorianam,” by the Argentine-born composer Alberto Ginastera, first performed in 1975.

headline: ‘The Night Shift’ Dispenses a Familiar Prescription
abstract: The NBC show has attained a measure of success by sticking to the template of a highly successful medical dramedy, “Grey’s Anatomy.”
lead_paragraph: Pity the ensemble hospital show trying to survive in the considerable shadow of “Grey’s Anatomy.” Since that ABC series — the first Shonda Rhimes hit — began in 2005, one doctor dramedy after another has had its plug pulled after a season or two: “3 Lbs.,” “Heartland,” “Three Rivers,” “Trauma,” “Mercy,” “Emily Owens, M.D.”

Need a book to read on the plane? For those with hard currency, a new copy of “50 Shades of Grey” goes for $2.50. Forget your toothpaste? A tube of Colgate costs 7 cents.

headline: Rothschild Family Treasures Find a Resting Place in Boston
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The family is donating a trove to the Museum of Fine Arts, which is devoting a show to how the items were collected, looted and recovered.
lead_paragraph: As the granddaughter of the Baron and Baroness Alphonse and Clarice de Rothschild of the banking and collecting dynasty, Bettina Burr recalls being mesmerized by one of the couple’s storied paintings. The work, by the English portraitist George Romney, showed his muse, a coquettish young Emma Hart, the mistress of Lord Nelson, dressed in frills and wearing a jaunty hat. “I remember stopping and just staring,” Ms. Burr said. “She has so much allure, you couldn’t help but ogle her.”

headline: As Office Space Shrinks, So Does Privacy for Workers

headline: Liberia Lifts Its Curfew, but Border Stays Sealed
abstract: Sierra Leonean authorities said Sunday that they had received no instructions to open their side of the border with Liberia, sealed in late July to try to limit the spread of the Ebola virus.
lead_paragraph: BO WATERSIDE, Liberia — Fatu Momolu, a middle-age vendor of cold drinks, danced gleefully on Sunday back and forth across the border, an imaginary line that for the last seven months had turned all too real, severing Liberia from Sierra Leone and Ms. Momolu from much of her family.

headline: Panel Disqualifies Egyptian Tycoon From Parliamentary Bid
abstract: The steel tycoon who came to epitomize cronyism and corruption in Egypt during the era of President Hosni Mubarak was disqualified after he had failed to submit financial statements from one of his wives, according to a judicial official.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A steel tycoon who came to epitomize the cronyism and corruption in Egypt during the era of President Hosni Mubarak was disqualified on Sunday from running for Parliament, according to state news media reports.

headline: Despite Wreck, Gordon Is Smiling After His Final 500
abstract: Gordon led for 87 laps over all on Sunday in his last Daytona 500, but was scored in 33rd place after a crash on the backstretch.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Few drivers in motorsports have ever had the view that Jeff Gordon had Sunday at the start of the Daytona 500. Gordon was on the pole for his final 500, with nothing but track in front of him and a racecar capable of putting him in victory lane one last time in the final year of his career.

headline: Fighting Is Long Over, but Western Sahara Still Lacks Peace
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Relations', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: There has been no fighting in Western Sahara for 24 years, since a United Nations-monitored cease-fire between Morocco and the Polisario Front, but residents say they want independence.
lead_paragraph: TIFARITI, Western Sahara — Ghalla Sid Ahmed and her mother eke out a living in this isolated desert settlement, subsisting on five goats and a war pension. For 40 years they have lived in exile, barred from their land by a heavily patrolled sand berm that runs like a scar for 1,600 miles through this remote corner of the Sahara.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Oh, baby, does James Hahn have a flair for the dramatic. In his last start before the impending birth of his first child, and with the minutes ticking down until the start of the Academy Awards a few miles down the rain-soaked freeway, Hahn made a 24-foot birdie putt on the third playoff hole Sunday to wrest the Northern Trust Open title from Dustin Johnson.

lead_paragraph: FERNDALE, N.Y. — The case of the People of the State of New York against Amber Canavan touches on a variety of issues: animal rights, food culture and tradition, and the advisability of posting online videos of yourself on other people’s property. But at its heart, the central matter in the case — currently percolating in Sullivan County — is this: Did Ms. Canavan steal a pair of ducks?

headline: David Wright Aims to Raise His Production, Along With His Number of Games Played
abstract: The Mets are hoping, finally, to contend. Those expectations rest on Wright, whose 2014 season was derailed by a shoulder injury but who seems more aware of his physical limitations.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — David Wright has learned a few tricks over the years to help him stay healthy for an entire season. He takes fewer swings during warm-ups now and fields fewer ground balls at third base. He is also more mindful not to overwork his body while training during the season. Essentially, he has tried to eliminate taking unnecessary risks.

The first three acts play out at a tipsy dinner party that could rival “Disgraced” for discomfiture. At least these Shakespeareans make it to the dessert course before things go seriously awry.

headline: A Rare Chair
abstract: One of Hans Wegner’s classic, Modernist pieces is now available for all.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, Hans Wegner created his famous Tub Chair, consisting of two upholstered shells on an elegant bent-plywood frame. The goal was that it “should be beautiful from all angles.” It has since become one of the most iconic examples of midcentury Modernism, and yet only three of the chairs were ever made — until now. The original is being produced by the Danish workshop PP Mobler and is sold in the U.S. exclusively at Wyeth.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) CITIZENFOUR (2014) Laura Poitras had been working on a film about surveillance for two years when Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency whistle-blower, contacted her in January 2013, using the name “Citizenfour.” When Mr. Snowden let Ms. Poitras know that he would not conceal his identity as the source of information about N.S.A. surveillance, she persuaded him to let her film their encounter. This Oscar-nominated documentary chronicles the encounter in a Hong Kong hotel room of Ms. Poitras; Glenn Greenwald, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who first wrote about Mr. Snowden’s revelations; and Mr. Snowden as he hands over classified documents that provide evidence of the N.S.A.’s invasion of privacy and copes with the resulting media storm. “Cinema, even in the service of journalism, is always more than reporting, and focusing on what Ms. Poitras’s film is about risks ignoring what it is,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a tense and frightening thriller that blends the brisk globe-trotting of the ‘Bourne’ movies with the spooky, atmospheric effects of a Japanese horror film. And it is also a primal political fable for the digital age, a real-time tableau of the confrontation between the individual and the state.” He added: “Thinking about the issues Ms. Poitras raises can induce a kind of epistemological vertigo. What do we know about what is known about us? Who knows it? Can we trust them? These questions are terrifying, and so is ‘Citizenfour.’ ”

headline: Complicating the Picture of Urban Life
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Photography', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A new exhibit features three Bronx-born photographers whose work explores the idea of community while challenging outdated, lingering notions.
lead_paragraph: The 1980 image of Paul Newman, taken in the South Bronx during the filming of “Fort Apache, the Bronx,” could be a production still or a publicity photo. But the photograph was taken on location for more consequential reasons: Its photographer, Joe Conzo Jr., the teenage son of activists, was there to document a film that many in the community believed would hurt and embarrass it.

headline: For Dortmund, a Dramatic Fall, but Not From Grace
abstract: Borussia Dortmund’s fans are used to emotional swings and are remaining passionate through a rough season in which the team won two of 16 games during one stretch.
lead_paragraph: DORTMUND, Germany — The home fans poured over the bridge from the city center toward Westfalenstadion, a wave of black coats and hooped scarves crashing into sausage shacks and beer kiosks. Finally, they arrived at the famed Südtribüne, the terraced stand at the south end of the stadium, which rises like a tilted baking sheet and clumps together some 25,000 spectators in what is known throughout soccer as the Yellow Wall.

headline: Oscars 2015: Passionate Speeches, but Few Surprises
abstract: Oscar nights almost always drag on too long, but this one was a slog almost from the very beginning.
lead_paragraph: “Life is full of surprises,” is how Pawel Pawlikowski, the Polish-born director of “Ida,” put it at the Oscars on Sunday night. And he was one of them. Mr. Pawlikowski managed to keep talking over the wrap-it-up music, which usually ushers off long-winded or lesser-known nominees, and actually finished his acceptance speech for best foreign language film.

headline: The Manifestation of Señor Bacon
abstract: Was the idea of having our own pet pig one better left to the realm of imagination?
lead_paragraph: One night, when my husband Jason and I were in the earliest stages of our courtship — which, since we lived in different states, took place over Skype — we found ourselves talking about potbelly pigs. We’d succumbed to the pastime of browsing cute animal photos, and together, on our respective screens, ended up looking at pig pictures. When I joked about getting one of our own, Jason said, “We could name him Señor Bacon.”

headline: Who Loves America?

abstract: Our allegiance needn’t — mustn’t — be blind to be true. We must acknowledge our warts if we are to proclaim our beauty.
lead_paragraph: We have arrived at the point where the utter tedium and desperation of personal attacks against the president about his life story and his loyalty are no longer news. The histrionics have shed their ability to shock. Most right-minded Americans — ethically speaking, not ideologically speaking — have moved on.

headline: Even Better Than a Tax Cut
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Productivity', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Income', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: What workers really need are higher wages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WITH the early stages of the 2016 presidential campaign underway and millions of Americans still hurting financially, both parties are looking for ways to address wage stagnation. That’s the good news. The bad news is that both parties are offering tax cuts as a solution. What has hurt workers’ paychecks is not what the government takes out, but what their employers no longer put in — a dynamic that tax cuts cannot eliminate.

headline: Cutting Through India’s Smog
abstract: Indians appear to be waking up to the dangers of dirty energy, but their current path remains self-destructive.
lead_paragraph: Proof of the grave air pollution problem confronting India is seen not just in the suffocating smog that on many days crowds out the sun in New Delhi, the world’s most polluted city. It can be measured as well in the fact that the country has the world’s highest death rate from chronic respiratory diseases, which kill an estimated 1.5 million Indians every year. A 2014 World Health Organization report concluded of the 20 most polluted cities in the world, India has 13.

headline: When Medical Devices Spread Superbugs
abstract: Surely there are ways to keep hard-to-clean tubing from transmitting antibiotic-resistant infections.
lead_paragraph: Germs that are resistant to antibiotics are cropping up with alarming frequency at American hospitals. A lethal “superbug” known as CRE infected seven patients at the Ronald Reagan U.C.L.A. Medical Center and killed two of them. The germs were apparently transmitted on inadequately sterilized medical scopes.

headline: A Bumpy Ride for the M.T.A.

headline: Race, Foreign Armies and United States Colored Troops
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States wasn’t the only country to deploy units of black soldiers in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 14, 1865, while commanding the 32nd Colored Infantry during mop-up operations as part of Gen. William T. Sherman’s northern drive through South Carolina, Col. George Baird was wounded in fighting at James Island. Five days later, a Delaware native and formerly enslaved private named John Walter, of the 32nd’s Company K, shed blood in an explosion near Camden. Walter survived that event and received a $300 bounty when discharged in August, before disappearing from the public record.

headline: France Warns of Nuclear Industry Shake-Up After Areva Loss

headline: ‘Brother Orange’ Pictures in China Help Find a New Yorker’s Missing iPhone

lead_paragraph: In China, not all things that are lost are necessarily lost forever.

headline: China Looks West to Bring ‘Wolf Totem’ to Screen
abstract: “Wolf Totem,” a film by the French director Jean-Jacques Annaud, opens in China with Beijing’s approval.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Ten years ago, when producers at the state-run Beijing Forbidden City Film Corporation began searching for a director for the movie adaptation of the Chinese novel “Wolf Totem” by Jiang Rong, they had no plans to look beyond China’s homegrown stable. It was a Chinese story, after all, written by a Chinese author, and had sold more than a million copies in this country in the year since its publication in 2004. (It has sold four million more there since.)

headline: Negotiators Weigh Plan to Phase Out Nuclear Limits on Iran
abstract: Iranian and American officials considered a proposal that would strictly limit for at least 10 years Tehran’s nuclear production but gradually ease restrictions in the final years of a deal.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Iranian and American officials ended a round of high-level nuclear talks here on Monday considering a proposal that would strictly limit, for at least 10 years, Iran’s ability to produce nuclear material, but gradually ease restrictions on Tehran in the final years of any deal.

headline: Morning Agenda: Valeant Scoops Up Salix
abstract: VALEANT SCOOPS UP SALIX | Valeant Pharmaceuticals, the Canadian pharmaceutical company known for aggressively buying smaller drug companies, has agreed to pay $10.4 billion, or $158 a share in cash, for Salix Pharmaceuticals, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. Including debt, the transaction is valued at about $14.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: VALEANT SCOOPS UP SALIX | Valeant Pharmaceuticals, the Canadian pharmaceutical company known for aggressively buying smaller drug companies, has agreed to pay $10.4 billion, or $158 a share in cash, for Salix Pharmaceuticals, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. headline: Can Genetically Modified Bugs Save Lives?
abstract: Is it safe and sensible to put genetically changed mosquitoes into the environment to fight disease?

headline: Behind New Dietary Guidelines, Better Science
abstract: Government recommendations on how much fat and salt you should eat weren’t always based on the best available evidence. That may be changing.
lead_paragraph: For decades, many dietary recommendations have revolved around consuming a low percentage of your daily calories from fat. It has been widely thought that doing so would reduce your chance of having coronary heart disease. Most of the evidence for that recommendation has come from epidemiologic studies, which can be flawed.

headline: We Keep Flunking Forecasts on Interest Rates, Distorting the Budget Outlook
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The overestimates on rates for government bonds seem to be systemic, and we may be demanding more budget restraint than necessary.
lead_paragraph: Government economists try to predict the future of lots of indicators, including G.D.P., unemployment and inflation. Their record isn’t great, whether here or overseas. No less a figure than the Queen of England said to scholars at the London School of Economics about the deep recession in 2008: “Why did no one see it coming?”

After winning election in November, she was sworn in immediately to fill a vacant seat, and for the first time in history, there were 100 women in Congress.

headline: 1890: Great Fire at Greenwich
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Greenwich has a large factory fire in 1890.
lead_paragraph: LONDON—  A conflagration, which involved buildings nearly one hundred yards square, of a field of barrels of petroleum and over a dozen barges, all blazing at the same time, broke out at an early hour this morning [Feb. 23], and is still burning to-night. The scene of the outbreak was the Ordnance Wharf, Blackwall Lane, East Greenwich. Several engines were soon at the scene. Even then the flames were visible as far away as Southwark. The factory is about seventy yards long and fifty yards wide, and was used by the firm for general manufacturing purposes, and was crammed with thousands of tons of stock of the most inflammable description. How it originated is a mystery. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1890

headline: 1915: Russians in North Poland
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Russians advance in the Carpathians in 1915.
lead_paragraph: PETROGRAD — The Germans have swept through Augustowo and are now fighting a fresh Russian column between Lypsk and Grodno, but they are being held at bay on the right banks of the Narew and Bebrz, they have not been able to invest either Osowiec or Lomza, and the Muscovites have resumed the offensive on the north bank of the Vistula, where Marshal von Hindenburg’s forces were most threatening to the safety of Warsaw. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1915

headline: As Tiger Woods Fades, a Fear That Revenue Will, Too
abstract: Opinions differ on whether young stars like Rory McIlroy, Bubba Watson and Jason Day can attract viewers in large numbers when Woods’s playing days are over.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Since joining the PGA Tour in 1996, Tiger Woods has been golf’s transcendent figure, credited with expanding the sport’s television audience, fan base, tournament purses and sponsorship deals. Over the last six years, he has missed chunks of time because of personal travails and injuries, enabling the tour to test its preparedness for life after the gold rush.

headline: The Engel Macher
abstract: It was while I was in a country where the names “Roe” and “Wade” are virtually unknown that I have learned the most about their legacy.
lead_paragraph: The end of January marked an important anniversary for those of us who work in women’s health care: the 42nd anniversary of Roe v. Wade. This eponymous Supreme Court decision carries a great deal of emotional weight, and once a year, much of this emotion boils over into a week of protests, both for and against it. The names “Roe” and “Wade” inspire passionate opinions in even the most apolitical of Americans; and yet, ironically, it was in a country where these two names are virtually unknown that I have learned the most about their legacy.

headline: How It Came to Be ‘Birdman’s’ Night
abstract: The Academy’s ways — including resistance to critical praise like that for “Boyhood” — made all the difference.
lead_paragraph: Well, there you go. With the Academy Awards, sometimes you just never know. Or, rather you do, if you know where to look.

headline: The Transformation of Duke Street
abstract: A London strip now boasts shops as British as afternoon tea.
lead_paragraph: London’s quiet Duke Street, a few blocks from the international megastores on Mount Street, has seen an influx of boutiques with a decidedly local bent. The new location from the quirky-chic shoemaker Penelope Chilvers includes a studio for custom “dandy slippers,” and Philip Treacy’s protégée Laura Apsit Livens, a milliner to Rita Ora and the Duchess of Westminster, has set up her atelier inside a repurposed Victorian stairwell. Meanwhile, the historic men’s wear label E. Tautz — founded in 1867 and recently revived by the Norton & Sons designer Patrick Grant — just moved their first store into the neighborhood, with tailoring in the basement and the debut women’s collection on the racks. These boutiques join the recently opened Duke Street Emporium, a two-level concept store offering emerging fashion labels, beauty products and books amid exhibits from hometown artists.

headline: Oscars 2015: An Excellent Night for Prediction Markets
abstract: The favorites won in every major category and most smaller categories. Just as important, market prices accurately reflected the night’s uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: The prediction markets had another good year in predicting the Academy Awards. Perhaps more important, the categories that the markets seemed to get wrong underscored the ways in which such markets are useful without being clairvoyant.

headline: On the Ice Beat: Reporter’s Notebook

lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Times Metro reporter Tatiana Schlossberg, wearing three layers, boarded the Sturgeon Bay, a 140-foot Coast Guard icebreaker, and  wrote about her ride down the bone-chillingly cold Hudson River.

There was palpable excitement about two key British wins, Eddie Redmayne for best actor and “The Imitation Game” for best adapted screenplay (though the actual winner, the writer Graham Moore, is American).

headline: At the Governors Ball, Winners and Even a Happy Also-Ran
abstract: Julianne Moore, Eddie Redmayne, Patricia Arquette, Felicity Jones and Michael Keaton all mingled at the Academy’s official post-Oscars party.
lead_paragraph: One of the perks of being on the West Coast for an awards show is that it’s beholden to East Coast time. Which means when things finally wrap up after dragging on for far too long, it’s only, like, 9 p.m. Delighted to have a first awards season behind her, and having endured a surprise red carpet rainfall (the tent sprang massive leaks), the Bagger was torn between a determination to head home, stat – what else is there to say to people after three months of nonstop talking about the same thing, for heaven’s sakes? — and wanting to let off some steam.

headline: Patricia Arquette: To Every Woman Who Gave Birth to Every Taxpayer

lead_paragraph: There’s been a little backlash against Patricia Arquette’s decision to use her Oscar speech opportunity to call for wage equality for women. A little sniping that wage equality for women whose paychecks include six or even seven figures is a little different than wage equality on a lower scale. Even more complaining that Ms. Arquette “ruined it” with backstage commentary “dismissive” of equal rights for others.

headline: States Are Blocking Local Regulations, Often at Industry’s Behest
abstract: So-called pre-emption laws, passed in states across the country, have stopped cities from regulating landlords, building municipal broadband systems and raising the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: Darren Hodges, a Tea Party Republican and councilman in the windy West Texas city of Fort Stockton, is a fierce defender of his town’s decision to ban plastic bags. It was a local solution to a local problem and one, he says, city officials had a “God-given right” to make.

headline: At Burberry, Romantic (But Don’t Call Them “Smoky”) Eyes
abstract: To match the eclectic, bohemian collection, the makeup artist Wendy Rowe created a beauty look that’s as effortless as it looks.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist Wendy Rowe built a layered beauty look for Burberry’s fall 2015 show. “It’s a folky collection that’s full of eclectic patterns and prints,” she explained backstage earlier today. “To complement that, I’ve created a patchwork of textures: a matte mouth, cashmere skin and iridescent eyes.” Keeping the skin very clean and the lips tinted nude, she focused on creating “romantic” but, crucially, not “smoky” eyes. After drawing a line along the upper and lower lids with cream eye shadow, Rowe then loosely blended beneath the eye for a worn-in finish. Her advice for artlessly recreating this disheveled feel: “It should look as though its been done in a rush.”

headline: Grandmother, Surrogate Mother

lead_paragraph: In 2012, Sara Connel wrote “Woman Gives Birth to Own Grandson” here (we both laughed at the opportunity to accurately use such a tabloid-style headline in this august space). After years of infertility treatment and disappointment, Sara’s mother offered to be the surrogate for her daughter’s biological child:

headline: Picking Up a Memoir of Madness
abstract: In “He Wanted the Moon,” the author fills out her father’s long forgotten, extraordinary effort to chronicle his severe bipolar disease.
lead_paragraph: On an early summer night in 1944, on the wooded shoulder of a rural Massachusetts highway, a man in a rumpled brown suit wandered in the shadows. Whenever a car passed, he dropped to the ground and lay flat. His hair was matted, his face smeared with mud. He was a respectable Boston doctor on the lam, hungry, lost and ill.
