headline: Schism Emerges in Bikram Yoga Empire Amid Rape Claims
abstract: A day of legal reckoning is drawing closer for the yoga guru Bikram Choudhury, who is facing six civil lawsuits, the latest filed this month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — He is the yoga guru who built an empire on sweat and swagger. He has a stable of luxury cars and a Beverly Hills mansion. During trainings for hopeful yoga teachers, he paces a stage in a black Speedo and holds forth on life, sex and the transformative power of his brand of hot yoga. “I totally cure you,” he has told interviewers. “Whatever the problem you have.”

headline: Debbie Harry on Four Decades of Blondie
abstract: In the coming weeks, the rocker will appear at the 25th annual Tibet House Benefit Concert and at a residency at the Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: On March 5, Carnegie Hall will host Tibet House’s 25th Annual Benefit Concert, whose ongoing aim is to preserve the awareness of Tibetan culture around the world. This year’s event has a lineup bursting with talent to match the organization’s quarter-century existence, with performances from the composer Philip Glass and the rock band the Flaming Lips. Perhaps most exciting, however, will be the appearance of the legendary troika of rock goddesses Laurie Anderson, Patti Smith and the Blondie frontwoman Debbie Harry. The latter of the trio, still going strong at 69, also has an upcoming run at the posh Café Carlyle, dozens of blocks north of the lower Manhattan landscape she’s been synonymous with for the past 40 years. Harry talked with T about what we can expect from her uptown persona, how she braves the frigid New York winter and why she thinks she became a music and style icon.

headline: IBM Tries to Paint the Computing Cloud Blue
abstract: IBM is going deeper in the plan of its chief, Virginia Rometty, to rebuild the computing giant as a cloud company. At a giant show in Las Vegas, the company announced new kinds of security and services for cloud applications, along with data centers in new countries.
lead_paragraph: IBM hopes everything looks better in IBM blue.

headline: New Directors/New Films Picks Sundance Hit for Opening Night
abstract: “The Diary of a Teenage Girl” will kick off the annual series.
lead_paragraph: “The Diary of a Teenage Girl,” about a 15-year-old, Minnie, who has an affair with her mother’s boyfriend, was a hit at the Sundance Film Festival last month, and now the organizers of the annual New Directors/New Films series in New York have chosen it as their opening-night selection.

headline: Shola Olatoye on Her Name
abstract: Ms. Olatoye, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority, discusses the pronunciation of her name and its origin.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Olatoye, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority, discusses the pronunciation of her name and its origin.

headline: Oscars 2015: Dull, Witless, Unjust … and Irresistible
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Movies', 'Theater', 'Toys']
abstract: Bruni and Douthat are addicted to the Academy Awards, but maybe it’s best that the show happens just once a year.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni: Ross, I begin this conversation with a sense of shame and the feeling that we’re feeding a bad habit, because there’s no annual event in American life more excessively and obsequiously chronicled by those of us in the media than the Oscars. From September, when studios start unveiling their award-season showboats, to late February, when the statuettes are handed out in a ceremony whose long-winded dullness never ceases to amaze, we’re Oscar slaves. Oscar suckers. We should be stronger. We should resist.

headline: Finding the Right Balance of Time and Money
abstract: We exchange time for money in the form of work, and money for time in the form of convenience. Our happiness may depend on finding an equilibrium.
lead_paragraph: One summer, a friend of mine planned a river trip. The closest public airport was a day and a half’s drive from the river. So my friend decided to hire a private plane to get his group to the destination in a few hours. I know this choice sounds extravagant, but it represents a choice we’ve probably all experienced at some point.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey’
abstract: A look at Jerry Marsini’s artwork for a one-man show about the killing of a gay 14-year-old.
lead_paragraph: The artist Jerry Marsini didn’t need to travel far to research his poster design for “The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey.” Written by and starring James Lecesne, a co-founder of the L.G.B.T. youth organization the Trevor Project, the show is about the murder of a gay artistically-minded 14-year-old in a small town.

lead_paragraph: London

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: On Immigration, Obama Turns a G.O.P. Argument on Its Head
abstract: Lawyers for the Justice Department argue that a judge’s injunction blocking the president’s immigration programs should be lifted because it violates the separation of powers.
lead_paragraph: For months, Republicans have said they are offended by President Obama’s executive actions on immigration, saying he is essentially making law himself in violation of the Constitution’s separation of powers.

headline: Egyptian Blogger Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison for Protest Role
abstract: Alaa Abd El Fattah and about two dozen others were convicted of taking part in an unauthorized demonstration in 2013 and were all fined $13,000.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A blogger who came to be one of the best-known faces of the 2011 uprising in Egypt was sentenced to five years in prison on Monday, part of the military-backed government’s continuing crackdown on dissent.

headline: Refurbished Stations From Denver to Tokyo
abstract: Train stations around the world are receiving significant face lifts, giving them a contemporary atmosphere and putting a new emphasis on retail and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Train stations around the world are receiving significant face lifts, giving them a contemporary atmosphere and putting a new emphasis on retail and restaurants.

headline: The 10 Best Dressed at the 87th Academy Awards
abstract: Last night, red and white looks dominated the red carpet — and the after party.
lead_paragraph: Red and white gowns dominated the red carpet last night at the 87th Academy Awards — and the after party. As usual, the evening wasn’t short on outfit changes (Emma Stone notably took off the stunning gold number she wore to the show and put on a red-and-white look for a night out), but a majority of the leading ladies got it right the first, and only, time. As for Lady Gaga and her three custom Azzedine Alaïa dresses: the one she arrived in, complete with a pair of red leather gloves that blew up Twitter, was the most unforgettable look of the night. Here, a look back at the evening’s most glamorous Oscars style.

headline: London Fashion Week: Thomas Tait Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Meet Project Phoenix, the new NYT Android App
abstract: Today we’re excited to announce The New York Times Android app 5.0, codenamed “Phoenix.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reaches more readers today than ever before in its 164-year history thanks to the rise of mobile. On Android specifically, user growth in recent years has been explosive.

headline: With Palestinian Debt Rising, Israeli Utility Briefly Reduces Power to West Bank
abstract: The move came amid a worsening crisis in the Palestinian Authority after Israel began to withhold more than $100 million in monthly tax revenue it collects on the authority’s behalf.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s state-owned electricity company briefly reduced the power supply to two Palestinian districts in the northern West Bank on Monday because of a ballooning debt, according to company officials, in a measure that also reflected the growing political disconnect between the Israeli and Palestinian sides.

headline: Valeant’s Deal for Salix Continues Frenzied Deal-Making in Drug Sector
abstract: There is relief among Valeant’s backers that the company has returned to signing deals, after its long chase of Allergan left it empty-handed.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has a penchant for deals, has taken on a $10 billion company in its latest deal to buy Salix. Valeant’s pledge last year to focus on organic growth and debt reduction didn’t last long. Cost cuts and tax savings from buying Salix Pharmaceuticals proved irresistible.

headline: Food Habits Getting Worse Around the World
keywords: ['Obesity', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Children and Childhood', 'Soft Drinks']
abstract: Some poor and middle-income countries with relatively healthy diets are being targeted by Western food companies with increased advertising.
lead_paragraph: People in some poor and middle-income countries have healthier diets than those in rich ones, but major Western snack and soft drink makers are targeting children in ways that will damage their health, according to a new series of studies on obesity.

headline: London Fashion Week: Thomas Tait Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: What Flying Was Like Before the Smoke Cleared
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Flight Attendants', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Pressure from a flight attendants’ union was crucial to the ban imposed on smoking on domestic flights 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: IF you think the air travel experience generally stinks now, consider what it was like before smoking was banned on domestic flights 25 years ago.

headline: Statement Earrings at the 87th Academy Awards
abstract: Last night at the Oscars, large diamond shapes outshone the red-carpet necklaces everybody else was talking about.
lead_paragraph: Although statement necklaces created predictable buzz at last night’s red carpet, the more interesting jewelry moments came via large, sculptural diamond earrings. At the 2015 Academy Awards, Julianne Moore and Marion Cotillard donned round, elegant pairs, both by Chopard, while the young starlet Chloe Grace Moretz opted for a single, edgier ear cuff by Forevermark, proving that sometimes, one is better than two.

headline: This Winter Has Gotten Old
abstract: This has been a season of freeze, thaw, repeat. Freeze, thaw, repeat.
lead_paragraph: “Then I’m laying out my winter clothes and wishing I was gone, going home, where the New York City winters aren’t bleeding me.” So goes the Simon and Garfunkel song, buried deep in the memory, an oldie that seems to have been around for as long as this old winter has.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Helping Boys Succeed
abstract: An educator urges schools to take steps to address the differences in how boys and girls learn. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Time for New Antlers
abstract: When deer lose their antlers each year, do they grow back in the same pattern?
lead_paragraph: Q. When deer lose their antlers each year, do they grow back in the same pattern?

headline: Mothers’ Sounds Are Building Block for Babies’ Brains
abstract: A study with premature infants demonstrated that a mother’s voice and heartbeat may help the developing brain grow.
lead_paragraph: The sound of a mother’s voice plays a critical role in a baby’s early development, multiple studies have shown. Now, researchers have demonstrated that the brain itself may rely on a mother’s voice and heartbeat to grow.

headline: Obama Warns of Homeland Dept. Shutdown
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While addressing the National Governors Association, the president warned of the effects of a Department of Homeland Security shutdown on states’ economies.
lead_paragraph: While addressing the National Governors Association, the president warned of the effects of a Department of Homeland Security shutdown on states’ economies.

headline: Meditation for a Good Night’s Sleep
abstract: Mindfulness meditation helped older men and women get a good night’s sleep, a rigorous new study found.
lead_paragraph: Do you have chronic sleep problems? You may be able to significantly improve your ability to get a restful night of sleep by practicing a popular form of meditation, a rigorous new study shows.

headline: Why Jeb Bush Has Only One Photo From His Wedding
abstract: Just one wedding photograph remains from Jeb Bush’s wedding.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s wife, Columba, is in the spotlight this week, with new profiles out about her wariness of the family business and her expensive taste.

headline: Brocade’s Renaissance at London Fashion Week
abstract: For fall 2015, British designers update the historic and opulent Italian fabric with dramatic shapes, bold hues and interesting lines.
lead_paragraph: In London, opulence and regality have taken center stage at many a fall 2015 fashion show, from the historic venues in which they took place — the Tate Britain art gallery and the Victoria and Albert Museum — to certain decadent details in the collections. And over the past few days, beautiful brocade fabrics have been ushered into the 21st century with dramatic shapes (a voluptuous cape at Simone Rocha), bold hues (rich berry-and-black palettes at Mary Katrantzou) and interesting lines (sophisticated patchwork and cutouts at Erdem).

headline: Wall St. and Law Firms Plan Cooperative Body to Bolster Online Security
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Legal Profession', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Banks and law firms are planning to set up a group that would be affiliated with the banking industry’s forum for sharing data on online threats.
lead_paragraph: The threat of ever-larger online attacks is bringing together Wall Street banks and the big law firms that do work for them in an alliance that could result in some sharing of basic information about digital security issues.

headline: According to the Words, the News Is Actually Good
abstract: An algorithm used to analyze millions of articles and books, and billions of tweets, determined that we are naturally upbeat, at least in how we express ourselves.
lead_paragraph: We journalists pride ourselves on a willingness to bring you bad news. The more death and destruction, the more words and pictures. If it bleeds, it leads.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Tuesday
abstract: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Sunday Routine Made Graphic
abstract: The Sunday Routine editor, Hilary Howard, talks to the illustrator Amy Reeder, who illustrated her Routine column.
lead_paragraph: Sunday Routine, a regular Metropolitan section feature, looks at the way newsworthy New Yorkers spend a typical Sunday.

headline: Reuters Bureau Chief Is Found Dead in Pakistan
abstract: Maria Golovnina, 34, the Pakistan and Afghanistan bureau chief since 2013, fell unconscious at her office in Islamabad.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistan and Afghanistan bureau chief for Reuters, Maria Golovnina, was found dead at her office in Islamabad on Monday, according to a statement by Reuters and Pakistani officials.

headline: Hunter Original: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Wim Wenders, Man of the World
abstract: The filmmaker documents his travels — and recalls his nights in the Australian outback — for his new film about Sebastião Salgado.
lead_paragraph: Wim Wenders explores pristine landscapes in his new documentary, “The Salt of the Earth,” about the photojournalist Sebastião Salgado. Here, he recalls his own memorable brush with the great outdoors.

headline: An Overture by Winter, Then Warmth and Energy
abstract: The orchestra, not well known in the city, brimmed with energy and enthusiasm in a program of Brahms and Tchaikovsky.
lead_paragraph: “Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon. My name is Yannick.” A ripple of laughter went through the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday when the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin took the microphone at the beginning of his Great Performers concert with the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra. To his adoring and vocal fans, he needed no introduction: As music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Mr. Nézet-Séguin is a frequent guest in New York. But the ensemble he was presenting on this occasion — and which he has led as music director since 2008 — is still unfamiliar to American audiences.

headline: Ukraine Rebels Celebrate Their Taking of Debaltseve
abstract: A rally for the separatists’ victory in the strategic town of Debaltseve came on Defender of the Fatherland Day, a holiday for veterans dating to Soviet times.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian rebels celebrated their recent victory at Debaltseve with a festive rally on Monday in Donetsk, the main city they control, where soldiers received medals in Lenin Square and the crowd cheered and waved Soviet flags.

headline: France Seizes 6 Passports Under Antiterrorism Law
abstract: The French authorities began to use new counterterrorism powers to halt the stream of young people suspected of going to Syria to engage in terrorist activities.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French authorities began to use new, sweeping counterterrorism powers on Monday to halt the stream of young people going to Syria, confiscating the passports of six people suspected of trying to go there to engage in terrorist activities.

headline: An Inimitable Western
abstract: Jim Krantz’s cinematic vision of the American West.
lead_paragraph: Jim Krantz’s cinematic vision of the American West.

headline: General Electric Deal for Alstom Raises Concerns Among European Authorities
abstract: The European Commission said it was worried that G.E., as the world’s top maker of heavy-duty gas turbines, would be eliminating a major competitor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — General Electric expressed confidence on Monday that its $13.5 billion acquisition of Alstom’s energy business would be completed, even after European antitrust authorities raised concerns about how it would affect competition in the market for heavy-duty gas turbines.

headline: Seeing Spots on the Women’s Fall 2015 Runways
abstract: Marc Jacobs, Erdem and Burberry all offered new twists on leopard print for the upcoming season.
lead_paragraph: The virtues of leopard print as a neutral are undersung. It goes with everything and is almost always in fashion — decade after decade, the print continues to find relevance, from Bettie Page’s midcentury pin-up swimsuits to Kate Moss’s signature vintage leopard coat. For fall/winter 2015, designers are revisiting leopard in new ways. First, in New York, Marc Jacobs used the print as trim on the collar and pockets of a metallic belted jacket, as well as on a matching bag. Across the pond at Erdem, the designer showed a ladylike leopard skirt suit, in homage to his Hitchcockian muses. Lastly, at Burberry, a demure midcalf-length leopard coat was toughened up with a built-in harness — Page would approve.

headline: At Vanity Fair’s Oscars Party, Jay Z and Beyoncé Steal the Show
abstract: America’s royal couple strode in late, and the crowd couldn’t help itself. An onslaught of photos began.
lead_paragraph: It may have been the most exclusive party of the year, but it didn’t matter: Jay Z and Beyoncé can stop any room.

headline: Andreja Pejic Transforms at Giles
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Andreja Pejic before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Sacha Mascolo.

headline: The Power of a Tease and a Bobby Pin at Erdem
abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: a classic, midcentury-inspired look.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

lead_paragraph: Egypt and More — Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Mr. Mulryan sings “Giants in the Sky” from the Fiasco Theater’s production of the musical “Into the Woods,” with Matt Castle on piano. The show is at the Laura Pels Theater through April 12.

headline: Feb. 23, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Bangladesh, Maldives and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Bangladesh, Maldives and Ukraine.

headline: Strong Sales for Larry David’s ‘Fish in the Dark’ on Broadway
abstract: The new comedy, written by and starring Mr. David, set a box-office record for the Cort Theater.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway comedy “Fish in the Dark,” written by and starring Larry David, set a box-office record for the Cort Theater last week, grossing $1,177,593, according to ticket sales data published on Monday. The previous record was set by the 2010 revival of “Fences,” starring Denzel Washington, during its final week of performances, when the play grossed $1,175,626. “Fish in the Dark,” in which Mr. David plays the son of a dying family patriarch, is still in preview performances; the critics’ reviews will come out after opening night on March 5.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘My Own Life’
abstract: Readers celebrated the life, work and inspiration of Oliver Sacks in response to his Op-Ed “My Own Life.”
lead_paragraph: The neurologist whose writing opened a popular window on a medical “awakening” of the human mind shared his personal awakening after receiving a terminal cancer diagnosis. Readers responded to Oliver Sacks’ “My Own Life” with gratitude.

headline: Oscars TV Ratings Fall 15 Percent
abstract: This year’s Academy Awards show, hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew about 36.6 million viewers, down from 43 million last year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Ratings tumbled 15 percent for this year’s Oscars ceremony on Sunday, delivering the least-watched show in six years, according to Nielsen data.

headline: Feeding Infants Peanut Products Could Prevent Allergies, Study Suggests
abstract: The finding, in The New England Journal of Medicine, addresses a condition that afflicts 2 percent of American children.
lead_paragraph: Turning what was once conventional wisdom on its head, a new study suggests that many, if not most peanut allergies can be prevented by feeding young children food containing peanuts beginning in infancy, rather than avoiding such foods.

headline: ‘Snow Snow Snow,’ and East Coast Skiers Rejoice
abstract: Back-to-back snowstorms in New England have made this a very good year for ski resorts like Jay Peak Resort, Stowe and Cannon Mountain.
lead_paragraph: In early February, the outdoor sports website Teton Gravity Research posted a video of a skier plunging down an alpine chute in thigh-deep powder, slaloming through evergreens and yelping with joy as clumps of snow pelted his goggles.

headline: Christopher Kane’s Perfectly Pink Crocodile Booties
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: boots that thrive when paired with a matching bag and skirt.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Vice Media vs. Brooklyn Indie Music Clubs
abstract: The company’s expansion on the Williamsburg waterfront has angered supporters of displaced performance spaces.
lead_paragraph: When word spread eight months ago that Vice Media was moving into a complex of warehouses on the Williamsburg waterfront in Brooklyn, supporters of two indie-music clubs being displaced accused the company of violating the very spirit of hipness and authenticity that it had seemingly built its brand upon.

headline: Review: In ‘The Buried Giant,’ Ishiguro Revisits Memory and Denial
abstract: Kazuo Ishiguro’s new novel, set in a mythical Britain around the time of King Arthur, examines the impact of amnesia.
lead_paragraph: Kazuo Ishiguro’s latest novel, “The Buried Giant,” is an eccentric, ham-handed fairy tale with a jumble of story lines lifted from “Beowulf,” Arthurian legend and assorted folk traditions. It is recounted in stilted, formalistic language that’s presumably meant to evoke a bygone era, and set in a mythical Britain equally reminiscent of “The Lord of the Rings” and “Game of Thrones.” King Arthur’s knight Sir Gawain is a major character, and so is a she-dragon named Querig.

headline: As ‘Ida’ Wins an Oscar, Poland Ends a Losing Streak
abstract: Before Sunday night, Polish movies had been nominated for best foreign language film nine times but never won an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The utter tenacity with which the director Pawel Pawlikowski talked and talked and refused to be shooed off stage by the Oscar orchestra has been matched only by the Polish film industry’s own persistent, decades-long pursuit of international recognition.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: Sometimes the anticipation for the game builds all week until Saturday’s kickoff. And sometimes you only have to wait a day. Here’s what you should watch this week.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the anticipation for the game builds all week until Saturday’s kickoff. And sometimes you only have to wait a day. Here’s what you should watch this week.

headline: Stifel Financial to Acquire Sterne Agee
abstract: In acquiring Sterne Agee, Stifel will gain about 730 financial advisers and management of more than $20 billion of client assets.
lead_paragraph: Stifel Financial, the financial services firm, said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire smaller rival Sterne Agee Group in a deal valued at about $150 million.

headline: Married Sex Gets Better in the Golden Years
abstract: Sex improves in later years among long-married couples, becoming more frequent as intimacy becomes more a priority, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Yes, there is sex after marriage. Particularly if you make it past your 50th wedding anniversary.

headline: Reviews: New Albums From Big Sean, Emile Haynie and DRKWAV
abstract: These artists’ latest releases cover rap, pop and jazz.
lead_paragraph: EMILE HAYNIE

headline: Funding Fight Over Homeland Security Poses Dangers for the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A partisan impasse over immigration could cause funding for the agency to run out Friday and damage the Republican brand, and the impact could carry over into the next election cycle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After promising an era of responsible governing and an end to federal shutdowns, congressional Republicans find themselves mired in an immigration fight that could cause funding for the Department of Homeland Security to run out on Friday.

headline: The Tangled Roots of English
abstract: The precursor to many modern languages, including English, was probably spread by force, not farming.
lead_paragraph: The peoples of India, Iran and Europe speak a Babel of tongues, but most — English included — are descended from an ancient language known as proto-Indo-European. Scholars have argued for two centuries about the identity and homeland of those who spoke this parent language, but a surprisingly sudden resolution of this longstanding issue may be at hand.

headline: New York’s Fluoridation Fuss, 50 Years Later
abstract: It took eight contentious years of debate before fluoridated water finally started flowing in the city in 1965. The issue still divides communities.
lead_paragraph: In March 1957, as Elvis was buying Graceland and the Soviets were preparing to shock the world with Sputnik, Robert F. Wagner, the famously cautious mayor of New York, was having trouble taking a stand.

headline: Marine Life Study Suggests Bigger Is Better for Successful Evolution
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Oceans and Seas', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: Scientists at Stanford found that the maximum body size for marine animals has increased by a factor of 100,000 over 542 million years.
lead_paragraph: Cope’s rule states that evolution favors larger bodies, suggesting that the average size of animals on the planet should always trend upward. The hypothesis has its proponents, but there has been scant evidence to support it.

headline: ‘Gangland Undercover’ and ‘Outlaw Country’ Examine Biker Life
abstract: One program, on History, is a scripted series based on an account of a federal informant, while the other, on WGN, is a reality show.
lead_paragraph: It’s an interesting week in the ever-evolving relationship between television and crime. The History channel, no doubt hoping to fill the “Sons of Anarchy” void, puts motorcycle gangs back on the air with “Gangland Undercover,” based on a federal informant’s real story. And WGN tries to push the police ride-along show to the next dubious level by adding a potential-lawbreaker ride-along.

headline: Mouse Brain May Give Insight Into Diseases of Human Mind
abstract: When injected with human DNA, mouse embryos grew brains that were 12 percent larger than those of embryos injected with the same genes from chimpanzees.
lead_paragraph: When injected with bits of human DNA, mouse embryos grew brains that were 12 percent larger than those of embryos injected with the same genes from chimpanzees. Scientists at Duke University, writing in the journal Current Biology, say the experiment demonstrates the role that a particular gene sequence, HARE5, plays in the development of the human brain, which is far heavier and more complex than the brains of our closest animal cousins. The research also may help reveal why humans develop conditions like Alzheimer’s and autism, but chimpanzees do not.

headline: Formula for Headache-Free Flying: Pack Only a Phone and a Book
abstract: Ben Weprin, founder and chief executive of AJ Capital Partners, a company that restores hotel properties, travels light. Very light.
lead_paragraph: I’VE spent my career in the hospitality industry, and in 2008 started my own company, AJ Capital Partners. My business is investing in and restoring hotel properties to their glorious state, and right now we have about nine projects underway in cities across the United States.

headline: Review: Carmen de Lavallade’s One-Woman Show Comes to New York
abstract: Ms. De Lavallade performs an hourlong performance, 83 years in the making.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean when an 83-year-old woman says, “Once I was beautiful”? Carmen de Lavallade is 83, and when she speaks those words in her autobiographical one-woman show, “As I Remember It,” their truth is unmistakable. You can see it in the projected photos and videos from her youth as a celebrated dancer and actress. But there is also the evidence of Ms. de Lavallade in the present, belying the verb tense. Her beauty is not a thing of the past.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

lead_paragraph: A collection of space program images, dating from 1946 to the end of NASA’s lunar missions in 1972.

headline: Disney Names Robert Chapek Chairman for Theme Parks
abstract: Mr. Chapek, who had run Disney Consumer Products, will succeed Thomas Staggs, recently named chief operating officer, at the theme park division.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Monday handed the reins of its sprawling theme park operation to a fast-rising executive known for streamlining the entertainment giant’s merchandise division.

headline: Please Stop Making That Noise
abstract: Misophonia, in which certain ordinary sounds offend or irritate the listener, presents special challenges to a primary care physician.
lead_paragraph: I can’t stand it when someone behind me at a movie chews popcorn with his or her mouth open. I mean, I really can’t stand it.

headline: Rarely Seen Images From Space Including the ‘Best Selfie Ever’
abstract: More than 700 vintage photographs from the early days of space exploration are to be auctioned Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of photographs from the early years of the space age are for sale. That includes the first image taken from space — from an altitude of 65 miles by a camera on a V-2 rocket launched from the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico on Oct. 24, 1946. (The boundary to outer space is generally placed at 100 kilometers, or 62.1 miles.)

headline: Tiananmen Square ‘Negatives’: An Art Book or a Protest?
abstract: The photographer Xu Yong published only negatives of his pictures documenting the 1989 protests, but they are likely to be seen as a provocation: Readers can unlock the full images with an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The latest book by the photographer Xu Yong is filled with the images of young Chinese idealists clamoring for democracy and denouncing the Communist Party, but he insists that there is nothing political about his decision to publish this trove of snapshots he had kept hidden for more than two decades.

headline: Former Chinese Premier Draws Praise for His Philanthropy
abstract: While Zhu Rongji’s charity has won praise, it has prompted discussions as to why so few of his political colleagues have followed suit.
lead_paragraph: Since Zhu Rongji stepped down as premier of China in 2003, he has pursued interests including playing a type of fiddle called the huqin, writing best sellers and practicing philanthropy. It is this last activity, in particular, that returned Mr. Zhu to the spotlight, while also drawing attention to how unusual such charity is among former Chinese politicians.

headline: Christie Broke Law With Pension Move, New Jersey Judge Says
abstract: The ruling against Gov. Chris Christie’s decision not to make the full payment into the state system for public employees, and the judge’s order to find a way to fund it, came as he prepared to unveil his next budget.
lead_paragraph: In a major blow to Gov. Chris Christie, a New Jersey judge ruled on Monday that he violated state law when he declined to make the full payment into the state’s pension system for public employees last year and ordered him to find a way to fund it now.

headline: The Next Big Military Civil Rights Issue: Transgender Service
abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter said he was “open-minded” about “personal lives and proclivities.”
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter got it right on Sunday when he said that nothing but “suitability for service” should “preclude” transgender people from serving openly in the military — in other words, ability to do the job.

abstract: The agency’s director, Mary Jo White, must recuse herself from cases handled by her former law firm as well as her husband’s firm, sometimes leaving a party-line stalemate.
lead_paragraph: Their legal careers, and by extension their marriage, are the stuff of lore. Mary Jo White leads the Securities and Exchange Commission; her husband, John, practices law at an old-guard firm as elite as the corporations it represents. Together, they are a legal power couple that straddles Wall Street and Washington like few others.

headline: For an Iraqi Expatriate, ‘American Sniper’ Both Draws and Repels
abstract: Yasmine Mousa, an Iraqi-Canadian journalist, left Iraq — her homeland — in 2003 with her children and returned there to work in 2010. She writes that a mixture of curiosity and trepidation compelled her to see ‘American Sniper.’
lead_paragraph: Like many others, I was intrigued by the attention the film “American Sniper” was getting. I knew I was treading murky waters, but I decided to follow the herd and see the movie. Unlike most people in the crowd, I had a very personal stake in the film. “American Sniper” takes place in Iraq, my homeland, which I left shortly after the American-led invasion that Chris Kyle took part in. So the film, powerful and sad, left me with mixed thoughts and reminiscences.

headline: ‘A Bronx Tale’ Musical to Debut at Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey
abstract: The new musical version of Chazz Palminteri’s semi-autobiographical story will be directed by Robert De Niro and Jerry Zaks, as one of five shows in the Playhouse’s new season.
lead_paragraph: Chazz Palminteri’s semi-autobiographical story “A Bronx Tale” has been a movie (directed by and starring Robert De Niro) and a Broadway solo show (directed by the Tony Award winner Jerry Zaks). Now it’s coming back again as a musical – with Mr. De Niro and Mr. Zaks teaming up as directors. The Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., announced on Monday that the world premiere of “A Bronx Tale” musical will be one of five shows in its 2015-16 season, running Feb. 4-March 6, 2016. “A Bronx Tale” features music by the Tony winner Alan Menken (“Newsies”), lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Mr. Palminteri (who will not be a member of the cast this time around); Sergio Trujillo is the choreographer.

headline: Jim Krantz’s Wild West
abstract: The photographer’s work was made famous by Marlboro and Richard Prince. The photographer himself? Not so much.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago-based commercial photographer Jim Krantz’s work has been famous in the art world for years. Krantz himself has been less so — a fact that perhaps requires some explanation. In the 1990s, Krantz, who had been documenting the cinematic vistas of the American West and its people with his camera for 20 years, went to Texas to photograph cowboys for a Marlboro advertising campaign. The final product caught the eye of Richard Prince, the “appropriation artist” who had achieved renown by photographing ads and presenting the resulting images in galleries and museums. Beginning in the 1980s, Prince reproduced images from Marlboro ads for his “Cowboys” series. One such print, at the time of its sale in 2005, was the most expensive photograph ever sold at auction.

headline: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
abstract: A Bangladeshi photographer who tired of seeing poverty portrayed in the usual ways had a brainstorm: He lived with his subjects and had them collaborate with him.
lead_paragraph: A Bangladeshi photographer who tired of seeing poverty portrayed in the usual ways had a brainstorm: He lived with his subjects and had them collaborate with him.

headline: Google Guns for Apple in Mobile Payments Race
abstract: The use of so-called proximity payment services is expected to accelerate in the coming year and Google isn’t ready to cede the market to companies like Apple and Samsung.
lead_paragraph: Technology companies have spent years trying to persuade people to put away their credit cards and pay with mobile phones instead, but consumers have mostly shrugged. Now, with the release of Apple’s Apple Pay application, the race to replace credit cards with mobile phones has turned into a brawl.

headline: Alan Howard, Actor With Royal Shakespeare Company, Dies at 77
abstract: An English actor whose regal bearing and imposing voice gave life to Shakespearean kings, Mr. Howard was a mainstay of the Royal Shakespeare Company for decades.
lead_paragraph: Alan Howard, a celebrated English actor whose regal bearing and imposing voice gave life to a spate of Shakespearean kings, died on Feb. 14 in London. He was 77.

headline: Jeb Bush Looms Large for Marco Rubio in 2016
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Bush, another Republican politician from Florida, complicates the choices for some donors considering whom to support in the next presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, stood in front of reporters before a book signing here, pondering the question that has dogged him ever since Jeb Bush announced his plans to pursue a presidential bid: How does a Bush candidacy complicate Mr. Rubio’s own Oval Office aspirations, especially among donors?

headline: Defense Chief Vouches for U.S. Strategy on ISIS
abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Monday that the United States now needed to better use the assistance of other countries in the international coalition that has come together to fight the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait — The new defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, said Monday after meeting with senior American military and diplomatic officials in Kuwait that the Obama administration had “the ingredients of the strategy” to defeat Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria.

headline: A Pesticide Banned, or Not, Underscores Trans-Atlantic Trade Sensitivities
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Pesticides', 'Defoliants and Herbicides']
abstract: Diverging regulatory approaches to atrazine, a herbicide made by a Swiss company but not used in Europe, shows the hurdles in trade negotiations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Syngenta, a Swiss chemicals company, produces one of America’s most popular herbicides. It is called atrazine, and 73.7 million pounds of the chemical compound were applied in the United States in 2013. It was used on more than half of all corn crops, two-thirds of sorghum and up to 90 percent of sugar cane.

headline: Columbia Hires Ex-Penn Coach Al Bagnoli, Surprising Its Ivy Peers
abstract: Three months after he retired with nine Ivy League titles at Penn, Bagnoli abruptly joined Columbia as its new head football coach.
lead_paragraph: Three months after he retired with nine Ivy League titles in 23 seasons at the University of Pennsylvania, Al Bagnoli stunned the conference on Monday when he abruptly joined Columbia as its new football coach.

headline: Rebirth of the Cool: American Music Makes a Return to Iran
abstract: A concert Friday in Tehran was the first by an American in Iran since 1979. Such cultural diplomacy would have drawn protests in the past, but stances are softening.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The audience members in Tehran’s Vahdat concert hall rose from their seats, clapping wildly as the frontman Bob Belden, a fun-loving New Yorker with a predilection for loud shirts, rested his soprano saxophone on a nearby stand.

headline: 12 at Wesleyan University Are Hospitalized for Drug Overdoses
abstract: The police said it was likely that the overdoses were a result of a “bad batch” of Molly, a party drug similar to MDMA or Ecstasy that has recently gained popularity.

abstract: A 2012 video shows a distraught Pedro Hernandez being encouraged and consoled by officers as he admitted that he choked 6-year-old Etan Patz until the boy passed out.
lead_paragraph: The tearful confession came after six and a half hours of interrogation, and yet, when it was over, the man now on trial in the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz had left key questions unanswered.

headline: A Marine Is Convicted on Two Counts of Desertion
keywords: ['Desertion (Military)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Corporal Wassef Ali Hassoun, a naturalized United States citizen, vanished twice, first while serving in Iraq, and later fleeing to Lebanon, his native country.
lead_paragraph: Wassef Ali Hassoun, a Marine corporal accused of faking his abduction in Iraq in 2004 and evading punishment for years by fleeing to Lebanon, was found guilty on Monday of two counts of desertion. He was sentenced to two years in prison by a military judge at Camp Lejeune, N.C., and given a dishonorable discharge.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Stiffer Rules on Vehicle Fuel Ratings
abstract: Starting next year, automakers will face tougher guidelines around how they conduct a test used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two years of imposing increasingly stiff penalties on automakers that overstate their fuel economy ratings, federal regulators on Monday said they would tighten guidelines used in determining the mileage advertised to consumers.

headline: Red Sox Place a Big Bet on the Latest Prospect From Cuba

lead_paragraph: Yoan Moncada sits at the intersection of dollars and dreams. He is a blank slate, completely unknown beyond the relatively few people who have watched him play. His potential, therefore, seems limitless.

lead_paragraph: Nearly three weeks after a fatal Metro-North Railroad crash, the National Transportation Safety Board released a summary of its preliminary findings on Monday, but official conclusions about the cause of the crash are months away.

headline: The Horrors Keep Coming at Rikers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Guards', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: The abuse from corrections officers that continues to unfold at Rikers Island must end.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year has passed since Mayor Bill de Blasio installed Joseph Ponte as his correction commissioner and charged him with reforming the house-of-horrors city jail system at Rikers Island, where guards have routinely beaten inmates bloody as a matter of course. The mayor has since shaken up the jail system’s management team, committed new resources to the reform project and pledged to make cleaning up the jails a top priority.

headline: For Mets With Major Injuries, an Incentive and a Memento
abstract: The Mets’ rehabilitation team gives coins to players as tokens of appreciation for their hard work in getting through a program designed to get them healthy.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Matt Harvey went into the training room for his normal routine Monday morning, Dave Pearson, the Mets’ minor league rehabilitation coordinator, shook his hand, congratulated him for finishing the rehabilitation program and presented him with a small coin, a token of appreciation for his hard work.

headline: Rhode Island City May Lose Its Red Sox and, Mayor Says, Its Heart
abstract: The new owners of the Pawtucket Red Sox, a Class AAA team that has sent many future stars to the majors, said they intended to move the club to Providence.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Pawtucket Red Sox have been a minor league team as familiar to baseball fans as the Toledo Mud Hens, the Memphis Redbirds, the Durham Bulls or the Birmingham Barons. Playing at McCoy Stadium, which opened during World War II, the Rhode Island team, commonly known as the PawSox, has sent future stars such as Jim Rice, Carlton Fisk, Nomar Garciaparra, Roger Clemens, Mo Vaughn and Jacoby Ellsbury to the big club in Boston.

headline: Review: In ‘Big Love,’ Fleeing Tradition Becomes a Messy Escape
abstract: Tina Landau’s frenzied revival of Charles Mee’s 2000 play about sisters betrothed by contract to cousins is at the Pershing Square Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: They’re bouncing off the walls in Tina Landau’s frenzied revival of “Big Love,” Charles Mee’s 2000 play of things martial and marital according to Aeschylus. They’re also dangling from ropes and jumping on trampolines and rolling on the floor and fighting with tooth, claw, knives and slices of wedding cake. Well, as the song says, that’s amore.

headline: Review: ‘The Insurgents’ Stars Cassie Beck in a Lucy Thurber Drama
abstract: Rage infuses this Labyrinth Theater Company production, about a woman with a love of reading and her gun who returns to her impoverished New England home.
lead_paragraph: Beware, America! Sally Wright, a young woman who spends a lot of time with a shotgun in her hands, is having one whale of a nervous breakdown. It is, you might say, a breakdown as big as a whole country, and it’s been building for centuries.

headline: Shades of Grey

lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Elizabeth Long’s puzzle is certainly timely. With the Feb. 13 release of the movie version of E. L. James’s novel, “50 Shades of Grey,” you might think that the theme of today’s puzzle ventures into non-standards-friendly territory, but it doesn’t. Today, Ms. Long is really thinking about shades that belong to people with the surname Grey.

lead_paragraph: The Fox News host Bill O’Reilly on Monday stepped up his defense against reports that he embellished stories about his war reporting earlier in his career, while some former colleagues continued to say he had exaggerated his experiences.

headline: A Melancholy — and Danceable — New Song from Brooklyn’s San Fermin
abstract: “Emily” is the second single from “Jackrabbit,” the sophomore album from the indie-rock band, which has roots in classical composition.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based baroque-pop octet San Fermin doesn’t approach new songs the way most bands in its zip code do — by assembling in a rehearsal space and jamming until something worth recording emerges. Instead, its songwriter and composer Ellis Ludwig-Leone writes preliminary versions of all eight parts for each new song himself, and then delivers them to his bandmates in the basement below his apartment, where they gather to practice. “The worst thing that I ever do with the band is rehearse a new song with them,” he says with a laugh. “Suddenly it’s like, ‘Oh, my God, I hope this is good, because we’re going to have to play this hundreds of times,’ and it’s terrifying.”

headline: A Winter Salad Recipe from Andrew Carmellini, in Honor of Bon Appétit’s New Kitchen
abstract: The chef shares a dish from his Little Park restaurant, which will be served tonight at the magazine’s ad hoc dining club’s opening party at One World Trade.
lead_paragraph: Bon Appétit magazine’s BA Kitchen was already home to some of the most exclusive culinary events in the city, having opened its doors to celebrated chefs such as Carlo Mirarchi (Roberta’s), David Kinch (Manresa) and Inaki Aizpitarte (Le Chateaubriand). But now, with Condé Nast an official tenant of One World Trade Center, the ad hoc dining club will have a setting worthy of its food. “As good as a job as we did before, you can’t compare it to being on the 35th floor of the World Trade Center overlooking the city with a view of the Empire State,” says the Bon Appétit editor in chief Adam Rapoport, who co-hosts the new space’s opening party this evening. And he’s tapped the James Beard Award-winning chef Andrew Carmellini to christen the place. “Adam’s an old friend, and we’re in the neighborhood already,” explains Carmellini, whose fashionable restaurants (Little Park, the Dutch, Locanda Verde) are, like the new Condé Nast headquarters, a Lower Manhattan fixture. “We’re going to have a party.”

headline: Fading Christie Is Giving Bush Stronger Grip on G.O.P.’s Center
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After Chris Christie’s recent troubles, Jeb Bush, having already dispatched Mitt Romney, now seems well positioned to consolidate the Republican Party’s moderate wing.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s presidential ambitions are in a lot of trouble. First he squandered his initial strength in national polls — he holds 6 to 7 percent of the vote among Republican contenders, down from about 20 percent before the scandal involving the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: An Embedded Photographer Empowers the Poor
abstract: A Bangladeshi photographer who grew tired of seeing poverty portrayed in the usual ways had a brainstorm: He lived with his subjects and had them collaborate with him.
lead_paragraph: Scenes of poverty are inescapable in a country like Bangladesh, where Western media and charities use them to generate outrage, sympathy and — sometimes — donations. That bothered Shehab Uddin, a former newspaper photographer in Bangladesh who knew there was more to the story than downtrodden people victimized by poverty, not to mention photojournalists.

headline: More New Jobs Are in City Centers, While Employment Growth Shrinks in the Suburbs
abstract: A striking reversal in a trend that dominated the 20th century could have big implications for how people live and work in the decades ahead.
lead_paragraph: For decades, most Americans working in metropolitan areas have gone to work outside city centers – in suburban office parks, stores or plants, not downtown skyscrapers. But as people increasingly choose to live in cities instead of outside them, employers are following.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) A LITTLE ROMANCE (1979) Lauren (Diane Lane, above right), a 13-year-old American living in Paris with her stepfather (Arthur Hill) and mother (Sally Kellerman) — who is currently enamored of a pretentious filmmaker (George De Marco) — falls in love with Daniel (Thelonious Bernard, center). He is a French film buff, and together they arrange a rendezvous under the Bridge of Sighs in Venice with the help of an aging pickpocket (Laurence Olivier, left). “Lauren and Daniel are, I think, meant to be comic and appealing in their mixture of innocence and worldliness,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. Yet the film, directed by George Roy Hill, “recalls most vividly the arch manner in which the Our Gang comedies worked — by having their child actors ape not the behavior of children but of grown-ups.” Georges Delerue won an Oscar for best original score.

headline: The Hamilton Experience

lead_paragraph: Every once in a while a piece of art brilliantly captures the glory, costs and ordeals of public life. Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln” did that. And so does Lin-Manuel Miranda’s “Hamilton,” now playing at The Public Theater in New York.

headline: Scientology’s Chilling Effect
abstract: It’s impossible to tell the story of Scientology without getting into the issue of intimidation and why the church will never turn the other cheek.
lead_paragraph: When I was at Fortune magazine in the 1990s, one of my colleagues was a reporter named Richard Behar. He had a special lock on his door, and he wouldn’t even let the janitor in to empty his wastebasket. He used a secret phone, which he kept hidden in a desk drawer, so that calls made to sources couldn’t be traced back to him.

headline: Conspiracy Claims in Venezuela

lead_paragraph: Listening to embattled President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela ramble for hours about an international right-wing conspiracy to oust him, it’s clear that he would use any fabricated pretext to jail opposition leaders and crack down on dissent.

headline: When the Best Sex Is Extramarital
abstract: Many people struggle to integrate love and lust in a single relationship.
lead_paragraph: I received a voice mail from a 40-something woman, Cynthia, who requested a late-evening session because she worked long hours at her law firm. She said that I was one of the few therapists she had Googled who seemed to have the expertise to help her. In recent years I have noticed that when potential patients Google me, they discover my university faculty profile, where I list as a research interest the psychology of infidelity. They also find a YouTube clip of an interview with me from a documentary on infidelity. Thanks to Google I am getting more patients looking for someone they think of as an infidelity expert.

headline: Twin Pole-Vaulters Reach the Height of Alikeness

Its short, gravelly path is decorated with pennants, and it leads to a metal building about half the length of a football field. It is a hangar of sorts, or, more accurately, an indoor runway designed to produce short but spectacular flight.

headline: Words We Love Too Much

headline: Buffalo Embraces Winter’s Chill
abstract: From new rinks for skating and, yes, curling, and even ice biking, to ice festivals, the city is enjoying its cold weather.
lead_paragraph: At Buffalo’s newest outdoor rink, Canalside, teenage couples skated hand in hand, while a few stumbling toddlers nearly pulled their parents down. From a pedestrian bridge above the ice, spectators drank Flying Bison beer and bit into hot sandwiches from nearby food trucks. Stereos pumped Bob Marley, although the tropical beat belied the 20-degree temperatures. All around the double-sized rink, market vendors under striped awnings sold jewelry, hockey sticks and sweatshirts printed with “We Made Snow Famous” and “Buffalonians Never Say Die.”

There’s even a mash-up of traditional barbecue and Eastern European meats called boilbecue (not recommended by this meat-eater).

headline: An Outpouring of Love and Onesies
abstract: There is so much effort and love in all these packages; so much support in all the inquiries. It’s shocking, humbling and fantastic.
lead_paragraph: Possibly because I’m a guy, I never really thought too hard about giving people baby gifts. It was just something that did not often cross my mind. When one of my friends or family members said that they were having a baby, I might have halfheartedly found them something off their registry that wasn’t too cheap, or just sent them a gift card, figuring that they may need it for diapers. If I found myself cruising the baby aisles of Target, it tended to be so overwhelming that I found the first age-appropriate toy I could, whether I thought the child could use it or not. Let’s just say that gift receipts were key.

headline: 1890: Arizona’s Catastrophe
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A dam near Prescott, Ariz., burst causing major damage in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The disaster at the dam on the Hassayampa River, near Prescott, Arizona, is the most fearful catastrophe in the history of the territory. The valley for miles below the dam was swept clean. The first intimation of the appalling disaster was a sound resembling thunder, and at the same instant a perpendicular wall of water, fully 50 feet high, came rushing down the narrow valley. The valley widens above Wickenburg, and much of the town lies upon lowlands close to the course of the stream, and it was almost certain that the vast body of water which rushed out of the reservoir had carried away many houses at that place. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1890

headline: Review: Robert Christgau Reflects on His Career as a Rock Critic
abstract: A memoir by an authority on popular music who spent three decades with The Village Voice celebrates the women he knew but is less forthcoming about major figures in the early years of rock.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a cardinal rule of book criticism: Never blame someone for writing a book that’s different from the one you wanted him to write. But Robert Christgau’s memoir, “Going Into the City: Portrait of a Critic as a Young Man,” is so far from what I wanted that I can’t pretend I’m not crestfallen.

headline: 1965: State of Siege Is Declared
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A state of siege is declared in Guatemala as guerrillas clash with the government in 1965.
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia’s government suspended the constitution and decreed a state of siege throughout Guatemala today [Feb. 24] because of what was called an attempt to overthrow his regime. Col. Peralta said ‘‘several groups of armed men have attacked civilians and authorities as part of a widespread plan to spread terror.’’ The national radio broadcast the state of siege decree, saying that it would be in effect as long as necessary. There was no immediate information as to who the plotters Col. Peralta referred to might be. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1965
