headline: Why Does Cuomo Want to Shutter New York’s Doctor Report Card Site?
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to close the site nydoctorprofile.com.
lead_paragraph: You need a good doctor. You try the Internet. It is baffling. The rankings seem better suited to restaurants—three stars, four stars. Comments from patients can be nothing short of ridiculous. The physician’s picture is nice, but it all has the feel of advertising.

headline: Pebble Watch Goes Color on Kickstarter
abstract: Pebble, the maker of a popular smartwatch, went back to its roots when it unveiled a new color watch, called Pebble Time.
lead_paragraph: When Apple unveiled the Apple Watch last year, the company chose to do so in the same space it showed off the Macintosh computer 30 years earlier.

headline: In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Babies and Infants', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Hospitals', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: When a woman learned that her daughter was not her biological child, she discovered a new meaning of family.
lead_paragraph: GRASSE, France — When Sophie Serrano finally held her daughter, Manon, in her arms after the newborn, suffering from jaundice, had been placed under artificial light, she was taken aback by the baby’s full head of glossy hair.

headline: At Gucci, a Messy Exit for One Designer Opens an Unlikely Door for Another
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The luxury brand ousted its chief executive, Patrizio di Marco, and his partner, Frida Giannini, its creative director. Her replacement left the fashion world asking, “Who?”
lead_paragraph: Patrizio di Marco wasn’t about to go out quietly.

headline: Smutty Books for Smart People
abstract: Erotica isn’t new, but the people who buy it might be.
lead_paragraph: Trashy novels aren’t new, but thanks to a highbrow approach to Harlequin tropes, the people who buy them might be. This month, the online art magazine Triple Canopy is set to release “Headless,” a salacious murder mystery that reads like Dan Brown while name-checking Georges Bataille. Delving into full-on erotica, Badlands Unlimited — the book press established five years ago by the 2014 Hugo Boss Prize-winning artist Paul Chan — will publish a series of three novellas titled “We Love Lucy,” “How to Train Your Virgin” and “God, I Don’t Even Know Your Name,” the story of an artist who, fresh out of rehab, meets a Finnish curator through a dating app called Bangly. “Ideas about what sex is, and what pleasure can be, are changing, as they ought to,” says Chan. “We wanted to publish works that respond to this new spirit.”

headline: Pensions Haunt Christie 4 Years After Being ‘Fixed’
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Government Employees', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie offered a plan to address pension shortfalls that mirrored his plan from 2011, demonstrating how the problem has become an albatross for him.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Four years ago, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey signed bipartisan legislation to overhaul public employee pensions and declared he had “fixed” the problem that was crushing state and local governments across the country with enormous debts. He held up New Jersey as a model.

headline: Private Equity Leaders Focusing on Returning Money to Investors
abstract: At the SuperReturn International conference, executives said that they were returning capital to investors, rather than taking on risky investments.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Private equity firms are shying away from overly risky investments as the price of potential acquisitions remains high, a panel of industry leaders said on Tuesday.

headline: Shire, Maker of Binge-Eating Drug Vyvanse, First Marketed the Disease
abstract: The strategy for a new drug to treat binge-eating disorder reveals how a pharmaceutical company can influence the treatment of a medical condition.
lead_paragraph: The retired tennis player Monica Seles spent this month making the rounds of television talk shows, appearing on everything from “Good Morning America” to “The Dr. Oz Show” to share her personal struggle with binge eating.

headline: At London Fashion Week, the End of Austerity
abstract: Forget minimalism and restraint. Collections from Christopher Bailey, Christopher Kane and others loaded on the ideas, textures and transgression.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Austerity” may be the watchword of Prime Minister David Cameron’s administration and a theme of the Tories’ electoral platform (see recent campaign slogans: “A Britain living within its means,” “Let’s stay on the road to a stronger economy”). But British fashion designers, it seems, have not gotten the memo. Or they have, and disagree. (They would not be the only ones.)

headline: Court Clears Mubarak Official
abstract: The acquittal of Habib el-Adly is the latest in a string of rulings in favor of former officials jailed after the Arab Spring uprising.
lead_paragraph: A Cairo court on Tuesday acquitted former President Hosni Mubarak’s longtime interior minister of the last of several criminal charges that have kept him behind bars, opening a potential path to his release.

headline: Film Scripts by Harold Pinter to Become Radio Plays
abstract: Two never-produced Pinter screenplays, “Victory” and “The Dreaming Child,” will be broadcast as radio plays on the BBC.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two film scripts by Harold Pinter, never made into movies, have been adapted as radio plays by the BBC’s Radio 4. The first, “Victory,” based on a novel by Joseph Conrad, will be broadcast on Saturday; “The Dreaming Child,” based on a short story by Karen Blixen, of “Out of Africa” fame, will be aired on March 7. (According to the BBC 4 website, most programs can be accessed from anywhere in the world.)

headline: Whose Eyelash Is This?
abstract: Researchers have discovered that among mammals, the optimal eyelash length is one-third the width of the eye. Can you guess what animal these eyelashes belong to?
lead_paragraph: Researchers have discovered that among mammals, the optimal eyelash length is one-third the width of the eye. Can you guess what animal these eyelashes belong to?

headline: Nordic Cuisine Moves In to Long Island City
abstract: Leslie Nilsson, who owns Sage General Store and the caterer Bartleby & Sage, decided that her Queens neighborhood needed some higher-end dining.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: In Privacy Update, Reddit Tightens Restrictions on Nude Photos
abstract: Reddit changed its privacy policy to prohibit posting nude photos or videos of people engaged in sex acts without their prior consent to do have it posted.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Reddit, the huge online message board, has been known for its freewheeling stance on letting its users govern themselves. That has resulted in an outpouring of user-generated content — for better or, sometimes, for worse — that attracts nearly 160 million regular users to the site.

headline: In a New Memoir, the Famously Pithy ‘Dean of American Rock Critics’ Goes Long
abstract: Robert Christgau, best known for his 37 years of short-form rock music reviews for The Village Voice, releases “Going Into the City” today.
lead_paragraph: As the half-jokingly self-designated Dean of American Rock Critics, Robert Christgau has appeared to readers in bite-size chunks for well over four decades. Throughout his storied career — he is best known for his 35 years as a rock critic and editor at The Village Voice, where he founded the annual Pazz & Jop poll and perfected the letter-graded rock album capsule review — Christgau’s name has become synonymous with pith; the album reviews he has written regularly since 1969 rarely exceed 150 words. (Christgau says he must have cribbed the format from the longtime New York Daily News writer Kay Gardella, but claims to be “the inventor of the good capsule review.”) The memoir he releases today, then, represents new territory in more ways than one; and on the phone to discuss it, the famously cantankerous Christgau is in a good mood.

headline: The Uninsured Rate Is Falling
abstract: Nationwide, the uninsured rate dropped 3.5 percentage points last year.
lead_paragraph: Here’s more evidence that the Affordable Care Act is working.

headline: Yellen Says Fed Can Be ‘Patient’
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a congressional hearing that the Federal Reserve was in no hurry to raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a congressional hearing that the Federal Reserve was in no hurry to raise interest rates.

headline: Sony Names Thomas Rothman to Succeed Amy Pascal
abstract: Mr. Rothman, once chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, will become chairman of Sony’s motion picture group.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In another jolt to its old order, Sony on Tuesday said that Thomas E. Rothman would take over as chairman of its motion picture group, an appointment that risks new turmoil on Sony’s lot, but represents a Hollywood-style comeback for the executive.

headline: Jenny Lind, Taylor Swift, and Me
abstract: Superstars in the long run.
lead_paragraph: First things first: I am a big Arcade Fire fan, but I had nothing to do with Will Butler’s new song about the Greek debt crisis. I will, however, be on a panel at SXSW with the Butler brothers among others. And I’m having an economist’s version of fun by looking at some not entirely random aspects of the economics of music.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwing Shade
abstract: Senator Harry Reid during a news conference on Tuesday on funding for the Department of Homeland Security. He is recovering from an eye injury.

headline: Semilla
abstract: Vegetable-Forward Tasting Menus in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Vegetable-Forward Tasting Menus in Williamsburg, Brooklyn

headline: Restaurant Review: Semilla in Williamsburg, Brooklyn
abstract: The vegetable-focused tasting menu at a new restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, props one unique flavor against the next.
lead_paragraph: I came up with my nature-preserve theory of tasting menus while eating a cabbage sandwich at Semilla, a new restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, across the street from Jack’s Cancellation Shoes and Rachel’s Corset Discount Center (“specializing in hard to fit sizes”).

headline: Hollande Discusses Kidnapping in Yemen
abstract: President François Hollande of France confirmed that a Frenchwoman had been kidnapped in the Yemeni capital, Sana.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France confirmed that a Frenchwoman had been kidnapped in the Yemeni capital, Sana.

headline: Flames Rookie Embarks on a Welcome-Back Tour
abstract: Johnny Gaudreau, who grew up in New Jersey and led Boston College to a national title, has played a key role for the Calgary Flames, who are contending for a playoff spot.
lead_paragraph: When Kevin Hayes, now a Rangers forward, was a sophomore at Boston College in the summer of 2011, he was the tour guide for Johnny Gaudreau’s campus visit.

headline: Last Thoughts on a First Season
abstract: Before signing off, the Carpetbagger looks back on some highlights (like tea with Tilda Swinton) and the long slog that is awards season.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood Reporter just published a list of films that could prove Oscar worthy or baity in the coming year, but the Bagger can’t bring herself to read it. After three months of increasingly fevered speculation over who might win best picture, director and actor; of controversies over campaign tactics and stories told; of exhaustive poring over the tics and proclivities of 6,000 anonymous members of what remains an old boys’ club, it’s fair to say that anyone who pays much attention to this stuff, let alone covers it, deserves a break.

headline: U.S. Won’t File Charges in Trayvon Martin Killing
abstract: After George Zimmerman shot Mr. Martin in a gated Florida community, erupting a national furor, federal prosecutors began a civil rights investigation.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Justice Department on Tuesday closed its investigation into the shooting death three years ago of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed black teenager in a hoodie who became a symbol of racial profiling and the face of a protest movement, without filing hate-crime charges against the gunman, George Zimmerman.

headline: Russia Heightens Dispute With Ukraine Over Natural Gas
abstract: The head of Gazprom said that Ukraine would use up its prepaid allotment in days and would not be able to pay in time to keep the supply going.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As Russia warned Ukraine on Tuesday that it could run out of natural gas within two days because of a dispute over payments, Britain said it was sending military trainers to aid Ukrainian forces while European diplomats labored to patch up a flagging peace agreement in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Politician Urges Japan’s Premier to Stand by World War II Apologies
abstract: Yohei Kono, who as chief cabinet secretary issued a landmark apology to women enslaved in brothels, said Prime Minister Shinzo Abe must not yield to revisionist pressure.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese politician who issued a landmark official apology to women forced to work in wartime brothels urged Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Tuesday to stand by Japan’s previous apologies for the country’s wartime agression, and not pull Japan too far to the nationalist right.

headline: Putting a Price on Simon Kuznets’s Nobel in Economics
abstract: The medal awarded in 1971 to the economist who created standard measures of national income and economic growth is on the auction block.
lead_paragraph: James D. Watson’s sold for $4.76 million while the one owned by William Randal Cremer, a member of Parliament and labor activist, fetched just $17,000.

headline: A Three-Bedroom Villa in the Tuscan Countryside
abstract: Between Florence and Arezzo, the house, which has nearly five terraced acres and a pool, is on the market for $2,153,987.
lead_paragraph: Between Florence and Arezzo, the house, which has nearly five terraced acres and a pool, is on the market for $2,153,987.

headline: Comcast Reports Small Profit Gain in the Face of Regulatory Uncertainty
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The F.C.C. will vote this week on whether the Internet should be regulated like a utility, a move that could substantially change the industry.
lead_paragraph: Uncertainty regarding new strict rules governing the Internet as well as the prospects for its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable hung over Comcast on Tuesday, as the media conglomerate reported fourth-quarter profits that were up only slightly compared with the period last year.

headline: Redesigned 20-Euro Note Introduced by E.C.B.
abstract: The bill will enter general circulation in November and features a transparent hologram intended to defeat counterfeiters.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The euro may be one of the most embattled currencies on the planet, but at least it will soon feature some of the coolest technology.

headline: At the 2015 New Museum Triennial, A High-Tech Take on Nude Sculpture
abstract: The Brooklyn-based artist Frank Benson’s piece in the show is a hyper-realistic, life-size 3D print of the downtown transgender figure Juliana Huxtable.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based sculptor Frank Benson is one of the only hometown artists included in the New Museum’s thoroughly international 2015 Triennial exhibition. Another is the muse for his new piece, the emerging downtown legend Juliana Huxtable, who as an artist in her own right will also contribute a series of photographic self-portraits to the show. Benson’s piece, titled “Juliana” (2015), is a hyper-realistic, life-size 3D print of the transgender beauty, the third in a series of figurative sculptures whose previous subjects were a nude man and clothed woman. Draped horizontally on a plinth with fingers pinched in a Cleopatran gesture, Huxtable was originally meant to be immortalized in one of her signature looks before Benson, apprehensively, asked her to pose nude. “I was nervous of what she might think of that,” he says, “so I sent her this intense email full of historical references.” And though she is without clothing, her personal style is retained in the braids Benson painstakingly drew in a digital drafting program and the green makeup spray-painted onto the statue’s skin. The artwork stands as a token of how virtuosity and virtuality come together in the digital age. “I want the sculpture to exist as a completely finished entity inside the computer,” Benson says. “The 3D model is its ultimate version and the print is the real-world manifestation of it.”

headline: Hitachi Deal Is a Signal that Italy is Open for Deal-Making
abstract: Hitachi is a credible buyer paying a full price for Finmeccanica’s rail units.
lead_paragraph: Hitachi’s $2.2 billion deal signals that Italy is open for mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Filing Away Gmail Messages
keywords: ['Laptop Computers', 'Gift Cards and Certificates', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Tips on how to archive Gmail messages to tidy up your inbox, and solutions for when your laptop battery begins to fade.
lead_paragraph: Q. If I archive a Gmail message in my browser, what does that do and where does the message go?

headline: Little Sprout Grows Up
abstract: The restaurant Dirt Candy has more space and a renewed mission: to create delicious vegetarian food and change attitudes, too.
lead_paragraph: Back when the chef Amanda Cohen was running her restaurant, Dirt Candy, out of an East Village nook that felt only slightly more commodious than a gopher hole, she received a call from someone representing a famous man who wanted to eat her food.

headline: French Development Worker Is Kidnapped in Yemen
abstract: A Frenchwoman working on a World Bank project was abducted in Sana, the Yemeni capital, with Yemeni officials saying Al Qaeda was probably responsible.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Frenchwoman working on a World Bank project was kidnapped Tuesday with her Yemeni translator in front of a ministry office in Sana, according to security officials there and President François Hollande of France, who took the rare step of speaking publicly about the abductions.

headline: American Is Kidnapped in Nigeria
abstract: A ransom has been demanded, according to officials, who said the kidnapping was probably not the work of the Islamist militant group Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — An American missionary was kidnapped on Monday from a school in central Nigeria in an area prone to kidnappings for ransom, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Tough Talk From European Commissioner About U.S. Tech Companies
abstract: Günther Oettinger, the European Commission member in charge of the digital economy, said that if companies did not comply with European data rules, they “ultimately, perhaps, may be thrown out of the single market.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — American tech companies have long suspected that Europe is out to get them. They might be right.

headline: In Tepid Housing Market, Builders Cater to Desires of Well-Off
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Building (Construction)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Home sales of $1 million and higher account for only a small share of the overall market, but it is an increasingly reliable sweet spot for building companies.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Lisa Gray spent a few months searching for a home that would span the generations, one where her two sons would want to bring friends throughout their teenage years and that her aging parents could navigate with ease.

headline: Taylor Swift Donates $50,000 to New York City Schools
abstract: Ms. Swift, always eager to please, had promised in October to make a donation following the release of her anthem “Welcome to New York.”
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift knows how to ingratiate herself with skeptics.

headline: Vanity Clause
abstract: With the hysterical rise in men’s grooming practices, one writer asks: Are we plucking and primping ourselves into submission?
lead_paragraph: One writer argues that the rise of over-grooming may be neutering his generation of men.

headline: McConnell Proposes Two-Vote Solution to Break Homeland Security Impasse
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: A day of brinkmanship could yield a short-term spending bill to avert a department shutdown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, on Tuesday offered a path to avert a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security, saying he would allow a vote on a bill solely to fund the agency, followed by a second vote on legislation that would halt President Obama’s 2014 executive actions on immigration.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Will Get Broadway Stage
abstract: The creator and the producers of the red-hot musical have opted not to move it to Broadway until summer. It will not compete in the 2015 Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: In a rarity for New York theater, the artists behind the red-hot musical “Hamilton” won out on Tuesday over commercial concerns about ticket sales and Tony Awards that usually carry the day.

headline: Federal Officials Return Tiepolo Painting and Etruscan Bronze to Italy
abstract: A Tiepolo painting and an Etruscan bronze, stolen decades ago in Italy, were returned to that country on Tuesday by United States officials who seized them before they could be sold at auction.
lead_paragraph: Federal law enforcement authorities in New York announced Tuesday that they had returned to Italy two pieces of that country’s cultural heritage stolen decades ago before being brought to the United States: a painting attributed to the 18th-century artist Giambattista Tiepolo and an ancient Etruscan bronze statuette of Herakles.

headline: Goldman Seeks to Raise Fund to Buy Energy Sector Debt
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Private Equity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Goldman Sachs joins other Wall Street firms in seeking to capitalize on the turmoil in the energy sector.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street money helped fuel the North American energy boom in recent years. Now that oil prices have collapsed, Wall Street is again looking for ways to profit.

headline: Czech Gunman Kills 8 People and Then Himself at Restaurant
abstract: The gunman, who was described by officials as mentally unstable, opened fire inside the restaurant in the town of Uhersky Brod, in the southeastern region of the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — A 62-year-old resident of the southeastern Czech town of Uhersky Brod burst into a restaurant near his home on Tuesday and began shooting, killing eight people in the lunchtime crowd before turning his gun on himself.

headline: Obama Vetoes Bill Pushing Pipeline Approval
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Vetoes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming']
abstract: President Obama’s rejection of a bill authorizing the Keystone XL oil pipeline swept aside one of the first major challenges to his authority by the new Republican Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday rejected an attempt by lawmakers to force his hand on the Keystone XL oil pipeline, using his veto pen to sweep aside one of the first major challenges to his authority by the new Republican Congress.

headline: Annotated Version of Hitler’s ‘Mein Kampf’ to Be Published Next Year
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The Institute for Contemporary History, which studies Nazism, will add more than 1,000 pages of critical commentary to the book in its new version.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Researchers are on track to finish roughly 4,000 annotations and historical notes to accompany a new German-language edition of Hitler’s manifesto, “Mein Kampf,” to be published in January 2016, after the existing copyright expires.

lead_paragraph: The head of the United Nations panel on climate science resigned on Tuesday after allegations of sexual harassment were filed against him in India, where he lives and works.

headline: Persistence Pays Off in Reporting on Jihadi
abstract: The struggles of a Times video journalist, Mona El-Naggar, to find and interview the family and friends of an Egyptian man who joined the Islamic State in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Islam Yaken slipped away from his middle-class home in Egypt to join the Islamic State in Syria. His family and close friends have not seen him since, except in propaganda and training videos.

abstract: In his first rejection of major legislation, President Obama vetoed a bill to approve construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: — President Obama, in a letter announcing his veto of legislation to approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: Tigers Are Built for the World Series and Hoping to Break Through
abstract: Detroit has won four consecutive American League Central titles, and it won the A.L. pennant in 2006, but October heartbreak haunts the team and its fans.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Three teams in recent seasons have hoarded most of the World Series championships. The Detroit Tigers helped each of them.

headline: ‘A Different Kind of Shocking’
abstract: A museum in Mexico City has cancelled an exhibition of works by the Austrian artist Hermann Nitsch.
lead_paragraph: A museum in Mexico City has cancelled an exhibition of works by the Austrian artist Hermann Nitsch.

headline: A City Braces for Its Ballpark to Go the Way of Its Mills
abstract: By announcing they intended to abandon Pawtucket, R.I., the new owners of the Red Sox’ Class AAA team reminded fans that beyond baseball’s innate poetry, it is a cold business.
lead_paragraph: The icy reminder of a baseball truth has blown down from New England, down from a Rhode Island city forever described as gritty, or struggling, or, more politely, challenged. No doubt you have seen signs for this brown-brick metropolis along the interstate, on your way to someplace else: Pawtucket, population 71,000.

headline: ESPN Suspends Keith Olbermann for Remarks on Penn State
abstract: Olbermann will not host his ESPN2 program for the rest of the week as punishment for remarks he made on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Keith Olbermann was suspended Tuesday from hosting his ESPN2 program for the rest of the week for churlish remarks he made about Penn State on Twitter.

headline: Onetime Mystery Informant in Galleon Insider Trading Case Gets No Jail Time
abstract: Thomas Hardin, who worked for the hedge fund Lanexa Management, got some of his tips from the same woman who gave information to Galleon’s founder.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, he was the mystery man in Wall Street’s clubby hedge fund community: Tipper X, a confidential informant working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who wore a wire and made dozens of taped calls to help the government build a major insider trading case.

headline: Mark Duplass On Cassavetes, Kale Smoothies and His Never-Fail Stevie Nicks Pick-Me-Up
abstract: The writer, director and actor, who stars in HBO’s “Togetherness” and in the film “The Lazarus Effect,” which opens this weekend, shares a diverse selection of influences with T.
lead_paragraph: The writer, director and actor, who stars in HBO’s “Togetherness” and in the film “The Lazarus Effect,” which opens this weekend, shares a diverse selection of influences with T.

headline: How Loopholes Turned Dish Network Into a ‘Very Small Business’
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Small Business', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Through sleight of hand and aggressive use of partners, Dish created an unfair advantage in its successful bid for wireless spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Charles W. Ergen, the billionaire who controls the satellite TV provider Dish Network, and his company are about to make a cool $3.25 billion — courtesy of the American taxpayer.

headline: HP Earnings Decline 4%, and Outlook Is Lowered
abstract: HP’s plan to split itself into two separate companies remains on track, Meg Whitman, the chief executive, said in announcing the earnings.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Meg Whitman, Hewlett-Packard‘s chief executive, says she thinks her company did almost everything well in its most recent fiscal quarter. Except make money.

headline: Review: ‘Farewell to Hollywood,’ the Last Years of a Budding Filmmaker
abstract: This documentary, co-directed by Regina Nicholson, who died of cancer at 19 in 2012, is moving yet queasily unsettling.
lead_paragraph: Rendering a verdict on the cinematic merits of “Farewell to Hollywood” seems beside the point or even inappropriate; the movie’s key attribute is that it exists. The co-director, Regina Nicholson, died of cancer at 19 in 2012. She is shown expressing a wish that the documentary about this period in her life “survive and be fantastic.”

headline: Grandmaster Sachs
abstract: With his handcrafted, fully functioning boomboxes, the artist Tom Sachs celebrates a bygone analog era, and reflects on what’s been lost now that all the world’s music can reside in our pockets.
lead_paragraph: With his handcrafted, fully functioning boomboxes, the artist Tom Sachs celebrates a bygone analog era, and reflects on what’s been lost now that all the world’s music can reside in our pockets.

headline: Critic’s Notebook: New York City Ballet Wraps Up a Memorable Winter Season
abstract: The many highs of the six-week term that ends on March 1 have included performances of central classics by George Balanchine, along with rousing modern choreography.
lead_paragraph: Balletomanes know how druglike their special brand of dance can be. Energy and beauty flow from the spectacle onstage; in the audience, perceptions of time, space and human potential feel profoundly changed. The need to follow performances becomes akin to addiction; and the end of a season brings withdrawal symptoms.

headline: Vial of Winston Churchill’s Blood to Be Sold at Auction
abstract: The sample was collected in 1962 at Middlesex Hospital in London, where Churchill was being treated for a hip injury.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Almost anything linked to Winston Churchill can be collectible, right down to the butts of his cigars. But it is hard to imagine an artifact rarer or more intimate than the one scheduled to be auctioned on March 12: a vial of his blood.

headline: Male Statuary, Illustrated
abstract: A series of paintings by Leanne Shapton based on the book ‘The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form.’
lead_paragraph: A series of paintings by Leanne Shapton based on the book ‘The Nude: A Study in Ideal Form.’

headline: Review: In Pam Tanowitz’s ‘Broken Story,’ Wit Comes Full Circle
abstract: “Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy),” which had its premiere at the Guggenheim Museum, tweaks dance traditions of romantic fulfillment.
lead_paragraph: In several ways, Pam Tanowitz’s “Broken Story (wherein there is no ecstasy)” is accurately titled. The parenthetical phrase might mislead, though. The work, which had its premiere at the Guggenheim Museum on Sunday as part of the Works & Process series, does have droll fun tweaking dance traditions of romantic fulfillment. But Ms. Tanowitz and her collaborators maintain such a high level of imagination that what is fragmented by design can be experienced as a satisfying, organic whole. Ecstatic is a good word for how it made me feel.

headline: Review: In ‘Addicted to the Spotlight,’ Mark Nadler Is All Hot-Wired Energy
abstract: The entertainer wants nothing less than to knock your socks off and break your heart at the same time in his new cabaret show at 54 Below in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mark Nadler’s new cabaret show, “Addicted to the Spotlight” at 54 Below, is a ferocious but good-natured retort to those critics (including this one) who complain that once he is on the stage, it is almost impossible to drag him off. He is a proud throwback to those voracious song-and-dance men from the vaudeville era whom you might have thought had gone the way of the dodo. But here he is. In their maniacal quest to shoot the moon, his closest equivalents are probably Liza Minnelli and Mandy Patinkin, who both also have sawdust in their blood.

headline: Review: ‘Wild Canaries’: Love, Death and Suspicious Minds
abstract: In this caper by Lawrence Michael Levine, a young Brooklyn couple suspect the worst after a neighbor is found dead.
lead_paragraph: A bickering young couple suspect the worst when an elderly neighbor named Sylvia dies in Lawrence Michael Levine’s Brooklyn comedy, “Wild Canaries.” Setting this pair of squirrelly, suspicious minds loose on matters of love and death, Mr. Levine spins a caper that wins you over more through tenacity than through originality.

headline: In Champions League, Barcelona Is a Familiar Thorn in Manchester City’s Side
abstract: Eliminated by Barcelona last year, City fared no better in a first-leg game this time as Luis Suárez scored two goals.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Luis Suárez ran in every direction. He slid at midfielders’ heels. He banged into defenders. Once, when the opposing goalkeeper was trying to throw the ball to a teammate, Suárez even jumped up in front of him, hand in the air, as though he might try for a basketball-style blocked shot.

headline: Study That Paid Patients to Take H.I.V. Drugs Fails
abstract: Scientists at an AIDS conference in Seattle said paying patients as much as $280 a year to take AIDS-prevention drugs failed to significantly improve adherence or infection rates.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A major study testing whether Americans would take their H.I.V. drugs every day if they were paid to do so has essentially failed, the scientists running it announced Tuesday at an AIDS conference here.

headline: A Conversation with Stuart M. Saft
abstract: Mr. Saft is a partner of the law firm Holland & Knight and the chairman of its New York Real Estate Practice Group.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Saft, 68, is a partner of the law firm Holland & Knight and the chairman of its New York Real Estate Practice Group. He also serves as the chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. Before joining Holland & Knight in 2012, Mr. Saft was head of the global real estate practice at the now-defunct Dewey & LeBoeuf.

headline: The “Is Obama Christian?” Question
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Was it appropriate to expect Scott Walker to know or say whether the president is a Christian?
lead_paragraph: Thrice in the past few weeks, Scott Walker, the Wisconsin governor and presumptive candidate for president, has delivered a non-answer to a prodding question: First on whether he believes in evolution, second on whether he would disassociate himself from Rudy Giuliani’s (since half-retracted) impugning of President Obama’s patriotism, and then finally on whether he believes the president is a Christian.

lead_paragraph: The Bergen County borough has diverse housing stock, high-ranking schools and access to two train lines that connect to New York City.

headline: Review: ‘Churchill,’ a One-Man Show at New World Stages
abstract: Ronald Keaton portrays Winston Churchill in reflecting on that former British prime minister’s anecdote-rich life.
lead_paragraph: For lovers of British history onstage, this is a season bristling with enticements: Elizabeth II, in the form of Helen Mirren, holding court in “The Audience”; Thomas Cromwell and Anne Boleyn, soon to follow in “Wolf Hall”; and over at New World Stages, a chatty Winston Churchill, dabbing at oils at his easel and expounding on an action-packed career.

headline: Museo Jumex Cancels a Hermann Nitsch Show
abstract: In abandoning a controversial exhibition, this institution in Mexico City may have hurt its credibility in the art world.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hermann Nitsch is hardly a stranger to controversy. This Austrian artist, whose notorious “actions” involve animal viscera and “crucified” participants bathed in blood, was arrested three times as a young man and expelled from Italy for disemboweling a sheep during a performance. But in all these years, Mr. Nitsch, 76, said in an interview, he has “never” had an institution cancel an exhibition of his work.

headline: Review: Diabolical Diabelli at Rutgers, With New Variations
abstract: The Piano Studio of the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers, in a program called “The Unknown Diabelli Variations,” strayed far from the beaten path.
lead_paragraph: The Piano Studio of the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers pulled off a neat trick last week. Its program at Weill Recital Hall, “The Unknown Diabelli Variations,” strayed far from the beaten path and, most notably, avoided Beethoven, the composer of the actual work called “Diabelli Variations.” Yet Beethoven’s ghost was a constant presence, looming over the proceedings with, undoubtedly, a wry smirk.

headline: Ted Strickland to Seek to Unseat Senator Rob Portman in Ohio

abstract: Writing labor and environmental standards into international trade agreements has had little effect. Perhaps real change should start at home.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Kantor has a vivid memory of August 1993. The North American Free Trade Agreement was in trouble. Though the agreement had been signed the year before, during the administration of George H.W. Bush, the newly elected Bill Clinton had promised to attach side deals to the pact to guarantee minimum labor and environmental standards.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Next week, the Supreme Court hears arguments in a case that could upend Obamacare insurance coverage for millions of people. Tuesday, the Secretary of Health and Human Services said there was little the administration could do to limit the impact of such a ruling.

headline: Length of Lashes Keeps Eyes From Drying, Study Finds
abstract: Researchers found that across a wide variety of mammals, eyelashes are always about one-third as long as the eye is wide, the ideal length for diverting airflow around the eye and reducing evaporation.
lead_paragraph: Long and luxurious eyelashes have been in fashion at least since Cleopatra. But scientists now suggest that their real function is to help protect eyes from drying out.

headline: Mystery Surrounds a Tunnel in Toronto
abstract: The structure was built in dense woods near a tennis stadium intended for use during the Pan American Games this summer, the police said, and it did not reach a specific destination.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — It was a baffling discovery: a hand-dug tunnel just over 33 feet long, tall enough for an adult to stand inside, fed with electricity, drained by a water pump and expertly reinforced with lumber and plywood. It started in dense woods near a tennis stadium — and it did not lead anywhere.

lead_paragraph: To judge from the public frenzy it aroused, the “Z” might well have stood for “Zowie!”

lead_paragraph: WARSAW — A decade ago, Rakhat Aliyev was one of the most powerful and feared men in Kazakhstan, the son-in-law of the country’s authoritarian leader with a raft of important government posts, a private security force and a network of lucrative businesses and shady connections.

headline: New Counsel for Deutsche Bank Is Used to U.S. Inquiries
abstract: Steven F. Reich will be on the front line of federal investigations into one of Wall Street’s biggest banks and Germany’s largest financial institution.
lead_paragraph: In Bill Clinton’s White House, Steven F. Reich fended off federal prosecutors and congressional committees. At the Obama Justice Department, he responded to investigations of the government’s botched gunrunning crackdown, known as Operation Fast and Furious. And as a defense lawyer at Akin Gump, according to his firm biography, he was “particularly adept at helping clients navigate crises.”

headline: Bruce Sinofsky, Lauded Documentary Filmmaker, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Sinofsky and his collaborator Joe Berlinger examined sensational crimes in “Brother’s Keeper” and the “Paradise Lost” trilogy, about the West Memphis Three, and profiled the heavy metal band Metallica.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Sinofsky, a filmmaker whose critically lauded documentaries tracked a notorious East Arkansas murder case and portrayed the heavy metal band Metallica as a dysfunctional family, died on Saturday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 58.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — DreamWorks Animation reported a bigger-than-expected $263 million quarterly loss on Tuesday because of a big-screen dud, “The Penguins of Madagascar,” and a previously announced restructuring.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A police officer shot and killed a teenage boy during an antigovernment protest in the restive Venezuelan city of San Cristóbal on Tuesday, officials said, as tensions rose over a struggling economy and the recent arrest of a prominent opposition politician.

headline: Support for V.A. Chief Who Lied About Serving in Special Forces
abstract: Robert A. McDonald, the Veterans Affairs secretary, issued a public apology, and the administration, lawmakers and veterans groups backed him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert A. McDonald, the secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department, pledged Tuesday to “do better” and brushed aside any suggestion that he would resign after he apologized publicly for having falsely claimed to have served in the Special Forces.

headline: Robert O. Marshall Dies at 75; Convicted in ‘Blind Faith’ Murder-for-Hire Case
abstract: Mr. Marshall was serving a life sentence in the 1984 contract murder of his wife, a case that became the subject of Joe McGinniss’s book “Blind Faith.”
lead_paragraph: Robert O. Marshall, a life insurance salesman whose conviction and almost 30-year imprisonment for the contract killing of his wife inspired the Joe McGinniss book “Blind Faith” and a television movie of the same name, died in prison on Saturday in Bridgeton, N.J., while awaiting a parole hearing. He was 75.

keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Organized Labor', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Company Reports', 'Ports']
abstract: The department store and home improvement chains, which both reported solid fourth-quarter earnings, have yet to see the full impact of shipping delays that hit inventory levels during a West Coast ports dispute.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s and Home Depot said on Tuesday that they were still trying to untangle gridlocked shipments at West Coast ports, a logistics nightmare that has affected merchants across the country.

headline: Donald R. Keough, Who Led Coca-Cola Through New Coke Debacle, Dies at 88
abstract: When the company introduced the sweeter New Coke, it did not anticipate the “depth of feeling” for the original taste, Mr. Keough said in announcing a return to the regular formula.
lead_paragraph: Donald R. Keough, who led Coca-Cola through the disastrous introduction of New Coke in 1985 and the return of the original formula just 10 weeks later, died on Tuesday in Atlanta, his family said. He was 88.

headline: Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez Takes Field Alongside Heir at Third Base
abstract: After Rodriguez and Chase Headley worked out side by side, Manager Joe Girardi said he would ask Rodriguez to move around the infield again, this time to first base.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Alex Rodriguez and Chase Headley, the player whom the Yankees re-signed to remain Rodriguez’s replacement at third base, worked out side by side on Tuesday, taking ground balls, hitting in the batting cage and running easy sprints in the outfield.

abstract: In a hurried roll call as protesters chanted in opposition, legislators voted to advance to the full Senate a bill that would bar unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — More than eight hours of testimony on a so-called right-to-work bill ended abruptly here Tuesday night after the Republican committee chairman cited a “credible threat” to disrupt the vote. In a hurried, chaotic roll call as protesters chanted in opposition, legislators voted to advance the bill to the full Senate.

abstract: How will a $655.5 million verdict against the Palestinian Authority and the P.L.O. in six terror attacks affect their future?

headline: Davis Love III Is Again Chosen to Lead U.S. at Ryder Cup
abstract: Love, the 2012 captain, will use a selection process slightly different from last year’s, with changes that seemed a reaction to the fact that two players on a roll were left off last year’s team.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Davis Love III was on the United States Ryder Cup task force that picked a captain — Love — for the 2016 competition. But it was not a case in which the veteran was asked for a list of candidates and suggested he was the best person for the job.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Is Set to Ease Rules on Circumcision Ritual

lead_paragraph: The administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, under pressure from ultra-Orthodox rabbis, is set to ease New York City’s regulations on a controversial circumcision ritual that has been linked to herpes infections in infants.

headline: Syria Dropped ‘Barrel Bombs’ Despite Ban, Report Says
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']

lead_paragraph: Human Rights Watch said Tuesday that the Syrian government had dropped so-called barrel bombs on hundreds of sites in rebel-held towns and cities in the past year, flouting a United Nations Security Council measure.

headline: Rule Change Sought by Tech Firms Will Allow Some Spouses of Immigrants to Work
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: The new rule, which mainly affects workers from some Asian countries who have applied for permanent resident green cards, added to a debate over President Obama’s executive actions.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Tuesday that it will give work permits to some spouses of highly skilled immigrants who are in the United States on temporary visas, a change long sought by technology companies and other businesses that is part of a series of controversial executive actions by the president.

headline: With Eagles Sighted, a Proposal Takes Flight
abstract: More than once, Andy Partridge set his mind to proposing to his childhood friend Mandy Hicks, but the moment was always ruined by other couples — until the pair went on an eagle watch in Upper Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: At midlife, Mandy Hicks and Andy Partridge, childhood friends from North Yorkshire, England, struck up a romance. To celebrate her 52nd birthday last week, they made their first visit to New York, in time for some of the coldest weather on record.

headline: Japan: Leak Is Disclosed at Nuclear Plant
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: The operator of the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant said Tuesday that it had neglected to stop a leak of radioactive water into the Pacific Ocean since last May.
lead_paragraph: The operator of the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant said Tuesday that it had neglected to stop a leak of radioactive water into the Pacific Ocean since last May. The operator, Tokyo Electric Power Co., said it had first detected the flow of contaminated rainwater nine months ago, but did not explain why it had been so slow in responding. The company, known as Tepco, said it would place sandbags to block the leak of water, which it said was too small to change radiation levels in the plant’s man-made harbor. A triple meltdown occurred at the plant after a huge earthquake and tsunami four years ago.

headline: Midwest Capitals
abstract: Michael Shteyman returns with an elegant and deceptively simple theme design.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — One of the things that constructors wrestle with when building a puzzle is where to place the theme in the grid without shooting themselves in the cruciverbal foot.

headline: Bratton Says New York Police Officers Must Fight Bias
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: William J. Bratton, the city’s police commissioner, delivered a broad commentary on the role of the police in fostering old divisions that still sow distrust in minority communities.
lead_paragraph: The New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton, on Tuesday delivered a broad commentary on the country’s troubled history of race relations and the role of the police in fostering old divisions that still sow distrust in minority communities.

headline: Review: ‘The World of Extreme Happiness,’ About China and Gender
abstract: This drama’s heroine seeks a better life in the big city, but frustration and compromise enter the picture.
lead_paragraph: Sunny, the heroine of “The World of Extreme Happiness,” may at times have a cheerful disposition, but there’s a bitter irony in this beleaguered young woman charting an odyssey through contemporary China while carrying the burden of such a hopeful name. Not a lot of sunlight filters down through the smog-clogged skies to brighten her hard life.

headline: Review: Jennifer Haley’s ‘The Nether’ Explores the Dark Side of the Web
abstract: In this futuristic drama, visitors to an online destination act out their depraved fantasies.
lead_paragraph: It’s a gray, gray tomorrow that greets us in “The Nether,” Jennifer Haley’s very cunning and equally creepy new play about alternative lives in a future around the corner. When first seen, Laura Jellinek’s fantastical set for this satisfyingly disturbing production, which opened on Tuesday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater, shows a world that has been leached of color.

headline: Man Convicted in 1990 Killing Recounts a Forced Confession
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Confessions', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Assaults']
abstract: Johnny Hincapie tearfully recalled the day he told a police detective he had nothing to do with the stabbing death of a tourist on a Manhattan subway platform.
lead_paragraph: The detective was in his T-shirt, smoking a cigarette, in an upstairs room in the Midtown North station house. There was a table in the corner of the room and two chairs.

headline: Hillary Clinton Sketches Campaign Messages in Silicon Valley
abstract: Preparing for a possible presidential run, Hillary Rodham Clinton called for equal pay for women, a higher minimum wage and more bipartisanship.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — After weeks of relative quiet as she assembles a presidential campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday provided the most detailed preview yet of the sort of economic and bipartisan message that her candidacy could be expected to deliver.

headline: Minimum Wage for New York City’s Tipped Workers Will Increase to $7.50
abstract: New York State’s acting labor commissioner, with support from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, ordered the raise to go into effect at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Continuing to push for higher wages for the state’s lowest-paid workers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that all of the waiters, waitresses and others who work for tips in New York City will soon get a raise of their minimum wage to $7.50 an hour.

headline: In Greek Crisis, Rare Moment of Consensus
abstract: Conflict between a new generation of populist Greek leaders and their European creditors was put aside as an agreement was reached to extend the country’s bailout program four months.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For the past month, as Greece once again emerged as a threat to the global economy, a new generation of populist Greek leaders vowed to shatter Europe’s austerity politics in what threatened to become an unbridgeable divide with the European establishment, especially Germany. There were insults, predictions of calamity and accusations of double-dealing and deceit.

headline: ‘American Sniper’ Jury Finds Chris Kyle’s Killer Guilty of Murder
abstract: Eddie Ray Routh, the veteran who killed Chris Kyle, the former Navy SEAL marksman who inspired the movie “American Sniper,” was sentenced to life in prison after a jury rejected his claims that he was legally insane at the time.
lead_paragraph: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — Eddie Ray Routh, the mentally disturbed veteran who killed Chris Kyle, the former Navy SEAL marksman who inspired the movie “American Sniper,” was sentenced Tuesday to life in prison after a jury here found him guilty of murder, rejecting his claims that he was legally insane at the time.

headline: Mets’ Lucas Duda Discovers Dangers of Training Too Hard
abstract: Duda, a first baseman, developed a sore muscle in his chest after spending months practicing his swing. He will not swing a bat for at least a few more days.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Lucas Duda was coming off the season of his life. He had established himself as a bona fide slugger in 2014, hitting 30 home runs. He had settled into a groove with his swing. His body, feet and hands were moving in unison.

headline: $60 Million Error Is Found in Connecticut Governor’s Budget Proposal
abstract: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy had already presented a budget to the state legislature before the accounting error was discovered by the Office of Fiscal Analysis.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after unveiling his spending plan to lawmakers, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut learned that because of an accounting error, his budget had exceeded the state’s spending limit by $60 million.

lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors presented the testimony of British intelligence officers as some of the most important evidence in the trial of Abid Naseer in Brooklyn, saying it was “essential” to proving the terrorism charges and insisting that the officers be allowed to wear disguises and that their faces be blurred by courtroom artists.

Last summer, they lived and trained together in Boston. When Gaudreau arrived in New York on Monday, they watched the Eagles defeat Harvard, 3-2, in overtime in the Beanpot consolation game, then went out to dinner.

headline: Gramercy Tavern’s Charitable Arctic Char Appetizer

lead_paragraph: Tomorrow evening, some of New York’s best chefs will gather for the second annual Chefs for Kids’ Cancer fundraiser, hosted by Cookies for Kids’ Cancer to raise money and awareness for the leading cause of death among American children. A roster of culinary heavyweights curated by Dan Kluger (formerly of ABC Kitchen) and Jonathan Benno (Lincoln Ristorante), and pastry chefs handpicked by Christina Tosi (Momofuku Milk Bar), will serve dinner at the sold-out event, which will also feature a live auction put on by Christie’s. One participating chef, the James Beard Award-winner Michael Anthony of Gramercy Tavern (and, soon, Untitled at the Whitney), shared with T a recipe he’ll be serving tonight: spice-cured arctic char with black radish, dill and rye, from the Gramercy Tavern menu.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE LAST ORANGUTAN EDEN The orangutan, considered Asia’s most intelligent ape, once roamed in droves across the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Java. But today fewer than 7,000 Sumatran orangutans exist in the wild, their population rapidly declining because of the deforestation of land for vast palm oil plantations. In this “Nature” episode, the ecologist Chris Morgan accompanies researchers into a protected peat swamp forest to study the culture and behavior of orangutans. He also visits a research center where orphaned orangutans are taught the skills — like using tools, sharing food and foraging together — they need before being released back into the wild.

keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Recent talks offer hope that the protracted nuclear threat from Iran can be resolved peacefully.

After months of little apparent progress, the quickening pace of talks suggests that negotiators in Geneva might be able to complete a framework by the end of March, with a final accord reached at the end of June. This isn’t certain, but it offers hope that the protracted nuclear threat from Iran can be resolved peacefully.

Not much new there, or surprising.

headline: When the System Fails
abstract: In the overwhelming apparatus that medicine has become, sometimes the patient gets lost. So does the doctor.
lead_paragraph: I PURCHASED a purple “My Little Pony” at Walmart. I told myself it was to bring a brief smile to a sad little girl’s face. In reality, it was for me. In the overwhelming apparatus that medicine has become, sometimes the patient gets lost. So does the doctor. As the major safety net hospital in our region, my own hospital is arguably better equipped than most to effectively handle the human side of medical care. But even the most experienced institutions face an increasingly uphill battle against the systemic shortfalls of American medicine.

headline: My Saga, Part 1
abstract: The Norwegian author of the six-part autobiographical novel “My Struggle” follows the trail of the first Europeans to set foot in North America. First of two parts.
lead_paragraph: I lost my driver’s license over a year ago. I lose stuff all the time. Credit cards, passports, car keys, cash, books, bags, laptops. It doesn’t worry me, they usually turn up eventually. The last time I was in New York, I left my backpack in a taxi. I had taken three of my kids with me, so I was a little distracted when we got out. All of our passports were in the backpack, as well as my laptop, where everything I have written in the last 20 years is stored. I never talk to taxi drivers, but this one had been so friendly that I ended up questioning him a little. At a red light he even took out a photograph of his children, which he showed me. When we got back to the hotel that afternoon, I asked the receptionist what we could do. He just shook his head and said I could forget about seeing my backpack again. This is New York, he said. But the driver was from Nepal, I objected. And he had two kids. I’m sorry, the receptionist said, I don’t think that will help much. But of course you can report it missing. At that point the doorman came over, he had overheard our conversation and said he knew some Nepalis, should he call them for me? So he did, and I met them outside the hotel a while later. Based on my description, they identified the driver, and the next morning the backpack was waiting for me at the reception desk.

headline: What’s Really at Stake in Ellen Pao’s Kleiner Perkins Lawsuit
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: If you want to fix Silicon Valley’s culture of sexism, venture-capital firms might be the best place to start.
lead_paragraph: It is telling that the highest-profile lawsuit of the moment in Silicon Valley isn’t about intellectual property or antitrust violations, but about sex discrimination. This week, a jury in San Francisco is hearing arguments in Ellen Pao’s suit against her former employer, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, one of the most prominent venture-capital firms in the tech industry. At the heart of the case is Pao’s claim that a married colleague at Kleiner Perkins pressured her into an affair and then, after she ended the relationship, retaliated by excluding her from meetings and email discussions, which affected her work performance.

headline: Early Memo Urged Moscow to Annex Crimea, Report Says
abstract: The Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta said that a memo, possibly from an oligarch, warned that Moscow should act quickly to protect interests in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A memo drafted in the weeks leading up to the collapse of the Ukrainian government last year recommended that Russia take advantage of the chaos next door to annex Crimea and a large portion of southeastern Ukraine, a Russian newspaper reported on Wednesday, printing what it said was a document that had been presented to the presidential administration.

And he vetoed legislation that would have stripped him of his authority to decide the fate of the much-debated Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: Michael Schur on the ‘Parks and Recreation’ Series Finale
abstract: The sitcom’s showrunner talks about that political cameo and whether or not Leslie made it to higher office.
lead_paragraph: Despite her negative-sounding surname, Leslie Knope (Amy Poehler) always stood out as one of TV’s most positive and upbeat characters, and this Pawnee, Ind., civil servant’s can-do spirit radiated throughout the sunny series finale of “Parks and Recreation.” Employing a flash-forward structure, the NBC sitcom’s send-off gave each of its characters a happy ending. For example, Leslie was elected governor of Indiana twice, with her beloved husband, Ben (Adam Scott), by her side. The show also implied that one of them ultimately reached even higher office.

headline: Bear Extraordinaire
abstract: A picture book tells the story of the real bear who inspired A. A. Milne’s Winnie-the-Pooh.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of human-animal comradeship, there is nothing quite like the tale of a brown bear cub named Winnipeg, Winnie for short, the inspiration behind A. A. Milne’s “Winnie-the-Pooh.” She was bought for $20 by a Canadian soldier at the outset of World War I, sailed with him to England, then ended up living out her years at the London Zoo. There, a little boy named Christopher Robin took a shine to her, renaming his own stuffed bear Winnie and prompting his father to write the classic children’s books. As a new picture book by Sally M. Walker plays it, this is a “gee-whiz” kind of story, with one improbable, satisfying moment after another and little to no conflict. Jonathan D. Voss’s sweetly realistic, nostalgic watercolor illustrations go down easy as well, casting a benign glow even over scenes of army life during wartime. The little brown bear is adorable and affectionate, winning the heart of every human she comes into contact with, and her owner, Harry Colebourn, is a paragon of kind, virtuous, never-say-never manhood. Though Winnie earned her place in history accidentally, Walker’s storybook narration makes her legendary status seem well deserved, even preordained.

headline: Time to Throw the Book at Us
abstract: The time for readers to help choose the next Big City Book Club selection has arrived.
lead_paragraph: Comments on this post for the next Big City Book Club reading have been closed. The chosen book is “The Island at the Center of the World: The Epic Story of Dutch Manhattan and the Forgotten Colony That Shaped America” by Russell Shorto.

headline: A Google Computer Can Teach Itself Games
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A team at Google has developed a way a computer can sense inputs, learn rules and successfully play a number of classic video games. That’s a step up from the Jeopardy!-winning Watson, which was taught rules.
lead_paragraph: In a big step in the development of computers capable of independent reasoning, a team of Google researchers has created a machine that can figure out how to play and win video games.

headline: 1940: British to Sacrifice Shirt-Tails
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: British to sacrifice shirt-tails in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British shirt-tails, noted for their length, must be sacrificed to the national welfare and curtailed for the duration of the war, according to Herbert Kay, Secretary of the Shirt Manufacturers’ Federation of Great Britain. The current demand for army overalls is absorbing a large proportion of the available cotton, he explained. ‘‘I don’t think it will come to such a drastic step as tailless shirts,’’ Mr. Kay said. ‘‘But the problem has to be solved somehow.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1940

headline: Kazuo Ishiguro’s ‘The Buried Giant’
abstract: Neil Gaiman reviews Kazuo Ishiguro’s “The Buried Giant,” a quest narrative set in a mythical time of ogres, sprites and dragons.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy is a tool of the storyteller. It is a way of talking about things that are not, and cannot be, literally true. It is a way of making our metaphors concrete, and it shades into myth in one direction, allegory in another. Once, many years ago, a French translator decided that my novel “Stardust” was an allegory, based on and around John Bunyan’s “The Pilgrim’s Progress” (it wasn’t), and somewhat loosely translated the book with footnotes to that effect. This has left me a little shy of talking about allegory, and very shy of ever mentioning “The Pilgrim’s Progress.”

headline: I Have Been Silenced
abstract: By means of a nasty cyberattack, my three Sudan-related websites became unusable to all who visited my Facebook page on February 21, 2014. I believe the Khartoum (Sudan) regime is responsible.
lead_paragraph: By means of a nasty cyberattack, my three Sudan-related websites became unusable to all who visited my Facebook page on February 21, 2014. I believe the Khartoum (Sudan) regime is responsible. Many Facebook visitors subsequently going to my Sudan sites immediately found innumerable and highly aggressive “pop-up” ads. Nothing could be accessed, by me or by my 1,200+ Facebook “friends,” mainly Sudanese from both Sudan and South Sudan. They had received as a “message” from me pornographic videography (purportedly including me) containing potent malware; the message was sent to both my daughters as well as other family members. Other visitors experienced various difficulties and anomalies in accessing their own Facebook page; other consequences may as yet be undiscovered (my computer has been behaving very peculiarly since then, and is now with technicians).

headline: Among College Students, the Frenzied Competition to Work for No Pay
abstract: My college freshman’s summer plans are keeping her up nights. If she fails to earn a spot supplying free labor, she might have to resort to a paid job.
lead_paragraph: My daughter, a college freshman, is stressed — but not about her coursework. What’s keeping her up at night is her summer plan: specifically, landing the perfect unpaid internship. She is worried that if she fails to earn a spot supplying free labor, she may have to resort to earning several thousand dollars as a camp counselor.

lead_paragraph: After an extended search, closely watched by both the real estate and independent school worlds, the Brearley School has decided to remain at its location on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: ‘Welcome to Braggsville,’ by T. Geronimo Johnson
abstract: College students head South to stage a misbegotten intervention in this darkly comic novel.
lead_paragraph: If you imagine a satirical “The Indian Princess,” James Nelson Barker’s 1808 libretto about Pocahontas, or a macabre “E. T. the Extra-Terrestrial,” you might come close to T. Geronimo Johnson’s second novel, “Welcome to Braggsville.” This is a prototypical encounter narrative, rippling with irony, in which four Berkeley students visit Braggsville, a segregated Georgia town, population 712, smaller than their freshman class.

headline: ‘Anonymous Soldiers,’ by Bruce Hoffman
abstract: An American scholar asks whether the Jews or the Arabs forced the British to leave Palestine.
lead_paragraph: On July 22, 1946, seven milk churns containing concealed bombs exploded in the basement of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem. Six floors of British government and military offices collapsed, and 92 people were killed, most of them Arab, British and Jewish civilians. What was at the time the most lethal terrorist attack in history was perpetrated by the Irgun Zvai Leumi (Hebrew for National Military Organization) headed by Menachem Begin, a future prime minister of Israel. The organization’s main aim was to force the British out of Palestine, which they had ruled since 1917.

headline: Vivek Wadhwa, Voice for Women in Silicon Valley, Is Foiled by His Tone
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Computers and the Internet', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Mr. Wadhwa was one of the loudest male voices pushing for gender diversity in Silicon Valley. His story is a lesson in how not to handle criticism.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has lately come to the realization that it is not the meritocracy it has long pretended to be — at least not for women and most minorities. Now, after years of ignoring the issue, and some serious prodding by the likes of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, tech companies say they will do something about the hiring gap between white and Asian men and nearly everyone else.

headline: In Mecca of Modernism, a New Pack of Devotees
abstract: Palm Springs has been marketing itself as a destination for fans of its slightly idealized past, playing up its modernist architecture and celebrity lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — They came for the walking tours of Vista Las Palmas, the neighborhood so popular with Frank Sinatra and his crowd that it is known as the Rat Pack Playground. They rode buses up steep hills to view the gemlike house built around a massive boulder by Albert Frey, an architect known as a father of desert modernism. And of course they could not miss the outdoor show of vintage travel-trailers and the nightly parties in private homes rarely open to the public.

headline: A Spicy Spinach Stew From Ghana
abstract: Ghanaians living within bunting distance of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx can have a taste of home with this dish.
lead_paragraph: I thought I would talk with Samuel Obeng about the smoky spinach stew the chefs serve at his Bronx restaurant, Papaye, but he steered the conversation toward weightier matters. “I want to set up an African cultural center here in the Bronx,” he told me. “In Manhattan, they have a museum about sex! So why can’t I have an African museum? We can teach our kids how people back in Ghana dress, how they talk. We can teach our kids how to drum.”

lead_paragraph: Nathan Lane will return to Terrence McNally’s comedy “It’s Only a Play” at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater on March 31, the play’s producers announced on Wednesday. He replaces Martin Short, who has been pinch-hitting since Mr. Lane left on Jan. 4 to honor a previous commitment to appear with Brian Dennehy at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the Eugene O’Neill drama “The Iceman Cometh.” Mr. Lane will remain in “It’s Only a Play” until its scheduled closing date of June 7.

abstract: The bank says it will rely on growth, cost cuts and new fees, The approach just underscores what an unimpressive business big banking has become.
lead_paragraph: The optimism at JPMorgan Chase reinforces the overall mediocrity of the banking industry. Growth, cost cuts and new fees can bolster earnings 43 percent, JPMorgan’s chief, Jamie Dimon, and his crew told investors on Tuesday. They also suggested that that was enough to silence talk of a breakup.

headline: 1965: U.S. Jets Hit Viet Cong
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. jets hit Viet Cong in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — U.S. Air Force jets bearing secret antipersonnel weapons today blasted Viet Cong ambush positions north and east of Saigon. Sixteen of the jets hammered Viet Cong positions in the Mang Yang Pass, about 280 miles north of Saigon, to help out an ambushed Special Forces company. The pass is on a road between Pleiku and Qui Nhon, both the scene of recent terrorist attacks on U.S. installations. The guerrillas have severed the main road from coastal Qui Nhon to the Cambodian-Laotian frontier in a dozen places in an evident effort to knock out all of central Vietnam. ‘‘I don’t think we’ll ever get the road open,’’ a U.S. Engineer officer said. ‘‘The main difficulty is getting in there to repair it.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1965

headline: Cheerleading for Milan
abstract: It’s hip for the fashion crowd to hate the city, but some fans are trying to change opinions.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Twice a year (four times for the durable souls who cover both men’s and women’s collections), international fashion professionals in pack formation wend their way to Milan, the home base of the Italian fashion industry. For many of these visitors, it is a trip accepted with the grim resignation that typically accompanies dental visits. Complaints, never absent from the industry even at its most celebratory, rise to a crescendo. The cause of consternation: Gray, unbeautiful, unwelcoming Milan.

headline: Reflections on the Greek Economic Crisis: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Liz Alderman, the chief European business correspondent for the International New York Times, reflects on the Greek economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been writing about the economic and political crisis in Greece since 2012, when it looked as if the country might exit the euro monetary union if a young leftist maverick politician, Alexis Tsipras, came to power during a pivotal double-election that was being held that summer. He lost, just barely.

headline: Josephine Baker, a British View
abstract: Cush Jumbo brings her solo show “Josephine and I” to New York, playing the American performer Josephine Baker.
lead_paragraph: Cush Jumbo is a name you don’t soon forget. Over the past couple of years, Ms. Jumbo, a British actress, has built a young career almost as unusual. In an acclaimed cross-gender revival of “Julius Caesar,” she played Mark Antony to very good reviews in London, then New York. This fall she starred on Broadway opposite Hugh Jackman in a modern play, “The River.” Now, to show some real range, she brings her solo show “Josephine and I” to New York, playing the American performer Josephine Baker, who became a star in Paris. The show, which begins previews on Feb. 27 and opens on March 10, juxtaposes Baker’s fabled career with a more personal story about struggling to get started as a performer. (Through April 5 at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street; 212-539-9778)

lead_paragraph: “House of Cards” began as a fun-house-mirror reflection of Washington, an outlandish sendup decked out in the pinstripes-and-Prada props of real-life politics. headline: In Challenger, a Chastening for Emanuel
abstract: Jesús G. Garcia, a county commissioner who is known as Chuy, gained a stunning victory in the first round of Chicago’s mayoral election by forcing a runoff.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As he posed for photographs and took sips of steaming coffee with commuters at a subway station here early Wednesday morning, Jesús G. Garcia, the man who would be the first Hispanic mayor of Chicago, articulated what is likely to be a rallying call of his final six-week campaign to unseat the city’s well-financed incumbent, Rahm Emanuel.

headline: Sillerman of SFX Proposes Taking the Concert Company Private
abstract: SFX disclosed that its founder, Robert F.X. Sillerman, had offered $4.75 in cash for each share he did not already own.

lead_paragraph: Two young men living in Brooklyn were arrested on Wednesday and charged with plotting to travel thousands of miles to fight under the banner of the Islamic State, the terrorist organization that has seized a wide expanse of Syria and Iraq.

headline: 36 Hours in Lake Tahoe

headline: 36 Hours in Lake Tahoe
abstract: The cobalt blue lake straddling California and Nevada offers cowboy-chic in the north, casinos and clubs in the south, and plenty of skiing in between.
lead_paragraph: Straddling the Nevada-California border, Lake Tahoe’s immense cobalt blue oval — unfrozen thanks to the lake’s depth — stands out against the snow-covered mountains like a colossal eye staring into heaven. This May, Tahoe’s wilderness will be even more accessible with JetBlue beginning daily direct flights between J.F.K. and Reno-Tahoe International Airport. The lake’s vastness can be absorbed only by being there — or better yet, skiing the dozen resorts surrounding it, their trails like frozen white waterfalls cutting through the fir-lined mountains. Lake Tahoe has two distinctive areas: the north side, where cowboy-chic cabins and semi-isolated shops and cafes overlook a quiet shoreline; and South Tahoe, which glitters with casinos, clubs and a slew of new upscale boutique hotels hovering above the lake. Skiing both sides in one weekend is an ambitious undertaking, but the lake’s wilderness spirit and surprising contrasts are compelling enough to pull you into its adventurous orbit.

headline: Apple Loses Patent Case to Small Texas Company
abstract: The computer giant was ordered to pay $532.9 million to Smartflash, which is based in a building down the street from where the trial was held. Apple plans to appeal.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury decided this week that Apple should pay $532.9 million in damages for violating patents held by Smartflash, a business based in Texas.

Republicans in the House, however, intent on thwarting President Obama’s executive action on immigration, have been unwilling to back away from the dangerous impasse on this issue in their party.

keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Sarbanes-Oxley Act', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fines (Penalties)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A narrowly divided Supreme Court on Wednesday sided with a Florida fisherman, throwing out his conviction for tossing evidence — undersize grouper — back into the Gulf of Mexico under a federal law aimed mostly at white-collar crime.

headline: Royal Ballet Choregrapher to Open Studio Space in London
abstract: Studio Wayne McGregor will form part of an ambitious new educational and cultural hub for East London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wayne McGregor, the resident choreographer at the Royal Ballet who also has his own troupe, Random Dance, will open a new arts space in 2016 in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park. The space, Studio Wayne McGregor, will form part of an ambitious new educational and cultural hub for East London, which includes organizations like the Victoria and Albert Museum, Sadler’s Wells theater and University College London.
