headline: For Scott Walker, a Consistent Approach Under Tough Questioning
abstract: The Wisconsin governor’s repeated refusal to distance himself from claims about the president’s patriotism was the latest example of his ability to state his case and stick to it.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — As Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin struggled to respond to questions about the president’s patriotism and religion last week, some saw an unprepared presidential hopeful in the national glare — not ready for “the N.F.L.,” as one participant in a Sunday morning talk show put it.

headline: Iran’s Navy Blasts Away at a Mock U.S. Carrier
abstract: The movie-style attack near the Strait of Hormuz appeared to be a show of might and an expression of displeasure at the American presence in the region.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s navy may pale in comparison to that of the United States, but on Wednesday it inflicted serious damage on an American aircraft carrier — a mock-up of one, to be exact.

headline: Enchanting, Loose Ponytails at Alberta Ferretti
abstract: The hairstylist Guido Palau created a coiffure to match the designer’s romantic fall 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: “Mrs. Ferretti loves romance, so there’s always that thing,” said the stylist Guido Palau backstage at the designer’s fashion show today in Milan. To add extra enchantment to the fall Alberta Ferretti runway, Palau used extensions to make sure the models had long, even strands, which he blow-dried simply and then arranged into a loose ponytail, achieved by pulling the elastic down to let the hair out around the face a little (as Orlando Pita did at Michael Kors). Like Ferretti’s new collection, the resulting coiffure has a flowing, classical quality that’s meant to enhance each ensemble. “It has a kind of purity to it, which is so Ferretti,” he said, “but it will have a slightly old-fashioned take which feels very right for this collection.” Palau also notes that the hairstyle hides the models’ ears, adding to its timeless appeal and giving it an “untouched” and “painterly” look.

headline: Marijuana Legalization—Not the Drug Itself—Sows Confusion in D.C.
abstract: At 12:01 a.m. recreational marijuana will become semi-legal in the district .
lead_paragraph: At 12:01 a.m. on Thursday, recreational marijuana will become semi-legal in the District of Columbia under a patchwork blanket of no-go zones, threats of prosecution from congressional overseers and confusion about enforcement by overlapping city and federal police agencies. There won’t be any clouds of smoke, though. The pot law, approved by 70 percent of city voters last November, is so tightly restricted to home use that this social revolution may be largely invisible in the city at large.

headline: Eurozone’s Future Remains at Risk, Mario Draghi Warns
abstract: Mr. Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said member countries might need to give up some independence and create more Pan-European institutions.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In a contentious appearance before the European Parliament on Wednesday, the president of the European Central Bank said that the future of the eurozone was at risk unless member countries gave up some independence and created more Pan-European government institutions.

headline: AnonyWatch: On Port Authority Restrooms and Jeb Bush’s Adviser
abstract: Two recent examples of anonymous quotation in The Times deserve notice.
lead_paragraph: I’d never want to stand in the way of someone fulfilling her ambitions, so I’m inclined to laugh — although it is a bitter laugh — about the most recent example of gratuitous anonymous quotation in The Times.

headline: Text to Text | ‘What Would Malcolm X Think?’ and ‘After the Bombing’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we feature an Op-Ed written by Malcolm’s daughter Ilyasah Shabazz, in which she asks “What would Malcolm X think?” about today’s violence and activism. We pair it with an excerpt from one of Malcolm X’s final speeches, when he addresses many of these same issues.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm X was assassinated (PDF) 50 years ago this month, cutting short a powerful voice demanding justice and equality for African-Americans. When he died in 1965 there were still two Americas — one for whites and another for blacks. And while the nation has experienced a remarkable transformation in racial justice in the decades since his death, just in the past year we witnessed echoes of that stubborn divide with police shootings, protests and anger around St. Louis, New York City and elsewhere.

headline: Just Outside Berlin, a Design and Arts Scene Thrives
abstract: Artsy types are increasingly leaving the confines of the city center in favor of adopting a country life nearby.
lead_paragraph: That Berlin has one of Europe’s most vibrant contemporary arts scenes is hardly news — but now, a key group of creators are moving outside the city center to build ethically motivated, innovatively designed retreats, concert venues and private homes. Native Berliners often describe a quest for gemütlichkeit — German for a space that inspires cheerful serenity — as a defining element in Berlin’s characteristic aesthetic and life-philosophy. When placed outside the city’s famously spacious old apartments, this sense of tranquility is supposedly achieved through considerate and conscientious design that fits into, rather than overpowers, the surrounding environment.

lead_paragraph: The case for strong government rules to protect an open Internet rests in large part on a perceived market failure — the lack of competition for high-speed Internet service into American homes.

headline: Mark Duplass On Cassavetes, Kale Smoothies and His Never-Fail Stevie Nicks Pick-Me-Up
abstract: The writer, director and actor, who stars in HBO’s “Togetherness” and in the film “The Lazarus Effect,” which opens this weekend, shares a diverse selection of influences with T.
lead_paragraph: Referring to Mark Duplass as a movie star doesn’t feel quite right, despite the fact that he co-stars with Olivia Wilde in the horror film “The Lazarus Effect,” opening this weekend. And mentioning that he is a rising figure in Hollywood seems somehow inappropriate, too, despite his role as the co-writer, co-producer, director and co-star of the HBO series “Togetherness.” Duplass, who frequently works in collaboration with his brother Jay, has established a low-key ubiquity that is perfectly in keeping with the duo’s aesthetic.

headline: Marco de Vincenzo on Where to Shop, Dine and Even Sightsee in Milan

lead_paragraph: Few emerging designers showing on the big-brand-dominated Milan fashion calendar manage to capture the attention of a global audience — but since having his debut in 2009, Marco de Vincenzo has pulled away from the pack. And last year, his innovative, detail-rich women’s wear piqued the interest of even more editors when he received a substantial investment from LVMH. (The only other young Italian to garner the backing of a major conglomerate in recent memory is Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy, and we all know how that turned out.)

headline: Review: David Ives, in ‘Lives of the Saints,’ Mixes Gags and Philosophy

lead_paragraph: A woman returns from the dead to reveal uncomfortable secrets. A friendship almost founders over a gift gone unappreciated. A boy becomes romantically obsessed with a washing machine. A man runs into a fellow who seems to embody, with eerie specificity, the life he chose not to live.

headline: Video: Skiing With the Sport’s Next Generation
abstract: The veteran skier Sage Cattabriga-Alosa spent a day skiing with the young talent in Alta, a ski resort in the Wasatch Mountains of Utah.
lead_paragraph: Sage Cattabriga-Alosa, a longtime Teton Gravity Research athlete, enjoys the atmosphere of Alta, a ski resort in the Wasatch Mountains of Utah. What makes Alta unique is not only its terrain, which is dotted with natural jumps, but also its large amount of young local talent. Cattabriga-Alosa spent a day skiing with these young guns, who impressed him with their double back flips, 720s and front flips.

headline: Explaining Recovery Performance in Europe
abstract: Austerity is the main story, still.
lead_paragraph: I was very interested by the new paper by Claeys and Walsh on “plucking” as an explanation of differential performance in Europe; basically, they’re saying that fast growth has come in countries that previously had deep slumps. But how does that result interact with the result many of us have found, which is that differences in austerity seem to explain a lot? Here’s an example of what I find:

headline: Monetarism in Winter
abstract: Intellectual and moral decline.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong is writing about “cognitive closure” on the right, and focuses on the case of Allan Meltzer, the long-time monetarist standard-bearer and co-founder of the Shadow Open Market Committee. Meltzer has been predicting inflation, just around the corner, for six years; the experience apparently has had no impact on his conviction that he understands the economy better than the Fed. And he considers it rude and unprofessional when some of us point out how wrong he has been for how long.

lead_paragraph: Weight-loss surgery may help obese women have safer pregnancies and deliver healthier babies, compared with women who do not undergo surgery, according to a major new study.

headline: Researchers Warn on Anesthesia, Unsure of Risk to Children
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Anesthesia and Anesthetics', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Brain', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Experts said that parents and their doctors should consider how urgently surgery is required for children younger than 3 years.
lead_paragraph: Faced with mounting evidence that general anesthesia may impair brain development in babies and young children, experts said Wednesday that more research is greatly needed and that when planning surgery for a child, parents and doctors should consider how urgently it is required, particularly in children younger than 3 years.

abstract: The mobile app has become a popular platform for X-rated photos, videos and personalized shows, often sold on the sly to avoid violating rules.

headline: Future Brown, Confident Song Collective, Cooks New Stews
abstract: The first full-length album from the Future Brown production collective emphasizes melody while fluently borrowing structural elements from a host of styles.
lead_paragraph: We were supposed to have reached the singularity by now, no? That place where the underground scenes that were born in opposition to the mainstream excess of the 1980s and 1990s and 2000s would, through the Internet, come to rest comfortably next to, and inside of, pop. The old distinctions were meant to be relics; now that anyone can get anything at any time, hierarchies were doomed. Right?

headline: Feb. 25, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from South Africa, Spain, Ukraine, and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Spain, Ukraine, and Afghanistan.

headline: Review: In Mo Yan’s ‘Frog,’ a Chinese Abortionist Embodies State Power
abstract: The Nobel literary laureate’s latest novel focuses on the narrator’s aunt, an obstetrician who switches to an abortionist enforcing China’s one-child policy.
lead_paragraph: When the Chinese writer Mo Yan won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2012 and was warmly lauded by the Communist government, he became one of the most reviled winners in the history of that great honor. Among the more benign accusations lobbed at him was that he was undeserving. Herta Müller, a fellow literary laureate, called the choice “a catastrophe”;  Salman Rushdie called him “a patsy” for not supporting the jailed Chinese Nobel laureate and dissident Liu Xiaobo; and he was labeled an apologist for not denouncing the government. By the time he made his acceptance speech, Mr. Mo said he felt as if he were watching a play about someone else.

headline: Review: Paulo Szot’s Commanding Take on Bossa Nova at 54 Below
abstract: Mr. Szot used his powerful baritone in songs by Antônio Carlos Jobim and Irving Berlin during his tribute to Frank Sinatra.
lead_paragraph: A wrenching adjustment is required to accept performances of classic bossa nova songs sung in a voice more commanding than an intimate near whisper. Even Frank Sinatra, who recorded two albums of songs mostly composed by bossa nova’s founding father, Antônio Carlos Jobim, shed his swinging ring-a-ding-ding persona to adopt the murmur of an enraptured lover.

headline: Despite Distractions, Rory McIlroy Finds Refuge in What He Does Best
abstract: The top-ranked McIlroy, 25, is the new face of golf, and could remain so unless Tiger Woods regains his championship form when he returns to competition.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — On the 17th tee of his pro-am round at the Honda Classic on Wednesday, Rory McIlroy struck up a conversation with Mike Collis, an executive officer in the Coast Guard who served as his caddie for the hole. For about 15 minutes, they spoke animatedly about strength training, a shared passion.

headline: App Smart | Think Happy Thoughts
abstract: Mindfulness training has arrived on the smartphone. Three apps help motivate you to meditate and teach you new techniques.
lead_paragraph: Mindfulness training has arrived on the smartphone. Three apps help motivate you to meditate and teach you new techniques.

headline: Video Feature: Apps for Meditation and Calming on iPhone and Android
abstract: A number of smartphone apps guide users through exercises intended to provide calm, mindfulness and positive thinking.
lead_paragraph: THE smartphone can be a wicked tool for distraction and complication. But it doesn’t have to be. Your smartphone can actually be an agent of calm, relaxation and mindfulness.

headline: Flume Rises in the E.D.M. World
abstract: Harley Streten, who’s also known as Flume, has carved out a multifaceted electronic dance music career through online exposure, concerts and business deals.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, a young musician in Australia named Harley Streten began posting electronic dance tracks online under the name Flume. Every morning before heading off to work at a magazine shop, he checked the site, SoundCloud, to see how many people were listening.

headline: Boris Bidjan Saberi’s Mad Method
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Clothes at the label reflect the personal attention given by the designer.
lead_paragraph: Boris Bidjan Saberi had a cold. Or the flu. Something like that. Anyhow, the point is he was sick, and it was an unusual state of affairs in his atelier. Look at a picture of him: He’s a hardy guy, strong, resilient. But this time, he was under the weather, and that was a problem.

headline: The Wanderers
abstract: A couple determined to enjoy “one more adventure” has been traveling the world from home rental to home rental.
lead_paragraph: A couple determined to enjoy “one more adventure” has been traveling the world from home rental to home rental.

headline: Kelly Link’s ‘Get in Trouble’ and Five Other Works
abstract: Ms. Link, John Boyne, Seth Greenland, Alejandro Zambra, Elisa Albert and Matt Sumell have published new books.
lead_paragraph: GET IN TROUBLE

headline: Review: Kate Weare Company Celebrates 10th Anniversary at BAM Fisher
abstract: A premiere and duets from the troupe’s catalog were highlights of the dance program.
lead_paragraph: In the decade since she founded her company, the choreographer Kate Weare has definitely figured out how to make a duet — a certain kind of duet, with lots of tension, sexual and otherwise, between the parties. This became clear last Thursday at BAM Fisher, where her troupe is offering a retrospective of sorts: three duets from 2007 to 2010; a new duet inspired by one of those older ones; and the early stages of a developing trio.

headline: A Plot to Keep Teeth Whitening Expensive
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Teeth and Dentistry']
abstract: The board of dental examiners in North Carolina tried to reduce competition.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court made the right call today by ruling against a state dental board that tried to limit competition from salons, spas and other businesses.

headline: A Fierce Combat Boot Stomps Down Fausto Puglisi’s Fall 2015 Runway
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a studded pair that rounded out the designer’s ’80s-meets-’90s collection.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Review: Schubert’s ‘Winterreise’ With Christian Gerhaher
abstract: The cycle of 24 songs also featured the pianist Gerold Huber at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Singers are sometimes understandably tempted to infuse Schubert’s “Winterreise” (“Winter Journey”) with melodramatic touches and theatrical poses. Schubert finished this cycle of 24 songs, depictions of loneliness, bleakly frozen landscapes and heartbreak, a few days before dying at 31, likely of complications from syphilis.

headline: England Triumphs at the Junior Camrose in Wales
abstract: This year’s Junior Camrose event was held last weekend at the Seabank Hotel in Porthcawl, Wales.
lead_paragraph: It is interesting to watch potential stars of the future during their formative years as they compete at international events.

headline: How NOLA Can You Go?
abstract: A pair of exiles from New Orleans have put down roots in Brooklyn — among their own.
lead_paragraph: In early 2006, Morgan Babst was wandering around by herself at a Katrina benefit at the Museum of the City of New York, after her brother stood her up, gamely introducing herself to other attendees like Scott Habig, whom she encountered at the bar.

headline: In Case of L’Oréal Heiress, a Private World of Wealth Becomes Public
abstract: A dispute over Liliane Bettencourt, 92, has riveted France by opening a window on the private lives of the rich and contested.
lead_paragraph: BORDEAUX, France — For five weeks, a French version of “Downton Abbey” has been unfolding in a courtroom here, providing a rare glimpse into the discreet lives of the ultrarich.

headline: What’s a ‘Credible Threat’ in Wisconsin? Unions.
abstract: A Republican committee chairman in the Wisconsin state senate cut short a hearing on an anti-union bill.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, a Republican committee chairman in the Wisconsin state senate, Stephen Nass, cut short a hearing on an anti-union bill, citing a “credible threat” that union members were about to disrupt the proceedings.

headline: What’s New in Space Heaters
abstract: A new generation of heaters has improved safety and efficiency. And some even look good.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of heaters has improved safety and efficiency. And some even look good.

headline: Beauty and the Heat
abstract: What’s new in space heaters: design, power, efficiency, safety and versatility.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a rare winter of cheap heating oil, but many homeowners still waste money heating entire sections of the house instead of warming smaller chunks of space where they actually spend their time.

headline: A Modern Catskills Country Inn Offers Throwback Pleasures — Ice Fishing Included
abstract: The nine-room Arnold House, just outside the small town of Livington Manor, N.Y., combines a homey vibe with luxe, minimalist details.
lead_paragraph: Just outside the small town of Livingston Manor, about two hours north of New York City, a unique winter weekend sojourn awaits in the rural western Catskills called the Arnold House — a nine-room country inn situated on seven acres atop Shandelee Mountain, surrounded by glistening, mountaintop lakes and snowcapped farmlands. And this weekend, the property welcomes its first winter with an inaugural Ice Fishing Derby. Provisions include hand-warmers and fishing kits, and the winner will have a cocktail named in their honor at the inn’s 75-seat Tavern, a cozy stone room lined with taxidermy and outfitted for billiards.

headline: Match Strikers: Making Sparks Fly
abstract: It’s all in the wrist: Lilly Bunn shops for match strikers with sizzling good looks.
lead_paragraph: The rooms that Lilly Bunn designs are traditional, but in a cleaned-up sort of way – not “that chintzy, stuffy look of the 1980s,” she said.

headline: Reducing Spectacular to Simple
abstract: The architectural photographer Hélène Binet, who shoots only on film, is the recipient of the 2015 Excellence in Photography award from the Julius Shulman Institute.
lead_paragraph: In a world glutted with crystalline digital images of buildings to be scrolled, scanned and pinned, Hélène Binet’s architectural photography stands out for its reserve, its simplicity and an ineffable quality that comes from shooting on film. Her images can reduce a complex building on a spectacular site, like Le Corbusier’s monastery at La Tourette, to a series of vertical lines.

headline: After Midnight, D.C. to Find Out What Legal Marijuana Is All About
abstract: The possession and use of marijuana becomes legal in the District of Columbia at a minute after midnight.
lead_paragraph: At 12:01 a.m., marijuana becomes legal in the District of Columbia.

headline: A Crime Reporter Teams Up With a (Comic Book) Crime Fighter
abstract: Michael Wilson, a Metro reporter, describes the experience of delivering a special gift to the subject of a recent article.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, Michael Wilson, who writes the Crime Scene column for Metro, filed an unexpected follow-up story.

headline: Chinese Leader Is Putting His Alliances on Parade
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin is likely to be a featured guest at a military parade in Tiananmen Square marking the defeat of Japan in World War II, an event seen as underscoring the anti-Japanese theme of China’s foreign poicy under Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: Last year the National People’s Congress set Sept. 3 as a new Chinese holiday to commemorate the defeat of Japan in World War II. At the time people here took notice, but there was little debate.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Material Matters
abstract: With their clean lines, minimal hardware and marble tops, Egg Collective’s new pieces could easily be mistaken for vintage designs.
lead_paragraph: With their clean lines, minimal hardware and marble tops, Egg Collective’s new Morrison Storage Collection pieces for Design Within Reach could easily be mistaken for vintage designs. The console, credenza/sideboard and dresser were created by “looking at minimalist art and early American furniture forms, Shaker, Colonial furniture,” said Stephanie Beamer, a partner in Egg Collective with Crystal Ellis and Hillary Petrie. “And taking inspiration from those forms, but really paring them down while elevating the materials.”

headline: Putting a Dent in College Costs With Open-Source Textbooks
abstract: At a two-year community college, textbooks can equal 40 percent of tuition. Free or low-cost electronic books can cut that way back.

headline: London Designers Beg to Differ
abstract: A government call for austerity doesn’t reach the runways.
lead_paragraph: A government call for austerity doesn’t reach the runways.

headline: Bottom’s Up in a Recycled Chandelier
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Lighting', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: Glass from recycled wine and beer bottles is shaped like a pine cone to make a chandelier.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, the designer Tord Boontje and the sculptor Emma Woffenden began making vases and drinking vessels in their London studio out of a somewhat unorthodox material: recycled wine and beer bottles. Called tranSglass, their creations soon landed in the Museum of Modern Art’s collection and spawned a workshop in Guatemala City, where artisans now produce the pieces for the accessories company Artecnica.

headline: Winter Relief in Bloom
abstract: The annual Orchid Show at the New York Botanical Garden will display the flowers arranged in hanging baskets conceived as chandeliers.
lead_paragraph: Starting Saturday, a profusion of frilly blooms will take the edge off winter in the New York Botanical Garden’s annual Orchid Show. Arranged in hanging baskets conceived as chandeliers, the blossoms will be “high and low and as far as the eye can see,” said Todd Forrest, the garden’s Arthur Ross vice president for horticulture and living collections. More than 30,000 orchid species grow in the wild, Mr. Forrest said, which makes them something like the beetles of plant life. Asked for another fun fact, he mentioned a variety that resembles female wasps and is pollinated with the assistance of male wasps buzzing from plant to plant in their futile attempts to mate.

headline: Cold Wind Can Take a Back Seat
keywords: ['Beds and Bedding', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Alpacas']
abstract: The Rug Company’s new alpaca blankets with patterns more subdued than one may expect.
lead_paragraph: The Rug Company has just added alpaca blankets to its offerings. And the patterns are a lot more subdued than one may expect, given the fanciful floor coverings by artists and designers that the company is known for.

headline: Lawmakers Seek Information on Funding for Climate Change Critics
abstract: After revelations about Willie Soon, an opponent of mainstream climate science, lawmakers begin inquiries into connections between funding and research
lead_paragraph: Democratic lawmakers in Washington are demanding information about funding for scientists who publicly dispute widely held views on the causes and risks of climate change.

headline: Dustin Yellin Sculptures at City Ballet
abstract: The third annual Art Series, which invites artists to install large-scale works in the David H. Koch Theater, ends on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The third annual Art Series, which invites artists to install large-scale works in the David H. Koch Theater, ends on Friday.

headline: New York City Ballet Applies a Surreal Touch to Build Audiences
abstract: The third annual Art Series, which invites artists to install large-scale works in the David H. Koch Theater, ends on Friday.
lead_paragraph: There seemed to be an explosion of young men in knit caps and young women in leather pants watching as New York City Ballet recently performed a trio of Balanchine classics. In fact, the average age in the David H. Koch Theater seemed to have dropped by years, if not decades.

headline: Food Waste Is Becoming Serious Economic and Environmental Issue, Report Says
abstract: A report released Wednesday shows that about 60 million metric tons of food is wasted a year in the United States, a problem that contributes to climate change and to the loss of natural resources like water and land.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With millions of households across the country struggling to have enough to eat, and millions of tons of food being tossed in the garbage, food waste is increasingly being seen as a serious environmental and economic issue.

headline: Sales at Crate & Barrel, Zinc Details, Global Table an Minam
keywords: ['Beds and Bedding', 'Pillows', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Discounts on bedding, tableware and home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: All bedding is 20 percent off at Crate & Barrel, through March 2 (Marimekko Kesahelle duvet covers and pillow shams, originally about $40 to $150, are about $32 to $120; Nantucket sheet sets, in photo, originally about $30 to $150, are about $24 to $120); 800-967-6696, crateandbarrel.com.

headline: Deep Sympathy for Derrick Rose, the Bulls’ Star-Crossed Star
abstract: Rose will need his third major knee surgery in less than three years to repair a torn medial meniscus in his right knee.
lead_paragraph: The cloud of uncertainty that had engulfed Derrick Rose of the Chicago Bulls since 2012 was beginning to recede. Then came the news late Tuesday night that Rose — a former N.B.A. rookie of the year and most valuable player — would need his third major knee operation in less than three years.

headline: The Reworked Military Jacket Makes It Big and More
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Military jackets shed the surplus look; cellphone “cages” from Anndra Neen; a new label that aims to bring something a little quieter to contemporary fashion; and more.
lead_paragraph: Military jackets shed the surplus look; cellphone “cages” from Anndra Neen; a new label that aims to bring something a little quieter to contemporary fashion; and more.

headline: A Grand Tour With 46 Oases
abstract: Debbie and Michael Campbell, retirees, have spent a year and a half crisscrossing Europe, staying in Airbnb apartments.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to be a Senior Nomad?

headline: Review: Ronald K. Brown’s Evidence Presents 30th Anniversary Season
abstract: Mr. Brown’s company performs a mix of recent and classic works for its season at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, a 19-year-old choreographer from Brooklyn decided to take a chance on himself. He formed a dance company called Evidence to pay homage to aspects of life that most people ignore until they hit middle age: family, teachers, faith.

headline: Otter Box, a Sunday Party for Hirsute Gays
abstract: Held at the Flat, the party evokes the freewheeling spirit of 1980s East Village rec rooms, complete with a go-go boy on a crate.
lead_paragraph: Why go to a “gay” bar these days when you can specify a niche like twinks, bears, muscle queens and “Hellsea” gays?

headline: A.D.H.D. Diagnosis Linked to Increased Risk of Dying Young
abstract: A Danish study found that individuals with a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder had twice the rate of premature death than those without the disorder.
lead_paragraph: People with a diagnosis of attention deficit disorder are at higher risk of dying young than those without the disorder, usually in automobile crashes and other accidents, suggests research reported on Wednesday, from the largest study of A.D.H.D. and mortality to date.

headline: A Faster Way to Try Many Drugs on Many Cancers
abstract: So-called basket studies, which group cancer patients in a new way, could revolutionize the path from the lab to F.D.A. approval and market success.
lead_paragraph: Chemotherapy failed to thwart Erika Hurwitz’s rare cancer of white blood cells. So her doctors offered her another option, a drug for melanoma. The result was astonishing.

headline: ‘A Legacy More Lasting Than Bronze’
abstract: A look at a new show of works by the Venetian printer Aldus Manutius, at the Grolier Club in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A look at a new show of works by the Venetian printer Aldus Manutius, at the Grolier Club in Manhattan.

headline: Goodbye to All That
abstract: This February, the last fashion show was staged at Lincoln Center. In the fall, the shows will be held downtown. Here, the final days are documented.
lead_paragraph: This February, the last fashion show was staged at Lincoln Center. In the fall, the shows will be held downtown. Here, the final days are documented.

headline: In The Studio | Donatella Versace
abstract: Donatella Versace, who became chief designer after the murder of her brother Gianni, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how her Milan office reflects her pain and inspires her to keep Versace relevant.
lead_paragraph: Donatella Versace, who became chief designer after the murder of her brother Gianni, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how her Milan office reflects her pain and inspires her to keep Versace relevant.

headline: Fashion Says Goodbye to Lincoln Center
abstract: A week ago, the last fashion show was staged at Lincoln Center. Here, those final days are documented.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, the last fashion show was staged at Lincoln Center. Come fall, fashion will head downtown. The Lincoln Center complex, home of New York Fashion Week since 2010, was often less than loved, tainted as it was by complaints of overcrowding and commercialism. All the same, it was the site of scores of shows this month. Here, those final days are documented.

headline: Back in the U.S.S.R.
abstract: Arthur Tress’s latest offering from his archives comes from a 1967 trip to Russia, where he chronicled daily life amid Soviet pageantry.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Tress’s latest offering from his archives comes from a 1967 trip to Russia, where he chronicled daily life amid Soviet pageantry.

headline: Shopping Sales and Events in New York City
abstract: A collection of shopping suggestions and sales.
lead_paragraph: Get colorful with Bloomingdale’s: The department store has teamed up with Crayola and a number of contemporary designers to create exclusive looks in a rainbow of hues. Stop by the second floor at 59th Street on Thursday at 6 p.m. to shop items like a Rebecca Taylor jacquard culotte jumpsuit ($450) and a Nanette Lepore shift with lace overlay ($450) — and to try out a photo booth that creates coloring pages in your outline. On Friday, the buy-one-give-one shoemaker TOMS is opening its first New York City shop. There you can enjoy treats from a coffee bar serving TOMS Roasting Co. coffee as well as One Girl Cookies. You’ll also find the brand’s full range of slip-ons as well as the new TOMS Handbags line, which includes an ikat duffel ($148) and cognac leather canvas backpack ($248); purchases help provide training and materials for safe births. At 264 Elizabeth Street.

headline: Ondria Hardin Transforms at Fausto Puglisi
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Ondria Hardin before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Franco Gobbi.

headline: Morgan Stanley in $2.6 Billion Settlement Over Crisis in Mortgages
abstract: The deal is expected to be one of the last major steps in the Justice Department’s push to make banks pay for their role in the subprime crisis.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley said on Wednesday that it had reached a $2.6 billion settlement with the Justice Department over the sale of mortgage securities before the financial crisis.

headline: HP Said in Talks to Buy Aruba Networks
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A deal, which could be announced next week, would come as HP moves toward splitting itself up in two.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard is in talks to buy Aruba Networks, a maker of WiFi access equipment for businesses, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Justices Find Antitrust Law Valid Against Dental Board
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Teeth and Dentistry']
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled that the North Carolina State Board of Dental Examiners may be sued for driving teeth-whitening services out of business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that a state dental board controlled by dentists may be sued under antitrust laws for driving teeth-whitening services out of business.

headline: Kerry Reminds Congress Netanyahu Advised U.S. to Invade Iraq
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry recalled that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel strongly supported the United States’ invasion of Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry reminded Americans on Wednesday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, who is expected to denounce a potential nuclear deal with Iran during an address to Congress next week, also visited Washington in late 2002 to lobby for the invasion of Iraq.

headline: Doctor Who Survived Ebola Says He Was Unfairly Cast as a Hazard and a Hero
abstract: In an essay in the New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Craig Spencer, who was New York City’s first Ebola patient, took issue with how he was portrayed by politicians and the news media.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Craig Spencer, New York’s first and to date only Ebola patient, said in an essay published on Wednesday that he was falsely accused of putting the public at risk and was superficially depicted as “a fraud, a hipster and a hero” after he was hospitalized last fall.

headline: Shale Gas Project Encounters Determined Foes Deep in Algerian Sahara
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shale']
abstract: In Algeria, a country dependent on its oil and gas reserves, daily protests against a pilot shale gas project have turned into a national antifracking movement.
lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Deep in the Algerian Sahara, daily protests against a pilot hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, project are now well into their second month. The demonstrations have spread to several towns and have provided opposition parties with a new platform at an especially precarious moment for the government, as oil prices have slumped and the declining health of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has removed him almost completely from public view.

headline: Edible Coffee Cup in KFC Tests in Britain
abstract: KFC restaurants in Britain soon will introduce an edible coffee cup, a product that addresses consumer concerns with the environmental impact of packaging.
lead_paragraph: Diners at KFC restaurants throughout Britain soon will be able to have their coffee — and eat the cup, too.

headline: Dori J. Maynard, Who Sought Diversity in Journalism, Dies at 56
abstract: Ms. Maynard led a journalism education institute named for her publisher father, Robert C. Maynard, and explored how race, class and ethnicity appeared in news coverage.
lead_paragraph: Dori J. Maynard, a journalist who was at the forefront of the campaign to make the American news media a more accurate mirror of American diversity, died on Tuesday at her home in Oakland, Calif. She was 56.

headline: In a Case of Religious Dress, Justices Explore the Obligations of Employers
abstract: A vigorous argument before the Supreme Court explored religious stereotypes, employment discrimination and the symbolism of the Muslim head scarf, all arising from an encounter at a clothing store in Tulsa, Okla.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. on Wednesday warned that “this is going to sound like a joke,” and then posed an unusual question about four hypothetical job applicants. If a Sikh man wears a turban, a Hasidic man wears a hat, a Muslim woman wears a hijab and a Catholic nun wears a habit, must employers recognize that their garb connotes faith — or should they assume, Justice Alito asked, that it is “a fashion statement”?

headline: State Closes an Illegal Hotel in Manhattan That Was Hiding in Plain Sight
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Affordable Housing', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Condominiums']
abstract: The 36-story building was supposed to be a condominium and received millions of dollars in tax breaks meant to spur the construction of affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: The tall, slim tower on East 34th Street in Midtown Manhattan looked like dozens of other moderately priced hotels that have sprung up in New York City over the past decade.

headline: Next Goal for Walmart Workers: More Hours
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Working Hours', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Part-Time Employment']
abstract: Even with the wage increases the chain recently announced, workers often do not get enough hours to make ends meet, leaving them in a precarious financial state.
lead_paragraph: For Anthony Rodriguez, every diaper for his 2-year-old son means less money to put food on the table, or to fill up his car at the gas station. His fiancée, Melinda Prothero, tries to make each diaper last longer, but there’s a limit to that, he says.

headline: Insanity Defense Fails in Killing of the Former Navy Sniper Chris Kyle
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: The defendant, Eddie Ray Routh, said he was suffering from psychosis and paranoid delusions when he fatally shot Mr. Kyle and Chad Littlefield in 2013.
lead_paragraph: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — It took two years for Eddie Ray Routh to face murder charges in the killings of the former Navy SEAL sniper Chris Kyle and his friend in 2013, and two weeks for his trial to conclude. In the end, a jury of 10 women and two men took about two hours on Tuesday night to reject Mr. Routh’s claims that he was legally insane, find him guilty and, in effect, send him to prison for life.

headline: Anthony B. Herbert, Decorated War Hero Turned Army Whistleblower, Dies at 84
abstract: With four Silver Stars, four Bronze Stars and four Purple Hearts, the Army poster boy was relieved of his command in April 1969 after reporting he witnessed war crimes in South Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: During World War II, he ran away to join the Marines, but was sent home the next day because he was just 14. He enlisted in the Army three years later and, bemedaled with four Silver Stars, four Bronze Stars and four Purple Hearts, became the most decorated enlisted man during the Korean War. He volunteered for service in Vietnam, where, as a lieutenant colonel, he earned a Silver Star, two Bronze Stars, an Air Medal and an Army Commendation Medal in only 58 days of combat.

headline: At a Brooklyn Cherry Factory, a Suicide and an Illicit Discovery
abstract: As a marijuana farm was being discovered under Dell’s Maraschino Cherries, the company’s owner, Arthur Mondella, 57, fatally shot himself in his office bathroom.
lead_paragraph: There was no sign on the former brick factory on the treeless block in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where Arthur Mondella worked. No name on the door. Nothing — other than the bright-red liquid trickling onto the sidewalk and into the gutter, and the thick scent of syrup on a summer’s day — to announce the presence of one of the country’s largest suppliers of maraschino cherries.

headline: Taking Aim at Icicles to Keep Trains Moving Into and Out of New York
abstract: With yellow poles topped with hammerlike appendages, the Ice Patrol rolls through tunnels under the Hudson River, hunting for icicles that can disrupt the tightly choreographed train traffic.
lead_paragraph: The rail tunnels that connect New York City and New Jersey are 105 years old, and the technique that Amtrak employees have been using to keep trains running through them this frigid winter is hardly more modern.

headline: Scott Walker Is Set to Deliver New Blow to Labor in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: A measure being fast-tracked through the Republican-held State Legislature would bar unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — It was a flashback to 2011: Hundreds of union members in hard hats and work boots waved signs under falling snow, denouncing Gov. Scott Walker and his fellow Republican lawmakers outside this Capitol building on Wednesday. Yet this time, their numbers were smaller, their chants softer.

headline: Jordan: U.S. Warns of Threat to Malls
abstract: The United States Embassy in Jordan on Wednesday warned American citizens to avoid high-end shopping malls in Amman, the capital, because of credible threats of terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: The United States Embassy in Jordan on Wednesday warned American citizens to avoid high-end shopping malls in Amman, the capital, because of credible threats of terrorist attacks. The embassy’s statement contained no information about the type or timing of any possible attack, but it advised Americans in the country and embassy employees and their families to avoid the malls in the next few days. “Extremist groups have repeatedly expressed interest in attacking so-called soft targets, such as malls and restaurants in Jordan,” it said. The spokesman for Jordan’s government, Mohammad Momani, said security measures had already been stepped up because of “regional events.” Jordan is taking part in the campaign against the Islamic State group, which recently killed a captured Jordanian pilot and released a video showing his grisly death.

headline: Eugenie Clark, Scholar of the Life Aquatic, Dies at 92
abstract: Long before “Jaws,” Dr. Clark rode a 40-foot whale shark, met great whites while scuba diving, studied “sleeping” sharks in undersea caves and witnessed a shark’s birth.
lead_paragraph: Eugenie Clark, whose childhood rapture with fish in a New York City aquarium led to a life of scholarly adventure in the littorals and depths of the Seven Seas and to a global reputation as a marine biologist and expert on sharks, died on Wednesday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 92.

headline: South Korean Island Grows Wary After Welcoming the Chinese
abstract: While many residents of the South Korean island of Jeju welcome the recent influx of Chinese investors, some worry about exploitation and becoming a pawn in Beijing’s power games.
lead_paragraph: DAEJEONG, South Korea — Not far from Shin Yong-kyun’s strawberry farm are the crumbling remains of an airfield that Japanese colonialists built in the 1930s, to launch air raids against China, and the coastal caves they gouged out to hide their warships.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 25, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Talk Toughens as U.S.-Israel Relations Fray
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: What started out as a dispute over the Israeli prime minister’s planned speech to Congress has consumed the two sides, threatening long-term consequences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama’s national security adviser sat down with her Israeli counterpart at the White House last week, she upbraided him over leaks in Jerusalem that the Americans interpreted as an attempt to undermine nuclear negotiations with Iran.

headline: Inquiry Into Working Families Party Spurs Charges Against Official’s Ex-Aides
abstract: A yearslong inquiry into the party, the influential left-leaning group that helped fuel the rise of Mayor Bill de Blasio, has resulted in the indictments of two former aides to Deborah L. Rose, a Staten Island city councilwoman.
lead_paragraph: A yearslong investigation into the Working Families Party, the influential left-leaning group that helped fuel the rise of Mayor Bill de Blasio, has resulted in the indictments of two former aides to a Staten Island city councilwoman.

headline: Review: ‘Brooklynite,’ a Superhero Musical With Matt Doyle and Nicolette Robinson
abstract: In this goofy, family-friendly musical, a team of superheroes wrestles with romance, a would-be supervillain and the prospect of a life after crime-fighting.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy being a superhero charged with protecting Brooklyn. Making sure all that fresh produce makes it from farm to table. Breaking up fights at the Park Slope Food Co-op. Preventing French tourists from falling into the Gowanus Canal. These and other daily challenges are the responsibility of six superpower-endowed men and women fighting the good fight in “Brooklynite,” a slight but goofily endearing new musical that opened on Wednesday at the Vineyard Theater.

headline: De Blasio, in Albany to Discuss Budget, Faces Competition From Cuomo
abstract: Questions about Capitol chicanery ran rampant in Albany on Wednesday after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo held a cabinet meeting at the same time as Mayor Bill de Blasio’s budget presentation to state lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — With 12 hours’ notice, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo convened an all-hands-on-deck cabinet meeting in the Capitol on Wednesday that focused on three issues: a previously announced plan to battle sexual assault on college campuses, a previously announced plan to expand prekindergarten, and a previously announced snowmobiling event.

headline: It’s All a Plot
abstract: In which Caleb Emmons asks for a raise.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I think Caleb Emmons is asking for a raise. You might not have picked up on this, but I did. I became a big believer in subliminal messages after majoring in Strategic Guessing in college. The university insisted on calling it “Marketing,” but guessing — as in, “We’re pretty sure consumers won’t sue us for selling them this product” — was much closer to the truth.

headline: As Vote Nears, Watchdog Agency Criticizes Netanyahu on Housing Costs
abstract: Successive governments in Israel have failed to address the lack of reasonably priced housing, the state comptroller found.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In another potential blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who faces his country’s voters in less than three weeks, Israel’s government watchdog issued a harsh report on Wednesday chronicling the failure of successive Israeli governments in dealing with a growing housing crisis — mostly on Mr. Netanyahu’s watch.

headline: Reconsidering Notion of Mercy After a Basketball Rout in Brooklyn
abstract: Brooklyn Collegiate’s 117-8 playoff loss illustrates how quickly a high school team’s abilities can change and the shortfalls of a citywide policy dictating who qualifies for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: The odds were long for Brooklyn Collegiate’s girls varsity basketball team going into the playoff game on Tuesday night. They were 1-14 for the season. Their opponents, Francis Lewis High School, were 13-3 and the defending city champions, and had beaten them earlier in the season by 85 points.

headline: Mark Teixeira Changes His Plate Philosophy, but Only When It Comes to Meals
abstract: Teixeira has a new gluten-free diet, but he is not going to alter his swing to counteract defensive shifts.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mark Teixeira arrived Wednesday for the start of spring training, declaring himself a changed man. No longer does he eat sandwiches or muffins, and when his children eat pancakes for breakfast, he joins them with a plate of turkey bacon and a veggie smoothie. (For inquiring minds, coconut yogurt, spinach and frozen berries are the go-to ingredients.)

lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday sought to reassure New Yorkers that the agency would secure the necessary funding to forestall what transit experts were warning about — a slump in service, overflowing subway trains and more frequent delays.

headline: Massachusetts: Opening Is Set in Boston Marathon Bombings Trial
abstract: Opening arguments in the Boston Marathon bombings trial are set to begin Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Opening arguments in the Boston Marathon bombings trial are set to begin Wednesday. After 21 days of interviews, Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. of Federal District Court has found 70 people he says are qualified to serve, a court official said. They are to face peremptory challenges Tuesday as lawyers whittle their number to 12 jurors and six alternates. Still outstanding is a ruling on a defense motion to move the trial outside Boston because of apparent prejudice against the defendant, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 21.

headline: Death Toll From C. Difficile Is Raised
abstract: Clostridium difficile is estimated to have afflicted almost half a million Americans and caused 29,000 deaths in 2011, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: The deadly bacterial infection Clostridium difficile is estimated to have afflicted almost half a million Americans and caused 29,000 deaths in 2011, according to a study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine. The estimate is drawn from laboratory testing and reporting in 10 states and is larger than previous figures based on narrower data sources. C. difficile causes severe diarrhea and colon damage and is linked to overuse of antibiotics. The study estimated that 24 percent of cases occurred in hospitals and 40 percent began in nursing homes or community health care settings.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Income', 'Labor and Jobs']

headline: Can I Stay Out of an Estate Dispute?
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Ethicists consider reader questions about family assets, hometown crowds at sporting events and gym etiquette.
lead_paragraph: In order to decrease his net worth before beginning divorce proceedings, my brother invested $600,000 in an apartment in my father’s name. Years later, he had our mother co-sign a business loan. When the business failed, my mother was sued for $3 million she didn’t have. After she died of cancer, my father fought the suit for many years. At 93, he settled for a $1.1 million loss. Unable to live his accustomed lifestyle, he approached my brother with the expectation that my brother would supplement his income. When my brother refused, my father sold the apartment and kept the $600,000.

headline: Building the First Slavery Museum in America
abstract: In Louisiana, a wealthy white lawyer has spent 15 years turning the Whitney Plantation into a museum dedicated to telling the story of slavery.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana’s River Road runs northwest from New Orleans to Baton Rouge, its two lanes snaking some 100 miles along the Mississippi and through a contradictory stretch of America. Flat and fertile, with oaks webbed in Spanish moss, the landscape stands in defiance of the numerous oil refineries and petrochemical plants that threaten its natural splendor. In the rust-scabbed towns of clapboard homes, you are reminded that Louisiana is the eighth-poorest state in the nation. Yet in the lush sugar plantations that crop up every couple of miles, you can glimpse the excess that defined the region before the Civil War. Some are still active, with expansive fields yielding 13 million tons of sugar cane a year. Others stand in states of elegant rot. But most conspicuous are those that have been restored for tourists, transporting them into a world of bygone Southern grandeur — one in which mint juleps, manicured gardens and hoop skirts are emphasized over the fact that such grandeur was made possible by the enslavement of black human beings.

headline: Do You Need to De-Clutter Your Life?

headline: Deadly Attacks in Xinjiang Go Unreported in China

lead_paragraph: The reports of bloodshed are nonstop. On Feb. 13, a man grabbed a police officer and then set off explosives strapped to his body, killing as many as eight people. Three days later, a father and son were shot and killed in another clash with the police. The following day, four police officers were stabbed to death, nine suspects in the attack were shot dead, and four bystanders were killed.

headline: Unexpected Lessons From ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’
abstract: A hit movie has a lot to say about franchises adapted from literary sources.
lead_paragraph: “A man watches a movie, and the critic must acknowledge that he is that man.” So wrote Robert Warshow, almost exactly 60 years ago, setting down what would become an unofficial motto for the profession. The idea that movies and other forms of popular culture could be subjected to serious critical scrutiny was a new and controversial notion in American intellectual circles at the time, and Warshow wanted to make clear that any such criticism would have to take account of its origins in everyday experience. Wherever your thoughts and judgments might take you, you always start out as a consumer, a member of the audience, a fan.

headline: Ravenna, Italy, Glittering Still
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Byzantine Civilization']
abstract: A few miles from the Adriatic Sea, the city has arcade-lined piazzas, wine bars brimming with locals and spectacular Byzantine mosaics.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of Ravenna, I saw some extraordinary fashion: men sporting leopard-spotted tights and velvet cloaks; women wearing dresses of shimmering silk, jewels gleaming at their ears and throats. But these stylish people were not strolling the Piazza del Popolo or sipping prosecco at a cafe; they were rendered in mosaic, created from tiny cubes of colored glass affixed over 1,500 years ago. Sparkling from the walls of eight early Christian monuments, the town’s Byzantine mosaics form the largest such collection in Western Europe.

headline: In France, a Visit With the In-Laws (Finally) Becomes a Vacation
abstract: Yes, Montpellier was the home of my husband’s family. But now I viewed it as a place of beauty and culture, not just an obligation.
lead_paragraph: In Montpellier, cypresses grow as high as the bell tower of Eglise Ste.-Thérèse. Whelks, caught that morning from the nearby Mediterranean Sea, are sold by the dozen with a side of aioli at the covered market Halles Castellane. The Musée Fabre, a national museum that houses works by the likes of Delacroix and Courbet in a grand 18th-century chateau, manages to feel inviting, not intimidating. Even its visitors, sipping their espresso at the cafe Insensé on the front lawn, look more like leisured houseguests than the sort of wearied tourists you see at the Louvre.

headline: No Crudités, but Hillary Clinton Still Has a Long List of Demands for Speeches
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton faced sharp criticism last year after a report by The Washington Post detailed the accommodations she had sought from a university for a paid speech. But as Mrs. Clinton prepares for an expected 2016 presidential campaign, her speaking agents have not let that stop them from continuing to make very specific requests, in addition to her often considerable speaking fee.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton faced sharp criticism last year after a report by The Washington Post detailed the accommodations she had sought from a university for a paid speech. But as Mrs. Clinton prepares for an expected 2016 presidential campaign, her speaking agents have not let that stop them from continuing to make very specific requests, in addition to her often considerable speaking fee.

headline: In Brooklyn, Eager to Join ISIS, if Only His Mother Would Return His Passport
abstract: The three men arrested on charges of supporting the Islamic State led quiet public lives, the authorities say, but privately they raged at what they saw as wicked behavior around them.
lead_paragraph: Like countless 19-year-olds, Akhror Saidakhmetov lived much of his life online.

headline: Kim Gordon: By the Book
abstract: The musician and author of the memoir “Girl in a Band” is a fan of Joan Didion: “How cool is it that Céline chose her for their new ad campaign? I want those sunglasses.”
lead_paragraph: The musician and author of the memoir “Girl in a Band” is a fan of Joan Didion: “How cool is it that Céline chose her for their new ad campaign? I want those sunglasses.”

headline: Carey Mulligan and Bill Nighy Prepare ‘Skylight’ for Broadway
abstract: David Hare’s play, which has transferred from London in a production directed by Stephen Daldry, finds two former lovers reuniting.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After Bill Nighy saw David Hare’s play “Skylight” in 1995, he telephoned the playwright to tell him he had never had a better night in the theater. “I was exhilarated,” Mr. Nighy recalled. “It was everything I loved and admired, and I picked up the phone and said, ‘David! I’ve just seen “Skylark.’ ”

headline: ISIS Onslaught Engulfs Assyrian Christians as Militants Destroy Ancient Art
abstract: An estimated 300 people have been taken captive, and 30 villages emptied, while Christians are forced to pay a tax to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The reports are like something out of a distant era of ancient conquests: entire villages emptied, with hundreds taken prisoner, others kept as slaves; the destruction of irreplaceable works of art; a tax on religious minorities, payable in gold.

headline: Banksy Releases New Works on Gaza
abstract: The graffiti artist Banksy posted a two-minute movie on his website this week, with short clips of Palestinian citizens standing amid rubble and what appear to be armed Israeli soldiers.
lead_paragraph: The graffiti artist Banksy unveiled his latest politically charged creation online on Thursday, posting on Instagram a photograph of a weeping figure, which the artist tagged with the hashtags “Banksy” and “Gaza.”

headline: To Rouse Bleary-Eyed Conservatives, Ben Carson Urges End to I.R.S.
abstract: Ben Carson, the retired surgeon, led off the presidential contenders speaking to thousands of conservatives at CPAC early Thursday. He called for curtailing government programs and a stronger response to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: “I’m for a fair taxation system that allows us to get rid of the I.R.S.”

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

lead_paragraph: Barnes & Noble said on Thursday that it would spin off its college bookstores business into a separate publicly traded company, changing up its breakup plans.

headline: Whistler’s Slopes and Après-Ski Charms, the Cheap Way
abstract: A favorable exchange rate and a yurt-to-cabin upgrade, along with tips from young employees, lead to an affordable weekend in the high-end ski town.
lead_paragraph: Seven little words sure to warm any frugal heart: “Sir, you’ve been upgraded from your yurt.”

headline: Guarding Denmark’s Jewish Heritage
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Religion and Belief', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: How can we protect not only the security of Jews, but also their position as a well-integrated part of our society?
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — The attack on Copenhagen’s synagogue earlier this month that left a volunteer Jewish watchman dead is a tragedy for a society that, for more than two centuries, has insisted that there is no tension between being Jewish and being Danish. It was precisely this sense of national solidarity across religious lines that helped save Denmark’s Jews from the Nazis during World War II.

headline: Request to Hold Defendants in Custody
abstract: A document that prosecutors presented to a judge to make the case to hold Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev and Akhror Saidakhmetov, both accused of planning to support the Islamic State, in custody.
lead_paragraph: A document that prosecutors presented to a judge to make the case to hold Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev and Akhror Saidakhmetov, both accused of planning to support the Islamic State, in custody.

headline: Review: ‘The Hunting Ground’ Documentary, a Searing Look at Campus Rape
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The director Kirby Dick and the producer Amy Ziering examine sexual violence at colleges and the failure of schools to seek justice for victims.
lead_paragraph: “The Hunting Ground,” a documentary shocker about rape on American college campuses, goes right for the gut. A blunt instrument of a movie, it derives its power largely from the many young women and some men recounting on camera how they were raped at their schools and then subsequently denied justice by those same schools. Their stories — delivered in sorrow and rage, with misting eyes and squared jaws — make this imperfect movie a must-watch work of cine-activism, one that should be seen by anyone headed to college and by those already on campus.

headline: Avery Blanchard Transforms at Fendi
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Avery Blanchard before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Sam McKnight.

headline: Chris Christie, Peacock
abstract: Just like the rest, only louder.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins has a characteristically hilarious piece about Chris Christie, who went around bellowing about his fiscal responsibleness, then, as soon as the question arose about how to pay for something he agreed to, welshed on the deal.

headline: Carmakers Find That Turbos Are a Powerful Path to Fuel Efficiency
abstract: Once mostly found in expensive sports and luxury cars, turbochargers are proliferating as automakers scramble to improve fuel economy without sacrificing performance.
lead_paragraph: EVEN as electric cars stall with Americans, another fuel-saving technology is revolutionizing the morning commute: the turbocharger.

headline: Despicable Monetary Me
abstract: Terrible true things I’ve said.
lead_paragraph: I want to weigh in on the issue of “cognitive capture” and the appropriate tactics for the reality-oriented community; more later or tomorrow. But I did want to remind readers of the column that had Allan Meltzer complaining that I say vicious things that the Times shouldn’t print. Here’s the column.

headline: Financial Aid for Undocumented Students Is Losing Its Stigma
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Colleges and universities are increasingly making higher education more affordable for students for whom all federal and most state forms of financial aid remain off limits.
lead_paragraph: For years, it was information shared only in whispers. Undocumented students, bright and educated, wanted to go to college, and a precious few universities were willing, very quietly, to help them pay for it.

headline: Classical Playlist: Haydn, Poul Ruders, Vaughan Williams and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: POUL RUDERS: ‘Nightshade Trilogy’Capricorn, Oliver Knussen, conductor; Odense Symphony Orchestra, Paul Mann and Scott Yoo, conductors(Bridge 9433; one CD)When the masterly Danish composer Poul Ruders wrote “Nightshade,” a work for 10 instruments, in 1986, he did not know it would be the first of three related scores written over 18 years, his “Nightshade Trilogy,” as he later called it. “The Second Nightshade,” a Symphonic Nocturne for chamber orchestra, came in 1991. “Final Nightshade,” an Adagio of the Night for full orchestra, ended the series in 2003. All three works explore extreme contrasts of high and low, loud and soft, fast and slow, and such, as the composer explains in liner notes. But nothing can explain the cosmic allure, audacious inventiveness and gripping strangeness of Mr. Ruders’s ingenious music. This recording album brings together three recordings of the three works made over 17 years, conducted respectively by Oliver Knussen (with the Capricorn ensemble), Paul Mann and Scott Yoo (with the Odense Symphony Orchestra). (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: At CPAC, Pushing Republican Hopefuls to Dive Into Policy Specifics
abstract: The Conservative Political Action Conference has added question–and-answer periods to satisfy a desire for White House aspirants to move beyond the red meat of their stump speeches.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prepared remarks are out. Answering tough questions is in. And there should be plenty of them — especially for a candidate named Bush.

headline: 1940: Aged Mother of ‘Traitor’ Flees
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The disgraced mother of the traitor, Paul Ferdonnet, flees home in 1940.
lead_paragraph: NIORT (DEUX-SÈVRES) — The aged mother of Paul Ferdonnet, a broadcaster for the Germans, who is known as ‘‘The traitor of Stuttgart,’’ today [Feb. 26] sought shelter and seclusion in a convent on the outskirts of Niort. She was grief-stricken by the appearance on public edifices of official posters that declared Ferdonnet together with another French broadcaster named Obrecht traitors to the nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 27, 1940

headline: High Rate of Shopping and Switching in Obamacare Plans Is a Good Sign
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The encouraging switching rate, announced by the government, remains a bit of a mystery to experts who study insurance markets.
lead_paragraph: For most customers returning to the Obamacare marketplaces this year, it really paid to shop around. New data shows that a large number of them did. That bodes well for those shoppers and the future offerings of the insurance marketplaces.

headline: Case Against Argentine President, Brought by Prosecutor Who Died, Is Dismissed
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner had been accused by the prosecutor Alberto Nisman of conspiring to shield Iranian officials from responsibility for the bombing of a Jewish center in 1994.

headline: Behind the Scenes of Pangea With Puppets

headline: 1890: Modern Crusoes
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Three castaways are rescued after four years on an uninhabited island by the American ship, Wanderer, in 1890.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despatches received here to- day [Feb. 26] from Vancouver Island state that three Englishmen landed there from the American ship Wanderer, which had rescued them from the uninhabited island of San Alesandro, where they had been for four years. They state that in October, 1885, they took passage on the Japanese vessel Matsuo Marie, at Hakodatt, for Anomari, and while crossing the Straits of Issugaru a gale was encountered, which blew them out of their course. For eighty days they were tossed about and finally the vessel was driven ashore on the island of San Alesandro. The three castaways lived chiefly on the fruit which grew on the island. They suffered considerable privations, and had all given way to despair when the Wanderer rescued them. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 27, 1890

Others might have used a more violent expression.

headline: Opening Oaxaca to the World
abstract: While much of La Morada’s menu is taken up by tacos and quesadillas, a few dishes offer a taste of the “infinite gastronomy” that is Oaxacan cooking.
lead_paragraph: The meatball is burly but yields in an instant, spilling its secret: a whole green olive, buried at the center. The olive is a small, powerful thing, radiating salt and vinegar, almost pickling the meat from the inside, transfiguring it.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — William Taylor III, once a lifer in state prison for two robbery convictions and the intent to sell a small packet of heroin, was savoring a moment he had scarcely dared to imagine: his first day alone, in a place of his own.

headline: Lurex and Lamé and Shine. Oh My!

lead_paragraph: Shine on, shiny fabrics! From New York to Milan, Lurex and lamé are lighting up the fall 2015 runways. In London, printed tops and dresses draped models’ bodies like liquid metal in J.W. Anderson’s ’80s-inspired collection. And in Christopher Kane’s hyper metallic fashion show, Lurex looks were amped up with equally glitzy bags and shoes. Then, yesterday, in the debut women’s collection from Gucci’s newly minted creative director Alessandro Michele (who embraced and modernized vintage dressing), pink mink cuffs tempered an otherwise shimmering gold dress.

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Celebrates the Chinese New Year

lead_paragraph: “Xin nian kuai le!” That’s a happy Chinese new year from the New York Philharmonic, which celebrated on Tuesday with its fourth annual gala concert at a packed Avery Fisher Hall.

abstract: Can the use of jails be reformed to reduce the number of inmates without increasing society's risks?

headline: Your Next Lesson: Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon

lead_paragraph: In the first full year of Wine School, we’ve focused entirely on the fundamental types of wine that have served as a foundation for producers around the world. Now, for the first time, we’ll examine a reinterpretation of one of those elemental styles as we take up Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon.

headline: Italian Purveyors Lay Claim To the Hearts and Bellies of Paris
abstract: France’s capital is now the world’s second-biggest consumer of pizza (and is rapidly embracing other goods imported from and inspired by Italy).
lead_paragraph: When the sommelier Enrico Bernardo moved to Paris from Italy nearly two decades ago, the world of French gastronomy brutally rejected him. No matter that he had won the competition for best sommelier in Italy; when he asked 30 restaurateurs for work in their wine cellars, all turned him down. “They took one look at me and said, ‘You’re Italian,'” he recalls. “‘You eat pizza and spaghetti. What do you know about French food and wine? Besides, you speak bad French.'”

headline: A Ghost City
abstract: Ordos is famous for being empty — a symbol, some would say, of the hubris of rampant urbanization. But the few people who live there see it differently.
lead_paragraph: Ordos is famous for being empty — a symbol, some would say, of the hubris of rampant urbanization. But the few people who live there see it differently.

abstract: We despise them – yet we imbue them with our hopes and dreams, our dearest memories, our deepest meanings. They unlock much more than our accounts.
lead_paragraph: We despise them – yet we imbue them with our hopes and dreams, our dearest memories, our deepest meanings. They unlock much more than our accounts.

headline: Targeted by U.S. Prosecutor, Hedge Fund Fights Back
abstract: The suit may be a long shot, but it comes as Preet Bharara’s image as an invincible prosecutor — racking up convictions on Wall Street — is beginning to fray.
lead_paragraph: On a crisp fall morning, F.B.I. agents staged a surprise raid of three hedge funds, feeding the growing national reputation of the prosecutor Preet Bharara as the new sheriff of Wall Street.

headline: Scenes From the Conservative Political Action Conference
abstract: The conference opened on Thursday outside Washington.
lead_paragraph: The conference opened on Thursday outside Washington.

headline: Isabella Stewart Gardner Heist: 25 Years of Theories
abstract: In 1990, 13 artworks — including Rembrandts, a Vermeer and a Manet — were stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. A quarter-century later, the hunt continues.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The hallway in the Brooklyn warehouse was dark, the space cramped. But soon there was a flashlight beam, and I was staring at one of the most sought-after stolen masterpieces in the world: Rembrandt’s “Christ in the Storm on the Sea of Galilee.”

headline: British Hospital Ignored Sexual Abuse Complaints Against Jimmy Savile, Inquiry Finds
abstract: A report on the Stoke Mandeville hospital found that Mr. Savile, a TV host, abused 60 people there as officials ignored complaints.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despite 10 complaints against him, and a reputation as a “sex pest,” Jimmy Savile, the British television personality, had freewheeling access in a hospital where he sexually abused 60 people over more than two decades, according to a report released Thursday.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Day at CPAC
abstract: Scenes from the second day of the CPAC conference in Washington.

headline: Review: David Cronenberg Dissects Hollywood in ‘Maps to the Stars’
abstract: The film imagines Los Angeles as an inferno of narcissism, greed and sexual perversity.
lead_paragraph: If the Oscars have left you with a residual hatred of Hollywood or a renewed appreciation of Julianne Moore, “Maps to the Stars” may be just what you need. Suavely directed by David Cronenberg from an elegantly waspish script by Bruce Wagner, it belongs to the venerable tradition of movieland self-loathing. The film, tipping its hat to Nathanael West’s “The Day of the Locust” and Mr. Wagner’s own novels, imagines Los Angeles as an inferno of narcissism, greed and sexual perversity. The radiant sunshine has a sinister glow, and the blossoms on the trees are surely poisonous.

headline: Review: ‘The Sellout,’ Paul Beatty’s Biting Satire on Race in America
abstract: Mr. Beatty’s novel is told from the view of a young isolated black man born on outskirts of Los Angeles who lands before the Supreme Court in a race trial appeal.
lead_paragraph: Paul Beatty is the author of four novels and two books of poetry, all of them worthwhile. But the book of his that I return to most is one he edited. It’s called “Hokum: An Anthology of African-American Humor” (2006).

headline: Appeals Court Backs Landmarks Commission on House Used for Underground Railroad
abstract: The Hopper-Gibbons House on West 29th Street in Manhattan was a stop on the Underground Railroad for ex-slaves fleeing to Canada.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court has ruled that a building owner should have sought permission from the Landmarks Preservation Commission when adding a fifth story to a landmark mid-19th-century rowhouse in Chelsea that may be the only surviving documented Manhattan station on the Underground Railroad.

headline: Adrian Peterson Ruling
abstract: A federal judge in Minneapolis, David S. Doty, overturned the suspension of the Vikings’ Adrian Peterson.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Minneapolis, David S. Doty, overturned the suspension of the Vikings’ Adrian Peterson.

headline: Republicans Warn Washington to Think Twice About Legalizing Marijuana
abstract: Under a law that took effect on Thursday, residents of the District of Columbia can legally possess up to two ounces of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some Congressional Republicans said Thursday that they would increase their efforts to prevent residents here from possessing small amounts of marijuana, which became legal in Washington at midnight, and warned that the city would face numerous investigations and hearings should the mayor continue her practice of telling them to please find something else to worry about.

headline: Shakespeare’s First Folio to Get 50-State Tour
abstract: A book tour of sorts for Shakespeare to mark the 400th anniversary of his death.
lead_paragraph: Four hundred years after his death Shakespeare is getting a national book tour. The Folger Shakespeare Library throughout 2016 will be sending copies of the First Folio to libraries, museums and other places in all 50 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia as part of its yearlong “Wonder of Will” initiative.

headline: Fatality Rate Is Falling in West African Ebola Clinics
abstract: At Doctors Without Borders’ remaining treatment centers, the average death rate has fallen to 52 percent from 62 percent, and doctors are not sure why.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — As the Ebola epidemic in West Africa wanes, physicians from Doctors Without Borders are confronting a mystery: More of their patients are surviving. They do not know why.

headline: With Revamped Gold Cards, Bruised American Express Returns Focus to Affluent
