lead_paragraph: American Express, bruised by the recent loss of two major partnerships and an important court case, is seeking to reinvigorate its brand by sweetening the rewards on one of its most popular lines of cards.

headline: Judge Overturns Suspension of Adrian Peterson
abstract: The reversal was another setback for the N.F.L.’s commissioner, Roger Goodell, who had suspended the Vikings running back until at least April for disciplining his son with a switch.
lead_paragraph: A United States District Court judge overturned the suspension of Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson, who argued that he was unfairly penalized by the N.F.L. The reversal was another setback for the league’s commissioner, Roger Goodell, who had suspended Peterson until at least April 15 for disciplining his 4-year-old son with a switch in May.

headline: Wisconsin, Workers and the 2016 Election
abstract: Republicans’ support for anti-union legislation is at odds with their professed commitments to helping the middle class.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-dominated Senate in Wisconsin passed a bill this week to weaken the state’s private-sector unions. Similar to “right-to-work” laws in 24 other states, the bill would prevent unions from requiring dues or other fees from workers they represent in collective bargaining, a crippling constraint. The Republican-run State Assembly is expected to pass the bill next week, and Gov. Scott Walker, who stripped Wisconsin’s public employees of collective bargaining rights in 2011 and is now eyeing the Republican presidential nomination, has said he would sign it.

headline: Shooting Film and TV Sex Scenes: What Really Goes On
abstract: Judd Apatow, Amy Schumer, Adrian Lyne and other film professionals talk about the reality of shooting sex scenes for film and television.
lead_paragraph: To hear most actors tell it, filming sex scenes is no turn-on. There are big cameras, of course, and big crew members that come with them. It’s a performance with a stranger-turned-scene-partner, for a director who’s judging every caress and whimper. It’s the antithesis of hot, stars assure us on late-night TV; it’s awkward and tense. Speak to the filmmakers, though, and you get a different take.

abstract: As the calendar shifts to March over the weekend, places in New York offer an idea of the warmth and color to come.

The thermometer might not show any sign of change, but there are places in New York where you can get an idea of the warmth and color coming soon.

headline: China Bans Import of Ivory Carvings for One Year
abstract: A Chinese official said the moratorium would allow the government to evaluate if a ban helps protect African elephants.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a move aimed at countering international criticism of skyrocketing Chinese demand for ivory that is decimating African elephant populations, China announced on Thursday a one-year moratorium on the import of ivory carvings.

headline: Pat McGrath’s ‘New Elegance’ Beauty for Prada
abstract: The makeup artist took cues from the designer’s fall 2015 ladylike collection to create a look for today’s show.
lead_paragraph: This year Prada gave the legendary makeup artist Pat McGrath two words to work with: New Elegance. “We used a little bit of a kind of a soft chestnut color on the eyes in the sockets, and then the brow was softly groomed,” said McGrath backstage before today’s show. For the lips, she chose similarly muted hues: “a pale pink” and “a pale orange.” (She also noted that she used “a little bit of blush” over the lightly applied foundation to complete the look.) It was a stark contrast to the brand’s bold spring/summer 2015 look, which involved bleached eyebrows with striking cat-eye makeup. “It was very funny because last season was a nod to punk — and for Miu Miu we had bad girls,” she said, referring to her work with another Prada S.p.A.-owned label. “But this year it seems like they’re good girls.” And it’s true — the fall beauty look has a refinement that matches the ladylike air of the collection.

abstract: Scoring in college basketball is down, but Tim Cluess’s Gaels are averaging 80 points a game over the last four seasons and seeking their fourth N.C.A.A. tournament bid in five years.
lead_paragraph: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. — It was after one of Iona’s easiest practices of the season, in which the team spent about 45 minutes working on — gasp! — its halfcourt offense, when Coach Tim Cluess ambled over to a folding chair in the empty gym, crossed his legs and began to enumerate the reasons he disdained the current state of college basketball.

headline: A Judd Celebration of Trisha Brown Dance
abstract: The Judd Foundation and the Trisha Brown Dance Company have organized performances of five seminal pieces by Ms. Brown in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the desolate streets of SoHo were home to many brands of weirdness. (The character Paul Hackett, stranded there in Martin Scorsese’s “After Hours,” complains: “I just wanted to leave, you know, my apartment, maybe meet a nice girl. And now I’ve got to die for it?”) But even world-wise SoHo residents were stopped in their tracks by the early outdoor performances of the Trisha Brown Dance Company. In “Man Walking Down the Side of a Building” in 1970, a dancer used ropes and a harness to walk perpendicularly from the top to the bottom of a Wooster Street building. In “Roof Piece” (1971), performers positioned on rooftops over 10 blocks functioned like ancient signal fires, passing choreographic messages from street to street.

headline: Personalized Bottles, Ceramic Royals and Chinese Artifacts
abstract: A glass historian spent decades deciphering the codes of antique bottles.
lead_paragraph: The British glass historian David Burton has created a 1,740-page set of books to analyze a seemingly narrow topic: antique bottles that bear raised markings identifying the original owners. Mr. Burton, 77, has spent decades hunting for intact and broken vessels in private and institutional collections and deciphering their codes of numbers, letters and family coats of arms for his new three-volume set, “Antique Sealed Bottles 1640-1900 and the Families Who Owned Them” (Antique Collectors’ Club).

The film is set in Belfast during the Troubles, and this scene involves a British soldier (Mr. O’Connell) being chased through an apartment complex. Here, Mr. Demange discusses slowing down the pace of the sequence and, in relation to lighting, treating the scene almost like a horror movie.

headline: Louise Nevelson: ‘Collage and Assemblage’
abstract: An exhibition of early and late works casts Louise Nevelson more as a restless searcher than a high priestess of wood reliefs.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Louise Nevelson took up a fair amount of space in New York in the 1960s and early ’70s. She was one of the most prominent artists of her generation, known for her imperious personality and a penchant for false eyelashes, heavy jewelry and chinchilla capes. More important were her forward-looking wood reliefs, painted entirely black or white, which linked the found-object aesthetic of assemblage to the clean lines and orderly sequences of Minimalism (and also presaged the all-black assemblage sculptures of Rashid Johnson). But by the time she died at age 88 in 1988, the art world had moved on.

headline: Reading The Times With Paul Butler
abstract: Reading The New York Times with Paul Butler.
lead_paragraph: Paul Butler is a professor at Georgetown University Law Center. A former federal prosecutor, he is the author of “Let’s Get Free: A Hip-Hop Theory of Justice.”

headline: Merlin James: ‘Genre Paintings’
abstract: This show nods to art history while also featuring astral flourishes and alternatingly measured and exuberant strokes of color.
lead_paragraph: One of the quietly great painters of our moment, Merlin James works in ways both predictable and surprising. He has established his own lexicon of terms, which includes modestly sized canvases, atmospheric landscapes populated with partial figures and coy maneuvers into the picture’s shape and surface.

headline: ‘Jim Lee and the Cream Tones’
abstract: This show offers a subtle contemporary spin on the artistic impulse to remake or deconstruct mediums.
lead_paragraph: There have been many attempts over the years to merge painting and sculpture. Robert Rauschenberg’s combines — a neologism inspired by Alexander Calder’s mobiles — combined the two practices, while Donald Judd’s 1965 essay “Specific Objects” identified a similar hybrid strain in 1960s art. Jim Lee takes on the project with a certain humor and humility, acknowledging his predecessors but offering a subtle contemporary spin on the artistic impulse to remake or deconstruct mediums.

headline: ‘Pulp Drunk’: ‘Mexican Pulp Art’
abstract: Lurid and amusing paintings made by Mexican artists as covers for pulp fiction books are being shown at Ricco/Maresca gallery.
lead_paragraph: “Pulp Drunk: Mexican Pulp Art,” an exhibition of original paintings made for the covers of paperback novels of the 1960s and ’70s, is a hoot. It’s also psychologically and sociologically resonant. Most were done in tempera paints on cardboard by unidentified Mexican artists, who vividly pictured primal fantasies and anxieties dressed up in midcentury garb.

headline: In Analia Saban’s Unassuming Artwork, More Than Meets the Eye
abstract: The Argentine artist, whose work has drawn support from John Baldessari and Paul McCarthy, has two concurrent upcoming exhibitions in London and New York.
lead_paragraph: Her works may be beige, but Analia Saban’s practice is anything but boring. The Argentinean-born artist, who at 34 has studios in both Santa Monica, Calif., and Hell’s Kitchen, New York City, is destined for art historical legacy — if her mentors have anything to do with it. “John Baldessari is my main adviser,” she shares, in a chat on the eve of her first London exhibition, “Interiors,” with her long-time gallery Sprüth Magers, which opens Feb. 27. She also concurrently has a solo showing — her second — at Tanya Bonakdar in Chelsea, New York. Both shows feature her signature playful approach to art-making, which slips between genres and subverts traditional usage of materials. “When people start calling me a painter, this is the moment I need to shift. I like to think about where I am showing, I make the work for the space,” she says. “It’s really about experiencing the world and analyzing my own interpretation of what I am experiencing.”

headline: On Daring Do-Overs
abstract: Plus: Foreign-language eavesdropping, a mother and daughter’s relationship and an evaluation of a former colleague.
lead_paragraph: I went out with a girl for two years after college. I broke up with her when I thought I had met the love of my life. (I was wrong.) My original girlfriend took the breakup very badly. She refused contact with me and wouldn’t return my calls or texts. But now, several years later, I would like to ask her out again. I think she may be “the one.” Is there a polite and respectful way to do this?

headline: House and Senate Prepare Measures to Keep Homeland Security Funded
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The House is likely to counter a Senate bill with one that would extend the standoff into the next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just a day before the Department of Homeland Security is set to run out of money, the Senate was preparing a bill that would finance the department without restrictions on President Obama’s immigration actions. House Republicans were coming together on a counterproposal that would provide the agency with funds for only three weeks.

headline: Morals Clause in Catholic Schools Roils Bay Area
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Stem Cells (Embryonic)', 'Stem Cells']
abstract: The changes in the staff handbook, which say that teachers at Catholic high schools cannot challenge church teachings, including against homosexuality, have caused a backlash.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the issue that is stirring San Francisco: The archbishop has specified that teachers at four Bay Area Catholic high schools cannot publicly challenge the church’s teachings that homosexual acts are “contrary to natural law,” that contraception is “intrinsically evil” and that embryonic stem cell research is “a crime.” He also wants to designate teachers as part of the “ministry,” which could, under a 2012 Supreme Court ruling, strip them of protection under federal anti-discrimination laws.

headline: Deciding On a Parent’s Death
abstract: The call from my patient’s daughter wasn’t the first time a patient or family member had revealed to me a plan for an exit strategy.
lead_paragraph: The phone call came when these types of calls tend to come — late on a Friday afternoon at the tail end of a brutal Cleveland winter. I picked up the handset as I glanced outside my office windows at the accelerating snowfall, wondering whether I should leave work early.

headline: Review: New Museum Triennial Casts a Wary Eye on the Future
abstract: “Surround Audience,” organized by Ryan Trecartin and Lauren Cornell, features artists crossing borders and worried about what’s to come.
lead_paragraph: If you’re fed up with big joke-shop sculpture, diva spectacles and brain-dead abstraction, the New Museum’s 2015 Triennial, titled “Surround Audience,” will come as a break in the clouds. Not a full flood of new light, but a pull in a different direction, a microgravity shift in a gross-objects industry. It’s a glimpse, and just that, of terrain composed almost entirely of border crossings: between genders, media, disciplines, ethnicities and species. Welcome to Planet Trans.

headline: Review: ‘Everything Is Design’ Showcases Paul Rand, Master of Brand Identity
abstract: This art director and illustrator, called the Picasso of graphic design, is the subject of a show at the Museum of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: You may not know the name Paul Rand (1914-1996), the immensely influential 20th-century advertising art director, illustrator and graphic designer, but it’s a safe bet you’re familiar with some of his works. After shaking up American advertising and book cover design in the 1940s and ’50s, he created the logos for UPS, IBM, Westinghouse and other American corporations, symbols that remain ubiquitously familiar today. His admirers called him “the Picasso of graphic design”; the Museum of Modern Art named him one of the 10 best art directors of all time.

headline: Review: Julia Holter and the Spektral Quartet in the Ecstatic Music Festival
abstract: Ms. Holter and the quartet managed to stand out separately and together at the Ecstatic Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: First it was brusque, then eerie and sly. Julia Holter and the Spektral Quartet shared the Ecstatic Music Festival concert on Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall in a program that lingered in the cloudy zone where contemporary composition meets the pop song. In its sources and allusions, the concert took for granted the broad-spectrum musical erudition of current composers: hip-hop, medieval motets, Broadway, Impressionism, dubstep.

headline: Review: ‘Bright Half Life,’ a Two-Woman Play by Tanya Barfield
abstract: Ms. Barfield’s new drama at City Center explores a long-term relationship from start to finish, but not necessarily in that order.
lead_paragraph: Erica and Vicky like to play a game of questions that they call “A B C”: “What’s your favorite color?” Vicky asks. “If you had a superhero power what would it be?” “Do you think forwards or do you think backwards or do you think just ‘now’?”

headline: Bringing a Daughter Back From the Brink With Poems
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Parenting']
abstract: A mother’s project helps remind her daughter that life is worth living.
lead_paragraph: When George W. Bush was re-elected in 2004, my 13-year-old daughter, Marisa, was so angry that she stopped wearing shoes.

headline: Call From the I.R.S.? Hang Up. It’s a Fraud.
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service has tips for handling criminals who call pretending to be tax agents.
lead_paragraph: A spate of fraudulent state income tax returns filed using TurboTax’s online software has unnerved consumers this filing season. But con artists also continue to use more traditional means to try to separate taxpayers from their money, like harassing them on the telephone.

headline: Quantitative Easing and Monetary Aggregates
abstract: Hoocoodanode?
lead_paragraph: I haven’t had time for the broader discussion of cognitive closure, but one more thing about Meltzer and all that: I get especially annoyed when economists who have been wrongly predicting inflation say that it’s not their fault — who could have known that banks would just sit on all those reserves? The answer is, anyone who had paid attention should have known that would happen.

headline: Review: The Robert Glasper Trio Presents Moody Covers at the Village Vanguard
abstract: The ensemble played a sold-out set consisting of a mix of jazz standards and selections from a new album that recalibrates songs by other artists.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Robert Glasper pitches his tent at the junction of coolheaded logic and digressive caprice. Not long into his sold-out first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, he tossed off a staccato solo interlude, notes clacking like marbles out of a bag onto the floor. A melodic shape emerged, and bass and drums hit a single, sudden downbeat — thump! — as Mr. Glasper kept extemporizing with chromatic flair.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Enlisting Viruses as Commandos in a War on Cancer
abstract: The topic on “Vice Special Report: Killing Cancer” is less sexy and more universal than the “Vice” norm, and the approach is straightforward and relatively calm.
lead_paragraph: Through two seasons, “Vice,” the newsmagazine assembled by Vice Media and carried by HBO, has been a travelogue for the gonzo armchair tourist. It circles the globe to report on every variety of crisis — wars, drugs, the environment, rape in India, desperate bachelors in China.

headline: Scott Walker Speaks at CPAC
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spoke at the Conservative Political Action Conference on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin spoke at the Conservative Political Action Conference on Thursday.

headline: Scott Walker Suggests Protesters Have Prepared Him for Terrorists
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Thursday emphasized his record as governor and his ability to win elections at an annual conference of conservative activists.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: “We need a leader who will stand with Israel,” said the governor of Wisconsin.

headline: 'Jihadi John,' in His Own Words
abstract: Mohammed Emwazi, 26, who was identified as the ISIS militant known as “Jihadi John,” encountered British security forces on his path to radicalization.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Emwazi, 26, who was identified as the ISIS militant known as “Jihadi John,” encountered British security forces on his path to radicalization.

headline: Review: The Artist’s Studio, From Refuge to Gallery, in Shows at the Gagosian
abstract: The Gagosian Gallery has mounted not one but two museum-quality exhibitions in its space on West 21st Street in Chelsea and at its flagship gallery on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: In these days of post-studio, post-Internet artistry, of nomadic careers and collaborative cohorts, the artist’s studio can sometimes seem like a thing of the past, a relic from that bygone era before the supposed death of the author and the age of mechanical reproduction. But even if young artists work increasingly out of backpacks, on laptops or in tandem, alone time in a fairly private work space remains an essential condition for creativity.

headline: Pining for Handel’s ‘Alcina’ Sorceress, Coming to Lincoln Center on Film
abstract: Lincoln Center’s Great Voices on Film series includes an act from a Handel opera increasingly revived at Manhattan institutions, but not (yet) at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Bellini’s “I Capuleti e i Montecchi.” Mozart’s “La Finta Giardiniera.” Berlioz’s “Béatrice et Bénédict.” Rossini’s “Otello.” Verdi’s “I Due Foscari” and “Giovanna d’Arco,” not to mention his “Don Carlos” and “Les Vêpres Siciliennes” in their original French versions. Ligeti’s “Le Grand Macabre.” Philip Glass’s “Akhnaten.” Zimmermann’s “Die Soldaten.” Meredith Monk’s “Atlas.”

headline: Beethoven From Andsnes and the Mahler Chamber Orchestra
abstract: The Norwegian pianist Lief Ove Andsnes’s four-year Beethoven Journey bears fruit in an evening with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: By calling his four-year immersion into Beethoven, particularly that composer’s five piano concertos, the Beethoven Journey, the superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes tried to bring extra attention to the project. He also raised expectations.

headline: Review: In ‘Sex Box,’ Couples Reveal Their Issues in the Bedroom
abstract: On the new WE tv series, based on a British show, troubled couples receive advice from sex experts and then enter a box.
lead_paragraph: The premise of “Sex Box” is twofold. Troubled couples receive valuable advice from a panel of “leading sex and relationship experts.” They also have sex in a box, onstage, before a live audience. This is why groups like the Parents Television Council are giving the show free publicity by demanding its cancellation.

headline: ‘Sniper’ Case Is Headed to Appeal, Lawyers Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The lawyers for Eddie Ray Routh, who was sentenced to life for murdering Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL marksman, will argue that the movie’s publicity prevented their client from getting a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Lawyers for Eddie Ray Routh, the former Marine sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday for murdering Chris Kyle, the Navy SEAL marksman whose autobiography inspired the movie “American Sniper,” plan to ask a state appeals court to overturn the jury’s guilty verdict.

headline: Theater Listings for Feb. 27-March 5
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Winners of Pictures of the Year International
abstract: This year’s winners included coverage of overseas crises, innovative uses of multimedia storytelling, and outstanding editing.
lead_paragraph: This year’s winners included coverage of overseas crises, innovative uses of multimedia storytelling, and outstanding editing.

abstract: A selected guide to improv, stand-up and other comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in theaters, as well as a selected overview of film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, hip-hop and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to classical music performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Feb. 27-March 5
abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Bobby Jindal on Obamacare, ISIS and the Big Gulp
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal offered three “key points” at CPAC: Repeal “every single word” of Obamacare and Common Core, and double down on fighting the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: “President Obama has shown himself incapable of being our commander in chief,” said the governor of Louisiana.

headline: Review: In ‘The Lazarus Effect,’ Young Scientists Play God
abstract: Olivia Wilde stars as a researcher brought back from the dead in David Gelb’s horror thriller.
lead_paragraph: The researchers in “The Lazarus Effect” devise a serum that resurrects the dead by stimulating brain activity. The film itself seems best watched with as few neurons firing as possible.

headline: Spare Times Listings for Feb. 27-March 5
abstract: A selected guide to readings, discussions, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: First Draft Focus: Heeding the Countdown Clock
abstract: The countdown clock stopped ticking on Gov. Bobby Jindal.
lead_paragraph: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

headline: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 27-March 5
abstract: A selected guide to cultural events and activities for children, teenagers and families in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Kids Food Festival

headline: Senate Panel Clears Auto Safety Bill to Reward Whistle-Blowers
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: After a record number of recalls in 2014, the Senate Commerce Committee approved legislation that would give whistle-blowers a percentage of federal fines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate panel on Thursday cleared its first auto safety bill stemming from last year’s record number of recalls.

headline: Review: In ‘ ’71,’ Young, Green and Behind Enemy Lines
abstract: In Belfast, 1971 was an eventful year of demands and bloodshed, and it was not always clear who was the enemy.
lead_paragraph: In “ ’71,” an excitingly jumpy, finely calibrated chase movie about a British soldier caught behind enemy lines, the director Yann Demange goes from zero to 100 in the blink of an eye. The soldier is played by Jack O’Connell, last seen being brutalized (in more ways than one) in “Unbroken,” the Angelina Jolie biopic about Louis Zamperini. That movie proved a bad fit for Mr. O’Connell, who never put down roots in the character, an Olympian turned World War II captive, because Ms. Jolie couldn’t or wouldn’t let him. By contrast, Mr. O’Connell runs away with “ ’71,” in which his character’s every emotional, psychological and physical hurdle makes for kinetic cinema.

headline: 101-Year-Old Veteran Who Survived Home Invasion Dies in Canada
abstract: Canadian media reported that the veteran, Ernest Côté, who was tied up and robbed in his home in December, had died of natural causes.
lead_paragraph: The 101-year-old war veteran who was tied up and robbed in his Ottawa home in December, then left to suffocate with a plastic bag over his head, only to free himself and call the police, has died of natural causes, Canadian news outlets reported on Thursday.

headline: Bin Laden Aide Convicted of Conspiracy in 1998 East Africa Bombings
abstract: Khaled al-Fawwaz was charged with publicizing calls to kill Americans in plots that eventually included the bombings in Tanzania and Kenya that killed 224 people.
lead_paragraph: A Saudi who was accused of being one of Osama bin Laden’s earliest and most trusted lieutenants was convicted on Thursday of joining a global conspiracy to kill Americans that included Al Qaeda’s deadly 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa.

headline: Review: ‘Five Times in One Night,’ at Ensemble Studio Theater
abstract: Chiara Atik’s series of comedy sketches has a lewd title and a tender heart.
lead_paragraph: There were ample giggles throughout the first three parts of Chiara Atik’s “Five Times in One Night,” a series of comedy sketches with a lewd title and a tender heart at the Ensemble Studio Theater. But it was only in the fourth scene that wails and whimpers of pained recognition rang out. I saw women watching with hands over their mouths and one man who appeared to have shut his eyes entirely.

headline: Carlyle’s 3 Founders Got $800 Million Haul in 2014
abstract: The cash paid to David M. Rubenstein, Daniel A. D’Aniello and William E. Conway Jr. included dividends, base salary and investment profits.
lead_paragraph: The three founders of the private equity giant Carlyle Group received more than $800 million combined in 2014, a regulatory filing on Thursday showed.

headline: Review: In ‘The Salvation,’ a Hero Lays Waste, Western Style (Danish, Too)
abstract: Kristian Levring’s blood-soaked tale of an immigrant farmer’s showdown with a gang leader has all the classic touches of the genre.
lead_paragraph: A luridly beautiful, lavishly violent western, “The Salvation” takes place in an America shaped less by history than by the legacies of some of its chroniclers, from Sergio Leone to Clint Eastwood to Paul Thomas Anderson. Set in a nameless, dusty patch of the Southwest apparently forsaken by God as well as the law, it spins a far-fetched tale of a not-so-simple Danish homesteader, Jon (Mads Mikkelsen), turned avenger. Yes, there will be blood, as well as Eva Green as Madelaine, whose corset cups runneth over and tongue was once ripped out by her Indian captors.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Feb. 27, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “’71,” “The Hunting Ground” and “Maps to the Stars.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “’71,” “The Hunting Ground” and “Maps to the Stars.”

headline: Canada: Survivor of Home Invasion Dies
abstract: The 101-year-old war veteran who was tied up and robbed in his Ottawa home in December, then left to suffocate with a plastic bag over his head, only to free himself and call the police, has died of natural causes.
lead_paragraph: The 101-year-old war veteran who was tied up and robbed in his Ottawa home in December, then left to suffocate with a plastic bag over his head, only to free himself and call the police, has died of natural causes, Canadian news outlets reported Thursday. The attack on the veteran, Ernest Côté, attracted national attention. An investigation led to the arrest of a suspect, Ian Bush, who was also charged last week with a 2007 triple murder involving a break-in and suffocation with plastic bags.

headline: Movie Review: ‘’71’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “’71.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “’71.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Maps to the Stars’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Maps to the Stars.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Maps to the Stars.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Hunting Ground’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunting Ground.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Hunting Ground.”

headline: Review: In ‘Bluebird,’ Momentary Distraction Sets Off a Chain of Misery
abstract: In this film set in a Maine logging town, a school-bus driver deals with the repercussions of a tragic mistake.
lead_paragraph: “Blown by wind, kissed by the snow, all that’s left is the dark below.” Heard over the end titles of Lance Edmands’s “Bluebird,” those words from the Fleetwoods’ 1961 hit “Tragedy” distill the film’s desolate mood. Set during winter in Millinocket, a fading Maine logging town, this polar vortex of a movie opens with a quotation from Thoreau’s “The Maine Woods” that evokes human helplessness in the face of chaotic natural forces. Then it segues to shots of snow-covered logs transported by conveyor belt for conversion into pulp.

headline: In Unusual Step, Regulators Invite Public to Open Meeting on Bank Merger
abstract: Federal regulators and the chiefs of the CIT Group and OneWest got an earful on the need for more investment in the community, especially from two banks that got federal aid.
lead_paragraph: The deal seemed all but done when the CIT Group, a lender to small and midsize businesses, announced in July that it was acquiring OneWest, a regional bank in California.

headline: Review: In ‘Eastern Boys,’ a Train-Station Pickup Gone Wrong
abstract: Robin Campillo’s film stars Olivier Rabourdin as a French businessman and Kirill Emelyanov as the young man who turns an assignation into a home invasion.
lead_paragraph: “Eastern Boys,” the most compelling film to be shown at last year’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Lincoln Center and just now getting an American release, is impossible to shoehorn into a generic box. This story of a lonely middle-aged businessman whose involvement with a scrawny rent boy he meets at the Gare du Nord in Paris explores interlocking themes of sexuality, immigration and power dynamics with a cleareyed sensitivity and refuses to demonize even its shadiest characters.

headline: Global Deal to Release New Albums on Fridays
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: To help combat online piracy, the music industry’s global trade group has decided on Fridays as the official day to make new albums available.
lead_paragraph: For music fans in Britain, new albums come out on Mondays. In the United States, they typically hit stores on Tuesdays. In Japan, it’s Wednesdays.

headline: Review: ‘Young Bodies Heal Quickly’ Follows Brothers on the Run
abstract: Andrew T. Betzer’s debut feature joins a Mutt-and-Jeff pair of brothers on the lam as they ping-pong around the Maryland countryside.
lead_paragraph: Boasting the hectic aggression of a silent slapstick short — without the silence — “Young Bodies Heal Quickly” pants to keep up with its rambunctious antiheroes. This debut feature by Andrew T. Betzer joins a Mutt-and-Jeff pair of brothers on the lam as they ping-pong around the Maryland countryside and across genres: road movie, family drama, even war film.

headline: Judge in Batista’s Insider Trading Trial in Brazil Is Removed From Case
abstract: The court’s inspector general removed the judge, Flávio Roberto de Souza, after he was filmed driving a Porsche that the police had seized from Eike Batista.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian businessman Eike Batista won a court victory of sorts on Thursday when the judge who had been presiding over his trial was removed from the case after he was filmed driving Mr. Batista’s seized Porsche.

headline: Rebels Accuse Saudis of Fueling Unrest to Divide Yemen
abstract: The leader of the Houthi rebel group accused Saudi Arabia, Yemen’s powerful neighbor, of financing armed opponents and trying to divide the country.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The leader of the Houthi rebel group here, in an unusually combative speech Thursday that reflected frustration by the rebel movement at its deepening isolation, accused Saudi Arabia, Yemen’s powerful neighbor, of financing armed opponents and trying to divide the country.

headline: Review: ‘The Widowmaker,’ a Heart Care Documentary
abstract: Patrick Forbes’s film looks at doctors’ treatment recommendations after heart attacks, comparing the coronary calcium scan with the more expensive, more frequently used surgically implanted stent.
lead_paragraph: By now the average health care consumer perhaps understands that treatment recommendations from a doctor may be influenced by research grants, financial interests and other personal entanglements. “The Widowmaker,” a documentary by Patrick Forbes, takes a lengthy look at that phenomenon as it relates to heart attacks, promoting the coronary calcium scan, a noninvasive procedure that faced years of resistance because the medical establishment preferred the surgically implanted stent. The film’s only problem is that it may leave you so skeptical that you’re not sure you’re getting the unbiased story on the scan, either.

headline: Amazon Hires Jay Carney, Former Obama Press Secretary
abstract: Amazon has hired Mr. Carney as senior vice president for global corporate affairs. The move is unusual, as Amazon is known for grooming employees from within.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, a technology company obsessed with secrecy, is hiring a former press secretary for President Obama, whose administration has been widely criticized for its aggressive leak investigations.

headline: Review: In ‘Futuro Beach,’ a Haunted Lifeguard Searches for Peace
abstract: This elliptical gay romance by the Brazilian writer and director Karim Aïnouz follows its heroes from the warmly golden beach of the title to the cool dampness of Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Within minutes of opening, “Futuro Beach” has followed death with sex and the loss of a friend with the gain of a lover. None of these events feel particularly momentous, however, in a film that ravishes the eye but keeps the heart at arm’s length.

headline: Review: ‘Out of the Dark,’ With Julia Stiles and Scott Speedman
abstract: In this film, a young London family moves to Bogotá only to be vexed by the supernatural and the disappearance of a daughter.
lead_paragraph: The sweat of three writers and the acting chops of Stephen Rea still don’t come close to earning “Out of the Dark” a passing grade. Derivative and devoid of tension, this stagy first feature from the Spanish director Lluís Quílez mystifies solely on account of its R rating. When a movie this lacking in sex and scares can share a rating with the “Saw” franchise, the entire system announces its irrelevance.

headline: Dutch Offer Preview of Net Neutrality
abstract: As with the rules adopted by the F.C.C., the Netherlands demands that wireless and fixed-line broadband providers treat all Internet traffic equally.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — When Bruno Leenders takes the 50-minute train ride to Amsterdam, he likes to stream blues and funk music through his smartphone. At home, Mr. Leenders, a Dutch technology consultant, watches Steven Seagal action movies on Netflix. Between meetings, he dashes off a few emails.

headline: Ariel Camacho, Lead Singer of Los Plebes del Rancho, Dies at 22
abstract: Mr. Camacho, who played guitar and wrote songs as well as singing, was idolized by youngsters in rural Mexico and had begun amassing a fan base on the other side of the border.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Ariel Camacho, the lead singer of the popular norteño group Los Plebes del Rancho, died in a car accident early Wednesday on a highway near the Mexican state of Sinaloa. He was 22.

headline: Obama Promotes Benefits of Trade Deals to Workers and Smaller Businesses
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Small Business', 'Law and Legislation', 'North American Free Trade Agreement']
abstract: Facing a battle to persuade Congress to grant him new authority, the president tried to ease concerns that such agreements would help corporations at the expense of others.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing an uphill climb in persuading Congress to grant him the authority to complete significant trade deals, sought to ease concerns on Thursday that such agreements would help corporations at the expense of American workers.

headline: U.N. Official Seeks Havens for Syrians
abstract: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees said that European countries must accept more Syrian refugees to dissuade them from making a perilous journey across the Mediterranean Sea.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations high commissioner for refugees said Thursday that European countries must accept more Syrian refugees to dissuade them from boarding overcrowded boats for a perilous journey across the Mediterranean Sea to escape the war in Syria as “the level of despair rises.”

headline: After a Stirring Introduction, Chase Headley Hopes for a Steady Follow-Up Season
abstract: Headley has been everything that Alex Rodriguez is not since Headley joined the Yankees, and Headley is hoping for improved offensive production as he takes over at third base.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As Alex Rodriguez stood a few feet away and signed autographs for dozens of clamoring fans on Thursday, Chase Headley skipped down the steps of the dugout, deposited his bat and helmet, and grabbed a glove before heading to the outfield. He did so all but unnoticed.

headline: Why FIFA Made Deal With Fox for 2026 Cup
abstract: When FIFA sold the 2026 World Cup rights in the United States to Fox Sports and Telemundo earlier this month, the announcement came with few details and no explanation for its timing.
lead_paragraph: When FIFA sold the 2026 World Cup rights in the United States to Fox Sports and Telemundo this month, the announcement came with few details and no explanation for its timing.

headline: 4 Different Turnaround Tales at Retailers Sears, Kohl’s, Gap and J.C. Penney
abstract: The four large retailers are all in the middle of comeback efforts, but they are each experiencing widely varying results, some positive, others much less so.
lead_paragraph: Four retailers, four turnaround bids — and they could not be more different.

headline: These New York Tourists’ Plans: A Play, Then a Power Play
abstract: The Coyotes, the Canucks and the Flames took up residency in the metropolitan area over the past two weeks but did more than visit the Devils, the Islanders and the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: The athletic-looking group of men at “Jersey Boys” on Wednesday consisted of Arizona Coyotes players enjoying a day off. The 6-foot-2 Swede taking selfies in the N.H.L. store in Midtown was the Arizona defenseman Oliver Ekman-Larsson. Tables at Mr. Chow in TriBeCa and Del Frisco’s Grille near Rockefeller Center were recently filled by professional hockey players, some on their way to “The Book of Mormon.”

headline: Secret Marijuana Farm Beneath Brooklyn Cherry Factory Leaves Many Mysteries
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Cherries']
abstract: Days after discovering the illegal operation inside Dell’s Maraschino Cherries Company, investigators had many questions, including how the owner, Arthur Mondella, distributed the drugs.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Mondella’s alternate life was buried behind a roll-down gate, behind a fleet of fancy cars, behind a pair of closet doors, behind a set of button-controlled steel shelves, behind a fake wall and down a ladder in a hole in a bare concrete floor.

headline: Rivals Christie and Walker Find Fortunes Reversed as CPAC Opens
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On the first day of the conference, the contrasting standings of Scott Walker and Chris Christie in the early stages of the 2016 campaign reveal how quickly perceptions of the race can change.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — In the early stages of the 2016 Republican presidential primary, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is the hot property, his poll numbers rising and the chatter from activists and contributors growing steadily more positive. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is the mirror opposite, his political stock falling along with his standing in surveys of Republicans.

headline: Historians Pore Over ISIS Video of Smashed Statues for Clues to What’s Been Lost
abstract: Video released by the Islamic State shows jihadists taking sledgehammers and electric drills to ancient statuary in the city of Mosul.
lead_paragraph: Confronted with the latest video news release from Islamic State militants in Iraq, which shows jihadists taking sledgehammers and electric drills to ancient statuary in the city of Mosul, historians and archaeologists spent much of Thursday studying the footage for clues as to what, exactly, had been lost.

headline: U.S. Push for Abstinence in Africa Is Seen as Failure Against H.I.V.
abstract: The government’s $1.3 billion program to stop H.I.V. infection in Africa is not cost effective, a new study by a Stanford student shows.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The $1.3 billion that the United States government has spent since 2005 encouraging Africans to avoid AIDS by practicing abstinence and fidelity did not measurably change sexual behavior and was largely wasted, according to a study presented on the last day of an AIDS conference here.

headline: An Immodest Proposal Rankles a Capital Known for Modesty
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: A proposal to build an immense memorial in Ottawa to the global victims of Communism has prompted protests from architects, the mayor and the country’s chief justice.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — You can make out Canadians’ reputation for modesty in their capital, a city that has largely avoided erecting anything you might call monumental. None of Ottawa’s landmarks are built on the grand scale of, say, the Arc de Triomphe or the Washington Monument — not even the national war memorial or the tower of the main Parliament building in the city center.

headline: Move to Ban a Bullet Adds to Its Appeal
abstract: The Obama administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of a popular bullet used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of one of the most popular bullets used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun-rights advocates and caused a run on the ammunition at gun shops across the country.

headline: Practicing in the Dark, Some Early Starters Grumble at the Honda Classic
abstract: The first 18 players on the course prepared for their rounds in near or total darkness, which was easy to overlook on a day when afternoon gusts swept several of the world’s best golfers off course, including top-ranked Rory McIlroy.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — An hour before his scheduled tee time, Ben Crane stood over a putt on the practice green while his caddie, Joel Stock, lined up behind him and used his smartphone to shed a little light on the situation. Only by the glow of Stock’s phone was Crane able to see the hole.

headline: Devils Send Jaromir Jagr to Panthers for Two Draft Picks
abstract: Florida will be the eighth N.H.L. team for Jagr, 43, who had 96 points in 139 games over one and a half seasons in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The Devils traded Jaromir Jagr to the Florida Panthers on Thursday for two draft picks.

headline: Review: ‘An Octoroon,’ a Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Comedy About Race
abstract: This coruscating play, restaged at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center, is a modern examination of a slave-era melodrama.
lead_paragraph: Walking on a stage covered with cotton balls is a tricky business. It’s all too easy to slip into a pratfall. And forget about running or dancing or hopping like a bunny, as the characters sometimes unwisely attempt in “An Octoroon,” Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s coruscating comedy of unresolved history, which opened on Thursday night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

headline: The Panda’s Thumb
abstract: A fairly wide open puzzle from Julian Lim.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Wow, talk about a high price of admission. I worked hard to get a toehold in Julian Lim’s Friday 62-word puzzle, but there’s always a way, isn’t there? There’s not much sense in having a puzzle no one can solve.

lead_paragraph: One result of the spread of digital music around the world is an explosion in the amount of data generated from all those billions of clicks and streams — and a resulting need to follow all this information accurately.

abstract: The tentative agreement is the latest indicator of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s bid to move beyond the police conflict that recently consumed his administration.
lead_paragraph: New York City has reached a contract agreement with the sergeants’ union, the latest signpost in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s bid to move beyond the police conflict that recently consumed his administration.

headline: Testifying in His Own Defense, Terror Suspect Starts Strong Before Faltering
abstract: Pressed by a prosecutor in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, Abid Naseer tried to cling to his assertion that emails to a certain address were merely in pursuit of women.
lead_paragraph: Abid Naseer, charged with terrorism, presented himself on Wednesday and Thursday as a studious, middle-class Pakistani, a suburban teenager who enjoyed American movies and was a semiprofessional cricket player.

lead_paragraph: The conference opened on Thursday outside Washington.

abstract: “La Coiffeuse,” or “The Hairdresser,” had been missing from Paris for more than a decade. It resurfaced in December in a FedEx shipment from Belgium.
lead_paragraph: A Picasso painting missing from Paris for more than a decade resurfaced in the United States, where it had been shipped under false pretenses as a $37 holiday-themed “art craft.”

lead_paragraph: The aunt of a 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested and charged with manslaughter on Thursday after the medical examiner’s office ruled that the child had been beaten to death.

headline: Terry Collins Sets Aside Cheerleading for Measured Tone
abstract: Collins, the Mets manager, talked to his players about becoming a team that will be playoff relevant as July turns into August.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The 2015 Mets officially convened for the first time Thursday. Matt Harvey and David Wright were back and healthy. Bobby Parnell was on his way back. And optimism was in abundance, although it often is at the start of spring training, no matter how strong or weak a team might be.

headline: Rangers’ Victory Pleases a Coach, but Not His Son
abstract: Henrik Samuelsson, the son of the Rangers assistant coach Ulf Samuelsson, made his N.H.L. debut against the Rangers, who are tied with the Islanders atop the Metropolitan Division after Thursday’s win.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers assistant coach Ulf Samuelsson was reviewing scouting reports on the Coyotes on Wednesday afternoon when a phone call interrupted him. On the line was his younger son, Henrik, who told him, “You better throw another guy in the loop there.”

lead_paragraph: Images from films in the festival.

headline: Irving Kahn, Oldest Active Wall Street Investor, Dies at 109
abstract: Mr. Kahn was a contrarian adherent who left Lehman Brothers in 1978 to open Kahn Brothers Group with two of his sons.
lead_paragraph: Irving Kahn, who made his first stock trade in June 1929 — turning a tidy profit from the stock market crash four months later — and persevered for more than eight decades to become Wall Street’s oldest living active professional investor, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 109.

headline: Appellate Ruling Supports a Police Whistle-Blower in New York
abstract: Officer Craig Matthews’s lawsuit alleging that superiors at a Bronx precinct retaliated against him for complaining about a quota system on arrests and stops may proceed, federal judges decided.
lead_paragraph: In a free-speech case that could bolster whistle-blowers, a federal appeals court ruled on Thursday in favor of a New York City police officer who said his commanders retaliated against him after he complained to them about what he believed to be a quota system that resulted in unjustified stops and arrests.

headline: Review: In ‘Focus,’ a Grifter (Will Smith) as Life Coach
abstract: Mr. Smith plays a seasoned con man who schools a novice (Margot Robbie) in more sophisticated scams.
lead_paragraph: A silky high-end caper about a pair of good-looking con artists, “Focus” is a movie blessedly free of self-importance. It constructs a seductive fantasy world out of actual places (New Orleans, Buenos Aires) and milieus (Super Bowl skyboxes, Formula One racing) and generously grants V.I.P. access to the audience. You may be a few steps behind as the big scams unfold, but you feel more like a player than a sucker. The preposterousness of the story doesn’t seem like a rip-off, since the twists in the plot, for the most part, pay off nicely.

headline: In Trip to Past, a False Confession Claim Meets Skepticism of Another Sort
abstract: Johnny Hincapie, who says he was wrongly convicted of murder in the killing of Utah tourist Brian Watkins in 1990, faced tough questioning at a hearing on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The video monitor switched off. Seated on the witness stand, Johnny Hincapie, 42, took off his eyeglasses and began to weep. Everyone around him in the seventh-floor courtroom in Manhattan fell silent. After 40 seconds or so, a phone rang, and a court clerk answered, whispering, “Part 73.” The sobbing continued. Mr. Hincapie had just finished watching a video of himself at age 18, confessing to being part of a group that had mugged a family of tourists in a Midtown Manhattan subway station and killed the valiant son who had resisted.

headline: The Sake Evangelist
abstract: A Portland resident’s mission: to change the way sake is brewed in America. Meet Gordon Heady.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Heady likens the taste of American sake to “jet fuel,” something he intends to change by becoming the country’s first master brewer. The Portland native was introduced to rice wine in college — the Japanese students he tutored in English paid him in bottles — and in 2012, he visited the southern island of Kyushu and fell in love with the 316-year-old brewery Wakatakeya Shuzo. Heady, who speaks about sake with reverence — “it’s the drink of the gods” — has since returned as an apprentice for about six months each year during brewing season. “The brewers are wizards who use fermentation to bring rice to its highest purpose,” he says. Fittingly, the blend he brews there — with notes of cooked citrus and wet wool — is called A Zen Ai Koshu, or “Love.”

headline: Word of the Day | optional
abstract: This word has appeared in 529 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: optional • \ˈäp-shnəl, -shə-nəl\ • adjective

headline: William Dieterle’s ‘Syncopation’ on DVD: Bending Notes and Jazz History
abstract: Dieterle’s 1942 film emphasized jazz as an intrinsically African-American art form, even as it played loosely with some of the music’s history.
lead_paragraph: Motion pictures and jazz were both born around the dawn of the 20th century. But did Hollywood ever get the music right? Take “Syncopation” (1942), a snappily titled, wildly ambitious jazz chronicle that might be the last thing you’d expect from Warner Bros.’ German-born workhorse, William Dieterle (1893-1972).

headline: Joel Potrykus’s Film ‘Buzzard’ Is Inspired by Dead-End Jobs
abstract: The writer and director’s deadpan comedies have followed a man-child on the skids.
lead_paragraph: Marty, the abrasive antihero of “Buzzard,” is not out to win employee of the month — quite the opposite. A temporary worker in the mortgage department of a Midwestern bank, he closes his checking account and opens a new one to take advantage of a $50 promotional offer. He returns office supplies for profit. After cutting himself in a poorly conceived attempt to attach Freddy Krueger blades to a Nintendo Power Glove, he fakes an injury at work to get the medical costs covered.

headline: Winners of Pictures of the Year International
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Ebola Virus', 'Photography']
abstract: This year’s winners included coverage of overseas crises, innovative uses of multimedia storytelling, and outstanding editing.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Berehulak, a freelance photographer for The New York Times, was named Photographer of the Year in the reportage category of the Pictures of the Year International contest. Brad Vest, of the Memphis Commercial Appeal, was named Newspaper Photographer of the Year.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:55 A.M. (MoreMax) MOONRISE KINGDOM (2012) In this Wes Anderson tale, 12-year-old Suzy (Kara Hayward) and her soul mate, Sam (Jared Gilman), fall in love and run away, while on an island, sending the adults in charge — Suzy’s parents (the Bishops, played by Bill Murray and Frances McDormand), Scout Master Ward (Edward Norton) and Captain Sharp (Bruce Willis) — into a panic as a storm approaches. “Written by Mr. Anderson and Roman Coppola (they worked together several times before), ‘Moonrise Kingdom’ breezes along with a beautifully coordinated admixture of droll humor, deadpan and slapstick,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But, she added, as in all of Mr. Anderson’s films, “there’s a deep, pervasive melancholia here, too, a sense of regret evident in Mr. Bishop’s slouch (with his plaid pants, he is a walking John Cheever tragedy) and in the way Captain Sharp and Mrs. Bishop look, and don’t look, at each other. Adulthood can seem so desperately painful, so maybe Sam and Suzy shouldn’t be quite as eager to grow up.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, February 27, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “There are no rules as to how long cases should cook, no recipe. Lots of factors must be weighed.”

headline: What to Expect on the Third Day of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Philosophy — the study of thought — has had an unusual presence at Milan Fashion Week this season.
lead_paragraph: Philosophy — the study of thought — has had an unusual presence at Milan Fashion Week this season. It has hung in the air ever since Alessandro Michele, Gucci’s new creative director, cited Roland Barthes in the show notes of his first women’s show, the first major show of the week. It made you wonder, what is the thought that runs through Fashion Week? Silly or not — Mr. Michele had to admit, “I’m not really interested about philosophy” — these designers are the ones we trust to push fashion forward. It’s reassuring to know that they’re thinking about clothes.

headline: Hopeful Signs of Recovery for the World’s Rarest Big Cat
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Leopards', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Tigers']
abstract: Thanks to conservation efforts in Russia and China, the Amur leopard population has increased dramatically, though with only a few dozen in the wild, the species still faces threats to its survival.
lead_paragraph: While poaching and environmental degradation have had disastrous effects on animal species across Asia, one highly endangered cat has seen a small but important rise in its numbers, researchers say.

headline: Hong Kong Woman Sentenced to 6 Years for Abusing Indonesian Maid
abstract: Law Wan-tung subjected her live-in servant, Erwiana Sulistyaningsih, to various forms of abuse for months, according to testimony at her trial.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong woman convicted of beating and threatening her Indonesian maid was sentenced to six years in prison on Friday, in a case that focused attention on the treatment of domestic servants here.

headline: Converting the Ayatollahs
abstract: The nuclear negotiations with Iran are based on misguided premises and could have disastrous outcomes.
lead_paragraph: Over the past centuries, Western diplomats have continually projected pragmatism onto their ideological opponents. They have often assumed that our enemies are driven by the same sort of national interest calculations that motivate most regimes. They have assumed that economic interests would trump ideology and religion — that prudent calculation and statecraft would trump megalomania.

headline: Happy Talk History
abstract: This assault on young people’s intelligence is anti-American. If you believe in American exceptionalism, then empower students with the critical thinking to defend it.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — This state has an extraordinary history. It’s where the Trail of Tears ended, and the Sooner land rush began. It suffered human-caused climate change at the most extreme — the Dust Bowl — and produced the wit and wisdom of Will Rogers. In all, the Oklahoma story is a compelling part of the national narrative.

headline: Nothing Is Wrong With Your Sex Drive
abstract: We don’t need drugs based on mistaken ideas about how desire works.
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. — LAST week, Sprout Pharmaceuticals resubmitted its drug flibanserin to the Food and Drug Administration for approval. Flibanserin, in case you haven’t heard, is a drug intended to treat low sexual desire in women. The F.D.A. has rejected it twice already, and will most likely reject it a third time because (if you’re Sprout) the F.D.A. is sexist or (if you’re the F.D.A.) the drug doesn’t work and isn’t safe.

headline: What Greece Won
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Why all the negative analysis about the debt deal that has actually done the rest of Europe a favor?
lead_paragraph: Last week, after much drama, the new Greek government reached a deal with its creditors. Earlier this week, the Greeks filled in some details on how they intend to meet the terms. So how did it go?

headline: Food Waste Grows With the Middle Class
abstract: The estimated one-third of food left uneaten is a serious threat to the global environment and economy.
lead_paragraph: Massive food waste by humanity is an undisputed fact documented daily in tons of discarded scrapings from dinner plates around the world. It is now being measured as a serious threat to the global environment and economy, with an estimated one-third of all the food produced in the world left uneaten at a cost of up to $400 billion a year in waste disposal and other government costs.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Expansion
abstract: The country could soon have 100 nuclear weapons, according to a new report, and America and its partners need to find ways to curb their production.
lead_paragraph: North Korea could be on track to have an arsenal of 100 nuclear weapons by 2020, according to a new research report. The prediction, from experts on North Korea, goes well beyond past estimates and should force renewed attention on a threat that has been eclipsed by other crises.

headline: Libraries of Life
abstract: Specimen libraries are vital for biology. So why are museums being forced to cut their funding?
lead_paragraph: HIDDEN behind the popular displays at many of your favorite natural history museums — in their basements, back rooms and, increasingly, off-site facilities — sit humanity’s most important libraries of life, holding not books but preserved animal and plant specimens, carefully collected over centuries by thousands of scientist explorers.

headline: Sit, Sparky, Stay. Good Dog! (Can I Dream?)
abstract: Beagle owners respond, lovingly, to a Sunday Review essay.

headline: Community Colleges That Work
abstract: A rigorous new study makes it clear that the approach taken by the City University of New York system could serve as a national model.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama called last month for making community college tuition-free for millions of students, he pointed out that graduation rates would have to improve to make the investment worthwhile. He also noted that the City University of New York system had already shown the way, with a program that has raised not just graduation rates but the rate at which students move on to four-year degrees. A rigorous new study released this week by MDRC, a nonpartisan research group, makes it clear that the CUNY approach, which offers students a network of support, could serve as a national model.

headline: A Town Where a School Bus Is More Than a Bus
abstract: Bus drivers, when trained to be welcoming and understanding, can help children begin their school day more ready to learn.
lead_paragraph: For the bulk of her career, Lavonda Thompson, a 48-year old bus driver and school custodian in Hartsville, S.C., never questioned either her role or the larger system she was serving. “My job was to drive the bus and clean the buildings,” she said. “The child’s job was to act respectful and follow directions.”

headline: Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, 97, Dies; Lifted Notre Dame and Advised Presidents
abstract: He stood up to the White House and the Vatican as he transformed Catholic higher education in America and raised a powerful moral voice in national affairs.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the strong-minded former president of the University of Notre Dame who stood up to both the White House and the Vatican as he transformed Catholic higher education in America and raised a powerful moral voice in national affairs, died late Thursday in South Bend, Ind. He was 97.

headline: How Liberalism and Racism Are Wed
keywords: ['Asian-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Philosophy', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Racism, racial exclusion and racial violence aren’t antithetical to liberalism. They are an essential part of it.
lead_paragraph: This is the seventh in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Falguni A. Sheth, an associate professor of philosophy and political theory at Hampshire College. She is the author of “Toward a Political Philosophy of Race.” — George Yancy

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday that it returned to a profit in 2014 as it prepared to pay its first dividend since the lender was bailed out by the British government during the financial crisis.

lead_paragraph: In “In France, a Baby Switch and a Lesson in Maternal Love,” Maïa de la Baume writes about a real-life tale of swapped newborns.

abstract: This insult of a month may be the coldest February in New York City in more than 80 years, the National Weather Service says.
lead_paragraph: It will end. Allegedly.

headline: What Should Be the Purpose of Prison?
abstract: Should jails and prisons punish people? Should they serve as a deterrent to crime? Or should they try to rehabilitate people — and help them get back on their feet?
lead_paragraph: More people are spending time in jail (PDF) because they don’t have enough money to pay fines or post bail, or because they are too ill with mental health or drug problems to adequately care for themselves, according to a new report. And the United States prison population is near a record high (PDF) even though violent crime nationally has fallen by nearly 50 percent and property crime has dropped by more than 40 percent from its peak. All this raises an important question:

headline: On Nantucket, Surf’s Up, if You’re Part Penguin
abstract: A photographer captured slushy waves in Massachusetts, a wintry phenomenon that even some glaciologists could not fully explain.
lead_paragraph: How cold has it been on Nantucket? Chilly enough to freeze waves.

headline: After Scandal, Petraeus Stays Under Radar, but Not Out of the Spotlight
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Facing an inquiry that could send him to prison, David H. Petraeus, the former C.I.A. chief, keeps a lower profile as White House adviser, college teacher and partner at a private equity firm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the top American military commander who oversaw the Middle East and Central Asia, Gen. David H. Petraeus worked hard to court the political elite in Kazakhstan. So the first time he met there with President Nursultan Nazarbayev, he made a joke to dispel fears that the United States had designs on the region’s oil.

headline: Beijing Courts Address the Right to Criticize Public Figures
abstract: Two recent court rulings, and Kong Qingdong’s refusal to comply with one of them, have prompted a debate about the extent to which public figures can be held accountable for their statements, and the right of ordinary citizens to criticize such figures.
lead_paragraph: In a political environment where public discourse is constrained by layers of censorship and self-censorship, Kong Qingdong, a neo-Maoist literary scholar at Peking University and an avid blogger, has long attracted attention with his vociferous commentaries.

headline: Exxon Settles $9 Billion Pollution Case in New Jersey for Far Less
abstract: The agreement emerged as a judge was believed to be close to ruling on damages for the contamination and loss of use of more than 1,500 acres of wetlands, marshes, meadows and waters.
lead_paragraph: A long-fought legal battle to recover $8.9 billion in damages from Exxon Mobil Corporation for the contamination and loss of use of more than 1,500 acres of wetlands, marshes, meadows and waters in northern New Jersey has been quietly settled by the state for around $250 million.

headline: Westminster’s Rule No. 1: Don’t Outshine the Dog
keywords: ['Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Dogs']
abstract: At the Kennel Club Dog Show, the handlers try hard to look good — but not too good.
lead_paragraph: Black? Cream? Erin Roberts stared at the clothing strewn across her bed. Years of experience were being brought to bear on this decision.

headline: Making Old Vegetables New Again
abstract: Aging vegetables can be revived by cooking or simmering them with bulger and rice, writes Martha Rose Shulman.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend it was time to reach into my vegetable crisper, pull out the lingering produce and use things up. I try not to buy more than what I need for recipe testing, but sometimes my imagination gets ahead of me and I soon find myself with a pile-up of vegetables that never made it into a recipe. I am sure this happens all the time with those of you who receive weekly CSA allotments. You have barely made a crack in one shipment when the next one comes in.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Review: Sleater-Kinney at Terminal 5
abstract: The three-woman band — Corin Tucker and Carrie Brownstein on lead vocals and guitars, Janet Weiss on drums and backup vocals — is on its first tour since the group dissolved in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Sleater-Kinney has made sure that its first tour since the band dissolved in 2006 is a resumption, not merely a reunion. At Terminal 5 in New York on Thursday night, opening a sold-out two-night stand, there wasn’t a hint of self-congratulation or nostalgia: just the same joyfully adamant spirit, odd-angled indie-rock, headlong momentum, banshee intensity and sense of purpose. The three-woman band — Corin Tucker and Carrie Brownstein on lead vocals and guitars, Janet Weiss on drums and backup vocals — was still thinking as hard as it was slamming out its songs.

headline: Germany Backs 4-Month Extension of Greece’s Bailout
abstract: The German finance minister urged lawmakers to support the move to ensure Europe’s future success, even as he conceded that doing so was “not easy for me.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German lawmakers voted overwhelmingly on Friday to extend the terms of Greece’s bailout by four months, despite growing misgivings over Athens’s willingness to make economic overhauls viewed in Berlin as necessary to ensure a long-term recovery.

headline: New York Today: Twilight of the Ice Age
abstract: Friday and the weekend: A salute to ice, gradually warming weather, and a look inside the lives of the men accused of supporting ISIS.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this frosted Friday.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission voted on Thursday to regulate broadband Internet service as a public utility, a milestone in regulating high-speed Internet service into American homes, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Steve Lohr report.

lead_paragraph: The first novel I really fell in love with I rescued from being used as toilet paper.

lead_paragraph: A generation too young to remember dial-up modems rediscovers the old, weird Internet.

headline: Re: The Student and the Mentor
abstract: A complex story about power and sex showed the difficulty that universities face in examining rape charges.
lead_paragraph: “The Stanford Undergraduate and Her Mentor,” Emily Bazelon’s Feb. 15 cover story about the fallout from a relationship between a student and a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, was an examination of the difficulties in addressing rape and sexual assault on college campuses. “What’s fascinating,” Matt Milliken wrote on Twitter, was “how my sympathies shifted over the course of the article.”

headline: ‘Moth Orchids’
abstract: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Georgia O’Keeffe’s paintings showed us how sensual flowers could be. Ellen Bass’s poem does this, too, reminding us of the power of metaphor: how one thing is like another, how desire can be reflected in the way we see and how our sustained attention — to language, to the things of this world — can reward us again and again. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: In Greenbacks We Trust
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Federal Reserve is playing a mind game — but with enormous real-world consequences.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. dollar, as we know it today, was born in terror. On April 18, 1906, the Pacific tectonic plate, which extends under the ocean from Japan to central California, darted northward about 20 feet in just under a minute; in San Francisco, buildings that were not shattered by the earthquake burned, and within two days, 80 percent of the city was gone. At the time, American companies and governments still bought insurance from the old British firms, and the payouts to San Francisco were enormous. As was standard practice, the insurers paid in gold, shipping $65 million worth of bars — an estimated 107 tons, representing 14 percent of all British gold reserves — to the Bay Area. Afraid that all that gold leaving its vaults would permanently impoverish the kingdom, the Bank of England doubled interest rates on British bonds. In response, so many wealthy Americans sent money to England that, a few months after the gold came west from London, $30 million in U.S. gold traveled east. The British vaults were replenished, while the U.S. stock fell by 10 percent in two months.

headline: How to Remember People’s Names
abstract: A little homework ahead of time doesn’t hurt.
lead_paragraph: If you are the name-forgetting type, you probably spend a fair amount of time feeling unmoored in a sea of vaguely familiar faces. Indira Pun does not have this problem. “Sometimes I see a guest I have not seen for years, and right away I know their name,” says Pun, chief concierge at the Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong. “I exercise that like a muscle.” After 11 years in the business and thousands of names committed to memory, Pun has a few name-recollection-workout suggestions.

headline: When Did ‘You’re Welcome’ Become a Gloat?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'English Language', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: What was once an authentic response to “thank you” has come to mean something more sinister.
lead_paragraph: In 1947, the Friendship Train left Los Angeles bound for Europe. The train crossed North America, picking up boxcars of Colorado wheat, Nebraska beans and Wisconsin condensed milk. By the time it reached New York, the Friendship Train had amassed $40 million in donations of food, clothing and fuel from people across the country, which were loaded onto ships headed for Italy and France, then transferred onto local trains festooned with American flags. The beneficiaries — starving from a post-World War II food shortage and increasingly vulnerable to creeping Soviet power — knew exactly where their free lunch had come from.

abstract: “It is at least not an escape from the human world. It is, in fact, an escape to the human world.”

headline: Can a Stock-Trader-Turned-Convict Start a New Life?
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Hedge Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Roomy Khan made a pile of money trading on inside information. Then she cooperated with the F.B.I. Where does she go from here?
lead_paragraph: One day in the middle of 2008, Sakhawat Khan, a Silicon Valley chip engineer, walked into a small house near the back of his two-acre property that his wife, Roomy, a stock trader, used as a home office. Roomy and Sakhawat met when they were electrical-engineering students at Columbia University. After graduating, Sakhawat started inventing, eventually gathering some 30 semiconductor patents to his name. Roomy, who was more outgoing in social situations and more restless in her appetite for risk, was drawn to Wall Street and joined Galleon Group, a New York hedge fund run by the charismatic, bullish trader Raj Rajaratnam. In 1999, she struck out on her own to trade technology stocks. She thrived. Riding the Internet boom, she said, she had amassed a paper fortune of $50 million.

headline: 5 Ways to Time-Travel (and Party) in New York
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties', 'Jazz', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: Anyone with a passion for the past can plunge into almost any historical period, from the Jazz Age to the Revolutionary era, for just a few dollars.
lead_paragraph: When William Faulkner famously mused on the power of history — “The past is never dead. It’s not even past,” he wrote — he probably didn’t have New York foremost in mind. The city, not known for its ability to hold on to old and historic spaces, has often directed its energy manically to the future. But in 2015, a contrarian spirit lives on in the city, and anyone with a passion for the past can plunge into almost any historical period for just a few dollars — and, in some of the more theatrical parties, by also investing in some decent vintage duds. We’ve covered how to enjoy Gilded Age decadence, but if your preferences lie in different eras, here are some events to seek out.
