headline: The Trouble With “Boyhood”
abstract: And why its failure to win Best Picture isn’t one of the all-time snubs.
lead_paragraph: I’d better slip this one in before last year’s movies vanish completely into the ether. In the Oscar-recap edition of the Moviegoers I did with Frank Bruni earlier this week, I expressed some skepticism about the idea that last Sunday night’s victory of “Birdman” over “Boyhood” is going to be remembered as one of the Academy’s truly epic blunders — not just the kind of ordinary bad Best Picture call that we see at least every other year, but the contemporary equivalent of “Dances With Wolves” beating “Goodfellas” or “Ordinary People” beating “Raging Bull” or whatever “instant classic gets passed over” travesty rankles you the most. (I’m a “Dances With Wolves” apologist, for what it’s worth … but yes, yes, “Goodfellas” is better.)

headline: 1890: Cholera in Persia
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Russians fear cholera in 1890.
lead_paragraph: Rigorous measures are being taken by the Russian Government, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of the Times, to prevent the spread of cholera from Persia and Mesopotamia into the Trans- caucasus. The Official Messenger publishes a long account of the progress of the disease towards the Russian frontier, with the opinions of Russian Consuls. The Consul at Bagdad states that, in his opinion the cessation of the epidemic in Mesopotamia at the end of 1889 was only temporary, and that it will soon reappear. Various arrangements of a sanitary and preventive character are ready to be put into force on the frontiers of the first warning. All vessels from the infected countries will have to submit to ten days’ quarantine and disinfection at Batoum and Theodosia. All pilgrims and travelers from Persia and Turkey are to be sent on through Batoum and Baku, where they will undergo quarantine and have their luggage disinfected. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 28, 1890

abstract: The congressman has become the go-to quote guy for journalists as he openly criticizes the G.O.P. majority.
lead_paragraph: Political moderates are so near extinction in the hard-edged House Republican caucus that Representative Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania is practically a miracle of ornithology — that rare bird called a G.O.P. centrist whose forthright call is something to hear. The congressman has become the go-to quote guy for journalists as he openly, almost joyously, criticizes the new Republican majority’s failure to get much done because of its dedicated avoidance of political compromise.

lead_paragraph: Maïa de la Baume’s article this week, about the families of two French girls who were switched at birth 20 years ago, has the qualities of a screenplay. But sometimes fact is stranger than fiction. Here, the reporter describes what it was like to experience that firsthand.

headline: The Closed Minds Problem
abstract: How do you deal with Rick Santelli and Allan Meltzer?
lead_paragraph: When I was a young economist trying to build a career, I lived — or thought I lived — in a world in which ideas and those who championed them met in relatively open intellectual combat. Of course there were people who clung to their prejudices, of course style sometimes trumped substance. But I believed that by and large better ideas tended to prevail: if your model of trade flows or exchange rate fluctuations tracked the data better than someone else’s, or resolved puzzles that other models couldn’t, you could expect it to be taken up by many if not most researchers in the field.

headline: ‘The American Lover,’ by Rose Tremain
abstract: Rose Tremain’s stories of transgressive love, unfulfilled desires and souls laid bare.
lead_paragraph: Reading Rose Tremain’s stories is like sipping a Campari and soda in the bar of an elegant hotel that manages to be up to the minute without being a slave to fashion: the Carlyle, the Algonquin, the Plaza before it was turned into condos.

headline: Transcending War
abstract: Elliot Ackerman’s debut novel, “Green on Blue,” was partly inspired by his experience training Afghan soldiers.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Elliot Ackerman studied literature in his undergraduate days at Tufts University, but becoming a Marine who served in Iraq and Afghanistan delayed his own literary career. “I knew I wanted to write but took an eight-year detour in the wars,” Ackerman said in an email interview. “While fighting, I couldn’t find the creative space to craft a novel or story; the emotions and material I was dealing with were too raw.”

headline: Elliot Ackerman’s ‘Green on Blue’
abstract: A young soldier from Afghanistan narrates this first novel by an American who served several tours of duty there.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, with the war in Vietnam ferociously stalemated, David Halberstam published a biography of North Vietnam’s leader, Ho Chi Minh, who had died two years earlier. Books about the enemy are typical in times of war. What was atypical about “Ho” was its fawning tone: “In his lifetime,” Halberstam wrote, “Ho had not only liberated his own country . . . he had touched the culture and soul of his enemy.” It’s a pretty lousy biography by any measure, every page a basket of freshly picked cherries, but for many historians on the right it’s still viewed as traitorous rot — as if Ernie Pyle had written, in 1943, “Goebbels: A Celebration.”

headline: Poetry
abstract: New books by Alice Fulton, Jynne Dilling Martin, Katie Ford and Erin Belieu.
lead_paragraph: BARELY COMPOSED  Poems  By Alice Fulton  Norton, $25.95.

headline: ‘The Big Seven,’ by Jim Harrison
abstract: An outlaw clan terrorizes a town in the Upper Peninsula, and Jim Harrison’s hapless detective is caught in the crossfire.
lead_paragraph: A startling moment occurs in Jim Harrison’s 2011 novel, “The Great Leader,” when the protagonist, Detective Sunderson, abruptly reflects on an incident that has landed him in the hospital. His soon-to-be ex-wife, Diane, has left with all of her things, and Sunderson drinks a bottle of Canadian whisky. “This had gone on a couple of days and . . . a colleague had checked up and found him facedown and comatose on the floor of the unheated enclosed back porch after a 10-degree night.” Up until this point, Sunderson’s steady drinking has been recklessly celebratory in this whisky-soaked novel, the kind of soaking one expects from a divorced detective at the outset of his retirement. But when he blithely reveals that he spent a few days unconscious, all the previous pages are cast into a foggy doubt. Just how screwed up is this guy, and exactly how stewed has he been for the past several chapters?

headline: ‘The Italians,’ by John Hooper
abstract: The Economist’s Italy correspondent explains the confounding inner workings of the Bel Paese.
lead_paragraph: One of the epigraphs John Hooper uses to introduce the various chapters in his new book, “The Italians,” is a bit of dialogue from the 1949 film “The Third Man.” In it, Harry Lime compares the tumultuous 30 years of Borgia rule in Italy, which produced the Renaissance and some of its greatest artists, to the 500 years of democracy and peace in Switzerland, which, he claims, produced only the cuckoo clock.

headline: Jorie Graham’s ‘From the New World’
abstract: Jorie Graham’s career-spanning selected poems show how she moved the art form forward.
lead_paragraph: Writing about Jorie Graham at this point, seven books after she won the Pulitzer Prize for “The Dream of the Unified Field: Selected Poems 1974-1994,” means joining a cacophony of voices. Google her name and you will find her elders, her peers and those she has influenced (and she has influenced most poets younger than she is, and not just in English, whether they know it or not) making cases for and against the importance of her work. People have all sorts of reasons to love or hate her, and even love to hate her for reasons they sometimes can’t articulate. The most evident case for Graham’s importance is the volume of chatter eddying around her name. Tune all of that out and the deeper reasons for her lasting reputation grow louder. Graham’s great body of work, summarized in “From the New World,” her new career-spanning selected poems (one can understand why active poets resist the tombstone of a “collected” volume), has so much in it, more of life and of the world than that of almost any other poet now writing. Or so it seems to me — as anxious, I realize, as everyone else to make my case.

headline: Daniel Handler’s ‘We Are Pirates’
abstract: A father and daughter pursue riches in the music world and on the open water in Daniel Handler’s comic novel.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t start with Gwen,” begins the second chapter of Daniel Handler’s new novel, “We Are Pirates.” “Don’t start” means “Don’t begin” but also “Don’t mess with,” because the Gwen in question is a furious 14-year-old girl who has just been caught shoplifting. Her mother has “ransacked” her room and “thrown all her stuff out, thinking it was stolen. Well, it was stolen now.” Gwen, you see, is ­upset, so don’t start with Gwen — the joke being, of course, that Chapter 2 is starting with her. The novel itself starts with the report of how the novel’s narrator meets Gwen’s father:

headline: ‘Why Not Say What Happened,’ by Morris Dickstein
abstract: A memoir mixes biography and intellectual history.
lead_paragraph: In his 1992 book “Double Agent: The Critic and Society,” Morris Dickstein urged his fellow critics to engage in a cultural conversation among citizens rather than insulate themselves in a ghetto of postmodern jargon. And he insisted that “like all good writing, criticism is personal or it is nothing.”

headline: ‘The Age of Dignity,’ by Ai-jen Poo With Ariane Conrad
abstract: Changing how society deals with caregiving.
lead_paragraph: For years, nonfiction books about aging have tended to fall into certain categories: pragmatic texts about coping with specific challenges and encouraging healthy aging; memoirs of the author’s experience of old age or of caring for elderly parents; research-filled narratives by experts or journalists.

headline: Kings Are Surging Without Slava Voynov as He Awaits Trial
abstract: Voynov’s indefinite suspension illustrates the way professional sports leagues have changed their approach to domestic violence cases since video surfaced of the N.F.L. player Ray Rice striking his fiancée.
lead_paragraph: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — A lone figure skated to the top of a face-off circle, receiving passes from a coach and firing pucks at the net. All three shots sailed wide, slamming against the plexiglass as two youth hockey players scurried past on their way to practice.

headline: Lene Kaaberbol’s ‘Doctor Death,’ and More
abstract: New novels by Lene Kaaberbol, Bryan Reardon, William Shaw and S. D. Sykes.
lead_paragraph: As an intelligent young woman living in provincial France in 1894, Madeleine Karno has two clear career paths: She can find a husband or become a pathologist. The strong-minded heroine of Lene Kaaberbol’s DOCTOR DEATH (Atria, $25) comes by her passion for the forensic sciences naturally since she serves as assistant to her widowed father, Dr. Albert Karno, coroner for the town of Varbourg. But Madeleine’s ambitions would scandalize the neighbors, so it’s kept very hush-hush when she visits the local hospital to help him examine the abused body of 17-year-old Cecile Montaine, who went missing after leaving her convent school.

headline: Irvine Welsh’s ‘The Sex Lives of Siamese Twins’
abstract: Irvine Welsh’s tale of abduction and mutual obsession.
lead_paragraph: Put down the novel and back away from the doughnuts. It is not advisable to read Irvine Welsh’s 13th book, “The Sex Lives of Siamese Twins,” and snack simultaneously. Because Welsh, known for his gleeful depictions of the depraved degenerates who populate Scotland’s seediest hollows, has turned his attention to one of his adopted homes, Miami Beach, that “sun-drenched refuge for strutting grotesques and desperate narcissists.” This is not Welsh’s first Rollerblade around Florida; “Crime” followed a coke-addled Edinburgh detective along the same bright sidewalks. It is, however, his first to be narrated by two Americans. And not just any two Americans. Female ones. This is a man who once successfully narrated a portion of a novel from the point of view of a tapeworm. The question is, in assuming the perspectives of women, has he bitten off more than he can chew?

headline: ‘After Birth,’ by Elisa Albert
abstract: A novel traces the changes brought by a baby’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: “A baby opens you up, is the problem,” explains Ari, who feels she didn’t actually give birth to her 1-year-old son because he was delivered via cesarean section. “There’s before, and there’s after,” she observes. “To live in your body before is one thing. To live in your body after is another.” Which might be the simplest way to communicate the impact of Elisa Albert’s brilliant new novel. “After Birth” cuts open the body of literature on mothering, birth, feminism, female friendship, female hateship — whether academic treatise or poem or novel — and wrenches out something so new we barely recognize it. Wet, red, slimy, alive: a truth baby.

headline: Laura van den Berg’s ‘Find Me’
abstract: Laura van den Berg’s heroine picks her way across an American wasteland, searching for the mother who abandoned her.
lead_paragraph: Joy Jones, the narrator of “Find Me,” Laura van den Berg’s pleasingly strange first novel, has spent her whole life waiting to be found. Born in the winter of 1995, she was left on the steps of a Boston hospital. The nurses gave her a name. Her birthday is only a guess. She grew up in a series of foster and group homes, feeling perpetually unwanted.

headline: ‘Hell and Good Company,’ by Richard Rhodes
abstract: Richard Rhodes offers an anecdotal — and technological — history of the Spanish Civil War.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to speak intelligently about supremely ideological political events from a standpoint that airily dismisses the supremely ideological politics? Richard Rhodes has put this question to a test by writing an aggressively anti-ideological history of one of the most extravagantly ideological events that has ever occurred, the Spanish Civil War of 1936-39. The Spanish war broke out because, on one side, the radically leftist Socialist Party pushed the Republican government ever further to the left, and large parts of the labor movement pushed still more sharply leftward, unto the zones of collectivist and libertarian revolution — and because, on the ­opposite side, the national army and most of the Catholic Church and other parts of society veered sharply rightward, unto the nether regions of the fascist extreme. And, well, the two sides could not get along. Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin made their own specialized contributions. Three years of this and Generalissimo Francisco Franco became the caudillo of Spain, and wartime atrocities gave way to peacetime atrocities.

headline: Marco Rubio at CPAC: An Immigrant Success Story
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio was well-received by the CPAC crowd Friday describing his own upbringing as an immigrant success story.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: President Obama has treated “the ayatollah of Iran with more respect than the prime minister of Israel.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Helen Macdonald, whose memoir “H Is for Hawk” is No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has become something of a sensation in her native England.
lead_paragraph: A Massive Wobble: “H Is for Hawk,” Helen Macdonald’s moving memoir about falconry and her father’s death, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8. Macdonald is hardly the first best-selling memoirist to combine nature and grief: In 2012, Roger Rosenblatt spent a couple of weeks on the extended list with the elegiac “Kayak Morning,” in which he paddles around a Long Island creek and reflects on the death of his 38-year-old daughter, while Cheryl Strayed’s “Wild,” about hiking the Pacific Crest Trail after her mother died, has logged more than two and a half years on the hardcover and paperback lists. (It’s currently No. 3 in paperback, after 100 weeks.) Still, Macdonald was unprepared for the kind of success her book has achieved — particularly in her native England, where it was published last year and has become something of a sensation. “It’s freaking me out a bit!” she told The Belfast Telegraph recently. “There was a moment about two weeks ago when I went to do a book talk. People were queuing up to get books signed, and some were incredibly nervous and had shaking hands. I was horrified! They didn’t see me as a person — they saw me as a place holder for being a ‘writer’ or ‘author’ or some figure that wasn’t really me. That threw me into a massive wobble!” Her experience, she said, “taught me that this relationship with what is technically very much a wild animal is a way of getting in touch with all sorts of elemental things. . . . I was in a really dark place, and the hawk helped me through it.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THIEVES OF STATE: Why Corruption Threatens Global Security,  by Sarah Chayes. (Norton, $26.95.) This important book makes the case that acute economic and political corruption causes both social breakdown and violent extremism.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SIGNAL AND THE NOISE: Why So Many Predictions Fail — but Some Don’t,  by Nate Silver. (Penguin, $17.) Silver has developed groundbreaking methods for predicting the performance of baseball players and the outcome of political races; here he assumes the role of public statistician as he investigates the world of forecasting, from finance to weather to epidemiology. Arguing for a sharper recognition of “the difference between what we know and what we think we know,” he proposes strategies for distinguishing true signals from a universe of noisy data.

headline: Don Johnson, a Yankees Sensation Who Fizzled Out, Dies at 88
abstract: Johnson, a hard-throwing pitcher who showed flashes of greatness in 1947, struggled with injuries and off-the-field troubles, finishing his major league career with only 27 wins.
lead_paragraph: Not many baseball fans — not even the die-hard Yankee variety — will remember the right-handed pitcher Don Johnson, but he was the Yankees’ most promising rookie 68 spring trainings ago. That was 1947.

headline: Making Money Decisions When You Lose Your Job
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Personal Finances', 'Unemployment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: About 1.7 million people lose their jobs every month, creating a hugely stressful situation and requiring potentially life-altering choices.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are striking: About 1.7 million people, on average, lose their jobs every month.

headline: The Secrets of Filming Sex Scenes
abstract: Judd Apatow, Amy Schumer, Sarah Treem, Adrian Lyne and Jean-Marc Vallée share behind-the-scenes details whether there’s real-life jealousy and why lighting matters.
lead_paragraph: Getting Hollywood types to speak on the record about the behind-the-scenes details of filming sex scenes was no easy feat — about a dozen people, Oscar and Emmy winners among them, said no — but once some filmmakers agreed to talk, they had a lot to say about the logistics. Read more.

headline: Mutual Suspicion Mars Tech Trade With China
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: With China and the United States wary of the other’s digital espionage, American tech companies are caught in the middle.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At an elegant guesthouse here recently, China’s top Internet regulator entertained ambassadors and diplomats with platters of tempura and roast on a spit, unusual lavishness in an era of official austerity in China, to celebrate the Chinese New Year.

abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: A Sugar Rush, Not Crush
abstract: The pastry chef Larissa Raphael’s confection is no harder to make than any other layer cake, but the precision of the ingredients makes it shine.
lead_paragraph: It’s unusual to be served a homey wedge-shaped slice of layer cake at an ambitious restaurant. It’s even more surprising when it’s a fluffy coconut number, as shaggy and proud as anything you’d see on a diner counter under a cake dome — but about a thousand times more delicious.

headline: Earl Lloyd, N.B.A.’s First Black Player, Dies at 86
abstract: Lloyd, who made his debut for the Washington Capitols in October 1950, played in the N.B.A. for nine seasons and was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2003.
lead_paragraph: Earl Lloyd, who became the first black player to appear in an N.B.A. game when he took the court for the Washington Capitols in October 1950, three and a half years after Jackie Robinson broke modern major league baseball’s color barrier, died on Thursday in Crossville, Tenn. He was 86.

headline: One-Stop Borrowing on the Web
abstract: Consumer demand for a streamlined mortgage process is driving investment in online lending startups trying to deliver loans more quickly, efficiently and reliably.
lead_paragraph: Consumer demand for a streamlined mortgage process is driving investment in online lending startups trying to deliver loans more quickly, efficiently and reliably.

headline: Is Introversion Still a Liability in Politics?
abstract: Introversion has become hip — or, at least, much-discussed. But when it comes to political candidates like Jeb Bush, the trait still seems to arouse suspicion.
lead_paragraph: “You could almost say that introversion has become the new cool,” said Brian R. Little, a professor of psychology at Cambridge University. In large part as a result of Susan Cain’s popular 2012 book “Quiet,” he explained, “there has been a recognition of the quiet strengths of introversion.”

headline: Capture of a Drug Lord Is a Small Win in Mexico
abstract: The police captured Servando Gómez, leader of the Knights Templar drug gang, on Friday, but experts said the victory would make little difference in the larger battle against criminal groups.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican police captured the leader of the Knights Templar drug gang on Friday, a victory against the brutal group but one that experts say will make little difference in the larger battle against criminal organizations that are rapidly splintering.

headline: At CPAC, Rick Perry Remembers His Memory Loss of 2012
abstract: Rick Perry’s speech received some applause and cheers of approval, but at no point were people on their feet, urging him on.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: “We survived Jimmy Carter. We will survive the Obama years, too.”

headline: House Passes One-Week Funding Extension for Homeland Security
abstract: The agreement was reached after a setback for Speaker John A. Boehner and his team earlier Friday, when the House voted against their original plan to extend funding for the department for three weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans vowing to govern effectively as a congressional majority failed a fundamental test Friday, when House leaders only narrowly managed to avert a partial shutdown of the Department of Homeland Security after an embarrassing defeat earlier in the day.

headline: As Rubio Eyes White House, Floridian Eyes His Senate Seat
abstract: Jeff Atwater, Florida’s chief financial officer and a former State Senate president, is eyeing a potential run to succeed Senator Marco Rubio.
lead_paragraph: When the talk-show host Sean Hannity asked Senator Marco Rubio to place the likelihood that he would run for president on a scale of 1 to 100, he demurred. But at least one of Mr. Rubio’s would-be successors in Florida is wagering that the chances are closer to 100 than to 1.

headline: Sophia Ahrens Transforms at Etro
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Sophia Ahrens before (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by James Pecis.

headline: West Village Townhouse for $17 Million
abstract: A 25-foot-wide, bow-fronted townhouse in the West Village, which served as the setting for movies, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A 25-foot-wide, bow-fronted townhouse in the West Village, whose distinctive facade, commodious interior and outdoor garden have made it a sought-after locale for filmmakers, sold for $17,000,000, more than 20 percent above its asking price, and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Trust Your Matchmaking Mother. She Only Wants What’s Best.
abstract: Our children have found their colleges and careers. Isn’t it time they found their soul mates? Trust us, we can help.
lead_paragraph: Watch out JDate and Tinder, here come the middle-aged mothers. We are mobilizing for a common cause: to find our children their beshert (their intended soul mate), and we are serious competition. We know them so much better than your apps and sites ever can.

headline: A Chicken’s Tour of the Mediterranean
abstract: Braised thighs with lemon and olives can be tweaked for various tastes from the region.
lead_paragraph: A good cook needs an assortment of chicken recipes up his or her sleeve. It’s fair to say that most carnivores like chicken, but even chicken fans prefer a bit of variety, a break from the familiar roasted, fried, grilled.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Elliot Ackerman’s ‘Green on Blue’
abstract: This week, Tom Bissell discusses Elliot Ackerman’s “Green on Blue”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; John Hooper talks about “The Italians”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Tom Bissell discusses Elliot Ackerman’s “Green on Blue”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; John Hooper talks about “The Italians”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: A Gaza Artist Creates 100 Square Feet of Beauty, and She’s Not Budging
abstract: Nidaa Badwan’s project is called “100 Days of Solitude” in homage to Gabriel García Márquez’s novel, though her isolation has lasted much longer.
lead_paragraph: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip — Nidaa Badwan’s room is less than 100 square feet, lit by a single window and a bare bulb. She has slathered one wall with aquamarine paint and covered another in a patchwork of colored egg cartons. There is a medium-size mirror, an antique sewing machine and iron, two easels, a large yellow ladder and a gas canister on which she boils water to make a sweet cappuccino drink from a packet.

abstract: This year, New York soccer fans will have two M.L.S. teams to choose from.
lead_paragraph: This year, New York soccer fans will have two M.L.S. teams to choose from.

headline: Whose Side Are You On?
abstract: The Red Bulls and the newly formed N.Y.C.F.C. both claim to represent New Yorkers, and for soccer fans, there’s now a real choice to be made.
lead_paragraph: New York sports fans can be a melodramatic lot, but in January one particular group had become agitated on a whole other level. The debut of a newly acquired star player, believed to be set for the season opener in March, had been pushed back at least three months for contract reasons, and they were outraged. Some returned the team jerseys they had bought bearing the player’s name. Others vowed to boo him when he did finally arrive. One group of die-hards issued a statement saying it “would like to publicly denounce” the club and the player for the delay.

headline: In Short-Lived Fish, Secrets to Aging
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Age, Chronological', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: Turquoise killifish last no more than a few months, giving researchers a faster way of learning more about the mechanics of getting older.
lead_paragraph: The turquoise killifish lives in a fleeting world: the ponds that appear only during the rainy season in East Africa.

headline: Leonard Nimoy, Spock of ‘Star Trek,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Nimoy won a worshipful global following as Mr. Spock, the resolutely logical human-Vulcan first officer in the television and movie juggernaut “Star Trek.”
lead_paragraph: Leonard Nimoy, the sonorous, gaunt-faced actor who won a worshipful global following as Mr. Spock, the resolutely logical human-alien first officer of the Starship Enterprise in the television and movie juggernaut “Star Trek,” died on Friday morning at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: For Leonard Nimoy, Spock’s Hold Made Reaching Escape Velocity Futile
abstract: The irresistibly distinct, coldblooded and cerebral Mr. Spock was something new and long-lasting.
lead_paragraph: The title of Leonard Nimoy’s autobiography was “I Am Not Spock,” and that so offended some fans that he followed it with a second, “I Am Spock.”

headline: The Man Who Was Spock
abstract: Leonard Nimoy, best known for playing the character Spock in the Star Trek television shows and films, died at 83.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Nimoy, best known for playing the character Spock in the Star Trek television shows and films, died at 83.

headline: Leonard Nimoy Was Not (Only) Spock
abstract: A poet, musician, director and photographer, Mr. Nimoy pursued a wide range of creative interests even as he periodically reprised everyone’s favorite Vulcan.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Nimoy, who died on Friday at 83, was known the world over as Spock, the Vulcan logician and cool counterpoint to William Shatner’s hotheaded Captain Kirk on “Star Trek.”

headline: Leonard Nimoy Dies at 83
abstract: Leonard Nimoy was an actor, film director, poet, singer and photographer best known for his role as Spock in the television show “Star Trek.”
lead_paragraph: Leonard Nimoy was an actor, film director, poet, singer and photographer best known for his role as Spock in the television show “Star Trek.”

headline: Myth, Reality and the Underground Railroad
abstract: How postwar whites reimagined the flight of escaping slaves to benefit themselves.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, 1865, William Lloyd Garrison, the editor of the antislavery weekly The Liberator, published an odd column – odd, because the piece, written by the New York minister Thomas Jefferson Sawyer, had already appeared in the paper, less than a year before. But Garrison believed that the article’s point – about collective memory, and collective forgetting – was an important one, and with the war’s end in sight, he wanted to make sure his readers saw it.

headline: Nimoy Explains Origin of Vulcan Greeting
abstract: As part of the Yiddish Book Center Wexler Oral History Project, Leonard Nimoy explains the origin of the Vulcan hand signal used by Spock, his character in the “Star Trek” series.
lead_paragraph: As part of the Yiddish Book Center Wexler Oral History Project, Leonard Nimoy explains the origin of the Vulcan hand signal used by Spock, his character in the “Star Trek” series.

abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a strappy, open-toed stunner we wouldn’t dare call sweet.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: ‘Jihadi John’ Stirs Britain to Defend Spy Agencies
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron spoke after disclosures that a man who posed in ISIS videos of the murder of Western hostages was known to British intelligence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After disclosures that the man who posed in videos of the murder of Western hostages was known to British intelligence, Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday defended the security services, saying they faced tough decisions and had prevented deadly attacks.

headline: Where Matchy-Matchy Meets Its Match
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The look of Lori Goldstein’s home is the same as that of her clothing line: Everything goes.
lead_paragraph: As a fashion stylist who’s worked closely with superstar photographers like Annie Leibovitz and Steven Meisel, Lori Goldstein has spent most of her professional life behind cameras. In recent years, she’s established a new career in front of them with her LOGO clothing lines on QVC, the television shopping network.

headline: The Rhythm of Great Performance
abstract: One productivity tip: Focus in the most absorbed way possible when you are working and then take a break at least every 90 minutes.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 15 years, I’ve been making the case — in my writing and with corporate clients — that employees can be more productive by working fewer hours and taking more time for rest and renewal during the work day.

headline: My Dad: Strict. My Daughter’s ‘Papa’? Not So Much.
abstract: My mom tells me that my dad has always been great with children. But that’s not what I remember.
lead_paragraph: I have always had a complicated relationship with my father. As the oldest of four children and the only girl, I resented my dad’s rigidity, his chauvinism, the perceived preference shown to my younger brothers. When it came to housework, I was relegated to the “girl” chores, which meant I regularly spent an hour washing the family’s dishes, compared with my brother’s 15 minutes of taking out the garbage and sweeping the floors. When I was a little older I was stuck at home watching my eight-years-younger twin brothers, while my brother was absolved from caregiving duties because he was “too irresponsible.”

headline: Blumarine’s Subtle Rock-and-Roll Eye Makeup
abstract: For fall 2015, a neutral face — amped up slightly with layers of mascara and a touch of black glitter — complements the brand’s range of looks.
lead_paragraph: “Our inspiration is about a young girl, cool, who wants to have fun,” explained the makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage at Blumarine’s fall/winter 2015 show today. To complement the range of textures (leather, lace, lamé), designs (mini dresses, structured coats, flowing gowns) and colors (light gray, burnt orange, electric blue) in the collection, Pecheux stuck to a neutral palette. “If you are a little disco, if you are a little bit rock and roll, if you are a little bit classy, a little bit punk,” he says, the look will work for you. He amped things up, ever so slightly, on the eyes: loads of mascara on the top lashes, a little bit of gloss on the lid and a touch of black glitter. It was a very small beauty moment that added just enough oomph to the rock-and-roll feel of the looks.

headline: Israeli Utility to Stop Disrupting Electricity in West Bank
abstract: The state-owned electric company, which briefly reduced power on two days this week, has reached a deal with the Israeli government to help offset what it is owed.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s state-owned electric company will stop disrupting power supplies to Palestinian districts in the West Bank after reaching an agreement with the Israeli government meant to help offset a ballooning debt, Israeli officials said on Friday.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from Tony the Tiger to “The Bachelor”
lead_paragraph: “It’s not going to help us. We need the hours.” That was the reaction of many Walmart workers after the retail giant announced it would raise wages for U.S. employees to at least $10 an hour beginning next year. While the increase is no doubt welcome, it’s nowhere close to the $15 an hour workers asked for and doesn’t address an equally big issue: not enough hours in the first place.

headline: Center Pictures Success, Then Calls the Shots
abstract: Instead of the point guards, center Seth Tuttle, who leads the team in scoring, rebounding and assists, calls the plays for the No. 10 Panthers.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa — Every time Seth Tuttle sits in the renovated video room at Northern Iowa’s McLeod Center, in one of the new black leather seats with the Panthers’ logo affixed, his gaze shifts to his left. A purple-tinted photograph of jubilant Panthers players celebrating the program’s signature victory, a 2010 upset of  Kansas, the overall top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament that season, covers the lower half of the wall.

headline: At CPAC, Rick Santorum Says U.S. Needs Wartime President
abstract: Rick Santorum urged CPAC attendees to support a presidential candidate with deep experience and a stiff backbone on foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: The former Pennsylvania senator received the best response for his tough talk on foreign policy: “We don’t need a weatherman in chief, we need a commander in chief to run this government.”Crickets: He attempted a joke about President Obama’s place of birth, joking that the Kenyan government had discovered that Mr. Obama was “actually born in America.” Nope.Biggest Pander: In a bit of country-when-country-wasn’t-cool, Mr. Santorum noted that he was against Common Core when he ran for president in 2012. “And today I’m still not for Common Core,” he said.Toughest Question: Not a one.Mood in the Room: Mr. Santorum had the unfortunate luck of following Senator Rand Paul, which meant that dozens of Mr. Paul’s libertarian-leaning followers exited the room during the opening minutes of his speech.

abstract: The F.C.C. passed an order to override state laws that hinder the expansion of community broadband networks, saying the laws limit competition. Legal challenges are expected.
lead_paragraph: At the Federal Communications Commission Thursday, the Klieg light of public attention beamed on the net neutrality vote. But there was an earlier vote on another matter, and that was the one that held Harold DePriest’s attention.

abstract: Times critics review “’71,” “The Hunting Ground” and “Maps to the Stars.”

abstract: Tom Bissell discusses “Green on Blue,” and John Hooper talks about “The Italians.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Tom Bissell reviews Elliot Ackerman’s first novel, “Green on Blue.” Mr. Ackerman served five tours of duty in Iraq and Afghanistan, and his novel is told through the eyes of Aziz, a young Afghan. Mr. Bissell writes:

headline: In Europe, Bond Yields and Interest Rates Go Through the Looking Glass
abstract: Policy makers are taking drastic measures to revive the economy, resulting in financial transactions that seem upside-down.
lead_paragraph: HVIDOVRE, Denmark — At first, Eva Christiansen barely noticed the number. Her bank called to say that Ms. Christiansen, a 36-year-old entrepreneur here, had been approved for a small-business loan. She whooped. She danced. A friend took pictures.

headline: Google Unveils Plan for New Corporate Campus
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Google unveiled a radical proposal for a new campus that would replace its current headquarters in Mountain View.
lead_paragraph: Google on Friday submitted a proposal to raze parts of its Mountain View campus and replace it with a series of airy, space-age buildings with translucent roofs and modular interiors that can be moved around and reconfigured like Lego bricks.

headline: The Significance of Lloyds’ Plan to Pay a Dividend
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The dividend is more about its existence than its size. It means that the British bank regulator is comfortable with Lloyds’ profitability.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Lloyds Banking Group paid a dividend, Gordon Brown was the British prime minister, Lehman Brothers still existed and “banker” was yet to become a term of abuse. The fact the British bank is making its first shareholder payout since August 2008 is, therefore, an encouraging milestone. But in valuation terms, this year’s dividend is more important.

headline: Leonard Nimoy Is Remembered by a Constellation From ‘Star Trek’ and Beyond
abstract: Mr. Nimoy’s”Star Trek” co-stars took to social media on Friday to remember the man who was Mr. Spock.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Nimoy and his “Star Trek” co-stars have all had careers with many acts. In recent years, they’ve connected with avid Trekkies on social networks like Twitter and Facebook. And his colleagues and other admirers, including President Obama, took to those platforms on Friday to remember the man who was Mr. Spock.

lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most important question in the Republican presidential primary is whether Scott Walker, the Wisconsin governor, is a capable presidential candidate.

headline: Study on Chronic Fatigue May Help With Diagnoses
abstract: Scientists have found biomarkers for chronic fatigue syndrome that may eventually form the basis of the first diagnostic test for it.
lead_paragraph: The immune systems of people with chronic fatigue syndrome differ from those of healthy people, and patients with recent diagnoses can be distinguished from those who have had the condition for longer, researchers reported on Friday.

headline: Before Justices Rule, Floridians Consider Life Without Health Subsidies
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As the state with the most Affordable Care Act enrollees, Florida stands to feel the biggest impact if the Supreme Court strikes down the law’s subsidies.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Sylvia Maltzman, a part-time tutor at a community college in Florida, pays $23 a month for the health insurance she got under the Affordable Care Act. A federal subsidy of about $475 covers the rest, and Ms. Maltzman, who has high blood pressure and arthritis, said she could not afford insurance without it.

headline: Sarah Goldberg of VH1’s ‘Hindsight’ Is Having a Blast in the Past

lead_paragraph: On the VH1 series “Hindsight,” Sarah Goldberg plays Lolly, the high-living best friend to Becca (Laura Ramsey), who passes out on the eve of her present-day wedding and awakens back in 1995, able to live her life over, scrunchies and all. In real life, Ms. Goldberg was barely 10 in ’95, but she still felt a part of the era.

headline: Riffing, but Not on the Rules of Golf

headline: Robert Benmosche, Rescuer of A.I.G. After Bailout, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Benmosche came out of retirement in 2009 to turn around the company, the worst casualty of the global financial crisis, which the American taxpayers spent $182 billion to bail out.
lead_paragraph: Robert H. Benmosche, a former MetLife chairman who engineered one of the greatest financial turnarounds in American corporate history when he took charge of the failed industry giant American International Group and restored it to health after it had been rescued by American taxpayers in a $182 billion bailout, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 70.

abstract: Police officials in the northwest province of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa said they had issued hundreds of arrest warrants for parents who have refused to vaccinate their children.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Determined to curb Pakistan’s polio crisis, police officials in the northwestern province of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa said Friday that they had issued hundreds of arrest warrants for parents for refusing to vaccinate their children.

headline: A Chant That Rand Paul Could Get Used To
abstract: Rand Paul, seeking his third straight CPAC straw-poll win, revved up the crowd with attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton on military intervention in Libya and the Benghazi debacle.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: “It’s time for a new president.” This brought most of the crowd to its feet, including a boisterous section up near the front of the stage that started waving its red “Stand With Rand” signs and shouting “President Paul! President Paul!” The spontaneous eruption brought a big grin to the senator’s face.

headline: Grandmaster Sachs

headline: A Dolly Parton Show Makeover
abstract: Dolly Parton’s “Dixie Stampede” show and dinner in Pigeon Forge, Tenn., has received a multimillion-dollar upgrade
lead_paragraph: Never one to sit idle, Dolly Parton, the singer, actress and purveyor of all-American family entertainment, has been busy revamping one of the most popular shows of her career. No, it’s not a musical version of “Steel Magnolias”; it’s the “Dixie Stampede,” Ms. Parton’s western-themed variety show and barbecue feast and one of the best-selling attractions in the country’s dinner theater capitals, Pigeon Forge, Tenn.

headline: Wed Once, but Seeing Triple
abstract: A marriage to a twin or triplet comes with its own set of privacy and sharing issues.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you are preparing to marry your soul mate, only to belatedly realize that this person is not truly yours alone? That may be because your mate’s soul is already intricately intertwined with others: a twin, triplets, perhaps a group of quadruplets.

headline: Is the Environment a Moral Cause?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Why left and right respond differently to climate change.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — ACCORDING to a recent poll, a large majority of Americans, and roughly half of Republicans, say they support governmental action to address global warming. The poll, conducted by The New York Times, Stanford and the research organization Resources for the Future, stands in stark contrast to the vast partisan gulf in political efforts to address climate change. How could it be that so many Republicans view global warming as a problem, but so few on the right are pressuring the government to take action to address it?

headline: CPAC Reception Is Mixed for Jeb Bush, Despite Bused-In Backers
abstract: Jeb Bush faced some tough questions and some boos from the crowd but boasted of his conservative credentials as Florida governor in appealing for support at CPAC.
lead_paragraph: Best Applause Line: Difficult to judge, because Jeb Bush’s partisans were determined to drown out any boos with applause. The most sustained applause came when he stated his immigration views, which are disliked by some conservatives. “The simple fact is there is no plan to deport 11 million people,” Mr. Bush said, calling for “a path to legal status” for illegal immigrants.

headline: Quinn Kelsey, Baritone, Wins Beverly Sills Artist Award
abstract: The award, for young singers who have already appeared in featured solo roles at the Metropolitan Opera, comes with $50,000.
lead_paragraph: The 10th annual Beverly Sills Artist Award for young singers at the Metropolitan Opera was awarded on Friday to Quinn Kelsey, a 36-year-old baritone from Honolulu.

headline: The Next Great Migration
abstract: Black people should pursue opportunities for the good life wherever they can.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — AT dinner last summer with my brother-in-law, a grandson of Jews who fled Algeria for France, the conversation turned to the rash of anti-Semitic incidents plaguing the country. At such times, the question inevitably arises in the minds of many Jews: “Where could we go?” He mentioned Tel Aviv, London and New York, but the location mattered less than the reassurance that departure remained an option. He’s not alone in this thinking: 7,000 French Jews emigrated in 2014.

lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling more than 467,000 vehicles worldwide to fix a problem that could prevent the vehicles from starting or result in unexpected stalling.

abstract: Richter, the former Rangers goalie, spoke before hundreds of scientists and doctors on Friday at a conference at NYU Langone’s Concussion Center.
lead_paragraph: Mike Richter’s Hall of Fame career as goalie for the Rangers officially ended in 2003. He was inadvertently kneed in the head by an opposing forward nearly a year before that and never played again. The concussion came months after a rising slap shot hit Richter in the face mask and fractured his skull.

headline: Review: Ryan Phillippe and Juliette Lewis Star in ‘Secrets and Lies’
abstract: A suburban jogger finds a little boy’s body and becomes the chief suspect in his death in this 10-episode thriller on ABC.
lead_paragraph: “Secrets and Lies,” the 10-episode thriller that begins Sunday night on ABC, gets points for style but not many for originality. It’s a crisply paced suburban potboiler with a murdered child at the center, and if you’ve been sucked in by other shows in this genre you may find yourself sucked in by this one. But also feel free to be vaguely annoyed that those clever TV makers are seducing you with formulas rather than freshness.

lead_paragraph: The highlight of the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, with the guest conductor Sakari Oramo, was an incisive and colorful account of Sibelius’s Violin Concerto, featuring the brilliant German violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann. Yet in one basic way, it was not the performance Mr. Zimmermann had anticipated.

headline: Review: ‘Around the World in 50 Concerts,’ a Documentary, Follows an Orchestra
abstract: Heddy Honigmann’s film looks at the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra on its 125th anniversary tour in 2013.
lead_paragraph: You won’t find talk about dwindling audiences or the need to expand repertories in Heddy Honigmann’s documentary “Around the World in 50 Concerts.” Ms. Honigmann’s movie, which follows the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam on its 125th anniversary tour in 2013, is more concerned with the power of music, both for the people who make it and the people listening, than it is with the business of running an orchestra in the 21st century.

headline: Review: In ‘milonga,’ Tango and Contemporary Flirt
abstract: At City Center, the Belgian choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui conjures the bustling atmosphere of tangueros’ late-night gatherings.
lead_paragraph: In “milonga,” the Belgian choreographer Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui explores the social aspects of tango as thoroughly as the steps. The show, which had its United States premiere at City Center on Thursday (part of A Bailar, a three-week Latin dance festival), takes its name from late-night gatherings of tango dancers and musicians. With the set and video designer Eugenio Szwarcer, Mr. Cherkaoui goes to great lengths to conjure that bustling atmosphere, populating the stage — and several screens — with silhouettes of people lounging, socializing, standing around. But all of that could go, and the essence of this impassioned production would remain: its 12 exceptional dancers and their supercharged relationships.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Peggy Bayer Tournament
abstract: The Peggy Bayer tournament, for players under 20, took place last weekend in Wales.
lead_paragraph: How does the play of those in their teens and 20s compare with that of present-day experts 40 to 50 years ago?

lead_paragraph: The end of winter is almost in sight, and the boys of summer are warming up.

headline: Review: Ronald K. Brown/Evidence Heats Up at the Joyce
abstract: Mr. Brown’s dance troupe brings the warmth of the islands in a program of recent and vintage works.
lead_paragraph: It’s a treat to wrap yourself up in some vintage Ronald K. Brown on a cold winter night. Leading off Evidence’s second program at the Joyce Theater on Thursday was Mr. Brown’s 1999 “Gatekeepers,” originally created for Philadanco. In a program note, he describes his dancers as “soldiers walking toward heaven, searching for the wounded and looking out to make a safe haven for others to follow.”

headline: Review: Takacs Quartet and the Viennese Masters Play at Alice Tully Hall
abstract: This string quartet, founded in Budapest in 1975, performed on Thursday night, offering a program of Schubert, Mozart and Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: From even the most prominent of string quartets, a program of Schubert, Mozart and Beethoven might come across as stolid. After all, there are so many foursomes around now that scoff at every kind of boundary, from the JACK  and the Kronos to the Ébène and the Danish. But the Takacs Quartet always shows that there is, and must be, room for insightful, intense performances of major works. That was its achievement in a superb appearance at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday: revealing the familiar as unfamiliar, making the most traditional of works feel radical once more.

headline: How Serious Was the Brooklyn ISIS Plot?
abstract: The war in Syria has blurred the line between armchair jihadists and real combatants.
lead_paragraph: The radicalization of three Central Asian immigrants living in Brooklyn, who were arraigned yesterday in a federal court for allegedly plotting to aid ISIS, seems to have taken place with surprising speed. According to the 23-page affidavit unsealed Wednesday night, federal agents began watching Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev, a 24-year-old gyro-shop employee from Uzbekistan, and Akhror Saidakhmetov, a 19-year-old Kazakh employed at a cellphone repair kiosk, six months ago, shortly after the two men began posting to a website sympathetic to ISIS. The investigation culminated on Wednesday when federal agents arrested Juraboev at his apartment and Saidakhmetov at John F. Kennedy International Airport, where he was attempting to board a flight to Turkey; each man allegedly had plans to cross the border and fight — and, they hoped, to die — in Syria. (A third man, Saidakhmetov’s 30-year-old boss, Abror Habibov, is alleged to have raised money for the trip.)

headline: I.P.O. Plans Withdrawn for Spinoff of JBS, World’s Largest Meatpacker

headline: Fashion’s Hollywood Connection

He was standing in the fortresslike Milk Studios in Hollywood, which was the site of that evening’s Tom Ford fashion show. He had gotten off a flight that afternoon.

headline: Randall Park Goes From Dictator to Dad Onscreen

lead_paragraph: On ABC’s “Fresh Off the Boat,” the actor Randall Park plays a first-generation Taiwanese immigrant with a steakhouse in Orlando, Fla. In real life, Mr. Park is a guy who barely knows the difference between strip and porterhouse.

headline: Review: ‘Social Security,’ the Heroic Poetry of Solitude
abstract: In Christina Masciotti’s play at the Bushwick Starr, a retired Pennsylvania pretzel-factory worker talks just to hear herself talk, even though she’s deaf.
lead_paragraph: She enters muttering, as if speaking without pause were as necessary as breathing. All subjects are given the same weight in June’s rushing river of words: the death of her husband, chocolate peanut butter Easter eggs, her most recent surgery, the virtues of Lysol and the dubious hygiene of the people next door.

headline: When Your Punctuation Says It All (!)
abstract: In the texting era, symbols may say more than the words around them (or, at least, we think they do).
lead_paragraph: I went out with a guy based on his use of dashes once. Within moments of our first interaction — over text message — I was basically in love.

headline: Decades Since Wasserstein’s ‘Heidi,’ the Glass Proscenium Holds Fast
abstract: A revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play “The Heidi Chronicles” feels as relevant today as ever, especially in terms of women’s success in the theater.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven years after its debut in New York, “The Heidi Chronicles,” Wendy Wasserstein’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play about the changing fortunes of women in the latter third of the 20th century, is the subject of a revival on Broadway, with Elisabeth Moss, already accustomed to stampeding her way over patriarchal guard rails on “Mad Men,” assuming the title role. Arriving in 1988, the play came a year after “Fatal Attraction,” “Baby Boom” — the Nancy Meyers film starring Diane Keaton as a single, high-strung Manhattan banker forced into a zany maternity when she inherits a child from a suddenly deceased relative — and the television premiere of “Thirtysomething,” which held the opinion-making class captive for the four seasons it aired.

headline: Documenting Selma, From the Inside

lead_paragraph: The best-known images of the civil rights era were often dramatic and shocking, to jar a nation into action. But James Barker provided a quieter, insider’s perspective.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman, Stanley Fischer, said that it was time for the central bank to bring a little more mystery to its relationship with financial markets, suggesting on Friday that the postcrisis era of detailed guidance was drawing to a close.

headline: In Brooklyn, First Comes Gentrification, Then Comes a Food Co-op
abstract: The Windsor Terrace Food Coop is expected to open on March 21 in Brooklyn, which has become a hotbed of small co-ops in the last few years.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2012, Windsor Terrace residents packed into a community meeting, furious that the Brooklyn neighborhood’s sole supermarket, Key Food, was being replaced by a giant Walgreens drugstore. Jack O’Connell, who had lived there since 1985, was put off by the rancor. But in the middle of all of the arguing, one man raised his hand with a suggestion:

headline: What’s an Economist’s Nobel Medal Worth? $390,848
abstract: The medal awarded to the economist Simon Kuznets in 1971 was sold to an unidentified bidder for $390,848, one of only a few such medals ever to have been sold.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel medal awarded to the economist Simon Kuznets in 1971 sold Thursday night on the auction block for $390,848.

headline: In Iowa, a New John Wayne Museum
abstract: The John Wayne Birthplace Museum is scheduled to open this spring in Winterset, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: The Duke is getting the royal treatment this spring with the opening of the John Wayne Birthplace Museum in Winterset, Iowa. Born Marion Robert Morrison in 1907, Wayne and his family moved to California around age 7, said the museum director Brian Downes.

headline: Lawmakers (Just Not Greece’s) Approve a Bailout Extension
abstract: Approvals of the bailout extension underscored how the political structure of Europe remains a work in progress.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The debate lasted more than two hours, with one conservative lawmaker sharply accusing the Greek government of acting in bad faith. A liberal railed against Greek tycoons exploiting the tax system. And the powerful finance minister argued that lawmakers must put aside their differences and accept the controversial four-month extension of Greece’s bailout program.

headline: Friday Night Music: Forever Young

headline: Destruction of Antiquities by ISIS Militants Is Denounced
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Museums', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Art']
abstract: The sculptures, statues and reliefs that were smashed by ISIS were crucial in the formation of early Arab identity, experts said.
lead_paragraph: The limestone sculptures, statues and reliefs smashed by militants in northern Iraq provided valuable historical insights into kingdoms that flourished thousands of years ago and were crucial in the formation of early Arab identity, experts say. The destruction took place in Mosul, in one of the most important museums in the Middle East.

headline: Diamond Thief Gets 15 Years in Paris Heist
abstract: A French court concluded that Daoudi Yahiaoui, a convicted drug trafficker, was the brain behind a $100 million diamond heist at a Harry Winston jewelry store in 2008.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court meted out a prison sentence of 15 years on Friday to a convicted drug trafficker considered the ringleader of a spectacular $100 million diamond heist at a Harry Winston jewelry store that thieves in flowing wigs carried out with inside knowledge from a security guard.

headline: White House Proposes Broad Consumer Data Privacy Bill
abstract: Under the proposed legislation, called the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights Act, industries would draw up their own codes of conduct on handling customer data, which regulators would enforce.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Friday proposed a wide-ranging bill intended to provide Americans with more control over the personal information that companies collect about them and how that data can be used, fulfilling a promise the president had talked about for years.

headline: Victim Objects as Long Island Banana Mogul Gets Prison Term for Assaulting Her

lead_paragraph: When Alison Bretherick stood up in court Friday at the sentencing of the man convicted of assaulting her, she might have provided the kind of visceral catharsis that domestic violence victims usually deliver in such a setting, a trembling moment as she confronted her abuser about how his brutality had poisoned her life.

lead_paragraph: Writing from an online perch in Istanbul, he calls on Egyptians to start off-hour attacks against KFC restaurants, banks, mobile phone shops and other corporate outposts. He urges assaults on the military’s commercial interests instead of its security checkpoints.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tense meltdown in the House on Friday over funding for the Department of Homeland Security underscores how Congress has lost the ability to perform its most basic functions no matter which party is in charge.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jeremy Bird, the architect of the grass-roots and online organizing efforts that powered President Obama’s presidential campaigns from Chicago, is advising a similar operation in Tel Aviv. But this time it is focused on ousting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: A Death Row Inmate Finds Common Ground With Theologians
abstract: Kelly Renee Gissendaner’s religious conversion in a Georgia prison, where she is scheduled for execution on Monday, has led many people to ask that her life be spared.
lead_paragraph: A lot of convicted felons find God while in prison. Some of their stories rise to the level of literature — Oscar Wilde, Malcolm X. Others are less sincere; parole boards around the country are treated to a lot of conversion stories.

headline: The Islamic State’s Most Recent Victims
abstract: It seems sometimes as if a band of fanatics has emerged from the dark ages to wage war on the present.
lead_paragraph: Reports of atrocities by the Islamic State never cease. Entire villages in northeastern Syria are being emptied of Assyrian Christians, with hundreds taken hostage and others made to pay a religion tax; priceless antiquities are destroyed in Mosul, Iraq, in a symbolic fight against pagan gods; Egyptian Christians are beheaded in Libya.

headline: Undermining Children’s Insurance
keywords: ["State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Senior Republicans in Congress are seeking major changes to the Children’s Health Insurance Program when the program’s money runs out in September.

headline: Pushing Through the Off-Season With One Question: Why?
abstract: Yael Averbuch is preparing for her sixth season — and seventh club — with diligence and introspection.
lead_paragraph: I’ve known what I wanted to do with my life since my third-grade teacher asked me what I wanted to be when I grew up. “A professional soccer player,” I answered confidently. I’ve never thought that I could be happy doing anything besides following that journey I began as a 9-year-old.

headline: ‘Different Destinies in One Place’
abstract: Marcus Trappaud Bjorn, a freelance photographer from Copenhagen, created a series of portraits of commuters aboard the Staten Island Ferry.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Trappaud Bjorn, a freelance photographer from Copenhagen, created a series of portraits of commuters aboard the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: Remove Unfair Barriers to Employment
abstract: Federal action is needed to ensure that people with criminal convictions are not walled off from the job market.
lead_paragraph: About 70 million Americans have criminal histories that may prevent them from ever finding a job, even for arrests or minor convictions that occurred in the distant past. Fourteen states and about 100 cities and counties have tried to help by barring public agencies — and in some instances, private businesses — from asking job candidates about criminal convictions until later in the application process, when they have had a chance to prove their qualifications. These measures help, but federal action is needed to ensure that people with criminal convictions are not unfairly walled off from the job market.

headline: British Bit of Headwear
abstract: A Saturday brain twister by Barry C. Silk.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — A good crossword puzzle will always remind you that you don’t know everything, and that goes double for Saturdays. No matter how much you think you might be up on your lingo, eventually someone will pull a TITFER on you out of nowhere and you’ll realize that there is still much to learn. Some people will find that unfair, but I think it makes life worth living. It’s also why I color my hair.

headline: A Bad Call on Risky Circumcisions
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to stop regulating a practice that could infect babies with herpes.
lead_paragraph: The herpes simplex virus, common and relatively harmless in adults, can be deadly to babies. Such infections in newborns are blessedly rare, but one thing is known to increase the risk significantly: the circumcision ritual called metzitzah b’peh, practiced by many ultra-Orthodox and some Orthodox Jews, in which a circumciser, or mohel, sucks blood from a newly cut penis with his mouth.

headline: Psychiatrist Says Etan Patz Suspect Gave a 2nd Confession
abstract: The psychiatrist, testifying at the trial of Pedro Hernandez, said Mr. Hernandez was “praying for God to forgive him” as he told her he killed a boy in a bodega.
lead_paragraph: A man on trial for the murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz confessed to killing a child in an interview with a psychiatrist at Rikers Island a month after his arrest, according to the doctor’s testimony on Friday.

headline: Bloomberg Sees a Way on Keystone
abstract: The former mayor of New York suggests that the Obama administration negotiate directly with Canada on a climate pact.
lead_paragraph: No one can question Michael Bloomberg’s climate change bona fides. As mayor of New York, he declared that cities had to lead the way in reducing the threat of climate change, and he strove to make New York greener. He has donated millions of dollars to the effort to shut down coal-fired power plants. He endorsed President Obama for re-election in 2012 primarily because the president, he said, “has taken major steps to reduce our carbon consumption.” Most recently, he was named the United Nations secretary general’s special envoy for cities and climate change, a position he appears to be taking quite seriously.

headline: Lawyer at Top of Huge Fraud Pleads Guilty
abstract: An 84-year-old lawyer on Long Island who led a scheme to defraud the Social Security Administration pleaded guilty to a reduced sentence in exchange for helping investigators.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island lawyer who led a huge scheme to defraud the Social Security Administration pleaded guilty on Friday, receiving a reduced sentence in return for promising to help federal investigators find other people cheating the disability insurance system, prosecutors said.

headline: No Swings vs. Matt Harvey, but Cameras Don’t Miss

LUCIE, Fla. — With about a dozen cameras trained on his every move, Matt Harvey toed the rubber on the mound Friday and stared down a batter for the first time in about 18 months. It did not matter that it was February, that the batter was his teammate and that the teammate was not going to swing at a single pitch.

lead_paragraph: Ryder Ripps, the 28-year-old conceptual artist known for his cyberpranks, controversial art pieces and other Internet projects, has created a site-specific installation that is as much a sculpture as it is a performance piece.

headline: Venmo Was Ordered in July by California Regulators to Address Security Issues
abstract: Venmo, a popular mobile payments app, was told to establish companywide best practices and programs around user privacy, security, customer service and fraud loss management.
lead_paragraph: Venmo, the popular mobile payments app, is one of eBay’s secret weapons. The app, which allows users to quickly send cash directly to friends’ bank accounts, is popular with young audiences, a demographic eBay desperately wishes to court.

headline: John Fairchild, Who Made Women’s Wear Daily a Must-Read, Dies at 87
abstract: As publisher and editor, Mr. Fairchild transformed his family’s fusty trade publication into a must-read among fashion elites.
lead_paragraph: John Fairchild, the witty and irascible publisher and editor who transformed his family’s fusty trade publication, Women’s Wear Daily, into the lively bible of the fashion industry, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Princeton Women Pull Away in Rout and Move 4 Games From Goal of 30-0
abstract: After Friday night’s steamrolling of Yale, Princeton is 10-0 in the Ivy League and is the last undefeated team in women’s college basketball.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Inside the locker room of the season’s last undefeated team in women’s college basketball is a hastily written checklist. It names the other seven teams in the Ivy League, with two underscore marks next to each abbreviated name. This is how Princeton is taking inventory of its season.

headline: New Bill Calls for More Port Authority Oversight in Effort to Break Deadlock
abstract: The legislation before the New Jersey State Senate aims to increase transparency following the scandal of politically motivated lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September 2013.
lead_paragraph: The Republican leader in the New Jersey State Senate is proposing legislation to increase oversight and transparency at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in an effort to break the deadlock that has existed since December, when the governors of the two states vetoed an overhaul bill unanimously passed by both legislatures.

headline: New York City Teachers’ Union Is Closing Portion of Its Brooklyn Charter School
abstract: Low student tests scores are forcing the United Federation of Teachers to shut down the kindergarten-to-eighth-grade portion of a charter school it started in 2005.
lead_paragraph: The New York City teachers’ union announced on Friday that it was closing the kindergarten-to-eighth-grade portion of a charter school because of students’ low scores on state tests, ending an experiment intended to prove that such schools could thrive even with strict labor rules.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Braving the Cold to Beat the Crowds
abstract: For some runners, the frigid temperatures before sunrise are an invitation rather than a deterrent in winter, as they relish the empty roads of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: For some runners, the frigid temperatures before sunrise are an invitation rather than a deterrent in winter, as they relish the empty roads of Central Park.

headline: Photos: Springy Steps in Icy Gloom
abstract: For runners at Central Park, beating the crowds means braving the cold before sunrise.
lead_paragraph: They bent into the wind, a parade of defiant-looking runners shuffling through Central Park just before dawn on one of the coldest days of the week. They had smothered their skin beneath layers of high-tech and higher-color clothing. They were not exactly sweating as much as steaming. They looked so cold.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Craig Sheffer portrays the writer Norman Maclean as a quiet young man and Brad Pitt is Paul, his wilder, more magnetic brother, in this adaptation of Mr. Maclean’s 1976 autobiographical story about the sons of a Presbyterian minister coming of age in Montana between Prohibition and the Great Depression — and finding expression for their emotions through fly-fishing. “These are men for whom the physical is inseparably entwined with the spiritual, men for whom both aspects of life are best appreciated knee-deep in a rushing river on a glorious day,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this visually stunning film, for which Philippe Rousselot won an Oscar for best cinematography. “Between the novella’s well-known first sentence (‘In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly-fishing’) and its elegiac last line (‘I am haunted by waters’), ‘A River Runs Through It’ circled gracefully among the landmarks of Mr. Maclean’s early years without violating the distant perfection of those memories.” She added: “It’s easy to recognize Robert Redford’s reverent film version of this beautifully spare novella as a labor of love. While the film is more lavish than Mr. Maclean’s story, and hence less commandingly precise, it radiates much the same seriousness of purpose. The same thoughts embraced by Mr. Maclean — of family and history, of the unbridgeable distances between men, of a wild natural landscape as a pathway to spiritual grace — are ably reflected on the screen.” The evening’s lineup, part of TCM’s “31 Days of Oscar,” continues with “A Few Good Men” (1992), at 10:30; “The English Patient” (1996), at 1 a.m.; and “The Fisher King” (1991), at 4.

headline: What to Expect on the Fourth Day of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Workweek’s over? Think again. Fashion Week is the week without end. At least the typical Milanese traffic abates a bit on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Workweek’s over? Think again. Fashion Week is the week without end. At least the typical Milanese traffic abates a bit on Saturday.

headline: Fear Envelops Russia After Killing of Putin Critic Boris Nemtsov
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Before he was shot and killed, Mr. Nemtsov had met with an old friend to discuss his latest research into what he said was dissembling and misdeeds in the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — About two weeks before he was shot and killed in the highest-profile political assassination in Russia in a decade, Boris Y. Nemtsov met with an old friend to discuss his latest research into what he said was dissembling and misdeeds in the Kremlin.

headline: India’s New Budget Aims to Boost Growth
abstract: The first full-year budget of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government promised a major increase in public spending on infrastructure and a lowering of the corporate tax rate, but it failed to offer any dramatic reforms.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government unveiled its first full-year budget on Saturday, promising to boost growth with a major increase in public spending on infrastructure and to lower the corporate tax rate, steps that were cheered by Indian industry.

headline: Brooklyn Arrests Highlight Challenges in Fighting of ISIS and ‘Known Wolves’
abstract: As officials around the world grapple with the emerging security concerns posed by the Islamic State, the New York case provides one of the first public examples of how officials in the United States are approaching the threat.
lead_paragraph: In Canada and Australia, young men inspired by the bloody, apocalyptic vision of the Islamic State were thwarted in their efforts to join the battle in Syria, so they took up arms in their homelands, staging small attacks that drew widespread attention.

headline: L.B.J. and Truman: The Bond That Helped Forge Medicare
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Lyndon Johnson admired Harry Truman and identified with his political career, his treatment by historians and his relationship with the public.
lead_paragraph: Lyndon B. Johnson was often derided for being egocentric, but when it came time to sign his landmark bill creating Medicare, 50 years ago this July, he graciously insisted on sharing the credit with the 81-year-old Harry Truman. At almost the last moment, Johnson decided to change the location from Washington to Truman’s presidential library in Independence, Mo.

headline: Out of Trouble, but Criminal Records Keep Men Out of Work
abstract: Men with even one past conviction on their résumés are having trouble finding jobs, and that is taking a toll on the overall labor market.
lead_paragraph: Michael Hugh Mirsky landed a temporary job in December rolling stacks of crated milk and orange juice to the loading docks at a commercial dairy in central New Jersey. He’s not making much, and he doesn’t know how long it will last, but after 30 months of unemployment, he counts himself lucky. Mr. Mirsky is a convicted criminal, and work is hard to find.

headline: Political Cartoons During the Great War
abstract: The work of William Allen Rogers, a prolific cartoonist for The Herald during World War I, eventually earned him the French Legion of Honor.
lead_paragraph: The New York Herald’s cartoons during World War I reflected shifting attitudes as events progressed. James Gordon Bennett Jr., the paper’s publisher, never made a secret of his political views: The Herald initially supported the Allies morally, but lauded America’s “strict neutrality.” The full page illustration, above, by Ridgeway Knight shows Lady Columbia as she comforts the French Liberty, surrounded by the ruins of the first battles. “Brave France, you have my grateful and sisterly sympathy,” reads the caption.

lead_paragraph: Anthony Mason, a muscular, bellicose forward whose bruising play helped the Knicks reach the National Basketball Association finals in 1994, died early Saturday morning in Manhattan. He was 48.

Get comfortable and spend some time trying to fill in the missing letters among the pairs that you’ve been given. You might think you have one of the words in each pair correct, but make sure that your word fits with both pairs.

headline: Exploring Art, On and Off the Clock
abstract: Jessica Morgan, the director of Dia Art Foundation, packs her Sundays with museum visits, with the occasional book or email break.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Morgan, the new director of the Dia Art Foundation, recently moved to New York City from London, where she was a curator at the Tate Modern. She’s been living in temporary housing on Wooster Street in SoHo since January, and spends her Sundays exploring the city’s art world. “It’s my job, but it’s also my passion,” Ms. Morgan, 46, said. This summer she will look for a more permanent home when her husband, Ulrich, 48, a design and fashion professor, and son, Konrad, 11, who sometimes visit on the weekends, join her.
