headline: You Say Myanmar, They Say Burma
abstract: Cafe Mingala is New York City’s only dedicated Burmese restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Tucked between flashier Chinese and Indian restaurants on Second Avenue on the Upper East Side of Manhattan is an unassuming storefront whose only markings are a simple awning and two blue neon words in the window: “Burmese Cooking.” The restaurant, Cafe Mingala, is so narrow and dwarfed by its neighbors that you’d probably never notice it. If you did pass it by, you’d miss out on New York City’s only dedicated Burmese restaurant.

headline: A Brutal Beating Wakes Attica’s Ghosts
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Guards', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']

lead_paragraph: ATTICA, N.Y. — On the evening of Aug. 9, 2011, one month before the 40th anniversary of the bloody Attica prison riot, a guard in that remote facility in western New York was distributing mail to inmates in C Block, one of the vast tiers of cells nestled behind its towering 30-foot walls.

headline: Medicating Women’s Feelings
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Emotions', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Serotonin (Chemical)', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: Emotion should be seen as a sign of health, not disease.
lead_paragraph: WOMEN are moody. By evolutionary design, we are hard-wired to be sensitive to our environments, empathic to our children’s needs and intuitive of our partners’ intentions. This is basic to our survival and that of our offspring. Some research suggests that women are often better at articulating their feelings than men because as the female brain develops, more capacity is reserved for language, memory, hearing and observing emotions in others.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Immigration officials are moving to deport at least 150 Bosnians living in the United States who they believe took part in war crimes and “ethnic cleansing” during the bitter conflict that raged in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Colleges and Universities']

headline: A Taste of Summer Under the High Line
abstract: Santina, tucked under the High Line and enclosed in a glass box designed by Renzo Piano, seems like a mirage.
lead_paragraph: Never has a restaurant opened at a more opportune time, hell having frozen over and over. Santina, tucked under the High Line and enclosed in a glass box designed by Renzo Piano, seems like a mirage. Yet the palm and orange trees are real, as are the Murano glass sunflower chandeliers. Waiters dress in pastel polo shirts, white pants and sneakers, like deckhands on a yacht. Corny Italian music wafts over the birds of paradise perched in giant vases atop a Carrara marble bar brimming with fashionistas, food bloggers and financial types. On folksy pottery direct from the Amalfi coast come Mario Carbone’s creations of vegetables, nuts and seafood: comfort food without the weight. No wonder Santina, named for Mr. Carbone’s Sicilian grandmother, and the newest venture from the Parm team of Mr. Carbone, Rich Torrisi and Jeff Zalaznick, has been hot since it opened five weeks ago. It’s a culinary spray tan, only healthier. LIZ ROBBINS

headline: After Boris Nemtsov’s Assassination, ‘There Are No Longer Any Limits’
abstract: The Russian opposition tries to make sense of Friday’s shooting and a deadly new reality.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, Boris Nemtsov, a Russian opposition leader and former first deputy prime minister under Boris Yeltsin, went on a prominent Moscow radio station to exhort his fellow citizens to come out to protest President Vladimir Putin’s policies. There would be a rally on Sunday, a spring march, to demonstrate against the deepening economic crisis and Russia’s involvement in Ukraine. The most prominent Russian opposition leader, Aleksei Navalny, had been put in jail for 15 days, which just happened to be long enough to keep him from attending the rally. Nemtsov, who was older and, by now, less influential, had handed out leaflets in the metro and encouraged people to come anyway.

headline: A Short History of Wiretapping
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Surreptitious monitoring of conversations did not begin with the revelations recounted in “Citizenfour,” but rather has long been conducted by the authorities, private detectives, armies and criminals.
lead_paragraph: Q. When “Citizenfour,” Laura Poitras’s film about Edward Snowden’s revelations of government electronic monitoring, won the Oscar for best documentary,

headline: Did Israel Put Money Over Justice?
abstract: A Jewish family whose son was killed feels betrayed.
lead_paragraph: ON April 17, 2006, a Palestinian suicide bomber killed 11 people near the old Tel Aviv bus station. Among the victims was Daniel Wultz, a bright and determined 16-year-old from Florida who fought for his life for 27 days before succumbing to severe injuries. His father, Yekutiel, who was wounded in the attack, watched the terrorist detonate himself. “I decided to do anything and everything I could,” he told me, “never again to have that helpless feeling.”

headline: Pat McGrath and Guido Palau Combine Forces for Jil Sander’s Androgynous Beauty
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: For the fall 2015 fashion show today, the makeup and hair artists created a decidedly un-girly look.
lead_paragraph: While the fall/winter 2015 Jil Sander collection was splashed with vibrant patterns and electric pops of color, the makeup artist Pat McGrath and hair stylist Guido Palau kept things understated — and decidedly un-girly. “It’s an androgynous look,” McGrath told T today before the show. “It’s all about the brows.” To make them stand out, McGrath said she “put pencil and shadows into the brow and brushed them through for a natural feel.” The result was a clean look, which aligned nicely with Palau’s take on the hair, which he described as “boyish, simple, very minimal.” To get the uncomplicated style, Palau used Redken Satinwear 02 Prepping Blow-Dry Lotion to achieve a smooth blowout and Forceful 23 Super Strength Finishing Spray to keep the bangs in place. Finally, Wind Blown 05 Dry Finishing Spray completed the coiffure and added some texture. Palau said the completed look was quintessential Sander, embodying “masculine femininity” rather than “feminine femininity.” And to top it all off, Palau threw in a small quirk: “a bobby pin on the side to add a bit of charm.”

headline: Governors Can Run, but They Can’t Hide
abstract: A state record leaves those jostling for the presidential nomination wide open to criticism.
lead_paragraph: The political risks in using a governor’s perch to run for the White House should become ever clearer to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, even as he leads some very early polls for the Republican nomination. Mr. Walker, wildly cheered last week at the Conservative Political Action Conference for his anti-union initiatives that incited state protests, seemed to suggest this somehow prepared him to deal with Islamic State terrorists. “If I can take on 100,000 protesters, I can do the same across the world,” he told the conference in denouncing radical militants.

headline: Protecting Fragile Retirement Nest Eggs
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Financial Planners', 'Consumer Protection', 'Editorials', 'Retirement', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Effective rules imposing a fiduciary duty on all retirement account advisers should quickly be put in place.
lead_paragraph: A new study by the White House Council of Economic Advisers has found that financial advisers seeking higher fees and commissions drain $17 billion a year from retirement accounts by steering savers into high-cost products and strategies rather than comparable lower-cost ones.

headline: The Faces on the Ferry
abstract: Marcus Trappaud Bjorn, a freelance photographer from Copenhagen, created an award-winning series of portraits of passengers taking the Staten Island Ferry.
lead_paragraph: For many commuters, taking the Staten Island Ferry means that “you’re sitting on the ferry and can’t do anything,” Marcus Trappaud Bjorn observed. He speaks from experience.

headline: Empire of the Institute
abstract: What was it about those late 1970s classes?
lead_paragraph: Not long ago I received a copy of MIT and the Transformation of American Economics, a collection of essays on how American economics became model- and math-oriented after World War II, and of the special role played by the department Paul Samuelson built. There was a lot in there I didn’t know, despite the many years I spent at MIT first as a student, then as faculty. So I found it — as Spock would say — fascinating.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: The House narrowly met a midnight deadline to continue funding the Department of Homeland Security, an embarrassment to Republican leadership, who will discuss it on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Late Friday, the House passed a one-week extension of funding for the Department of Homeland Security, narrowly meeting its midnight deadline. The House had rejected an earlier version of the bill, which would have extended funding for three weeks, dealing a humiliating blow to the Republican leadership.

lead_paragraph: “They call me the Keith-iest Keith,” said Kevin Gleeson, 55, referring to his resemblance, both visually and musically, to the Rolling Stones guitarist Keith Richards.

headline: Colors of Mets Blend to Make Glove of Gold
abstract: No matter the glove, no matter the design or its weight, or color, it is what Juan Lagares does with it in center field that has propelled him to new heights.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Several characteristics distinguished Juan Lagares’s outfield glove last season. It was orange with blue trim — Mets colors — along with a patch of black on the back. His son’s name, “J Lagares Jr.,” was stitched into the side. And inside the pocket, on the palm, the leather was worn and scuffed as if permanently bruised.

headline: Hyundai Recalls Vehicles Over Power Steering Loss
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker said that the power steering could suddenly stop working in 2008-10 Elantras and 2009-10 Elantra Tourings but did not mention any related accidents or injuries.
lead_paragraph: Hyundai is recalling almost 205,000 of its Elantra cars because the power steering could suddenly stop working, making the vehicle harder to turn, according to a report from the automaker posted on Saturday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website.

headline: Before YouTube, Experimenting With Video
abstract: An exhibition at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art looks back on Videofreex, a 10-member collective that lived and worked together from 1969 to 1978 and pushed the boundaries of a new artistic medium.
lead_paragraph: Today, smartphone users take for granted that they can record what they choose and circulate the results on a host of social media platforms. Rewind half a century and the public’s ability to produce and disseminate video was nearly nonexistent. In the late 1960s, television was controlled by three commercial networks that broadcast a prescribed selection of content.

headline: The Phony Legal Attack on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: King v. Burwell, which could tear a huge hole in the Affordable Care Act, is a marvel of reverse-engineered absurdity. From March 1, 2015.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court will hear oral arguments in one of the most anticipated cases of the term: King v. Burwell, a marvel of reverse-engineered legal absurdity that, if successful, will tear a huge hole in the Affordable Care Act and eliminate health insurance for millions of lower-income Americans — exactly the opposite of what the law was passed to do.

headline: Martin O’Malley, in Veiled Jab at Hillary Clinton, Derides Politics of ‘Triangulation’

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Welfare (US)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']

headline: Attack of the Student Hairdressers
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Re-entering the workplace after 20 years, a homemaker wages an uphill battle trying to teach anatomy and physiology to students in a beauty class.
lead_paragraph: When my two eldest girls went off to college, I began to look for a part-time job. Through the grapevine, I heard of an opening for a part-time substitute teacher at a high school near home. I applied and was hired right away. What great good luck, I thought. Not only could I help pay my daughters’ tuition, but the job would be a nice transition back into the workplace after 20 years as a homemaker.

headline: Pioneering G.M. Is Eager to Mold Another Winner in Atlanta
abstract: John Hart, formerly a general manager with the Indians and the Rangers, is fired up about resuming his position in the front office and “restarting” the Braves.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — John Hart likes to use the word create. It is the essence of the job of general manager. You are shaping an organization, making sure that it stands for something. You want the impact of your leadership to last.

headline: Despite October Errors, Pitchers’ Fielding Drills Wither After Spring
abstract: For seven weeks in spring, pitchers drill hard in the field, but once the regular season starts coaches, managers and players cite many reasons for not practicing the drills so frequently.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — It is a rite of spring, as much a part of the training camp atmosphere as the palm trees in Florida and the cactuses in Arizona. It is known colloquially as P.F.P., pitchers’ fielding practice, and it takes place almost daily on the back fields of the sprawling major league complexes.

headline: Pirates Free 4 Fishermen in Somalia
abstract: The four Thais were released after being held for nearly five years, longer than any other hostages seized off the Somali coast.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Four Thai fishermen held captive by Somali pirates for nearly five years, longer than any other hostages seized off the Somali coast, have been released after intensive negotiations, according to Somali and United Nations officials.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: As Oil Prices Fall, Houston Shudders
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: America’s energy hub prays for the cost of gasoline to rise.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — LATELY — very lately — I’ve started to enjoy driving by my neighborhood Kroger again. The boldly colored curbside sign has been showing an uptick in the price of gas in the last few weeks, from $1.75 a gallon to $1.91 to $2.11. In fancier parts of town, I’ve even seen it hit $2.50.

headline: Make School a Democracy
abstract: Children will learn better. Look at rural Colombia.
lead_paragraph: ARMENIA, Colombia — IN a one-room rural schoolhouse an hour’s drive from this city in a coffee-growing region of Colombia, 30 youngsters ages 5 to 13 are engrossed in study. In most schools, students sit in rows facing the teacher, who does most of the talking. But these students are grouped at tables, each corresponding to a grade level. The hum of conversation fills the room. After tackling an assignment on their own, the students review one another’s work. If a child is struggling, the others pitch in to help.

headline: Almost Famous Feels Like This
abstract: The Oscars the other night sure seemed glamorous, didn’t they?
lead_paragraph: The Oscars the other night sure seemed glamorous, didn’t they? The gowns, the applause, the flashbulbs. Well, on Thursday night comes a reality check: a documentary on Showtime called “That Gal ... Who Was in That Thing: That Guy 2.”

headline: Rustle, Rattle And Exaggerate
abstract: The theatrical magic is in the details, and the details keep changing.
lead_paragraph: The theatrical magic is in the details, and the details keep changing. Vicky Shick’s “Pathétique, Miniatures in Detail,” which Vicky Shick Dance offers as part of the Harkness Dance Festival, is composed of vignettes showing oddities of behavior.

headline: Percussion To the Extreme
abstract: New chamber music by Augusta Read Thomas is the focus of the Miller Theater composer portrait on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: New chamber music by Augusta Read Thomas is the focus of the Miller Theater composer portrait on Thursday, but don’t expect to see much free space onstage during the New York premiere of her “Resounding Earth,” scored for a truckload of percussion instruments played by the Chicago-based Third Coast Percussion.

headline: D. W. Griffith, A New Perspective
abstract: Hollywood usually loves an anniversary, yet even in the centennial of “The Birth of a Nation,” theatrical screenings of this foundational movie that helped establish the industry are rare.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood usually loves an anniversary, yet even in the centennial of “The Birth of a Nation,” theatrical screenings of this foundational movie that helped establish the industry are rare. It’s no secret why: D. W. Griffith’s three-hour blockbuster of the Civil War and Reconstruction, while a giant leap forward for cinema, is also art in service to racist propaganda, promoting the Ku Klux Klan as defenders of the South from predatory freed blacks.

headline: Six Clarinetists In a Circle
abstract: The rigorous, even-toned Chicago clarinetist James Falzone takes the role of his instrument in the history of improvised music seriously.
lead_paragraph: The rigorous, even-toned Chicago clarinetist James Falzone takes the role of his instrument in the history of improvised music seriously — and also the practice of balancing tight composition with open improvisation, extending outward from jazz into European classical and devotional traditions. He doesn’t come to New York often, and he comes to Roulette this week with a special new group, the Renga Ensemble, playing from a careful, bracing, provocative album, “The Room Is” (Allos Documents). It’s a set of pieces written for six clarinetists in a circle, with no rhythm section; it was inspired by renga, a centuries-old Japanese form of collaborative poetry, with a protocol to weave together individual voices into a coherent whole. The musicians on the record, and in the concert on Wednesday, are high-powered improvisers: Aside from Mr. Falzone, there’s Ned Rothenberg, Ken Vandermark, Keefe Jackson, Jason Stein and Ben Goldberg. Within the design of the compositions, each will get his say. (8 p.m., 509 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, roulette.org.)

headline: The Creativity of Almost Anything
abstract: An event of brief presentations includes artists, of course, and a beekeeper and a clam digger.
lead_paragraph: An artist, a poet and a maker of sauerkraut are among the 10 East End residents scheduled to tell their stories to an audience in Watermill on March 6. Each presenter will share 20 slides on a large screen, discussing each image for about 20 seconds.

headline: Every Installation Needs a Shoe
abstract: Paul Chan first came to notice in 2004 with a brilliant, apocalypse-minded digital animation called “My Birds ...Trash ... the Future.”
lead_paragraph: Paul Chan first came to notice in 2004 with a brilliant, apocalypse-minded digital animation called “My Birds ...Trash ... the Future” that channeled Leviticus, Beckett and Goya in a response to the American war in Iraq. After Hurricane Katrina, he took free performances of Creative Time’s production of “Waiting for Godot,” using Classical Theater of Harlem performers, to devastated neighborhoods in New Orleans in 2007. Lately he has devoted his time mainly to a publishing venture and to writing. (An excellent book of his essays recently appeared.)

headline: “Mondo Cane”
abstract: Photographs capture the shadows of dogs at the park.
lead_paragraph: Photographs capture the shadows of dogs at the park.

headline: A Dog’s World, in Shadow
abstract: Silhouettes seem to capture the spirit of the dogs — an outward projection of how they see themselves, off the leash at the park.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, my parents and I started taking our family dog, a standard poodle named Tino, to the Dyker Dog Park in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. It was essentially a large, enclosed dirt space with some grass toward the back — by no means Prospect Park, but also without leash laws, so dogs could run free.

headline: After 50 Years, Oracle of Omaha Looks Back on Less Prescient Moves
abstract: Warren Buffett recalls missteps during his five decades with Berkshire Hathaway, a period that saw the company’s stock rise nearly 2 million percent.
lead_paragraph: The rise of Berkshire Hathaway is the stuff of legend, memorialized in dozens of books charting the creation of perhaps the world’s greatest conglomerate, and the rise of its patron saint, Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Targeting Inequality, This Time on Public Transit
abstract: A new project in Seattle, closely watched around the nation, gives discounts on public transit to people whose household income is no more than two times the federal poverty level.
lead_paragraph: SEATAC, Wash. — On Sunday, the county transit system for the Seattle metropolitan area began hurtling down a road that few cities have traveled before: pricing tickets based on passengers’ income.

headline: Fertile Ground for Militancy in Hometown of Jihadi John
abstract: Mohammed Emwazi, better known as Jihadi John, was part of a loose network of young Muslims known as the North London Boys that has sent dozens of young men to fight abroad.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Mohammed Emwazi went to the mosque, a short walk north from Notting Hill and its millionaire mansions, he would sometimes run into another young Muslim from the housing projects in his neighborhood in northwest London, Bilal al-Berjawi.

headline: A Dog’s World, in Shadow
abstract: Silhouettes seems to capture the spirit of the dogs, off the leash at the park.
lead_paragraph: In our latest Menagerie installment, a photographer captures dogs at the park.

headline: Tough Knick Anthony Mason Was True to the City
abstract: Mason, the N.B.A.’s Sixth Man of the Year in 1994-95, will be remembered as the brawny, funky southpaw from Queens who willed his way onto basketball’s Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mason died at 48 on a day when St. John’s beat Georgetown, a season-affirming victory of 1980s vintage. That happened to be the time when a teenage Mason was growing into his muscular body, setting out on the long and winding road to Madison Square Garden from Springfield Gardens High School in Queens.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Women Take the Mike
abstract: Female vocalists are headlining clubs throughout New Jersey during the month of March, which is Women’s History Month.
lead_paragraph: The jazz business was once known as a man’s game. That may, in some ways, still be true. But this March, as Women’s History Month unfolds, jazz clubs throughout New Jersey will come alive with groups led by women.

headline: The Tale of Lupita Nyong’o’s Stolen Oscars Dress Deepens
abstract: The gown worn by last year’s Academy Award winner for best supporting actress appears to have been recovered after a tipster’s call to TMZ.
lead_paragraph: While most of the online world spent the past few days debating the colors of a dress, another gown has become the star of its own strange story.

headline: Free Throws Haunt Rajon Rondo
abstract: The Dallas Mavericks guard has been abysmal from the free-throw line, and things appear to be getting worse.
lead_paragraph: Illustrating just how bad Rajon Rondo has been from the free-throw line this season can prove difficult. His struggle to get along with Coach Rick Carlisle after a midseason trade to the Dallas Mavericks gets most of the attention, but when a former All-Star is missing nearly 70 percent of his shots from a spot on the floor known as the charity stripe, a closer look is in order.

headline: Jazz That Spans Generations
abstract: Willie Ruff, the musician and Yale faculty member, will host the pianist Aaron Diehl at the School of Music’s Ellington Jazz Series on March 6.
lead_paragraph: Willie Ruff, the French horn player and double bassist, enjoyed a celebrated musical partnership with the pianist Dwike Mitchell that, over more than half a century, took him to stages around the world, from the segregated South to Communist China to Town Hall in Manhattan. It was a long and winding road that ended with Mr. Mitchell’s death in April 2013.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in sports.
lead_paragraph: Ballplayers Who Gladly Made Sacrifices for Their Country

headline: Detained American Missionaries Leave Venezuela
abstract: The four missionaries, who were held for three days and questioned by Venezuelan authorities, were on their way home on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Ratcheting up tensions with the United States, President Nicolás Maduro on Saturday ordered a sharp reduction in the number of diplomats at the American Embassy here, said Americans would now need visas to enter the country and took other measures to retaliate for sanctions imposed by Washington on Venezuelan officials.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Emilio Pucci Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: At the Mall, Mexican Cuisine Beyond Chipotle
abstract: This three-month-old restaurant in the Gallery at Westbury Plaza offers a delicate balance of innovative Mexican fare and the more crowd-pleasing cantina-style cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Malls are garishly commercial but a necessary suburban evil, many of us think, as we wince at the prospect of eating a “serious” meal in one. But before we swear off mall dining forever, there is Tocolo Cantina, in the Gallery at Westbury Plaza, to consider.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Emilio Pucci Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Former Star, Healthy Again, Adjusts to a Humbler Life in the Minors
abstract: Dany Heatley, a 13-year N.H.L. veteran and a former rookie of the year, is now playing in the American Hockey League, where his younger teammates idolize Heatley and he is trying to make his case for rejoining the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Mass. — Before a game on his team’s recent trip, Dany Heatley took his place in warm-ups next to players who had asked their parents to take them to see Heatley play with the Ottawa Senators almost a decade ago.

headline: Pillowy Pork Buns and Noodles to Slurp
abstract: The six varieties of ramen at Ani Ramen Noodle House in Montclair are so close to the ideal type that they lure a capacity crowd year-round.
lead_paragraph: The temperature was 8 degrees during my second visit to Ani Ramen House in Montclair, which makes you wonder why anyone would want to stand in a line outside of the restaurant for a table. On the other hand, aren’t steaming bowls of ramen exactly what you want on a freezing night?

headline: Italian, Informally
abstract: Tavern 1757 draws a crowd with a rustic atmosphere and simply made yet flavorful food.
lead_paragraph: Towering above the frozen landscape of the late winter snow pack in Seymour is Tavern 1757, a structure that evokes the grand style of the Habsburgs in its combination of stucco and stonework.

headline: Noted Anniversary
abstract: Warning: You will wind up singing along to Finn Vigeland’s Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m not sure how anyone wouldn’t have good feelings about today’s tribute puzzle to a very special film’s 50th anniversary. I know it took me back to my own childhood, back in the 18th century, when we had to wait for the annual televised showing of certain movies like “THE SOUND OF MUSIC.”

headline: Playing It Straight, Even on ‘Game Nights’
abstract: This warm and cozy two-year-old spot has a creative yet unpretentious approach to the farm-to-table trend.
lead_paragraph: The waitress leaned in to confess her secret. “To be honest, I’d never had grits before I started working here,” she said softly. “But wow, are they good.”

headline: Henry T. Segerstrom, California Developer and Arts Patron, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Segerstrom turned his family’s lima bean farm into Orange County’s cultural and commercial downtown.
lead_paragraph: Henry T. Segerstrom, a California developer and arts patron who transformed his family’s lima bean farm into Orange County’s booming cultural and commercial downtown, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Newport Beach. He was 91.

headline: Yasar Kemal, Master Turkish Novelist and Strident Political Critic, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Kemal repeatedly clashed with the Turkish state while emerging as his country’s first novelist of global stature.
lead_paragraph: Yasar Kemal, the master storyteller who repeatedly clashed with the Turkish state while emerging as his country’s first novelist of global stature, died on Saturday in Istanbul, according to Turkey’s state-run news agency, Anadolu.

headline: Ebola’s Retreat in Sierra Leone Is Interrupted
abstract: As the disease moved closer to elimination, fishermen back from a trip at sea were believed to have started a new cluster in a phase that health officials call “the bumpy road to zero.”
lead_paragraph: As the disease moved closer to elimination, fishermen back from a trip at sea were believed to have started a new cluster in a phase that health officials call “the bumpy road to zero.”

headline: Nearly Halted in Sierra Leone, Ebola Makes Comeback by Sea
abstract: Sierra Leone thought it had beaten back the disease, then two fishing boats carrying three infected mariners arrived at a wharf in February.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — It seemed as if the Ebola crisis was abating.

headline: William Thomas McKinley, Jazz-Loving Composer, Dies at 76
abstract: A hallmark of Mr. McKinley’s music was his acute sensitivity to the tonal possibilities of each instrument.
lead_paragraph: William Thomas McKinley, a prolific American composer whose music was infused with the jazz he had performed since childhood, died on Feb. 3 at his home in Reading, Mass. He was 76.

headline: Charming and Erratic, a Notorious Afghan Speaks
abstract: Shirin Gul is in the 12th year of a 20-year prison sentence for a killing spree that claimed the lives of 27 men. She says the murders were her lover’s idea.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — One of Afghanistan’s most notorious serial killers lives in a dank prison cell in Jalalabad, sharing bunk beds, meals and blankets with fellow inmates. But the guards do not carry weapons, and the prison aides spend much of their days socializing with the convicts.

headline: Ebola’s Retreat in Sierra Leone Is Interrupted
abstract: As the disease moved closer to elimination, fishermen back from a trip at sea were believed to have started a new cluster in a phase that health officials call “the bumpy road to zero.”
lead_paragraph: As the disease moved closer to elimination, fishermen back from a trip at sea were believed to have started a new cluster in a phase that health officials call “the bumpy road to zero.”
